Title: China wants to take a victory lap over its handling of the coronavirus outbreak
Generation:
['By Randall Stafford
Beijing, China — For the first time since November, China is taking a victory lap over what it describes as a “brutal” attack on the world’s largest pharmaceutical giant, GlaxoSmithKline (GSK).
GSK has been miffed about the coronavirus, first found in Thailand, as well as in the Philippines, by the Office of the High Commissioner for Public Health (OHHP), which revealed in March that it had also suspected cases of infection elsewhere in China.
During a briefing on the first discovery of Zika in China, China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi expressed the government’s opposition to GSK’s facility in Hainan, said, alleging that Wang’s removal of a green sign near its office in Hainan represents a threat to public health. “We have no right to interfere in the world’s most important health service … they should get rid of their green fluorescent lights,” Wang said, according to an NHHP spokesman.
In early April, WHO said it had begun a full investigation into the latest latest Zika case in central Asia. Officials from WHO, the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) will meet this week to discuss their work on Zika.
On Tuesday, China’s Deputy Ministry of Public Health confirmed on Twitter that the first Zika case was caught in China in February.
“The presence of ZIKA, or non- Zika virus, was detected today at a hospital in Hainan,” the ministry tweeted.
Earlier on Tuesday, China Development Bank President Chen Yuxin said China was ready to promote fast relief for infected people if people are unable to get adequate treatment and preventive measures.
“I have said repeatedly that there is no question that this virus has spread,” Chen said at a forum organized by the CPNEP-Tm-Lab County.
“Particularly in the region affected by the virus, we will strive to do everything possible to help as many people as possible and to prevent sick persons from contracting the virus in the first place.”
']

Title: China's economy could shrink for the first time in decades because of the coronavirus
Generation:
['BEIJING (CNN) — It might sound weird to describe Chinese authorities as “obsessed” with the officially paralyzed. But I’ve encountered no more intense political intrigue than that in my days in the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.
Last weekend, the beleaguered body office gave an extended memo detailing how the choking flu and respiratory infections that have taken the lives of hundreds of Chinese of migrant workers — including many infants — could be pushed back into the months ahead.
Add a suspected coronavirus that threatens humans who use vaccines from around the world, and we’re right in the middle of a tricky economic stretch.
The mess is so bad that, on top of the containment problems, the National Health and Family Planning Commission last month ordered changes to the country’s aging health system in an effort to slow the spread of infectious diseases.
And in a single weekend, the government last month banned the dumping of refrigerated milk and food products which give off mysterious shingles.
The ban stems from a contaminated ton tonnage that is used to carry Tamiflu, a substance used to protect against most forms of flu, respiratory infections and other respiratory ailments.
The ministry will appoint a chief medical officer to oversee the safety of all the food, water and medicine sold by the main earthen dams throughout the vast northeastern provinces, resulting in the first significant statewide closure of agricultural stocks over the next few days.
In addition, the government is warning China’s farmers to stay away from milk powder and flour that are being sold at a premium but contaminated with choline virus.
“The levy is already inadequate for safety,” said Mr. Li Wanxiang, the official at the ministry, who is the main symptom of the worst pandemic in China’s modern history, saying the order, which he did not name, will cost farmers of at least 200 billion yuan ($21.4 billion) — three times the annual bill for the country’s annual public hospital costs.
Ms. Wang Hongjie, director of China Academy of Social Sciences, warned that complications that could flare up before a mid-stage coronavirus and the highly contagious respiratory infection that would cause “major hospitalization.”
“It is clear that the current outbreak must be addressed and we must reduce pressure on the public health system,” she said in a statement.
After a bad but mild flu epidemic spread to roughly 26 million people in 2009, health authorities eventually settled on the carnavirus, which has infected more than 2 million people in China in the past three years.
Ten years later, China’s spread has not been confined to the same patients.
Earlier this year, the fact that China’s birth rate is lower than South Korea indicates that it could become even more difficult for people to get sick due to this side-effects.
If the infection continues to spread, “it means that the virus could be in even greater danger of spreading to South Korea,” Guo Ping, an infectious disease expert at the Chengdu Institute of Medical Research, told CNN.
We’re far from seeing the end of China’s deadly illness anytime soon. But if it seems like there are no major health problems this time around, it is — at least, short of monumental disasters like the 2010 Beijing Olympics pandemic.
And the Chinese people have invested far more in catching the first flu than they have in any other illness.
Indeed, 14 million people have been diagnosed with early stages of the illness in China since 2008. But the numbers are also increasing. At least five people are reported to have died as a result of illness, including last Friday.
Until last week, this outbreak is easily treated by viral medicine, and medics in isolated cases are on the hunt for treatment options that are fatal in the short term.
In addition, the relatives of victims who died are often ill from influenza in later stages of the disease, such as miscarriage or stillbirth. That’s not bad. But the families of those who died are still waiting to see whether they’ll recover.
And is it any wonder that the most stressful part of my day is talking to the visiting traffic police out on the road? I can even hear the driver say, “We have her. We will notify her.”
']

Title: China and Japan's budding relationship in the time of coronavirus
Generation:

"Under international pressure, we need to work with both other countries to fight the world's strong vulnerability in an emergency," said Beijing's president, Wang Yucheng, during a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in Tokyo on Tuesday.
Wang said the two countries will "always pay attention to the present situation," and the multi-level cooperation would come together amid concerns of a flu pandemic triggered by a massive outbreak of flu virus that Beijing says is moving into Japan.
"New viruses are emerging to lower our air pollution, quell strong and induced diseases in the country, and we must collaborate with the Tokyo government to address the immediate threat of pandemic flu," Wang told Abe.

Title: Coronavirus is fast becoming an 'economic pandemic'
Generation:
['Three years ago, around the same time studies on U.S. environmental and health claims indicating the disease was spreading all over the globe were launched, the country concerned was buzzing.
The worst news was from the United States: 63 people died in 20 of the 50 countries tracked. A single but unrelated international outbreak in the Pacific Islands struck in early 2012, bringing the world's population in that area to 19.5 million people.
But reports of global health-virus outbreaks across the globe, from Britain to Haiti to Singapore, are starting to emerge anew and again as cases of acolytes dig deep into the form and symptoms and seek answers.
Globally, the number of people infected by something like the virus has climbed to 18,151, according to World Health Organization data. In the last eight months alone, some 1,132 cases of the disease have been diagnosed in countries around the world, not the least of which is Canada and Switzerland.
"This virus is making a lot of progress," says Norman Butler, a physician who has been chief health officer at the University of Alberta in Edmonton since 1997. "It's very hard to guard your data from all sides, but where we are probably focused is on outbreaks. It can go away quickly."
The Canadian government began an official observation count in March to determine whether there was an outbreak of virus activity and look for diseases that could be linked to it. That was backed up by a U.S. Health Department report last year that said Canadian virus outbreaks were growing on average daily, up from 523 in 2007 to 524 in 2015.
So where is the country with the largest number of cases of the disease (14,677)? Not only is it the greatest health-village in the world, but there's also a tremendous appetite for talking about it. In 2003, then-premier of Canada Bill Blair lambasted a "name-brand" study by National Institute of Health researchers that it linked Canadian circulatory system issues to the virus, and a literature review revealed doctors could be relying on a cheaper and safer method to spot problems, if their symptoms do not show up soon.
These types of outbreaks, experts say, offer opportunity to take a hard look at the whole picture: Health experts can offer first aid and other tests and treatments to their patients and physicians to help diagnose conditions.
And if the main concern is making sure the symptoms are not taken seriously, health-company professionals can help evaluate the causes before a disease is found, Butler says.
While virus transmission can be severe enough to cause severe pain, illness and death, people can become infected by mosquitoes carrying the virus or in infected people who carry it.
And humans, particularly, don't respond well to it. Smelly bugs require antibiotics to kill them. And to avoid infection, people should wear gloves. Some germs should not infect anyone. The suspected strain of the virus is very hard to detect: Like the toxin paralytic there is in some medical viruses, it can cause severe inflammation.
The predominant cause of the disease is transmission of "coronavirus" to people in Asia and Australia that causes fever, diarrhea, white blood cells, spot attacks, osteoporosis and death. In some of these countries, the virus is infectious because it is transmitted among individuals. It is also highly contagious among live piglets.
On the flip side, the reason why individuals are sick is out of respect for people who do not want to be infected. "If people are not taken seriously it means they don't care and need to get tested," says Butler.
Given that the risk is too high for those people, Butler says he prefers taking the virus directly to the source. The recovery from outbreak patients requires some time and a willingness to listen and ask questions, he says.
"For individual cases I really like to go the steps of a responsible commercial health authority and ask them, 'How can we be the first to do this right?' " he says. "In the United States I don't really believe that this is something that we could easily do."
']

Title: A history of Wuhan, one-time Chinese capital and coronavirus epicenter
Generation:
['Wuhan city is set to experience a large-scale re-birth in its gastronomic history after a very long human migration through its rutted mountainous region during the 17th and 18th centuries.
In an early-to-middle-20th century movie, Jia Baie, a Chinese monk accused of harboring a handful of coffees, was gunned down in the middle of a village complex by a mob for threatening to shoot monks. The family moved to a high-profile monument in Wuhan.
Many outsiders say this is part of a relic from a period when the city suffered bloody discontent and signs of modernization.
Many museums are closed, and festivals are wonky — now fun, but too much—in areas where the famous international hangouts can feel too ancient to cut these craftsmen down.
Making the re-birth
To modernize and develop the capital itself, Wuhan has been working to create a million-square-foot long-sea reconstruction center for local people. One of its tasks is to deface some of its rural neighborhoods with renovated mounds of eru with tak-e-ho limestone, bamboo homes and old and rotting old pagodas.
If you see Wuhan, look to Katter’s People’s Party district, which locals say is the region’s last intact religious center. Both Katter’s and district house the Katter Shilokum temple, one of the three a traditional pre-Christian church: The area was occupied by ancient remnants from Emperor Ludwig at the beginning of the 17th century.
Some of the most important resting places are buried deep in the fields, including the hilltop Tomb of Silang and the Tomb of Dios Jose. In this past fall, architect Robert Wagner left the city after much of the destruction of the temples and buildings, and the light has been slowly extinguished on past rains.
But Wagner appears to have shaken off the \x93uncle” reputation and people living in these neighborhoods often report being greeted or noticed by strangers.
A stop at the 12th Floor Hotel
Up until the 19th century, Wuhan was governed by a Ku Klux Klan, and the school system was not regulated by the Ku Klux Klan. Organized by the Kumbava minority group (today sowed fertile soil in the birthplace of Myanmar), Jews and Poles started to cross to join the Traditional Chinese Way of worship, which sought to demean and kill spiritual people by bringing them here.
In 1895, the Ku Klux Klan at the end of the period created a second Ku Klux Klan in Korea, which later pushed those to commit murder as much as the 20th century.
By the early 1900s, the kwak monks in Wuhan used to terrorize foreigners, living in an even more brutalized atmosphere — trapped in the drinking trough and literally a basement for begging.
Wuhan started to enjoy rapid modernization — including a massive reconstruction of the city itself — in the early 1920s, and its story started and then continued a long time later.
Many monuments in Wuhan today have been rehabilitated, and will soon join a different story: they’re modern and accommodating.
On Wednesday (April 5), the new Wuhan architological center will open its doors to the public to create a new kind of monument to the glory days of the city.
It will be located directly in the temple complex, said Wagner, the head of the cultural heritage institute. “An average person will have maybe twenty years of history, maybe two generations,” Wagner said. “And with the renovation we’re going to preserve it.”
Until now, the old temple buildings and monuments and roads have been neglected and had been built in neat rows. That must change, or the sacred building, a memorial on the hill side, will be converted into a museum with more than 300 artifacts — including ancient structures, tombs and temples.
It will be open from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily.
Follow William Gold on Twitter @TimesReview.
']

Title: Global stocks pull back from the edge after historic sell-off
Generation:
["NEW YORK (CNNMoney) — Global stock markets were close to a four-month peak for the first time in two months on Thursday after the flash crash of the previous day sent global equity markets heading toward a steep decline.
After plunging, Asian shares pared losses and Europe's benchmark indices recorded a brief rally, again, on the back of hopes of greater global growth.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average posted a massive 27.5-point decline Wednesday as investors sold everything from Japan to Greece. The Dow plunged 236 points in the first hour of trade, marking its biggest one-day drop since December. It was also the largest one-day drop since March 13, 2010.
In Europe, France's benchmark Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena slipped 0.7% to 10.10 euros. Trading in Italy's biggest lender, UniCredit, was little changed at 10.35 euros after its shares slid about 1.6% to 11.69 euros.
By midafternoon, the dollar had fallen to a 19-month low against the euro, extending this week's rout. European shares lost 0.1%, the Bloomberg Barclays Bank Emerging Markets index .BKX was unchanged and Germany's DAX index .GDAXI was down 0.3%.
Asia lost further to head into European and U.S. day, giving up some of the gains early in the day and then slightly recovering in late morning trading. Asia’s main stock indexes also dropped as commodity-related currencies fell, giving up all of those gains.
Earlier in the day, the dollar traded in a narrow, one-way range as traders looked ahead to next week’s meeting of the Group of 20 industrialized nations, scheduled for July 16-17 in Australia.
The current week of U.S. economic data has been negative on the economy, raising worries that the Fed will slow its pace of growth and this is causing investors to focus on Fed policy, which is to start tapering its massive bond purchases by the end of this year.
U.S. stocks jumped after Trump and German Chancellor Angela Merkel met in Paris on Thursday. This move had the reverse effect of hitting global stock markets as well.
An hour after Trump and Merkel met, German stocks sank as investors raced to lock in profits ahead of a weekend dinner in New York, the first time a U.S. president has met a joint session of the U.S. Congress since 1986.
On Tuesday, a Reuters poll showed only 33% of American adults are confident in the economy right now, down from 44% on March 13, while 40% think the Trump administration will do a good job on jobs.
Comments from Merkel and Trump amid a contentious meeting earlier this week were seen reflecting the worries she felt about the relationship with Trump.
"]

Title: The 30 most troubling lines from Donald Trump's latest news conference on coronavirus

['By Brian Stelter
WASHINGTON - We are struck by how insensitively these remarks could be perceived. Many, perhaps most of us are used to ignoring news stories that advance their agenda while they serve to send the country further backwards.
We haven't yet seen what they say. If we did, we'd be presumptuous of the willingness to include them in our stories.
But the Trump administration is beginning to wear its leaders as we mortals. The president announced plans Tuesday to declare a state of emergency as the mosquito-borne coronavirus spreads to humans, a decision the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention also announced.
It's unlikely this declaration will delay or reverse efforts to prevent the spread of the viral disease, which causes severe diarrhea, muscle and liver problems that can result in dehydration and death, but has long been associated with diarrhea and dehydration, according to a report on CNN earlier Tuesday by Dr. Peter Debruge, director of the CDC's Division of Allergy and Infectious Diseases.
"We are not perfect but if we allow the general public to get their hands dirty with this virus, it's a prudent decision that we will not have the burden of doing the same thing again," said Debruge, who was not immediately available for comment.
While he's determined to send a clear message to Americans that health care needs to be tailored to local conditions, sometimes difficult to understand. At first, he focused on what he considers "ordinary" someone with a family member or loved one who has been in the hospital and whose only known illnesses have been diarrhea. Later, he reinforced his perspective.

Wirke examined 118 of the six 737 Max series planes that originated in China, before the Boeing 787 made its debut in China in December 2011, relying on noise surveys to determine its effects on the airframe, climate, engines and manufacturing of the plane.

Wirke said the FAA wouldn’t risk changing the software that prompts an airliner to refuel, saying that such software complies with safety and security rules.

In the latest report, he and co-author Paul McCoy produced experiments that are “further necessary to ascertain what caused the catastrophic failure” of the Boeing 787 Dreamliner, and are still “fantastic” in their assessment of their findings, he said.

Title: Christmas in Hong Kong marked by demonstrations and tear gas
Generation:
['The official opening of the city’s annual holiday season, Christmas in Hong Kong, took place early Thursday and will last until mid-May.
The festivities will be attended by the city’s government, traditionally popular with hundreds of thousands of families and retirees who send their children away to play and shop in Hong Kong.
With more than 450,000 visitors expected in 2014, Hong Kong was the fifth-largest region in the world outside of Japan.
Hundreds of soldiers and policemen were deployed in the area near the intersection of Race Road and the Central business district, and clashes broke out between protesters and police.
“There’s been a lot of damage done but Hong Kong is a safe place,” an onlooker, who asked not to be named, told CNN.
“We haven’t heard any public opposition to the parade. People are getting used to it, but there’s another side to that. We’ve done our best to move this out of the shadow of the huge Memorial Day holiday.”
Demonstrators returned to the opposition strongholds from the Hong Kong Broadcasting Corporation and Resorts World for the official opening ceremony. They also gathered for a symbolic protest led by one of the head of the group Human Rights Watch.
“There will no move this year to show opposition to the parade or to celebrate the 53rd anniversary of the birth of Hong Kong,” Wang Yi, a leading politician in one of China’s most populous cities, said in a statement.
Thousands of police, firefighters and government representatives are expected to be called in to tackle the crowds and sit at City Hall in the morning.
Hong Kong is scheduled to celebrate its 70th anniversary in May with a big party.
']

University of Maryland medical school communications coordinator Catherine Roske told CNN that she was "waiting for our heart rate monitor to be positive" at a meeting of the college's fire department on Wednesday morning. She added that she thinks it's just a matter of time before students return to campus and that it will be the most hazardous situation they've ever seen.
"It's going to take months, perhaps even years, to get to that point," she said.
Given that it's a winter that is usually fairly dry, it's even more unusual for so many people to reach university.
As of Thursday morning, 44 people had died from the colds, the CDC said.

Title: What the US can learn from Singapore's coronavirus strategy
Generation:
['By Elaine Lies and Louisa Catlett
SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (CNN) — Silicon Valley investors and leaders now think so hard about Singapore's coronavirus strategy.
Singapore is the fourth-largest country in the world for swine flu. It is also the first to have both an internationally used antiviral (H3N2) vaccine and a vaccine that is only effective against rabies. So what can the United States learn from Singapore's policy?
Here are three things we can learn about the importance of coronavirus research:
Cradivalis: "Cradivalis," based on the genes LMLs (meaning genetic variation) have in H3N2, is one of the few broad and widely used vaccine that we can enjoy. If you use LMLs, you won't have a lot of protection against the spread of influenza. It's difficult to accurately isolate genes in a vaccine. For example, virus can pass on an antibody that is infected by two viruses, flu and now pandemic influenza, and which scientists say is a potential source of this deadly strain of flu.
TARGETING REMARKS: Researchers and clinicians in Singapore use radio frequencies to transmit germs and models that target them. When patients are in the unit of care they are expected to take an antigen of high availability or intense resistance, which means they will encounter less resistance than if they were on the same unit of care for an extremely common virus. That's what's happened to some models that catch H3N2 infections in laboratories. In the meantime, patients who are resistant to pre-emptive radiosarcom (known as phase 1/2 mutations) will not have an antiviral against pandemic influenza. If you go to a hospital and double your defibrillator when the virus is on the other side, you might be infected.
GASTRISES: A similar approach has taken place in other countries, but this is a new opportunity for the United States to use it in Singapore. The primary reason for this is that people are more likely to talk with their doctors about vaccines, so the doctors' questions have less scientific value. Singapore uses five different types of microphones to listen to patients' talking heads. The microphones have different listening patterns, so if the respiratory therapist is listening to a patient, they're more likely to hear what they're saying.
According to a government fact sheet, up to 18 million people in Singapore have exposure to influenza during their lifetime and therefore exposures to influenza can reach the critical threshold that has already reached. Scientists believe that vaccine-effectively controlled infection rates should be recommended for childhood children. "We believe it's simply too late for people to get infected," the document read.
Cradivalis: "Cradivalis is the right vaccine to prevent flu," the statement said. We don't like talk from a family doctor to infants, but it doesn't seem too tough to get vaccinated by a family doctor. It also doesn't appear to protect young infants.
TOESULT: Through different collection methods from different risk factors, it looks like it's likely to work. The virus also gets stronger, and children who meet three different risk factors are more likely to develop the flu. "When people start having symptoms, they don't talk to the person who's sick," said Dr. Andras Weiss, chief executive of Every Day I Bite is Blood and Soil research firm.
CAZIES: A section of China's anti-flu strategy recommends the use of a filtering vaccine such as a Cnerbac with modified viruses. Cnerbac is an antigens vaccine, according to a recent report in the Macomb Daily. It's protective against six diseases. Every Day I Bite, the antiviral in the acronym, recommends hearing German speakers talk about the flu virus.
SERCIPHRANS: Singapore is one of only two countries that have ever manufactured a humane work-around-vaccine. The import-export exemption, or SCOVIR), lets doctors hire community veterinarians to test the flu virus and eliminate cases within 48 hours. Small islands and faraway parts of the world have limited test results, but this exemption has been seen in the United States, Sweden, Turkey and France.
']

Title: The disease expert who warned us
Generation:
['By Katie Wortman
CNN Consumer Reports
You should never throw your skin off the leash when opening a door because it could cause deadly complications.
But most people also have to pretend they don’t handle their illness: they feel horrible when they’re not sick and not told how to treat it. These day-to-day complications can also prevent you from making important decisions about what to do for yourself.
Now, oncologist Dr. Jennifer Hare of Bristol (RCA) has had a goal.
“I taught myself the ins and outs of the road – why do I make the decision to stop? What are the chances that I could run out of it?” explains Hare, a cardiologist at Fordham University Medical Center in New York City.
Hare has been suffering from a chronic inflammatory bowel disease for more than two decades. Within months, she started feeling fatigued and dizzy. Now, she says, her intestines feel like a liquid sponge – and she takes her medications to make her feel better.
“It took me a whole year to forget to administer my medicine,” she says. “If someone showed me a cardiologist, I’d tell them I had a death in my family. And you know what? They didn’t.”
So, in 2013, the doctor asked Hare, “Are you trying to slow down?”
“We all do that,” says Hare. “But as the years went on, I was terrified.”
Hare was horrified to learn she had been in the hospital one week and was soon on antibiotics. Now, she’s enrolled in the MCLA program to determine if she should be on a waiting list for the first phase of the cancer vaccine.
“If I’m new to medicine, how can I expect to improve my immune system?” she asks, breaking into small bites from a vial of water that hangs from the ceiling.
And it’s not just those who might be suffering that need a first look.
“I ask patients at the highest risk, especially among the disabled, if they don’t have a cataract – another reason that every doctor wants to give them a second chance at vaccination,” says Dr. Tom Dornier, director of MCLA and author of “A Better, more affordable, preventive health shot program”
Dr. Matthew A. McQuaid, MCLA’s director of Community Based Therapeutics (CI), has been the first to advise women about vaccines.
The CI program works by prescribing pain medications to women and women who may be taking anti-inflammatories – those who’ve suffered from painful side effects such as weak stomach muscles or tendons – to prevent back pain. There are medications available to make sure women get a well-rounded vaccine through CI and cervical shot.
These are the first women’s shots that patients received from CI and given before their bodies started rejecting their anti-inflammatories, results in high-focal-nanolytic antibodies. If they don’t react, patients have a flu-like effect, resulting in serious side effects.
In determining what shots are best, health experts advise that women in their range of 85-90 days after they’ve been on anti-inflammatories face five weeks of best-case-before-they-disease prevention, with a red flag warning that they may have post-inhibitor side effects.
“If they don’t adhere to their initial dose of antibiotics, they may feel better and maybe go home and take a shower,” says Dr. Johnson. “I urge women to talk with their physicians and if they have persistent side effects – it could be very dangerous to take these medications, which are highly recommended.”
If you or someone you know needs a shot, or someone you know has been diagnosed with illness, get tested or can show up at the CI clinic. Call 800-225-3146 or visit specialist health programs at NMDC here.
']

Title: Angelina Jolie: What we must do for Afghan women
Generation:
['(CNN) — The advance of America and its alliance with China will slow and the process of progress toward a safe and stable Afghanistan will suffer.
“That’s the nature of the beast,” said Malala Yousafzai, 10. “We must not let it deplete our potential as women.”
Malala and her mother, Muhammad Yousafzai, the third Taliban leader to be killed since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, are in recent days bearing witness to the heroic effort by the United States and Afghanistan to make a difference for their oppressed brethren in the world’s poorest country.
While government officials and the public of Afghanistan have encouraged violence against women, many foreign troops have been harshly criticized for sending in female support soldiers and for sometimes killing them. Many girls and women sit at remote tribal camps in neighboring Pakistan, where powerful tribes from neighboring Pakistan have allied with al Qaeda.
“The insurgent women are completely separate, they don’t have anything to hide,” said Yousafzai. “They can act independently but don’t have the capacity to be taken from their families or fathers.”
In a message to her sisters, Yousafzai urged girls, even women, to prove their worth to protect one another: stand firm. She said she first learned about the use of extremism when she was in school. She said at one school rally when she was not permitted to speak she saw one of her classmates crying on the other side of the table.
“We don’t know why this was happening. It’s not our fault, it’s not their fault,” she said. “We must be responsible to one another.”
Malala spoke directly to the Taliban: that is to say, their influence is not limited to their online presence and popularity. A weekend of violence in Kabul and Swat this week took the lives of 18 people and wounded three, all men. Her protests, however, were outside Afghanistan’s limits.
“A thousand these people must die in suicide attacks by suicide,” Yousafzai’s voice added. “How many people’s lives can we afford to put down to suicide attacks and renege on?”
She said the Afghan army would be the last word, but the trend it had to learn to counter, will ultimately be their undoing.
“Futility of a nation is very, very important,” she said. “This country is invincible, it is the castle of the world, which, for a lot of people, is very important.”
Since 2009, more than 8,000 Afghan women have been killed by extremists, according to Chaldean authorities.
Yousafzai recalled, as of late December, that she had gotten some help from girls. Her mother is fed from a small, hand-delivered canned fish. She said that she was concerned that “money will get lost” because of the violence.
“We have been told we will get ahold of a donor like this,” Yousafzai said. “The fund, if it’s released, will send the money. But I don’t know how long.”
She said: “There’s a huge hunger for humanitarian work. …
“What if we don’t have a job? It will not take a single day,” she said. “We will be millionaires and become the landlords of many more.”
To keep others out of the violence, Yousafzai said, she hoped that girls would encourage their young children to play by different rules.
She said her mother supports the Taliban, telling a meeting of international women’s groups that “war is a war. It is not over for everyone. But it should not be over for children.”
“No child is spared,” she added. “You will be doing something better, whatever your life’s worth.”
Yousafzai advocates for Afghan women.
“It’s our basic right to raise our children with dignity,” she said. “And it’s our responsibility to take care of the children when they are in danger.”
']

Title: 'A Quiet Place II' release delayed by coronavirus
Generation:
['(CNN) — "A Quiet Place II" was delayed by the coronavirus, it was revealed Monday, less than three weeks after its U.S. box office debut.
The delay was driven by rising chills for the American movie whose makers said the virus had taken over the system that controls production.
The update to the film, created by the tech industry is "certainly not covered by the virus" affecting any of the film's actors, producers said. And it was not revealed to be the cause of the delay.
Viruses can cause fatal lung infections, flesh-eating diseases and even mysterious cancers, according to the World Health Organization. These types of viruses don't appear to be directed by an individual. They are dormant in the body, making it harder to predict exactly when they will cause harm.
The virus that insiders say brought the ICP in this film's production has now infected nearly 10,000 people, affecting over half a million who have taken care of it, according to a preliminary investigation.
"We are unaware of any deaths, but unfortunately there is no hospital treatment," Scranton, Pennsylvania-based Universal Pictures said in a statement.
The delay comes nearly five years after the ICP was discovered in living mice, the rare mutation that is the hallmark of an isolated coronavirus of the same name.
Multiple Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) officials released the official report explaining how a coronavirus that appeared in mouse colonies on television in 2014 had spread to infect at least 150 countries. A team of 68 CDC officials was also involved in the research.
The CDC officials said an investigation revealed that coronavirus testing in humans is well enough advanced to know it wasn't just the mouse's immune system that created the virus.
CNN reached out to the makers for comment but was not immediately able to reach a representative, Daren Tsui, the acting director of the CDC. He told CNET in an email that the company continues to investigate the investigation into the incident and many others that followed.
"We are working closely with our laboratory partners to identify the cause and patient histories and other relevant local and national information from a timely test procedure so we can determine the cause and effect of this recent viral outbreak," he wrote.
']

Title: Pete Davidson doesn't exactly stretch much in 'Big Time Adolescence'
Generation:
['For those of you without a smartphone, surfing the net, binge-watching your favorite shows or chatting to up your friends, you’re in luck: you have a virtual Jack Russell Terrier named Donny in the movie Big Time Adolescence.
Seriously, for non-prime-time comers, it seems like Donny is kind of the sure-fire poster child for the internet’s shtick of juvenile, slapstick, borderline offensive jokes.
Sure, his interactions with the people he meets (who, I know, are similar to us, but their appeal is much more specific) are essentially non-existent in “Trolls” and “Potterheads,” but the character is actually comedic and stunningly human.
Perhaps he and Ray Bradbury would have created a nicer reputation for Donny in the 1980s than himself and Jake Gyllenhaal, the actor known for a vocal singing voice in “Baby Love.” Donny seems to be a lovable type, not spiteful.
Sound familiar? While talking to one of the two characters, Daniel Dae Kim, Donny is able to articulate that his aim is for Ray Bradbury’s “Do the Right Thing” and put so much effort into it that he looks and acts like none other than three giant puppet ears with the occasional you-know-what at their mercy.
Donny would easily be the best of the family in “Trolls,” and its precise opening scene about a pair of human kids playing carnival sports is kind of gross.
Smashing down candles
Donny is not a person, unlike most puppet/monster characters, that is actually scary. The juxtaposition with “Big Time Adolescence” sends a perfectly justified sense of dread and guilt: death, I know, but are you just like me when I wake up tomorrow and find a pool of scary twins hovering around my head?
Donny doesn’t seem to have inherited the nastiness of the “Trolls” character. These adorable kids are cruelly being yanked by Donny’s late mother, and it’s become a point of tension not only with Donny but with everyone around them.
Even Donny’s father Paul likes him.
The fact that Donny is much more aware of the fact that Benji [his onscreen dad], who is stuck with the only thing that will help him out from the insanity is pinching us, is not enough to make the “Trolls” character any less awful.
Donny is not just looking to fit in. He wants to live his life to the fullest, and as such, it’s quite scary that Donny might morph into a bear.
Really, there’s nothing really like a “Trolls” character in movies that need to grow into their nuanced, realistic selves. The colors and the songs make the character all the more complicated.
In “Trolls,” the slight, indispensable addition is that Donny recognizes our loneliness, and he doesn’t just accept it as part of life, but even among the other humans. And while we’re at it, Donny fills Donny with a poignancy about his vulnerability.
Donny’s relationship with Ray Bradbury
I know they got to do a superb job of capturing the fact that a person with a digitally homogenized face has tremendous power, but maybe Donny can help amp up the illusion.
As does his father Paul, who is supposed to be Donny’s way of expressing his feelings.
With this monologue put together, Donny and Ray try to cope with the reality that we feel as though we really only have one identity: we feel way too much.
Just don’t go to the movies with us.
']

Title: Gloria Gaynor fights coronavirus by taking her hit song 'I Will Survive' to the sink
Generation:
['In the halls of the High Desert Nevada Camps, friends say they've never had to deal with a respiratory illness like Merle Haggard's recent, life-threatening staph infection.
"Haggard had a respiratory virus that left pneumonia and was all over the place," said Aaron Kovinsky, 10, a senior at Mad Dog Spring Farm in Logan, Nevada. "It's too late because he's going to be gone for good next month. MHS is a good place to come in and bond."
Both have experienced shock reactions to an infection that infects anyone - in other words, anyone with a common cough.
(CNN's Maria H. Flores and Ken Sillmer contributed to this report.
Tuesday morning, 39-year-old Rachel Bivins was coughing up blood in the Carbon State Fire District in Rancho Mirage, California when her mother said she heard a big explosion and asked her mother, "who is this?"
The message did not go over well with Bivins, whose mother left her with severe vomiting and diarrhea and was "very tired." She spent an hour crying at home, then awoke to others moving in her father's vehicle.
"She kept turning and coming back, but had no room for anything to breathe. I was really impressed," Bivins' grandmother, Saralita Tagovic, said in a telephone interview.
When her daughter became sick Tuesday morning, she wailed to an acquaintance to call him, but this did not stop her from continuing her talk.
"I didn't want to believe it, but then she started coughing up blood," Tagovic said. "I told her, 'Rachel, that is going to be awful.' "
Tagovic, who remains hospitalized, was surprised by her phone call.
"You are so vulnerable," Tagovic said. "It's really scary - I'm surprised that no one was calling to ask questions about this. I never really asked about it."
The temperatures couldn't have been cooler.
By 6 a.m., those who were cooling off were having their tongues ripped out by a foul odor.
The district posted signs including one that read, "Are there any ways to please an animal?"
Tagovic's father is in the burn lot to see if there is enough room.
"Even though I expect he's going to cry, no one cares about that," Tagovic said. "That's the only message I'm getting from the desert."
ABC's Candy Spelling, a children's talk show host in her home state of Florida, had nothing but good things to say about her newborn.
"You look very, very pregnant," Spelling said to a friend who, just days before giving birth, took her on her short walk through the desert. "Nobody cares about you. People do care about you."
Asked if Merle Haggard deserves to be hailed for making her age young all the more redeemable, Spelling said: "I don't think he deserves to be hailed for everything, but everybody knows what he's gotten up to."
Haggard served time in prison for a 1996 drug sale and as a former stunt double for Guns N' Roses guitarist Slash. He died in 2009, aged 45.
Like the rest of the country, The Hershey's Food Festival in Rancho Mirage was once the target of animal cruelty and drug abuse in 1983, according to USA Today.
By Stephanie Pigram
CNN
']

Title: Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson: What we know
Generation:
['Remember the movie thriller All the President’s Men? HBO’s The Leftovers?! HBO’s fresh new crime drama? Here are some of the things we’ve learned about the cast of “The Leftovers.”
Director Justin Theroux told Deadline he wanted to “take the idea of a new take” and “pull what was already established with a ton of timelines in the game.” If you’re unfamiliar with the show, it centers on a couple of New York City cop-swapping hacks who must change the definition of what constitutes “a good cop” in a shrinking world — and yet it feels like there’s something to be said for cops: love an imperfect hero, let’s face it, like Cleopatra on ice. We did get to see, by the end of the first season, one of the most beautifully talented, resonant actors working today.
A new online ad for the show debuted Wednesday. It’s called “Artist Led and Powerful” and has 10,000 words in it: “Here’s a picture of us together at the end of ‘The Leftovers’ and it speaks to our real, powerful, powerful selves.”
The show’s slogan: “There is no love among us.”
It says something about us as artists: We’re captured, violated, with no love for us. That is disturbing, because that’s not the message that “The Leftovers” feels meant to convey. The hope is that we’ll change as we move forward. At this point in our lives, just getting to stop and think about what it was like to get to the bottom of the story is pretty important.
The show leaves us on a different trajectory than we are currently giving ourselves. We’re constantly imagining this big story, like that unfolding on its own in a massive puzzle. For us, everything in this season is a piece of cake. The answer to our question is from the outside.
HBO learned “the world loves us first” in the games of knocking down the Oculus. Here’s what that meant: Whoa!
A “safe space”
It would be easy to get pushed away from the “safe zone” in “The Leftovers” on a strictly practical basis. Something about being in “Moby Dick” is, in all at once, a seismic tectonic shift. We’re moving from understanding George Clooney, to being able to imagine Clooney inside a vacuum instead of eating it, imagining this. Anything. Everything.
It would not be true for us on the show, yet. As we sit there hoping it won’t happen, fearing the worst of the worst and all along being surrounded by people, maybe even assuming we’re unhinged on the phone, experiencing the worst that’s out there while the other people still want to talk to us. If there’s hope for these characters, it’s certainly there. Because this is us.
We are not just captives in this saga.
For us, where we are in this story, we are also what it is that we are. We aren’t based on or about the general populace. We are modeled on hundreds of million of people, living their lives in their own horror stories, and figuring out how to realize that before we become whatever we are now. Whatever we are. That’s why it took so long for a show like “The Leftovers” to hit its breaking point.
']

Title: Kate Beckinsale posts powerful response to Harvey Weinstein's prison sentence
Generation:
['By Alison Williams
(CNN) — A scathing letter published online Thursday shows Kate Beckinsale getting resolute on the court's sentencing of former Weinstein producer Harvey Weinstein.
"The personal consequences of their heinous conduct will not be calculated, nor will their ability to eliminate them," the director wrote in a tearful, lengthy letter to U.S. District Judge Alice Wells.
Beckinsale, who famously played Alice Cooper in the 1980s Broadway musical "Midnight Memories," said in a statement from her lawyers, "I am grateful for those who made these senseless decisions and by extension my family — my colleague, my parents, sisters, brothers, my brother, my wife, and my current and unborn-child. These suffering people deserve better. We deserve better."
There were other tweets Tuesday that included a photo of the actress asking the judge to "open up his public bench to the world and every person who feels it's necessary for people to come forward."
There also were damning remarks about Weinstein from a former colleague at the studio that were deleted after he became the next director on the film.
"He could be doing this, in the best interests of me," Ridley Scott's black-and-white sports film "Alien" was shown to audiences at the time of its release.
An open court is a rarity in Hollywood, where there's a general public sense of expectancy at what could go wrong. But in this case, much of the publicity was largely about acknowledging the gravity of the crimes Weinstein has faced and the challenges they face in their profession.
The actress added, "I was shocked and betrayed by some of the decisions the judge made to discipline the individuals he held responsible for the crime."
In the letter, Beckinsale recounted the years she spent in a "secret holding pen" with Weinstein, at the Temple of Bess in New York, where they met for the first time at the afterparty preceding the movie's release in 2005.
She recounted how Weinstein started dropping her off at the establishment when they were both still teenagers.
"You and I had never really crossed paths in any way," she said. "It was mostly a verbal exchange between us. I suppose that part of the process you had to re-enter the agency."
Beckinsale took aim at Weinstein's "marvellous" film career, saying he produced "dark and deranged films like "The Departed," "Disgrace," "The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel," "The Hateful Eight," "Lincoln," "Lincoln" and "The Ides of March."
"I feel for those women who have been sexually assaulted and for those women who were not specifically targeted, because I believe their fates were intertwined," she said.
Beckinsale wrote that he "dropped his shoes … at the heels of my own shoes and walked through the gate at the crack of dawn and into the evening and said, 'Enough.' I pulled out my, skinny blouse and jeans and I sat there. Well, maybe because I didn't know."
"I don't want you guys to think me looking back at this is my fault or if I was doing what you were doing, but it was. I don't care, I loved it. It was a dream."
On Wednesday, Weinstein spoke to CNN's "Erin Burnett OutFront" outside the courtroom.
"We were talking about the charges that I pled guilty to, I'm sorry, we were discussing an investigation," Weinstein said, who, like Beckinsale, also received "treatment" for his behavior.
"We spoke about the case. I was very much on board with this conversation, and I did try to think of something to do with this. I wanted to do everything in my power to make this conversation good."
Beckinsale did not take the opportunity to comment.
But on Tuesday, Weinstein said the seriousness of his crimes is a goal he's trying to uphold.
"If I put it best, we still have to live together and if I live together with these three women, they can still come forward, at least for me — this is my thing."
"We want it to be the open court and all of us can have a conversation," he said. "And it's my place and the place to do that. I don't think it's right for the public. I think it's the right thing to do."
']

SAN FRANCISCO (CNN) — Jerry Seinfeld announced Monday that he will not perform in New York City in May at a reception hosted by New York Fashion Week organizers.
“My intention was never to perform in New York in May,” Seinfeld said in a statement released Monday. “Still, I did want to engage with New York fashion, and, I hope, address the differences between New York and Los Angeles that are so prevalent. From May 4-11, Seinfeld will perform at Donington Theater at 9 p.m. EDT.

He revealed he will not perform onstage during the fall collection season. “The power I think about my stage name is that I’m always thinking about something so captivating, and it only makes me a better stage name. … I guess I’m gonna go back to ‘How I Got All the Money.’ I’ll have to really just come back there,” he said during last week’s opening night of the first run of “What Do You Mean?” at the AMC theater in Queens.

Title: Tom Hanks and Rita Wilson's family speak out after coronavirus diagnosis

Though most of the outbreak has been traced to the United States, experts say that it has been posing a threat across various parts of the world.
On Tuesday afternoon, via Twitter, Hanks replied to a letter from three of his adopted nieces to talk about the outbreak. According to the four.
"The fact that we are all so determined to prevent any further spread of this virus around the world, despite the cumulative cost and devastating effect, now seems rather rather unnecessary," the letter reads.
Wilson's family, including her children, are living in New York City and will not be staying put until the outbreak is over.
They've also revealed they "are not yet home," according to the statement.
This is a family that has spent several years and thousands of dollars fighting for independence. We thank you for your patience and prayers over this time and wish you peace in the coming days."
In all of his public statements, Hanks has come to the aid of his wife, who's in the midst of touring the world with their son, Paul, in the D-Day deployment.
Sadly, just weeks after the attack the pair underwent colonoscopies in July 2009.
The surgery revealed that Tom's colon was suffering from colon cancer, a potentially fatal form of the infection that has been linked to several outbreaks in Europe.
In response to the news of Tom's demise, Wilson's family said they are "up in arms."
"The truth is, I am a bit embarrassed and frightened to see Tom Hanks dead," Wilson wrote. "I will never be able to see him again. I don't want anyone to think that I will ever hear 'Hey hey, hey, hey, hey, hey.' Nobody ever looked at Tom Hanks. We've done so much work and we've got an incredible future together."
Well since last week, there have been no further negative reports from the media.
Wilson says the greater the media's support for Tom Hanks, the more normal viewers can expect to get when they find out about the horrible news.
"Really what's really hard is to endure the many reports about somebody else's illness," Wilson said. "It's a fine line. It's a very sad job to lead my country to this tragedy.
"For Tom it's just terrifying that someone would do something like this to even die. It feels like something that happened to him."
The announcement has reverberated across social media, with some people posting condolences on Twitter.
"I hope that Tom Hanks has a wide outlet. Yes, there's a national consciousness that the world needs an official 'Hollywood celebrities' to unite around the tragic news," Nelson Bell wrote.
As for Wilson, she notes that there is yet to be a scientific basis for her statement and has long been a victim of the disease.
"The body of research just begun over at Penn State is finding out where genes turn over," she said. "We just have to wait to see what is shown to be a really significant gene loss test."
Wilson has posted on Twitter multiple times since the news broke with a wide array of thoughts and prayers posted all around the world.
"The news is devastating, and particularly frightening for a daughter that loses both parents who have worked so hard to understand this," writes Margaret O'Hara. "Anyone for no other reason than what devastation this news brings to her family."

Title: 'The View' and more shows suspend studio audiences over coronavirus

Title: Time's Up and others react to Harvey Weinstein sentence
Generation:
["NEW YORK (CNN) — Harvey Weinstein’s sentencing to 10 years in prison on sexual assault charges is now nearly two years out, according to a judge in Manhattan.
And he got off easy, too.
The maximum sentence, after a victim’s attorney raised questions about Weinstein’s culpability, was stayed.
A judge also acquitted Weinstein of 15 charges of voyeurism, making sexual advances against a woman who worked as a masseuse.
Weinstein, 69, was thrown into prison without any prior court supervision, pending trial. His sentence, set for next month, is longer than the 11 years served by federal prosecutors.
How Weinstein escaped
The Weinstein Company, the Weinstein Co. and the Weinstein Company owned by Weinstein had previously been accused of sexual misconduct with women.
In December 2017, a jury convicted Weinstein of criminal sexual assault and tampering with evidence. The company continued to sell its Weinstein trademarks for decades.
Weinstein said in an interview published Monday in The New York Times that he was in the habit of drinking whiskey and smoking.
“Those cocktails were totally physical,” he said. “People might say these things but they didn’t do anything about it. I was in the habit of drinking alcohol the whole time. I didn’t drink.”
The treatment of women in the #MeToo movement was also something on which he had been highly criticized, prompting some to question his treatment of women by female executives at his company.
The director was also facing a full civil trial in October. In October, Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Anna Throne-Holst imposed strict punishment for the groping scandal that has rocked Hollywood.
The judge set a Sept. 7 trial date and an April 19 trial date.
Weinstein is the highest-profile of six Weinstein executive pairs who reached settlements with victims.
Weinstein also released his name from a nondisclosure agreement with two of his accusers.
An earlier version of this story included Weinstein's lawyer recanting his earlier statement.
"]

Title: Kumail Nanjiani recreated buff movie scenes because we still deserve nice things
Generation:
['If you’re any type of moviegoer, you’ve always been told to treat yourself well when the movie goes on the road. And we’ve never seen anything like anything like what Kumail Nanjiani did, at least in the feature film’s third act.
The Boston Globe points out, while the film directed by Rian Johnson may have a strong sci-fi component, it’s not exactly a subtle satire or satire of Twitter. You will have to pick up a Chinese wall ($8,500.)
What many viewers will be interested in seeing more of is the two-dimensional, bad-guy versions of Bryan Cranston and Donald Glover, the two actors who play the characters side by side in order to get to the end of the movie. Cranston really gives an expression to the film that sounds like Cranston uses to say to each other, “You must have had this conversation with my wife.”
But Nanjiani offered up more of a description in a new interview with CNN:
Did you see it? I did. No, I didn’t have this conversation with my wife.
Did you think the script was written right or wrong? In other words, no — I never thought that it was going to be anything that made the first movie a decent or worthwhile movie. There was not enough material where we could keep it going for half a century.
Why did you want to do it? Because I’m an actor. I love movies. I love people. I’m like, “I’ve read the book I want to write.”
And it became so rich. I spent hours just in this office doing these lines for this big-budget film and so it was a good experience. But what made it so fun to do it was, you did have to throw yourself into it. I didn’t want to go and do it again and again.
It became this kind of retreads and rewrites and reworkings and all that stuff. So it became about us filling in the holes, giving the actors room to think and to play with each other.
It was about actual change. Change in a way — and this is where things start to happen. Just about that same point as I was 15, about, “What’s happening this week? What’s going to happen next?” We don’t know. We don’t know much, so all we know is we’re in this real world that it’s me telling, “What are you doing now?”
And that’s where it goes on a real world level and the actors do get to play with each other. So that kind of thing, I was more interested in playing with all the different dialogue in this movie. You know, it’s what it’s like to be an actor and to be that person who brings so much of that to it. And that kind of character works in some cases better than others, and it’s about showing it.
In the movie, there are a few different characters. For instance, Tien Chien and the character they play in The Commissary in Interstellar was that one of the characters named Brody, the father of a young boy. And there are other characters who were named Reince, the younger brother of the character named Eric. So there are different aspects of the same character.
What’s going on with these characters of yours in the movie? I’m not sure. I’m pretty sure their careers and the kind of backgrounds that they have in their life, even though they are movie players, sometimes some of the things that get written in there, are very veiled.
It’s a story about birth by birth, which is kind of hard for people to fathom or even understand. What they’re most comfortable with is being people and being alive in your own skin, and just that’s the real story here.
Even though they probably are trying to cross that line, you guys don’t want to cross that line with that. It’s important, it’s important that these characters are not like you guys. It’s important that them have the intention that they would be an actor. And then you can’t argue with that, when your characters are smart and know the rules.
']

Among the highlights of the season:
– The discovery that Serena Sorvino (Amanda Seyfried) is pregnant. She’s quickly found out she is pregnant. “We’re seeing things that will shape us in the future,” says executive producer Charlotte Riley.

– Mark Lytle, whose part in “The Shining” is an improv coach, is the show’s emcee. “We all got together just to say some stuff,” says McBride. “It was really cool.”

This is not just a show about a girl who dreams of marrying a high-schooler, which might be a tribute to TV history – but it’s one with a lot of great shows that could eventually make their way in the director’s chair.
“Superhero Place” will premiere on broadcast TV on May 17th.

Additionally, Hulu sales revenue also increased more than 25% year-over-year. Since 2015, the two companies have shipped around 380 million units of Hulu and 1.5 million units of Amazon Prime subscribers.
Roughly 4.4 million videos and films streaming to Hulu and 1.1 million videos and movies streaming to Amazon Prime is expected to remain strong in the coming months. The expansion of Amazon Prime helped increase Hulu viewership while also kicking off talks between the streaming company and the content distribution company.
“We are excited about the launch of Netflix Instant in almost half of the U.S. market with more than 200,000 subscribers since last January,” said Mathew Martoma, Chief Strategy Officer for Amazon.
“This marks the debut of our first U.S. subscription Prime TV service in over one quarter of the U.S. television households. By 2023, more than 45 million households will subscribe to the service.”
On Amazon’s new Prime Video application, Amazon Audible includes 24-hour audiobooks with custom audio captions that allow users to choose from five titles from the catalogue for both free and for no cost.
“Amazon Audible is one of the newest software extensions on the AWS cloud, creating a new level of community in which customers can connect to businesses across all industries,” said Margaret Kaczor, Amazon’s VP of Devices and Platforms.
Amazon has also made it easier for its customers to subscribe to Amazon’s 7-day waiting time and reduced prices on select products. The service also delivers Red Dot to e-readers and devices, FreeTime Unlimited streaming (Netflix vs. Amazon Prime), Monster Hub2 streaming (free to die per month), Amazon Live Video On Demand and preorder Kindle Air.
According to a report by Thomson Reuters, Netflix video subscribers in the U.S. in March spent nearly $1.2 billion on streaming movies and TV shows, one of the highest spenders in the market in 2014.
According to CNNMoney, CineFix, a group that makes video production and distribution, estimates that viewers spent $2.6 billion on streaming movies and TV shows, the most over the past six months.

Title: The Fastest Way To Pay Off $10,000 In Credit Card Debt

And those numbers have grown tremendously. Not only can the vast majority of adults have missed out on half a billion dollars in credit card debt, but the amount of money that’s left over after taxes is almost three times higher than the amount spent on gas. So it’s amazing to me that a lot of people who got as much money as they could can, in just two seconds, stack their cards and come up with a bunch of money.
More than $10,000 in credit card debt
The biggest big payoff was in the first $500 of Geller’s book, “Why Women Should Be Listed As High School Graduates.” She hopes that book and this tip will inspire young women to become more responsible as they enter adulthood.
The Tip: Look Into The Collection. Forget “T” and “K” like “D” in your credit card statements. Focusing on what you already have will allow you to qualify as high school graduate debt during the first year, and in the next year and a half, as Geller said, “you’ll really begin to understand what’s really important and who you are in your life.”
Protect Yourself From Debt

Although there’s no silver bullet when it comes to protecting yourself, starting conversations on credit cards and other issues with your bank could result in more savings. “I have found that 12 to 15 minutes of discussing a personal financial issue with your bank without having to put a personal trip or auto trip on hold while making payments helps increase the confidence you have in yourself during the course of your life,” said Caitlin Barnes, a corporate communications manager at Jackson Heights, N.Y.-based retirement startup, Formspring Corp. “People don’t just look at savings and credit card debt, or a monthly payment, they make the key decision to save as quickly as possible.”

On the Oculus Rift’s website, you can see that you can use Oculus Rift in conjunction with apps for more than two million VR headsets. For those that only work with VR, please post your VR experience to your Facebook account, or follow Oculus or Facebook into the Oculus app stores.
More importantly, if you need a VR headset that you can control from your phone, Oculus Rift is you. Thanks to its shiny new build, Oculus Rift VR requires only a few apps, has 50,000 titles and downloads and has the ability to use in-game co-op for free.
3. You can set up your own VR experience. You can use a tablet that you choose to keep held up, tablet or camera. You can set up a showroom setup, photograph with your self, store your files and organize your characters. The goal is to you: create your own unique VR experience. Special instructions are posted on Oculus’ website for telling some of the key questions you should pose before engaging with Oculus Rift VR. For example, if you don’t want to see your character appear on screen and then you’re unsure of which mode to explore, set up your own Oculus Rift VR experience and quickly. At this point, you will find it easy to experience Oculus Rift VR content, as well as the virtual world.
4. You’ll need a headset which can support 3D Printing. Like the iPhone 7, the 3D Printing app Apple produces is based on current technology but includes such things as 3D printers and virtual reality headsets. With the 3D printers, you don’t have to worry about labor and design fees or product costs.
Look at this example of how to build your own virtual reality experience that comes with Oculus Rift.

You can also spend more time with your Rift Pro or Rift Pro Pro directly off the Oculus Rift and HTC Vive. You can just enjoy watching your VR experiences now. Title: Beyond Earth: A VR experience
Generation:
['I arrived at the AMAT @TempleWood – when they put so much work behind it – it was like a trailer on a trailer’s set. Get off the set and get down in the Ramblas, yell some music in front of yourself. Wake up with the first pitch of a game. Don’t talk to other people… watch it, don’t talk to people….watch it. Do this for two minutes. You’ll understand your gear. Buy your gear. Create your own virtual reality experience. It will change you forever! Of course, there’s a lot of work involved – creating the terrain, manufacturing the environment and making all that stuff go down. But if you do enough, you’ll do something utterly amazing.
Why is it so cool to play VR? It brings content to life, uses great imagery and acts as a creative challenge of a novel. Beyond Earth is in many ways the perfect combination. Virtually every character in this experience belongs to an impressive cast of unique individuals. They are incredibly adept at VR in an immersive way – from human actors to VR acrobats, med school students, scientists, virtual jewelry designers, animators, U.S. animation and more. There’s something to be said for an exceptionally creative team.
You can play through to be that annoying viewer, or at least briefly, there. There are a number of ways you can do this:
Upload a video for the pic. Get some fuzzy art as well, so you could make a segment of the space station, lit up (if you are capable)… open up a beautiful virtual reality module (to inspire you to get out)
Upload a spot to make your own real-world landing spot for a VR show (just make sure it’s real enough so you can run to it. For the site, mention “Enduring”. If you are in Europe, read on.
Enjoy the cut-outs and extras, but in a virtual reality sense, you’ll get multiple options:
VR School for a VR Professional – develop/produce still videos/logs
VR School for a VR Designer – craft, design, landscape design, all VR-related video
Support Crew – Community, NGO, Arsonists, the former foster kid
If you have more (if you are interested in VR) and have seen them, please send a photo or email me at stevesteinmanin@cnn.com

Title: Ski at Austria's Soelden resort
Generation:
['Any summer weather conditions you can spot and there is no cloud in sight. Cars and airplanes light up the scenery while people observe them, smiling and ballsy in the snow. But whenever you make a mountain bike trek around Austria’s Soelden, one of the most famous ski destinations, you are left in little doubt about what it is.
Hotels, restaurants, saunas and biking tours are examples of the signature Alpine driving quirks. Although complete with a guide for tourist satisfaction, the soelden approach also offers some basic pleasures: The cobblestone streets and sheer white slopes above make for a wonderfully broad and warm environment.
All the same, there is a strict ban on those with short hair and mountain bike rides: Those who remain will be cited for being unable to ride without makeup. They will be fined or even imprisoned for a year or two if they do not travel within the shortest day of the week.
Although the approach to the Soelden is very leisurely, it is very quiet. The excellent Louvre Art Museum and museums in Austria are also dotted around the tiny valley. Couples have a great time soaking up the noise and the lumbar breaks of the slopes themselves as locals will show off their talents in the village famous for its piano, and the women will indulge in all manner of trade.
The “occupation” and its sacred rules guide for everything from men’s spending to how much non-believers should spend on a ski trip. Those who do not do enough in the ski area get their own locks and allow tourists to ski off.
']

Title: Fly in a WWI fighter plane

['Recently I retired a massive U.S. Sauer-Porsche A320 that lived up to its name. The crash of the A318 from the Detroit Air Show two weeks ago raised concerns of possible damage to the engines and mechanics.
As I spoke, the lines of blades around the windshield of the flight deck flew in and out like phantoms, with a trailer full of hair! It was done to perfection.
There was no one on the ground, in the planes, of any perceived damage to Boeing’s planes.
This story is not unique. Civil aviation is a nationwide phenomenon and our military is an integral part of that. But even amid the world’s changing interest in aviation I think there’s just one person in the world who’s thinking about aviation and who gets their head around this issue.
Air Commodore Percy Goodwin has always been interested in the flying public. And he certainly feels our military. But unlike in many other professions, he’s spent most of his adult life not involved in the industry or volunteering to give back. So in the last few years, he’s been working to raise funds to try to place the future of aviation closer to his heart.
One goal is to hopefully make the A318 stand out again. There were several people on the ground Sunday evening who knew the iconic plane, and were mystified by the mystery about the crash.
Goodwin quickly came up with a $1 million project to raise funds for the plane, like one they had been planning for a long time. Another project: a fly it off the plane again at the Detroit air show.
He’s not alone. Doug Wilson of the National People’s Congress, the country’s largest opposition group, tweeted that the A318 “stands up to the very nature of evil,” and that as many as 350 fighters could be killed if their engine dies.
Goodwin and others are working to find and save parts of aircraft like the A318. Ground support and ground division are also working hard. His ultimate goal is to make the plane as recognizable as the American one it belonged to.
As a country, we’re great consumers of air travel.

Title: Ride along with the Hogwarts Express
Generation:
['(CNN) — Get ready for some spring and there are days when a little teenage angst could be your only problem. Many summers don’t exactly invite fun. Imagine overnight world travel with smartphones and the discovery of the catapults that guides your door each time a friend exits the home. Such adventure is not an excuse for idleness. Parents should work themselves up to the older years. And, great wisdom says, there are too many great things to mention just to go here and don’t remember to arrive at your house late at night or drop you off after a long night, wish you had your car when it came time to go home and bring your family to the hospital and get you some hot drinks.
Nowadays, when parents think about their kids’ safety, all they think about is that they will end up with the hardest roads: there will be good friends and a family to share the bar with and their cars. They will want to cross the paths of you and this world is ours as our children.
And, it’s not all fun and games. Most teenagers are more comfortable in the house with the two-way radios in their rearview mirror. These are the features that parents are looking for. They are not missing any of the nice kid-to-be destinations we have used for years to explore. These days we are still able to indulge our family’s thrill, but at a much slower pace.
Children should develop lifelong gratitude, compassion and purpose. Parents need to encourage children to be thankful for their parents. “I think it’s really hard to be thankful for children and look back on that period of their lives and remember their failures,” said Good Advice Marketing Manager Rob Christensen. “That’s when we can help children start really thanking and respecting the people that are around them.”
Parents have a way to remember us by remembering what we truly are in a nutshell. Instead of judging us for our failures and regrets, remind us of our qualities and engage us in new feelings about life.”
Watch what life is really like now and what makes you even more hopeful and hopeful to succeed. Continue with the experience and you will have a more balanced view of life’s possibilities. You will have a better appreciation for the triumphs of every situation. You will, therefore, be seen as more satisfied with your family. And if you have such great children you will not have to worry about the cars.
The environment in which we live has been altered every few years or years, but it has never changed the meaning of life. Our children will always be here and the expectations remain high. They don’t need us to do those things they don’t have the pleasure of, but they need to do the things we ask them to do to keep the success we have here from happening. We need them to live by the standards that are in place for them today. What are our expectations today? Where are they headed for? And how do we and our children hope to attain those ideals and demonstrate them? And how do we reconcile those realities with these bigger, more real-world expectations?
']
