Title: One of India's biggest banks has been rescued by the government
Generation:
['India's largest bank Vikas Sahib
(CNN) -- State-run State Bank of India said Friday that it has received all necessary approvals to continue as it is meant to be.
The results of the bank's stress tests showed that it has submitted total capital of Rs 2,325 crore ($200 million) to the central bank. It had total assets of Rs 1,028.4 crore ($193 million) at the end of March.
The bank has also said that it has paid all the post-tax provision expenses of Rs 532 crore.
The most recent U.S. loss estimate put its combined capital at around Rs 11,600 crore ($412 million).
The bank suffered its worst ever quarterly financial losses last year, at Rs 9,570 crore, largely due to impairment losses in its property business. Its credit ratings are now of negligible importance in India, where the lender struggled to improve its financial position.
Amid this shortfall, Indian regulators have put together an emergency capital package.
SBI CEO K. N. Bhargava said in a statement Friday that the bank also decided to put a resolution fund of Rs 3,000 crore into the bank's capital, with the rupee expected to strengthen above 66 US cents to effectively restore access to banking.
Speaking at a press conference on Friday, Bhargava said, "We have given all necessary permissions to complete the evaluation in due course to ensure that we can move forward with the capital raising".
The bank also confirmed its first-quarter net profit, which rose almost 50% to Rs 1,015 crore ($170 million) while revenue grew nearly 30%.
Krishna Mehta, chief executive of the bank, said, "We have responded with strong financial performance while adjusting our capital structure to meet our long-term growth objectives."
His company reported an operating profit of Rs 1,135 crore ($102 million) for the first quarter, up 63% from a year earlier.
Bharti also has a large user base outside the subcontinent.
"India is our fourth biggest market and, at the end of March 2017, total international assets of Rs 9,600 crore (current) and Rs 1,027 crore (current) were registered on our parent's books, as compared to Rs 8,335 crore in 2014," Bhargava said.
Consequently, the bank has consolidated some 670 branches across the country, covering 12 markets, with combined customers reaching about 5.2 million.
']

Title: India's top court strikes down ban on cryptocurrency trading
Generation:
['NEW DELHI (CNNMoney) — The Supreme Court’s decision to relax limits on cryptocurrency trading during the year 2017 has paved the way for the latest variant of his crypto, the Digital Currency Market Association (DLMA), to debut in the country.
The apex court’s decision, which was implemented on 25 January 2018, was expected to increase the blockage of several cryptocurrency exchanges, run by operators of the global cryptocurrency markets.
The Administrative and Tax-Adjudication Committee’s (AAPCC) tentative target for continuing blockage is worth Rs 600 crore. It must be implemented within 11 months, or until lawmakers raise the quantum.
More than one billion coins, valued at about US$87 trillion (around Rs 3.83 trillion), have been blockaged since 2016. In that year, 126,400 coins blocked by blockages numbered 5,246.
In late 2017, the central bank set a limit of 200,000 shares of the non-listed cryptocurrency Mint. Having been blocked by the AAPCC, Dotcoin was purchased by the government.
The battle over tokens like cryptocoin coins from India was complicated by the commissioning of Dvapap Yojana (DudePac), a scheme by the Indian Securities Exchange (ESEX). Market participants received 5 million shares of the crypto.
But the Supreme Court, in its 2016 ruling on the third phase of the DudePac scheme, urged the Etoons to drop its non-commissioneded target of 2 billion coins.
But seven-judge bench of justices N.R. Sathasivam and A.S. Pai declined that part of the appeal.
In January, the AapCC chief Mukul said the ban was likely to spur more customers to try to get into digital coins. Blockchain scholars fear the trend has come to India’s fore.
“The outcome of the AAPCC meeting meeting will provide guidance for market structure and for other areas of demand like price stability,” said A P Srivastava, founder of Darktrace.
The Delhi Centre for Science and Environment had proposed a ban on the weeklong DDB auction. The government approached the Dye Association but the association was silent on the matter.
Mukul and S.V. Singh, principal secretary of the National Commission for Promotion of Science and Technology, have since returned the advisory to the apex court. The agency has initiated legal action on the matter.
The high court is currently conducting a hearing on the Delhi Commission for Promotion of Science and Technology’s petition. It has asked BCCL to file an application before it on the ban.
AAPCC could also modify the suspension of all certificates issued by the exchanges for the week long DDB auction. The agency had said that any eligible certificate of traders could be withdrawn and replaced with a new certificate issued by an alternate entity or a third party to invest in infrastructure projects.
India is only the eighth country in the world to invest in infrastructure for a continuous investment of more than $ 1 trillion, according to the investment management company Bain & Co.
Last month, Dye Association had filed a petition in the Supreme Court challenging the decision. The Delhi Centre for Science and Environment argued in the petition that demonetisation violated the free movement of goods and services, which has helped the value of unlisted currencies with relative ease.
By Taiga Uranaka and Donna Lamsie
']

Title: Apple is finally opening its first store in India next year
Generation:
['(CNN) — Apple has opened its first store in India in July.
The global company was seen at a press event in India on Monday morning to introduce the Mobile Service Centre at Sanjay Nagar in Sanjay Nagar. The store, Apple estimated, is likely to be open for up to a month. It will be the first New Delhi store for the Cupertino-based company.
Apple is also planning on opening another Apple store in Bangladesh and moving its online stores to Bajaj Mall in Bengaluru next year, respectively.
“This is absolutely a game changer and a brilliant step forward for India,” said Francis Tyre, senior vice president of product management at Apple, in a statement.
However, things are about to get a lot more complicated for India’s Asian manufacturing giants that last year racked up nearly a billion dollars in Chinese theft charges, including Apple. The country, which accounted for 8.5% of Apple’s global market in 2017, will lack a widely recognizable manufacturing sector due to being Asian-dominated.
“India will change that in the next quarter and it will become a very important region for Apple. It will enable them to focus on acquiring top quality, rather than competing against their competitors,” said Adam Semple, head of the manufacturing business at Markit, an automotive software services provider in London.
Consumers could make better decisions about purchasing Apple devices if they knew just where they were going to be manufactured rather than where they were going. Other factors that affect price range and demand in India are India’s government taxes, a large number of low-skilled jobs, and no tax on the sale of gadgets abroad.
“Long-term, if it goes well there will be a substantial increase in volume of net devices. But the economy will not have a quality life any more as fast as it used to,” said Nicholas Considine, a partner at the London-based Fast Company.
Apple is battling to reinvent itself. The tech giant has carved a home for itself in fashion. But Apple has been plagued by accusations that it owes customers money after claims of iCloud blackmail.
During the 2016 launch of the iPhone 6 Plus, the tech giant did not disclose the millionth phone sold in the United States. To date, Apple has sold more than one million iPhones in the United States and has had a 17% year-over-year rise in quarterly revenues.
']

Title: How India's Silicon Valley is using tech to tackle traffic
Generation:
['(CNN) — Walk to Silicon Valley and you’ll be faced with two unwelcome reminders.
One is the fact that black cars (a once fashionable industry, and then, no longer!) have been banned from the city limits in the past, slamming women and blocking its burgeoning nightlife and conference spaces.
The other is that tech is selling out. And whether you’re first-time users of the new AI or part of the tech-run economy, the city is setting a precedent in the effort to overhaul how cars are sold, driverless taxis banned and ultimately, social media-fueled traffic jams.
India is cashing in on the tech bonanza.
About 150 companies are building out their vehicles in the city. Uber, Google, and an array of other startups have been investing in public transportation systems in India, starting with an Aug. 15 investment deal with W.E. du Pont de Nemours and Co.
SEE ALSO: Faces of Africa's $1.4B trade mission
“We are the first among the cities in India to have a fleet of autonomous taxis built and operating on public roads,” said Chris T. Diamantchhi, vice president of government affairs at Uber, in a video released earlier this year, describing a workforce of more than 10,000. “Drivers and passengers alike are being expected to register with our network, and be able to drive around every corner until we stop.”
A decision on whether to open a public system to drive has been pending since 2016, when the Supreme Court on March 7, 2018, ruled against a request to ban all vehicles from “public” roads. While the law went into effect on June 30, months later, the country has yet to roll out its own system.
In 2017, India's Ministry of Road Transport & Highways announced that it would not only issue a ban on all Uber and Kazeem rides on the city's roads, but it would also shutter additional service based on driving standards.
“In keeping with the people's expectations, the Minister convened a meeting in the capital city of New Delhi — the capital of India — during which she raised the issue of the taxi fleet, and the pace at which it is being built and the connectivity issues being faced with such large volumes of traffic,” an IndiGo spokesman said in an email to CNN.
Uber and other companies have also said they would first show a public approval (or "public disapproval") and then come up with an easy-to-understand, quick-launch system for determining the vehicles' availability at points of traffic.

"Modi is scheduled to arrive in India on Tuesday and meet people from Hindu minority communities in Chennai," Jaitley’s spokesman Saifullah Shahi told CNN.

Title: Why India's citizenship law crosses the line

That doesn't necessarily mean you must "submit proof" to go back to India.
For instance, people wanting to become citizens can wear a simplified Indian national identity card and qualify to be a citizen after passing a simple physical test that requires them to show proof of their Indian citizenship in the first four years of their citizenship.
On the other hand, some Indians who want to become citizens can't. And for those of us who wish to become citizens, the process can be intimidating.
The issue of Indians acquiring citizenship in India has been repeatedly raised since the country's last prime minister, Indira Gandhi, took office in 2002. While most of those members of her family were Indian of the Indian Gauravkhan-type people, a few, like Rajyavadi Mulikarthi, still hold their country's native amity and love of India and much of their soft power in the country.

Once they heard about my intention to become a citizen as they are then, I tried to explain that my desire to become a citizen was also to avoid unfairness for different groups.
Though most people wouldn't feel confident about committing to being a citizen in the country that they are currently in, they were able to learn to argue they were not a citizen. For instance, some students and teachers who own business establishments were able to explain that they were not as a citizen as they first thought they were. And for the common folk, nobody knows the difference between them and foreigners or different kinds of Indians.

As the problems in the Indian right become more visible, creating more awareness among Indians around possible citizenship choices, I think this would be a good step in recognizing that some Indians prefer not to become citizens because they don't have any guarantee of a comfortable life after moving to India in the first place. But, they're still reluctant to do so, wary of the possibility of easier and more difficult employment opportunities in India and the region.
When I say I fear for the Indian right, that's because I don't have any sort of guarantee to not be a citizen if I don't want to live in India. It's because I can't deny that people who have remained in India for so long are in a class of their own, without any guarantees and fears.

Title: Volcano victims: New Zealand orders 1,292 square feet of skin for patients injured in eruption

ZAKARTA, Indonesia — Volcano victims in Indonesia, fighting for control of one of the world’s largest volcanic areas told CNN they are receiving several skin donations, part of a $1,292 million compensation fund for residents who have lost everything.
Researchers have identified nearly 1,300 structures — or 22 square miles — in the Pearl River Basin near Mount Tugun, the biggest volcano in the world known to have fanned out and risen over a remote area five times the mass of Antarctica.
Raely Tsang, spokeswoman for the Joint Agency for Meteorology and Geophysics in Jakarta, described the influx of skin donations as a sign of “strong desperation” from the fire survivors. Tsang said units are being sent to aid the treatment and extraction of the bodies and shields to help the victims recover.
Volcanoes are the world’s fourth-biggest volcanic force, capable of inundating and damaging entire towns in order to expand and build their capacity, the JAAA said. And unlike gas-spewing, they cause hot, uncontrollable eruptions across its 8,231-square-mile rim — which makes them the world’s highest amount, according to the Institute for Geophysical Research at the University of Warwick in Britain.
“Each volcano is uniquely powerful for its locations,” Tsang said. “Volcanoes these days occur there only to be fortunate that there are the best of them — as it has been with nearly every other factor,” he said.
Volcanoes can erupt at any time in a million years, especially in wet climates, the JAAA said. The strongest eruption occurred in Indonesia’s forests in 2003. That year, 1,294 people were killed when an 80-foot volcano erupted near the volcano in its central heart region.
It has also erupted close to Java’s Sumatra island, with more than 3,400 people killed since 1983. Some have been buried there for more than a decade and dozens are believed to be buried along the isolated shoreline, according to a toll compiled by the Information Institute of Indonesia, an association that monitors casualty statistics.

Title: Fight is not over, says winner of vaginal mesh implant court victory
Generation:
['A federal jury on Wednesday found Florence L. Tyler, a once-promising Brooklyn woman whose implants were rejected by a federal judge because they didn’t comply with a 2004 state law giving women access to vaginal mesh procedures, a victory she said was decided by pure luck.
Tyler, 28, of Riverdale, Brooklyn, also received $3.1 million for undisclosed legal fees by reaching an agreement with the federal District Court judge who rejected her implant removal claim after her trial in 2016.
The US Supreme Court in February paved the way for a 23-year-old Michigan woman to appeal that decision to the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals. A lower court would rule on an appeal, taking precedence over a much longer process.
Monday, Judge David Offset said Tyler had received no facts proving she was the plaintiff. A three-judge panel overturned her judgment.
Tyler declined to comment beyond her attorney's brief.
“Mr. Tyler has proved his will to take this matter to the point of litigation, and her trial did not take this into account,” said Rusty Hardin, a lawyer for Tyler's organization, Last Wish.
Firm misses out on temporary relief
Tyler remained optimistic of her chances of victory.
“I'd ask just to be clear - there is a lot of work to be done, there’s a lot of obstacles in front of us and we’re still hopeful," she said.
But Tyler, who is now working as a research associate at the University of Michigan, said she was confident she could persuade Judge Offset to allow her to proceed with her claim that she was harmed in the federal court proceedings.
“I really think this is a bigger case than ever,” she said. “I’m confident we’ll win the case.”
The trial in 2016 found Tyler and her attorney, Michelle Carey, liable for paying a $1 million judgment in a wrongful-missgment defense to Backhoe Chemical Corp. that paid her $2.9 million in an involuntary sterilization contract.
The judge had previously rejected claims about the size and construction of the implants that she could have been relieved of due to inadequacy, which was the conclusion of the trial.
Hardin had estimated she could get $8.5 million plus legal fees to address the remaining verdict, which he dismissed on Wednesday.
The jury found Tyler did not appear to be motivated by a desire to protect her privacy.
Tyler’s family said they believe the verdict is not surprising.
“Our family is upset that the verdict is held in such low regard by our medical professionals, especially the women who benefit from her surgeries,” their lawyer, Jen Miller, said.
“These are young women suffering the life-changing injury of living with chemical attack and poverty as a result of their false affirmation,” she said.
Legal troubles back on store shelves
“They took advantage of a woman in my mother's arms, to put a false instrument in front of the judge and undercut the legitimacy of her case and to be held to a very limited standard that has no merit,” Tyler said.
Trial attorney Amy Rosenkranz, speaking for Hardy, said Tyler's left of $1.3 million in judgment is pending payment.
Hardin could not be reached for comment.
More than 30 clinics – including thousands of health centers nationwide – have reported problems with women continuing to have her surgeries after their devices were rejected.
Congress has made issue of its own. A 2012 law passed by the House of Representatives requires all surgical mesh implants to meet guidelines for coverage and training of emergency care, and the FDA has not asked how many of those implants are not meeting federal guidelines.
In response to any increase in the numbers of women seeking mesh implants, several states have passed or expanded their laws. The Oregon Attorney General's Office plans to seek state and federal regulatory actions to require such implants.
In New Jersey, the state Attorney General’s Office is looking into allegations against a pelvic mesh clinic that had tested female patients and provided them with valuable training.
Providing training is another issue, just as providing financial support to survivors of breast cancer was a reason many people are in business today.
Doris Primos, 26, a spokeswoman for the National Congress of American Men Health Care, said the organization met with a representative from the Health Care Access coalition before ruling out further litigation.
']

Title: Flames are chewing up my country
Generation:
['Do you know when the next hurricane will hit?
If so, how bad will the weather get, and how will the contagion spread? I think I know.
So much a part of your soul and heart related to the recent hurricanes in the United States were wiped out by five brutal storms that just seven months ago actually struck the northeastern United States.
This same event in the Eastern Gulf has allowed potentially new storms to be hatched by years-old people.
As of Monday, 2013, the last known hurricane in the United States was the front-running Tropical Storm Alberto, about a mile from the port city of La Jolla, California. Alberto was only 40 mph at the time.
Another 87 fatalities in 2007 were also from hurricanes in the eastern Pacific, according to The National Hurricane Center, a university monitor in Miami. That storm, named Tropical Storm Fay, struck far west in 1980.
Another quake in 1989, named Nansen, sent a wide tinderbox of cold air rumbling. It was forecast to bring at least a dozen aftershocks, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. In 1983, a 5-foot-tall monsoonal wave crashed into the South Pacific, sending out a huge tsunami.
By Saturday afternoon the South-Pacific wave, dubbed El Niñero, was killing nearly seven million people in the United States, an estimated 50 million more in the Caribbean and U.S. territories.
From Louisiana to southern Florida to Rhode Island to the Louisiana coast, the storms also contained nearly three dozen fatalities in the Gulf of Mexico. In Mississippi, along the Mississippi River, there were seven fatalities. And, in Louisiana, the people killed in storms in the New Orleans area were 159.
And you know where the hurricane originated from? On Monday, National Hurricane Center Chairman Carl Weinberg began to describe the place where it originated: Washington.
America’s shoddiest place? At this point, for one week.
Suddenly, the nine hurricanes and just three of the “L”s just are wrapping up their 23-year-span. Not only are we re-energized at the presidential level, but the way we respond to disasters of all sorts is so bipartisan.

Staff were called to the zoo after the last of the roo's eyelets died on the deck of the water's surface, according to a report on BBC Radio 4's Today programme.
"When I found out that the koala had died, I was extremely sad," said Sharma.
As part of the ongoing rehabilitation of the koala park, the vets concluded that the koala was suffering from a problem of hypothermia.

Title: The extinction crisis is far worse than you think
Generation:
["The global glut is now bigger than ever, and the price of oil has collapsed to historic lows. While many countries and businesses continue to be fine, the people around the globe are in deep, deep debt to make ends meet. They've stopped being strong, and now will not be able to stay strong enough to keep up with the demands of an ever-changing world. One simple thing will sink in: we're on a planet that's already in the midst of a catastrophic existential crisis.
It's pretty sad. Yet most of us never have even looked at it as such. And we're not alone.
As the global downturn intensifies, the number of jobs trapped in low-income countries has grown dramatically. We're not so bad anymore, when you take account of the fact that the world economy is far smaller than that of major developed economies, and about a third of the size of the United States. And by 2020, we're expected to outgrow the United States by two million new jobs. People living in countries with high rates of poverty will feel very strong pain, and massive destruction of their infrastructure, including agriculture.
The sheer magnitude of the depletion of these rapidly growing, increasingly unsustainable and bankrupt nations will require an overwhelming level of deep red ink for all the world to process.
We need to take action now, because this is no longer a state of war. The rest of us, whether in those increasingly tough economic times, or in various parts of the world that are dealing with extreme, enormous life-threatening problems such as climate change and HIV/AIDS, have put up a valiant front. But we can't let things slide anymore. As the world's population ages, it is increasingly difficult to find human assistance for conditions in which humans have proven to be crucial.
While circumstances around the world are changing fast, we can only get there if human-to-human movements toward adaptation continue.
The poor are no longer required to feed themselves in a dirty bowl of rice alone. But they have to eat in a way that brings their food from the depths of poverty — with our natural food-processing machines flooding from the neighboring countries with the right amount of water. Just a few recent examples illustrate this solution.
About a decade ago, Rio de Janeiro launched the world's first bio-fuel-friendly urban mass transit system in one of the world's busiest cities, which boasts seven miles of bus lines and three subway lines that connect to its subway system. It was a remarkable start.
But Brazil actually did not keep on the leading edge of the bio-fuels revolution for a generation, which culminated in the demise of the coal-powered Arcore. Many believe this gives Brazil a very different chance to make a quantum leap ahead. But it still lags the world when it comes to developing knowledge and craftsmanship. And, as the Brazilian government is proving every year, the world is turning into an abysmal living laboratory for those who can make the truly slow, tiny steps in the path of progress.
That's why we need you. You've given us that help. You've given us a beacon that's right around the corner: one that will know that once the world returns to normal, we can help make this chapter right.
*This video has been modified to fit an image of
the WORLD as a whole.
"]

I’m talking about, for a brief second, if your alphabet network is airing “Bad News Bears,” the Nancy Drew pic co-starring country music legend Willie Nelson, dabbling in medical metaphors (pronounced “towel”) while reassuring folks that things have turned too bad.

“Bad News Bears” is the second most successful original movie of Soderbergh’s cinematic career, following “Goodfellas” last year. Title: Plastic island: How our trash is destroying paradise
Generation:
['SAN FRANCISCO — Even though an island is supposed to be forever, it’s starting to come crashing down on those of us who live in it.
The Brazilian village on the islands of Costa Rica gets the job done — from that place of vacating our landfill to composting all of our trash in its design-less paradise. Here’s how it happens.
Levi Starr creates traditional dump-outs. As a child and therefore more passionate about preserving Costa Rica’s ocean, Starr has been recycling plastic utensils, in South America and around the world.
“In his life, my father and I did everything together because we wanted to be in control of our household,” says Starr. “We wanted to send that trash back to the people on our island.”
It’s a process that can take years. Starr says his tires are less than two feet tall and he wants to release a letter I love.
You can shoot him a paper bag and throw it into it. Or you can use the fabric-lined mattress that Starr and his husband are building.
And that’s just the tip of the iceberg. Designers are starting to look beyond plastic into roofs and walkways, where even your trim is a plastic wrapper that can just fit on a bank of pants.
Worldwide, the majority of recycling material is being poured in recycling containers, and some experts predict recycling will surpass the amount used in incineration by 2030.
“The world has already surpassed the amount of plastic that was used in the 1990s,” says Mikael Hilkevicius, an expert in material recycling at Muckenthaler, a chemical engineering institute in Brooklyn, New York. “You start somewhere.”
But there’s another factor in the shift. Mother Nature’s surprising inclination to recycle is affecting the world’s garbage bills. Roughly 400 million cubic meters of solid waste — lots of germs, rotting plants, rotten grass — has been dumped in the United States since 2004, according to the Environmental Protection Agency.
In 2015, the government spent $22.3 billion to house its excess waste in Peru, Mexico and Chile. Twenty-three years later, garbage rates are still the lowest in the world and sustainability advocates say this has nothing to do with growth.
“The challenge here is the sustainability that goes with recycling on paper. If you remove the plastic bags, the same thing can happen to bricks that we give to the Superfund sites or the environmental authorities to clean our trash,” says Hilkevicius.
With so much trash coming out of our homes, with so little oversight, waste management has become increasingly important in protecting our environment. Just as the GPS remains a livewire and peacekeeper, the marine life in our oceans is also becoming a greater threat to ours.
Humanity has made many changes to the oceans to accommodate the human waste we ship into them, and it may not be worth it to the environment to just send the waste our way.
Still, the international debate about plastic and composting doesn’t seem to be slowing down.
The 2015 Pew Charitable Trusts study shows that methane, an important contributor to climate change, will peak at a US average rate of 16 percent by 2030. Just as deforestation didn’t stop but ended, so is recycling.
The land that our planet once used for our food, water and medicine is falling into tremendous garbage disposal pits, according to a CNN analysis from the year 2017, dropping to less than 80,000 acres of landfill-filled land a day. And that’s just the tip of the iceberg.
“It was never the volume of tons of garbage that we’d had before 2001,” Starr says. “In the last decade, we’ve seen an unexpected surge of trash pouring into the oceans and rivers.”
']

Title: When the coral disappears, so will they

['× When the coral disappears, so will they
(CNN) — It’s great that there’s a biannual coral reef break off the Mississippi River as folks head out for a late spring barbecue. But you might know a certain section of the river that may contain a new supply of stuff.
You could count on there’s been a huge coral-tied move. The Mississippi River corals, which have already been felled, are set to disappear, off the coast of Alabama. And the U.S. Geological Survey published a new report Tuesday that concludes that the so-called “Exotic Reef of the South” will disappear at some point in the next 100 years or so, displacing some 1.3 million people across Alabama’s 3,000 miles of the U.S. northeast.
It means that every two days, more than 1.6 million people, either starting and retired or working, will migrate north into Alabama to experience the mass extinction. They’ll be either killed or washed off to the sea, scientists and environmentalists have said.
And there have already been a couple sightings.
But this is a really small mass extinction — it occurs during the migration phases of life, not the death phase. In other words, it’s really not as massive as we think.
USGS scientists published their news release Wednesday in response to a question from CNN.
“This is also a massive–and it’s premature to expect it to happen before the summer,” said USGS conservator Matt Tancredo. “Our previous reports have highlighted some preliminary evidence that a life event will occur in the area and next year.”
There’s another reason why this particular piece of the river may go beyond due to the luck of the draw. A number of (albeit small) insects that are able to feed and move through it really attract some species to the river as they move north across Alabama, Texas and Florida. These insects likely attract young, relatively young carnivores to the spot.
You’d think these coyotes, for example, would find early indications that the cross-pollinating young do will not be able to survive.
But don’t take this news for granted. Whether it’s right, wrong or not, some of us are now free of these great invertebrates that are becoming extinct.
So if this news doesn’t make you rewound to “the Earth is cleaning up the corals,” better start scouting for alternative sources for this post.
']

Title: Sixth extinction: 20 years to stop ecological collapse
Generation:
['SUN VALLEY, Va. — For years, children’s stuffed animals and YouTube videos broadcast their murder and destruction in an effort to obliterate their habitats.
Yet images are fading for grainy snapshots of just what is left of the Chesapeake and Monroe counties, where people will not yet be aware that some of the massive wildlife and marshes that once grew to support dozens of grocery stores never grew, experts say.
As a result, the farmers — especially those in parts of Virginia and North Carolina — will need to be devastated if they want to prosper, said Paul Jago, a program officer at the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
With little reward in return, these little people became prime target for killers.
From 2001 to 2009, more than 2,000 animal carcasses were seized from the owners of livestock farms, inter-cropped “apcogenes,” including deer, horses and birds, said Ian Chase, the Washington Water Polo Club’s trainer, and a former Navy SEAL.
Most of the carcasses that disappeared were documented on YouTube.
Another 1,177 carcasses, containing 50 percent of the animal population, were seized from farms in Montgomery County, Virginia, and Virginia, said Yigal Zipkin, a former Wal-Mart manager who also works for the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.
Only about 30 percent of those killed were each mammal or marshes native to the region, Zipkin said.
“There’s no way to really capture wildlife like this,” he said.
Voting kept the money coming back, siphoning it to air pollution mains, for many farms — about $100,000 in the last year, Zipkin said.
The resulting toxins produced in these woods and ditches, and and their accompanying ecosystems, have been tossed into the air and sent out to local rivers. Over time, these toxins circulate in rivers and streams, triggering a feeding frenzy, according to the Chesapeake Bay Foundation.

"The umbilical cord is the largest food chain that defines both the DNA and the whole human being," Dr. Erica Salioyakis, Executive Director of Research at the Hospital for Sick Children of Toronto, explains.
"Our message to the families is always, 'if you want to see a baby in your life, don't stand on the next level.' If you want to see a baby in your life, change up the look of your baby, and allow the umbilical cord to take on a role for you."
Over time, little baby Brasy becomes more and more attached to her mother, sticking to her mother during her pregnancies.
"The menstrual cycle begins at about three or four months old," Dr. Salioyakis explains. "We will learn to tell ourselves why Brasy is in her menstrual cycle—and we will learn to ... make sure she is not going to have a bad birth."
"Every single day when we add anesthesia to our babies, she begins to grow in a new shape, and is able to detect any obstacles in the background," Salioyakis said. "Once she realizes that everything has changed, which is probably about 80 per cent of that time period."
Ahead of the time of birth, there's a remarkable natural response. "Our babies start to grow up quickly; they don't have time for us or to nurture. Most women who want to have a baby in a situation that doesn't allow them to nurture [these children] have to let their babies grow up so quickly that they can only wait as long as they want to be."

Title: Where Trump support and Obamacare use soar
Generation:
['WASHINGTON (CNN) — Donald Trump clearly views the Republican Party as “crazy” because of Obamacare, a fact that is becoming increasingly obvious in polling, according to a new poll released Tuesday.
The upward trend that has developed over the last week is no surprise to anyone who has ever spent time on the couch with a polling staff, especially after holding a polling desk job for President Obama for two years, and hours of draining away each new poll.
In a recent poll taken March 22-26, 85% of likely voters said they now have a favorable opinion of the GOP, compared to a recent 15% approval rating, a non-partisan finding that is consistent with a basic polarization of beliefs between the country’s two major political parties, according to a poll released Monday by ACORN.
More than two-thirds said their views of the Republican Party are being “honest and trustworthy,” compared to just 49% who said they were in the opposition.
Indeed, whatever one views as “crazy” are less associated with Trump than with others, except for the famous quote: “If you gave them a telephone poll, they’d be like your Mother!”
More importantly, after Trump and John McCain’s fortunes waned in early 2014, the Republican Party completely took over the Republican National Committee’s executive committee structure. And if the numbers continue to improve as they have since March 22, those power players can easily adapt.
According to the political consulting firm Stratfor, Republicans now have 60% of the newly elected members, even though they were expected to change their messaging, and only 37% of those members are Republicans. And, by far, most of the new members are moderates.
“The fate of the Republican Party as we know it today depends in large part on the size of their organization,” Linda Sanchez, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said in a statement Monday. “All eyes are on the party in our most important and targeted state now, and all signs point to a new Washington party that can win elections in November.”
According to the Stratfor Poll, the most popular GOP side of the nation was formed in February to begin consolidating its leadership following President Obama’s ascendance.
Among the most popular GOP candidates was Republican Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas, who, according to a poll released on Monday, now has a 42% chance of winning the party’s nomination.
Like Cruz, Perry topped in the rankings on the right, while former Alabama Gov. Haley Barbour, Tennessee Sen. Dan Coats, and former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin shared five or more chances of winning.
The fact that each of the new committee members are more liberal than the two previous four and a half months with which they ran the party is particularly shocking, and highlights the fact that both have already experienced slumps of their own making.
Still, the official question in polling is whether the next four months will be a bruising month for the party.
If the Republican Party is poised to grow in popularity, Republicans will no doubt take advantage, but both parties will have to work to convince voters they can still summon the will to go forward if they want to keep sweeping into the next election cycle.
The bottom line, though, is the Republican Party needs to look beyond its Republican Party base.
']

While people can search for specific examples of recovery in other cultures, whether online or in person, unclaimed family members find each other on Facebook, says Wil Renscher, a psychologist who studies lost and lost kids.
No one speaks to their friends, acquaintances or their neighbors. Even in a family, the missing person’s phone is completely disconnected.
“There is still a stigma that somebody is not in the photo on their parent’s phone,” Renscher told CNN. “On many occasions, the parent is actually responding to the call or recovering from it, ‘Got Dad missing?’”
Renscher’s research so far has drawn comparisons to another Alaska family, "Rosie."
Dutch refugee Olivia Murphy — who lost her entire family in 1972 — turned to her Facebook page to locate missing four years ago. Title: Halted MH370 search is not an end for one man

['“The search for a missing Malaysia Airlines flight to Beijing has ended, with the search to be extended indefinitely,” Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak said.

Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 went missing Wednesday night after taking off from Kuala Lumpur bound for Beijing.
The captain of the Boeing 777 apparently put the radio out for air by accident and discarded it shortly before the flight departed, the company said, according to local news station ANT.
A piece of electronic equipment, carrying black boxes, would be recovered if the found wreckage was within of the plane, investigators said, but they would likely retrieve it from a field near land.
There had been no reports that something odd happened to the plane.
Some Boeing experts had said it looked like a normal semi-automatic air-traffic-control system as turned and climbed slowly to give a sound to the aircraft.
Notwithstanding the concern, Chinese aviation authorities remained on high alert.
In the immediate aftermath of Wednesday’s flight’s disappearance, new planes began disappearing across China as a result of new aviation restrictions.
Much has changed in the aviation landscape in the past two decades, with almost all the routes operated by Boeing being canceled or diverted due to more intrusive rules involving intercontinental air traffic control.
Until now, such restrictions have yielded no lasting improvement to airlines.
“It’s going to be very much like five to 10 years down the road,” industry consultant Kim Hong said.
']

Title: How ordinary people become 'white supremacists by default'
Generation:
['By Josh Rourke
Driving into the University City parking lot to sort out a car sticker was a case of naïve belief.
"For me, my primary loyalty as a white Jew is to be able to do business in America," said Erik Avelen, an African-American from Los Angeles, who's watching a TV commercial for a high-end grocery store he knows well.
Avelen says he first became interested in pushing the line of white supremacy by imagining other people as his own, and then by looking through the history of White supremacists.
But after seeing television commercials, he found a kindred spirit in the self-taught, somewhat nerdy, college professor and fellow at UCLA.
"I saw what he was doing," he said. "I couldn't believe he was around for three years."
Avelen watched the commercial online, alongside some of his friends, and knew something he didn't: young white supremacists, the provocateurs who view America as a homogenous open society, fighting the best of white supremacism and hate.
"It was fascinating," he said. "Like I have thought about it several times."
'It does not fit'
The protest started in February when white supremacist group UltraViolet chose 23-year-old Jesse Owens to walk into a store to stop a sales agreement between his family's clothing company, Owens Family International, and Latino Latino Resource Center, an organization working to integrate Latinos in American schools.
Owens had helped to plan the rally, calling himself "the first true hero."
Avelen says he was a little disoriented by how it's covered by campus police. "I was just numb," he said. "It does not fit. I don't think people understand the full extent of the Klan because white supremacists have a totally separate image."
One of those images is Owens' name, the original Jackson, New Jersey representative who hosted the downtown rally. He also had shown up in New York City as Owens' campaign team issued his campaign request. Avelen noticed that an image that same day of the former congressman in New York listed the same problem on Owens' website.
That photo now has more than 2,000 names on the Web. "That's probably the one face of white supremacy," Avelen said.
Avelen, whose friends gather nightly to call and address the news, expects news stories to pick up from this sketchy encounter, and that he will even need to show his film to anyone who might want to see it.
"If there's an artist out there that provides some perspective, this is not new," he said. "It's interesting because it's not just, 'I love Jesse Owens.’ There are a lot of things that maybe aren't common in the comics.
"But I do think he probably looked at his own sort of mentality from that perspective."
']

Title: Get ready for a more militant and 'woke' NAACP

Let's go a little closer, shall we?
About that "woke" movement
Black Lives Matter activists based in Savannah, Georgia, have a strong, unofficial agenda, but their ability to get things done is limited. They do not need the Internet and public television to scuttle the agenda.
During the last presidential race, African-Americans voted twice to make it easier for white-collar murder cases to be prosecuted. They also went so far as to write for The New York Times that "every political race you can think of has at least one black prominent congressional occupant," which is why most white Republicans don't really understand the Democratic Party.
For those in the media, the most common argument is that blacks in the Democratic Party -- as a group -- are soft on crime and violence, and have little concern about attacks on black people. While white journalists have often criticized the "woke" movement, they, like the black people in Savannah, have no problem with a new right-wing movement.
In fact, this led one newspaper photographer, Kevin Liles, to know some facts. It is a hard way to build a bipartisan movement.
"If you want to draw a line, my goodness," he said, "you've got to start somewhere. If the Black Lives Matter movement is going to bring you a group with a black face, that's something you can do."
The reason to not sign up for an edge groups like APA is that APA -- the movement that is now the democratic resistance movement, led by George Wallace -- wouldn't allow for BSA (bide your hat, marinate your spirit), so they aren't going to get involved with political events.
"With APA, we don't get to dictate how the movement goes about all the things that are important to our people and our country," APA President and CEO Josh Oakley told the Times this month.
We don't have black leaders in power to address this internal political barricade of silence. Nothing is happening. That is why I decided to do this blog post.
Basically, I wanted to show the progressive side of a common civil rights movement which was already under assault in the Obama administration and in the media. It didn't hurt that I am comfortable with the Black Lives Matter movement, and I am more confident that another right-wing movement like APA will have a lot more influence on policy that's important to African-Americans than APA.
']

Title: The first time I realized I was black
Generation:
['By Giorgio St. Laurent
The first time I realized I was black I told my grandma. I thought she used to give me a hug. Later that day I said, “I’m going to take my black pride and turn it around.” My grandma gave me a hug, and I reached for my hands and said, “That’s who I am.”
She did what she did as a stranger. Whenever I was on a date, she was always generous. This time, she was open about my family. Although we have been divorced since 2010, I still want to do things differently with my grandma. She wasn’t traditional, she was open and she was full of love, even though she didn’t have the courage to say what she did. The same could be said for this couple, my grandmother and my teacher. They all believed in treating my grandma with the respect and dignity she deserves, even though she was in prison.
When the proposal came, it was like I was fighting with my father. He said, “We can settle your marriage, or we can sit back and talk about you.” If he could wait, then I could relax, then I could catch my breath.
At the end of the night he told me, “You are my daughter, after the best of times and the best of times,” and it was easy to understand my father when he saw me sharing a love for my mother, who died four years ago. He also looked at my grandmother and said, “The question is, you’re going to have to make a choice.” But it didn’t matter what the choice was.
I didn’t think about what I would say. I wanted to go with the other person. I wanted to give my parents, my teachers, and my mother a good opportunity to talk about each other.
Now, in 18 years, I have learned and grown to love the same people for the same reason. Because of how much I love my parents, I tried to find my own path. When I was in high school, my parents decided to send me to the private school. When I graduated, I heard my mom was volunteering at the Teacher Leadership Institute. Now I have enrolled in that institute, even though there were over 3,000 students enrolled for the Institute. To me, these volunteer opportunities are priceless. When I volunteer, I want to inspire other students to get involved in service work.
I love my parents, I love my teachers, I love my teachers, and I feel very close to them. They always taught me how to be more than just a parent. They taught me what it takes to be loved by others. I miss and depend on them every day. I could never fill that void in my heart.
A couple years ago, after months of deciding to move from Oklahoma, I did both of those things. I entered the Institute. I graduated from the Institute, served as a Sustainability Master, and taught corporate how to be more efficient.
Over the years, I’ve learned how to successfully run organizations, teaching me how to set a company goal for growth, and helping others like myself. I feel blessed to be able to return to my parents. I look forward to learning all I can and finishing the Institute in an April 1st hand-eye coordination class.
– Gloria De Melo
']

Title: When exorcists need help, they call him

["Family Therapy Association of Utah (freelake) is hosting a free seminar for the entire family to share their thoughts on traditional catechism, non-medical techniques, and their healing techniques for difficult situations.
This year's seminar is the first time audiences, families, and therapists will be able to join in on the discussion and take the discussion all on themselves. There are some limits to the amount of debate to be in. So how do they plan on explaining all the differences between the ancient world and modern Japan?
From the psychology of catechism:
In Japan, the practitioner is a reputable person with special skills in research, home relations, and age. This person’s sense of inclusion and critical need to rebuild their faith have a place in the family as they try to cope with the harshness of contemporary society. This individual creates a protective mechanism of instinctive fear and vulnerability, with clear expectations of one another to become the next heaven child.
Whereas in the ancient world, the person has strict social norms, the person remains rigid, an angry and negative person, who only tries to say something concerning to others because this becomes his own way of coping with life. As an example, Mika Kaplan explains that when a man is supposed to be supportive of his children, they have no thought of him as an older man when that person is supposed to be physically, mentally, emotionally. This person’s problem is that he does not understand the situation, which makes it difficult for him to express anything considered negative. Catechism:
While modern catechism professionals have emphasized proper catechism practice, in practice, there has been little research to support the practice. This assumption should be implemented immediately, as catechism is the only way to truly know how the body functions, and it must be done in a responsible manner. This has resulted in many failures to test the healing processes as we know them.
The premise of catechism is that a person needs to reframe their perception of life to help them understand their role as a parent. While therapy works to help a person understand the negative aspects of everyday life, non-medical techniques can help the individual learn to cope with the tension of our surrounding society. This article discusses the positive, and troublesome, elements of catechism that might be useful to parents.
For example, families can also utilize the procedure of a non-medical counselor. What if there is someone who has a problem with their child and wants to advise them on how to cope with the situation? This person can also be explained to by making an offer to speak with him or her:
A counselor can help the child learn things he or she can’t, especially as the main focus of therapy. The counselor can request that this child also attend a “family” orientation session, a time to heal the child’s grief. This is a time to ask how the child handled the situation, and to talk about how they have learned to deal with one another.
If you want to receive additional information and resources for your family therapy experience, please reach out to Rob Schneider, CCTA president and CEO, at 2502-338-1111 and rob.scc@cctaan.com.
Note to editors: the topics covered in the seminar, which are not included on the website, are listed on this website and are available to a range of people from different backgrounds. For more information on this topic and how you can contribute on the website, please call me at the CCTA office (515) 30000 or go to www.cctaan.com.
"]

Title: 'Folks don't feel safe'
Generation:
['The people around me are, uh, frightened. I feel like we're being hemmed in. We're all overwhelmed with that feeling that no matter how many desperate meetings we make, we're not safe.
In the middle of the night, I found myself mumbling something I hadn't heard in about a week. It was Trump, who once had huddled in the Oval Office with the Russians as Presidential team, and predicted that a Democratic takeover of the White House would "establish a South America PR model where we can beat this one in the United States." The participants arrived about 11:30 a.m. PT Sunday, gave the ball to Washington's best economic wizard Domenic Sclavos, delivered a few minutes before their meeting. One minute later, we took the stage, as is the custom, to a standing ovation.
And then, it was the never-ending flow of reports and thoughts at every other one of the four corners of the political spectrum, someone bellowing with unabashed anger. Inventive at best.
The days of anxious days were numbered, but now, as Trump ditches the usual bright yellow coiffure, he always has his black suit in his hand and his sneakers in his hand. This year, it seems he'll wear jeans because he does have a special suit. He rocks his full chambray mane, literally. Trump's hair is styled and comes out in waves as he puts his lipstick on. A never-ending chant of "Trump no pants!" is croaking all over the room.
He's become a celebrity and everybody knows that for one moment. But once the cameras stop rolling, people will be shocked and hurt that he hasn't tweeted from the Oval Office instead of his own office. I imagine there will be a mixed reaction, emotional and perhaps mad.
The pooling of emotions is what we hear as we think of Trump. I was touched by the solidarity. But other people are less lucky.
I saw a woman in a wheelchair in the background, looking frightened and confused. This woman was clutching her little boy, who appeared to be in a really hard situation. She was more than happy to help and toss him an egg. Even after being hit by the man's vehicle, she is conscious and carrying a written statement; she looked up and saw the man was in a wheelchair. She could feel that he was a bright innocent one. At times, it appeared to her that she should turn her cat away from the maniac on the street, but the reality was far more somber.
She lives with her son, while he was in bed with another man. He's a man, with thousands of children, small stature, foot and hand, even in dreams and jokes. This was clearly his inner child, another adolescent molester. She knew there would be heavy coverage of him.
She welcomed the man into her home with peace. She wondered how he should be treated. She felt like she had heard someone else's voice to announce something important. Maybe she had heard his need for a baby or a rose and thought about sex. Maybe this was a young man in a happy light.
Maybe she felt happy and serenaded him with a song or was touched by a joke. She could see that he was trying hard to understand, as she did, what she was doing. Was he in a complete meltdown?
In this quivering, unconscious state, a woman's well-being is a picture of sorrow and anger, comfort and peace.
']

But don’t worry, please: If you want something bad enough — such as receiving a prohibited gun, or witnessing a killing or shooting — you have to give it time. But here’s an idea. Somebody, perhaps even one of the government’s most professional police forces, might use your guns.
It used to be that the police were considered a militia. Now that’s nothing to worry about. In fact, roughly 70% of Americans think police should think about shooting guns if they feel they have a right to do so, according to a survey released in November by the Pew Research Center.
And there’s been a lot of talk lately about more guns in our society. The 2010 best-selling Gilt Groupe — the flagship U.S. clothing e-commerce startup sold by T-Mobile — found that only 51% of Americans own a gun, according to Quartz, which compiled the survey with researchers at the Institute for Governmental Studies and the Pew Research Center.
Now though, the nation has one of the best records for citizen approval of gun ownership; the Reuters/Ipsos exit poll found that one in five U.S. adults have a gun, compared with 44% who still own a firearm. And the phenomenon affects those in Congress (one in every 23 Senate seats holds a gun).
Beyond the potential problems that come with gun laws, we can learn a lot about why some gun enthusiasts, people with guns, and people who would like to help combat them all have taken up weapons in the first place.
Government officials are engaged in “special measures” to limit how much guns the government can confiscate, according to Richard Pearce, a policy analyst for the Institute for Governmental Studies and former president of the National Shooting Sports Foundation, the arm that promotes gun ownership.
These measures, Pearce told me in an email last month, include weapon confiscation of arms by self-defense forces, as well as routine arrests of handguns that don’t meet a strict criteria — such as excessive force, bans on “knowingly carrying weapons,” or similar measures that prevent their use if someone serves “a risk of violent discharge or harm.” (They can’t be extended to alcohol.)
If these laws work, why not expand them further? More than half of those polled in 2011 by Gallup, which provides gun control research, said they’d use more of their guns for hunting, fishing, or any sport, compared with just 20% who didn’t. And it’s a trend.
Gun owners continue to run the country, Pearce said, and look for practical ways to safeguard their interests.
This summer, UNI will launch its gun control web site. There’s a similar site with options including online registration. The service has such safeguards as limiting straw purchases and notifying participants of the lifetime risk of carrying a gun. Meanwhile, the New Hampshire Association of Gun Owners will use the gun control Internet to reach its readers, according to the ANGA.
Get similar tips for getting a good shot. “They sell them all,” Pearce told me last month.
Still, weapons are a weapon, and we must take them seriously in other ways. Our neighbors to the north, for example, use more guns than we do. Men with guns have doubled their physical assets since 2006, according to an estimate in the Frank Miller book, “The Guns War.” But the reasons for the increase are largely semantic: Men are not very territorial, as do women; women as use of guns have been relatively stable, and men do a lot of hunting and fishing.
But if you want to defend yourself, you need a gun, too. “We have seen with more than 300 firearm fires in nine cities,” Pearce said. It’s no secret that property prices in the region are high.

Title: 25 of the most iconic photographs

['Why do you see such icons? You give me a poster on the stairs of a building and I think of one who exists on the other wall. My mom used to work in construction and I grew up in a big house with only four adults, which I am still present to this day. Because of my mother’s voice and my career, I think of the writer Elizabeth Gilbert. She had a brilliant mind and a cool one.
However, a time can’t be too far off from now. Just two years ago, I was at night while on assignment at the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture when I was covering a story about Jamie Oliver, chef of the Oliver Queens-run Oliver’s Kitchen.
Naturally, Oliver was on the scene and we were listening to a podcast, which was a pretty rude show from any journalist. It was one of those you wake up from a really bad dream and go running and say, I’m sitting down, like, La presciently, an emotional sort of jail break, and then everything kind of takes me back to the hotel and the rest is history. I stayed there, I saw Jamie Oliver eating supper in an elevator and I sat there, reading the contents of the paper, absorbing the composition, and I thought, well, OK, this is odd and I’m not sure I want to talk about it.
I was working on the blog. I was going to be there for one day, so I was going to be sat there and read the contents. I was working a site called The Reader, about the history of the memoir and wrote a piece on the blog for the piece, and I thought I’d read it and I would show it to people. We had a video show, and it was like, something needs to happen, and in that moment, we stood there and said, “Of course, we need to talk about it.” It wasn’t a chore at all, it was just really exciting.
Of course, it really wasn’t something I saw every day. But this moment had given me a new outlet to really be who I am, which was getting to know Jamie Oliver and the extraordinary people he was going to feed himself for the rest of his life. You make an acquaintance, and it’s hard. This is the way you are supposed to be. The person you are meeting and hearing and feeling this and feeling this is different from whatever it is that you are experiencing, and I have not seen anything like that in my life, and it’s always been such a privilege to have been a part of such a relationship, which was part of my experience at school, all of the things that I need to do if I’m going to be interested in anything.
And so I kept learning. I love going to museums, listening to cultural history. Sometimes you do that, sometimes you do that and you spend a lot of time interacting with these people and being like, I know that he’s amazing, but the thing is, and I hope people like him can find his passions, will find the passion, and those passions can feed off of him. And the thing about “The Reader”, which feels like it came at the right time, is that I was pretty young, and in middle school, it was hard.
People were saying this is impossible, this is impossible. We were thinking, how can we fix it? You can’t. There are different avenues, and if you want to change the trajectory and change the belief system then there is no reason to change anything. I was lucky. I have so many wonderful relationships with people.
']

With a little help from a man in a tuxedo, Amazon is hiring designers for the design studio, founded by the three executives who helped solve the problem of page building for Apple’s “iPhone 6S” and smaller models for Dell, MSO and HP.
“There’s a new cloud experience coming with Amazon — no staff, no language,” said Kathleen Sparks, a Seattle native and Microsoft strategist. “They’re an extremely diversified tech company.”
In addition to recruiting designers, Amazon is looking for a new administrator and security engineer, on a year-round basis. Here’s the part of the job description that says the company will ask them to help plan and “build comprehensive cloud services, business processes and key initiatives.”
Amazon has been trying to get into the software industry for a while now, has acquired a firm called Cloudflare for a reported $2 billion, and has been selling cloud apps like one created by Manhattan-based cloud information service StartUp 24.
The Seattle company still doesn’t have any deals in front of it, Sparks told me in a phone interview.
The company grew its CFO from a low-level position to a high-level, high-demand lead recently. By late January, he’d signed a five-year contract to become head of Amazon Web Services, a job title that’s a big tie-in to going digital, as Amazon is known.
But Amazon still doesn’t have any deals in front of it, Sparks told me in a phone interview.
Amazon is also hiring engineers to do big things for “the big house,” mentioned by John Peters, a vice president of artificial intelligence and data centers. “Our algorithms are testing engines that may manage entire cities, like in Dubai,” Peters told me.
According to the annual applications were due out on Thursday, but it’s not clear whether Amazon will begin hiring for that purpose.
By making tech-savvy engineers the lead, Amazon is helping it with one of its biggest challenges: putting a pipeline of tech talent into the company’s fields, Sparks said.
That means every boss is doing a much more strategic job first, figuring out where to get the most from their tech training.
“We see a huge, direct correlation between digital service delivery and the purpose of the job,” she said.

Title: The Kurdish women fighting ISIS

['At war with ISIS in Syria, the Kurds are supporting the ISIS children on a humanitarian mission -- in Iraqi Kurdistan.
Muhayla Sahim, a 29-year-old mother of three who lives in the city of Erbil, near Erbil with her husband and two young sons, said that she has been pregnant for nine months and is very confident with her pregnancy.
"In the beginning, I think I'm okay," Sahim said. "However, just as I've grown older, people in the city have decided to attack me. If I was better off than the children, which I'm not saying, I'm saying I'm fine."
Sahim is a representative of the organization All Pakhhtāy and is currently serving as an adviser to Iraqi Kurdish government and Kurdish-run areas in northern Iraq.
"Many of them have said that they have no interest in fighting against the Islamic State," said a Peshmerga official in Baghdad. "However, they want to draw benefits of foreign assistance to the Kurdish region."
With her husband, Ahmad Alilah, fighting alongside the Peshmerga, Sahim said her time in Iraq has been better than many of her friends' - including some very strong -- children.
"Sometimes we've asked, can you help us? Who wants to fight? It's very hard, because I'm very optimistic," she said. "I hope that in future, you will see that young women [in Erbil] will grow with their husbands and to better themselves. Being a protector against extremists is our goal."
Ashraf Abdullah, who manages the organization All Pakhhtāy, said he is making commitments to Erbil and doesn't plan to stay at home, though he said he is still cautious.
"I know that Islamic State will do well and stay where they are," he said. "But if I need help, I will come. It is better than nothing and when there are so many traitors, I want to give them strength. I hope and pray that they will stay if they are scared of the terrorists."
Another woman who has been giving birth for seven months, Nisina Dahna, said that as an Iraqi Kurdistaner, she is especially hopeful.
"I want to live with my children," she said. "When my children are grown, they will be my children. I am happy and I am very positive. I have to make myself happy, not sad or depressed."
[Tip: kal Rahmas is an Eunice of Kurdistan, an organization of journalists, politicians and others trying to document the history of Kurdish-Arbaeen-Iraqi relations in Iraq.]
']

Title: Girls behind bars tell their stories
Generation:
['Georgia Mama Tells of Her Detention
A young girl in Georgia’s Henrico County was given an unexpected source of inspiration in the form of a Facebook friend called Josh. Josh didn’t write about anything but high school, and from a hometown newspaper called Vietnam. Josh spoke to the girl about speaking to the black community and buying education for the youth, and about having something positive to look forward to.
So Josh got the girl a Facebook profile. She just had a message for Josh to invite her to cover the Henrico County school district. Josh told her she could follow them on Facebook, and she could follow them on Instagram too. And they’d read about the school district.
“Next page” was the next message and when the girl saw Josh’s picture on her timeline, she started to cry. It was a wonderful scene: Josh picked up the girl on the street, and took her aside, and cried about what she thought of Josh’s calling girl.
“After that, Josh set me a few days ago and told me he would support me in news coverage,” says third-grader, Carrie.
While he was talking to the girl about the boy he’d met, he remembered from a young school friend a kid who’d been beaten by a bully. “He knocked that kid down and pinned him down,” she says. “When that happened, he came home screaming.”
The teen had been attacked, and appeared healthy. She’d been held in a locked cell for over two weeks and kept in solitary confinement at the jail. She hasn’t spoken to Josh since, and she’s worried about what her future will be.
At the Henrico school district meeting this past Monday, there was a crowd of girls. Anna’s mother met the group, and said Josh went from a juvenile to being the youth representative to the superintendent. “I’m so pleased and thrilled,” says Anna. “It’s an honor.”
Josh, who has a thing for each of his friends, wouldn’t say when or where he got the information. At this point, he can’t turn the Facebook thing into some fashion statement.
His reason for wanting to go for a date? She likes the “we’re a few days away from my marriage,” but she has to get in touch with Josh first. “He wants to stay with me just to let me know that he really liked me,” says Anna.
Weeks passed, and the girls got there early. In the waning days of summer, they watched the Teen Choice Awards on Channel 4, where they congratulated the girl for meeting Josh’s family and who she goes to college with.
“I couldn’t sit still,” says Anna. “I’m not sure how she did that; she chose me.” Anna thinks it might be the last time Josh will see her. “I’m not sure if he’ll go with her,” she says. “He wants to say he left to have someone else go before he’s gone.”
The girl says, “You didn’t just tell her I got an internship?”
“Mama,” Josh asks.
Anna was available for comment as she swears she never lied to him.
']

Title: Up close in the brutal world of a female fight club
Generation:
['By Susan French
When the lead dancer in a club, the men, choose who they will attack. Just a few examples, here are the 18 men and women who have voluntarily partied with giant girls at a local strip club.
But how are the women’s choices based?
Because their breasts are too small to stab on the men, the male dancers’ choices can only go so far.
So when it comes to the male dancer, his decision is often (somewhat) about size. Or he just prefers his roles more liberally weighted so that his physical size matches his sexual orientation.
More than any factor, sex plays an important part in how men choose female dancers.
In 1974, the League of Women’s Bowling Associations (LWBA) had a list of the chief tasks for its forthcoming class of 50 female/female (male) contestmasters.
The three categories of the newly-formed club were character, athletic support and ideological representation. Each category was then divided into four classes to match the coaches’ first preferences.
It turns out that the campers with no sexual orientation or makeup were more than suitable for each category.
The group faced a host of challenges.
One of them was limiting exhibitionism, where fun was aimed. The skills involved involved men being too naked, making infanticide look less likely, and affecting our sexual orientation.
With the women and men equally judged, one could guess that their desires were one size fits all. A female battle club would also have difficulty challenging competition.
Then there was the question of who the sexes were sexually than the other teams.
In 1967, the League of Women’s Bowling Associations took its first steps into the female contest arena with its first group of female bambuses.
At its first meeting in 1960, the International Association of Bambuses and Matches for Women (IATW) said it would concentrate on a group of adult 12-year-olds, whether they wanted to be in a more “healthy” position.
In 1970, IATW’s retirement board accepted the recommendation of a new board of bambuses; in 1974, the following year, the Divisional Tourism Board (DHB) approved the formation of a bambuses federation, which was later made into the Association of Bambuses and Matches.
But the position of female bambuses has evolved quite a bit. It was at DHB’s 75th anniversary convention in 1988 that Racist Richard Richard, chairman of the Board of Directors, proposed the creation of the ABAAs women bambuses. It is unclear if the issue came up at the convention.
Today, Bambuses is a much bigger, more frequented group of women than the still-formal women bambuses. So, should the Bambuses show signs of disowning their power? Or should the dancing girls really be revved up about what qualities they want to bring to the contest?
In the spirit of the “we all work together,” we suggest the following simple ideas for men’s teams and women’s bambuses to provide for a smooth tournament.
1. Look for the men. You can “run up” each judge with their individual actions. Don’t be surprised if two-thirds of the time, they are running around in their scrubs looking for something.
2. Look for the men. You can “run up” the size of an men’s bambus or anyone else that looks like that. Only men can fire him away with these skills, and by weight, not sexuality.
3. Generate the men as inspirations. Follow their winning tumbles every time. Show them the power of the men and do not send them the “get out of the way” ogles of any females.
4. Compete for “spends you time too much of your time and time of desire” rather than more or less. This is some of the best and most important choices we have made.
5. Make your own judgments. Certain groups like bambuses and Bambuses form the very body of each group. They expect to win. No women.
6. Don’t confuse the sexes. Just because these two groups are like the males doesn’t mean they are alike in any way.
It would be good if every male and female bambuses in each grouping heard some entertaining opinions regarding its attributes.
']
