Title: Feds open investigation after CNN reports
Generation:
['WASHINGTON, D.C. (CNN) — A controversial child pornography ring that spanned Washington, Colorado, Arizona and Delaware reportedly has been shut down by federal investigators, the latest addition to the ongoing investigation.
The five men – all in their 30s – allegedly created online images of images depicting children and taught them to search for porn or distribution, according to the FBI. Federal agencies are still investigating, but believe the allegations come from anonymous conversations they have been sharing with others, and are also looking for any software for web browsers.
CNN’s investigation reached its peak on Sunday, when news agencies reported that the alleged, state-sponsored group could have had hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of online proceeds. CNN’s Erick Erickson wrote on Monday that the FBI “will question and seek to hold whoever sets up this operation for more serious charges than how much money these ringsters stole.”
Feds launched a special review of the case as part of “Operation Encryption,” an investigation that also detected links to Russia and the CIA’s infamous Silk Road Internet Exploitation Project, according to John Culberson, vice president of investigations for the National Counterterrorism Center, a federal agency that does not directly hold the president.
A government official told CNN that law enforcement has traced computer access to the FBI’s investigation, but the source in the case has not been released. The official said the FBI still has no leads and there are no suspects yet.
Additional details of the investigation are being kept under wraps by the FBI’s offices in Washington, which launched a nationwide search for the men late last year. Authorities say they are now exploring the terms of any civil or criminal agreement that could provide them access to the funds, according to CNN’s confidential sources.
The FBI already has been in the middle of an investigation into some of its more prominent anti-terrorism programs, which included a federal sweep of Washington, Pennsylvania and Oregon in the wake of the 2012 attacks on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya.
']

Title: Schools knew of trouble before student deaths
Generation:
['Students were being taken to the doctor for their treatment after a student fatally shot her teacher in downtown Denver's Columbine High School in 1999, said police and witnesses who spoke to CNN.
“I saw an instructional video so I called and there was it,” 17-year-old Melanie Jerome said. “I said 'These are the bullets and they're coming down.' My dad said I heard a loud boom and then I heard an incredible explosion."
1011 WIS
Wilson Elementary School, which houses the Columbine school, was cleared of wrongdoing and turned over to the school district, Denver Police Chief Robert White said Monday.
Authorities said authorities found Thomas Ramsey, 19, shot to death on April 6. Police originally said 16 shots were fired.
While the shooter was later identified, he is being charged as an adult with three counts of first-degree murder in the deaths of 18-year-old Dylan Klebold, 16-year-old Eric Harris and 15-year-old Dylan Reynolds.
Authorities announced on Friday that public school workers knew of problems at the school in 1988 but did not take disciplinary action until this January, when The Denver Post first reported on the new letter from school officials.
“I really did not know that there were problems from that point forward,” Louise Kile, then the assistant principal in the school, said in an interview last week. “I knew at that point at least in front of me and in front of everybody that it was not happening. It wasn't and I think all the teachers did.”
The school was a "students' learning center" where students used private lessons for basic learning, according to school district information.
Many educators saw students make the final decision to walk away before they scored the school on the SAT or other tests, making clear that a student had suffered a "tension that was toxic" but had not been subjected to harm from there, according to police and hospital officials.
“I don't know if I would have cared about that,” said Udon Newhouse, a teacher at Wilson Elementary. “I would have cared about I put that kid through the right mental health program, put him in the appropriate educational environment, were they had a picture in the school.”
Wilson's principal has vowed to find out what happened, and they have launched a campaign.
“I really believe and we are looking into the facts to find out what happened,” Principal Alberto Castaldo said. “Clearly they did have very good options, no matter what the outcome. And we will know if we missed something, given what happened."
Students at Wilson Elementary have been given "good guidance" on their role in the tragedy, Castaldo said.
A year later, a class taught by the school's therapist "detailed her thoughts, moral compass," said Betty Maltby, who has been employed by the school for more than four years.
“The way she treated Dylan and Eric, the way she was restrained with what she said was a pressure point, it turned out to be to get Dylan in a better mood and take him off the road. Her supervision went awry,” Maltby said.
She said in the third grade, Georgette Tettamontagne studied student learning after they were expelled from a high school in a Cleveland neighborhood.
“It wasn't just social media that she brought to attention in the class. There was peer pressure that all her peers would get excited about,” Maltby said.
When asked who asked Tettamontagne to take over class, she said: “I do not recall that.”
But one child quickly asserted that Tettamontagne, who is white, was her choice, according to London School of Economics expert Mark Halperin.
“I'm referring to an arrogant school administrator who can never teach anything and this is a case in point,” Halperin said. “What’s a logical person to do?”
']

Title: The real story behind those Planned Parenthood videos
Generation:
['Let’s be honest: Americans love Planned Parenthood. I used to want to demand the care of women, but women also need public discourse. They have the right to complain and they have the power, whether or not Planned Parenthood cares about their community.
(And I wanted the transparency.)
All we want to do is have people talking about abortion and contraception, and all that. Yet in a body of excellent work, high tech website Quartz, we know no better than US law enforcement that drones can destroy the backs of Planned Parenthood’s high-tech weapons collection networks.
According to Quartz, where the drones are used: • Where the drones are flying according to mandated protocols; • Where there are approved locations where drones can be placed inside homes; • Where the drones are being used to monitor, track, and temporarily monitor health clinics; • Where there are no cameras in front of the clinics and any locked cars parked in front of clinics; • Where there are no built-in cameras within a clinic; • Where there are no video cameras inside the clinics; • Where there are no recorded operators in the clinics; • Where there are no access portals to the internet; • Where there are no special-needs care centers and no such groups.
At first glance, it makes sense — because we Americans tend to be women, and they tend to be all about money and self-centered politics.
This is an interesting space, as Quartz makes a curious comparison to the #MeToo movement from which many of us have turned to fighting systemic sexism and violence against women. Whether you’re a woman or a man, a solution must be found. It needs to end the patriarchy, so it simply cannot wait around to give people a reason for voting.
In theory, no shortage of solutions exists. Consider ours.
We’re all vulnerable because we’re a woman, for example.
(It gets worse.)
And yet, there’s so much evidence that feminism is currently in full swing, primarily from the original unarguable (albeit subpar) kind that it was spawned in the early 1970s.
This isn’t a new idea, by any means. In fact, some feminist historiography tends to come up with a few precedents for the term. Harry Ford thought up the idea of the feminist chicken shop in Allentown, Pennsylvania. He went on to invent the “GoGo ‘The Beers’ Chain”.
Others, such as Stephen Colbert, whose bad nagging obsession about TV chefs’ kitchens become a fixture on Colbert’s nightly comedy program Colbert Report, is the perfect example of the kind of manhole bit that every late-night host pretends he’s on at all.
Their archaic ways of objectifying women would hardly look out of place in a pre-Trump era, where everyone likes a woman.
In this case, no one is going to stand for it, just as they did against voting rights and their civic activism.
• It’s an insightful analysis, uncluttered by the usual blather and blubbering, that none of us can quite get over
We need a woman to never be underrepresented in our institutions, even though we are still a minority group. What is worse — now that we know that everyone is secretly a bigot — than a woman being underrepresented?
I recently wrote about the notion that we have sexual relations between men and women but are so misguided about where we’re going that it’s useless to talk about the immorality and prejudices among our men.
I think it is the best-written material on what it means to be the person you want to be. For one thing, it’s about the sheer weight of the experience of being a woman and also about the odds it could have ever happened. It also suggests that feminism does indeed have sex.
Female justices need not know what they want to do but are armed with educated judges in an unfortunate feminist utopia: Rape is wrong, but it’s OK. It is intelligent, nor should they fail to earn the high honor of women.
(Not because it seems perfectly “American”, though, because not everyone likes their patriarchal ways any more. “American” could get caught speaking of what they did or whatever. Understating even an “American” is half the battle.)
Just like with sexual assault and sex discrimination.
Allyson Wong is the author of “There’s Something Going on: Inside the Politics of Victimhood” (Penguin, 2018) and a senior fellow at the University of Virginia']

Title: Sources: Disabled work program mired in fraud
Generation:
['Security clearouts at Tuesday's U.S. Labor Department elections stand out as evidence of multibillion-dollar fraud. Nearly 1,000 employees are claiming work permits issued by the Multi-Care Work Program Office (MLWPO) just before the election in every state except for California.
The U.S. Treasury Department is holding a closed-door hearing Monday to determine how much money that program actually siphoned from taxpayers to cover claims in about 2,700 of those cases.
Federal officials said the $700 million in alleged voter fraud this election season dates back to October 2014, when legislators in California briefly postponed a ballot measure that would have allowed states to take over a federal program. They said Republicans had used the program illegally.
Federal officials have worked from the beginning to catch fraud here. In California, Texas, Nevada, Iowa, Michigan, Illinois, New Jersey, Ohio, Vermont, New York, Oregon, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, New Mexico, New York, North Carolina, and Wisconsin, which are run by the U.S. Department of Labor.
Federal officials allege that about 230 of the 3,400 claims were fraudulent and there was a little more than $250 million in the fraud.
The goal of investigations is for victims to come forward and help prevent a repeat of such cases.
Secretary of Labor Sally Jewell told congressional staffers Monday that those fraud claims were handled "appropriately." Her department has received numerous emails, so far.
But she told lawmakers that "we believe that as the result of accounting for 'voter fraud,' legitimate Michigan and California claims had been processed and issued through noncompliant means."
Federal officials said reports of fraudulent work permit applications filed at the Wisconsin Bureau of Motor Vehicles were consistent with those made by workers at the DHS office in Oakwood.
Davis Efsinger, executive director of the bipartisan Michigan Citizens Against Government Waste, a watchdog group, said that auditors from the DHS agency said that out of the 1,500 (about one-third) allegations, about 44 percent contained all the claims that were submitted before the election.
He said that the Texas case is among the many such cases.
It was not clear how many of the claims were the product of the DHS fraud. The U.S. Department of Labor would not confirm or deny a report that stated only 19 workers had been arrested at the agency for filing false claims.
The department estimates that the program was targeted at taxpayers seeking information about voting rights.
A U.S. Department of Labor spokesperson said the agency had no role in the U.S. voter verification process. But labor rights groups, including AFL-CIO, used a different strategy.
A dispute over the alleged voter fraud at the Department of Labor has forced DOL to cancel Thursday's scheduled election in Missouri's 2nd Congressional District.
']

Title: Government says four cancer charities are shams
Generation:
['Kentucky state public health officials on Monday urged patients suffering from cancer and individuals suffering from other illnesses to avoid open carry fliers and the use of baggies as stress relief.
Kentucky state public health officials on Monday urged patients suffering from cancer and individuals suffering from other illnesses to avoid open carry fliers and the use of baggies as stress relief. The state's health department said it asked for people to stop carrying boxloads of pills and other medications to comply with policy that requires health care providers to store their doctors' prescription of weight loss and other medicines.
The department's policy says people who fail to deliver weight loss supplements and lifestyle changes will "proceed to treat or avoid the potential health problems or adverse events associated with such products."
"Most people recover easily after their drug or weight loss prescriptions and after their medication is evaluated appropriately," David Caruthers, deputy director of Kentucky's Division of Health, said in a statement.
The Division of Health regularly sponsors programs that ensure patients can avoid liability and issue tickets to medical providers who act as customers.
Kentucky Governor Matt Bevin responded to the state health department's request for unusual postage and packaging, saying the department wanted to keep its consumers informed about the state's collection and licensing requirements.
Bevin's office said health officials are forwarding the letter to the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's office of pharmacy safety and quality. "We hope that we will see the details soon," he said.
The Kentucky Department of Health also uses a nationwide database of insurance company issuers for handling the state's patient lists, and groups that accept information from the state Health Department for examination would be required to charge Medicaid patients less for the specialty services they receive.
Kentucky's health department has about 44,000 patients registered, according to state Sen. John Vernon, who introduced the legislation.
"I am confident this law will eliminate unlicensed providers who do not have a valid insurance policy," Vernon said.
Vernon said the addition of the new standard was a precautionary measure to force the state to maintain existing treatment protocols.
"There are three distinct levels of participation and the connection between that and our patient list has nothing to do with whether patients are sick or not sick," Vernon said.
']

Title: Hidden cameras show airport workers stealing from bags

With the U.S. air traveler shortage putting pressure on prices, one possible way to avoid the consequences would be to use private self-serve airplanes for everything from video chat to bags. For as much as $2,300 a month, a private-parked jet like this can transport 300 people. But for the maximum price, you'll need a camcorder to photograph the rest of the room. The Wall Street Journal reports that the unidentified men in the video footage began posing as occupants of a plane and pretending to be camera-toting airport workers. Based on the seemingly random footage, the argument is that these guards weren't all fighting terrorists on the flights, but American Airlines workers who use private cameras for their job.
The video comes from nearby Denny's, which has a plethora of private-parked cabins on its website. So technically, this video isn't exactly a scam either. But actually, if you do use private cameras to document the everyday things that go on in the airport, that can be a bit scary to watch. For instance, after the 6:45 p.m. news and the popular New Year's holiday celebrations were over, a pool of body scanners would have been going down in Orlando.
The real problem is there are 40,000 private U.S. jets waiting to land in Orlando this year, which can suck up airport labor. The tough and potentially-surprising prospect is this: when the labor force begins to falter, some of the hundreds of private jet-delivery jobs might be left to the temp workers. Would that really make a huge difference? Shouldn't airport workers have to interact with passengers?

We would clean ourselves up, maybe drive off somewhere to be with her.
Then she killed our little carousel. She'd cut the heart out of the bird (at least we told her. And she probably would have done anyway) and fill it with peaches, spring onions, basil, rosemary and ham that had been dipped into a puddle of almonds. I thought, “Wouldn't it be better?”
That was a year ago. But where do we begin now?
I was in college when we started. I was healthy, the only child and the only friend. Not far from my home on Boring Rd. So when she hit three car roads south of downtown Hollywood just a few minutes away, I panicked. I sprinted toward the school. Most of them had been ripped off.
I don't remember details—maybe lights out, too. Other cars at first light probably caught my eye, but I still couldn't get a complete picture. A couple of times, I let myself roam out in my car and up in the school. It was like a dream: weird, strange, strange. I'm a pretty kid and a pretty girl in the end.
Then one night, I turned to the news. I saw the story on the news. “A Salinas mother found her two teenage girls and their car on a Las Vegas street with a plastic bag full of paint and it had peeled out their front glass windows, left with the crumbled metal shell. The mother and her friends, now 14, and nine-year-old Natalie, who hadn't caught her eye, heard the news and did what anyone in real life can do: turn the carousel off. An hour later, she had already stuffed her yellow flannel pajamas in a French bag. Nothing was going on in our little town.
And it was literally! The news of what had happened came over the radio from California, rather like bad insomnia. My middle school cousins Andrew and Jason are here in Salinas, and Nora Cuskis was a witness to all this. Her aunt, Roxanne, joined her sister, Anna, in doing the circle around the carousel as well.
Anna thought, “Holy cow, now she'll have this plastic bag full of flannel: A severed head of a face, legs and arms? Isn't it human? All I can see in the dark is, for a long time, overgrown and chest-deep blue paint, a single little pipe in the round corner of the crossface.” She also saw the girl with the broken heart. She chipped it in with the cheek and a nice piece of amber paint that caught the sense of her mourning.
It took Nora a half hour to clean the carousel. The next day we drove to downtown Hollywood, and something strange happened. There was a carousel that night, a huge bowl shaped like a baby.
I started to search for it, then went back to the news.
Nora had interviewed two sheriff's deputies that day. The next day they came over, and she looked outside and said, “Dang, what if we had an ambulance the next day?”
The cops was stunned, because there was nothing else they could find and they had their two trunks. That's when I heard this news—let's give Carmelo Anthony a chance.
***
Nora had found a San Jose Sharks activity book that she used to help train killer whales in captivity. He'd found it back then. Now I was starving and thinking, “Geez, how do you know anything about this?”
What I found with Carmelo in a tank next to my mother's house was three puppies floating lifeless lifelessly in the water. Our little town suddenly seemed like Miami Beach, Florida. I probably wouldn't be alive to hear that, but Carmelo was nice enough to come right over to our house after we bought the page from our mother's sister. He really saw for himself, too, and if only he'd seen this open in the first place.
“Is this it?” he asked.
My mom looked at my clothes and my weight and she thought “Of course, just know right away!”

Title: It's not over: Veterans waiting months for appointments
Generation:
['NEW YORK — Waiting at the Brooklyn Veterans Affairs hospital at 36 Rockwell Place, waiting for appointments for up to six months for vets waiting for appointments, is hardly unusual.
Though it's only a few minutes to two in the morning, some of these veterans have waited longer than that for appointments within the time frame.
"It is crazy. They've waited 18 months to get an appointment for a vet," said Susan Wampler, who took medication to treat her acupuncturist after her son, a Navy veteran, was admitted to the hospital last year with AIDS.
Wampler said she was being treated last year for serious kidney dysfunction, possibly because of inflammatory arthritis, while at another hospital that specialized in geriatric treatment.
Within weeks of her diagnosis, she had to lie in wait for an appointment, even though she knew her son was sick.
"It's been six months, seven months; he's been out of bed since I went in," she said.
Six months in waiting means that waiting might not only cause further complications but also hurt the doctor's work, she said.
On the other side of the gender-based gentrification issue, some veterans say the annual wait times keep coming.
"I've heard a couple stories that my case managers have been asked to come out and say, 'We're having a busy session in 30 days' or something like that. No one's heard about this," said 40-year-old Aldrum Davis.
Davis was serving in the U.S. Army in the early 1990s when he was transferred to the Brooklyn Veterans Affairs hospital. He's been in a waiting list for more than 18 months now.
He said he also has run into veterans who request to go on long waiting lists.
"They're holding on to wait for months and months because they don't think they'll be able to get an appointment," he said.
The transition to gentrification has a long and close history in Brooklyn.
When asked whether he has ever thought of going back to Brooklyn, Davis said he's not sure.
He and his family also live in Manhattan, but says Brooklyn has been his home for as long as he can remember.
']

Title: IRS scam costing victims $15 million
Generation:
['(CNN) — It’s been called a tax scam involving the IRS or a Hail Mary pass designed to scare large numbers of voters into helping the IRS.
Experts say the scam that uncovered IRS officers posing as door-to-door campaign workers looking to vote, reignited the issue earlier this year with two high-profile audits of the agency.
The two audits turned up millions of dollars in fraudulent payments that appeared to stem from a Nov. 26 tax scam involving the Internal Revenue Service targeting nonprofits and religious organizations. The IRS says people affected likely won’t find out anything out of the ordinary in the future.
Unsuspecting voters are prone to repeat these stories once they learn of the scams, but make no mistake about the bad practice.
“People are absolutely fearful of doing something like this,” said Bob Shepherd, a consultant for the accounting and consulting firm Public Employees for Government Reform. “They have the option of bouncing a refund and then go to the IRS. … It’s not like all these recent stories about the IRS turn out to be true.”
Those who are more than happy to use tax preparation software like Microsoft TaxPortal and TurboTax, can check the verification and charge.
“Typically, if you click on ‘Get prepared now’ on your personal account as an easy way to shop and complete your taxes, you’ll then be able to engage in tax work without paying any taxes,” said Shepard.
Thrifts, chaos
Payroll fraud and giving Congress a helping hand are illegal in the United States and IRS officials’ reluctance to figure out how to begin providing refunds to affected people is frustrating.
Internal Revenue Service employees have been working overtime in the field not knowing if they will be accepted in the first place, said Al Smith, an IRS spokesman.
“One possibility is that in the event that a certain group of people have contacted the IRS, we will write a letter at that time to ask them to take matters into their own hands,” Smith said.
Taxpayers are split between taxpayers who act on advance claims, rather than taking the personal actions needed to file for an IRS filing.
“A majority of the complaint files are false,” said David Leipold, IRS deputy commissioner for commercial operations.
A sense of confusion about IRS refunds may be a major problem. And trust is at a premium for taxpayers who help prepare their taxes.
“People need to realize they won’t get a refund if they didn’t do it right,” said Linda Braga-Scafier, a tax counselor who oversees all forms of money management for a Chicago-based company that has four Federal Employees for Government Reform.
Taxpayers beware
“The IRS can always tell you if you’re a trustworthy person, but they’re not going to let you take matters into your own hands,” said Richard Schonfeld, a business development professional who helped develop the Allocate Tax Donation Fund.
The funds are used to help restore the finances of U.S. hospitals in countries around the world, as well as a U.S. hospital in need of building repairs and payments on its former hospital property.
“If it’s multiple people of various ethnicities who have contributions to go toward that hospital, which is this in the U.S., or it’s multiple localities, the odds of going bankrupt go up enormously,” Schonfeld said.
And IRS delays that, Schonfeld said, may force them to rely on fraud experts with advice about using information from the Internet for their intended tax return or passover.
“You don’t want to rush into someone else’s account. One of the ways you can do that is to get a tax form filled out, submit it online and process it,” Schonfeld said.
Be prepared
Urgent calls to the IRS help are being dropped from hundreds of different calling centers this week, the IRS said.
']

Title: School fundraising letters signed by fictitious boy
Generation:
['Please enable Javascript to watch this video
(CNN) -- Lorna McNeill's wide smile was apparent throughout her work, even when the school was named "The Good Schools for Your K."
The 35-year-old New Jersey native wants to be one of the first to take a stab at using that name, which she discovered in the tiny letter boxes she found on her doorstep.
"We sell things through Telling Stories," she says. "I thought, 'I don't even know what this is, I know that I'm a 13-year-old woman.'"
For McNeill, there was a time when she was "knowing that I would never be able to start the school when I was a little girl."
It was then, the newspaper she went to was often filled with similar writing.
Newly, the letters began growing in popularity in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Ohio as time passed by and the girl stayed with home school.
An aspiring computer programmer, McNeill became distracted at school because her mother not only looked after her, but cared for her as well.
"For the first three months I did what she did for me," McNeill says. "I could never walk. I could never run. I could not do anything, and I wasn't able to do anything. But I was able to stay in school, go to first grade, and hope nothing bad happened."
Despite her progress, McNeill and her husband hadn't been able to raise enough money for their second-grade classroom. They were starting out by giving gifts to the poor, too, so it turned out they were always getting mail after the holidays.
"I didn't know if it would be anything else, but it was just something like sending Christmas cards and wrapping paper," McNeill says. "I was so aware of the mail before I ever started that I even checked the mailbox when I picked up the mail, and it started to indicate, 'I don't care where my mail is.'"
Then, in 2009, there was just enough money that McNeill stopped counting. Not only was she nowhere near enough money to cover rent or food, she had to write a check to the church or buy gift cards and credit cards.
Suddenly, there was enough to feed the family. And she found her own meaning as well, in the phrase "On the road to greatness."
"I believe in something other than being good at what you do, even though you probably weren't good at it," McNeill says. "I believe in this environment where you don't put everything on hold for reason, but you still continue to push for things that are good for you."
For McNeill, the closest to the beginning of school was signing the letter "The Good Schools for Your K."
Now, more than 50 years later, there's an online community online. To help with local school fundraisers, see "SchoolBalls."
And to raise money for the future, McNeill is working with Autism Speaks of Greater New Jersey.
More information on Autism Speaks of Greater New Jersey is available here.
']

Title: Alabama town mirrors US class divide on immigration

TUCSON, Ala. -- In September last year, Willie Wilson became a college freshman.
He thought he would never have to go to college in Alabama. But after declaring allegiance to the Confederacy, his hopes were dashed.
"It was never, ever gonna happen," Wilson says, "but I had to fight it."
Now, he's one of 30,000 students nationwide who want to study abroad.
Fines also apply. And what about the kids?
According to Alabama Senate President Pro Tem Darrell Steinberg, schools like Montgomery or Blountville are dumping undocumented immigrants on other states.
"We need to move forward and push forward for these students so that they know that they will be recognized and that their status will not change in Alabama," Steinberg says.
Wilson himself points to US Customs and Border Protection inspections. And one of the methods that ICE found to be illegal immigrants.
It found that over 14,000 illegal immigrants are living in Alabama. What's more, 51.3 percent of the border agents were warned not to bring them in.
Wilson says the US Department of Homeland Security is a big part of the problem.
"I think they have brought on so many lawsuits and they try to take away the ability to work to improve our roads and school systems," Wilson says.
State Senator Steve Bair told CNN the problem is more than immigration. It's class divide.
"As some people might have thought, it's not only a matter of injustice. It's a democracy," Bair said.
"An immigrant should be able to get here lawfully," Wilson says.
And what about the refugees?
"I'm asking that all graduates be treated the same as everybody else and that everyone should be treated equal at the university, not to him," Wilson says.
But what about 3,500 refugees?
"I'm the person who's been brought here and they're here because they believe in their country," Wilson says.
With a higher degree, the degree will support them. And even better, most students will receive help preparing to become citizens.
Whether you're trying to start a business or have a criminal record, the answers will come. And those answers can be found all over the United States.
"Nobody stopped me," Wilson says.
He's been in the country for nearly 13 years. He believes America really is our best.
"It's an attempt to repress people's hearts," Wilson says.
']

Title: The truth about the white working class
Generation:
['By Natalia Reyes and Kate Gavin
We are under the gun to demonstrate at the Beijing Olympic Closing Ceremony how the so-called white working class has been linked to a significant influence on politics. After all, the WH has always been the campaign to give the elite a voice in the debate of American politics. And to do this in a predominately white race that has historically been resistant to promoting its own voice, has come across as an encouraging project of corporate America.
It does not make a difference how this so-called “white working class” has come to be portrayed to the nation.
The white working class that we have been talking about for years is largely composed of white progressives whose battle to oppose the Tea Party (in the large cities, what many call the “mockery of America”) was perceived to be as a rejection of white middle-class middle-class voting patterns, labor quotas, and small business policies. As such, these were the foundations of the Tea Party insurgency, but not because the party had now turned off traditional voting patterns.
But the problem in this economic climate has to do with its increasingly small states, because like the land of the open road in California, they have few commercial landowners or jobs available to provide for their populations.
Three small states — Arizona, Colorado, and Nevada — now have such huge middle-class populations. They are the most populous of the large states, and the fourth-largest in the nation. At approximately 14 million, these states are roughly 16% of the nation’s population, if you include a very small population of Hispanics.
But while the white working class stands shoulder to shoulder with these states, it is the massive concentration of white racial elites, from the Reagan-like “Top of the Hill” era, along with their small and medium-sized majority black/Latino population, that are claiming power to Western capitalist nations, while the lone white working class is becoming a menace to American capitalist democracy. They do so using socialized medicine, and the price of their natural resources is higher-income jobs and a national debt which has been swollen by white wealth.
The point of this country, at least insofar as it is involved in this nation’s economy, is not that its interests should prevail over the interests of whites. What concerns it in this decision was that the most directly affected and affected by the #MeToo movement, under the auspices of the Republican party in America, is a perception by white liberals of societal evil, i.e., a recognition that the culture and ways that facilitated systemic racism have not been challenged; and it is completely unacceptable for people, who are considered irrelevant and insignificant in the lives of white people, to be denied the same equal rights as everyone else.
It is understandable that many whites are waiting, and, in many cases, willing, and able to respond, if victims of sexual abuse by their employers, lies and teachings on the internet, and one thing they can expect is justice, but there are no excuses for past injustices and reprehensible practices, or the ugliness of political discourse. But racism, in a pluralistic society like ours, takes on extraordinary levels, and is totally out of touch with the American way of living.
We can go on to prove beyond doubt that the ancient guilt at the original white working class, through the misrepresentation of its culture and beliefs, is capable of reinventing itself in a healthy manner to meet the local needs of its population. The philosophy of Wallace R. Perkins — “Have one law. But have two.” — can help usher in this new age. Our collective culture, and the economy, is finding itself in the midst of something more significant.
']

Title: 2016: Last call for working class whites?
Generation:
['By Taylor Fergusson and Nevin Burns.CNN
New York, April 3 (CNN) - President Donald Trump should use the January Republican legislative session as a springboard to roll back the political setbacks that have derailed the nation's economically diverse communities, they say.
That's the view of former Trump adviser Stuart Stevens.
"Ladies and gentlemen: Republicans in the Congress still have about as many women and minorities as most Republican governors in the nation's capital," Stevens wrote in a response to the president, released by the Republican National Committee.
"Today, it is incumbent upon our Congressmen in both parties to pass the House and Senate legislation that will strengthen and modernize our economy and empower millions of Americans across the country.
"The very meaning of "I am therefore the Republican nominee" is being lost because the Republican Party finally coalesced around its theme of pro-life values," he added.
Stevens helped organize a campaign committee in 2014 to oppose the GOP's assault on abortion rights.
Congress has since withdrawn bipartisan legislative efforts on reproductive health and family services.
If Trump is winning new elections, the administration may be setting the stage for election campaigns as well.
"We may have the best positioned Republican Party in the nation at each election," said RNC member Richard Tisei, president of the National Organization for Women.
With one of the strongest federal records in Senate history, the Republican senators have one of the few Senate records that include female senators.
"The notion that they'd be able to say, 'We're not Democrats, we're not going to compete with any of the other party's policies and messaging was unacceptable,' are things that I believe were out of line," Tisei said.
The GOP holds 60 of the 114 U.S. Senate seats. Democrats hold all of the remaining 38.
Trump has waged a national campaign, expanding his national reach into the three states where he won in 2016. The president has taken to Twitter to discredit Democrats, calling them "corrupt" and "a disgrace."
In December, he paid a visit to former Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal, who led Georgia when the nation's youngest governor was killed by a bullet in 2017. Deal, who was the Republican nominee for governor, said he does not support banning abortion or universal pre-K.
As Republican presidential candidate Rick Perry won Oklahoma in 2016, Trump did the same with Texas after his state repealed its abortion ban.
In a conservative state, most Republicans dismiss these political setbacks as an admission of defeat. Republican Reps. Steve King and Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania, two Republicans facing retirements in next year's elections, still call Trump's message that women and minorities "political" and "sanctioned birth control" an attack on the wealthy.
There are concerns in Georgia over the election of Democratic Rep. Jackie Speier, who is due to face a competitive primary next year in an area that is predominantly red.
Speier did not immediately respond to CNN's request for comment.
A Bannon ally, U.S. Rep. Frederica Wilson of Georgia said that she and Washington D.C. Rep. John Lewis III, who the congressman represents, would not likely seek re-election this year.
']

Title: White working-class evangelicals: Christian values are under attack
Generation:
['Dayna Kerschner poses for a portrait in front of one of her TV set-top boxes outside her home in Alexandria, Virginia, U.S., January 24, 2019. Picture taken January 24, 2019. REUTERS/Joshua Roberts
WASHINGTON (CNN) - America is facing major new attacks from Trump and his followers on religious liberty and on the sanctity of marriage.
Among those attacks is an attack on religious freedom, according to a new report by the Pew Research Center.
The report makes a clear theme about what divides the country: a view of freedom being infringed on by the U.S. Constitution, in which some conservatives use religion to justify discrimination. It also says that values of honor, responsibility and decency and a belief in the sanctity of marriage often hide in the framework of religious freedom or contradict their other purposes.
"When it comes to the practical issues of race, housing, identity, sexual identity, sexual orientation and sexual orientation, those concerns loom large in areas as diverse as immigration, safety, property rights, job protection, preserving educational opportunities and defending social security," according to the report.
The survey was conducted Feb. 4-8 among 2,017 adults nationwide, aged 18 to 64. The margin of error for the survey is plus or minus 3.9 percentage points.
The report reveals a divide among evangelicals, a GOP demographic whose core vote lines up strongly with Trump and Evangelicals, where these groups account for 41% of GOP support.
The survey had an immediate impact: Since 1980, when polls first began tracking the gender identity and sexual orientation of American women, the prevalence of sexual orientation at a young age among evangelicals has risen dramatically. This pattern shows just how deep the divide is between Republican evangelicals who are committed to God's message and those who are disturbed by it. The survey has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.9 percentage points.
"So what is this shift into behavior that is seen across all of the groups? More distrustful of the political process," said Nikole Wright, associate director of the Pew Research Center's Center for the Study of Faith in America. "And also one of the consequences of that so-called 'disinformation" in this polarized culture is a fear of disagreeing with Donald Trump."
Roughly six out of every 10 evangelicals feel the same way as Trump about faith and democracy.
In a two-way conversation, 77% of Republicans and 85% of Democrats agree with Trump on the economy, according to the survey. Less than two-thirds of Republican voters see the economy as negative.
The Pew Research Center report explores areas of the public's concern about religious liberty, funding the health care system, defending social safety net and personal freedom.
The report also interviews experts in religious liberty and civil liberties to examine options for holding public officials accountable in a variety of ways. That includes actions such as rescinding a lifting of federal support for a program that suppresses forced abortions or extending government assistance to those without health insurance. The report also explores whether the political process is driving a wedge between those who believe in God's message and those who are worried about religious liberty.
In January, the Pew research found that Trump's supporters viewed the concept of religious liberty as "pretty much consistent with today's values in this country. But they don't fully understand why it's failing," Laura L. Hart, director of the Pomerantz Law School Center on Faith and Liberty, said in a statement.
"The rest of the world has gone full-throttle in tackling religious liberty and their allies are trying to be as effective and efficient as possible. The same goes for America's freedom of speech. Christians have never used religion to divide us, but they did try," Hart said.
']

Title: The shell-shocked white working class
Generation:
['By DAVID BURKE
They live in a world dominated by white Americans, home to four million black American workers and seven million white middle class workers. Young black folks, this generation, playfully plant pots, flume plants, landscape cranes, black people pick gold. Blacks never knew that white people were still patrolling the streets, prowling, groping, eating doughnuts, putting more dust in cans and those nights when loud plugs go off about Halloween. The camp was fought by men who had walked their black teams back to the streets on foot.
Still working hard and exposing their black family to the hazards of life off the street is what distinguishes the lives of U.S. working class whites from their white American counterparts, leaving an entire generation woefully unprepared to help their grandmothers fight for financial independence, to whom their black community might have been so unprepared to help them deal with the serious life aspects of having to live as breadwinners without the necessary shelter and aid they need.
Take, for example, Julia Wolfe, a 28-year-old actress and musician who was introduced to working-class roots by her grandmother, Anne, who shared a farm in Long Island, N.Y. You get the idea. As a five-year-old and single adult, Julia pulled herself together, married, lost her dad, went to college, worked her food budget, had time off to meet new people. By the time her mom died two years ago, her father’s job was gone and she’d left the farm, which earned her a paycheck from collecting signs and painting white white homes.
At age five, she started working as a waitress at St. Mary’s Church in Long Island City, a small establishment that operated independently, but it wasn’t at St. Joseph’s in Cutchogue that her grandmother, aunt and uncle were back. In that time, she forged a lifelong friendship with Anne. Anne lived in Long Island City long before her relatives, although she eventually moved to Central Islip, N.Y., for good.
Then at age 12, Julia bumped into Anne, who lived only about 15 miles from the community’s power plant. Anne had established a wood-fired stove, filling the stove with homemade buttermilk pancakes and bottled orange juice to use as longcakes. They had many life lessons. In the moment, Anne would put a golf club in the front seat and hand the kids a golf ball by a C. J. Quinn approach a speeding car. When the driver jumped out of the vehicle, Anne would casually slip the golf club under the seat of the car and catch them moving quickly.
After the tragedy of June 22, 1856, the family moved to Boston. Her father, Pierre, died on September 14, a few months after her mother, Lyphilds, had become pregnant with him. Shortly after, Julia offered her advice to Jacques, then 14, her younger cousin. Jacques decided to grow American—his birthing tradition since he was a child was born in 1907—and so Julia cooked sandwiches, homemade baked goods and used other relatives as a spare-for-school babysitter. Jacques was a tough guy, though those opinions did not sit well with her parents, as was Julia’s viewpoint. Her parents moved to New York to be closer to her grandparents, who were ultimately away.
When, in February, Julia and Jacques went swimming with their son Jacques, her grandmother, Martiney, left for Boston. She was arrested for demanding a parking ticket from a man with two overdue marijuana warrants, citing identity theft, then helped police recover her purse. Julia, who had long argued that the reports of the theft were not false, kept her account up until an ambulance arrived in Boston later that night and paid the ticket. She then had a flight back to L.A. and booked another visit to New York to see a celebrity chef and possibly her doctor, and enrolled in the fall program at prestigious Columbia University’s Graduate School of Business.
When she returned to L.A., in fall 2015, Martiney quickly lent her son a coat. In the summer, Julia took him to a local sports league tournament to go fishing. The exhibition of cartoon character Snoopy might also be heralded by blacks at a time when little kids have four times as many options on one deck as white kids. Yet Julia never wanted that gift. In an age of racial divide, it would be nice to see a toddler like her.
']

Title: Poll: White working-class Americans have complicated view of Muslim immigrants
Generation:
["NEW YORK, NY - JUNE 30: President Trump speaks during a joint press conference with Italy's Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni (C) at St. Peter's Basilica, on June 30, 2018 in New York City. (Photo by Alberto E. Rodriguez/Getty Images)
WASHINGTON — Economists for the American working class said the question of whether those who come to America to pursue higher education are good or bad immigrants has evolved over the past 60 years.
An American for the Young and of the Household Tax Reauthorization, the group surveyed from February to March on the issues of race, religion, nationality, sex and experiences. The public had a slightly different idea of whether immigrants could lead a modern-day society, according to the poll.
For instance, 66 percent of white working-class Americans said immigrants led a modern-day society, compared to 34 percent of respondents who said immigrants were bad and 22 percent who said immigrants were good.
“Compared to previous surveys, this is slightly more optimistic,” said David Wambach, director of the group.
The survey was conducted for Gallup and which did not ask voters about whether their views on immigrants are as bad as public opinion.
Eighty-three percent of black Americans polled had a negative view of immigrants — a similar number who said immigrants generally led a modern-day society.
But Mexicans in large percentages had a positive view, beating out students and Americans who said they think they were bad.
Is immigrants terrible or good immigrants? 51 percent said immigration was terrible, while 49 percent said poor immigrants were bad.
“The American working class is still growing from here,” said James Lopez, president of the Civic Alliance, which advocates immigration reform. “We hope we can get this conversation right.”
Among Hispanic Americans, the poll found the report was essentially unchanged. Even among whites, 57 percent of Hispanics said immigrants contributed to a modern-day society, compared to just 40 percent who said they contributed to a modern-day society.
Regarding personal views on immigration, just 13 percent of Americans said they felt some degree of effect on their personal lives, compared to 71 percent who felt an effect on their overall life.
Even among people with a high school diploma, 45 percent said immigrants changed their lives, compared to 51 percent who said so.
Trying to achieve a satisfactory living standard for Americans in all social and economic categories could be just as hard for immigrants as for white Americans. Fewer than a third of whites say their personal lives improved within five years, compared to 80 percent of whites.
"]

Title: Working class whites blame Washington, but still want more government help

A new study from the National Employment Law Project suggests that the number of working class whites with higher incomes, by the end of the decade, could have doubled in the past five years and another five percent by 2020.
In the job market, the irony is the large numbers who are able to find full-time jobs are speaking to frustrations they are not getting yet.
“Nationally, the white nonwhite population’s share of the workforce is falling, and increases in marginal poverty in the working class are likely,” writes FRP Executive Director John Mills in the study.
Other factors are to blame for these disturbing changes, the study finds, “all linked to the prevalence of violent crime and the declining use of social services.”
The authors also look at how to bolster the existence of a working class before Trump or Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump becomes the president.
Some welcome his long-shot campaign promise to bring back states like Pennsylvania and Ohio. Others have kept up with the Trump era, is labeling the tax cuts, and wanting to reopen all government entitlement programs, as extensions.

According to the study, 2 million Americans by 2020 will not receive universal health coverage. Many less wealthy Americans will have fewer children who have nothing but the dream of an ideal middle class. Those at the bottom will face limited coverage and larger deficits.

Title: The anatomy of a white, working-class Trump voter
Generation:
["It was now about 1,000 miles away in Santa Cruz, Calif., Monday afternoon when I checked on the polls. It was Dr. Seuss books and my new favourite amusement park.
Of course my focus was on about 200 of those few people who weren’t on the polls but didn’t give up when the polls closed. So all of a sudden I didn’t pay attention to which polling site I didn’t want to go to, but from the very bottom of my brain I knew that the election was over.
I want to ask Trump a lot. You said he’s crazy and maybe he thought we’d have a conservative president. If he was truly crazy, he would have beat Hillary and not re-elected because of the move on issues like immigration. I want to hear what a hard-headed conservative thinks. As for myself, if Trump was truly crazy, he would have passed up all the VP picks in 2000 or '01, and instead got Bob Dole and John McCain. Sure, McCain was a crazy choice, because he was at war with China and the Iraq war, but we have a president with crazy ideas who just barely survives this election.
I’m not sure what he thinks he should do. Is he crazy or just reflective of reality? Is Trump out of his depth? What do we do about fear? Shouldn’t he learn that the way we handle those of us who are in his orbit is to be smarter and more humane and ask these questions?
I think he understands that there’s a fundamental conflict, and he understands that by being like him we are much too arrogant and too stupid to care about anything else. He understands that leadership is not about jonesing for power, but what you have to understand is that the ascendancy of the ascendant leadership rests entirely with the electeds.
You’ve lost a lot, right? Is it me? I’m putting my trust in you, but I am starting to think the power shift may be a rather bold—and necessary—growth path, and you should use your leaders wisely.
You have led the charge to improve this country and of course you have been tirelessly kind and benevolent toward the Obama people. But let’s not blame Obama for everything that hasn’t worked out. He was an actual, good president and my all time favorite Republican presidential candidate had a crisis moment where he choked on turkey. And that can happen in this country. He would be so proud to see his legacy here, and take a shot at what it took him to have this country built, and to really give it a new lease on life.
And let’s get your guns out. Now? I won’t blame this president for the state of politics when it comes to misogyny, but it’s outrageous that they used this opportunity to impose a rigged system. I will say this: I’m glad that most of the accusations are dismissed as disproven. But remember that this country has never been challenged by a strong leader and may never be challenged when it comes to sexism, racism and the like.
Even if we ignore how Trump’s problems have come to symbolize how we’ve been rocked by a president whose politics create a confusing juxtaposition that he doesn’t understand as much as we either think he does.
I don’t say that because of the qualities that make me want to kill it. He was born to a black mother and white father. I don’t claim he learned all that from the experience. He’s a genius. People just don’t make them. But I will say the fact that he’s described as being like a monkey on his way into being president again is actually a testament to his unique brilliance.
"]

And people are afraid of the free enterprise economy.
This is not the glory days of Che Guevara or those pines that romp high over this recent frosty weather. These are the days of Americans achieving more relative dignity than the Nazis. There is a hideous value to this downward descent in the kind of ingenuity that eases the time between the time of Buddha and the age of the T-shirt. So far, the problem has been Obama’s white-collar economy.
I was driving home from work about 9:30 a.m. and found my dog in my car, a tent of the sort I build in our desert home town of rural Wyoming, without the Internet, because I’m trying to work that day. Rising across the Interstate into its sunshine-blue sky, Nevada’s state capital was mostly scarred for the festival of the dark, ebb and flow of work. I had only a few patrons, besides movers and shakers, enough to cover the days between New York Times Day in Wausau, Wis., and White House Correspondents Dinner in Washington, D.C. And enough to be an architectural gem of the town where grizzled, raven-faced, clunking sculptors mill and erect other marvels on the banks.
Sen. John McCain’s unwelcoming New Hampshire Primary had occasion to set a new example, one that could make Texas seem home. In every state, at least, most people in oil, coal and gas fields received some kind of free news service while watching oil companies slash capital costs. It is a polite, finely calibrated gesture to elevate a state that, for decades, had been considered the envy of the world.

The rabid liberal bloggers are leading a charade on the economy, and Democrats are losing ground to Republicans.
The revival of the free-market economy is a violation of the American spirit. According to Gallup, despite the late-1960s bankruptcies of a dozen major steel companies, the economy didn’t shrink until 1970. After 1973, the economy was growing 5.5 percent a year.
The landmass above Washington DC was cleaned up, boondocks were hauled, and something dramatic happened. Yet we still need the devolution of the governor’s mansion and other high-gear fundraisers that we now have to hurry to show off to friends.
Americans are endlessly complaining about the steady wind of government. They believe that governments give more value to people’s money than to their hard-earned security. They want a massive government welfare state that serves only the few. A new populist president needs to appoint economists who will rediscover the free-market idea that favors our talented, educated people at the expense of how much we actually work.
Gone, for a time. But they were a dime a dozen at the time. Americans want good-paying jobs, they want middle-class pensions, they want a rising stock market. And they want one that they can live within their means and not"]

Title: Help Iraqis displaced by fight for Mosul

KIRKLIN, Germany - Iraqi forces have detained more than four thousand refugees in the city, including nine Kurdish fighters, as they look to regain control of the strategically important Anbar province.
On Tuesday, an hour's drive north from the city, Kurdish-run Anbar governor Shamil al-Mulkhati told CNN that Iraqis carried about four thousand wounded people across the country. The government also said one person was killed in the fighting.
The Kurdish governor said Iraqi forces in Abar are now concentrated on the province and are dealing with more than 160,000 people, many of them displaced or involved in mass cross-border border attacks.
"Thousands are still still displaced and this is not an example," he said. "They are working hard."
One last milestone has taken place since advances began last month in Abar.
ISIS leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi declared the ISIS caliphate in all of Iraq and Syria in June 2014. The jihadists have seized parts of Iraq and neighboring Syria, and have called for a new offensive to retake more territory.
Rushing into the cities where the fighters had staked their claim last week, the operation is seen as the major piece of the challenge for the Kurds in their fight to take back Anbar, a city that once held Baghdad's city limits. Kurdish leaders say the capture of Anbar will help them expand their territory across Syria.
"It is not only Kurdish fighters. It is also eastern, predominantly Kurdish people who the regime and others who command responsibility for their own cities and territories, what they do and how they do it, how they maintain their independence and that will be critical," said a Kurdish Kurdish official, quoted by CNN.
There is also an effort by different factions to break up the city and control further territory.
The battle for Anbar has involved security coordination and an apparent exchange of fire, with around 70 per cent of the city settled before the governor from Anbar gave up control last month.
Since the offensive began on April 1, Kurdish forces have killed 5,000 fighters in Anbar -- a record number. They have besieged a senior officer in Mosul on their side. They are now trying to retake the provincial capital Mosul.
"We don't know how these side clashes work. If the situation continues what happens will just be a very bloody situation," said a Kurdish official.
Iraqi forces announced on Saturday that Anbar had captured three villages in the town of Apkan, making it the first Syrian province to fall.
That day, Kurdish security forces moved into villages outside Apkan, about 140 miles from Baghdad.
']

Title: Drug addiction: There is help
Generation:
['The road to recovery is particularly daunting for a patient who is intent on being violent, because everybody has a story to tell.
Violence is overwhelming and can make the feeling of helplessness disappear. Fines and jail sentences can force a patient to wander away. Abuse can be treated, with no doubt, without resorting to force — not even a harsher sentencing. The sentence is simply too severe. How difficult is that? Fines and prison time are the lowest proportion of recoveries with substance abuse.
Even life experience can make life unbearable. When a family has a huge influence on a substance abuser, the long-term consequences are often dire.
Now that I am a parent, I have to step back and look in my child’s eyes. The quick and easy way to fix a child’s addiction is to give it its ear.
(The main issue here is that, even in the most vulnerable of households, such people cannot see themselves on a much bigger scale, but where and how they can see is unclear. Too many people have strong personal biases or reason to disregard the consequences of their behavior.)
The most common suggestion for a child drug abuse treatment program is to keep him or her connected to an in-house treatment facility so that the relapse can be controlled.
Unfortunately, many people find that putting someone in residential treatment won’t do enough harm.
That’s why I love to help other parents by persuading them to help.
(On a recent evening, at the former Elkdale High School in New Hartford, N.J., I managed to attend an 8-month-old son who spent most of the time and money caring for this pet. He had no idea what his mother was doing when I helped him to clean up his stepfather’s car. I encouraged his mom to think about what would have happened had I not allowed him to get involved in all his social activities, even at night, before the baby’s birth.)
I didn’t try to help the man, but I did try to keep this beautiful creature — and to show them how damaging drugs can be.
“You’ve got some drugs, too,” my daughter, Christian, said to her dad.
I reminded her, “You don’t have a gun. How do you keep a gun? That’s what you’ve got to do for yourself.”
“There aren’t any guns,” my child responded.
“You have a .22?” I told her.
“You don’t have a .22,” Christian started asking. “Why? Why did you do it?”
To Christian’s relief, Christian nodded, the cop smiled and gave him a recommendation that he should leave the meth habit.
Soon after, our son returned home and me proceeded to drive him home to his father’s home in exchange for a recommendation that he abandon his abuse.
The kid looked remarkably distraught. I asked if my job was in saving this kid’s life.
“If it makes me happy,” I said.
“No,” he replied. “It makes me feel worthless.”
']

Title: The impact of a little boy named Youssif

["This story is part of a review of parenting articles about infants, toddlers and infants-to-be (and families as a whole). Here are some facts you probably never heard of.
MY baby boy first tells me he loves basketball and his mom loves football ... and he loves cheesecake.
My daughter has painted the front of her closet pink, and she tries to do all the baby stuff first.
MY baby is very spoiled, and he doesn't want a makeover ... he wants a mojito.
MY baby cares about the most important things in my life, and that's real life ... but not his style.
MY baby’s cooking is either adorable, clever or disgusting. If nothing else, he likes seeing how far he has to go before he can deliver a baby, and he has an instinct that a father could build a fine shield and get embarrassed the minute he needs it.
MY baby’s parents always tell him that he loves to bake, but only if he doesn’t get the salt around his eyes, and this wouldn’t be true unless he saw Mitzi how sweet she is ... Mitzi’s delicious, moist, tender baby marshmallow cookies, and Mitzi’s burning blueberry pie are part of his side of his own family ... and I almost feel bad for him to be so distracted, so stuck in diapers and hands.
MY toddler’s spelling game is one of the things that everyone wants their little angel to know -- so that they can go into puberty without hurting themselves. And when she’s given all the attention, she’s creating a field of fields of students waiting for her.
MY baby’s mealtime is the most delicious thing he ever said. He loves to munch on cornbread and to wash up at the office and at a sushi restaurant.
MY baby comes home for mom and dad to see him, and the focus is on him. The only thing he hasn’t done is accompany him to other doctors to see them, or to show him pictures of himself in the orthopedic and spinal surgery ward.
MY baby’s worried about all the clothes in his room, but he hopes he finds something for his future.
MY baby’s friends and family tell him to look for a girl ... until he realizes the same girl can’t stand to have sex with him!
MY baby is fearful of the room, as his parents teach him every night … but he isn’t afraid to watch her.
MY baby takes baths in the shower; he turns his phone off, and he loves to watch TV with his grandma. I’m always worried that even though he’s too young to watch, when he’s older, he’ll be afraid to say he thinks his mom hates him so much ... and it’s causing a disturbance in his life ... but I know it’s because he likes to watch it.
MY baby’s first year was really rough. He was so anxious that he couldn’t swallow even now and he felt bad about his new baby.
"]

Title: How to help educate girls around the world

As I wandered around Newark every morning on the morning train that was supposed to be taking me to Grand Central, I had not stopped for coffee or a bath, something I was doing to prevent the overpass crowding my back.
I'm sure that, as I prayed at the White House to be allowed to return home, my good sense of humor picked up. I was adamant about not smashing my toddler's head against the wall of the West Wing while typing.
My husband and I were seated on the West Wing and I was about to blow myself up and am about to miss my honeymoon and friend's destination, she was in the middle of an upstate high school assembly meeting with little to no money left to pay for dinner.
So much travel has preceded our honeymoon, that I found myself trying not to look so gross, staring out the window at the magnificent view from the Capitol that didn't seem so remote after a recent trip to Washington, D.C.
All it took was one hundred miles to reach my brother in captivity at the Capitol. With less than 50 miles to travel, I had saved up some cash and set my expectations on nothing but the life we had known.
We were headed to Washington for the U.S. Conference of Mayors' conference, which took place in May of 2005 in Philadelphia. Together we were promised beautiful destination. We had arrived in DC, met this guy our dad was planning to marry, and sent off on a whirlwind trip to Pyongyang to raise our three children. We took our passport to Pyongyang but to the horror of our parents everywhere we went - i.e., thousands of miles and four years back - our travel documents were sent back to our old lands.
A Foreign Desk, our back door was fenced in, and we headed to North Korea - where we were sure our sanity, our father's, our mothers', our much younger sister's and my husband's unconditional adoration would be greatly improved. We celebrated our one year anniversary with Kim Jong Un and President Donald Trump in that same year.
Since those events, I have thought a lot about other places besides the U.S. and what it meant to be raised in a place that I have never seen on earth.
I know it would be hurtful to let people know that you are from a more powerful country with more people, but it's not the only thing that defines us all. I remember the smiles and the tears we'd hear about the Iraq war and the steady stream of people who were shocked by what we had just been taught about their country.
When I think back to the one campgrounds that never open the rest of my life and whenever I go home to get work done, maybe I'll be referring to the staff in my own back yard. Maybe I'll be referring to myself for a second having forgotten what it felt like to live in a country without a desert who, as bad as it was, lived happily ever after. Maybe it's what I learned in Germany that altered me just a bit.
But for the most part, it's not going to be enough for me to trust and love my country anymore. There will always be people who will always believe I made the right decision.
A daily blog covering topics such as education, sexuality, equality, the minimum wage, how far we are from actual healthcare and the movement for global women's rights has struck me as the closest I have been to a country from Russia without human rights violations.
People in my country are still afraid of anything even close to the norms, laws, and culture that they were taught to be expected to live by. But when I hear stories of some of those institutions not having the freedoms or privilege they feel free to apply, I want them to stand up and say: we love you, but maybe we're wrong about something?

It's the beginning of a process that could draw the estimated 15,000 to 30,000 people evacuated from the city of Raqqa in just a matter of days.
The Government-controlled ISV said Monday that it had resettled more than 100 people, and that 10 of those students have finished their studies.
For some Syrians, waiting in refugee camps for a chance to return home is a fantasy.
"I want to stay here," said Khaled Aaby. "I want to stay here because I am Syrian, I want to go back to Syria."
Faced with a country without Syria, perhaps no one in their right mind can convince them to leave.
To prevent them from going back, Syria has presented them with 50,000 dollars for food, shelter and medicine.
"I need food to eat. I need medicine for sleeping. The government isn't feeding me. They have nothing for me," Aaby said.
"I have nothing. But there is help everywhere, God willing."
The U.N. in November released a humanitarian aid map of 20,000 potential areas in Syria, showing water, food, medical care and military supplies.
Even after the intense fighting and civil war that the U.N. has fought is over, it's more than likely Syrians will stay at home until American financial support catches up with the rebel-run city of Deir Ezzor.
Aid is already piling up to hold back refugees since one of them asked the international community for only 2,000 dollars to help him buy shoes.
Foreign and technical aid is still flowing in, even after the fighting and civil war has ended, but one hotbed of al Qaeda-affiliated organizations has begun offering help.
The 30,000-person Syrian Red Crescent (SRC) campaign in 2017, most recently helped doctors and nurses who were displaced by fighting.
The city's poorly equipped hospitals and port facilities have taken a beating, and the government has pledged not to absorb all aid. But also said it has the ability to provide medical facilities that Washington wants.
In Raqqa, the rebels have provided a platform for fighting and starvation. At least 180 civilians have been killed in what U.N. Special Representative for Syria and Iraq Tony Blair described as "under siege, besieged, some hoping for safety".
The Syrian U.N. Assistance Mission in Syria said on Wednesday that the Syrian side has been granted a 40-day deadline to make its three-month-old operations complete and is also planning additional aid for the embattled city.
CNN's Evan Perez contributed to this report.

Title: Sex trafficking survivor who wants to end 'The Game'
Generation:
['SOUNDERVAGE, Conn. (CNN) — Amanda Kaschitz of Maine is a survivor of human trafficking and may be one of the few victims alive.
Kaschitz entered the world of prostitution in 2002, selling people through her coke room. The 31-year-old has had many jobs over the years and has overcome great adversity, including having mental health issues.
Kaschitz is used to finding a place to live. Her owner pimps her about her name. That’s how she learned about anti-trafficking advocates but never told her customers.
When Kaschitz’s boyfriend is called for help, they ask if Kaschitz has some spare cash to buy her. She agrees but gets a long wait.
“I’m like, they don’t have anything to do with the owner. She doesn’t have the money for anything,” she told CNN affiliate LBT.
MNT spoke with Kaschitz for this story about being on a boat that approached Maine on a recent day. At the bottom of the water, Kaschitz said she was followed as she ran into her friend’s motel. She said she and her friends picked him up at the bottom and brought him inside.
Kaschitz was a little surprised that Kaschitz didn’t call her, knowing she just happened to be on a boat with someone she knew. But she said that she knew the other gang members who ran away after having a conversation with Kaschitz.
“It was very exciting and real because I thought they were friends. They were real,” Kaschitz said.
Kaschitz said she believed there was someone on the boat, but did not know what kind of friend the other gang members had. Kaschitz said the two of them were the one pimps would call to get Kaschitz into their safe place.
On Thursday, Kaschitz was getting ready to leave Maine when she stopped by a friend’s house in northeast England. Kaschitz stopped, saw the man and then let him go.
“I think he was the last one at the house, so I knew the whole situation was right by my name,” Kaschitz said.
Kaschitz said the man left and Kaschitz began asking if she wanted more. Kaschitz was skeptical but decided to trust the man.
“I thought, ‘Oh, that was great,’” Kaschitz said.
The victim said she was unsure why Kaschitz had people talking to her, but Kaschitz insisted they knew each other in Ireland. The victim said she called the man’s family. She said she believed he had the money to buy her. Kaschitz’s friends passed that information on to the other gangs. She admitted that she met the stranger over a drink a couple of times, but denied the man did anything to her.
She said the man threatened to pull her from the boat and had other offers. Kaschitz said that’s when she realized that she still had a desire to escape.
“I mean I wasn’t acting like a cavewoman,” Kaschitz said. “I didn’t really expect to get back on the boat.”
The man once spent $8,000 on a rescue yacht and protected it from thieves and thieves’ loot. Kaschitz’s friend was willing to lend money to her but wasn’t sure whether Kaschitz would survive. Kaschitz said she was determined to find her way.
Kaschitz and a friend last year rescued an 81-year-old who was cooking with his baby as she walked home from work. The 10-month-old boy was on a German national army plane when Kaschitz arrested him.
“I was like, ‘It’s really important,’” Kaschitz said. “I’ve got to break it, I’ve got to break it.”
']

Title: Workers fight for rights at 'ground zero for US slavery'
Generation:
['By Edith Honan
AN immigrant workers' rights group has painted a bright yellow "not to be trafficked" sign on South Street.
The sign says it "respects the humanity of the entire undocumented workforce, and the dignity of work which humanity deserves."
The group, called LEAFPA, has created a Facebook group that is buzzing with people taking up the cause of mass deportation.
So far about 500 people have posted their Facebook status asking for President Donald Trump to end the Dreamers deportations.
Employees at the rally last month gathered to march in Washington DC, D.C., and local authorities had to move stoplights around the area.
Shortly afterward, a DHS facility was evacuated. According to CNN affiliate WEWS, a DHS spokeswoman told them it was determined the department did not have the manpower to move to Atlanta.
Through social media, the Immigration and Customs Enforcement Department has seen a spike in enforcement activity, says Los Angeles-based lawyer Maurice Urbina.
Last year ICE arrested more than 400 workers from Latin America, according to his agency.
After the strike, late-night conversations with employees intensified, with many feeling they were being denied rights from immigration authorities, Urbina says.
As jobs opened up across the country, the NLRB moved its headquarters to Arlington, Virginia, to further de-escalate the same phenomenon, spokesman Rob Sebert told CNN.
In June, Trump tweeted that some people must be "visited at all times." He also said he would destroy "the American Dream" if he kept his comments a secret.
And then, in December, Trump said his goal was to "end the death tax" paid by "criminals and illegals" and "get rid of the damn Wall Wall."
It's unclear why the right-wing organizations have been so active on the issue.
According to media reports, labor rights groups have been working to secure the demolition of the gates at S&O and JCP&L stores, after it became known they were being used for the illegal immigrant labor industry in "full and processed housing."
The visit in late March was also timed to coincide with a D.C. immigration hearing on the issue.
']

Several of the most famous National Chocolate Company products (from Campbell’s Lunchables to Chocolate Mojito) are among the varieties I taste in this year.
When made in-house, the glaceless chocolate chips, dark and red, are usually fruitless – something that I often think is the sensible strategy to save energy and time when eating at a restaurant.
Go down to the holiday market with these tasty treats, and by the time you wrap around them, you’ll have a chocolate graham crust.
And the recipe calls for one of the most startlingly simple “Deck the Halls Chocolate Triple Chocolate Smash.”
Zotah Rusted Ruby Mix for Chocolate Creme

6 mrs. shredded coconut

Zotah Rusted Ruby Mix for Chocolate Creme
2 Tbsp. unsalted butter
1 tsp. vanilla extract
2 cups blackberries
Directions:
In a large deep skillet over medium-high heat, melt the butter. Add the blackberries, 2 tablespoons of the butter, wine vinegar, hot sauce, chili powder, hot sauce and chili powder and cook, stirring occasionally, until the water has melted, about 5 minutes. Stir in the vanilla extract and 2 cups chocolate syrup. Cover and cook until a toothpick inserted through the center of the toothpick comes out clean, about 1 minute. Simmer the chocolate mixture in the pan for another 2 minutes and taste for the dark chocolate. Let stand 30 minutes before serving.
