Title: Thousands forced to work on Brazil's cattle ranches
Generation:
["Posted on By now, everyone’s bummed away about the soggy coverage coming out of Brazil’s cattle ranches after the winter — but what about long haul? That’s exactly what happened on Monday when angry people flooded the private ranchers feeding them with liquor in March’s northern Cauca state.
Some fought the “soggy” run-up in cattle numbers, trying to pull down prices as stocks were “bouncing back” and the cattle go from getting cheap stuff — the feedlot could not turn them all “dry” — to more desperate sales. Others, however, made people laugh, exclaiming, “There’s no need for ‘soggy’ cattle.”
Where people in the midst of this rodeo feel that lack of survival need not be a concern, the million-dollar question arises: When will it come to letting everyone down?
READ MORE: 'Twilight of temperate America' kicks off more food wars
The solution? Companies like RT Las Carras de Cauca, which distributes cattle through the process of every slaughterhouse in Brazil, step up their prices, cutting feedlots’ required numbers from what were typically 10- to 50-ton per head to help the ranchers outbid the premium prices. RT Cauca’s prices stand at $1.05 per head per kilogram (3.5 pounds/ kg) in the northeast of the country.
To test that, cattle in the round, a slaughterhouse (or private ranch), will always be a good proxy for cattle to eat when cattle are busy — and it will often well overkill.
Thus far, the industry has responded by lowering feedlots’ required numbers even when cattle are required to die. These cuts will increase prices because they can accurately reflect how those slaughtered cattle eat into the feedlot. But there are many ways to raise prices because cattle are eaten, and the cattle simply are not chicken feed.
In 2016, farmers slashed their feedlots’ numbers and made a poor financial decision. When the rand currency did not improve in August, it drove a mass exodus in local cattle to big cities to provide cheap labour to the hogs.
The cattle of then-President Dilma Rousseff’s Workers’ Party (PT) came from Central America, and Central America’s biggest producer also now controls a big swathe of the country.
“The new administration is setting the total modern world wage for the PT,” her party described its recent presidency in Brazil’s Workers’ Party media guide. Rousseff called on people to buy beef because her policies could save the economy from years of cheap prices: “Cattle stands to be a new nightmare to live with,” she said in a recent news release.
Rousseff's people’s money were tight and she badly wanted to boost exports of grains and chemicals to central Asia and the Middle East, which also produces dried grain. But things did not work out.
By selling scrap together few profitable parts of the process, they also bought feedlots that avoided laying hundreds of thousands of small operations to save themselves. By the end of the year, they stood to make 70% to 80% less of the $3 billion they invested.
The fact that cattle were so scarce doesn’t mean the issue is hopeless. When purchasing cattle is an exercise in cheap labour, people get to enjoy it — and it’s part of a good overall social and economic strategy for the post-Brazil kick-off. When it’s already a real and present problem — like the usual men and women out, rich and poor — people can work themselves back into the game.
Sluggish prices could allow the PT to avoid such problems and steer the country in the right direction.
READ MORE: Mexico's Cinco de Mayo tribute: Why Mexico's elites are too rich
"]

Title: The children working in Cambodia's brick kilns
Generation:
['When Jam on the 24th round of World Snorkeling Championships opens up next month, there's going to be plenty of hungry young people who have no idea how to survive the 32 weeks they spend on their absolute living conditions in a brick kiln in the Cambodian capital.
Starting April 13, walkers from around the country will try and avoid the huts. According to the Cambodian government, the resources that they use in the kilns are five times more valuable than the land they have to occupy for the day.
The kilns, which allow local people to leave their homes to live in harmony with the land and people, were first developed in the late 60s and early 70s, but the villages around the area have been dwindling since 1994.
The government estimates that around 75,000 people live in the old brick kilns with most leaving as soon as they are able to move out. The kilns provide accommodation, food and water for 400 people.
The kilns were originally intended to educate the public, but have since become targets for militants, according to Human Rights Watch.
The Cambodian government is in talks with Belfocal, a non-profit organization to train 6,000 locals to become soldiers in 2019. Belfocal is expected to give them military training, food and hygiene products.
CP: Isn't war an inevitable social injustice?
MPG: Now it's war, but we know that war has consequences and a war has consequences. People have lost the land, their homes are destroyed, they have children who lost a sister, who lost a dad, who lost a brother... people from many different ethnic groups and cultures and cultures living on a communal situation can sometimes have problems.
If you go and bring your kids, we should teach them how to educate their brothers and sisters... We have to teach them how to use drugs... We have to teach them how to abuse drugs... they have social and economic problems like this.
CP: Wouldn't human trafficking be devastating?
MPG: The last thing we want in the world is an ever large collection of people and children on a single piece of land. Cambodia is the only place on Earth where human trafficking is not a problem or a problem we have to educate our children about the dangers of it.
CP: Isn't it a nightmare for anyone, especially children, who have to live with the consequences of their actions?
MPG: There's not a country in the world that has not taken a lot of effort to educate its people. They don't know the consequences of anything. We're not going to let them go to the trash. The situation is so desperate, it will take a lot of planning, dealing with it ... We need to come together and allow the right people to come in and help these children learn, who maybe could possibly be better at education."
CP: What are you hoping to do with the money that you've invested into the projects?
MPG: We definitely need to go back to the old bricks, but even that money can be used to learn how to construct a new brick kiln.
CP: How do you plan to accomplish these programs and programs?
MPG: We're going to build bricks factories. We're going to build brick factories in our area. We're going to create these are the full access to the natural resources of Cambodia to build here.
CP: Will technology be part of your projects?
MPG: Not necessarily. We're going to give them tools and to connect to people to help them connect with a bigger voice.
CP: Are the eight kilns getting as much attention in terms of the official effort?
MPG: I don't know if that's the case. The reality is that when we travel as many countries and places as are right now, what we do is something that if you don't bring it in, if you don't understand the work that's needed to provide a modern life for people, it hurts you. So we're going to do that and we're going to bring them in.
CP: Are you planning anything major for 2019?
MPG: We'll plan to do big things this year and they will start like this. But when the money runs out, we'll depend on the word from the government. Our biggest priority is with the children and the village, and we're going to take it from there.
']

Title: City of Tomorrow
Generation:
["You likely have never heard of City of Tomorrow, because the Amazon-owned automaker is a public idea: one that would bring all of Canada’s municipalities under one umbrella, free from municipal government and economic meddling. The idea had largely been in the works for years, but was actually dropped out of consideration last year.
But one change is coming: Amazon is planning to roll out the system in communities around the country. And the first countries to implement the system would be in Spain. A week after its Paris launch, Amazon unveiled its first autonomous city in Toronto, which already boasts a number of other kinds of smart city projects.
Amazon has been developing a system of connected cities for decades, and has long campaigned for people to create a sustainable model to operate in them. Now, it plans to develop autonomous cities and share their technology with the public.
As with now existing municipal systems, these cities will give cities and their mayors a “giving voice” in decisions on issues like parking, student housing, and transit. For cities like Toronto, many simply can’t afford to have to care for themselves, while making the system more efficient and competitive.
It’s not like there’s much of a need for technology here, but a smart city will give cities a new way to serve public services and give residents more dignity and opportunity. The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission has proposed how to define “global connected city,” and how cities should prioritize local concerns rather than individual areas of expertise.
Officials at each local municipality have a plan but no defined funding goals yet. Cities can waive some of their taxes on urban forms, though, which will allow them to give themselves good relations with the public.
With a proposed system that adds more creative choice — and the kind of innovation that City of Tomorrow will provide — these communities can start to approach the concept in a more thoughtful, flexible, and comfortable way.
There are a number of objections. Cities can't just serve themselves. Everyone needs to think small, and urban delivery venues are now getting a lot of funding, but building infrastructure requires more imagination, innovation, and cooperation. The challenge in Ontario has been to convince communities of how well it will work.
By all indications, the federal government will not support city and community-planning autonomy in the long run. But it’s a very different policy than our current finance priorities—and one that should have a much bigger impact than what’s currently moving around in cities around the country.
"]

Title: Queen Elizabeth postpones engagements amid coronavirus pandemic
Generation:
['DUBLIN (CNN) — Britain’s Queen Elizabeth II began her Diamond Jubilee tour on Wednesday with a somewhat cryptic message on Instagram which she shared alongside a collage of portraits and photographs depicting the storied monarch, first lady and children of British royalty.
Prince Philip and Queen Elizabeth and Prince William, accompanied by their wives, and their sons, were expected to attend ceremonies and lunch at St. Mary’s Church in Belfast before heading to London for an Easter visit.
They will be joined by the queen, 96, and Prince Philip, 87, in an ornate reception at a tea party hosted by her grandson James Dyson, the founder of Rocket Internet, Britain’s biggest online retailer.
Queen Elizabeth called the royal life “the great enterprise of my life” on Wednesday, according to a post on her Instagram account. It was first shared online this week, on one of the official fan pages of the Church of England.
“Our monarch will receive her first piece of art from a dear friend outside our walls,” Queen Elizabeth wrote on the message. “Her wish is to all beautifully sum up the joy, for the people of our religion and nation, that since childhood the lives of all people have been paved with love.”
The precise cause of the virus that swept Britain in December is unclear, but it is thought to be related to the human papillomavirus (HPV), a disease that spreads through biting, not just coughing, contact with the skin or spreading to others.
HIV is commonly spread in intravenous fluids, sex and rape between adults who come into contact with infected people.
Campaign to eradicate the disease grows
The 2017 coronavirus pandemic in the Caribbean and around the world
The coronavirus was first detected in Western Europe in 1984 by a severe cold epidemic in Scotland, and has spread throughout Asia and Africa in recent years.
The virus is transmitted between people by infected flesh and other organisms, mainly from laboratory-confirmed virus samples, mostly rodents.
The virus is believed to be passed by an infective insect, provided an infected person undergoes fever, cough, runny nose, swollen glands and red-shirted urine.
Attempts to control infection by opportunistic infections, said the World Health Organization, have failed so far.
British MP and Labour leader Ruth Davidson, who chaired the parliamentary health committee’s health and social care committee, this week welcomed the work of scientists “to try to rid ourselves of the terrible disease which drenchs our nation.”
“We desperately need to do more, particularly to educate ourselves and the wider public, and what we know about this virus is that it spreads through contaminated blood, urine and faeces. It also spreads by virus in very highly infectious disease from infected people. We need to do more to stop it and we must do it better,” she added.
She said the outbreak “causes a massive sense of urgency that British public health policy is desperately needed and to step up in order to keep people from spreading this disease, and the work needed by the health system around the world.”
Meghan Markle, who is dating the Duchess of Sussex, was “deeply inspired” by the plight of the disease, she added.
“As recently as last summer I read the messages from activists around the world urging me to protect young girls like Meghan, who could potentially become victims of this infection,” she said on Instagram.
“I’m an activist for girls’ rights. I hope the current outbreak will help save lives from the virus.”
Britain says quarantines between people infected with the virus will allow them “to recover” and the EU’s Animal Health Commissioner, Cecilia Malmstrom, told the BBC “to finish” the work on caring for the survivors.
“It is in our interest to ensure we do everything we can to achieve the best outcome,” she said.
']

Title: No-deal Brexit is back -- and it looks more likely than ever
Generation:
['The “no deal” Brexit debate over the next few days will almost certainly determine what happens in the end, National Security Advisor John Bolton warned Tuesday, although not before coming under plenty of questions about the UK’s ability to move quickly on a “delicate cliff edge”.
Bolton later said he expected an agreement in which Britain issues a neutral exit certificate to EU27 governments in return for reciprocal assurances of withdrawal.
He predicted a government will end up in a position which “certainly would” be determined by a Brexit deal.
The U.S. president made his remarks after discussions with European Council President Donald Tusk, who was due to meet with Bolton at the Council’s summer meeting, on Tuesday evening.
“I think it is going to happen, we are going to make the decisions,” he said.
“The sooner it gets to that point, the sooner we can get there, because we have some good consensus in these discussions.”
Bolton, who was warmly welcomed by both the former foreign secretary Boris Johnson, and EU vice-leader Amadou Diallo, seemed more relaxed than he had been in weeks.
He said that it was not that different from Brexit talks with the U.S. at the beginning of the year.
“What is more interesting is that there is a good consensus on the way forward,” he said.
“There has been some tentative progress on this front over the past few days.”
Bolton stressed that the U.S. was committed to working together to secure a deal, following the Irish border issue which could lead to the use of force if Britain was unable to leave the European Union.
However, the vice-president also said that the “durable confidence we feel would be about a no-deal” Brexit and that the EU must ultimately agree to keep open the possibility of limited divorce talks as the Irish border issues were clarified by government officials.
“It is very much going to be up to the British government to decide what we do on the ground tomorrow and when we do get there to deliver on the real concrete Brexit terms that we gave them in our negotiations,” he said.
British Prime Minister Theresa May signaled no new talks on the Irish border if her government faced a no-deal Brexit, but signaled that such talks might be revived if there was a release date.
Bolton said the question was whether the deal “meets the lowest possible standard” - one he saw as precedent for a no-deal – at a meeting with May and her team.
“If there was a few years off, I doubt what the period would be like with a 30-year Brexit,” he said.

Title: UK courts will now livestream divorce proceedings
Generation:
['There’s hope after long and shameful battles with the law: as a result of recent rulings in the U.K., divorce proceedings will now be livestreamed on social media, the law firm that deals with divorce cases says.
The public use of livestreaming will be prohibited until a court has addressed the issue or a ruling is reached, the law firm Lucie Murphy says.
“It is easy for small cases to get trolled,” Murphy said. “It’s difficult for complex issues to get resolved.”
Weighing in on both sides of the law’s #NowThatSex scandal
About 12.5 million people watched the livestream last week in England and Wales, according to figures from social media website Twitch. More than 100,000 people watched it in the U.K. — including nearly 40,000 people who downloaded a 25-track-that-of-credit-only tape of the case online, on Twitch.
Mark Collins, who is representing 59-year-old Billy Coyle in his dispute with ex-wife Sophie, said livestreaming of divorce proceedings provided an opportunity for people to make an informed decision.
“We had the opportunity to break the taboo of the male and female splits and get justice for others who are less fortunate,” Collins said. “The reason why divorce proceedings can be relatively unsound is because people generally don’t believe in divorce.”
Collins said lots of women’s and men’s customers watched the video, a rare selling point for online video-sharing sites such as Twitch.
Murphy said that although some people watching a video of divorce proceedings could potentially be recorded on their phones, it is an opportunity to change the way they approach matters.
“It’s such a taboo subject,” Murphy said. “Often, divorce litigation can’t be broadcast so that conversation turns into publicity.”
Legislation to regulate the livestreaming of divorce proceedings will go before the Department of Justice soon, he said.
Careful tracking of ‘slaves’ online
Dismissing broadcasters, Collins says, is not an uncommon request in the U.K.
Some 660 million people, on average, watched a video of divorce proceedings in 2018, he said.
Lee Stewart, who created a website for livestreaming divorce proceedings and created a video piece to help people track their videos, said it “would be nice to change the story of divorce.”
It’s important “to understand that (redacted) broadcasts and performance codes need to be changed so this doesn’t have to be a taboo subject,” Stewart said.
Collins said publicizing the legal age of consent in divorce proceedings can help people get a better impression of the two sides.
“The awkwardness of ‘spending your weekend laying on a mattress and trying to get some kind of financial return is no longer acceptable,” Murphy said. “It’s so unaccepted that some people may, in some cases, prefer to just watch one person complaining that they might not get to spend the money they wanted.”
Unlike their counterparts in the U.S., where divorce proceedings are not commonly heard on television, Americans generally feel they are being heard, with Jones v. Martin Herce (2013) that became the United States’ first televised motion picture to take in the case.
“Forget (France) about black women saying ‘I’m so sad that God didn’t send us to prison,’” Collins said. “I think the U.S. government is evolving its stance on issues of justice and equality.”
The Law Enforcement Interception Plan for the United States and Britain has produced a guiding text for the use of livestreaming in divorce proceedings in several countries. While such services often are free to stream on Facebook, Twitch host Erin Kerr said allowing people to provide feedback to publicists, lawyers, police and judges about the outcomes of the most pressing legal issues or their roles is important.
“We need the public to be aware that this legal information and service can have a significant impact on their participation in the process,” Kerr said.
']

Title: The coronavirus has officials running the world from home
Generation:
['Starting with a computer in the dentist’s office, where we’ll quickly walk through a strange space filled with other people, viruses and all the other useful technologies that computer technology is supposed to replace.
Interactive machines, maps of the world so you can see what’s around you and software to help you navigate the world.
But the coronavirus this year looks to be so serious and so deadly that officials in several countries are already scrambling to figure out just what it does and how it works.
An outbreak of the virus in Germany has made Germany the latest country to succumb to a coronavirus linked to the 2011/2012 Linus Pauling outbreak in humans. Officials there say it’s the biggest and most serious outbreak of coronavirus in the world.
About 32 people have died and 2,611 people are being infected. An outbreak of meningitis in Jordan has linked 20 to an outbreak in northwestern Nigeria.
The virus dates back to 1991, but experts say it’s only now that public health officials are exploring how it can spread around the world.
“Clinical research is underway,” said Angela Grosch, lead scientist at the Wuchwein Institute for Global Health and Development, which works on the disease in cooperation with the private Austrian Plurademia Research Center and at the Lübeck School of Infectious Diseases in the Austrian capital of Vienna.
The government is investigating while the European Union is checking whether other countries can test their machines before testing people for the virus.
But the thing experts like Grosch agree on is that coronavirus in old science tools means the public health system is at risk.
“Countries don’t always have the scientific abilities to manage viruses,” said Grosch. “You could have a coronavirus in people’s homes. If there’s no structure to sanitize them, people have the option of locking themselves inside a room and talking to their neighbors about what kind of help they need.”
']

Title: This small island chain is leading the way on hydrogen power
Generation:
['Some private island chain in the Cayman Islands, set in an archipelago of 18,300 islands spanning six continents, has found an intriguing new way to power its power — and can do it without fossil fuels.
The island’s 3,700 people can withstand the carbon of road exhaust and coal in any amount of up to 3 miles (5km) of stream, public records show.
The power on the island’s portion of 8m solar panels is enough to power 17 separate boilers. Built using old-fashioned coal, it is now one of the largest private island plantings in the world, according to marketing at the company RMAX Insight.
The island is a key leader in integrating the various elements of solar energy into its power system. Everything else in the system — from power tariffs and other insulation costs to replacing old insulation — is adapted for a high-use climate, said Reginald Jaely, CEO and founder of RMAX Insight.
“We have seen only another possibility — that these add-ons could be feasible and cost-effective,” he told CNN.
He said the island’s population of about 190,000, about 11,000 of whom live on Orkin communities, is similar to those in Berlin, a suburb of Washington D.C.
“We are the newest renewable power producer in the United States.”
Some efforts at creating high-efficiency solar arrays on the same island’s base mostly succeeded but others went nowhere, according to research by the International Energy Agency (IEA), which supports climate change targets.
However, in 2016 the IEA declared that any such solar market to date will represent a significant saving on the grid when built on near zero solar energy.
In July, the institute released a report predicting that a lower global emissions market generated in 2020 will provide energy savings of $20 billion — on top of the net price savings generated by the industry itself.
In addition to powering a small island with 3,700 residents, RMAX Insight said it had partnered with the Scottish city of Glasgow to create a 100 megawatt solar photovoltaic array on the island, using a PG3PP battery instead of traditional fossil fuel.
The solar battery it received was derived from the company’s Finnish technology, making it the only megawatt-scale renewable energy company that is currently using recycled material in its solar-powered turbines.
']

Title: CEO of huge UK company says he has coronavirus
Generation:
['LONDON (CNN) — Cyril Potts, CEO of UK telecoms firm Sky , says he has coronavirus, the latest piece of aviation news he hasn’t heard since it was reported last summer.
The recent reappearance of the highly contagious virus, which is linked to frequent flight cancellations and disruption to travel, worries Potts and Sky, which launched a cybersecurity crisis last August.
“At no stage have I heard about nor do I have any credible information about coronavirus from Sky,” Potts told CNN on Monday.
“Sky is taking all the necessary steps to protect everyone involved in this business from this threat and its harms,” he added.
The telecoms chief warned against complacency. He announced Sky would start stockpiling aircards next week to protect up to 18,000 Virgin Mobile users and 20,000 BT customers.
Potts said at the time the airline was being criticised for not fully monitoring passengers to make sure they weren’t flying with a defective airline.
“Balkan passengers and Virgin are even more likely to receive this exposure,” Potts said.
Sky and Virgin previously agreed that as many as 4,500 people could be exposed to coronavirus, which can strike anywhere during the flight, and Potts said was going to get more attention than its existing blobbering game.
“I do think our virus should be around around so that we make sure we can manage these alerts and go about doing exactly what we need to do,” he said.
“We’re just a range of little operators who’ve been doing a tough job. What we’re getting wrong is Virgin is getting the help it needs to handle the situation.”
Petersen Global airlines boss, Paul Tease, was still refusing to take responsibility. He has not been seen at meetings with Virgin over its immigration policy.
“I’ve asked my staff not to talk to Virgin about the death of a customer,” Tease said.
“If people have had contact with our third-party lab you should be given all the necessary care and take the necessary precautions.”
Sky told CNN it would take a “relentless” response to any recent deaths.
The cabin crew employees who are likely to die of an exposure have not been notified and the crash is not yet seen as a direct blow to morale, the company said.
Last July, it was thought that 200 people had died. Today the figures is 70 to 180.
Of those, 18 people died from virus infection.
All of them were Spaniards, but it was also thought that 37 of them were Austrian-born.
For Sky, it is the sixth such first-hand confirmation. It is suing Virgin Media, the British phone company responsible for flying Virgin, for £200million.
Virgin has already paid up. The company, which like Sky does business in most markets around the world, will be in court on May 8 to decide how much it is owed.
In a prepared statement Monday, Virgin said it was “committed to working with stakeholders to implement the protection we already have against risks”.
“People also have real safety concerns, which is why we have taken a number of measures to protect our customers,” it said.
“The response we have received to this has been very thorough. We have a robust authentication system and have a large proportion of our customers using simple code on our apps – ensuring that any consumer account will be encrypted.”
The company said its approach has been the most promising so far.
The first-hand counts seem to confirm this as Sky workers have continued to try and board up the infections – just 14 people have so far died.
“We had an incredibly busy few months last year when we issued this ill-advised warning and today we are being treated for the deadliest of these,” Potts added.
“These individuals are very hard to see.”
']

Title: What 'Wolf Hall' trilogy reveals to us (opinion)
Generation:
['By Victor Rizzo
If there's a book about James Andrew Wolf Hall, it's called The Wolf. The story about a young London playwright who recounts his own misdeeds to his family and upper middle class family—whose love (or at least, navels) play out through the narrative—is astonishing enough, but it's almost as rich and complex as Hamlet's "The Catch," starring Ryan Gosling, and Gladiator's "Master and Commander."
And somehow, that's not difficult to recognize.
It begins with the story of Pomeranian Kate, born with cavities where babies and mothers were able to float to birth. Her mother, Mary, an upper middle-class housewife, and her mistress, Helen, an alcoholic mother, survive the summer before Pomeranian Kate was born, and grow up to become a part of her family's family.
Pomeranian Kate, who initially sits next to the queen of the house, acts as a more important character in "The Wolf" than her mother, who is is a servant to Pomeranian Kate who lacks interest in social groups. Before Pomeranian Kate's birth, Mary was a pioneer in the family business, serving as Pomeranian Mama. Mary Magdalene was the wife of Scottish writer Henry VIII and he was aware that it would be a bloody war when Pomeranian Kate was born. But she has survived it, and will remain a model for younger generations of beauty.
It is an "animal romance" about an impoverished family fighting the extremes of economic and societal prosperity, as Mary Magdalene looks into the world of George and Georgina, and how wealthy Georgina would have married Elizabeth for the privilege of being the queen of the house. One of Pomeranian Kate's admirers, George Barris, has been hired by the queen to advise George on what a monetary and social burden to endure as the heir to George's throne.
But Pomeranian Kate is not only wetland watcher, but, one of the princes, would be an especially exciting prospect. A whole quarter of George's life in the house—or at least the house life during which he belongs—has not been well, and the marriage is at best tortuous. But this tells us something about Pomeranian Kate, or another struggling middle-class woman.
The upper middle-class women in Britain who had to fend for themselves are not just a sort of "jockeying for position" almost to get by or feel comfortable making money. In a cramped house and her own place of employment, Kate has to be protective of her daughter, Mary—a younger woman who is called by her own name when she eventually becomes the Queen. While Mary Magdalene looks for Mary around the castle, she has little contact with Kate—only a handful of intimate text messages.
"What's inside her? [Kate] doesn't know, is anything at all," says Pomeranian Kate, as Kate tells him of her dislike for Mary. "I can't handle it, because you haven't given me a reason to."
Instead, the queen is replaced with another one, which is, essentially, the mother of the house. Mary stands on the throne, and her sister, Princess Mary, is still living there. But there is a desperate feeling for a new person to get into her place. Mary thinks of herself in this new person's eyes and in a way, Pomeranian Kate represents her own memory of what a life took her when she was a child.
Pomeranian Kate smiles up when he tells her he's recovering. "She was lost," he says. "I'm not . . . Googling. . . ." But he has a problem with her memory, he writes, which leads to a whole column of chauvinism in front of him.
In the book "The Wolf" he tells Mary Magdalene that he gave her his vote for her too. What if she voted for a latter-day version of the old brother, Ned?
The plays themselves are exquisitely conducted, and keep all my favorite things to mind: "Death in Paradise" is Kate's title poem; "The Sandwich Theme" is a report on the short lives of Jamaican journalists who found themselves being enslaved for publication; and "Enter the English English Wine" isn't too long for a whiskey-soaked being; all are included in "The Wolf."
I have to confess to being bored by reading the books, and "The Wolf" is not the book I want to read anymore. I would like a horror novel and a drama of Richard III. I still want to read "The']

Title: Airlines extend waivers, adjust schedules for Europe travel ban
Generation:
['By Lynne Roorda
WASHINGTON, April 5 (Reuters) - Airlines extended travel restrictions on Wednesday as the United States Supreme Court granted final, but no final, rulings on the travel ban, sending a mixed message to travelers seeking exit permits.
The Supreme Court gave final rulings on a case on the legality of President Donald Trump's directive allowing restricted foreign travel to people from seven predominantly Muslim countries and which was challenged by state attorneys general.
The decisions followed a ruling on Tuesday by the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Washington, which said the travel ban should stand pending a ruling from the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York.
The ruling covered cases against airlines and airports nationwide that had argued that the travel ban was constitutional because Americans are allowed to travel to the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act of 2000.
Monday's ruling was issued after earlier challenges to the travel ban had been filed in federal courts in 18 states.
Trump's directive affected travelers from seven Muslim-majority countries and banned them from entering the United States unless they were a candidate for citizenship or family that is not related to a particular country.
Trump wants to build a massive wall along the U.S.-Mexico border and to deport more than 1 million undocumented immigrants whose immigration violations are being prosecuted at the border.
In a letter to congressional lawmakers, he urged lawmakers to "restore the rule of law," and last week he opened what he termed a "politically motivated" investigation into alleged voter-suppression attempts by his opponents.
Trump's order bans travel to the United States by most nationals of seven mostly Muslim countries and barring all Muslims from entering the country. The travelers are mainly Sudanese, Saudi Arabia, Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Libya, Somalia, Sudan and Yemen.
The lawsuits filed by those countries over the travel ban stand pending a higher court ruling, and it is unclear when the appeals court will hear the case or whether it will grant final rulings on the travel ban.
The review process has been highly complicated by challenges to Trump's authority under the Constitution. Congress has no power to overturn the president's order by law.
But the Trump administration already had applied for expedited review under the special immigration judge mandated to weigh the president's options before issuing a travel ban.
Congress granted some relief to travel to the United States by halting most class action lawsuits that had sought travel ban relief.
']

Title: Europe travel ban: Will it be possible to sneak into the US via the UK?
Generation:
['BRUSSELS (CNN) — “Passengers might go through an airport checkpoint” to get to Europe, officials announced Friday as they set out suggestions for ways travelers are being prevented from going to the United States via the UK.
The European Union has traditionally closed the Atlantic Ocean to the sea to avoid disaster, but because of the countries’ divergent traditions, there have been few restrictions.
“We have been inundated with requests from people on the United States side for what we call seasonal hassle, this problem where travellers see a terminal or a security check as they come in,” chief official Florentijn Hofmann of the Europol, the European law enforcement agency tasked with enforcing European laws, told CNN on Friday.
Hofmann added that a coordinated, local crackdown would “enhance the integration of customs and law enforcement at the borders”.
The EU’s Christmas holiday has generally opened days later, much like the U.S. government tries to advance its nation-wide travel agenda — only it’s not going to be as seamless.
Three countries introduced “fake” passports to gain access to the United States via the UK in July.
A German official in charge of sending financial and logistical goods to Germany, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom pointed to a UK decision to abolish all fake passports as a factor that could potentially leave all citizens in the UK in violation of the trade laws.
Once it becomes law, the use of digital identities or digital-only passports will all disappear, he added.
The German government had to submit a bill for the legislation to parliament in the Netherlands following delays from politicians and EU member states.
While refusing to speculate on how long that timeline might be, Hofmann hinted that a number of variations of the system might be involved.
“We’re trying to gather more data,” he said. “There’s a big risk in this, but we’re also not going to give an estimate of the length and type of disruption, which we think would require a lot of time.”
There has been a small uptick in the number of UK-bound journeys by EU citizens since the UK reverted to the EU travel-ban, which has been credited by the CBI and others as a “proportionate response” to the problem.
However, Hofmann warned that when the rules apply, people need to be aware that they might not be able to go to the United States because the travel document still exists on the European system.
Once they do, travelers will be able to enter their vehicle online, which will help ensure they’re not screened or killed.
If they’re not, they’ll be able to leave the car.
The transport minister Gerard Canete told Associated Press that the country of origin for several European ports have been suspended for checks, but the shutdown will still take place, he said.
Cetteete also made it clear that it’s important to allow people to hold passports in the hands of the time when they’re most vulnerable.
']

Title: Biking to work appears more dangerous than other commuting options, study finds
Generation:
['(CNN) — Cycling to work is something that bothers up several people who can't stand boredom in the middle of the night, says a new study published in Psychological Science.
Most people end up skipping cycling, and those who skip cycling struggle to find parking, and are unable to do much of anything. But the 2-year study sheds light on what is meant by a "bad habit."
Using data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), researchers think it's a sign of boredom that bicycling allows people to safely try to ride. That's in part because Americans ride more than 190 million miles every year.
That can lead to bottlenecks -- or, in some cases, chronic traffic congestion -- that make it even more frustrating for those who will stop to pedal.
"Biking for a problem is certainly one of the most frustrating activities, a reality that improves just as we all experience it, and provides us with alternative ways to engage in these activities," study author Andrea Cullen, a psychology professor at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, said in a statement.
To test the correlation between cycling and depression, Cullen and her colleagues recruited 1,076 adults from the United States and the Dominican Republic. In the study, they quizzed them about how much they travel. (A large national sample is designed to improve its accuracy.) After their finding, they asked them to complete a specific trail across the U.S. that they cycle to work.
For each trail, they asked them to set aside two minutes per day. Then they took a half hour. If they completed the task on time, they would go on a 10-mile commute.
The researchers found that people who bike to work tend to spend more time cycling than those who don't. As a result, they left more time for bicycles than people who bike to work. But cyclists had a higher rate of fatigue fatigue than people who don't bike to work. They also reported a higher rate of headaches, and had an increased body temperature over the study period.
The researchers believe that sharing information with one's primary co-worker or co-worker's boss is helpful in building a positive relationship between cycling and the work experience.
"If shared information is beneficial, this could also improve the quality of the experience," said Kathleen Gray, assistant professor of organizational psychology at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina.
However, "it would be difficult and economical to recruit a co-worker on a bicycle who is spending some time on a bike," Gray added. "Many in the transportation community prefer to stay on the road, unless they live in poorer areas."
The work-experience comparison isn't aimed at novice cyclists or those who can't easily switch to a crowded and crowded ride. In order to contrast the divide between people who cycle to work and those who are less physically fit, the researchers also tracked riders' exercise habits.
The study shows that cycling makes people happier, even if they're on the most crowded roads. Cyclists who reported having enough exercise on a bike were 45% less likely to report decreased symptoms of depression. A study published in The American Journal of Preventive Medicine, earlier this year, indicated that bicycling could help people who've struggled to control their stress.
At times, cycling can be very stressful, experts say. Some biking marts have turned people into subway riders, taking sides in sexual assault. And driving can cause distractions when listening to music while driving, and late at night, researchers say.
']

Title: Catherine Opie: 'Beauty has to encompass more about the human condition'
Generation:
['
The phrase “beauty has to encompass more about the human condition” might surprise some people who may not normally associate beauty with cigarettes, electricity or violence. But Joanna Honick, a professor of behavior at the University of Missouri, Madison, was adamant that the phrase doesn’t make beauty optional.
“It’s been my philosophy since I was in a modeling program, and I’ve never actually heard it,” Honick said. “On television, someone will say that Beauty is compulsory. It’s not when people come to a club.”
Honick pointed out that the US has virtually no such requirement or reason for beauty.
“That’s how much beauty it entails,” she said. “If a skin-care product is actually worth something, a doctor will label it. That’s most commonly considered ‘beauty’ when it isn’t necessarily made to be more desirable, or not at all.”
Hilton Moms and Papas like Honick agree that beauty is needed more than ever, but can it be so controlled by Mother Nature?
“In addition to that, we had a lot of beautiful people just talking about loving the color of their skin. So if you want to put beauty out there, that’s what you need to do,” Honick said.
Still, Honick worried that a rich and diverse body is the only way to be celebrated. She urged people to exercise more, to get through their day, and to become taller and leaner.
“To me, everybody’s got the same issues, and that’s why no one wears sunglasses, no one wears grey slacks, no one wears bright colors,” Honick said. “It’s all about acknowledging beauty and respecting people.”

Title: Photographer Kyle Weeks uses his medium to show that manhood in Africa is not a singular image
Generation:
['For two years, a young photographer for the South African military has been documenting the war in the Central African Republic, but he didn’t have any idea what he was going to display his works of art.
The images, which had been shot with the latest GoPro Hero cameras, included that increasingly strange, exotic mix of contemporary and old shots showing individuals – both white and black, male and female.
“The results had to be unreal,” Weeks said. “We sat down with our friends and said, ‘Let’s stop making these.’”
FULL COVERAGE: Faces of AIDS-affected people in Africa
Instead, he had his work originally used in the Vietnam War and by the time he got to Africa, he was struggling with the effects of his photo work.
Last year, the photographer started taking some notes to see how his art had been created in an attempt to find the demons left behind when combat was over.
“I realized the story of war—the war and genocide—is incredibly powerful and moving,” Weeks said. “I had become very disillusioned and frustrated with myself, and it made me realize I could not be an artist any more.”
So Weeks decided to use the medium to show that manhood is not a singular image.
“I wanted people to know it isn’t that I’m an object only,” Weeks said. “I am not an artist. My work has a human aspect, it does not exist in the image.”
Observers in Africa
Camera technology has supported the use of photography as a source of social media literacy. And throughout the development of the Internet, photographers have captured messages or social topics that quickly come back online.
Self-portraits are the fastest way to document what’s happening in Africa through digital hands-on experiences. In order to help people understand what it’s like to work in one’s own country, the emerging digital technology, IKEA, offers tools that help people understand that each other, or even what it means to be “fully awake.”
In addition to the modern digital photography, cameras designed to protect against car accident complications through their clarity and coverage can also be a double help. In fact, a 2014 study in the journal Vensiology shows that people get picture-posters if cameras provide a better representation of their position.
“One easy way to make a communication tool like IKEA frames and documents an incident that happens in Africa; through an app, an Instagram, a Buffer, and the ability to post it by yourself and your friends,” Weeks said.
Furthermore, he has picked up mobile technology to aid the facilitation of communication through digital phones. Right now, many people in North Africa look forward to when they may be able to interact with the camera in Africa.
Dissemination of Photography
Many North Africans for whom photography isn’t or doesn’t bother them believe in photography, but these images work because they’re “always interesting,” in Weeks’ case.
“They often simply picture an object and reflect their imagination,” Weeks said. “One thing that shouldn’t be emphasized is that certain images may be sad, violent, or disturbing. In other words, photography can facilitate communication between ordinary people and even normal people—but it is also important to add context, to make the images that actually relate the medium more appealing and inspiring.”
Still, as Weeks and his colleagues use the medium to share his personal experience with one another, it has a positive impact on the quality of the African manhood and its impacts on others.
For him, that translates into active, well-being for the rest of us.
“I don’t care if I write poetry or read ballet or anything else. I want to be active, to have a high quality of the youth’s life. If I want to get back into a job and see how it would affect my dad and my daughter, then I can,” Weeks said.
']

Title: Photographer Daniel Arnold visits the center and sidelines of the world's largest gem show

The MacArthur Foundation announced in September that Arnold — “The Charles P. Bryrd” at the front of the Wynn W Hotel — will be meeting up next week with its executive directors to discuss issues such as offshore tax havens and ways to grow the industry in the U.S.
So Arnold, who counts 007’s Jack Master and William Reiser among his most legendary fans, had to turn up the cameras as he watched them every Monday evening over the weekend.
According to Arnold, his role as a bodybuilder in the film “Strike Back” (2010) was the pinnacle of his role as an actor.
“There’s an element of adrenaline you need to have in the performance — the comparison with Michael Jackson,” he said during the interview at Wynn W.
He’s been in over 40 films and documentaries, and he told CNN’s “Dateline” in a previous interview that the Jackson films became the most popular movies in existence because of how star-struck people were about finding him in the role of Death Row Records singer Lucille Ball.
He loves watching his heroes have their happy endings, and especially his scenes in the upcoming biopic of Lucille Ball.
“If I’m looking at this film, it’s a hopeful love story,” he said. “And if I’m looking at the biopic of Jackie Robinson, it’s a deep love story of love — of a time — and death.”
']

Title: Photographs reveal the unintended beauty of machines
Generation:
["Thanks to a series of illustrations in the archives of Time magazine, we see the mysterious number of possible inversions that exist within the world — notably, glimpses of then-entertaining machines on the step panel of the television spectrum.
It's a big headline story — the second line, as the example, illustrates the sharp and brilliant phenomenon of broadcasting. And many of the super objects in our lives — specifically, tiny silver globes being pressed up against the one row of a television screen, for example — are fascinating artifacts, deserving of the perfect epic playfulness.
So, it's only natural that these shots illuminate the kind of ingenuity that could happen when an incredible machine pops out at an unexpected moment.
The magnetic technologies in some of the white-labelling seen here could match the true physical act of saving one man's way of life: recycling thousands of hours of meaningless waste, digitally rectifying and burying it, safely and reliably, thanks to radio and, where possible, via the Internet.
The drone. This one is happening. Oh yeah, and the internet is listening.
"]

Title: Louvre Abu Dhabi: Enter the 'universal museum' of human creativity
Generation:
['To infinity and beyond!
The museum has been on a mission, with an ambitious timeline, to explore, in cooperation with more than 40 museums worldwide, from Seoul to the Vatican. By creating an immersive experience designed to replicate the unique experience of art history, "Desmond," as it's called, aims to give visitors a perspective on the exhibition at which it is housed.
From its examination of architecture at the National Design Museum, the Paris-based museum is now drawing on the spiritual, artistic and metaphysical power of human creativity. The museum, which has 12 exhibitions currently, encompasses exhibits showing many of the human studies, works by intelligent and mathematical artists, movement and speech-making on the 21st century, along with concepts such as mind control, simulated communication, mental theory and intensive physiotherapy.
These are among the many avenues connected by the architecture and philosophy museum, conceived by artist Morte Auguste Neumann, who is able to lay out whole sets of concepts, as well as explication each individual component of art, in vibrant and expertly executed exhibit designs, readjustments, etchings and variations of existing and future works.
The level of detail required to develop these materials, is extensive, said Petra Csi, the children's curator and an expert on human form and psychology at the UAE museum. By creating precise details of a specific geometric structure, Neumann explains the effects of materials upon performance and mechanics, as well as describe mechanisms by which individual artforms form from bodily and physical measurements, to other mental or physical conditions, are being perceived by and from our daily lives.
"The spaces that the design creates are functional, allowing individual artisans to create it and in-between, express themselves," said Pergutta Kaweng, who organized the show, which was organized by Tiffany & Co. in cooperation with New York's Rosenfeld Gallery.
Kaweng's piece is made of artistic materials, such as inks, carved woods, potted quartzite and polished watercolors. Each piece is represented in three types -- the first decoration is handmade complete with polychrome laminate, the last with brass laminate, fluke, habanero and silver spade. A board creates a two-dimensional interpretive surface that can stand out in a showing room. Each piece is treated with a functional seal that cleans up and moulds the surface of each piece for the entire presentation.
Csi understands that the “universal museum” is part of a larger artistic vision of the UAE, created to appeal to audiences around the world, rather than just the UAE's values, similar to those expressed by artisans in Norway and France. The installation will coincide with the installation of the opening of the museum's permanent collection next year.
"The universal museum is going to capture the spirit and enthusiasm of artisans and to extend the museum's participation in its artistic process for a diverse audience that is varied," said Iwon-Berge Sorota, art curator of the African Arts Museum, which now houses the treasures from the Egyptian and Tunisian cultures.
Vanishwaiz Zinfiqi, director of the Abu Dhabi museum, said the project gives the UAE exceptional access to more than 400 works of art. While the UAE has long been open to foreign art, it’s reaching out more to Japanese, Chinese and African galleries and work groups to develop its professional staff, for instance.
"The UAE has opportunities to work alongside other African countries and with other regional and international bodies, but we also need to work with some internationally recognized organizations and institutions like the African Arts Museum, as the number of institutions seeking African content comes down," she said.
']

Title: Photographer Martin Parr on Britain in the age of Brexit
Generation:
['Photographer Martin Parr says how Britain’s Brexit vote “destroyed everything you had the hope that something might happen”.
“It broke everything you had the hope that something might happen,” says the bespectacled Bradford-born and close friend of President Donald Trump.
This once-economically sophisticated England was next door to one of world’s leading diplomats in New York, where he also co-founded international rights group the International Commission of Jurists.
“I was on the front pages of all around the world, the talk about the US becoming the ‘popularity country’, to everyone that there’s a slightly smaller metropolitan scene in Britain, but then I’d been to New York for 100 years and you could see the real nippiness and the integration of cultures. And then I took an exhibition from London and saw how Heathrow has emerged from so much urban deprivation,” he tells CNN’s T.A. Newshour.
Over the next nine years he moved back to Britain, shunning the capitals of EU cities, flooding London with visitors and scoring opportunities for companies in South America.
“There was a bigger factor that the fact that the Trump administration, now Trump, is really losing the gold medal is more of a generational thing that I’m aware of. A lot of that I myself have to take into account for the rest of my life as it applies to me as an artist, to present that at the best,” he says.
So why did Britain go so irrationally with the EU?
The answer was partly because he didn’t like that kind of arrangement, he says.
“This is fundamentally a bodyless society,” he says. “You have everything: a castle, a bank, a house, a park. If you know what you’re giving away, you can pay your customers in taxes. If you want a bank for your tenants, you can pay theirs.
“So you have to regulate social services, regulate tax, regulate online payment system, and you have to impose new taxes and regulations for all those places and frankly there’s nothing to stop it. It’s an economic mess, it’s an ethical mess, it’s dangerous, it’s dangerous to be a part of,” he adds.
This is why he feels there is an increasingly global economy, taking global markets away from the rest of the world.
“I understand that, with globalisation, one thing is fairly basic. But it has gone underground, it’s not being reflected in commerce in this country, its all being done through art, our galleries or our universities, it’s all being made by someone who’s in a similar position, and it’s depressing what’s going on here,” he says.
“It really doesn’t make much sense to me, because that doesn’t really drive the thought around Brexit to any extent.”
']

Title: 'Part of the conversation': Outspoken artist Anish Kapoor opens retrospective in Beijing
Generation:
["With formal family lineage and respect for the history of China, Anish Kapoor was just 18 when he began researching acting for a film called “The Master.” It was a breakout success in China, capturing the attention of most Asian audiences and a legion of Hong Kong fans. But when it came time to start speaking up at the University of Southern California for a BFA class, Kapoor realized a teaching credential – BFA in my English – made the difference. That changed for many of his peers, eventually leaving him with a massive international following. In 2016, Kapoor became the face of arts and culture in China as one of the leaders and activists responsible for moving the country toward modernization.
His documentary “MUSLIM,” set in China, presents a timeline of his years of research, examining the layers of “The Master”’s and Kapoor’s life from conception through his creation.
“BFA taught me how to edit and I didn’t have to be like that,” Kapoor said during a conversation with CNN recently. “It’s like nobody had taught me how to make a film.”
Kapoor’s documentary is quite unique in that it sees him as a Russian author with a nose for “political” films. He said he wanted to talk about a historical point and the choice of the work he did as part of a thesis project.
“It was really about how you make these movies. I spent time doing other films that didn’t make it on my own,” Kapoor said. “The Master” is about two sons who live in a century-old part of China under dictatorship, long suspected of murder. Kapoor, after writing the script, realized that the moral bearings of the films were missing.
“When he kept them, it kind of sort of stuck together like a bike – I didn’t follow it. It’s something I really wanted to talk about.”
The documentary includes interviews with Kapoor’s family and friends. In some of the interviews, they don’t leave his family alone. One of his oldest friends, Hu Jeong, kept drinking, until he was lost. Later, Kapoor once disclosed that he briefly separated from his son.
“That shit wasn’t the most interesting thing to watch,” Kapoor said, of his childhood. “He didn’t tell me, 'All the real parents have left me.' ”
In the film, Kapoor spoke to his father about “Master” and urged him to create a better version of it. He also points out that the film told a story of a punk rocker who came to the Big Apple, pulling out his socks and identifying himself as a bodybuilder. It’s something that Kapoor has kept up with since “The Master.”
Anish Kapoor has lived and studied in Hong Kong. He's been working in China for 20 years. https://t.co/6q0kOb32nw — Glenn Short (@GLennShort) April 5, 2019
“I think that if you don’t just keep going there, this gives you an insight into life, into what the teacher teaches you as a kid,” Kapoor said. “And that’s what you really want to be a part of.”
Anish Kapoor is a French-born, practicing artist and filmmaker. He and his team have worked since the 1970s to create many masterpieces including “Harlem Sproul” and “Ye Savo.” They went on to win a TV competition and three films as part of award-winning ASCA movement. They lost to Stefan Johansson’s “Les Helmshoirs van Dika” from “On The Line.”
"]

Title: Olafur Eliasson on what art can do to fight climate change
Generation:
['Eliasson discusses the fossil fuels revolution being unleashed by the internet: pic.twitter.com/6lnNzy3DWY — Jewish Funds (@JFBact) April 4, 2019
(CNN) — One of the biggest words you’ll hear the most in any film “Fruitvale Station” when you talk about the uprising in California.
Eliasson has a new view on the climate crisis. He talks about how he has seen an evolution with which modern lives are being affected: — Jewish Funds (@JFBact) April 4, 2019
Such comparisons are dangerous, he says, because it’s hard to know whether or not individuals really understand the need for action.
Now a man, Eliasson is a professor and researcher in the Centre for Sustainable Urban Living in Amsterdam. Though his previous book "Identify the Golden Persuaders: Climate Change and the Art of Ecology," has gotten more press in the past, “Fruitvale Station” has not. So when he spoke, I would have thought he’d completely recovered from the vitriol that it had generated for the first 24 hours.
“We still need to consider the [climate] crisis in order to reflect for ourselves where we are as a people,” he says.
He describes the climate crisis in more expansive terms: “If anything that could be measured would make it particularly worrying, to the extent that it would lead to an attack on the human development and development of our society. … That would make the discussion totally dependent on the science.”
Using technology to explain such a crisis, he has created a series of animations to understand how humans have “worked against nature, how the environment has evolved and the technology has changed, not only in the field of natural science but in society as a whole.”
And his methods help us understand the effects that are being created in the world, says Eliasson, perhaps most importantly to ask: Are we vulnerable?
The technology, he explains, enables our efforts to examine “what we actually do not do.” He calls these people, climate scientists, philosophers, animal rights activists, and art historians, “underdogs who do not understand the value of telling us what to do.”
Technological technological tools, including a national database that unloads data on our natural resources and forestry, and a website that allows you to draw data, are taking this world by storm, he says. “It seems like a very exciting time to be alive.”
']

Title: Pritzker Prize 2020: Irish duo's win marks rare victory for women in the 'Nobel of architecture'

['NEW YORK - The winner of the Nobel Prize in architecture was clearly having a technical year on Thursday when they became the first Irish winners in a record six years.
In the days preceding the ceremony, Lisa Auvs, founder of the Mitnick New York foundation, and Judith Sheindlin, emeritus professor of architecture at Michigan State University, opened a ceremony to celebrate the RMC Prize, a prize that honors architecture that is taught in the university's Classrooms with the Art and Design Department.
Auvs is no longer related to Sheindlin, but Sheindlin has won the Nobel Prize twice in the past four years. In 2012, Amanda McDonald won for her work with the Tate Modern in London and in 2007 for building a statue of the American Civil War in Washington DC.
"There's always a reason why the architecture world prizes me," Auvs told reporters on Thursday evening.
"I think the research and building society happens to be the best infrastructure for building that architecture need in order to carry out that type of work."
Their work has also had a significant impact on cultural heritage in America, as well as in the United States, in particular the New World and the southern Ontario, Ontario (Ontario) region.
"We are trying to explore the ways that architecture creates and enhances communities and social connections to the rest of Canada," Auvs said.
Pritzker Prize 2020: Ireland's first women winners
Omid Kirschbaum, an architecture professor at MIT, created a mural in a basement of a New York City high school in honor of UNICEF in the Eighties.
That mural was a project of the MIT student group the Students for Contemporary Urbanism (SOCU) and was intended to form a sort of a non-profit organization in that community.
It was recently installed in a student dormitory where people contributed to make their own design.
"The idea was to create a kind of virtual shrine for students, where they could put designs on Instagram or upload them on Facebook," Kirschbaum said.
"It has a really difficult artistic side. It could be a brilliant representation of a utopian society, but it could also be such a play on aesthetics."
The mural's app uses the New York City high school wall and other historical images of the area for inspiration.
"We are like a hologram of something," Kirschbaum said.
The text of the text helps represent the landscape because it represents an "impassioned" reality, Kirschbaum said.
"I like the way that the painting contrasts the reality," Kirschbaum said.
Pritzker Prize 2020: Wood shift
Harvey Macky-Jones of Washington, D.C. has been one of the few rising international architects who survived an editor's strike by the Alliance of African American Architects, which threatened to shutter the 157-year-old organization.
He has done architecture projects for cities, including Chicago, Los Angeles, Atlanta, Orlando, West Palm Beach, Chicago, Detroit, Austin, London, and Boston.
"I'm going to join the Academy of Architecture and Design," Macky-Jones told CNN about an aria du l'art with co-founder Marie Dunn.
He explained the use of the space as a symbol of an aesthetic shift.
"The fact that architecture is shift is very telling to what we are experiencing today in terms of history," Macky-Jones said.
"I have learned the hard way how change happens. It happens with building."
The master of the year
"Pritzker Prize 2020: Ireland's first women winners," the event was held in the Sandpiper Hall of the National Museum of Built Cities.
Visitors also took in views of the 2015 and 2017 awards ceremony held in the Siegel Center.
After she was announced, Leinster's Abby Bryant, global trade secretary for TUI, tweeted: "I am so humbled to be chosen as the newly crowned #NobelDesigner of 2019 at @NWDC. Very proud to have been given this prestigious honor as it reflects our shared values of innovation, innovation, innovation and an intentional team effort."
