Dunn: "The amount of work I have done in this field since this announcement is incredibly remarkable. I think that has transformed my life for the better, allowing me to truly get where I am now."
Auvs: "It's really a great day for architecture."
Griffith Institution: "I'm glad I didn't see my name in the press."
']

Title: The Catholic nun who made joyous, politically charged Pop Art
Generation:
['The Catholic nun who said iconic modernist Pop Art was part of a racket of dirty money was ordered to submit to a diet of McDonald's, chips and vanilla ice cream.
Some of the anti-poverty activists who spoke out against Pope Francis in a symbolic calling were taken aback.
"Wow," said resident novelist Natalia Narreza, who is a food writer. "Didn't she just feel inadequate? Who was meant to be helping to promote food as a social symbol? Wasn't it in the spirit of faith that people had a responsibility to eat from healthy food sources? Somehow, these references have struck me as serious."
Nutanza told CNN she took long walks on her next day with her grocery cart out. She never ate any. After he played with a slice of pizza, she would return and enjoy another slice and something sweet with a side of french fries.
Now, Narreza is a regular at Subway restaurants, where she has substituted organic salads for unhealthy versions of the staple bread.
"Why would I be hurting to give someone else the chance to be able to take care of themselves?" she said. "I am sick of free passes. They're always more lucrative than 'cause it brings money to the bank, no need to worry about your Visa costs."
Nutanza has kept her location secret since she joined a religious order in Singapore in the early 1990s, when she had poor marks on her English and Arabic exams.
In 1996, a friend of her mother took a knee for Pope Francis in a public demonstration. Narreza laughed and shouted at the pope, arguing that the senior citizen was not religious enough to preach to the public.
Sister Maria, the Dominican Sister of the Pontifical University of Culture in Miami, told CNN last year, "As a Jesuit, I was incredibly embarrassed by my country and how transparent and humble it was to be so uncritical of any man and woman or woman with a disability. The entry of sacred symbols like the Blessed Mother (and her son) makes me angry."
']

Title: Has the wooden skyscraper revolution finally arrived?
Generation:
['(CNN) - Building by the buzz word in construction-speak, a slender, elevated tunnel has finally arrived for shuttered South Tower at Tokyo's Nikkei Tower.
Tokyo skyscraper crews have been hard at work for months to build the monument, which boasts 2,770-foot ceilings and supports every conceivable structure imaginable: shipbuilding, oil rigs, schools, churches and waterfront parks. Construction is just beginning on a colossal concrete pyramid - a towering eight-story skyscraper measuring more than 26,000 feet (11,000 meters).
The project, tied up in a 1998 Tokyo earthquake, and which is scheduled to begin at the end of the month, is finally heading into completion. With so much need for it to start, construction was initiated more than a decade ago when the ninth-tallest building in the world, the 103-story Anja Fischer Kochi New Sails, opened in 2000.
The 23rd-tallest building in the world, the 11th-tallest skyscraper, Venice Beach, went up later that year. The tallest building in America was actually the one that graced the Plaza Hotel in New York City.
But the 16th-tallest building in the world, the 250-story Sky Tower in Madison Square Garden, New York, was an unfinished Macondo-sized record breaking hole constructed in 2011 after the 1929 stock market crash.
That doesn't mean it won't happen again, though.
"For an encore in the Garden Theater, we're all going to be a generation older," said Jamie Barrett, senior executive vice president of TowerAid, the nonprofit that brought the tower to life.
The system already has ties to former Red Sox pitcher, owner and finance chief Jack Neidhardt. In a garage, Neidhardt spent 10 years building a variety of buildings with his family, including a one-story transmission tower and public housing units. He designed the facade of the Maison Mocourt, a 6th-floor facade tower, erected in 1912 and that was the most decorated building by any of the American businesses in the financial capital.
"Our millennial generation that's stuck with it has always been very supportive of it," said Jiro Okamoto, the one-story general manager of Tokyo-based TEVA, which is responsible for putting up the tower. "Once our marketing manager finishes putting up the towers, people start liking it. They love it. It's a unique asset."
The developer of the tower, Tokyo Dome Development, recently released a six-page itinerary detailing the lobby, architect and exterior design, calling it "the first augmented reality tower of all time." On May 12, the tower will begin the first-ever use of 4G video camera technology. And in June, the home of the world's tallest buildings, the $42-billion Rimyorashi Twin Towers, will be first to host a digital billboard.
So what is all this like? Unlike the similar projects of Florence's Beso Tower in Florence, this one'll get built around almost 60 meters of concrete. The last time it was completed, the Los Angeles Town Center, once touted as the world's tallest, opened the morning after the quake struck near the epicenter.
For some, that was a disaster.
"We saw the city was going to change forever," said Gordon Hsiao, a 58-year-old retired teacher, who lives in Hong Kong, where the gates had been locked up. "The last time that they built this in time for the next earthquake, it was more than eight feet tall. This time, I think a lot of people saw it, too. And very few saw how it was a relief."
A crucial part of the challenge is permitting. How many of the beams in the chimney of the first building, like the mammoth, adorn the second building, a 46-foot-tall structure called THE Reichmerukson, will need to be replaced? Will it need to be built on an average of 10 feet of steel?
"There are still thousands of fans when this first building opens," said Oded Anjman, chief executive of The Hawks, a developer of 40,000-foot Olympic and Paralympic chalets built in Chicago, the site of the 1933 World's Fair. "It has five beams and six bolts going at a time."
Some other issues, too. Residents of the former Reichmerukson Tower told CNN they wanted the tower built with steel and alluvial steel - needed for pipes and extensions to carry electricity. The builder said all 37 metal doors must have windows, doors, backs and walls.
"The building has to be constructed in stone for seismic phases']

Title: Discarded photo negatives show China in an era of change
Generation:
['By Philip Wen
For decades, the misadventures of neon photographers have faded away.
The sleek red, white and blue stores of neon have flooded the market. From orange and yellow neon frames, to neon and blue neon bottles, neon and blue neon shades, neon pinks and blues, neon curvostrons and neon reds, pink, yellow, and blue neon bottles, neon colors and colors — at least one new high-performance camera has a point.
There’s one caveat, though: Some of these hard-wired neon electronics may simply be old and in need of repairing.
Wen is an attractive young artist from Heilongjiang Province. He has been developing neon-based microdevices since 2014 at the Qumai Lab Studio that he helped sell to Beijing Commercial Bank, which bought him with capital he could no longer spare. As part of his lab, he designed original circuitry to create devices that show advertisements for neon and neon brands.
An eyesore
The idea for his electronics after his father went missing in a car accident in 2010 earned Wen time at a hospital specializing in electronics research. (He was also a molecular biologist at the time.)
In March, China’s Ministry of Industry and Information Technology issued a directive requiring manufacturers of consumer electronics from Jan. 1, 2019, to create new devices containing the microchip technology by May 1, 2020. The policy was also meant to be seen as intended as a statement against China’s display companies, as imagery they promote is widely viewed as evil, damaging its image in the international community and generating income for overseas tech giants like Google and Microsoft.
In an interview with Reuters in Beijing, Wen said he had spent a year in incubation between the two sides of the accelerator program, which also includes work at the China Institute of Digital Electronics and Recycling.
Even as well as working in a lab, he also “had a lot of research experience developing electronics.”
His work in the lab in 2016, he said, included drawing textiles, jewelry, products and street merchandise on the insides of microgreens, which serve as catalyst.
An artist rendering of the current growth and development of microtechnology over the past 10 years. Courtesy of InterNorth London, USA.
During a conversation with Reuters, Wen said, “I don’t see it as a legacy project. I see it as a skillful service project.”
“Chinese electronics companies are an important part of a country of 85 million and they are very open about their technology capabilities. If they are not as transparent as we want them to be, that’s a major issue,” he said.
To be fair, Chinese consumers do indeed purchase an electronics product there, especially in mobile phones, but that market grows so rapidly that several tech giants have some direct exposure to the idea.
A simple microchip lens will offer over 75% to 90% coverage, while a simple design that is top secret also boasts space for a photo-resolution camera lens. The evidence is not enough to convince some that brands and the media are not cashing in on the boom in small nanos, or microchip-based microdevices.
While brand fragility is the real worry here — and if the prevalence of so-called random microchips can also be ruled out — there’s also the issue of PRS we’ve all had many, many times this year: how little is known about how blue neon sells; and how much price is beyond anyone’s control.
And despite resistance, at least one manufacturer is in China.
']

Title: Why the NBA All-Star Game is a runway in its own right
Generation:
['You know, it was back in January when NBA All-Star Week began, and the story of the league's ongoing evolution of the sport, let alone the sixth NBA All-Star Game, offered it's replay evidence.
Well, for starters, it was a good time to be up against LeBron James and company.
Most of the NBA All-Star Game, you may recall, was media day, a very "let's look at where we can go," team versus player.
Maybe LeBron wants you to know that the NBA All-Star Game doesn't take place in a hotel room.
Or maybe James wants you to know that he's catching the wind when he's game.
I doubt, and may not say here, that, when you're hosting an All-Star Game that functions like an actual national team, you're not, just like you're hosting a broadcast.
You host an All-Star Game? You lead them in the announcement room? See, the franchise is big enough, you've got enough personnel, and if you're hosting one of them, you're doing it right.
And yet, when there's an actual game being played at the game itself, and nobody's broadcasting it, you're hosted to a small screen the way in which it was before.
Sixty-four cities, eight teams, a pool of like-minded people, and twenty-five college basketball coaches or coaches.
I will confess to having never tuned into the All-Star Game, or been remotely interested in All-Star Weekend, or even its programming, until yesterday.
In fact, the NBA All-Star Game always attracts comparison to the NFL All-Star Game, but I'll stipulate otherwise that no.
I say that because this isn't the league's crown jewel. It doesn't have a core, a catalog of superstars. And if you're considering the league as a broadcast network, it has to bear a certain certain cost.
If All-Star Weekend proceeds to be the equivalent of Game Day, or Game of the Century, you could even be charging for everything else you can be a part of. And if the sport has just slipped below the radar, you could never seem to get a word in edgewise.
Championed by young superstars, and standing against far-fetched, defensive targets like, um, the Miami Heat, the NBA All-Star Game is a business worth doing.
There's a great deal of success here to be had when you're hosting the All-Star Game. While there's a lot of chatter about whether the NBA's the most profitable corporation in history, having a serious championship title in your hands is a little more appealing.
Wanting to be part of a war chest, or standing in the way of the NBA's best campaigns, says you've got to be preparing. And while we've covered many complaints about the league's Yearbook, this year's edition may have expanded upon what was happening in previous years, in which, at a minimum, the league goes back to four rags.
Again, this column is about actual facts. In true basketball tradition, much of what we know about events is happening in places that we know nothing about.
This column does not necessarily reflect the opinion of CNN's editorial board or CNN International.
']

Title: Will the future be grown from mushrooms?

['Dear Amy: I am 14. I am totally immature for this and I would love this to end. Should I be dating someone who has roots of their own? Should I turn to nature and explore the wonders of it?
This holiday season, we get to walk and talk and eat. We do so with a high regard and appreciation for nature, but perhaps we should try to harness it.
I would rather spend my Christmas this year with the “tanish” sage, grandma’s rags, crinkle-cut grass, the sagebrush gass of land and beautiful little fireflies everywhere.
We even have the pooch who can sing to us for days, because she loves to sing.
Amy,
Dear Missy: You may be mature and enjoy this, but let’s not forget that the variety of flavors makes it easy to overlook.
While you’re coming for the scent, you should also consider being out for the date. It’s not so much romance as it is fun.
While I love your enthusiasm for the holidays, you should take into consideration that your other kids may give you a hard time about letting you go. Let them know if you’ve done your best (they know that) or if you’re just not ready.
Check out other traditions or make sure to go have a good time if possible. This is the time to move on.
You may also ask for a date with your grown siblings or any third party that can help with some of your activities.
— Not Ready To Go
Dear Not Ready: Since the holidays are so inclusive, this is a time to make fresh starts. Again, hold onto the color palette you established to cover the rest of the calendar and allow others to have your fun (again, sadly, we’re giving out Valentine’s Day to other folks who love to go out with the next person).
We have a problem with people seeing the season with the contrast and glorification of the holidays, which leads to feelings of joy, but also “stuffing” us into something we don’t like.
The fact that your mom is living in a house where the year is “revelation time” was created by her grandmother for much of her life, but is now in your home is making all of the travel-related visits uncomfortable and upsetting. You understand that if she’s not “in the house,” but I hope she had some time to enjoy the truly wonderful autumnal foliage and the outdoors.
Amy,
Dear Amy: Have you ever tried going out in public after having sex with a co-worker?
Dear Amy: My daughter recently decided to “donate” her virginity to people I admire. My advice is to contact the point person who manages this and see how you feel about this thing.
I’m interested in your reaction.
— Wondering At Home
Dear Wondering: You are made to think that you are still one of my favorite parents, yet your daughter is accepting her virginity and letting others have it. If you are in doubt about her feelings, these points may be helpful if you find yourself stuck at home. However, you don’t need to be a parent to do such a thing. A woman with dignity is unafraid to do something that others would probably disapprove of. This woman will not allow any male lover to eat and mingle, yet she may harbor bitter feelings about her parents.
If this teenager is interested in taking her virginity, she should be aware that you don’t want to jeopardize her future when she’s not dating anyone else, but should be in a place where she knows she’s done some mentalizing. As a society, we are often the first to admit something and then move on to the next one, but don’t ever touch your daughter.

Title: Mona Lisa for $60K? The curious market for Old Masters replicas
Generation:
['NEW YORK (CNNMoney) — You’d think the veracity of a vast collection of 19th-century Italian possessions by the fountain of eternal memory would have earned you something out of nothing.
Not.
Off the wall, no less.
In an astounding display that shows a treasure trove of 18th-century Macarthur pieces, there are more than 1,300 memorabilia pieces from the 1789-1865 restoration of the Basilica of Our Lady of Lourdes in Barlow, Massachusetts. They’re among the greatest pieces of Leonardo da Vinci’s work — first displayed at The Barnyard Museum in Boston in 1809.
This collection of contemporary pieces, on loan from the State of New Hampshire, was a cornerstone of American ornamental art and practices, making up the museum’s program for the past 10 years.
Others have appeared on loan from galleries around the world, including the Steven Spielberg Museum in Chicago, the Mondrian House in Geneva, Italy, the St. Cloud Galleries in St. Cloud, Minnesota, and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C.
“We always felt it was important to do a restoration and work that would establish the place of the older pieces that we thought were a real piece of art,” Ruth Sabel, director of the Massachusetts Paintings Restoration Society, said in a statement.
“There are so many amazing pieces in all these galleries, we have to have the best of both worlds,” said John McInerney, director of the Hoopla League Gallery, which has the restoration project open at the Massachusetts Historical Society.
More than 2,000 mementos made by visitors to the museum will be on view in up to 100 museum spaces at the beginning of April. Upcoming items include Guillermo Polanco’s model of the Cicero Monument, installed in 1889 and dedicated at Barlow Art Museum, a 100-year-old British instrument that was imported from France during the Depression to create a piece of 17th-century 18th-century art.
More than 70 pieces are available, including items that were commissioned by the Barlow Gallery and others, according to Sabel.
“As one of the world’s leading visitor agencies, it’s always really nice to see the many pieces that are already visible and exciting,” Sabel said.
Once you choose one of the 35 pieces for sale, you’ll have to get approval from the American Association of Museums or to find one of the special offers on the web page.
Overall, the purchase is worth more than $60,000, according to Sabel. The museum will admit to a small number of the restored objects to help collectors keep track of them. It’s worth $100,000 for a chapel located in the young parish hall of the parish church, according to Sabel.
']

Title: Under Xi's rule, what is China's image of the 'ideal' man?

But Chinese media, up to now obsessed with who Xi really is, forget about that."
Perhaps it isn't more mind-boggling than that, but after a government that's been the target of a lot of criticism, a Chinese man -- the world's wealthiest and the voice of China's most powerful -- has come home to roost.
Taken together, these seem like microcosms of China.
Touted as the foreign policy utopia of the modern era, China boasts a thumping GDP growth of 12 percent, with higher median household incomes than would be expected for a Western nation. To say there's no reason for that rise is to rue the poor Chinese citizens whose currency is at record highs.

CNN/CNN International 2017 China News Month covers an entire year in the nation's rolling population, and highlights a brand new twist: China's changing political environment is a close call.

Five ways I'm more happy with a superwoman

Title: Seoul's burgeoning drag scene confronts conservative attitudes
Generation:
['By Susan Levy Associated Press
SEOUL (AP) — Seoul's ramped-up drag scene, fiercely anti-LGBT, is just getting started.
With new shops that the city council considers offensive and borderline insensitive, activists in the ramped-up capital expressed concern Monday that LGBTQ people will not have fun.
Several nation's most prominent leaders joined the fervent problem in expressing outrage over the country's new tactics.
President Park Geun-hye and other top leaders pledged to deal with the situation in a "principled, civil and respectful manner."
Seoul's LGBT Movement in Jeju Island, which is protected by the law, was at a fever pitch Monday. Attendees said they expected to see even more pushbacks, if they ever felt comfortable with the policies they have left unchanged.
Pyoo, a trendy Southeast Asian neighborhood with 10 bars and a concert venue just blocks from Seoul, challenged Seoul's Pro Party administration to apply more robust crackdown tactics to preserve the same kind of tradition as one of its U.S. rival parties.
"The new approach is designed to ensure that we have continuity with some elements of LGBT politics," Pyoo said in a Facebook post. "We believe this approach will block their advancement."
Pyoo further called on the central government to "make accommodations for the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community and for it to receive the same government support as that of the minority."
The local government has been trying to make accommodations for the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) community, who can come out comfortably in their bedrooms or on outings in public places but have increasingly become targets of campaigns to gain visibility.
Pro-LGBT lawmakers have resisted efforts by the mayor of Seoul and Park Geun-hye to implement gay rights that contribute to the 30 percent drop in overall crime in the South Korean capital in the past five years.
Police at a tour of the hundreds of drag venues that have sprouted since their registration on Ellis Island in New York in 1986 seem optimistic that Seoul will join the large number of trans community in extortive acts of prostitution, sex trafficking, drug deals and other crimes.
More than 40 states have enacted laws that allow people to use, sell or let others use sex-edas, but no laws have been enacted to effect the same thing.
Anti-trans activists generally have the support of conservative Seoul society.
"I don't think there are huge differences between the two other parts of the country," said Andi Walander, who co-founded the organization Siding Up Seoul in 1980. "What is important for us in South Korea is that things have been worked out to make that all possible."
Siding Up Seoul also presented its vision for increased visibility and attention to the LGBT community. It urged the government to enact its policies in a time of economic growth.
It called for continuing to listen to South Korean values and dignity — something that South Korea shares with China and Japan.
Walander also hopes to go to the Supreme Court in a non-confrontational lawsuit that would demand that Seoul's lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender population "be allowed to use a variety of civil-liberties protections as well as the right to have adult children available."
It is far from clear that the gay and transgender population will get any pass from Park Geun-hye on other issues because she and Park are allies and friends, not business partners.
As parts of Seoul continue to grapple with unwanted expressions of anti-LGBT sentiment, activists are grappling with how to deal with a "culture of fear," said Thae Woo-sook, a professor of Indonesian cultural and human rights.
"One of the most important and important things is avoiding the perception that people are closeted," said Kim Tsang, who helped organize a drag party Sunday, where the police arrested people who had come from other districts.
North Korean authorities have tried to poke the spotlight off South Korea by turning undercover sting operation into a high-profile PR exercise, in which they roughed up residents for being LGBT. Title: Menswear has never been so casual. So why is the image of a man in uniform still so alluring?
Generation:
['Standing in front of a football stadium and attempting to build scaffolding atop or beneath a vast concrete barrier, Stan, a wealthy British businessman, is unsure about his new outlook on business - and the globe.
When he returns to London from the Office of National Statistics' spring re-tanners in May, it will be the first time the country has had a national figure such as the race horse in 40 years.
It will be the last time the 6-foot-tall marksman takes it upon himself to show a man he adores what he sees as the perfect definition of masculinity. "I think it's interesting that the picture of a man who has been a knight in knight's defence in 75 or so, it's not always the right thing to take," he tells CNN in a phone interview.
For Stan's next task, he plans to show a man he once tried to seduce by saying, "I don't mind lying in bed a lot," but not hanging out with "old b*****d" types. "I'm going to show a man that is not getting along with a lot of the old b*****d types I like," he says, "and that is something that I'll be doing in this particular month of this year, after the exercise."
"I'm coming up with some new ways of making things more relaxed about sex," he told CNN.
However, Stan is no novice to men's fashion. Over the last 18 years, he sold off several hundred pairs of “aborts' shoes” which have been called “brush makers” by the army, giving this company a run for its money. "We changed the footwear a little bit," he says.
In July 2014, Stan bought an entire sports utility vehicle (SUV) for around £300,000, and other than paying for a few marksman rougher-than-evening bandages he wanted a clear picture. "He agreed to work the part," says Marcus Thieme, director of Stan's Sportsier campaign. "He comes out of the kitchen and he talks football...not so much about numbers but about what everyone is going to wear when they go to bed."
His campaign, backed by regular members of the Football Association, has raised more than $70,000 for the cause. "I did not take away how cool it was to be a footballer," Stan says. "But now that I see the model profile of a man I have become captivated by, and who has been studying fashion over the last six or seven years, I'm really satisfied that it matters a great deal. I don't mind the idea of being a knight in knight's defence."
Although the debate is likely to remain, he says he stands by what he's decided to portray in the campaign:
"My intention is not to strip women of their masculinity, to show how good men are in owning things, because it's rather a sad story," he says. "Men in general are in retreat. I think that if women were able to make straight men feel physically good and physically safe, then the whole idea of marriage would really become relevant."
You can read more of Stan's new campaign here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YYBxsUP3lvS

Title: Brazil's fashion industry has a diversity problem

['(CNN) — Two world-class companies combine to come to mind.
First, L’Oreal, one of the world’s largest global beauty brands, is known in South America for the creatively high point of its products, a bottle of Atelier Listerine whose sparkling sheen is stamped on jeans by one of its owners and on beer leftovers from a fight over a famous event. Now, in the wake of the 2016 death of model Shelly Goldwater in Rio de Janeiro, L’Oreal has taken ownership of several top brands, among them Michelée as well as Purity Brand of St. Laurent in Paris.
“It’s not like all these brands aren’t growing, and they’re certainly helping us [be] strong in Brazil,” observed Marvini Vola, founder and CEO of Ambrian.
But just like the already established luxury powerhouse, the Brazilian fashion industry isn’t feeling the same as the global beauty brands of the past couple of decades, which have tended to turn more toward the world of swimwear or fashion in the name of innovation.
“Brazil is a world-class industry and it’s hard to evolve to a world-class market from Brazil,” said Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s first president and the son of former President Dilma Rousseff.

For some fashion consumers, the fashion industry seems to provide the best in terms of choice. But perhaps worse is for those consumers who are too scared to take a chance.

The top three brands here are La Paradie and Louis Vuitton. In the last five years, the companies produced 12.4 million bags — up 4.6% from 2015. These products tend to be popular in a country where the everyday luxury touches are limited to hipster brands such as Hermes.

A case in point is L.A. Vice President Natalie Pietsch. Backed by some 90,000 mega-chains, L.A. Vice President P.V. decides on her own.

There’s a certain mystique about Odile Pascual that grates a little.

Title: Fashion gaffes are a reflection of the industry's diversity problem

['A year ago I was in New York for a gathering of today's fashion geeks and faffes. It wasn't Glam Nation, but a rather eclectic week of fashion, conversations, and reclusiveness. I was invited to a Starbucks, my apartment, and house in Manhattan to learn how important I could be more than just the cause of change.
On the eve of Valentine's Day, I joined the challenge of co-creating the first trans-made furs in history.
I hesitated briefly, but fortunately I had the courage to enter the vision because everyone else had already joined. There's a conversation to be had in my soul, but the idea of trans firsts as a commodity has nothing to do with the speed and scale of trans commercialization or the rigidity of policy. It comes from people who can't catch up to the modern space.
In addition to the subway rail, the first ever transgender person to be recognized in Chicago was Isabel Toledo, who's experienced 100km (42 miles) of traveling through a safe, secure and secure environment. An amazing second came from nine year old Abbie Hallett – the youngest person ever to do so. Her journey was a journey of hands-on empowerment. She had, and will continue to have, the courage to pursue her dreams while completing the all-time comestibles.
Can anyone else really afford to be a part of a straight, cisgender, cis-male fashion house?
In finding ways to create trans-inclusive artists of every stripe, women and men wanted input from their peers.
Within a year the fashion design community of Brooklyn had joined forces. The fashion a/c process has evolved from body positivity and acceptability to inclusion, connecting one another to the cultures, histories, passions and values in the fashion world. It's everywhere, and in the fashion world.
Being trans-inclusive was a big part of it. In 2014, California was the first state to allow for gay marriage. This attracted a lot of new followers, since the state said: "All men are entitled to equal rights, but the lack of equality prohibits the most basic freedoms like right to life and the ability to have a meaningful life." When it comes to making shoes, I will forever stay on the fence about the color of the shoe – sometimes I prefer light to dark. As in a way, while the choice on price and gender identity might be aesthetic and for whatever reason we are nothing but people's worst nightmares, we are nothing but people's most crucial assets.
Ultimately, it's about how you use them in a way that respects the person you are and allows them to provide the greatest contribution to your life. We all have an unmet need for shoes. Without the visibility we have, we are out of step with the beliefs we hold, and we don't build businesses from ethical ideals or even the ideals that are a beacon to the world.

Title: The designers changing the conversation around lingerie
Generation:
['One of the coolest trends in lingerie is getting more fully focused.
Leading the conversation comes the statement age group that is strongly dominated by the 'fashion' line (of the more recent era) and has, for many, transformed the bulk of its time.
The dramatic transformation in the 1990s, as well as the powerful influence on teenage models such as Jessica Simpson, Kendall Jenner and Bella Hadid, has created a long-term core group of cool young women in powerful roles.
"Designers are interested in having a greater influence on this shift," says Meg White of ASOS, who discovered a time-honored trend that drove early adopters and their clients into new forms of luxury.
Models, if you have dreamed of seducing and showing a glimpse of yourself, are now once again the face of the brand. Gone are the days when models focused on the sexiness, the luxe comfort and the glamor of the clothes.
Look no further than Tommy Hilfiger's Fall 2013 show in his signature designer studio. "In the past few years, we've established greater influence on models by getting everyone talking, including the race, that is who they are, and which clothes make their person," he says. "This includes a greater fear, confidence and sense of self."
Since the start of fashion's shift toward more premium stretchwear, craftiest menswear designers have brought their pieces into vogue.
No more traditional lace and sheer dresses and tuxedo-like jackets (but no longer are they so off-the-wall). No more decadent vixen outfits, just regular ones that give the image and fun of the brand.
The health and beauty trend, which, until now, was more focused on women's needs, is back in fashion.
"Only a few years ago, it was considered that the top ladies did lingerie," says White. "Instead, we see a crop of bold, inspired garments that reflect the current industry."
Look no further than the elaborately embroidered Calvin Klein pieces and elevated pop in the spring runway, an ad for this should surprise no one.
"I understand and appreciate young women getting the attention and the attention to themselves, the treatment they receive," says White. "But instead of trying to force the attention back on other women, they're repackaging something very powerful and frivolous."
And with that more tailored in mind, brands like Hermes, Givenchy and Balenciaga are now diving deeper into the wearables space.
In 2018, the trendiest fabric in the runway was the stainless-steel beige, with the runways serving as an appropriate jumping-off point. Now, over 50 percent of dresses in showrooms are in stainless-steel; 5 percent are in black leather and slim-capped Tykes.
At the same time, designers are expressing some of their own thinking on the subtlety of the fabrics that feed into the wearable elements they're designed to deliver.
They're mixing elements of both bathroom and air purifier systems, extending the era to make actual men's clothing look literally woven in an important way.
"The goal is to fully develop our wearables into custom-designed garments with the natural relationship of texture to function," says Oren Karstinic, president of Dolce & Gabbana Group.
One of the ways these innovations can stretch the boundaries and impact on everyday life is by giving people what they crave.
In a recent interview with French media, Topshop founder Patrick Stewart described his new line inspired by heartthrobs like Rebecca Minkoff, David Jones and Alexander McQueen.
The Italian designer would have nodded nodded as he wowed his entire audience in wearing skin-tight, tasseled gowns that mucked out a backpack, while wearing one hand underneath.
But with the new tone, the streetwear is becoming more sophisticated, comfortable and chic.
"The French look is much more deeply focused on the black leather and T-shirts; trousers are luxe yet they don't feel like everyday-life staples," says White. "The look is more thoughtful than drab.

Title: Ceiling fans, brooms and mangoes: The election symbols of India's political parties
Generation:
['By ZEV ZITIERASA
All we have left for the election day is a traditional cordiality and lingua franca of the nation’s political parties.
Bugs are waved by the crowd before we board the bus that will take us to our polling stations and we sit down. Two cups of tea still float inside our cupboards.
We immediately see that the party leaders have marched on the town of Arunachal Pradesh.
Unimaginable queues of people are waiting for our bus in the main town of Kysaungyapagar, Naang.
When the famous lyricist’s name is Taslima, we are moved to tuck our bare feet on board the stroller that we head down to the town center.
When we join the caravan, we are then told that we are seats of national politics.
We fly on the bus and take seats in the back.
A wall is placed up in front of the bus and we sit down in the lane next to the lines for first, second and third seats.
On the ramp, all the lanes are lined with colours and the victors will be able to vote for their party in the round of the election.
Each of us then has the opportunity to vote for a candidate of either the BJP or the Congress party or there will be two lists made for our candidates.
In each seat, each party also has to vote for its nominee.
Here we get the historic election symbol, a white blanket that comes up on the sides of the bus.
It has nothing to do with politics and everything to do with symbolism.
It is a symbol that symbolizes the ebb and flow of the political pulse in the state.
A symbol that symbolizes the growing sympathy for the ruling elite.
The symbols they hold dear are strength, resistance, courage, kindness, humility and courage, evoking hope to move the country forward.
There have always been different political parties in this part of the country.
An apple tree in the northeast is a symbol of supremacy, rooted in the Rajapaksan tradition and a symbol symbolizing resolve and selflessness.
It is also the symbol of strength and resistance.
It is also the symbol of the resilience of the downtrodden.
It is the symbol of resilience, of hope, the symbol of hope that symbolizes the renewal of hope.
When we fly on the buses we look at the bus as if we know in the dark, the buses they are.
In this bus we are surrounded by wreaths at the various events, especially the Bhagwan Chair Chair Chair, the coal-cannon chair chair chair and Chairy Chair Chair.
We are there to worship the task of God and also to pray.
By the time we take off we are one more bound to what the victorious party hopes to achieve.
We have visited four different events and come to know how they align with India’s political parties.
We see in them the formation of national parties, the leaders of the parties and the new leaders who will implement their programmes.
We read in a book of people, people who have been on the streets to change the colour of their skin for voting.
Since the day it comes we must hurry and take off.
If we can make it in time we can complete the journey and get back home.
— can agitate as the opposition parties are being kept busy throughout the elections.
']

Title: The soft power impact of Ruth Bader Ginsburg's decorative collars
Generation:
['Imagine back in her early, impenetrable pre-U.S.B.
In her iconic California Supreme Court robe and spacious chair, Ruth Bader Ginsburg is hand-folded to one side, all three feet above the other with a sigh from the humming chairs’, a shudder of silent shouting all around.
A crowd gathers with her, shouting “No” as they approach her for her speech, and to this day she refuses to get up.
Around her warm, haunting room a crowd of daughters and grandchildren gathers round her, congregating to observe the little milestones she was born into.
But never minds, while dreaming of her daughter Mary’s baby, She’s as squeaky-clean now as she was when she was just a child.
No small house flower, she’s realized, is the thing to be to most women. And a new book called “Why Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s House Is in the MIDTOWN” reveals the truth.
In her beautiful cottage at a London train station, Rachel Sanders’ keen eye picks out Bader Ginsburg’s final voice, which begins with a heavy voice, the two-second tone she picked out for her.
“I love black gowns,” she admits. “I look like she’s doing the Snow King.
What do all those long, soft dresses mean?
“They always look wrong. It’s so beautiful.”
She glows briefly, then quietly voice delivers a poignant eulogy — “You were all my spirit and I know you taught me to love you, care you, be beautiful” — accompanied by a gentle, spoken grunt of encouragement from her elder daughter, Mary.
“I’m a little more inclined to get up and make sure everyone is smiling,” she says. “But I always start at the right spot — sometimes — and that’s where we have to be and make sure everyone knows we’re good and that we have good friends, good food and good times.”
So it seems, at least, that Ruth could both dream about the future and be a feminist.
She’s a scholar, writing for New York Magazine and a visiting scholar at the University of California at Davis.
She loved college, but she couldn’t find time to study. She wanted to spend more time caring for her growing son, but the best guy at the school was Bill — a trans woman who was barely in the polls.
So it made sense that she flew in for a deeper relationship with the man, in his late-50s. But Bill was not a millionaire, at least not yet. He stayed away from that plane because “he was so proud of what he did for women.”
And yes, he also put on her beautiful plush chair. He liked to infuriate her with food and clothing, sometimes having her first inkling she was a widow.
“He really, really liked my body and they liked my clothes. For me,” Ruth says. “And I thought, this is beautiful! We’re looking at you and … maybe, maybe, this will help us stay together in a healthier way.”
The two crossed paths in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as well. Ginsburg — the only one of her offspring at Harvard — left Harvard for the European Business School.
“So at Harvard, I thought it was the smartest thing,” she says. “For me, this was what I wanted to do.”
While at Harvard, she met Edith Windsor, a pretty but matronly “bungie chick” at a literary conference in France.
“They were like two of you,” she recalls. “But Edith was a little more uptight than we were at Harvard.”
Later, in 1955, when she was 27, Ruth said that she dreamt of being an actress at age 19. She said she dreamt of first starring on “Buffy the Vampire Slayer”, the show that was named after her boss, Fr. Ernest “Puffy” Rose O’Neill.
Ginsburg ended up looking to move back to England for a meeting with women’s suffrage activists after being cast as Frankenstein in the 1985 film version of “The Wizard of Oz.” She helped the campaigners seal the deal on a commercial featuring a woman holding one of her bouffants.
']

Title: Why Beijing's Serpentine Pavilion signals a new age for Chinese architecture
Generation:
['Like a clear path to a higher order.
For the week of April 5-13, the Chinese government has put a palpable New Age under control, leaving the Grand Central Ballroom in New York City to its rear, a new public space to chart China's new urban scene.
The Belt and Road Initiative, which officially kicked off on June 23, is a massive effort to launch cities across Asia toward denser urban living and innovation.
That is because China's 80 million urbanites are aging -- moving from urban cores, especially in cities, to expanded suburbs and urban mores. These data can be a significant shift from "modernist" cities like Beijing and Shanghai, where new and redeveloped areas are being ground zero.
As a result, the Beijing theme park is much closer to suburban and new design.
The theme park is called Serpentine, for "our new design" and features a glorified glass terrace for elephants. It's open daily from 12:30 to 5:15 p.m. It also offers a "Great Park" -- which caters to Hong Kong, the capital of China -- that enables young urbanites to travel underdeveloped island-like islands for breathtaking views of the city.
The design is heavy on modernism. It includes scenes like bright blue tents and huge lights the size of around 2,000 ping pong balls.
Its centerpiece features 52 stories of 'deconstructed' tall skyscrapers (about the size of a basketball court) which are a source of modern urban architecture.
Imagine creating 200 or more high-rise contemporary buildings of the kind unveiled in New York.
Then there's the Tower of Tsukuba, one of the tallest structures in the city, with 30 freestanding "sinks" in its tower. It's an historic landmark, one of only two in Japan that still hang as an ancient temple of the cross-hunting kakaburu warrior.
When it was completed in 2004, it was seen as the dawn of urban culture, in which rich oil and coal resources, fresh air and raw materials are turned into urban scenery. Over time, it became a model of Asian design -- its "houses of the 21st century," said Chinese architect Wang Yunxiong in an extensive exhibit at the Yangtze River Cultural Center in Beijing.
The size of Tower of Tsukuba? No big deal, as Liu Yunxiong pointed out. It spans 18-24 miles and costs about $32,000 -- which, no, the Guangzhou Studio had earlier mentioned during its time as the premier of theme parks. But that number is much smaller than what the Tower of Tsukuba cost.
As for the central theme park (called Serpentine Gardens), last month, the movement of the exterior of the 3-story pyramid, unveiled a distinctive "MULTI-NOCKET" -- a six-tiered structure that expands on the grid. It will be visible for 60 years, according to Wang.
The biggest design update is in the design and construction of the public and residential buildings, which is already scheduled to be completed before the end of the year.
Wang said that the new Public Square City is the closest city to the Serpentine that has yet to be completed -- for a host of reasons, not the least of which is that officials have suspended construction.
The changes will come at a great cost.
This summer, the People's Liberation Army will declare a regional championship football tournament, which will mark the grand opening of the capital's new Baseball Stadium.
Tickets for that tournament are already sold out, according to Wang.
And then there's the sight of the grand opening of the 13,000-seat East River Aquatic Center, which is expected to debut in November.
It will be open through September.
']

Title: Meet North Korea's art dealer to the West
Generation:
['CLARKSVILLE, South Carolina - Like this little kangaroo, every step of the way while on my walk I had been framed by a fierce challenger to the concept of the "art dealer" and its profile.
I don't feel like grabbing hold of it.
I feel like an idiot and a few fewer glassy pacts. I'm tired of being so rich - the way we speak, where we should respect the body they have created. But this is who they are. And they feel like they have been picked up by an evil cabal and the creative genius of Russia, China and North Korea.
I feel like someone in this room had pooped into my (everything this reporter had been given could fit nicely into one of the classic jeans. Why anyone would want a moving garment, I was asked - assuming my grandson wants to buy a high-street heavy for his birthday or some kind of weekend bender.
What is important, I realized, is the money this stuff is raking in. I believe that what a lot of artists are making is produced in actual factories that they submerge, combine, protect and sell their products. Do you really think they'd make enough money with a set of jeans to go home for your birthday?
It reminds me of the old thinking that told me you want to buy sneakers, Ikea furniture and, of course, tennis shoes to keep track of and distract yourself from the law of averages. He didn't buy any sneakers, I thought. He started off with low-priced ticket to New York, cost me about half what I was using at the station for casual shopping.
Now he's building new warehouses to fight your next cycle of charges from income taxes and wholesale tariffs. So maybe he would be smart to purchase Ikea flooring and ship out pieces to West Africa, stop waiting in line and donate them to churches or help his rums set up a school.
Do you want a fellow artist in this room who also I love to have my hand-painted art? Then that same artist could be picking up fabric and taking it off the walls and getting hooked into a story about how maybe poverty isn't just a violent situation for disabled people, it's a necessary evil to actually create work.
']

Title: David Hockney at 80: An encounter with the world's most popular artist
Generation:
['Few people get into a bit of an adventure when the guy first first hits the recording studio.
David Hockney has been one of those pioneers of the pop era and has also been a musician of his own, owing to his award-winning release, "Surprise!"
Given the following, we can't help but get a little nostalgic about the days of the Egg Hotel in Greenwich Village, where Kenneth Lonergan lived while managing to give most of his lives away to produce half of his records.
Originally from Edinburgh, in the small town of Raenagh, we wanted to take a look at Hockney's world tour at the Baths a few weeks before "Surprise!" with Billy Whitbread.
Not so though, we figured if there was any consolation for appearing in memory lane of the Lang’s late alter ego Johnny Freeman and all the people who dined at the hotel’s perfectly-configured, all-white-oak music spaces it would be that Hockney didn’t end up in our homes, to be precise, next to the Daniel John club at the Baths.
“Why didn’t I go to the old Substation on East 18th Street?” he asked recently.
But our 13-year-old and 17-year-old son did, and so we are left with this fragment of Hockney’s life with a slightly altered cut-out in the corner of our living room: only days later, he was at a Baths exhibition. This passage is from his interview for Harper’s Bazaar.
Hockney and his wife Susan spent a year there in 2001. The couple had been living in Edinburgh when they bought a studio in London, when the lighting and decor of the couple’s former beater house became impossible to bear. As the building was turned into an abandoned studio, they were told they could afford to expand inside.
Suffice it to say, the new world was already moving.
“The edge of everything came to us," Hockney said. "We did a bit of stuffing and then two weeks later, had to plan for the move all in an instant.”
']

Title: Long-lost picture archive celebrates glamour of 1950s Senegal
Generation:
['The Untamed picture archive of Gold and Pearl have made their debut in the West African nation of Senegal, a process that began in the 1950s with the Civil War. The documents, a collection of the late Hollywood heavyweight’s family photos, share a love story through photographs. A reception for the collection was held April 1 at the Senegal Fine Arts Center.
A snapshot of Gold, Pearl and other Supreme Chartug groups of Dakar later reprinted as “Images from Senegal 1974-1976” was made available to viewers at a free workshop on Friday.
“To me the beautiful, second-screen appearance is part of the healing process and to me it can bring light to the world,” Gold’s son, Alexander Gold, said.
Alexander and his cousins lost their only daughter when her necklace was stolen in the Baurant el-Boit region of Senegal in April 1953. More than a century later, Gold’s daughter was honored with a gold glove-esque necktie on an international gold awards program in London. When Gold walked away from New York to give up his own 20-piece play for children in the U.S., Pearl was struck by the tragic loss of their 17-year-old daughter.
']

Title: How ancient Egyptian cosmetics influenced our beauty rituals
Generation:
['I am part of the humanity that hopes to build a diamond ladder every time I try to brush, chop or dry something, and that being a born beauty has enabled me to experience magic and the world has certainly become familiar with my mom. She’s the one who created me.
I was born in the eastern part of Cairo. My mother had gone in search of the highest possible dry and hardy stones in the area. She found them in unique collections in Cairo including gemstones known as druithiths, and little metal fragments in ancient Egyptian ceremonial pieces. I was bewildered at first how to break through the shiny sparkling glass shards into gold-thumbed gondolas and order my grandmother’s hair to braid into one shiny gray blob, but by the time she cleaned me up and gently wrapped me in glittering sequins I was ready to regrow my features and add a fabulous shine.
Beyond her forays into the world of gemstones and sparkling I had a spectacular vision of my mom’s grandmas at their wedding. First as a half-century old wedding gift, she said, “I will certainly give her another beautiful bride, that little girl, and my father will always be your brand name,” but despite the sparkle, the father looked at me with her eyes swollen shut. “Aren’t you lovely?” she asked. “Look there she is,” he replied. “She’s beautiful and I am going to marry her!”
I see myself hanging out with the handsome, smiling gentleman that accompanies me on trips to Muslim temple sites. I see women in pink and gold rubbing shoulders with the men that side me instead of falling asleep at the couch. I see beauty in women like Tila de Larraga, whose amazing eye makeup instantly brightened up the eyes and forehead with the rubbery side of her forehead down.
I feel incredible right now when I see makeup, mascara, bronzer and loose lips that reveal the bumps and brown and mottled breast, and even skin-tone scales from the after-dark hours of the beach. It’s hard not to picture my mom at the beach in the morning with another woman, drinking a glass of soapy water, floating in a bucket full of coconut and trying to scoop the rough seas off my arm.
By the time the surf came up, every penny was piling up, the river was pouring rain with smoke and rain, so me and my grandma were sweating through their hair and I stumbled across a gray island before the ocean moved into the middle of the tarp and I managed to cover up my coat and brow. I remember the rainbow logo boards on my glasses reading “Bulory Theme.” In a lull, I looked over at the tree in the street where the rock stopped so I could snorkel over there and help my cousins at home to reconnect with where they live and what they missed the most.
Somehow, I found ourselves inside a safe room and realized that my Mom’s adventure was just going to live on. We could be cousins, grandparents and husbands and parents, grandmothers and granddaughters. Today we look forward to sitting in the cave on Saturday mornings where we can relax and enjoying our curls and see our fair cousins as I do.
When I forget, I hope I forget and know there are so many different things that made my Mom happy, old and young. We couldn’t make this trip without my mom. She did a fascinating job of bringing elegance into her world, giving high standards of elegance to her workforce, their home and her home’s life. I loved being there and felt cared for and respected, but I would never forget why I chose to be there.
I wonder whether today we will have the same kind of sense of community that my grandmother’s brand icon raised. Are there any ways we can feel more self-acceptance today and share our beauty experiences with each other? I’ll never tell them, but I hope so.
']

Title: Vintage photos show the unsung heroes of the US suffrage movement
Generation:
['Things are a lot more complicated for the suffrage movement when you combine the silent men in order to get elected, while the unheard women were evicted to the housing market.
This week, one photo made popular over a decade ago illustrates the havoc that was wreaked by injustice.
In December 1950, during the second American Civil War, Democrat Ralph Hall displayed what became known as his “Un-room Law” to a window and yelled, “As fast as I can go and it’s nobody’s business who has lived here ’til late at night.”
For some, he was legitimizing the suffrage movement as it spread from grassroots to state.
Today, that symbol is lost in the Vultures!
The vintage photos tell the story of the political change that happened when that Congresswoman saw a B, R and F going to the polls. Though she and Representative Mary Lousen hated the voting machines, they largely ignored what was going on in the system.
The election didn’t produce any legislators, both of whom voted “towards marriage equality.” However, the Vultures, or small towns as they were known, would use the machines to draw opposing votes. They gained ground in conservative states like North Carolina and South Carolina, as well as into Massachusetts, where African Americans still lived in a similar society.
It’s a powerful image, and shows an actual underdog after a fact about the result. Perhaps, even more powerful, it’s the speech, or the photo, of John Deere Chairman Edgar M. Evans stating, “Everyone needs to stand up for each other and defend each other.”
The suffrage story finally won a few states, and then another in Alabama that captured it for the first time. More than half of the state’s voters voted Democrat. And the story was helped along by these photos.
Of course, you know that heroics aren’t universal, and that even the typical suffrage story is missing a major element.
The class struggle of America itself is still suppressed. Civil Rights and segregationists took it upon themselves to leave the country. The suffrage movement came to close the door to secession in the early 20th century. But after the Civil War, the nation was governed by a small group that ruled by Communists.
More recently, the Vultures, or small towns as they were known, would use the machines to draw opposing votes.
That was a watershed moment in American history, as that nation was one of the most active in social change in history. And in a short time, the suffrage movement brought about a revolution of sorts. Even after all of this, suffrage activists had to use silent men in order to find an answer.
']

Title: El Helicoide: The futuristic wonder that now sums up Venezuela's spiral into despair

Until this past week, it was a fixture in the neighborhood’s nightlife: a sprawling array of cafe, bar, nightclub, movie theater, impromptu nightclub, and the world’s tallest roof over the South Barraza Boulevard to the right.
But the Alameda was soon headed for an even further odder frontier: Venezuela’s newest capital, at the highly trafficked intersection of Petare and Carrillo.
So, on Wednesday, the city’s Planning Commission and Valor Development Agency began enforcing an ordinance mandating that any buildings being demolished, or an annex or control in one of the adjacent neighborhoods, be no more than occupied and recoup all of the cost with no profit.
The legislation, passed with the council’s approval and then briefly approved in a meeting attended by representatives of the Venezuelan Red Cross and Medical Society, is now going to the National Council of Municipalities and most of the elderly.
But I like what I’m seeing: Giant dusting clouds of dust, which would, in this new era of desertification, make living as normal as the market would, and my friends at the Keyboard Baglaw have given a concrete forecast for the next two decades:
“The Rubicon at the intersection of Telesallu and the Barraza is a bright, vibrant community,” said the woman from the community, Stephanie Bowers. “The new rules are already forcing us to move into mass demolitions. When the plans begin to come out, they will start demolishing people’s doors, their houses and even the families’ televisions. And of course, my friend who just moved in [from Dominguez] is still in a construction project.”
And it’s not just people who are in hot demand, according to Bowers. It’s also high-profile citizens from Caracas, El Salvador, and El Salvador.
They have dedicated weeks or days worth of activity in the neighborhood to making the Rubicon’s wake up.
“Just over the past four days, our partners in the project have been busy building hundreds of new façades, upgrades and rebuilds that make access from Petare & Caracas terminal congest to Caracas public buildings that also occupy the space,” said Banistan Valerioz, a nearby urban planner, who admitted that she received a phone call about her good-looking neighbors’ demolition plans on Wednesday.
What’s even more exciting is that residents from nearby neighborhoods have been raised in this uneasy orbit: frequently bombed by crime, chaos and evil.
Venezuela isn’t the first country in which neighbors have tried to break up families or families have tried to build new ones.
In 2013, some cities developed a three-part plan where one wall of regulation were to be temporarily erected, one wall used to be to prevent the building of houses, and one wall was to be erected to prevent the demolition of trees and other delicate fields, to ensure a stable environment for farmers and the rest of the building-and-developing country.
Which is precisely what Venezuelan residents are demanding.
Thousands marched and chanted with the demolition of neighborhood homes in Caracas. But in Caracas, they were only one part of a bigger plan that promises to push the neighborhoods like plague – illegal structures, scaring off or breaking up residents, especially homeless people.
Without a sense of direction, the neighbors are left wondering just how important the new government is to their neighborhood, which is undergoing a so-called zero-emission revolution.

Title: The great shutdown of 2020: How newsrooms and media companies are adapting
Generation:
['Newsroom reform and radicalized “intellectual divide” caused a major shakeup in U.S. media when newsrooms launched their own “competent” attacks on conservative media elites, particularly the late conservative pundit Arianna Huffington, according to a new research from eMarketer.
That hate came along way after the nightly political news on CNN, a mostly left-leaning hub, more than doubled since 2001 and still attracts many of its viewers between the ages of 18 and 34, according to the study.
But it’s also just a bumpy road.
Several months after the shutdown of February’s unprecedented internet shutdown, CNN cuts back to regular and nightly morning news, reports said.
When it came to radical new thinking, only around 10% of staffers in CNN’s flagship newsroom added to that work year after year, according to data leaked on March 14.
In other words, six or nine years ago, newsrooms had no virtual presence outside the room at CNN, either if they did have affiliation with a real public television network or simply a “senior producer,” when the network’s actual audiences were considerably smaller.
In effect, the company was trying to replace its massive network of employees with “high-quality, targeted people,” according to the study.
The results of the study were outlined in eMarketer’s Economic Sustainability Update, an annual data forecast and analysis project based on numbers of companies’ products, services and products industry activities.
Here are some of the highlights:
While the topic “internet” nearly doubled from 2001 to 2012, less than a third of staffers in the company’s distribution force did so in the previous 12 months, the study said. It also noted fewer than half the employees in CNN’s newsroom consumed any news product in the past 12 months, meaning less there was in monthly decisions between newsrooms.
Among the biggest shifts were in the total number of people working in production, as well as in those who make their own reports, eMarketer said.
In the distribution side, fewer and fewer top reporters were deployed during the shutdown. More reporters at home made it through by spending less time working behind the scenes, eMarketer said.
However, the ratio of corporate staffers to “deep royal patrons” - of which both editorial and employee salespeople are known - is also increasing, eMarketer said. “Since change is as much about staff and services, our findings suggest that change-oriented, heavy editing of short and long investigative reports is more likely to require post-shutdown operations,” the company said.
Of the 82 corporate divisions that made up 83% of CNN’s distribution and production staff in the past 12 months, 39% had no people at their desks during the shutdown. That figure may have declined, but there were still 11,000 people at CNN’s main newsroom.
Some studios had relationships that were devoted to researching conservative media like Wired, and some projects looked at ways to fight climate change, eMarketer said.
“E-commerce, a vehicle that a staff member is mainly relying on to run most business, is becoming a trend,” eMarketer said.
']

Title: How Fox News misled viewers about the coronavirus
Generation:
['CLEVELAND (CNN) — Have you known anyone that was critical of Fox News? Have you heard from people who loved to tell people how great they were? That’s the message viewers of CNN were hoping to get from a new “Fox News Sunday” talk show, hosted by Scott Gaffney.
“I’m going to stick with Fox News Sunday,” he said. “There are six million new viewers a day. My daughter is watching, and she doesn’t know this. She wants me to know how Great — quite frankly.”
This year’s lineup includes “The Kelly File,” which Gaffney described as the “most beloved evening news show on cable television.”
But the talk show is just the latest addition to a channel Gaffney, a former anchor and executive producer of ESPN’s “SportsCenter,” says broke the “news cycle.”
“The one thing that challenges that generation is, there’s so much instability,” he says. “With Trump and the same issues as the ones that I was exposed to growing up, this election, has been a complete disaster for my generation.”
He said he’s helping ABC pull in a higher-than-expected ratings.
“We’re counting the legs,” Gaffney says. “Hopefully, this will help us get some advertisers.”
How Fox is misleading viewers
Gaffney says Fox News the network uses scare tactics that helped make the spread of the coronavirus, the disease that causes chlamydia.
“A lot of cable news networks have spread this story and pounced on the chlamydia concern in the months prior to the coronavirus being declared as a public health threat,” he says. “They circulated a link to the ‘scare materials’ used in this past election cycle as a cover to scare the viewers away. The network put them on a grainy, sizzle reel.”
It doesn’t take long to find out what’s driving the measles outbreak, which erupted almost exactly two years ago when the CDC began screening people from affected countries.
A spokesperson for the Centers for Disease Control says a link exists to the virus but has not yet been confirmed.
“CDC is still investigating this case and we don’t know what triggered the link,” the spokesperson tells CNN.
The Infectious Disease Research and Education Project says the virus “clearly” starts in the mucus membranes in the lungs.
But the CDC said in February that the diagnoses were made in the United States and that the virus could go into countries without tests proving it.
More people didn’t die
“Chlamydia has been confirmed in 10 states, but that doesn’t give the virus a set-up,” Gaffney says. “I have no evidence that could be meaningful.”
The government says it detected one case of chlamydia two years ago, but there has been no official confirmation.
About six weeks ago, the CDC told Gaffney that it had concluded that a case of lupus was related to the coronavirus infection, and he asked how we could have heard the word — the word wasn’t his and he didn’t understand it.
“That sounds a little bit like not being on the same page as the CDC right now,” he says. “But he, in an effort to do the right thing, has admitted that it wasn’t his decision.”
Not everyone
“He’s the opposite of the people responsible for this,” says Dr. Raju Nayanan, an infectious disease specialist at Vanderbilt University. “Not everyone agrees that this has become a global epidemic, and that there needs to be accountability.”
Nayanan worked for CNN before joining the network.
“If we agree on everything that we agree on, as CNN, and not others on it, then it doesn’t make a difference,” he says. “There needs to be accountability and there needs to be investigations and there needs to be content changes. I expect that standard and standards will emerge.”
']

All other networks are following the same standard as customers. The US Federal Trade Commission says it's an ad-hoc agency to track stolen credit and debit cards and trace the payments to an account. Google and MyCit is also doing this.

Title: US airlines will continue their European flights for another week

['× US airlines will continue their European flights for another week
(CNN) — Airlines on the US East Coast have decided to continue their nonstop flights to Europe this week, according to a statement from American Airlines.
But the three major carriers on the West Coast will not resume flights to Europe until May 26, American Airlines said in its statement. That means European flights will remain operating to the U.S.
The statement said the flights, which would begin as late as Monday and take several weeks to make up for lost time on Monday, would not resume until next week.
A ban on new airline tickets, also announced Sunday, will remain in place until their validity is confirmed by a USCAT examiner.
“Today, United Airlines and AirTran Airways announced that they plan to continue their bilateral airlines talks on Tuesdays and Thursdays through May 25 with USCAT,” Delta Air Lines said in a statement.
British Airways will resume its Delta Air Lines flights on May 27 for a night flight back to London while HWA added 5 cabs for its scheduled flight from Atlanta to New York City.
Air France, which announced Sunday that it would begin flights to Europe on May 12, said it would continue its flights to New York for 90 days — from May 22 to May 25.
The American plan of action is just the latest in a dizzying series of moves.
Last month, Southwest Airlines agreed to start its new Atlanta-Los Angeles flights on May 13. That leaves British Airways, Air France, UAUA and Air New Zealand — and possibly long-haul US carriers — unable to fly routes originating from their back-to-the-landers.
On Friday, Air France said that it would begin six new flights from Toronto every day of the week, starting on May 21.
For its mainline schedule, WestJet Airlines began flights on Mondays and Tuesdays from Los Angeles to Winnipeg, Manitoba — meaning that planes on the way from Ontario will take off from Calgary and Manitoba to Chicago and Minneapolis, respectively.
“These signals from the FAA and airline industry confirm, through a process of investigation and rescheduling, the likely order of air service in certain markets,” International Business Machines Corp. said in a press release.
']

Title: Walt Disney World closes, paralyzing the company's tourism empire
Generation:
['NEW YORK (CNNMoney) — Walt Disney World is closed, will no longer operate the attraction IMAX, and tomorrow the company said it’s suspending all promotional efforts to keep the company afloat.
Last weekend the board of directors announced that Disney’s parks would no longer be open. It has operated for nearly 50 years at the theme park for more than three decades, when it has had “periods of constant problems.”
Among the company’s many parks are the Magic Kingdom and Disneyland resort, in addition to two Star Wars-themed companies, and the Bob’s Pet Car park.
On Wednesday, Disney announced it would shut its Holiday Train Station, which it’s reopened since 2011, between 26th and 27th streets, to “begin a reorganization process.” It left 19 locations open to public transportation and one 50-foot jetty at Disney World, where evening entertainment is now available as well as in parks around the world.
Hours will be scrapped in the mornings to give focus to all the ongoing festivities, Disney said.
“It’s sad for a few people, but not for us,” Jill Morrison, chairwoman of the board of directors said in a statement.
Facing a $250 million hole in its budget, Disney has grappled with the biggest problem it has encountered in its 30-year history. All of its newly built theme parks are estimated to be deficient, and many museums and resorts rely heavily on brick-and-mortar stores. Many of those stores were built before construction began, and that decision is weighing on Disney’s revenue.
Related: How We Became A Beatle at 36
The closing of parks also would mean that Disney’s decision to divert some of its development budget to pay for retrofits and other improvements would hurt its tourist count in certain Western markets.
Walt Disney World, which opened in 1955, has steadily struggled since Disney first opened at Walt Disney World in Florida. It expanded through several acquisitions that paved the way for the company’s acquisitions of such European names as Disney and Pixar in the 1980s.
The company is now tasked with rebuilding its franchise. In addition to the Board of Directors, the company is also grappling with painful stock splits, advertising expenditures and new management teams.
In February, it decided to sell off some assets to give investors a choice. Investors who purchased shares were faced with risk of a $450 million penalty if they died.
The company is also confronting declining attendance at its parks, which jumped 11% last year. Attendance has fallen because many resort owners have abandoned those operations, according to a survey last year by the Institute for International Business Research.
That’s also a step closer to making it clear how the company’s working around-the-clock planning for its future will be funded, said the institute’s Philip Tenev in an email.
']

Title: How to work from home without losing your sanity

['Some of you may be thinking it might be fun to block out work from your busy life and stay home for hours. Well, not so fast. The Internet, we are here to help you create a work day that’s more leisurely and enjoyable — or that you’ll be able to actually enjoy — without worrying about your busy life.
At times, you might find this job is more stressful than you imagined. It also may be adding to the confusion of what works and what doesn’t. So when I asked Julia Roberts, now 42, to explain working from home, I was a little curious.
You should focus on building a day’s worth of productive activities for the rest of your day. Here are three key steps to ensure that your well-being is sustained throughout the day:
• Focus on the ones you care about most. Doing your work well is an important component of being human. Even if it’s hard to climb a certain fitness level, the good things are often just finding the one you’d like to pursue. When your life demands it, do this by working on things you’d rather get accomplished and be excited about. Don’t settle for what you’d like. Do more than just get in the habit of thinking about the task at hand. If you do your job well, you’ll be satisfied with it.
• Focus on your body. Work may seem like fun, but the truth is very often detrimental to your health. Think about your diet and habits of sleep. Put more exercise into your day than worry that your days could be shortened. If you don’t have a good day of sleep, you’ll be a lower-quality person in your sleep and you’ll be easily distracted. Leave time at home for things you care about. For example, washing dishes, cleaning out or taking medication for anxiety. If you don’t do a lot of people’s morning exercise — stop after 10 p.m. — you’ll take a hit from boredom. Try to pay attention to the daily schedule. Read and respond to your email until you’re ready to run from home and go anywhere. If you have a question about something you’d like to do, say it aloud. If you’ve come to fearlessly write down what you want to do, take it all down and then work on it until your mood improves.
What’s your idea of a low-stress day? How do you know which one to try?
']
