Title: What is a bear market?
Generation:
['NEW YORK — This is a question that most Americans are asking themselves. The answer seems likely, and it depends on which way you take it.
The bear market has started out with a slight uptick, but it quickly rose to a rally of sorts, reaching an all-time high of 11.28 before slipping back to a five-week low in the early morning hours. And as the supply of high-quality stocks gradually increased, stocks rebounded — especially in the fine industrial and consumer stocks sectors.
And this has not led to a long, steady, frothy rally. We're not here to rest on this evidence.
What is a bear market? It's not just about 1.2% annual growth, as the Standard & Poor's 500 index appears to be getting, but also of roughly 0.8% annual rate for the past five years, according to a 2005 survey by the MSCI World Index and by my own calculation as a number of guru custodians from Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
It's based on the theory that every expansion in prices leads to further price declines. But we may look back at the record 2001 bear market as that one. The big-cap telecommunications operator Xcel Energy Inc. has been one of the worst performers over the past three years, losing over 90% of its value to the late 1990s and 2001 recession.
"We are watching the drop in stock prices as a way to gauge if it's more likely that the rise in prices is becoming more like that behavior than something else," Marc Birtel, the portfolio manager of GAMCO Investors, told CNNMoney. "All the big changes are going to come from the rise in the price of certain stocks and that changes the number of people who feel comfortable with that."
One major reason this could impact stock prices is due to the fear of higher corporate debt rates. Earlier this year, the Federal Reserve eased interest rates for the first time since 2009. These lowered borrowing costs reflect a desire by consumers to invest even more in their homes and retirement plans. Then they see these higher interest rates get pushed up by the credit markets, particularly those with lower-rate mortgages.
While those higher interest rates may be a negative factor, the "only rationale for selling stocks is a fear of rising prices," said Rick Jaffe, an analyst at Technomic Inc. in New York. "As households grow more comfortable borrowing money to make purchases, they need an asset to buy back."
Indeed, the S&P 500 recently hit a 5-week high. With profit taking taking the market higher — folks selling stocks because the rally is too slow to grind upward — stock prices are being sold again, Jaffe said.
Others in the investing world say there are some signs that things may pick up, but not as quickly as some people may be hoping for.
"Many investors recognize the premise that the current high doesn't reflect expectations," said Nicole Trimingham, the chief investment officer of North Shore Financial Group in New York. "It's too soon to be a bear market. But when you have a so-called bubble-buster or bubble-gum type of event, you can do damage."
As for stocks that took a hit last week, Trimingham said it's not enough for investors to own them because the down-cycles do not seem to have started. If they are able to survive, "we'll know the fears and uncertainties have been carefully thought through, and some are still unforeseeable."
Jaffe said potential gyrations in the market are to be expected, but he doubts you need to panic to know they're high-risk.
"If people are still panicked, that could make that stock much more attractive for other investors and their portfolios. So your best bet is to put your money in stocks before a big downturn," he said.
And that's OK if you don't want to make the mistake of buying stocks at ground zero for the next bear market.
This is the question the experts are wondering. How do you evaluate where your money is based on what happened in the past?
']

Title: How a coronavirus 'infodemic' is infecting the internet
Generation:
['A coronavirus “has recently hit the internet, infecting almost 1,000 people in just over a week, experts say, according to CNN Digital News Bureau.
It’s not the first outbreak, though. Earlier this year, five people died, and officials still have not released the virus’ origins. But just this month, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said coronavirus activity for the moment was “in progress” and “far advanced”.
For now, though, coronavirus activity is clearly visible through the sky.
In a viral-like outbreak, it infects adults and children, often in the run-up to Christmas. And users of social media sites like Snapchat are so informed that they are often sharing their personal details like where they have been staying at, instead of direct medical tests or identifying where they came from.
Nonetheless, there’s a big difference between the two. Infected people tend to be sick in one way and treated in another. Individuals won’t be rushed from hospital to hospital, nor will they be diagnosed in a doctor’s office. The risk, at this point, is a little too low, because in the past, these things work out badly.
The main event
While the coronavirus is not completely unheard of — a norovirus was detected in 2012 at some California beaches, briefly causing severe vomiting, diarrhea and possibly kidney failure — this outbreak suggests that children are not immune to the virus. It’s impossible to definitively say for sure — the public health agency is only starting to address the disease — but more and more people are becoming aware of the link between the virus and people.
Risk is in the air, though: People have been identified as potentially infected once or twice in the past, with potentially a fifth suspect being removed from the picture as the public health agency sees fit. And the viral viral sides of the animal cannot be spread by mean-spirited, harsh doses of immune systems. It can spread easily through viral transmissions.
So, we can rest assured that the Global Warming Solutions Network is watching what happened and reporting on it. Not knowing who to trust, and don’t know which agencies are issuing updates on where they are reporting on the disease is as risky as the internet at this point.
Alas, the problem’s still not totally solved. Though coronavirus officials are looking for signs of the virus, while doctors are working on more than 2,000 cases, they haven’t found evidence yet to support the notion that it is the cause of such a widespread outbreak.
In its study about coronavirus, the CDC described the virulence of the virus, with the company mainly attributing increases in infections due to the potential to infect animals and humans. But that isn’t the point.
“There’s a terrific possibility that something more severe was going on, and it was not the lead element in the viral race,” explained Jane Whitlock, chief epidemiologist at the CDC. “The viruses represent a huge and thriving infection pathway, and that a lot of these factors play a role.”
']

Title: 5 things to know about the payroll tax
Generation:
['WASHINGTON (CNN) — Americans will soon pay a second year of a five-year payroll tax cut, known as a 10% payroll tax. The tax was first phased in in 1991 to partially reduce the wealth gap.
To read about it, click here.
Here are five things you should know about the tax for 2019:
It’s the longest of the tax cuts, which was enacted in 1991. The government has estimated the tax cut reduces the value of the U.S. dollar by almost $54 billion a year by year three.
It’s not automatic, however, so workers who do receive less income will pay more income tax for their workers.
Because the tax cuts take effect from 2019, at some point in time, the federal government will have paid approximately $50 billion in personal income taxes under this bill, a figure called the tax shelter. That’s the cost of the tax in most states, and that’s also the cost of the tax in taxpayers in more than half of the states that don’t have a state tax shelter.
The 11-year record was 12.2%
By contrast, it was 19.8% when it took effect in 1995.
The Senate passed a law to lift the tax deferral period.
By law, employees in states with a payroll tax are allowed to claim tax deductions after tax breaks have expired in a consecutive year. Most of the people who took advantage of the program would have taken advantage of it if a sign-up had not been extended.
Employers will earn a lower personal exemption under the tax cut compared to the top of the range.
To read about it, click here.
Saying “sorry” for it isn’t going to lead to higher insurance premiums.
The tax cuts are subject to a one-time rate of 39.6% based on the value of the U.S. dollar. It will remain at that level throughout the tax reform, which is scheduled to take effect on April 15.
Many of the remaining deductions will also be automatically taxable and indexed to inflation, which should make an impact on ratepayers who don’t save enough to cover the government’s obligations for the $8.5 trillion budget deficit, which grew by an average of 0.5% a year between 2013 and 2017.
The tax law then also makes it more difficult for businesses to deduct annual employer-sponsored health benefits from their federal income taxes.
For the first time, the costs will be shared among individuals and the states, which will make a cut in the corporate tax rate.
If you’re worried about losing your job, keep in mind that this plan does nothing for middle-class Americans, who will receive fewer benefits and may pay more in taxes in some cases.
The number of hard-earned tax credits will remain unchanged.
The tax cut will also ease some of the capital gains tax rule.
The estate tax will be halted after 2027 for estates exceeding $400,000. The tax cut, meanwhile, will go into effect for most estates and will lower income tax rates for families with assets valued at $1 million or more.
Those with more than $10 million in assets will still pay an exemption of up to $250,000. Those with more than $50 million will be paid a tax break.
The rates on individuals and couples with total assets exceeding $10 million will remain unchanged.
Companies will continue to be able to deduct other deductions from their federal income taxes.
']

Title: Minecraft hosts uncensored library full of banned texts
Generation:
['Most game creators never think of a ban that has been issued or lifted, but once it does there are constantly bugs, myths and inherent dangers to computer games.
These pesky and frustrating bug reports have proven to be a major pain in the ass, and gamers may not always be good at using their systems.
That's where the free online storage app Minecraft comes in. The tool, available on iPhone and iPad, offers a freely available library that keeps library books and videos accessible.
“Minecraft is a huge word of mouth type experience with a number of different communities and different partners,” Dan Koedler, lead developer of the third-party website 16BigBuild3 and a marketing guru at the company behind Mojang's hit PC release Minecraft Studios, said in a YouTube video posted on Tuesday.
“Even though the words ‘Minecraft’ are out on the free app, it’s important to know that there is absolutely nothing for you to say about that book and it isn’t something that you should be using.”
While there's certainly much better alternatives to the endless anthems of the world, most players only get "closed library" apps.
“We constantly monitor the updates by players, that can prevent them from having their library back open, or indeed, support problems like weird rumblings if an app restarted a problem,” Koedler told CNN.
So why are libraries so suddenly banned from online play?
These are the elements that are known to be clunky and complicated and often disable library functionality. In addition, games aren't just digested in smaller libraries.
“You know just by the basic flaw of the game that the library lacks massive amounts of resources,” said Poppy Champ, the founder of website Slippery Fishing. “It’s the holes and gaps you’re missing in the game that make it so very difficult to program that library to program the game.”
“It’s a blanket ban that says that you will not be able to play on all your devices, but unfortunately it’s not true,” said Dave Hankinson, the product development director at Address.
To combat this problem, you can turn off folders, not folders, off all supported libraries. To do this, you need a second set of folders and screenshots.
“Making a small substitution a few days later and a full library in the same image and location was probably just a matter of designing a little additional library that people could download and use,” Hankinson said.
Hankinson said doing that simply required combining two unrelated libraries, and the potential is there for long-term benefits that will outweigh any negative consequences if you accept the message.
“If you can’t master the art of maintaining libraries, then it’s somewhat less important that you rely on positive forums where people share stories and look into the exploits of holes and quakes and other unexpected and controversial events.”
“Most games come online and are sold for free, so having these libraries in the hands of friends is a good thing,” he said.
While there's still some legitimate issues on the horizon, Minecraft offers exactly what you'd expect for such a limited window.
']

Title: Apple's massive WWDC developer event will be online-only this year
Generation:
['SAN FRANCISCO (CNNMoney) - A crowded Apple keynote Monday evening is the last chance users will have to wait before they can chat live with the world's leading tech company about its newest and most successful products, and how Apple is affecting people's lives on and off the iPad.
All said and done, and today, Apple is paying tribute to 9.7 million developers and small companies. That's more than 13% of all tech companies in the US and a lot more than the combined spending on digital advertising, outside advertising, of hundreds of thousands of businesses.
It's a point executives at Apple have made for years, and on Monday they described the huge fan base that is just getting started.
"We need to strike a balance and sustain and innovate in this market," Apple's John Gruber told reporters. "But we also need to make sure the ecosystem of developers, everyone on the platform, engages developers as we evolve."
Developers, developers know that iPads are the biggest revenue source, so it's important to figure out where everyone is contributing to tech spending growth.
That's why the shows at Apple's annual developer conference usually end in a speed bump last year, when smaller numbers of developers attending for a typical live gig show emerged unscathed. They cancelled altogether, selling out of tickets, other attendees started looking elsewhere or cut back on their efforts.
"They chose to isolate the success of the incredible star developer ecosystem from revenue," Apple analyst Mark Gurman wrote in a blog post. "For Apple, this contributed to a new set of fees charged to developers," he wrote.
Gurman's blog post contrasts the best of Apple's response to problems encountered at iCon in San Francisco.
"Apple employees have sought the best business practices for iPad design — whether you like it or not," Apple's Sheryl Sandberg said on the conference's opening day. She explained why her company had spent $1 billion to retrofit its iPad tablets, making them more affordable. And she stressed the need for apps to be "accessible" without having to pay multiple people on a business end.
The Valley's sometimes fake interactive Apple parties seemed to work well, she said. But she added that the platform wasn't without some glitches. She didn't elaborate.
"There are several Apple events within the year for iPad and iPhone events," she said. "You'll hear more about these events over the next few months. But to date, a great deal has been made about the way Apple is managing various problems and enhancing the community. We're at an inflection point where we are working as a team and with our customers to engage and learn from them."
Though Gurman offered a suggestion to figure out if people were giving up on the iPad, or if they were running out of room for an idea to pop up with a better platform, anyone who has purchased Apple products is likely to be surprised.
One of the biggest selling points of the iPad has been its ease of use and safety. Apple released the iPad Air the week before Apple opened its new iCloud service to developers, and Apple chief executive Tim Cook responded by talking about how much more safe and up-to-date the company's main product is now.
Though the iPad Pro is considerably better at making photography better, the Pro doesn't hold its own against what Apple is likely to gain by giving the iPad a stylus that can actually mimic a photo — but if the iPad Pro can help the position, it could make it a little more palatable to families.
Let's say users don't live in California and live near Apple, which has new iPads in every market in the world in 2019. They'll be able to take an Apple TV and watch videos, chat with Apple speakers and use their iPads or tablets as plug-ins for TVs and more.
According to McKinsey & Company, the lower-cost iPad Pro offers buyers a cut in the initial costs of cloud services. That, or it could cost anywhere from $200 to $400 less to $499.
Copyright 2019 by CNN NewSource. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
']

Title: Finding God online: People turn to live-streaming religious services during coronavirus pandemic
Generation:
['You’re on vacation? The last thing you should plan to do is search for a doctor to tell you about your case, or turn to Facebook to find prayers and concerts before you die? And that is what makes people turn to live-streaming religious services around the globe for answers.
The trouble is, this is the 10-year-old Web-based Internet, and the majority of Americans are consumers of entertainment media, not religious services. (That’s a problem, because I used to play video games and watch movies online every day, but I hardly make a dent in online storage.)
Determining where to look for accurate information is a difficult process, and people increasingly are relying on live-streaming services that typically start in foreign locations and last from a distant family or religion. The examples here include the viral Games With Games, which has streamed live-streaming Christian prayer services at the world’s most-popular festivals (such as Saint Peter’s in the Jewish Quarter of Jerusalem and The Ghetto Visitor in Buenos Aires) and The Walker QQ Service, which also streams online.
And according to The Washington Post, Global Internet Watch estimates that 34 countries have services dedicated to Palestinian religious organizations, as it reports. The figures are based on tracking visits to the services by 23,000 people worldwide, the online giant’s data shows.
It’s not surprising that such services are popular in some countries: Seven of the nine countries are leading Asia and Europe in membership in the World Internet Day for Electronic Religious Media (WTOP) worldwide, and 73 countries have applied, according to the report.
The poll of 62 countries came to Pew’s conclusion that 68 percent of those who are Internet users are religious believers (that is, they follow the faiths of others on the Internet).
More than half of those who are Internet users still participate on a regular basis – with 60 percent of younger U.S. Internet users — and the median age of those who are internet users is under 20, with 32 percent of ages 18 to 29 among them. But when asking people what religion they belong to, 25 percent of those older than 20 said “Christian.” There’s a strong sense of religious pluralism in conversations, and that two-thirds of those online use a religious site.
The data shows that the sites increasingly have come under increasing scrutiny – and has stirred new concerns about the digital sexting habits of companies engaged in sexual conduct in order to get or maintain youth demographic attention.
“This is a huge, and obvious, concern,” said Mark White, a research fellow at the U.S. National Bureau of Economic Research. “We now have to see this through, and try to make the debate for an informed one about how this is affecting all of us.”
For how long may this wait? The Pew report found that the U.S. Social Security Administration might see an uptick in the number of religiously-affiliated bodies affected by the RSVP pandemic.
That would make it one of the few surveillance strategies with upside. Still, it’s a big deal for two reasons: It will reduce the amount of time individuals spend looking for religious services in their own locale and reduce the potential vulnerability of religious sites.
For churches and synagogues, the political concerns arising from the pandemic leave them baffled. Even more troubling than giving a loved one a phone call is having him or her profile on another religious site.
“I am busy here without any religion whatsoever to ask for anymore answers,” read a statement by the Solebury CT-Tower Senior Pastor Jane Scahill, who worked for the RCH Group for 21 years.
“I feel like I’m doing it myself,” she told CNN. “What if someone from a high-profile Muslim cleric contacts me about an incontrovertible problem? Who am I, over my phone?”
By Amy Lafleur and Michael Grunwald, CNN
']

Title: Pentagon 'wishes to reconsider' $10 billion contract given to Microsoft over Amazon
Generation:
['SEATTLE – The Pentagon is continuing to explore the role Microsoft Corp. plays in the military, but said it wishes to reconsider a $10 billion contract that the Redmond, Washington, software giant offered to Microsoft last year, according to a classified memo obtained by CNN.
The Pentagon awarded Microsoft a contract valued at $10 billion last year, but officials said they had been looking to turn the $10 billion over to the Congressional Research Service, in an apparent response to criticism from its staff that the project was still being run out of government money.
“Microsoft will provide the federal government with a set of new services that reflects the fundamental values and values of the Washington Department of Defense,” the Pentagon memo said.
The memo noted Microsoft had contracted with a service of the Defense Department’s Precision Pilots Service, a civilian agency formed in 1985, that had recently replaced the DoD’s Department of Land Management.
The memo was first reported by The Washington Post.
A spokesman for Microsoft said it was still looking at the contract, which was given to the same group of service members at Fort Hamilton in Maryland in the early 1980s.
“In the end, you’ve got to have the right people, and if they don’t have the right skillsets in mind, they’re gone,” he said in an email.
Mark Adams, the Pentagon’s deputy chief of staff for military affairs, said the funding for the service had been approved in 1985.
“It’s just been awarded because we believe the numbers are what we had hoped,” Adams said.
Microsoft spokesman Paul Kocher declined to comment for this story. He told CNN that the Pentagon would examine the contract.
“We are encouraged by the feedback that’s been received,” Kocher said.
The question of whether the Pentagon has appropriated money to the military has come up frequently at meetings of Congress.
“I was quite struck,” Arizona Democratic Rep. Dina Titus told CNN. “If we’re talking about a budget decision between the U.S. government and the private sector, I think we should treat all military spending as public spending.”
']

Title: Disney delays 'Mulan' because of the coronavirus outbreak

According to the National Health Service, Lorencia virus is an Influenza A form of coronavirus. Cases have occurred in Argentina, Brazil, Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Cuba, Central America, Thailand, the Philippines, Colombia, Guatemala, Honduras, South Africa, Taiwan, Malaysia, Mexico, Sudan, Thailand, and Cuba.
No deaths have been reported from the virus, which causes pneumonia and serious conditions such as chronic respiratory diseases. The virus can cause miscarriages. It is considered endemic to Asia and is spread between humans.

Title: Disneyland closes because of the coronavirus outbreak
Generation:
['NEW YORK (CNN) — Disneyland said Thursday it was closing all of its two theme parks because of the outbreak of coronavirus.
The parks will remain open in both Florida and California, but staff at Disneyland will no longer work at the park. Disneyland will operate in Florida. Walt Disney World will remain open in California.
Disney is still unable to confirm whether the outbreak itself was the result of the outbreak.
“While there was always a risk that this issue might affect my employees as part of a continuous staff review process, the news that this is the result of this internal review was unexpected and it did not appear as though the company understood the severity of the crisis,” said Disney Disney Americas CEO Christopher Yancey.
The risk of coronavirus infection is more than 900 times greater than the risk of a flu in the general population, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. About 5 in 10 illnesses can cause a fever, rash, joint pain and swelling.
The CDC said coronavirus is an exceptionally rare disease known for having no known genetic or chromosomal mutations.
Contaminants that cause these illness can spread to others by touching or touching surfaces, including surfaces where water is contaminated, park gates, lifts and other property that are covered by clothing.
People infected with coronavirus as a result of travel, direct contact or social contact — between individuals and suspected people — are not contagious and have no symptoms.
']

Title: NBA suspending its season is a serious blow to its TV partners
Generation:
['The NBA is reportedly suspending its second straight year, just days after the league announced that it had approved an overhaul of its broadcast rules.
The decision follows a series of lawsuits over whether last season’s work was fair to its sponsors, including Nike and Hyundai.
The league’s vice president of sports and communications, Jamie Horowitz, told CNNMoney in an interview that the league had made its decision because media are increasingly aware of the effect of these setbacks on their broadcasters.
To uphold the rules, the league recently cut the number of commercials from four to two per minute, and threw out those considered too ad-free.
"The 5-second rule has to be reinstated,” Horowitz said. “So we have suspended a season this year.”
The suspension will be lifted April 30. The NBA and partners will do the same for each of the next four years, at least, they said.
"The league’s decision to drop the 5-second rule was not based on any incremental disruption to the revenues it serves by its licensees," said ESPN Executive Vice President of Sports Business, Larry White. "If the NBA drops 5-second advertising, our teams and clients will no longer have to spend on those revenue-producing programs."
Watch the full CNNMoney story here:
']

Title: How NASA's Apollo program kicked off Silicon Valley's tech revolution
Generation:
['Thirty years ago, I got a lot of steam in my mouth when I walked out on Tech@Work - a big event, estimated at 300 people - without hearing anyone ask me why I was there.
I remember the mood first great shock. A small cohort of young entrepreneurs, mentored by Silicon Valley co-founder Larry Page, arrived at my cubicle in the morning to start a nine-person crew. The first question I got is: why are you there? A modest, similar outcome than we had imagined three years ago, when I grew up in Winterset, Ga. In 2008, my daughter, Madison, was born, and we started as a small group of travelers - from the U.S. and Singapore to the London, Tokyo and Beijing - who wanted to explore the world at all.
I watched as students started using (or as the media put it - borrowed) Einstein software to track their successes.
In fact, I was a part of a group that was started because it seemed like a huge, world-renowned company, capitalizing on the luxury and economic opportunities that were available. The group launched into an aggressive cadence: One of its main accomplishments was partnering with tech banks. Many of the professors from Stanford University and Stanford-based firms were also participants in a roundtable discussion, and I spoke with them about why we worked in tandem.
I put in almost everything I could.
I put in my time, wardrobe, hair and clothing. I went from yacht cruising cruising at sunset to launching the rocket industry on an ice tanker on a Gigafactory-sized ship with a bandaged arm. I worked out a letter schedule and raced with the radio to make the best leap possible to sustain the momentum built in the Silicon Valley days. I talked with my crew at four to five newscasts. I was part of a Twitter-industry contingent. I met customers. I met engineers. I built whatever I had on paper.
That's what I did. Because I knew that to understand the real challenges ahead and to continue doing as much as I could, I had to learn to work. On the runway, listening to those who had made a name for themselves and had sent thousands of emails that would get our replies sorted.
And then there were the motivational speeches on the steps of the U.S. Capitol as training instructors, in a time where Silicon Valley interns had never even spoken to each other in person.
While I was at work, hundreds of others began enrolling in massive open online courses, or MOOCs, from David Kilcullen, Google Ventures and early investor Jeff Skoll, all of whom I had been around for so long that I knew they had to be ready and prepared for anything. The larger, deeper business organizations, the STEM community and tech businesses in general were rushing to get their hearts and minds spinning.
Silicon Valley veteran Daniel Heyman, speaking at Tech@Work, struck me as almost visionary: "This new generation is absolutely prepared to take full advantage of the opportunities there," he told attendees.
']

Title: Jeff Bezos just sold $1.8 billion worth of Amazon stock. Here's why
Generation:
['Best of all, for some extraordinary reason Jeff Bezos just sold another $1.8 billion worth of Amazon stock.
Amazon stock, which had previously been listed as "undervalued," was bought with proceeds from an acquisition just as Bezos did not go public again.
Drew Stubbs, a professor and chair of economics at Stanford University, posted the news of Bezos' sale to his Twitter account. But first, he shared a screenshot of the sale to Bezos on Twitter.
The sale to Amazon — said to be an all-cash transaction — was being made because Bezos, Bezos's richest company, is facing growing competition and rising costs from new entrants in an increasingly competitive market.
"Amazon has flourished in recent years, and their stock price is likely to continue to surge in the near term," Stubbs wrote. "Many who believe Amazon is no longer a core business are out of a job."
Amazon stock rose substantially last year on speculation of a possible sale. Since its IPO, it's risen 64% to $101.39 per share.
Those figures reflect the company's advanced technology and plan to modernize its products faster and ultimately convert those services into low-cost ones.
It's also challenging to remain in one of the world's wealthiest companies. Bezos himself is making money off sales from Amazon.
In the closing hours of his public announcement, Bezos addressed the latest round of speculation in the company's stock, but did not mention his income by name.
Amazon's stock, which had risen 50% the year before after top CEO Jeff Bezos announced the sale, looks expensive now, Stubbs said.
He concluded, "We know that our business model is working at scale and we have delivered it to all our customers."
']

Title: Bill Nye's experimental spacecraft that sails on sunlight declares mission success
Generation:
["FILE - In this Aug. 6, 2015 file photo, astronomer Jim Ayers, left, and luminous planetary research module Onyx are working on a cloud-powered cosmic platform that will beam images back to Earth using solar systems that have been associated with sky-watching, as well as speculation about extreme solar weather. In the International Astronomical Union's scientific meeting in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Wednesday, March 4, 2019, Onyx was named a major 2012 candidate for the four-person team that will study low-earth orbit (Earth-Solar Belt) at the helm of new space orbiting spacecraft known as InNova. The trip to New South Wales, Australia is slated for late spring. (AP Photo/Albert Choudhry, File)
WASHINGTON (CNN) — An American spacecraft orbiting an old moon named Onyx has won its fifth prize, promising to bring back photos of the sun when it reaches zero gravity and rotates in orbit around the planet.
Onyx, one of NASA's last astronauts to attempt a spaceflight, will go on a full moon in January and the moon in February with the other nine astronauts on the mission during the mid-term elections in 2020.
The space station is orbiting the world's largest moon, called Nusa Dua, about 9,000 light-years from Earth. Its orbit is targeted to end this year.
It's a third prize in a new NASA collaboration with Bright Horizons, a Colorado-based nonprofit that coordinates the space station's science missions. Bright Horizons will work with the space station's Science Mission Directorate, or GSID, and NASA will deploy its orbiting activities.
ESO, an EU-based organization that conducts orbital operations, recently named Enclared, a name referring to a spacecraft made by the European Space Agency, or ESA.
Onyx is the final named NASA rover before it is canceled. In the meantime, it travels through an asteroid-orbiting suborbital path around the Sun.
As Kepler revealed in 2009, one of 10 planets investigated with radiation likely escapes from the binary system because of its orbit.
Onyx will sail on at least six times its initial diameter with two arrays of solar panels aboard. The solar panels take over three-, three- and five-times the weight of the power generated by the modules, yielding a 1-kilogram space rock as strong as the solar panel.
The solar panels are required to withstand harsh conditions with a temperature of just 45 degrees Fahrenheit.
Scientists project the solar panels will run in conditions where temperatures are likely to be a few degrees cooler than the Earth.
Solar panels must stay on as long as 4.5 billion years — more than the time a typical summer clings to a brick wall, when the solar panels were used more often.
"]

Title: SpaceX's massive Starship prototype lifts off
Generation:
['United Launch Alliance's International Space Station, designed by the ULA CEO, SpaceX, landed in the sun Monday on its fourth attempt at transporting the current Dragon space capsule to its destination.
The 55-foot-tall Starship, which stands about 60 feet in the air, is designed to carry two rotating Earth probes into orbit to test whether or not it will survive another year of operation, NASA said.
By transporting the mission, SpaceX hopes to re-enter the space station to make sure it reaches its scheduled April launch date. The mission took about 30 minutes to set up on a periscope, and typically spends two months or more in the pad, one NASA spokesman said.
"We can operate more efficiently during the Earth and Mars summer months, and potentially be able to grow a better view at the space station for Earth and Mars," Musk said.
The capsule, designed by a cosmonaut from Alaska, will receive a cargo of oil, newsprint, and other components as it arrives in orbit, SpaceX officials said.
The spacecraft will then lift off on its next rocket launch. SpaceX officials are in talks with all major bidders to get the first unmanned test flight ready, the company said.
SpaceX's robotic Red Dragon, launched in 2015, landed in the sun just last year, moments after launching back into Earth orbit.
']

Title: Elon Musk's brother wants to transform farming
Generation:
['Mumbai, April 5, 2017 (PTI) Tesla Inc. chief executive Elon Musk announced yesterday that his own backyard farmer needs a replacement for a gas fireplace.
“The fire is the most challenging part of any kitchen-burner. The boiler puts it off, sometimes it burns or the ceramic pipe doesn’t work,” Musk told his audience during a meeting of Indian professionals.
“I’ve got to downsize the boiler to kill it,” Musk added, adding that he is already considering using it to help make his estate more fuel-efficient.
Instead of burning wood or steel, he uses heat from a fire escape.
He claims to have found a way to compete with Korean wood manufacturer Sunbeam by using the heat from a traditional fireplace instead of running off coal-burning furnaces.
And his company says that its new fireplace also allows the company to reduce energy use.
His family empire is worth $10 billion.
Ever since the company launched in 2005, its founders have been working hard to follow the golden rules of economics.
On May 5, the company announced it had concluded an engine cooperation deal with Dubai-based agri-trader SA, which involved the creation of the world’s first fire escape.
Criminals at the heart of both Musk and Sunbeam’s deals are fugitives.
Sunbeam’s garage in Mumbai is home to more than 6,000 pieces of equipment a day, from electrical wiring to mirror optics, that can convert carbon dioxide from a wood fireplace into light for cooking and lighting.
Rocket guru Elon Musk Ltd. is investing in Mumbai to keep track of patterns in the city’s electricity supply, the state-controlled Mumbai Electric Supply Company, and the Mumbai Electricity and Natural Gas Corporation.
This enables the city to take advantage of a country where power cuts are virtually non-existent.
This partnership is expected to transform the city’s electricity supply, with the leakage rising to nearly two out of every three connections according to India’s Electricity Distribution Company, a Delhi-based business house.
Last month, Musk opened a hydroelectricity venture that would put an investment of around $4.6 billion into a development scheme that will also utilize electricity generated from water.
In November 2017, Musk said he is considering the use of computers to rate the bottom of a car’s cost. Musk said that the project could also help advance electric vehicle development.
“The car is the key to the economic growth of the city,” Musk said in a conference call earlier this week.
']

Title: How virtual reality is changing the live music experience
Generation:
['SAN FRANCISCO — A little less than 12 months after its release as Sony Ericsson’s first foray into virtual reality, Sony Ericsson is reimagining it for the living room.
Sony Ericsson, which released the concept, now says Oculus Rift VR will cost $1,000, while the software series will cost $25,000, including a subscription. In the office, the virtual reality app is also free, though that starts at $20.
Related: Oculus Rift 2 and Oculus Go are working together
Virtual reality is a “luxury of the moment,” Richard Cornish, director of research and the product design team at Sony Ericsson’s global PC group, told CNN in an interview.
“We’re playing into virtual reality’s natural appeal when it comes to getting our movies in front of the world, making it more visually engaging,” Cornish said.
YouTube videos are just beginning to roll out and streamed content for the headset is likely coming early next year, Cornish said.
Besides doing the virtual reality, virtual reality is also being used in the research and development of VR assets, the companies said.
There are already headsets on the market called HTC Vive, Microsoft’s Project Morpheus headset and Sony’s Project Aura, which also uses a camera.
For iPhone users, those headsets feature 64-bit processors, using the same Adreno GPU as the iPhone’s 1.4 GHz Dual Core processor.
Of course, there are more exciting features that could be brought to the living room.
“We’re trying to make the headset meet the reality we’re trying to lay claim to on the market and that will be true regardless of our technical prowess,” Cornish said.
Others are also bringing 360-degree video features, such as Oculus’ own VR Experience, which is one of the first virtual reality apps.
Like the Oculus Rift headset, a 360-degree camera that takes some pictures can’t actually sit there. The camera then records the distance between the view and the viewer in order to capture the scene.
To be held in your hand while watching a game, a compatible controller is included. This makes filming as a virtual reality experience experience feel even more immersive.
Other clients include GoPro, Ring, Airbnb, Space.com, a tech company “reinventing the idea” of indoor space, a VR company “to play with social networks like Facebook, which provide a sense of what the virtual space can bring,” Cornish said.
As well, the new phones support a mobile app for monitoring, storing and receiving captured images and videos.
As with the way the real world works in- and out, bringing smartphones to the living room could be in line with how the makers are designed.
“You have to be able to act quickly to take them,” Cornish said.
Rob Enderle, president of the Enderle Group, said the need for headsets to work together to form a “real-time experience” is nothing new.
“There’s a lot of competitive focus here. They’re starting to build on some of the advances in the ability to work more efficiently on technology and VR,” Enderle said.
But the key to getting their software to work as well as on the move is more than just looking at experiences in the office — it’s building them as applications and services.
“You want to be able to provide them with a unique experience,” Enderle said.
']

Title: A new use for McDonald's used cooking oil: 3D printing

['You don’t have to be a pioneering scientist to understand the latest innovation on kitchen concepts.

Moved up in the competition for consumer attention is McDonald’s

A pioneer in 3D printing

Johnson explained that the machine was invented in 2012 and it has been using 200,000 markers to make “social” posters, stickers, patches, bracelets, edibles, and bio-doubts.
The previously tried 3D printing tool hasn’t been backed down, he added.

Plastic or tray of food?
Johnson also noted that, like many personal chefs, “they figure out a way to make it easier to handle it,” said Johnson.

According to Tu’s FizzCon, the concept was almost finished and was “surrounded by 50,000 fans that turned out every Sunday for a press launch and party with celebrities such as Steve Madden, Miley Cyrus, Joel Madden, Jean Paul Gaultier, and guests of the celebrity chef.”

Title: US clears the way for this self-driving vehicle with no steering wheel or pedals
Generation:
['By Leigh Dorsett, (CNN) — Inside the world of self-driving cars, autonomous driving is no longer a novelty or convenience: The approval of a self-driving vehicle is a prerogative.
Just a couple of years ago, it was a rare, dystopian and out-of-the-box idea: What if a law made it possible for anyone to summon a car—or, it seems, a car of its own—without having to walk through a public park or post a Facebook status.
Now, relatively quickly, it’s a mainstream reality. Google’s self-driving Vision cars have made a big splash on the road thanks to their global launch last year and are rolling out on more than 100,000 vehicles. Thanks to social media-savvy brands like Drive with Google, bots, and self-driving taxis, zero-emission vehicles make a comeback to the road, only to be shunted back into the field when a key development or roadblock becomes necessary.
Today, while fully autonomous cars exist, it’s still some way off. For now, self-driving cars are simply a glimpse into what’s possible. But what about when we’re looking at the future of the ride-hailing app and self-driving SUV?
The 2016 Consumer Electronics Show was full of talk about self-driving cars, but the biggest was the Internet.
The boom in ride-hailing services and driverless cars ended up siding with traditional car-less societies, where select members of a defined group of workers could fill the roles of driver and helper, with their own vehicles.
Not only did self-driving cars end up being entirely feasible, but they all came with a price. For starters, self-driving cars must be able to change the vehicle’s primary positioning if the driver tries to exit, and more importantly, when it’s no longer possible for a driver to stop. That means automakers need to make their cars more efficient and maneuverable, even without seeing how well they handle serious traffic accidents.
Ride-hailing “experts” say that never-ending waits for emergencies and high crashes, even repeated slowdowns and stomach-churning lost flight times can lead to unsafe drivers. These advocates argue that providing safety for the public with an open road can be reined in by highly trained drivers.
So what’s going to happen if the highways and cities across the country slow down as self-driving vehicles roll in?
The popularity of self-driving cars has tapped into a larger long-standing shortage of decision-makers in the U.S. for the skilled position of executives at autonomous vehicle companies. First, these people have to show the public that autonomous vehicles are safe and often the only people who will risk their lives to drive them are people like myself, who I could be saved in seconds.
Then, drivers have to convince their employers and workers that they know they’re saving human lives—in fact, self-driving cars cost less money than driving wheelchairs or wheelchairs with a steering wheel—and there is reason to think people on boards and boards are going to be interested in this kind of artificial intelligence.
For self-driving companies, Uber and Lyft are simply embracing the digital presence and autonomous driving trend they have built for themselves. While autonomous ride-hailing may make consumers wary, its partnerships with transit companies and self-driving schools are making autonomous vehicles economically viable and offer a bigger picture of the potential economic benefits.
And through the improvement of public and city streets, it’s less likely we’ll be faced with the kind of safety issues we’ve often been saddled with at once, just as it was the precursor to the automotive boom.
Simply put, the future of the ride-hailing market is simpler and more predictable. But, as electric cars fade, so do the idea of driving electric cars. My point is that these are the future, and it’s working.

Title: Welcome to Walmart. The doctor will see you now

Those questions have all been plaguing Walmart for years now. This February, the company officially went forward with a pilot program that requires applicants to pick a gift or deliver it (while not ordering food, it was ordered in the parking lot). Passengers will be able to order groceries at Walmart without having to speak to a human or navigate a kiosk.
Problems have arisen all around since the pilot started, but let’s assume that Walmart has only managed to arrest some of them. The retail giant is currently undertaking tests to test whether use of the technology will cut down on customer frustration.
The safety of this type of service is one of the most important questions for the company, and for the employees involved. Walmart had to apologize to customers because of the pilot program, but it’s only created concern that they will be overly-drastic with their operations.
Walmart is doing this to appease many people and in order to increase revenue, the company needs to boost sales even more. Stores are going to be smaller because they have to constantly emphasize their customers. And I expect this experiment to grow even more with millennials, and millennials seem to be happy with that choice.
Perhaps most importantly, Walmart is still learning its lessons from its many failed trials with human side-pods. After all, the store stores always look slightly different and real life slightly different, and Walmart is still trying to hone those aspects as efficiently as possible. We haven’t seen them master that yet, but eventually it will come.
Meanwhile, the new operation by Walmart and the technologists that will eventually onboard the pilot program are people who are going to carry the groceries, and may not be expecting to be able to get through the next few days without the computer being in your face.
The pilot is fairly stressful, and the testing has already begun, but what’s to stop the company from having to cut back on more than one service?
The people behind this experiment are doctors who get a lot of help from Walmart workers. They’re majoring in computer science, because they’ve never been a part of anything but their compassion and love for people.

Newstix

Back in 2006, 10 years after signing a U.S. agreement with Audi, BMW named it the “Primary Line,” meaning “Voyager.”
Initially, that phrase meant “The mission and the purpose of BMW is to, by and with the people and agents that drive vehicles, lead the society to a better future,” according to the company’s website.
Now, the badge icon is not a flag, but rather a form of self-expression: a place for on-the-road experiences where customers would get to see and hear the vision and experience of their lives if they drove a BMW.

Another adjustment, with the introduction of an adaptive wing mirror in 2016, involved merging BMW’s signature features with the offerings of its digital signage.
Among the upgrades, the lightness of the headlights, for example, and a number of other changes, include standard body and wing tail lights, as well as a wider “full-up moonroof” featuring fog lamps, a more upright backview and a narrow rear wheel-drive.

Lavocel grew up a big fan of wine grapes, especially grapes growing in Peru, which he first visited at the beginning of the year and saw the vineyards of Tavecchio and Don Echoc, who both started this was their last. "Jungle Bubbles" is a nonprofit teaming up with the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) to lay the groundwork for a new way of making itself known in tourist and campground-bound areas.
A bouquet of mama elephant tusks has been included with safari tickets, but that's not what's as eye-catching as the sight of elephants sitting on trees to kiss and pat one another.
"That's simply the nature of a mama elephant. And that's what this new platform we're creating is designed to make about 110 elephants, as many as a hundred of them, available for virtually any tourist to stroll in a single destination destination on the lush Golden Triangle," said WCS President Kim Compton in a statement.
Jungle Bubbles will be one of 22 cities in Thailand hosting wildlife parks across the Golden Triangle, which officials say is the world's largest.
Most of the cities will be within two hours of each other, but visitors are allowed to wander through the vast complex in the wild around midnight.
In addition to the ropes of trees, bamboo tusks and a white barrel adorned with exotic and rare animal names, elephants will also make it a place of worship for visitors.
And the elephants have to have had a healthy diet to support their daily lives.
"What these animals are being forced to eat is going to be difficult for them to find food and other undisturbed, nourished creatures that are so nutritious," Compton said.
People will also have to endure some new challenges to make it out of the jungle, without a full-blown tourist experience from the park.
"People will come and enjoy nature while it's not real," said Compton.
People who attend the park will be seated in the "Jungle Bubbles" canopy as artificial creatures dancing in the trees. These animals get to greet the visitors with kisses on their leftovers and also learn about animals brought in by adults.
The project is funded in part by a $4.3 million grant from WCS, which will also direct hiring and development efforts to sustain the three million-plus animals in the park.
One and all, the new identity will be given to nearby areas to emphasize the holiday spirit.
"Looking around, through the different trees and in different ways, from destination to destination, the tourist experience will take place and continue to feel like a local holiday," Compton said.
The new "Jungle Bubbles" tree will be open on October 1 in selected places around the Golden Triangle. Those are open from 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.
The new attraction, a "terroir with no wall, no one," will be complete in December.
']

Title: Boris Johnson won't be tested despite UK health minister contracting coronavirus

['London, UK — Boris Johnson cannot be tested for coronavirus, the British Health Minister said on Thursday.
Johnson, who publicly revealed Wednesday he was infected with a form of coronavirus while on a trip to Brazil with his wife Emma, said that he’s had received credible reports that it’s not true that he’s contracted the virus.
There has been no link between two viruses, no sign of flu, no increased risk of contracting the infections, Johnson said at a press conference in the capital city, according to AFP.
London police said Thursday they will be investigating the allegations.
“I’ve reassured our minister that I’m very sorry for the initial statement that the Health Minister made,” London Mayor Boris Johnson said.
“I would like to stress that I have spoken with my health secretary about the report that the British Medical Association publishes with regards to the accusation that I may have contracted the coronavirus, the one that was really passed to me personally, and that it is a false statement.”
Johnson has been in the public eye ever since he told reporters at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, last month that he was ill with the dangerous virus.
He said in a lengthy letter that he began experiencing “a very low rate of sleep” two weeks ago, because of fatigue from the trip.
He said he experienced mild headache and difficulty breathing while in the ambulance, while was stitched together.
The infection was suspected in early February while in Brazil with his wife.
Health experts at the time said that the presence of the virus was not conclusive enough to confirm that Johnson had contracted the virus.
A second source — a person whose symptoms have included weakness, confusion, severe vertigo, and suffering from acute intoxication — has also become ill after arriving in London.
Doctors said their operations could have resulted in further infections — the source has yet to be determined — but they also said they believed they would not have contracted the virus since his symptoms had not been noticeable at the time of the trip.
Johnson told the Press Association in March that he was taking steps to protect himself from the virus.
Capping an hour-long news conference on Thursday, he said: “The only conclusion I can draw as a person is that I should be taken more seriously because I know how much (my medical troubles) have contributed to this particular tragedy and that is why it is necessary that we act now.”
He added that “if I can get away with it, even if I mean it” he was “not going to get me back into the crowd.”
Campaigners have been increasingly calling for action against British health ministers and health insurance companies over the investigation, claiming their response to allegations from the BMA was biased.

Johnson said he understood that the BMA has informed him “all the time” that its investigation would focus on whether there was a broader pattern of failures in the industry.
But he added: “My mind is clear now: No other member of government ever is going to take the fight to the media and press who allege the wrongdoing of my ministers.

But in this nation of immigrants and Italians, it's quite possible you're the one who's lost your identity and identity in just a few minutes.
In Italy, where people of all persuasions are fighting for their identity, an act of national condemnation that many saw as retaliation for those immigrants have dropped off as the immigrant population of Italy flattens.
The lockdown in the countryside were intended to make people aware of the fears they had for their identity and for their national unity, said a public relations consultant who was on the ground for roughly 60 hours towing the evacuation order Thursday.
The authorities had said they were leading a push for immigrant citizens to come to the security forces' door as some, including doctors, had their names and photographs removed.
"I've been to the border, so I know what they're going to do," an immigrant said after authorities ordered him to leave, "and my all of my family's around here, so this is an attempt to discourage immigrants from returning to Italy."
There were a number of attempts on social media to spread the news but none appeared to work.
"We were all sleep-deprived, and I saw the mirrors of young children and young adults crouching around in chairs and crowds, and all that stuff," said Silvio Fiori, 40, a returning pizza maker and a member of the Rome Archdiocese of Naples.
A man on social media posted a photo of his mutilated son in protest, with the caption, "Grievances from Italy." The couple called the night evacuation a deliberate attempt to entrench their right to protest, Fiori said.
Local politicians expressed their anger online and three social media accounts, TMZ.com, BGR.com and QIQ -- which is owned by viral video website TMZ.com -- boycotted the event.
And some were still waiting for the announcement that the detention order was lifted when rescue workers went into the village of Yrudrugi.
The government's secretary of state for security Sicily Kekua promised a complete week of "stop and search."
Kekua said the evacuation order had been lifted and federal investigators had taken their report to the head of Italy's civil aviation authority, who said he would take a board meeting later Thursday to decide whether to stop the nationwide work stoppage.
On Thursday, Kekua said the government was not trying to get rid of private citizens or businesses, but was trying to improve the situation.
The event had also stirred up street protests on several Italian streets, as workers attempted to get permission to resume the leave. They tried to get the mayors in Umbria and Palermo on side streets out to the north of the town hall, using the roads as platforms to reach their homes.
Emanuels Party mayor Il Cerito called the action "another manifestation of the lies coming from all those who have said that if foreigners are visiting Italy they don't want to live here, and they were afraid to say so."
Several of Italy's political parties defended the decision to detain immigrants, saying security forces are always capable of reacting.
"We will not allow those who visit our country to violate our borders, get inside our borders, and never come back," said Silvio Berlusconi, leader of the ruling centre-right PDL, referring to the frequent walkouts by labor and immigrant rights groups in the past.
']

Title: Desperate migrants keep coming. Now vigilantes are threatening the welcomers
Generation:
['(CNN) — Women fleeing life-threatening conditions are flocking to remote mountains and ziplines, rescuing people in low-grade ice and in often intense heat before returning to the villages or rivers that feed their push towards the world’s most dangerous and impassable places.
At a sweltering Munich, Sweden’s modern equivalent of the Arctic Circle, about 1,300 people in Croatia are scheduled to leave Croatia for Switzerland, but only about half of them are physically enough to travel far enough for crossing the river into Austria and Switzerland, according to the migrant-refugee crisis center International Rescue Committee.
What’s more, despite international aid organizations’ desire to address the issue, more than 2,600 people have managed to go since September — still more than half as many did a year ago — with dozens still too exhausted to try to get across, ICRC said.
“The challenge is continuing to rise at a rate similar to the number of European migrants, since the situation on the ground, including in some of the ziplines, is not fully democratic,” said Peter Gabriel, head of the ICRC.
Sections of Central and Eastern Europe will be affected by the scaling back of winter aid deliveries to some of the region’s poorest eastern Europe, said Gabriel.
According to an Indian official, 250 people have arrived this week in Germany and 300 in Hungary.
Traveling expenses
The ICRC estimates the economic impact of the tightened aid shakedown efforts in Central and Eastern Europe will be worth a minimum of 10 million euros ($12.5 million) over the next two years, while humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders estimates the cost could be up to three times higher.
The ICRC worries that more than 2,300 people have set foot across the route from Slovenia to Austria in the last year, crossing from the Nordic country’s volatile border with Austria and Slovenia.
“From Austria we were at about 6,000 euros per day, about 10,000 euros in the last year, and this period is going to increase,” Gabriel said.
“They’re going to have to take even more desperate measures, not the least of which, because we are under-construction in Hungary, or in many cases Belarus, so we’re seeing further straining on the infrastructure of Hungary to build the borders.”
After months of talks with the communist governments of Austria and Slovenia, the International Organization for Migration has advised Hungary to distance itself from smugglers.
German authorities launched an investigation and Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Urrike Giordano called the ICRC’s human-rights report “textbook.”
Their fears are echoed by Falun Gong practitioners in Hungary, who also await final decisions on who will bear responsibility for the human misery inflicted on their adherents.
Sobriety, stress
Meanwhile, migrant arrivals have increased.
More than 500 passengers have managed to safely cross the icy border between Hungary and Austria since September and 2,200 have crossed into Italy since that date, with others landing in Berlin and several moving to Austria and Germany for their own benefit.
Officials say they’re monitoring the situation closely, but there is a “high risk” of additional migrants landing at the border and making it through via Bulgaria or Macedonia if they are in Hungary.
Hundreds are expected to make the crossing, and a “call-out” warning has been issued for the two Balkan countries. One Turkish official says the country is already considering asking for the rest of the migrants to stay.
“These figures are true of every other country, but we need to see a real and moral risk to be a part of the global plan to help people in the hard times,” Gabriel said.
Yvo Leipold, deputy chairman of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, said at a conference here Thursday that “I hope that 2018 marks the beginning of a new era of refugee arrivals.”
Some are fighting in Europe to get out or get back to their home countries. In the Arctic Circle, a relentless flow of up to 4,000 people by the thousands has spread throughout Central and Eastern Europe and has prompted predictions of a “second migration wave.”
But media reports on Monday express a different prediction: At least 15,000 migrants won’t be inside Hungary or Austria if the authorities fail to reroute those attempting to reach Europe.
']

Title: Putin backs amendment that could see him run Russia until 2036
Generation:
['Russia’s president gave a news conference Wednesday at which he backed a proposal he’s submitted to the Congress in the wake of the failure of an emergency summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin over the weekend.
President Putin told lawmakers he is planning to file nomination papers with the emoluments clause to run in the presidential election for 2036, which officials have said will no longer be the case after he takes office at that time.
Speaking at a television ceremony Thursday at the Kremlin, Putin praised Trump’s efforts in trying to repair the strained relationship between Washington and Moscow — but cautioned against viewing it as a policy choice.
“It’s not an (election) decision, and a promise is not simply. It’s an attitude,” Putin said. “I’m glad we can now consolidate this relationship,” he said.
But Putin also defended US-Russia relations in general.
“We are an alliance which is not just a bilateral relation, but one in which our two national interests are always central,” he said.
Putin said the present push for change is a recognition that for the Trump administration, the 2016 election was a classic case of the Trump effect.
“The manipulation of the electoral system has been accelerated by people who, to a great extent, saw not only the election outcome but also by Trump,” he said.
Notably, the Kremlin says it has reached out to its partners and allies to try to support the proposal, which Putin says is being aimed at hitting the “threaten” of the Americans’ expulsion from the United States.
Putin also gave praise to Trump’s counterterrorism adviser, Michael Flynn, whom he says was critical of the US government in Syria.
But Putin found some of his praise to be rather petty, accusing Flynn of lying about his conversations with Trump.
“I say very forcefully that, in the very first in the process, Flynn lied about having these conversations,” Putin said.
Putin also questioned whether Russia had to pay for those sessions.
“I find it perfectly clear that there have been exceptions.”
But Putin and other world leaders also accused the Trump administration of fabricating evidence to justify its crackdown on journalists, including Trump’s former national security adviser, Michael Flynn.
“My explanation is that these were decisions made by the American administration and — such as the informality [here] — they happen to fit the worldview of the president of the United States,” Putin said.
“Trump has exhibited in many ways what he has said all along the last few days.”
Clinton had said Trump’s repeated calls for the withdrawal of US troops from Syria last month “deserve the same degree of scrutiny as what’s happened here.”
But it was Trump’s campaign adviser, Rudy Giuliani, who said in an interview with NBC that Trump’s campaign had been “pretty inconsistent.”
He also challenged Putin’s assertion that the situation at the summit has improved.
“Maybe it is the administration, but President Trump and the meeting in Washington may be better than Obama,” Putin said.
']

Title: Legendary chef Michel Roux dies at 78

['Michel Roux’s restaurants, among them Café Caprice, Café Nicolai, Central Saint Martins, Cololi-Le Mars and Sheraton.

“He could end any restaurant up with ‘I am on the staff’ or ‘My steak is better than your own’," one friend once told some.
He also dabbled in Greek pastry, even so much as his tongue. “Nothing against Perlstein or Scrivner or Zephyr (the Von Boel taverna the great dish of the 1980s), but Roux was a very serious raconteur," one of his last remaining friends said, adding that he even cooked for some real meals.
Roux died at a Paris hospital late Tuesday, which confirmed his death. In a statement, Park81, a spokesperson for Roux’s Restaurant and Provisions, confirmed that the famous chef died after suffering from pneumonia.
After some success as a cook, Roux set his sights on French gastronomy. Not satisfied with his efforts, he moved to England. He threw down the gauntlet to renowned funder Grant Ferretti.
“Who wants to get to Paris?" Ferretti said the the year that he launched his “Mehal” line in 1991, which sold more than 150 million units worldwide.
In 1994, the French chef even reinvented himself as the boy next door. As one of his early influences, he held the title of best cook in France until he was killed in 1999 in a car accident.
In a 2005 interview with France’s newspaper Le Figaro, Roux defended his French restaurants. “I simply can’t cook in Paris. The phrase ‘room for food, for service’ is one of those moments in life, a moment to experience somebody else in depth."
The chef also said that “unless you are a cynic, you’ll find something in Paris where you don’t think things will improve overnight."

Rapinoe, a U.S. Olympian and former Wall Street Journal economics editor, was among a dozen women who accompanied head coach Jill Ellis, recently thrust into the national spotlight after revelations that she once sent players teary-eyed on social media about being coached by Bill Donohue.

Title: Ohio governor explains why he closed all schools

['Ohio Governor John Kasich on Monday decided to “work all year with the students” to close the schools until possible legislation to prevent “scheduling conflicts” at other schools is implemented.
Kasich clarified the move when he addressed the Ohio Chamber of Commerce.
Kasich recalled that he opened three different schools in the state prior to the 2008-09 school year. These were convocations, presidential retreats, and lectures for “unfettered access” by non-native speakers.
“Our governor has decided to leverage all of these lessons, as he articulated to us in 2016, for the school closings … in 2014,” Kasich said Monday during an event at the Ohio School Debate Center in Parma.
“If if you close any more, this one you will do,” he told the audience before switching gears and asking them if they supported closing any school or programs.
For nearly two decades, Kasich has pursued opening all of the schools. The only president who allowed those closures was George W. Bush.
Kasich didn’t directly address whether he still holds that view, but did say he continues to believe a closing of the school would never happen.
“That’s all going to happen and even if it ever happens … in the states of Ohio that you talk about, we’re going to re-think things and we are going to re-evaluate the opportunities that are open to us,” he said.
“And that’s what’s really driving us to have these choice decisions, the choices that we want them to be open … we want them available to everyone,” Kasich said.
At the April 2013 commencement ceremony for Michigan’s University of Wisconsin’s Paul T. Ashe School of Law, Kasich made clear that Michigan’s lawsuit against the state is a “very serious issue” and the case is set to become a hot item in the 2016 presidential campaign.
“And if we need one more way, if we need another way, we are going to come forward to come forward and we are going to fight with all our will,” Kasich said.
Kasich said Ohio has roughly 30,000 law schools. Of those, he believes 67 to 79 will be hit with the statewide or statewide closings, while the remainder will be shuttered.
He explained the closed schools would mostly be closing school day operations, similar to schools with a larger campus, such as the Southeastern Ohio University School of Law in Saginaw, and many more smaller.
And he cited the four-year project he had with Wachovia to purchase the principal’s and custodian’s properties and to take them out of office areas.
The state has increased capital investment for the school districts, and for the businesses that will be closed, Kasich said.
“I also think our revenue was very much sustainable,” he said.
Kasich also addressed two of the reasons he closed dozens of schools:
“One, there is less mobility. You know how there is with school days and there was a, I think, an undue anxiety about time times that children don’t have a second break that feels like they’re coming into full-time employment,” he said.
The other reason he closed 50 schools is, “Some schools just won’t be closed anymore,” he said.
“And therefore our schools are going to be closed,” he said.
“Because of the tuition and fees and other things of that nature, there’s not so much – there’s not at the school level, either. And we’re talking about really, really important projects that will build a successful institution, and there’s going to be educational programs,” he said.

Volume on the Dow surged 100 million shares, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence.
At the close of regular trading on Monday, the Dow is up 15.12 points, or 0.06%, to 16,294.62.
The Standard & Poor’s 500 index is up 6.12 points, or 0.06%, to 1,707.75. The Nasdaq composite index is up 8.13 points, or 0.3%, to 2,027.93.

Title: Trump suspends travel from Europe to US
Generation:
['FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump arrives at the Downing Center in Downing Center in London, Britain, March 30, 2018. REUTERS/Hannah McKay
By Faye Flam
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump suspended entry to the United States into Europe for the 90-day period Thursday morning after Britain's decision to leave the European Union and has ordered his unilateral ban on all new visa applications in the Middle East and Africa.
Boris Johnson, the Foreign Secretary, announced Trump's action at a news conference in London, where he expressed confidence the United States would not face "catastrophic consequences" from the decision.
Trump said the ban would be issued on Sunday, when European Council President Donald Tusk opens an emergency meeting of EU foreign ministers.
In Brussels, the EU expressed shock and dismay that British foreign secretary Boris Johnson had reinstated the program, after the EU expressed alarm over the May 9 referendum vote.
While it can take until May 12 for one visa for a new case to be approved and after that time for it to be re-used, Britain and Europe cannot attempt to make permanent arrangements on their own.
"This so-called Brexit was a stupid decision by an incompetent, arrogant and inept British politician with a superficial understanding of the EU," Irish Secretary of State John Denham told Sky News.
At a news conference with his counterparts, Trump said he would not allow his executive order to be reviewed by the European Commission, which reviews matters that go beyond the "day or night" when Britons go to vote on Brexit.
"I would advise all European leaders to make clear that the Brexit process is an administrative nightmare," Trump said, declining to elaborate.
A copy of the statement of the U.S. presidential message was released in White House comments, and the text of it was not immediately available.
"As a leading advocate of the best interests of our country, this is a tough decision," it said.
In all, as many as 21,000 visas have been issued for European nationals since the referendum in Britain.
The European Commission, a common "customer-lending" body, said that no order had been issued in total over the past three months.
During the U.S. presidential campaign, Trump vowed to prevent Europeans entering the United States but later appeared to backtrack.
His decision was an unusual joint, bipartisan move by the governments of both parties.
Trump said the people of Europe did not want "an America that has fought those wars, grown up with those monsters, and doesn't want to confront those guys."
Much of Britain's leading opposition has warned that there would be much greater fallout in Northern Ireland as the United Kingdom falls to the EU after Brexit.
Separately, U.S. officials said they believed that new refugee policies would help bring in people to the United States. (Reporting by Faye Flam; editing by Jill Serjeant and G Crosse)
']

Title: This child is smiling, but her story is devastating
Generation:
['CLEVELAND, Ohio — What just happened to this 7-year-old toddler this week has revealed, at a time when young children are becoming exposed to so many drug and alcohol abuse stories and accusations of sexual abuse, pain and trauma, why this story might just be so much better for them, and how quickly they will improve.
The girl’s story brought tears to everyone’s eyes.
About a week ago, she was eating toast when she said a man tried to rape her, and when she heard his screams he was locked in the kitchen. When she didn’t answer, she saw the man in front of her.
That’s when the boy grabbed her, put his hand on her shoulder and then jumped out of the kitchen. She fell.
It’s the time when most children use these experiences to try to connect with their family or even to correct their own behaviour. Like a train rushing down a street.
Yet when an injury happened to a toddler, the good news is that the worst comes when a child and her family figures out that they do not have to be the ones risking their own lives.
That’s when the issue starts, not the child but the family, and that causes many kids to suffer.
I recently wrote an article about two young children who were locked in the kitchen and told how their mother locked them in the kitchen because they were afraid, unable to handle the stress of the situation.
Why is it that these children are afraid to confront their abusers? They think that if they get the legal duty to do so, their parents may be powerless because they are too young and afraid to talk to their abusers.
It is common for a child’s family to be violent toward parents and make threatening comments to them when they have difficulty handling their own stressful situations.
These abuse stories take the life of all kids.
My story was heart-wrenching.
This child was only 7 years old and cannot read. She is critically ill and his mother has lost her job.
When she told her parents about her ordeal and how her life is in danger, they ignored it and she was severely injured and wheelchair bound for months. Then she visited the U.S. and received a diagnosis of brain damage and lumbar fusion and subsequent spinal cord injuries.
The doctors began taking at least two or three of her measurements to see how she would be in the future. After months, their thoughts were good and they did take at least one more test and an MRI.
I told them about her disabilities and how she was so badly hurt that her nervous system was no longer working and she needed brain surgery to start fresh.
When the operation was complete, she became 9 years old and soon lost the ability to talk. She has visions and dreams and therefore has difficulties talking.
Because of her severe neurodevelopmental issues and subsequent spinal cord injuries, she is unable to find or think anything. She will often hide her emotions behind tears, which is an incredibly painful process.
It’s so frustrating and cruel for families to deal with such a heartbreaking story. I am personally heartbroken.
The reports from this event should be terrifying to everyone. I suspect if parents and the media hadn’t pointed out this, so many could have ended up like this kid.
So let me pause here to say that no matter what type of situation this child’s parents, their families, and the families of all other children, would be able to put this childhood story at the heart of their lives.
I will be examining this story by donating to a family that I could do something to help, and I hope they’ll find their right now.
']
