The European Union has maintained that it has the right to tear up such a deal if it disagrees with its commitments to Turkey and other EU member states. It is likely to reject the revised language.
The deal paves the way for Turkish Prime Minister Binali Yildirim to step down once the economy rebounded following three months of austerity.
Commenting on the specifics of the deal, a NATO official described it as “unwavering confidence” in Turkey’s ability to keep its membership bar firmly in place.
“Today, I’m confident that the EU’s bedrock partners, Greece and Turkey, have approved this latest development of negotiations to sign a full-fledged project to liberalize the European Union into a truly free trade zone under two million strong,” the EU official said in a statement, adding that the group would continue to seek an alternative.
Yildirim has been ill since the two-day EU-Turkey summit on Friday saw the usually vigorous opposition represented in the European Parliament and others who led the charge to push his candidacy for prime minister.
Earlier Tuesday, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said: “In the summer’s international community there will be a free movement of people; in the summer’s international community there will be not even free movement of people.”
It remains unclear how Turkey would react to what it sees as a violent crackdown after Prime Minister Binali Yildirim finally rejected an EU offer to host the 1 million Turkish hryvnia (1.3 billion euros) aid package.
Akseddin Demirtas, the executive director of the Turkish Media Institute, said despite Turkish concerns that the deal has not yet been fully implemented, it remains a point of hope.
“For the Turkish people, this is a potential hostage for the deal that we are seeking as a whole,” Demirtas said.
To try to contain the EU, Ankara had adopted a common language with the European Union that highlights challenges. But this would not have allowed for Turkey to negotiate directly with the EU, dealing a blow to its EU-brokered aims.
Relations between the EU and Turkey soured sharply after Turkey blamed its terrorist groups for the chaos in the south. Erdogan blamed ethnic Kurds for the strife, trying to undermine popular anger for next year’s presidential election.
Turkey rejoined the European Union as part of the 2015 deal but President Donald Trump opposed the move, insisting it will free up EU foreign policy.
Since then, Erdogan has used his crackdown on protest and repression to seek the EU’s blessing on a group of rebel factions running a rebel coalition in northern Syria, threatening to bring war to Turkey.
']

Title: American Dynasties: The Kennedys
Generation:
['(CNN) — Which three of America’s most famous politicians are connected to the National Security Agency? That matter came to court Thursday as prosecutors sought to prove that they were not just some ordinary citizens of the United States but actually were individuals associated with the federal surveillance program, whether or not they were already in government office at the time.
From intelligence agencies to Congress, they are believed to be paying attention to whenever one of these little guys has entered a government service. The Reuters/University of Chicago report on Thursday alleged that a large number of young Americans recruited to join the U.S. intelligence program in the 1990s were essentially given “tactical protection” during their years at the agency — not as spies.
In 2011, while they were preparing to go public with their identities, a former consultant contacted an FBI agent posing as a middleman in determining how to secure a conviction for the CIA-led “black site” operations. The agent expressed interest in working in a White House security detail for former president George W. Bush. He claimed he was “a very reliable case study,” though the agent refused to describe him as a “smooth” and “an honorable man”; the FBI said in 2011 he was “not much more than another piece of paper.”
A Justice Department attorney, though, never attempted to address the relationship between the former consultants and the FBI agents used to investigate his ideas. “There was no agreement or understanding of any firm that they were going to work together,” the attorney reportedly told the Justice Department. “At that point, they were not going to question the man.”
While the two men have since cooperated with the government, now-defunct companies are at war over whether the NSA is authorized to spy on their communications and whether their communications resulted in personal communications (which they were not privy to), or should be used as hostage-taking tactics.
The House Intelligence Committee in February last year unanimously voted to condemn the unprecedented Justice Department probe.
According to documents obtained by Reuters, the CIA-led “black site” operations conducted under FBI command oversaw plots for the CIA to hack into and steal emails, passwords and other sensitive information.
In “White House,” a note included in the indictment notes that a former intelligence analyst from Nevada, Jack Dorsey, who had served as the president’s chief technology officer, was involved in the groups when he brought up the NSA program while investigating presidential communications.
In February, Dorsey’s lawyer, Scott Reed, called the FBI’s appearance in court a “complete fabrication” and accused them of trying to “silence the public” in the aftermath of Clinton’s resignation.
“What the FBI has tried to do in this case is to silence the public’s questions,” Reed said during a court-appointed recess. “It’s a felony. It’s a perverse irony.”
']

Title: Pope: The Most Powerful Man in History
Generation:
['PHILADELPHIA, N.Y. - The biggest man in American history received the 2016 Kennedy Center Honors on Thursday. It is a special honor that recognized the former pontiff for his leadership in the fight against AIDS, the fight against climate change and work to end poverty.
Vatican secretary of state Cardinal Timothy Dolan received the Kennedy Center Honors for his five years of service at the helm of the Roman Catholic Church. Pope Francis received the award on Monday, the most successful pontiff ever inducted into the hall of fame.
Dolan, who was an administrator and a bishop from 1974-74, before retiring, has worked as the pope's spokesman for the Vatican and government for the last five years.
He has a strong record of serving on top policy and other high-profile positions and has considered changing the Vatican to allow universal marriage among the group, a demand that would open up a new front in their fight against AIDS.
"If you listen to the pope's comment, it is quite an accomplishment," said former clergyman and congressman Pat Toomey. "He knows what everyone wants out of life. But he is telling people that that is a challenge. He thinks this is not the end of the world."
Toomey was one of the staffers who focused on the push toward universal marriage.
The American Family Association, which represents about 250 evangelical Christian leaders, also lauded the pope for his efforts toward this goal, noting his role as a friend.
"Many of his words have come from the heart -- the humility with which he addresses his age, his understanding of the scriptures, and his awareness of the power of the Gospel to help human beings to live God's commandments," said President Reagan's spokesman, Tom Albanese.
President Clinton's Secretary of the Treasury, Mary Baker Eddy, also received the Kennedy Center Honors for her work in the struggle against AIDS.
']

Title: Louboutin wins fight to trademark red soles
Generation:
['(CNN) — Danish metal grinder and electronic super fan Stefan Louboutin beat out the other three competitors for the coveted red soles at the 2018 Winter Olympics.
The 25-year-old Austrian held off the doubles team of Manchester native Shawn Sloss and German teaming stalwart Toby Kuhn to become the first professional male to triumph at a Winter Olympics.
The gold medal was Louboutin’s second of the night after he won the bronze-medal victory over Lithuania’s Yulia Yaggin in the semis. He also won the bronze in men’s Alpine skiing last year.
Louboutin had his bronze medal in the men’s single-pine skiing moguls crash on a snowy piste at St. Moritz just a month before the Olympic closing ceremony in Pyeongchang.
The gold and silver medal in the men’s figure skating will play a big role for this year’s Winter Olympics when the three medalists are announced in early October.
Louboutin received an update on his progress on Thursday, tweeting out “most important time” after he’d raced his first road race of the season on Friday.
“I think my first practice victory was probably around 3:40 p.m. in the morning,” Louboutin told the Munich-based newspaper Darmstadt Zeitung. “And by the third quarter I had broken my neck.”
On Wednesday, the 30-year-old tweeted out a “thank you” to world championships medalist Jonas Hojn at the Rosa Khutor Alpine Center in February.
“Thank you to the Russian team, Joe Olina [Sebastian] and [TOM] Kronshild,” Louboutin wrote in a tweet. “Your healthy spirit made for an awesome moment. Thanks for allowing me to have such an amazing run.”
The Austrian faces a tough task in this week’s big meet, hosting a short track event at San Jose in California at the weekend.
Sloss, whose pursuit of a maiden Olympic gold medal in the women’s skeleton won gold in the 2014 Vancouver Games, had a nasty fall during Sunday’s medal push, plunging to her knees and gasping for breath before being stung by Louboutin’s heels before returning to the track.
“This, my second start at the Olympics, was a spectacular one,” said Sloss, who also raced his father Ryan Sloss to the 1924 Salt Lake City Olympics. “The success I’ve been enjoying this week and all the hard work I’ve put in throughout the season has helped me continue my development.”
Meanwhile, Louboutin told Darmstadt Zeitung that he is still frustrated at missing a chance to compete at this year’s Olympics.
“It was really amazing,” he said. “I was surprised that I was at these Olympics because you see so many upsets.”
Louboutin will take an advanced package from his father in his attempt to compete at Pyeongchang, where his dad won the last four events.
The Austrian, who finished fourth at this year’s Baku Winter Games, is best known for his electronic style in tight pants and sporty caps, and has won gold medals at two of the events he competed at at the Sochi Olympics.
Louboutin’s strong standing in the world of electronic music certainly wouldn’t hurt Louboutin, who just last week entered a record book with twenty new songs.
Louboutin’s songs have been included on Billboard’s Hot 100 countdown. He also recently landed on the concert soundtrack for the Disney Channel TV series “Flowers in the Attic,” about a singer-songwriter who gets hitched to his dreams.
He tweeted about celebrating his feat on Thursday.
“Just finished recording my first #Electronic music album,” he tweeted. “However after a week of delay, it is finally coming out this week. Thank you to everyone for their support and staying the course!”
']

Title: Netflix is worth more than Disney
Generation:
['Every year, data from entertainment websites like Research In Motion’s Research In Motion Ltd. and Starz shows a correlation between the number of monthly Netflix subscribers and the number of Hulu subscriptions. Is Netflix like this? Yep.
The activity is quite random, though, and, really, what they show is over and over again. Netflix’s $40.1 billion in revenue at the end of last year was on par with Disney’s $47.3 billion in revenue. Unlike most on-demand entertainment providers, Netflix doesn’t stop streaming content all the time. Netflix also tracks subscriber engagement and demand; with Netflix’s first year’s number of U.S. subscribers I’d consider an early indicator of engagement.
Netflix is already grappling with declining monthly user base, with subscriber costs increasing while streaming revenue is falling: about 25% growth from 2012 to 2017, to $1.2 billion. Two of Netflix’s key sponsors, iTunes and Disney, recently announced a joint venture with Apple. iTunes is a digital music store offering content from artists like Miley Cyrus, Ray Charles, and many other artists. iTunes said that streaming video on Netflix and iTunes is over 95% penetrated.
All of this illustrates the one thing Netflix could do differently. No matter how open we are to sharing our internet, simple information or snooping on our friends, the way we use our voice and screen is going to disappear. The tech companies that want to fight at-large control and censor content, do so in ways that benefit consumers. Microsoft, Google, Amazon and the like are currently unable to do so, as a result of their stake in satellite TV distributor DirecTV. They can’t fully build any “computers” when those control groups aren’t removed by the DMCA. The far more worrisome tactic they’re using might be to get their overly profitable cash cow out of the way. Dish wants to kill that business model and grab 10% of the space in the whole pay-TV business.
Netflix is so effective at doling out such free TV content that some analysts believe the company could be on its way to being the dominant video content provider around the world, if not a satellite TV provider. There’s a price to that: Significantly less than Apple and Google could require such a truce. Fortunately, the studios in attendance at this week’s CINEMA conference are accustomed to this concession: Netflix has also signaled that its content will also be marked down if it gains significant market share.
Netflix is more than just a streaming service that consists of massive data streams. It also manages the astonishing size of its subscriber base. Since 2014, Netflix has grown almost 13% from 58.6 million to 73.7 million. And, if this trend continues, as expected, the company’s subscriber base should exceed 400 million by 2018. It’s where we’re going to see serious inflation over the next five years.
Netflix’s move to crack the $30-per-month for streaming is a stroke of genius. Consider that at the end of last year, 40% of its current subscribers streamed more than one service, so the company is shooting for 200 million monthly Netflix subscribers in 2020. To put that number out there, you can’t say the same for just Netflix. It’s not a singles or doubles market.
']

Title: Transcripts
Generation:
["From Faro, Baleno and Lelli
I will have neither liberty nor liberty to be a guest on this program to share my diaries and have found those to be useful: to tell the journey, when my mind is free, of life and nature and how we live and our social life - a different journey to nature and the human urge to grow and live life.
This is my telling of my diary during the period of my final years in high school, seven years, from 1960 to 1983, long after I had left my last, living a life of modest living and suffering.
The diaries and their reflections touch on those who had been incarcerated - my family, friends, former classmates, folks with whom I formed relationships, people I met in my therapy, friends I could feed with my green thumb, and the downsides to prison life.
This is my diaries of a man who as a man of conscience repudiated the corrupt and selfish ways of others and chose in part to live alone and be no less than his best friend and lover. But I think that these reflections and observations are very real: not only for myself and of my generation, but for those who have been incarcerated and involved with prison.
And, of course, for the coments of liberty, too, our shared companions and survivors of incarceration.
So, this diaries are important. But whether they are written or recorded by convicts, people have begun to write about it.
They have published their experiences, they have collected their writings, their anecdotes - anecdotes relating to those who have been incarcerated. They have histories. They have entered the opulent with the idea of giving up one's freedom, which may or may not be true, but they have written with the conviction and the determination and the resolve to change the course of their lives. They have posted their stories and stories as a new form of public memory, a new beginning. They have opened the door of people whose life had been altered and who had contributed to the understanding of their lives, their relationship with others and with their community.
They can make a much fuller, important contribution to life than those entrusted with compromising their shared personal and social values or to clandestinely electing or censoring certain members of their community. They can influence and influence and influence millions of Americans.
Most importantly, they are dealing with the enduring themes of spiritual awakening and existential crises, in our own hearts and minds. They are the reflections of our profound sense of the divine and our need to enter and self-immolate at another's leisure, to exercise refuge and reflection in the present moment, to have anew-water the soul of life, to transform and unlearn the darkness of our past as a new, new beginning. They are the reflections of our hope, its possibility, its way of living - that we may learn to be bolder in our own lives, to rediscover ourselves, our own sense of the infinite, of the infinity and infinity of our world.
This anthology is important because it demonstrates that our pilgrimage to free from the temptations of the prison can be reversed, and instead we may be able to recharge into more solid and life-giving long-term communal and relational life experiences as witnesses to the ways and actions of others.
We may explore, guided by the Bible, the veracity of our convictions, the mysterious and the infinite, our courageous road to spiritual awakening, a timeless vision of living as life.
But we can also try to open our search for the depth and pride that might help us get to know ourselves - and bring forth our deepest selves to be seekers of the humanity.
I am speaking here of a man who as a man of conscience repudiated the corrupt and selfish ways of others and chose in part to live alone and be no less than his best friend and lover. But I hope you can get out of that prison life and go back to your place of refuge with your natural capacity for charity, good will, courage, generosity, cooperation, of thinking and word of mouth.
In such times, we stand to learn what we know - what we have learned - and become role models for others. We are born to journey again and, especially, grow wiser and better. We are ahead of the competition of the pack. And that's what Jesus has taught us.
There are 8,000 words here in the diaries. These are still the usences of my life. I think we will find more of them on the diaries and other writings I have sent out.
"]

Title: Transcripts
Generation:
["Twelve years after 9/11, the real hero of our country died on 30th February 2010: John F. Kennedy.
Kennedy was the country's greatest and most beloved soldier, leader and hero whose courage and compassion for other’s in war gave all our servicemen and women precious and invaluable service.
When I went to work this morning for the Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency (DoPA) as a translator, I met JFK’s son-in-law, Arizona Coriello, along with the rest of Arizona’s congressional delegation. My feelings on the death of the nation’s finest military veteran, also known as John F. Kennedy, began to grow more clear by the day as he, never shy about showing the way into our nation’s heart, seemed to effortlessly switch into a quiet dignity and life’s simplicity as the subject of war dramatized by his father’s contribution to our national security.
From the inside, we knew that John F. Kennedy’s life, and what America represents, would forever be defined and even later hardened by the understanding that there were no profits made in the execution of his life in public. He lived by a code of honor, a code he still maintained and a code the documents he made available to his fellow soldiers, including his video diary of their combat hours in Iraq. His diary would reverberate over and through us, affecting our reactions and focusing us on the continuous stream of broken promises and betrayals which lingered for us in our daily routines, as well as the tragic loss of countless American lives in the war to name just one example.
Many of us now have found solace by following his lead on a far greater scale. We took his fight on back to the lower levels of our government, giving him a second chance, serving him with distinction for decades, making the decision to extend his life in active service during a time of promise and promise fulfilment, and ending his time in prison, away from their blood and hearts, in London. Many of us followed his lead along the way as our lives were written up in the same anthology while another, unconnected portion of his life was simply celebrated in front of the world as the complete and enduring valor of the martyred.
For the past year I have been busy traveling the country for what has become an annual memorial memorial service for John F. Kennedy, with additional traveling trips (in connection with the Global War on Terror) to other countries to honor him. As he sat in his plane in Philadelphia on 31st February 2010 I started to see how much America really appreciated and appreciated his act of service and his courage. This year I thought I would revisit what was happening in the earlier years of John F. Kennedy’s life.
There’s no being let go from that work which would belong to the poeple. Only being born on 7th July 1783 to an American father, John F. Kennedy headed the Army of the Republic in the Caribbean before dying at the age of 31 in Las Vegas on 30th February 2010. After serving two years in that plane home in the United States, John F. Kennedy died in a Texas hospital while in an Oklahoma prison on 31st January 2010 at 38. I wonder what was said to tell my brothers and sisters in law and others that just starting to chart the trajectory of the distance from the tragedy to the future: “Oh, my gosh! I love my freedom! Let’s fly, have a life, take it to a new place.” It was perhaps the language of the rebels who wanted to the rebels feel of their way through the globe’s turbulence, and John F. Kennedy was a man of courage and faith in himself. No stoning or imprisonment he would have ever lasted.”
John F. Kennedy will be sorely missed by many of his colleagues, sons, daughters, grandmothers, siblings, colleagues, parents, friends, and countless members of the military and the family. His image will never be duplicated and forgotten, but his importance still has not diminished.
"]

Title: WHO declares novel coronavirus outbreak a pandemic
Generation:
['ADVERTISEMENT
BANGKOK (CNN) — The World Health Organization’s highest level official on Wednesday declared a novel coronavirus outbreak that has cast a shadow over Thailand’s tourism sector the most severe yet.
The virus has been described as a “cocktail” that people suffering from flu-like symptoms could infect not only themselves but travellers and pilgrims, suggesting it has developed in many ways.
(CNN)
“We have a very serious problem at the moment with this superb virus that has been associated with travel into Asia,” said Olivier Szpunar, WHO director-general.
Officials launched an inquiry into the outbreak last month and believe it is linked to flocks of Thai people living in Malaysia, the Maldives and islands in the southern Philippines.
It has “undoubtedly had an impact” on tourism activity in Thailand, European Health Minister Ho Dhammok told reporters.
Almost a week after the disease was discovered, the government announced that it was still considering taking drastic action to prevent other people from infecting themselves.
The U.S. National Institutes of Health plans to conduct a routine screening test for the virus.
At least eight people were hospitalized and 62 people were infected with flu-like symptoms, according to the WHO. But a late-break outbreak had seen more than 7,200 cases across 13 countries in the past week and more than 400 fatalities.
Kartibooni, a small monkey that had been shown to pick up food that had been contaminated, has been identified as the most severe and potentially responsible of the outbreak.
The white monkey, called Sulu, has been isolated at the sex workers’ house in Maungdaw, 100 km north of Bangkok, and is now “walking in a closed area,” Asia’s top health official said.
Kharkod Chieh, WHO director-general, said infections “can last days or weeks and can lead to serious, debilitating damage to humans”.
']

(CNN) — The New CDC recently issued guidance that says older adults should “stay at home as much as possible” due to the coronavirus, which comes from the same family as the deadly Ebola virus.
In October, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention finalized recommendations related to watch lists, provided by physicians who prescribed any medicines not used when someone is 89 years old or older, for passive caregivers in the United States, Canada, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.
The CDC’s guidance will appear in the current issue of the journal Archives of General Psychiatry, a print-only medical journal that is published by the CDC.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention officials also noted how others are not doing that.
“As citizens in the United States, we should be in contact with appropriate caregivers, safe producers, and to regularly monitor our air quality,” the group writes in its guidance.

Title: Former CDC director: It's time to restrict visits to nursing homes
Generation:
['(CNN) — More than 160 doctors and other health professionals belong to the American Academy of Pediatrics. The group was founded in 1905 as a movement to discourage exposure to dangerous chemicals and public health risks.
Though the organization never formally recognized itself as an advocacy group, as it has gotten more global, it’s its power at the local level now feels more generalized.
“Not only does it say its goal is to create and promote great patient care, but it does it to help elect members of Congress to build better medical communities within the country — one that is better equipped to hear medical concerns, how to disseminate information, and how to run multiple clinical and related networks,” said David Faxon, co-chair of AAP’s board of directors.
The most recent executive order from the Trump administration drew immediate objections from the most prominent medical groups.
On Thursday, the American Medical Association called the directive — this time to require screening and phasing in the now-standard daily required intake to consult with a doctor and pay a fee to attend a medical conference — “deeply troubling.”
Beth Kochner, president of the Institute for Family Medicine, warned that “restricting these important government organs to private health providers is morally bankrupt.”
James Gottlieb, a professor at Texas A&M and director of University of Missouri’s APM-Poster School of Medicine, told the panel: “I have heard this a number of times in recent meetings. This is really a time to allow emergency rooms to determine whether they can pay their bill.”
The new directive requires doctors and other health professionals to leave the country with at least four minutes to sit down and talk to a patient in their own room. And that takes care of most of the questions that patients have to ask — such as, “How is this handled?” and “If your child is old enough to sit in the room, could you provide some data for you?”
Health professionals sometimes said they feared this step would allow them to do both things: reducing their potentially harmful exposure to chemicals and upending the strict health-safety regulations that health officials still have to adhere to.
Related:
Previous Obama-era order in wake of CDC exposure blurs history
CDC orders to control problematic chemical labels
']

Title: The coronavirus pandemic is closing schools. How will kids eat?
Generation:
['Five minutes ago, it seemed as if the coronavirus (virus — coronavirus) was going to strike the United States. But now it’s unraveling like a snowflake in a sugar dump. A new coronavirus has spread from its breeding center in Argentina to a nearby south-western Peru, bringing diarrhea to hundreds of thousands of students and teacher-proficient students in the region.
The vaccine, H3N2, has already been used in a recent outbreak of León virus in Guanajuato state. It has no vaccine for infectious diarrhea, nor has it been approved by the federal government for use on children.
So it’s no wonder schools are struggling to prepare for what will surely be a catastrophic pandemic. What did the schoolchildren learn?
“We have taken the children out of the classroom,” said the school psychologist. “That’s really sad. This one’s a learning experience, but there’s a life lesson that needs to be learnt.”
Recent shows
Worldwide, the number of children hospitalized for major virus infections in the first 24 hours of the illness has more than doubled since 2009, said Phil Boroch, a former microbiologist at NASA, who served on the undersecretary for health. “These kids tend to hit it hard, which is why we are talking about the three stages in Viruses 1 and 2: full-blown diarrhea, partially (filament) and partially refirals,” he said. “But their major symptoms are aberrations and seizures, which is the hallmark of these viruses.”
And the strains that control the virus have receded, he said.
“Within the first 24 hours, kids have an infection (which according to the latest projections can last five months). They do vomit, they cough, and they don’t respond to anything else,” Boroch said.
That’s especially true because the viruses cause diarrhea, not reining in their massive appetite for food. “Doping was part of their diet, but they don’t fight. They just take a few pills,” he said. “It’s probably not infectious since the brain tells it there are measles and rubella (infections). That’s why kids have to learn about these plagues.”
But there are other things that are cause for concern, such as the vaccination process, Boroch said. The US government and HHS are set to release final reports on the steps taken by the Department of Health and Human Services in response to the latest virus outbreak on Friday.
So how will children handle the inevitable death of their classmates? “We want to reassure you that we are making a difference in your lives and your future,” Boroch said. “That means that they, in turn, need to make sure that they are being trained to carry out the rigorous research, which is something that we will do.”
There will be a fight
The U.S. government is already making investments in help to support county-based volunteers. Officials say that this outbreak has been wiped out, with 154 or 88 percent of children infected with the current outbreak back in school.
']

Title: Fish oil supplements linked to lower risk of heart disease and death, study finds
Generation:
['By: Tikka
Published: 05/05/2019 by: McDevitt Ltd.
Weighted supplements such as omega-3 oil and omega-6 fish oil are associated with a lower risk of a number of serious health problems such as heart disease, stroke and Parkinson’s disease, according to new research published this week in the Lancet.
Researchers believe that these pills may help boost cardiovascular health.
The findings contradict previous research suggesting that eating omega-3 supplements can relieve symptoms of heart disease or stroke, which could result in lower rates of blood and gastrointestinal bleeding.
“These results will put additional emphasis on increasing dietary fiber and supplement consumption and further increase the number of effective treatments for cardiovascular health,” said UC Berkeley professor and senior author Ryan Ball, associate professor of epidemiology.
Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of death in humans and has become one of the leading causes of illness.
Foods that contain fatty acids found in omega-3, omega-6 and omega-3 omega-6 are “associated with the risk of impaired cardiovascular health,” according to the study.
Study authors chose fish oil and a low-fat diet because of its taste and omega-7 is found in fish oil that not only increases heart rate and calories burn by approximately 3.5 percent, but also flavonoids, which increase HDL (good cholesterol) and prevent LDL (bad cholesterol) from falling away.
“The fact that omega-3 supplements seem to have a lower risk of heart disease and stroke than those found in low-fat diets — and that the approach is not supported by observational studies — may have implications for small fish,” said senior author Laurie McMahon, professor of medicine at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
Processed fish
According to the authors, “dietary supplements” have the ability to be marketed at a “natural” and “medicine-free” level, including either dietary fiber, antioxidants, and alpha-carotene.
But none of the supplements can regulate blood pressure or heart attack risk, according to the authors. And there are few guidelines for dieting.
“Contrary to many estimates, consumers not only have the wrong food choices, but also are over-exercising and inactivity,” the authors write.
“Interestingly, both dietary fiber and antioxidants can increase the use of supplements and pose risks.”
But the findings suggest that diets that combine dietary fiber and supplements can promote weight control and this can also aid heart rate and blood pressure, the authors note.
']

Title: What this sunny, religious town in California teaches us about living longer
Generation:
['A few two years ago, I had a cup of coffee with my liberal coworker to talk about life ahead and what some of our community’s younger generations (one of them the kids of my parents) might be thinking about. What she and I had shared, in no small measure, was that our grandparents, who lived to be 50 and were predisposed to Alzheimer’s disease, had been walking long distances all along their retirement years before we were going to die. This was a wise decision.
After more than 20 years of hoping for a normal life expectancy, we entered my niece’s home in Northern California. I was looking forward to lunch and weekends away from home, but while I was tired at work when I was sick, I found the plans for a quiet home and the mind-bendingly expansive views of the Pacific Ocean to be incredibly challenging to design and execute.
Upon my arrival, I found a guy who was in his late 30s living around 50 to 60 years old with a predisposed to Alzheimer’s disease.
Well, his five years and the time he was spent in his 90s didn’t end with him being a good husband. He came back home and missed his family, the first time I had had a conversation with him and I wanted to speak more freely about his situation.
We talked about whether or not he had an environment in which he knew his fate. For many of us, planning is a process of moving away from poverty or isolation, and often in much worse moments than we usually do. The choice to move out is critical in deciding if to live long enough to endure the agony of failure and hopefully slow down the process of becoming a normal person. And when we have families in place that are ready and willing to hold us, even as years or generations pass and there’s time for us to be comfortable knowing that we can stop the process and live life with minimal regret.
For many older adults, starting at age 50 is the place where we finally begin to pay into the nest. As seniors are nearing retirement and becoming, maybe, new, qualified providers, we’re starting to listen. We can’t be complacent, we can’t seem to believe we have enough time to be certain that we’re doing well.
With the passage of one vote in the last decade, we can now boldly head out for better, healthier life choices rather than pursue every option we’re afraid of.
Before I reached 62, I did a couple of things right; one was getting in touch with a pediatrician. She is widely regarded as the best prognosticator in the field of pediatric care and offers diverse advice and resources. The other was getting involved with a community project involving the children of parents with oncology-delinquent families.
Every month we prepare an end-of-life paper for our grandchildren and their caregivers. Each December, we write a thank-you letter. The paper was inked into our palms, leaving us with a touch of hope, hopes and love. “In each year since then, I have had the opportunity to say, ‘Thank you,’” writes Ruth Whittaker, our kids’ director of child development. “I am grateful for all the additional blessings I have had in the short years since I have been old.”
I know that as life moves forward, we’ll have to change our negative behaviors; how we respond to strangers and see them as often associated with our ailments, talents, or abilities. There are many reasons why we’re not living to our full potential, so imagine being part of these systems of well-being that we’re not able to enjoy the privilege of just hanging out with friends.
I know. You don’t. You don’t bring life, sunshine and ease to life when you look at it, saying how grateful you are that something like this came your way. You’re a person with a deep connection to God, a reason to not care anymore, a reason to find the inner peace, the reason for feeling good to begin with.
If anyone thinks our culture hasn’t changed since our pioneers and elders were old, try ordering yourself a birth certificate. Just don’t think this is a “pro-life,” “sisterhood,” or a lifestyle choice. These things, more than anything else, can all be changed — with or without a few conveniences and certain basic behaviors.
As we age, we must change our attitudes, our behaviours, our behaviors.']

Title: US life expectancy climbs for first time in four years
Generation:
['WASHINGTON — The U.S. population age rose 0.7 percentage points in 2018, falling from the year before, according to new figures released Thursday.
The average life expectancy for Americans aged 55 and older increased for the eighth year in a row, from 54.3 in 2014 to 55.2 in 2018. That’s the most since 2002, when the average life expectancy for Americans aged 55 and older was 54.6, the National Center for Health Statistics said.
Based on older Americans, the gains in life expectancy underscore the importance of programs to improve health.
“When our nation’s population age as soon as we can, it increases its chances for a healthy person to survive life and make a healthy future,” said Timothy J. DiMaio, the senior vice president of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in a news release.
Spending on family and healthy living also improved significantly in the past 12 months, and in 2017, the U.S. increased spending on health services, DiMaio said.
Medicare reimbursement for medical care slipped 1.3 percentage points in 2018, to $155 billion from $160 billion in 2017, according to the CDC. Spending on the Medicare program, which covers health care for people 65 and older, increased 4.1% in 2018.
The government has developed new ways to provide health care for the elderly in ways that allow them to earn and afford whatever medical care they need, said CDC spokesman Andy Byars.
“This latest growth should provide these families with a lifeline to help them get back on track,” he said.
']

Title: The mystery of President Trump's unannounced hospital visit
Generation:
['(CNN) - It's a mystery to some.
"Who is this president?" CNN's Gene Ryan asked on "Question No. 2."
"I'm wondering if the president's in the hospital because they're getting sick. Are the people at the hospital with them scared that he's being sneezed or would they be afraid?"
You can see a muddled picture on his Twitter account, with a busy tweet address: @govleak american.
His office says he has "health care planning and administration management advice." The Twitter handle @realDonaldTrump really only has @peaksout. The office doesn't immediately respond to CNN for Monday morning's scheduled questions.
Last Friday, @realDonaldTrump went public with his hospital visit, tweeting about medical procedures and a mystery he wanted to keep to himself. The President's frequent tweets took many by surprise.
At the time, he also mentioned that his name didn't happen and that he was visiting doctors.
In a tweet on Monday, he said he was having "bad start" but was back at work the following day.
On Thursday, he tweeted "Very nice work today!"
On Friday, he called on the staff to "stop putting off that last one or getting scared."
Sunday, he again referred to them not sharing details and asked: "Is that nasty ..let me put that in context."
A tweet on Monday is really about Michael Jackson.
Mr. President, are you approaching anywhere with a smidge of nervousness?
"I'm excited that I'm coming home," it's now rained all of the time.
Are you seeing a ghost?
"Yeah," Mr. President replies.
A second tweet on Monday featured his "says it like it is."
On Sunday, a rep for the President criticized Twitter for shutting down coverage of his visit.
"Ironically, a lot of people view the president's visit at this point as a precaution, according to his official press advisor Sarah Huckabee Sanders," Sanders tweeted.
Democrats said Trump needed to stop taking his job to a Washington hospital.
"I would have ordered him to get to St. Mark's," Rep. Michael Grimm told CNN Sunday night. "That was an acceptable procedure."
A House Oversight and Government Reform Committee hearing on his travel and drug use also concluded Sunday night, despite skepticism from the White House.
"I think it is important that a lot of people aware of this, that they know it took place for us to try and discipline him," Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, D-Fla., told CNN on Sunday.
Another factor in Trump's public challenge for the White House, however, is the seriousness of the illness that has cropped up over the past two weeks.
As some critics have noted, Trump's health has been consistently low-cost, with top surgeon general Andrew Welles saying he would not hesitate to order a private hospital in the White House, if that were the case.
Then last week, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said he was looking for private hospitals, and that the city will provide them. The city official told CNN's Jake Tapper that "I think there are a lot of ways that they might have sought that facility ... I think they're willing to deal with it, and I think they certainly feel as it pertains to the people who are bedridden at this hospital."
The New York Post first reported the story, with de Blasio's office saying that while Trump's visit was his first, "it was for an event that wasn't authorized by the commander in chief."
So, apart from Monday's surprise, rumors will continue to swirl about Trump's health, with varying issues raised and hoped over the next few days.
CBS News confirmed Monday that the president wasn't at the hospital but said that they are investigating. The network could not confirm if Trump is anywhere visiting, given the unusuality of his appearances and the length of time he's been on the air.
CNN contributed to this report.

Title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta on medical marijuana: We are in an age of wisdom, but also an age of foolishness
Generation:
['NEW YORK (CNN) — Comedian and activist Dr. Sanjay Gupta of HBO’s “black-ish” is a neuroscientist, champion of medical marijuana.
But just like many of us, he’s not a medical marijuana user, despite consulting with and teaching at various medical agencies and clinics on his legal practice. And, at 74, he thinks more of himself is his best resource, according to a new column in People magazine, for having advice on how to behave against societal thought.
“To get my facts right, it is appropriate to assume I was smoking dope from July 1 to October 3,” Gupta writes. “That is not the only time someone is smoking weed.”
And he says that drug users today have a different set of priorities than did decades ago.
“We were in our time of hubris, we were in my time of ridiculousness, we were in our time of superstition, we were in our time of foolishness,” he says. “We were all in our time, but we still were in our time.”
As a gay man, Gupta hopes to bring a little bit of relief to the “noble” people who work with him in his particular field. But in truth, doing our jobs is just as good for our safety, Gupta says.
“We are all putters, and they don’t respect you if you do,” he says. “We make decisions based on our public health, because we know the impact on the environment is huge and the impact on the health and wellbeing of our communities.”
So when Gupta travels, he wears a holster he maintains at his local corner store and keeps it under his locker. Not that it’s all unfamiliar territory, though.
“I can’t even imagine what these guys go through and what their lives are like without their real-life experiences,” he writes. “This is all part of what I’m here to teach.”
Binge-watching TV shows like “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Scandal” remind Gupta of his own life story. They’re as true as the ever-present $30 television show that airs his stories.
But the most fascinating aspect of this story — at least as far as Gupta’s own life goes — is that it’s much harder to project the self-anonymity he is insisting on when he is pleading guilty to marijuana possession charges.
“I felt I was going to be more anonymous, which I’m not,” he writes, but also remind that the recent FBI sting was also framed in the culture of informants wanting to weed out TV series.
“I’m convinced that people might be committing more crimes and should know better,” he says. “Who knows? If somebody can look at this young man’s background, they might know more.”
']

Title: Not all screen time causes kids to underperform in school, study says
Generation:
['Rebecca Black is right. It may be time for kids to start looking at screens a bit differently.
According to a new study that published Monday in Pediatrics, kids who sit a low or four points behind their peers at school are much more likely to become delinquent in their assigned class.
Those with less screen time are more likely to become delinquent within four years of graduation, according to the study's findings. For the rest of that time, kids aren't much better.
There's a basic reason why: kids, particularly those who do not have a lot of screen time, spend as much time sitting in front of television and computers as they do playing computer games.
"An overly active child is a little less likely to get into school if he's exposed to other activities,” said study co-author Madeline Ellens, an associate professor at University of California at Davis School of Public Health.
Children with less screen time tend to get less emotional rest and social mobility, and also get worse in the long run, the study authors write.
Meanwhile, those kids are clearly more prone to setbacks.
“But this finding shows that that can certainly have a significant effect on behavior toward responsibility and response,” Ellens told CNN.
Her study focuses on primary school children, and is not the first to say that shorter-than-normal screen time results in lower social mobility, which seems to be especially important in low-income communities.
But it points out that the study's conclusions don't mean our cultural biases behind screen time will stop.
Rather, it's likely to become the primary means of checking the kids in class. Schools, schools and kids will need to be more scrutinized.
The kids will need to feel they are contributing more, Ellens said.
"Even though they need to be likelier to be in school and be proactive in supporting an array of behaviors we see on a daily basis — playing for an hour for a Friday afternoon, or watching TV in a 15-minute period for a period of time — eventually we'll begin to see broader declines than even this small but significant number of students,” the report said.
That means kids coming from less advantaged households will experience a relatively larger drop-off in social mobility, and that may have a big effect on "an adolescent's ability to participate in and experience studies and parenting,” the report authors wrote.
']

Title: Mixing less than 6 hours of sleep with chronic disease is deadly combo
Generation:
['(CNN) — In a study that included more than 34,000 people who took more than 6 hours of sleep a night, researchers found that people who slept fewer than the recommended 7 hours a night also had a higher risk of developing chronic disease.
“We believe that when people become severely ill that their body’s biological clock changes between 7:30 a.m. and 6:30 p.m., it plays an important role in chronic disease,” said the study’s senior author, Anthony Luh, M.D., lead author of the study and a board-certified general-market dentist who lives in the District of Columbia.
Luh said a variety of factors may contribute to the health problems of the participants. For example, people have higher blood sugar levels in adulthood. Pain and stress may also play a role in maintaining a healthy immune system.
Blood sugar in adults is common in adulthood, and immune systems can be more prone to “stress weapons” — such as food or medicine — that trigger chronic disease, Luh said.
In the latest research published in the Journal of the American Medical Association, Luh and his colleagues found that insomnia was the most common cause of death in such patients.
Other researchers have shown that chronic symptoms and chronic disease are related.
The study focused on a group of 200 people.
Those who complained of low body temperatures and low-quality sleep quality were shown to be higher risk of having multiple different chronic conditions that produced similar benefits.
Researchers divided 2,485 people into two groups, those who had experienced no chronic disease or chronic sleep fatigue, and those who experienced no chronic disease and chronically ill.
The researchers found that patients who were affected by chronic disease had 30% higher levels of insomnia than patients who had slept about 7 hours a night.
Those whose insomnia led to accidents or suicides were even more likely to have a risk of developing chronic disease compared to those who didn’t suffer from insomnia.
The risk of dying in the study is higher if people used a long, longer sleep schedule over the course of the study than if they were alone, said the study’s co-author, senior author Zorgy M. Geragos, M.D., a major research economist with the CDC and a professor of psychology and neuroscience at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Maryland.
They did note that the lower sleep duration did not lead to higher cardiovascular risk.
“But we think that isn’t enough to persuade anyone not to sleep the night before a doctor prescribes sleep apnea,” Geragos said.
The study cautioned against extrapolating where insomnia was on the table — it was too early to tell if patients at higher risk had shorter sleep schedules and were likely to be harmed by insomnia.
But the study’s conclusion that people who slept about 7 hours a night had a higher risk of developing chronic disease was broader than the findings earlier based on other studies, Geragos said.
“If you don’t sleep during the week — like 12 hours a night — you’re probably going to end up having a higher chance of developing some type of chronic disease,” he said.
The researchers identified 14 common symptoms in patients who had chronic sleep issues: insomnia, chronic headaches, headaches and frequent flushing.
The one risk they found for chronic sleep issues were chronically ill individuals who had not slept at night.
But it was the effects of the conditions that were most common among the older participants — stroke, stroke — that was not widely known.
“The biggest limitation of this study is that the participant respondents were all healthy,” Geragos said.
He said the researchers recommend people having nightly sleep for most of their lives, and he had no worries about keeping them all awake.
“If you’re really in the throes of a high risk event, the things that protect you are the drugs and other treatments — recovery from physical or psychological trauma, or power loss — and then the antipsychotics and such,” he said.
“Perhaps there will be more research to determine what’s going on in the disease, whether they have predictive value, whether they show meaningful improvements from an assessment standpoint.”
']

Title: A man's false teeth were stuck in his throat for eight days after a surgery
Generation:
['By Gary Locke
CNN Senior Writer
SAN FRANCISCO (CNN) — A stunned Utah couple called it “horrific” to hear their curious story of finding their six-year-old son hanging from a Christmas tree after he’d been poked in the throat by a yule log.
How do you keep a pup alive at all? The DIY DIY medical biz worked with Mona Park of Salt Lake City and Michael Gallan of New Jersey to find a miracle cure.
After calling his dad repeatedly as they tried to perform a bone-marrow transplant in 1988, they named their son Stoner. Stoner survives cancer, sleep normally and has a few puffy lesions, according to a story in the Salt Lake Tribune.
“As the story goes, ‘Oh, well, why didn’t she find another tree?’” said Gary Titlock of New Jersey. “He managed to get the tree down to the top, and made sure it was propped up.”
What happened next is anyone’s guess.
The North Coast couple called police but the cops came back calling them and determined to locate the tree, according to a story in the Salt Lake Tribune.
The man, who was 19-1/2 months, was recovering from surgery when they finally discovered the tree.
“It looked kind of glamorous, but it wasn’t,” Titlock said. “It was like a white-knuckle set-up.”
The couple that called to find the tree were afraid that needles wouldn’t fall off and said it might break in a few seconds. Instead they did what many families do in less than a decade: Work with local animal control.
Dietitian Brian Brian Mason, director of the Food Safety Section of the National Center for Disease Control, said the family was very careful. They didn’t skimp on their “rattlers.”
“If they’re storing something that can fall off someone’s clothing, they’re not going to put their toothpick and skew it,” Mason said. “And they’re not taking in a cutting method that requires almost the same kind of welding and cutting.”
In the end, the trio took almost as long as they’d dug a hole in the tree and used biopsy strips to mark the wound.
“What impressed me more than anything was the patient’s dignity,” Titlock said. “It said all you need to know about recovery and how far you’ve come.”
The story of the Pioneer Child became popular after the 2005 documentary “Cops and robbers: The Video Gang Wars,” which chronicled a weeklong occupation by a gang of criminals, including robbery and murder, by the very groups described in the film.
Both men attended their first medical school together. Among other things, the Pioneer Child group taught social workers and women how to recite a swear word.
“Our lives were forever changed by the legacy of the Pioneer Child,” Titlock said. “And that’s just what this story is about.”
It’s a story that has further touched the lives of doctors and society.
But Stoner’s story isn’t unique.
In the United States, thousands of people each year get the procedure. Some opt for IV lines. Some don’t. A recent study found that those experiencing infertility don’t even have to worry about needles causing their true reproductive dysfunction.
Yet, experts caution that people who get the procedure have a higher chance of developing complications such as postpartum depression, fertility problems, anxiety or/or low body weight, as well as behavioral and emotional complications.
“Overall, what’s most important to understand is that, in an era when the Internet is going to be the latest social media, myths have advanced,” Titlock said. “And it’s by no means easy to do.”
']

Another participant, Liz Portus, 39, can now provide competitive advantage to kids, too.
As a participant in the competition she played because she is an autistic adult, with varying disabilities.
At a place where teachers helped test the disability of the number of autism survivors, many educators talked about their students and how so many were coming for the competition, but there weren’t enough adults there to accommodate families whose kids were able to attend.

“They are the ones who can literally take full responsibility for everything. There is nothing better than coming to an opportunity to take control of it all,” she said.

Title: Her son died. And then anti-vaxers attacked her
Generation:
['How brutal that is.
My son, Adam, died yesterday, Dec. 17, 2015, from complications from a rare genetic cancer of the umbilical cord. His body was wrapped in a layer of food and sheet, and the bedspread was encased in a plastic wrap that no one would reach.
On a daily basis, his father has told us, he has never seen his son with flesh and blood.
His death left me dizzy and berserk. He started clenching and rambling — a symptom, not necessarily inherited, as his parents want us to believe.
And there is no way he could have survived without it. At least no one else to care for. When his father died, he would say, “forgive me for not knowing better.” He would tell us, “I will spend years and years now helping make a memorial to my daddy.”
But then, those words became fake, because Adam was never given the proper context, or proper family support, because Adam was dying, and he never had such a ring of support.
He would tell us, “I want to make my daddy proud of who I am.” Instead, Adam would tell us, “I’m happy to be my daddy’s girlfriend.”
Neither of Adam’s two sisters — who aren’t named (in this case Adam) nor their children — were acquainted with his father, and so Adam ended up in his father’s arms. Not even Adam’s parents could stand up for Adam, without mentioning his right to take his life.
Now, half a century later, I’m still figuring out if my son had known better. Does he have a sense of who we are, or how he might have reached a place as grand as here in this story?
My journey of revelation opens a path, one not without its woes. Perhaps Adam’s death shed new light on his love for the Jews and perhaps that link altered who he really was, to believe that someone of Adam’s father’s stature may have been searching for the spirit of the man he loved the most and that he had lost all that he had loved.
However, for all those who think that all this unhappiness and divisiveness are preparation for surrender to the corporate noise about the possible sale of British beef to Israel or the dissolution of the so-called Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, at least I have tried to understand Adam’s chosen issue by explaining how he and his father work together.
I could set up clear rules that only the idea of their fate should be established, and then divide their battle among them on various levels.
Why would anyone support such a deal? At the core of it are the two Jewish leaders whose ideals include justice for the Jewish victims of genocide and a safer future for humanity. How could those two be in conflict?
Consider the following solution:
The reason we chose to remain apart is to realize that we just can’t live without each other.
It does not matter that no one other than Adam’s parents have met the Nazis or that his parents have met those born from the Norwegian birthplaces. Neither of them seems to have had any time for planning. Neither of them seemed at peace.
If there was ever a time to meet, to form an understanding of one another, Adam certainly was one of them.
We knew he was a uniquely Jewish boy who wanted to break out of his parent’s arms and turn into the spirit of him, while remaining, in his, Jew’s, father’s arms, the most fabulous in Judaism. One might ask why Adam chose to break away, even because he thought he wanted to become an heir to a different family’s sins?
In his plea for God, Adam touched on such dark subjects as that of the Holocaust, and reveals as much when he describes his love for the ancestors of the poor and that of the sick, I THINK the way Jesus was blessed, for that was ultimately for all of us.
As he described those who tortured Adam, his father’s tragedy and his mother’s death, he refused to accept his destiny alone.
That’s a fate other Jews just have to fall in love with.
T
']

Title: Raising an intersex child: 'This is your body. ... There's nothing to be ashamed of'

["SANFORD, Fla. - Men growing intersex body parts are no longer acceptable as parents-child advocates grapple with their children’s likely reaction to the practice, and raising the topic brought to light by a Florida patient.
As a result, several Florida families have petitioned their state legislature to require such practices to be prohibited in at least four different states: in multiple states; in three states; and in many other states.
“For parents who are already concerned about their children's reaction to those parts being inserted into them, screening and medical procedures done for gender reassignment [is important],” said Dr. Cyril Coleman, director of the Center for Gender, Sexuality and Relationships at Children’s Hospital at Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
Coleman was among the first to respond to the Florida petition and asked his pediatrician to conduct a urine test to see if there was any evidence of the gender expression on children in his clinic.
But his daughter, and she happens to be seven months old, doesn’t seem surprised by the fact that her parents would like her to look at adult gender expression. “I had kids growing up straight… I said ‘You know what? A double gender multiple sexes up,’” Coleman said.
When asked whether he believes gender expression on children is affected in his clinic, Coleman said “absolutely.”
But his recent campaign has created an international outcry, according to CNN affiliate WJXT in Florida.
“I have my daughter born intersex,” a supporter wrote. “She was born straight. Why is that? What is wrong with her? She is not born with no clear disability.”
And, “This is your body. ... There’s nothing to be ashamed of.”
Families that have filed the local effort had a higher level of passion and commitment as they approached what seems to be a pivotal turning point for their discussions with parents.

Title: Live Longer: Could you improve your lifespan?

This could mean benefits in terms of hours of work and leisure, like attending any sporting event, including concerts, meeting new people, and engaging in more leisure activities, possibly even fitness sports such as walking.

The same way many doctors would like to see the quality of life observed by a person aging to 90, researchers in Sweden suggest that body composition might be critical to physical fitness. This means that obesity and exercise may influence blood pressures in future, so losing weight might have a bigger impact on the longevity of those in the midst of it.
Exercise is perhaps the most important factor for a person reaching 90, according to the economists who led the study. So it’s possible the increased lifespan can happen during a very young age: A study from 2009 looked at over a million people, and claimed that lifting weights, not standing, led to increased lifespan.
The researchers used independent computer models. They compared people with an age of 90, where 85% of them had no known physical activity, and observed that 60% had no known significant changes in weight or cognition. This meant that 81% of people had no changes in their lives — but half would have had no noticeable changes in longevity if not for the impact of their surroundings on their life goals, researchers said.
Which is actually great news, because you never know what you’re going to get up to in the future.

That’s not super science. It’s superstition. And we disagree with it.
As it turns out, there’s at least a somewhat higher level of science that says these superstitions matter. And yet—as the most radical iteration of the superstition appears in The Metaphysical Reserve, a conspiracy story that comes from abroad—the rest of the world does as well.

But maybe it’s more nefarious. It could be just that, scientists realize.
If you’re one of those people who believes in superstitions, or are less likely to report them to you—when both of those points have been taken to extremes by skeptic groups—refer to The Metaphysical Reserve to Eeterolden, you’re basically for disobeying the superstition.

Because a virus is acquired by a person, viruses from flu can infect people, which means that people who have never had a disease experience a period of prolonged, unprotected contact with their body, the study said.

The similarities between coronavirus and non-travel travelers account for their cross-symptoms, the findings said.
"Another key point is that inter-human people rarely come into contact with their own body cells, which could lead to an increased risk of infectious diseases when all interaction is deemed to be preventable," Hansen and colleagues said.

One of the first findings was that the soft-haired babies in the dark were more sensitive to noise and odors. All of the babies spent at least three days in a darkened nursery.

Title: Lessons from Ebola: The secret of successful epidemic response

Some simple steps—using public knowledge more than seen in the “official” CDC newsletter—were one step toward preventing Ebola. Sadly, as the CDC studies in bigger and more nuanced language take our medical database to heart, we are missing the apparent path to preventable deaths and, more important, avoidable lives.

To date, only 15 cases have been confirmed and an additional 1,610 deaths have been classified as probable. Even though most of those involved the health sector, which is implicated by large numbers of international partners and pressure on our borders, are strangers to many countries, the country response was never in a position to respond well enough.
This is why we need to raise our awareness about outbreaks and the need to prepare. Two and a half decades in the “advanced care and control system” infrastructure has led to no real response by health entities or providers. It is past time to change the culture and begin the paradigm shift.
Like many major crises, Ebola is transmitting its treatment and containment protocol from farm to factory, without our knowledge or regard for who has contracted and did so. We need to talk about how we best prepare the public for such disasters, such as Ebola and like the Drought Storrs. In 2009, a Drought Storrs team estimated that it cost about $2.5 million to respond to the resulting outbreak. In the aftermath of 2008, when the Drought Storrs team was completely overwhelmed by the amount of response, CDC mobilized emergency medical responses to the entire country. We need to build in strong communications, risk avoidance mechanisms, and resources that help coordinate and coordinate, as well as activate networks that assist across healthcare systems, government, and institutions.
We need to translate our way of communicating with the medical community so that it is true to what is clear in a state of urgency, and something more tangible, so that the public knows. To step back and readjust the lessons learned in recovery is of immense importance. While post-eclampsia patients in the outbreak don’t die yet, they will shortly, and we will see when so many others will, the inevitable labor for discussion about our nation’s health status, its politics, our differences, and our ability to respond effectively.
As Ebola continues to grow, it will be difficult to avoid any contagion. We need to support and help coordinate what it takes to provide the best resources and help to develop strategies to combat this great epidemic.

Title: How to keep your workplace clean -- and yourself healthy -- during the novel coronavirus outbreak
