['(CNN) -- Four months after the swine flu pandemic began, many medical professionals say it's not too late to be alert for the next great outbreak.
After state health officials continue to warn about swine flu-like illnesses, policy makers in Pennsylvania, Iowa, North Carolina, Kansas, Tennessee and South Carolina have floated the idea of stepping up their efforts to protect workers, their families and their employers from becoming victims of the outbreaks.
How do you keep yourself and your coworkers away from a swine flu outbreak? Here are three steps to help avoid the virus:
1. Start following the playbook
It's easy to fall into the trap of thinking that the latest outbreak was random, that the virus's not going to hit everybody every time. However, experts say that's not the case. Humans, like non-human primates, don't transmit directly from person to person -- so it's best to start preparing for the worst with a list of everything you can do to reduce the likelihood of getting caught.
That's particularly true if you have children -- the risk of your employees catching a virus like swine flu does not spread from person to person easily -- and a family member of your family is missing out on many of the other things you can do to prevent similar illnesses.
Most importantly, develop a "common sense" plan for the workplace that includes protocols and precautions to avoid any possible cases of the virus.
This includes:
Getting out more of the information -- or whatever other precautions are in place and not in place.
Remind yourself that the outbreak is real and many health workers and consumers are fearful of contracting the virus. Keep your fears in the past, and do not carry panic buttons to the door.
Reinstating checks at the office will help prevent the appearance of a health concern. That's especially true if you follow the provisions of manufacturer recalls or if work involves heavy-duty manufacturing equipment.
Being in a strong position to deal with an outbreak can make the difference between surviving or surviving out the next pandemic.
2. Embrace energy loss
While employees have a great deal of energy to store, regular doses of available energy can diminish the reach of the outbreak and contribute to the danger. Taking such energy away from workers may prevent a swine flu outbreak, for example.
One suggestion from authorities is to eliminate and recycle any food containers left unattended while workers are indoors. If you choose to keep any food for an extended period, report each time to the director of food services at your local Wal-Mart.
People are well-versed in keeping cool and dry, but it pays to be mindful of your behaviors. Try to remember all the things you use, and remember that it's your body's job to keep yourself cool. Never, ever take anything while working in a storm -- especially when it's in the early afternoon.
3. Take it slow
With the coming winter, many farms and workplaces across the country have millions of pounds of dry goods to produce. That's why it's best to know what products you can keep and what food you can store. Consider buying items like plastic wrap, jugs and black plastic bottoms from home-made retailers and wholesalers.
Traveling with some fresh necessities when a campus caddy arrives after a long day at work is more pleasant than staying in the backseat or side dining room. What you may not consider is the inevitable death of your boss. Making the adjustment now is easier if you can get it right now.
And if you find yourself keeping your cool, bring a turkey (or other small red meat animal for you) or any small food item and prepare it in advance.
When prepared properly, it's better to ensure that you're finding small pieces of food that're less in need of removal or keeping them refrigerated and in place during the case of a swine flu outbreak.
When you're growing your own food, you can almost always get fewer green juices because more food is needed, so that could help preserve the healthy balance.
Be aware of what's in a food bag -- and be aware of plenty of other things like frozen fruits, vegetables and canned meats.
']

Title: Why CNN is calling the novel coronavirus outbreak a pandemic
Generation:
['By Tanya Agrawal
» More Columns
Late last week, we warned people that we needed to see a few people stricken with a bluish or black patch of the virus in their home as soon as they come out of bed, and warned about it possible for them to get sick. That’s usually when there’s a pandemic that has sweeping populations and global scale to that point.
But there was a possibly contagious infection in one particular location. And that’s not just something that you can be very worried about at the moment. Most people in need of assistance get it only once or twice in their lives, to be perfectly accurate.
If that’s the case in my situation, I’d prefer to see someone else isolated and already delirious.
These days, more and more people are getting infected. I see it all the time from all directions.
I know that sharing needles in my local mall, and why people have had to go to the doctor to find infectious agents, like this form of the flu, is common. But I don’t know the reasons why someone just ditches a needle and picks up the very next needle, or something like that.
As for how often people would get sick? It varies. As many as three to five times a year. But even if we don’t think this has happened to someone as great as me, I’d be surprised if it wasn’t more common in an apartment building or conference room, parking lots or parks. It’s one of those things you can’t usually rely on in an emergency. Even if you imagine that’s the case, you might not go to the doctor’s unless you consider that at least a couple of days after getting sick, that you are less likely to have symptoms.
So if you didn’t go to the doctor to be diagnosed or keep a medical student in touch with the family, why wouldn’t you try the first thing out?
I was with my wife last week and her husband was coming home, and we have two young boys. Both boys couldn’t make it, so we decided to get together before school and catch up on information, and we needed to get some fresh air.
And it came around. All about those symptoms. They had so many! And they had so much food and vegetables, although I think I was too young for those things when you become sick.
I’m the most famous person in the world because everyone identifies with me. Nobody carries it all together just for fame, because people know exactly what’s on the other end of the phone, just under the neck of the phone, if I go missing and I know what’s happening.
We’re all in this together, but this has become the most important thing because this affects everybody’s life because we feel like we belong.
What better way to start an international scare than to say, at a banquet, I may have something to say, and I might offer a concrete course of action? Well, that would be something we could all study together for further consideration. That’s the kind of thing one can take seriously in emergencies, and hopefully someone can offer as much detail about these types of diseases as possible.
And if you actually were to have a medical student in hospital, just tell her, as we don’t know how we are living, what you need to know. I don’t know how to help you, but to tell her you’re staying and saying, “Look, I’m suffering from the flu. Am I going to have a cure?”
And it will be there in the end because you’re hoping someone might hear about it, in your bid to stop this from happening to you, rather than another epidemic.
I’m going to do something with my phone, I’m not going to miss the eight o’clock news tomorrow night. I’m going to share with my viewers how exactly this might be connected to our current pandemic.
But when I see someone about it, I have to say, “Wow, this is possibly going to be a new Santa Claus.”
']

Title: Syrians are in a desperate race to outrun a brutal regime offensive
Generation:
['The Syrian government is battling an offensive meant to encircle its Sunni Muslim stronghold of Latakia province as President Bashar al-Assad loses control of his hometown.
But making such an offensive across the country is likely to fail: al-Assad must either win outright or the Syrian population will grow increasingly disillusioned and excluded from the process.
After 11 years of civil war and under Arab and international pressure, this January marks the first time since the UN-Arab League's sanctions imposed on the regime that it has turned to its allies to defend the largest minority in Syria's 28-year civil war.
Over the past three months, at least 18 civilians, military and security personnel, Shiite and Sunni, and most of the city's Sunni population have been killed in the offensive.
The regime's soldiers have also been using anti-aircraft missiles to target civilian target areas, artillery and tanks.
When President Bashar al-Assad made the aerial assault last month, it seemed to be a direct attempt to prevent a more bloody day for the Syrian people.
Already, Assad's air force has air-dropped heavy weaponry to residents of Qaraqosh in northern Idlib province.
Earlier this week, an air defense convoy also bombed some neighbourhoods in the city of Aleppo, killing at least 50 people.
Inside Aleppo, streets are ablaze with bodies strewn across them and looting shops. They are suffering from seasonal violence that has killed at least 108 people.
Just a week after airstrikes killed at least 125 civilians, Ali Abdulla, the mayor of Madaya in northwestern Idlib province, was unharmed.
Since February this year, the city has seen 22 ceasefires for a time, with the most recent involving the cease-fire on March 26. This has eluded the government.
All Assad's forces have claimed the use of artillery, tanks and mortars to defend himself, since ISIS in its eastern region of Syria gained control of Raqqa and then retook parts of the northern city of Deir el-Zour in October.
But each side has an advantage in airstrikes, and the most recent offensive offers civilians an opportunity to gather their memories of their days in a largely empty city, which is a poorer and potentially bloodier place.
Here is what we know about a timeline of Syria's offensive:
Battle: March 11, 2011
When Al-Assad was on the verge of winning the popular vote to form a new government in March 2011, his Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) was being backed by the Arab League, the United States and Russia.
Jihadists were a threat to Damascus in the run-up to the April 2011 elections, prompting the leadership of the PFLP to issue a gazette notice that they were already in control of town of Sharm el-Sheikh, "in anticipation of capturing by the Syrian army."
The Islamist Hizbullah movement was the precursor to the Alawite militia, an offshoot of Shiite Islam, that officially supported Assad.
The forces of Hizbullah now controls many of Assad's strongholds in the province of Idlib.
The forces of Hizbullah routed the regime in August 2011 and formed a coalition with the military and foreign fighters of hardline Shiite jihadist group Hizbullah.
This war was televised in which more than 70,000 people died.
At the time, Hizbullah and Hizbullah are considered close allies in the Syrian civil war.
']

Title: Satellite images show Iran building burial pits for coronavirus victims
Generation:
['The satellite images, which have reportedly been used to confirm the existence of seven bodies, show Tehran has buried several bodies by working with German scientists.
Representatives from Europe’s Public Safety Ministry declined to comment on the photos’ authenticity, which were reported by Iranian media.
Iranian intelligence has acknowledged that the bodies were buried by Iranian scientists to bring back more advanced engineering skills to Baghdad, the Algemeiner reported on Thursday.
In an interview with ABC’s The Associated Press in Tehran, Iran National Coordinator for the Search for the Missing in Iran Ibrahim Hammad said “manuscripts of equipment samples” were collected from a site in Tehran that has also confirmed the existence of several deceased bodies.
“We do find other samples of objects,” Ahmed Makhmour told the AP. “We will continue to search and test samples.”
Hammmour said this country is researching equipment “for next to nothing, not because it is technologically advanced, not because it is technologically sensitive and relevant.”
“We have not enough blood to test for another kind of disease,” he added.
Iran’s ballistic missile programme is also said to be involved in killing or infecting six members of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps.
The agency has said it plans to set up a laboratory in Tehran to test its equipment.
Such probes are supposed to be an update of the program, which was halted when US President Donald Trump imposed sanctions on six countries that were found to be working on missiles.
GPS and internet
The final confirmed bodies in Iran, as well as four people killed when a ballistic missile exploded in international waters off the coast of west Africa in March, are believed to be the remains of Iran’s four largest families, said Haider Refahi, spokesman for the Mossad, the agency in charge of security.
Iran has long been responsible for the practice of burying bodies. Last month, the Islamic Revolution Guards Corps, Iran’s military wing, and its intelligence chiefs compared the practice to the practice of every individual to be buried with ashes in the living grave.
Last month, 11 bodies were found last week. “The government does not participate in grave excavations without Israeli participation,” said a woman identified as Bahram Qumari, the head of the Iranian Interior Ministry’s news site, Alarain.
Iranian al Qaeda assassinated Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on April 3, killing the leader of Iran’s Al Qaeda-affiliated Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, Qari Jafari.
The Iranian government has so far not decided who will be the next head of the organization, but the Ministry of Intelligence has said “They (the Islamic Republic) know who will succeed us.”
']

Title: Iran to temporarily free 54,000 prisoners as coronavirus spreads
Generation:
['VIENNA, (CNN) — Iran on Friday said it would temporarily free 54,000 prisoners as it fights a virus spreading across the Gulf region.
The government “is discussing with the Iranian judiciary and judiciary agencies how to build a buffer area” around vulnerable prisoners inside Iran’s jails, and “the plan is to begin the work of establishing a comprehensive measure of protection and rehabilitation for detainees,” the official IRNA news agency reported, quoting a Revolutionary Guards official.
It added that the government was planning to host high-level officials at a special meeting on March 31.
Four men died in Saudi Arabia in February, and another two days later in a remote island province in West Africa. Four more cases were confirmed in Iran over the past year.
Asked about the higher number of people joining Iran’s imprisoned population, Mohammad Jahanpour, foreign secretary of the government’s National Security Council, told reporters he hoped to find a better resolution.
Iran is waging an internationally declared state of emergency after its Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei announced a nationwide state of emergency on Saturday.
In February, the security chief in Iran’s modern state agency dined with local officials and invited them to attend his official inauguration in Tehran.
While Khamenei has asserted that Iran is free of terrorist activities, Islamic fundamentalists are believed to have carried out 9/11 attacks on New York and Washington and have pledged in the past to wipe out any country whose government lacks freedom of movement.
Human rights groups have raised concerns over Iran’s ill-treatment of detainees and punishments for dissenters.
A hunger strike in Tehran in February by prisoners made headlines, but was short-lived as the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps introduced a range of measures.
The Guards said they would speed up treatment of prisoners by using force and quick arrests. There are reports that some prisoners are shot while serving prison sentences.
']

Title: UN nuclear watchdog finds Iran has nearly tripled its uranium stockpile
Generation:
['DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (CNN) — The United Nations nuclear watchdog has long recommended the International Atomic Energy Agency develop a longer-term, cross-border verification process to verify Iran’s compliance with its latest nuclear deal with world powers.
But its renewed concerns regarding Tehran are mainly because Iran was singled out by the IAEA for so long, allocating 2.2 metric tons of their highly enriched uranium to Iran this year — nearly nine times the previous year’s allocation.
In recent days, critics in the IAEA made pushbacks about the IAEA’s overall findings, including whether Iran had indeed diverted some of the uranium to its main supplier, or an additional amount.
The objections came amid arguments in Europe and North Korea over the wisdom of Iranian President Hassan Rouhani’s hard-line stance toward the West and the future of the nuclear agreement, despite a U.S. Supreme Court decision to uphold the deal that specifies Iran’s nuclear activity will be restricted to peaceful purposes and not military, part of a negotiated nuclear deal.
In its July report, the IAEA found Iran was sharing still more than 2 metric tons of its enriched uranium to Kazakhstan. “Resumption of this activity is expected in late 2020, as measures are under development. Such a pace of activity would result in the necessary necessary volume of Iranian uranium to be produced, but would need to be approved by the IAEA,” the agency said.
Citing a U.S. intelligence assessment, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called on Iran to suspend uranium enrichment in the second half of the year after some results weren’t obtained.
In a letter released Wednesday, Pompeo urged Iran to suspend non-nuclear activities for a total of five years. He said Iran had been requesting additional deliveries to come “around 2021,” including more targeting of targets in the so-called “dirty powers.”
The U.S. agreement provides that Iran will “explore” a “coherent cooperation program” to restart enrichment of uranium and conduct civil nuclear work, although the “secretory program” is an intended endgame.
Pompeo is also calling on Iran to “take advantage of existing technical and information gaps and cooperation arrangements, including the resumption of nuclear activities and agreed step-by-step verification to create a threshold for verification of Iranian compliance” within the next two years.
Iran’s top leaders did not attend the Monday Paris climate change talks. And Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif cautioned the country’s leaders against their outreach to the international community.
Iran denies any role in its nuclear program and denies it is seeking to build atomic weapons. But it says it wants only peaceful nuclear energy, including by developing uranium for fuel.
']

Title: Trump's Middle East plan could jeopardize Jordan-Israel peace treaty, Jordan PM says
Generation:
['WASHINGTON (CNN) — President Donald Trump's Middle East peace plan to achieve a durable ceasefire with Israel by resolving long-standing disputes could potentially imperil peace hopes in Jordan and Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told CNN's Brianna Keilar on Sunday.
The Israeli PM, who enjoys growing support in Arab states due to his handling of the Middle East diplomacy during the Obama administration, said Trump could be mistaken if he doesn't consult his party leaders and community in announcing the new peace proposal.
Trump's June 12 summit with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu under the auspices of the Quartet of the U.S., Russia, China, France and the United Nations had largely turned into a battlefield in which the leaders discussed the issues of border security, regional peace and Jerusalem, and more specifically whether to move the U.S. Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.
Trump's meeting with Netanyahu is the first since the other U.S. government officials last month said the new plan would lead to an Israel-Jordan humanitarian co-operation, two major issues that had been at the heart of its negotiations.
Though it signaled a willingness to walk away from early stage deals that have been in place for decades, Netanyahu said Trump's proposals are "no longer an obstacle to peace".
"If you wait too long, it will find itself telling Israelis and Palestinians that 'Lionel, it's no longer the end of the road'." Netanyahu said.
The joint statement, released earlier on Sunday after a State Department media briefing, said Trump's proposal does not undermine or decrease the "shifting international authority on Jerusalem," where Israel holds most of the land around the Jewish city.
Under the new proposal, a Palestinian state will be created in exchange for an agreement that can be made by a negotiated Palestinian-Israeli two-state peace process. It also would recognise Jerusalem as Israel's capital, bypassing regional and international agreements that had rejected it and offered to deal with "the East Jerusalem issue".
"The states parties agree not to advance the onus of finding a middle ground and to make it clear that our method of settlement is the direction the Palestinian and Israeli governments are heading," the statement said.
Trump, Trump, Trump: We're open to negotiation. We have ideas. Trump, Trump: If you want the Palestinians to get the money and leave Israel, we'll talk about it," Netanyahu's press secretary, Sean Spicer, said following Trump's policy announcement.
Mixed results
A week ago, Trump denied the progress made in the negotiations, saying: "We've been on slow-game, all indications of failure for what would have been years, so you probably agree with me."
Netanyahu, meanwhile, says the conflict created by Israel's annexation of the West Bank, East Jerusalem and any area it had lived in for decades will be resolved.
Israel and its allies claim a Palestinian state under Islamic law is a final claim. It is the first time since the 1960s that the two sides have reached an agreement. Netanyahu has said only that an agreement made by Trump and Netanyahu included regional cooperation between Israel and the Palestinians.
The Jerusalem Post on Friday said Israel and the Palestinians reached a preliminary agreement on April 1 in the presence of a group of 100 top figures from Abbas' Fatah, a militant group believed to be planning its own interim peace proposal for an Israeli-Palestinian state.
Palestinians want East Jerusalem, occupied since an army offensive in 1967, to be an independent and unified capital.
In a stark rebuke to Trump's move, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki Haley, said Trump was trying to shift American policy and destroy the budding ties between the two sides.
The Trump administration had accused Jordan and Israel, claiming that Abbas was meddling in Middle East peace negotiations with his offer of sanctuary from Washington to “colonialist” states like Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
WATCH: JERUSALEM AUSTERIA - Key statements on the U.S. plan to withdraw U.S. forces from Middle East: https://t.co/ddGixnEHF pic.twitter.com/en54XdwzAB — CNN (@CNN) April 3, 2017
Trump's proposal would also cut Egypt’s peace agreement with Israel. It provides security aid and provides recommendations about policing, intelligence cooperation and efforts to deal with organized crime.
BRIANA KEAROK
CNN's Brianna Keilar and Paparazzi's Molly Smith contributed to this report.
']

Title: Israel's Netanyahu on course to win most seats, but may be short of majority

With the vote, Netanyahu is relying on convincing majorities of voters to stop a right-wing incumbent — whose country's coalition has been split since December — and establish a six-month process to build a centrist government. The polls were scheduled to close on March 19.
So far, they have won most of the 537 seats in the House of Representatives, most of them uncontested. Only 18 seats in the other 50 are in question.
However, the margin is still wide, and Netanyahu's lead over rivals could be reduced. Not only would some vulnerable centrist voters lose their seats — the Election Commission has taken the example of the anti-militant Hamas, which is running a multi-year campaign operation for parliamentary seats on the same day as the election.

If Netanyahu wins, it would be the first election to nominate a Jewish or Muslim man as prime minister since 1946. Netanyahu has launched a scathing attack on other liberal and pro-Israeli parties in the wake of his tough parliament performance in 2011.
The polls predict more extremist candidates like Meir Kahane, a hard-line former leader who is being investigated for embezzlement. He is set to be challenged by a conservative party's former chairman.

Jewish centrist parties are also experimenting with the prospect of "grand coalition" — which will see each candidate opposing the other — that could seem a final test.

Netanyahu himself was in the prime minister's orbit after his party took over Jerusalem in 2001, and has held the post since assuming office. His movement has posted strong numbers in several other towns and cities, and polling is expected to increase further.
Labor's Isaac Herzog, a former Israeli military commander who is a possible contender, will appear as a challenger to Netanyahu.
The government's staff must hand over to the electoral commission the results of an election to be declared by the following day.
Meanwhile, Hamas keeps pushing for elections. The Palestinians have called for parliamentary democracy after the 2010 elections in which they won 57 percent of the seats.
Kosher and madrassa
Biden, who was elected Israel's first vice president on Jan. 6, has championed the centrist Knesset. His recent statements have focused more on the policies that beheaded Palestinian citizens of Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza.
In November, at the invitation of Israeli officials, Obama offered Netanyahu the support of an agreement with Hamas that would release tens of thousands of Palestinians who had been held for more than a year without rights or a legal basis.

Title: Netanyahu projected to win Israeli election, but exit polls suggest bloc just short of majority
Generation:
['Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke exclusively with Zeev Elkin over the weekend, signaling “thumb play” in the country’s upcoming election, but dismissing incoming chief pollster Yisrael Katz as the mastermind of the results so far.
If the primaries are held today, Katz, a non-politician, will preside over the stunning finish, with the 35-year-old relatively unknown right-winger securing a majority.
Most polls since Netanyahu swept into office in 2013 and served as his prime minister, are ahead of his governing coalition. But Katz has a relatively narrow lead over his nearly opposite-side counterpart Netanyahu, according to Zeev Elkin, a political scientist at Tel Aviv University.
The 65-year-old Katz built a loyal following for decades, counting National Identity, the nationalist party that holds most voter registration in Israel, which requires members to hold a citizenship test to vote in order to qualify.
Critics are criticizing him for playing favorites with the parties he narrowly won in last year’s national elections, which largely represented left-wing and religious voters. Katz favors closer integration of the Palestinian West Bank, similar to previous regional plans that bypassed that region’s peace process with Israel.
Conservatives also complain of Katz’s personal involvement in politics.
“Many Israelis feel that Netanyahu and his party are getting a bad deal,” said Gerrie Fonseka, a research fellow at the Israel Democracy Institute and an observer of Israel’s electoral system.
Despite government objections, the polls show the formation of a Palestinian state with permanent peace negotiations as the only viable solution.
Israel captured Jerusalem from the Palestinians in a 1967 war. Israel claims it would retain its Judea and Samaria territory, the Golan Heights and the Mediterranean Sea, and East Jerusalem. Israel, which calls them the “West Bank,” broke up the two-state arrangement last year.
The Palestinians want the 1967 borders for a future state that would include Jerusalem and a future Palestinian state.

Title: South Africans in Wuhan lockdown call for evacuation
Generation:
['South Africans on Wednesday summoned authorities in the densely populated capital to evacuate at least three people in an escalating crisis.
A magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck in southern Wuhan province, a suburb of Johannesburg, on Wednesday, killing scores of people and injuring many others, the Interior Ministry said.
Initial reports put the death toll at around 150, according to media reports. Three people died of their injuries in Wuhan, provincial health director Martin Mwirunga said.
Saturday marks the anniversary of the independence of the nation from South Africa and a year since independence for the whites in 1974.
There are fears of contagion from the unrest in Wuhan.
“Why would authorities in Wuhan evacuate people and dispense evacuation instructions to that region?” Mpofu told CNN by phone.
“They are saying that they’ve heard an earthquake and that they’ve heard people from that area telling them to evacuate, to keep quiet.”
People were reportedly asking rescuers, including white officials, to move them in order to boost evacuation chances, causing “collateral damage,” “a humanitarian disaster,” looting and “malicious intent on the people,” state media reported.
“I understand that some of the casualties are black, but it’s hard to live with a situation like this,” Mpofu told CNN.
“We’ve thought that you might have people who are willing to die, you can’t just tell them to evacuate. But we can’t continue saying all the games are over. The worst thing is if you hear an earthquake and the village collapses. It’s dangerous. We have to try to stop it.”
Yesterday, one person had to be rescued by the police, who said the two bodies were taken to the Urban divisional hospital in the capital. They were released Wednesday evening, officials said.
Police said in a statement posted on social media that search and rescue teams have been sent to Wuhan.
In response to their calls, the white government was silent.
“Clearly, there is no administrative or social responsibility on the part of the occupying forces for the government to step up on our behalf to offer assistance,” President Jacob Zuma told members of the nation’s political and business community in an address on Wednesday.
“We ask the black audience and investors here to ensure that the family gets what it deserves.”
On Thursday, the president said that the political system had failed to restore confidence in the region after last week’s violent protests.
“No one deserves more than who lives under the rule of law … who not receive the day’s justice, nor receive adequate security for their family and friends,” Zuma said, quoted by the South African Broadcasting Corporation.
Sisi to take the reins in Egypt
Sisi will take over at least two months in which five people have been killed in the unrest, according to Egypt’s state news agency.
Sisi said in a televised interview late last week that he would step aside after the white police are dealt with, removing him from the presidency.
At the moment, Sisi, who just took the reins in Syria as president, is at the centre of a dispute between the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and security forces for crackdowns against a Muslim Brotherhood movement that was banned and now takes control of several Arab states.
Sisi, a self-described moderate Muslim who used to be a member of the opposition, has said he wants to end attacks on Muslim Brotherhood leaders and remove extremists from power.
Over his lifetime, he had visited the cenotaph in Cairo, along with Egypt’s military chief of staff, Ali Abdel-Fatah, according to Egyptian media.
Top Western diplomat Nikki Haley was working on a cabinet reshuffle as the crisis there continues.
— CNN Washington Bureau Chief Phillip J. Nielsen contributed to this report.
']

Title: Caught between roadblocks, they were sitting ducks for Boko Haram massacre
Generation:
['By Carl Burgdorfer, Sara Iizuka for CNN
A Christian group that specializes in ties to Boko Haram has said soldiers in Niger are recording videos showing Boko Haram fighters looting homes, roads and churches.
The official statement from the group, which calls itself the NCAID, shows them bringing livestock to long distance stops and mowing down people and returning with no compensation. They did not specify why they were fighting.
It was the U.S.-based NCAID that first reported the report of the episode, and was given a more detailed description by the Nigerian government’s spokesperson at the time. It only later accepted that the footage may well be authentic.
“We didn’t investigate before,” said Biyi Wangel, the group’s acting director of state operations in Nigeria. “Instead, we began to request for a video tracing the movements of the four soldiers to investigate incidents of looting, violence, military exchange fire and calumny.”
In the video, soldiers are seen firing at farmers’ fields and seeking refuge from the violent encounter, like a lot of peace-loving residents across the country.
The military on Thursday said it found evidence of the raid in Niger’s other north-western region, Nigeria’s commercial hub, Kano, which the Nigerian army has clamped down on in recent days. The military removed a man from his farm there, the army said.
The 19-year-old soldier from the Kano region, who asked not to be identified, is shown showing up in the truck carrying livestock.
He and four other soldiers are seen mowing over homes and businesses and shoving trash into roads, the military said.
None of the soldiers in the video come to attention to the combat after Boko Haram splintered after four years of war.
The group engaged in the “showdown” Tuesday on the roads of Lake Chad, Nigeria’s worst crisis since 1991, with a nearly 11,000 death toll, the U.N.’s worst conflict in decades.
“Our soldiers heard Boko Haram’s cries of God before they spotted them,” the NCAID statement says. “They then crossed into the surrounding countryside.”
More than 10,000 people have been killed since Boko Haram launched its recent offensive in 2014.
“The (Boko Haram) militants of northern Nigeria were defending their homes, and women and children slaughtered in the name of their religion,” the statement said.
“Their Muslim husband was killed and his children killed because Boko Haram leader (Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau) had dumped away goat carcasses in the bush and killed two children.”
Boko Haram had been emboldened by the president’s Jan. 29 call for Western-educated militants to move to East Africa to join its ranks.
Heikki Gunadasa, U.N. Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs, said earlier this week that $32 million had been given to finance new humanitarian and food aid programs in Chad and Niger since May.
NICOSIA, Cameroon (Reuters) — At least 12 members of Boko Haram’s African wing have been killed in attacks in Nigeria and Cameroon, the coalition of Nigerien-based insurgent groups said Thursday.
Groups of the 19-year-old soldier from Kano-class aircraft fighter pilot said in their statement that they had evidence of their involvement in the raids, which include a joint raid with Nigeria’s army. The NCAID said the planes “did not take part in actual or suspected combat.”
It was not clear if the group is affiliated with Al-Qaeda or the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. A military official in northern Nigeria said the men have been leaving the country as it sought to quell protests about tougher anti-Boko Haram measures.
Boko Haram, which has killed more than 8,000 people since 2009, has been fighting an insurgency that has swept from the capital of Baga into cities around the Niger border. The men, some fighters and private contractors, have converged on the western Nigerian city of Maiduguri in recent weeks.
']

Title: This South African pilot is on a mission to change the face of aviation in Africa
Generation:
['LAMBOURNE, SEOUL, April 5 (CNN) — The insectoid wing out of an Airbus A320 crashes early on Tuesday, injuring 59 people, including the pilot, Canadian authorities said.
No new information has emerged from the crash, said a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration.
The Airbus A320 was leading a commercial service flight from Johannesburg to Cape Town when the plane veered and hit a tree, resulting in the ejection of the pilot, authorities said.
The South African Air Line Pilots Association has estimated that two people died in the crash.
The crash is the latest tragedy for South Africa’s civil aviation, which was slammed by a wave of travel problems and an overhauled network of airport hubs just a year ago.
As many as six pilots were injured in the crash and five others are still missing.
“If anyone would have taken to it more carefully it would have happened in less than a minute and there could have been fatalities,” said Lucile Ohmyer, the CEO of the Civil Aviation Authority of South Africa, the authority in charge of overseeing aviation in South Africa.
“Our main concern is to make sure that the crash does not continue to be a tragedy, and that passengers and safety are being protected and that we take the best care of them.”
Airbus said it was investigating the accident.
The Airbus A320 aircraft has been one of the most popular jets in South Africa — an aviation rarity — for many years and carries more than 2,000 passengers per flight, according to industry figures.
South Africa is home to thousands of aircraft built in the past 15 years. They include Boeing 737-800s, Airbus A350s, Boeing CSeries planes and Boeing Cessna 208s and others.
Each of the A320’s eight cogs suffer from loss of altitude when turning down altitude. That can lead to a collision with an engine attached to the aircraft. The pilot of the plane or another passenger died as a result of that ejection.
South Africa’s civil aviation agency is among the most stringent in the world with high-tech standards aimed at ensuring flight safety.
The A320 had been refuelling, when it was destroyed in an airplane crash in the western Libyan city of Sirte on Monday, officials said.
The planemaker noted that none of the A320 crew survived the collision. However, it will test out the plane for flight safety tests and have the aircraft equipped to react to the difference between altitude and high flight.
']

Title: Senegal launches wind power plant as part of its commitment to renewable energy
Generation:
['(CNN) — Senegal is tapping its renewable energy potential for economic benefit and is looking forward to energy production as part of its continued commitment to its traditional energy sources.
On Saturday, the country launched an ambitious plan to produce about 42 gigawatts of wind energy capacity, with billions of euros being provided towards investment in hydropower and a potential 11 gigawatts for solar panels, rsvp Sahalane Diaguade said.
The country, which has the seventh-largest in the world population of 1.2 billion, is in the midst of ambitious climate-change adaptation and development priorities, particularly as its population ages.
Read more: Africa is taking technology to the next level
“This initiative will boost national economic development, contribute to energy security, address climate change impacts and eradicate desertification,” he said.
The wind power project is expected to generate more than three billion euros for the government’s fiscal policy, Diaguade said.
Seventy percent of the country’s energy comes from coal-fired power stations in the northwest and southwest regions. Electricity accounted for almost half of the total energy consumed in the country in 2017, up from 54 percent at the beginning of 2016.
A mid-term report issued last week on Senegal’s plan to reduce dependence on foreign aid said its own two-thirds of its population is now dependent on domestic energy supplies.
The country has already said it wants to boost its energy exports to more than $10 billion a year.
Boosting energy security comes in the form of a new $1.5 billion development fund, which aims to bolster efforts to develop coal-fired power stations and help industries diversify into biomass.
This is one of its most important initiatives.
The Fund will go to expanding jobs and bolster the economy, Diaguade added.
“Energy is the most basic investment for our modern economy and for the world we live in,” he said.
"The key to innovation lies in technology and not just energy technology,” he added.
']

Title: Expert view: Seven leading African photographers from across the continent

['By Ted Chiang
When I first met Batang, the breathtaking, stranger-than-fiction author from South Africa, I had an almost extraordinary view of him from the perspective of an engraver.
Batang was born in Rotterdam in 1954 and grew up in Colleen, South Africa. He later moved to a rural village of Keetmanshoop in the Basque Country and eventually spent his time in southern Africa in rural Cambodia. He continues to attend an annual photography conference at a university in the Southwest African region, often visiting me there as he works on his book Living in Africa.
A lot happened in his short time there. The country of his birth was world-famous for its early move from the cotton mines to its southern Africa capital, Cape Town. We were there trying to document the beloved golden boy of Ghana, Hippocrates. And after all this, he was so captivated by the entrepreneurial spirit of his early West African contacts that he began traveling to exotic places all over the world, setting up his own side-project, “The Coghong” at the tender age of 30, out of Amsterdam’s Park Rd, Amsterdam.
He was moved to New York by the mix of comfort, wellness and writing, so the second time he brought up the subject of his book he went to Dakar, Senegal, and he returned there by a second time to expose the desert landscape he had visited. That book was titled “Camped Out in the City,” and an advertising campaign for the book was soon produced.
With the help of colleagues and his dealer, Arthus Gurkuyana of Beeji National Institute, I was able to film his travels here and there, especially the colonial-era village where he and his cousins sold cigarettes and tried to fight famine.
Batang studied photography in the United States and chose to become an amateur photographer. But his curiosity over photography was what prompted him to launch “The Coghong,” and it was despite the fact that his alma mater at Cornell University provided him with a course in photography there that led him to establish his own studio here in New York.
After this period of exploring Africa, Batang brought home his treasures, as well as his photographer husband, Willie, and their nine children and many pets.
Ted Chiang is a visiting photographer who is based in South Africa. At @tchiangangning @TheCoghong, I will be presenting a post-photographic tour featuring man-made landscapes and animals. https://t.co/Rl4TkFLI0Z pic.twitter.com/ihzZds68oB — We Are The World (@Coghong) April 3, 2019
This trip to Africa — which I’m really hoping will offer a more a return experience than the actual trip — started with lunch with a local artist, Akhiraj Singh.
He was eventually invited to come to the Coghong for an unscheduled lunch with a particular person, but I think, for the many reasons he related, those were not his experiences.
Good luck to all of you, Kind fans, deep rooted storytellers, and conservationists who are part of @bihihihang.
In her e-mail, Harris Archer wrote: “I’m going on a special trip to Africa in May. Chris and I are both avid game fans and we are travelling together to Indonesia’s Calomar Pacific Tertiary Reserve, and this week Chris used our Maluku resort for a run-in with very excited local game players, so they were eager to meet me.
There’s a reason Chris went back to the ‘Seoul Fountain’ of peace.”
This will be the first part of my blogging series, will focus on Africa’s most famed photographers, all while also focusing on inspiring African explorers and conservationists.
']

The symbol was conceived by Joe "Rud" Savage, an ice cream lover (and the inventor of the sculpture "The Rainbow"), at a Manhattan hotel in New York. Title: This iced tea is harnessing South Africa's miracle plant
Generation:
['NEW YORK — It's that time of year again, when the lights dim and you have the ability to look away, make a cup of tea and sip the most magical 20 shades of brightly colored tea you've ever made.
It's a century old tropical banana-wettling tea plant just out of South Africa — and it's brand new, at the CFB South Africa Planting Facility in Johannesburg.
The steam-cooled plant produces tea tea syrup from regular banana leaf oil and water, which it mostly uses as bath salts, ice water and water (today, it's called "reverse tea.")
The cinnamon tea plant, which is tucked away in an underground trench, turns hot and has sat in a "cook orchard" deep in the Indonesian jungles for thousands of years.
The plant is not only about the things and emotions flowing inside the banana tree.
"This plant is reaching the taste of the tea plant and its inhabitants around the world," Sarah Burra, head of operations at CFB South Africa Planting Facility, said in a statement.
And what's true for the world, you may not even know it's true.
Burra says the plant's other potent, fresh fruit, called chambadensis, is its best thing: A small bite of heavy, naturally strong bitter, sweet tea can make a hefty amount of tea time.
"This plant has its own unique unique fruit. Chambadensis is similar to (10 tablespoons of) pomegranate, or Madagascar cinnamon tea," the CFB South Africa Planting Facility official told CNN last year.
The official even called the plant "the first produce plant in South Africa built around a cheap, underground trench where the two species live in harmony," according to CNN.
"The seeds and fruit have been grown, and there are believed to be seven workers working the plant," Burra said.
It's a bit of a feat, given the state of South Africa's latest agriculture program, according to the South African Ministry of Agriculture.
"South Africa is one of only two countries in Africa not to have a $2 billion agriculture program," Ag Minister Jacob Zuma told CNN last year.
How much a handful of banana plants can produce in one day might be harder to grasp.
"We don't think a handful of bananas can produce that kind of quantity. Three banana plants can produce as much as the national average of 10 bananas," as CNN reported last year.
"South Africa is one of the few countries in the world without a robust agricultural sector. Africa is one of the few countries without a diverse agriculture sector and is one of the few countries in the world without farmers."
The plant makes its own sweet tea, but it also uses giant pods of fruit to its core and processes them in super-hot, low-salt capsules, so tea is not nearly as hard to digest as real tea (which could be another very expensive gift to a young child).
Other South African tea plant attractions include the creation of Kiswahili rice, which becomes hot and slow.
Now, thanks to a Series A financing venture, South Africa Planting Facility also has its own innovative tea plant, at the same facility in Johannesburg.
The plant is said to produce a wide variety of food-grade tea, from fresh chambadensis to dried sweets.
It also has a mix of textured milk and non-hydro tea:
']

Title: The president of US Soccer steps down as he apologizes for legal document's language
Generation:
['The next president of the United States, following Michael Bradley's resignation in February, has announced that he will step down as the United States men's national team's assistant coach when he finishes his term, effective immediately.
Nicknamed "The Concierge" by the moniker of Rob Bradley, the contract he signed with Trump's National Women's Soccer Team was set to expire with one season left on his deal. While it was initially stated that John Brockway and Bradley had signed a three-year extension, the federation then determined that they would not be able to renew the contract, so Bradley opted to leave the USA's national team through the winter.
He said in an announcement released to the media on Friday that the decision "reflects regret about the potential actions taken in 2016, and concerns the future of the international team."
Bradley wrote that he was "deeply remorseful" over the decision, and detailed his previously "total disdain for our environment," as well as his "deep disappointment" over the nature of the U.S. team's activities that he considered unsuccessful, which he described as "highly improper," and the fact that he received threats and beatings.
In an internal letter on behalf of the organization, Trump praised Bradley, who had been working alongside his wife Michelle and three children for nearly two years when Bradley resigned last January, as a person who "firmly believes in the values we have brought to this national team, including having representatives of our membership receive ethical and religious instruction."
The US Soccer Federation president also explained that they needed to understand Bradley's background, and that he lacked a PhD in international law, so that his replacement could correct a major problem.
A memo with Bradley's legal adviser said he said he was "proud to have brought thousands of hours of work to the U.S. national team during an inauspicious tenure. I thank all of my friends and family for their support over the past year, and I will miss the game of soccer with all that makes it work."
He told the USSP: "I remain confident that U.S. Soccer will and must continue to make great strides to ensure a positive representation of the United States international team."
Throughout his tenure, Bradley discussed the situation with select U.S. Olympic team officials, media and the Olympic Committee, multiple other NBA stars and U.S. officials. As the San Antonio Spurs coach, he was a source of pride for the team, including allowing his players to take part in qualifying matches, and delivering pep talks during the current run to the quarterfinals of the 2016 Olympic men's basketball tournament, including the president and general manager meeting.
Through his actions, Bradley received multiple alleged threats over the course of his coaching career, and family and friends were repeatedly threatened in very public ways. He spoke in private, apologized publicly for all the things he did wrong, and added that the former Bruins star wanted to bring a "new day" to the organization.
He also said he felt "vindicated that the U.S. national team holds up the standards that we, as fans, expect from our team."
Bradley would not disclose the name of the coach he was looking for in a prospective interview with reporters.
He had previously said he would still coach the national team after his contract was expiring, but a source, adding that the man that the organization had to choose was not directly related to his athletic coaching position.
']

Title: Here's what Harvey Weinstein said in court before his 23-year sentence
Generation:
['The #MeToo movement sure is sending a mixed message.
On Tuesday, Harvey Weinstein agreed to plead guilty to a "defamation" charge related to a salacious 2004 scuffle in his hotel room at the Sundance Film Festival, a reporter had reported at the time.
The victim, 29-year-old writer Tim Seeley, filed an FBI complaint accusing Weinstein of sexual harassment and assault, according to the New York Times. He was 24 at the time of the alleged incident, the Times reported.
Weinstein admitted his guilt "on behalf of all of us," according to a statement issued by his lawyer.
"Finally we have the opportunity to move past this trial and pursue the common sense defense of sexual assault for the sake of a better future for all of us," Weinstein said.
The statement did not mention the charge, but the reporter who filed it cited texts, an email and other items stolen from his hotel room, the Times reported.
Weinstein "had made numerous verbal threats against the writer," the statement read. "He has been disciplined by Warner Bros. for those statements."
Weinstein's attorneys said the "vast, unprecedented" cooperation was a step in the right direction, according to the Times.
The United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York sent a statement praising its work on Weinstein's case, calling the late executive producer "a trusted mentor and friend" who made dozens of personal visits and gave "a full accounting of himself and his work history."
The statement continued: "Thanks to our dedicated staff at the L.A. P.A., we continue to provide them with access to and access to evidence in this case and to our immense support for their family. We thank them all."
']

Title: Homeless Californians join in a lawsuit to mandate Los Angeles provide shelter for thousands
Generation:
['SAN JOSE, Calif. — National League of Cities leaders have teamed up with one of California’s worst and most homeless shelters to launch an effort to force the state to address the complaints of residents who receive food and other assistance during cold weather.
The fight to become one of California’s “worst” in recent memory follows a similar lawsuit filed in Los Angeles County last month, which served as a backdrop for a series of meetings Tuesday in San Jose aimed at raising public awareness and urging the Legislature to close the aging Los Angeles homeless shelters.
The groups of San Jose’s homeless program are the National League of Cities, a nonpartisan advocacy group dedicated to combating homelessness and climate change.
“This partnership is the perfect opportunity to help Californians become successful recipients of the most basic public services,” Jon Leitner, president of the League, said in a statement.
The Los Angeles shelter business “has been the conduit through which homelessness and global warming have been established through devastating mountaintop stormwater runoff loss,” he said, calling the programs that have delivered protection, meals and thrift stores “both critical public health issues in and around our cities.”
The shelters house roughly 16,000 Californians without permanent housing in the state, according to the California National Guard.
Because Los Angeles is the county with the largest population, they typically house only the most severely traumatized.
“Southern California’s homeless population of more than 7 million accounts for one-third of the state’s population of residents,” Riverside County Supervisor Mike Antonovich said at Tuesday’s meeting, referring to the state.
The National League’s president and chief executive, Stephen Leitner, called the marches on Tuesday “extremely innovative and uncoordinated” in his 22 years in business. He noted that the California Legislature has agreed to create a task force to consider solutions to address this “chronic issue of homelessness.”
Antonovich, chair of the Assembly’s oversight panel, said the Legislature’s blueprint for government funding aimed at addressing homelessness and poverty “does not follow clear separation between institutional income and reduction. It follows not nearly as closely as the proposals enacted by California and by local governments, and it requires cities and counties to find billions in funding to provide services to the individuals and families they are supposed to be helping.”
Antonovich said the city’s supplemental fiscal funding, under state law, generally comes from healthy sources, but the state has limited funding for housing and shelters, so he urged lawmakers to tackle changes to the state’s proposed No Child Left Behind law.
“Unless we take action quickly to reduce the past two decades of the devastating effects of this educational achievement gap on our schools, it is clear to me that Assemblyman Leitner and the Legislature must increase the funding needed to adequately address this crisis.”
']

Title: Robert Durst found his friend's body and ran, attorney says, but he didn't pull the trigger
Generation:
['DORPHANT, MI -- He had been called by the neighbor for a parking ticket when he took the keys out of the car and ran out of there, he tells CNN's Todd Busch.
As he ran out of the house, Sam Warrick, a housekeeper, said she smelled something strange inside.
"Do you know what? No, I don't know what that smell is," she told him.
He knew who that was and didn't make a call. He drove from the house to where Sam believed he had left her -- away. But he didn't get out until he arrived at home.
Then he drove back to where he left the keys and let Mary Marramando and Lynn Burgin go to sleep.
Mary Jane, a sister of Durst's daughter, reported that Mary Jane was outside her house Monday afternoon with her son. Her father and Mary Jane's daughter followed shortly after.
Mary Jane didn't see her son until Tuesday morning.
She said Mary Jane did see the missing person's card at work and the suspect's car on the side of the road.
Mary Jane's mother on Tuesday learned of the missing person's card, looking to collect them.
On Wednesday afternoon, when she entered the basement of the house, she noticed a suspicious car.
"When I was outside, I looked up and it said, 'Your car. Dear siddim,' " Mary Jane told CNN's Todd Busch.
Her was about 6 feet, 9 inches long. Her arms were bare. She weighed about 20 pounds and could not say how old she was.
On Tuesday, she and her sister were fed with blood, Mary Jane said.
They said Sam was a suspect in their death.
He started spraying their house with chemicals, she said.
Sam was a devoted husband and father, who worked as a wine buyer for several years and who lived in Glen Arbor, Mary Jane said.
She told guests at a fundraiser the night before that her father told her he wanted them dead. She said she did not think she was being truthful.
Mary Jane said a state-backed official confirmed that, but acknowledged there was no way she could prove that.
Her sister, now 30, said Sam, 38, did not own a car or do anything like that.
The three got married the night before and Sam lived with his parents in Michigan.
"He was a trustworthy guy," said Mary Jane. "He got along with everybody, even my family."
Although Sam lived in the house, Mary Jane and her sister drove to the spot that she used to "greet" him, Mary Jane said.
But Sam left for the restaurant around 4 p.m. and she would let him leave.
Sam drove out of the house the next morning, Mary Jane said. They spoke briefly but couldn't talk.
"He had walked out of town," Mary Jane said. "He was hot. There was this smell in the house. He had keys. He had hot toenails. That was an accident."
Mary Jane said she heard screams in the house and wondered where Sam was. Sam drove home, but her sister-in-law raced to the scene and realized that Sam was gone, Mary Jane said.
He told her that someone had taken over the keys and ran through the house.
Mary Jane told CNN that the door was opened and she heard the names of the housekeepers in the neighborhood. She thought they'd passed to her brother, who had made the call and allowed them to call her to get an itemized bill for a time.
Mary Jane said she and her sister-in-law took Sam and Mary Jane's daughter to the house and found them covered in all their activity.
Sam was an avid reader and avid car fan, Mary Jane said.
It seemed they were missing.
She said Sam told her a car rental driver for the same company that told Mary Jane to drive him home found the keys.
The day before, Mary Jane was asked if her brother and sister wanted to move in with him, she said. She told them she'd leave for a "fallout," Mary Jane said.
The day before, Mary Jane was a little bit upset and she woke up crying, Mary Jane said.
The house was the first they knew they had left since her brother was indicted on murder charges in July 2015.
She said Sam's father was unaware of any arrests in the case. Mary Jane was still missing Wednesday afternoon.
']

Airplane flight passengers between the United States and the British Virgin Islands may have been affected, according to airline spokeswoman Alexa Cullen.
Cullen said the episode was “a very minor case” and the airlines have notified the Health and Safety Executive of the data collection process after authorities first learned of the outbreak.
“If Airline passengers do fall ill, please contact their airline directly at their local airport to tell us of the situation,” Cullen said in a statement.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Department of Homeland Security had been tracking the virus for a “very short time” late Monday or early Tuesday, according to Greg Brown, a CDC spokesman. Title: With coronavirus closing schools, here's how you can help food insecure children

Food-free boarding – children currently under 6 months have a 14% higher chance of developing food-borne illness than their peers, according to the latest research from MD Smith Children's Health Canada.
Those receiving their boarding while sick or experiencing medical problems may not realize that food storage for meals is essential when interacting with people who may be at risk of developing food-borne illness, explains the organization's John Busoli.

Call us at 843-845-4444 for documentation or email a PeopleGuard@fullercn.org or visit the PeopleGuard website.

Title: These states have been hit the hardest by coronavirus. Here's what they're doing to fight the spread
Generation:
['It's the climate it seems, but there are heretofore no vaccines to combat coronavirus virus. Until recently.
After a spike in HIV cases in 2016 that killed a WHO-accredited cancer specialist, researchers set up a partnership with the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to focus on detecting and fighting the virus. And now, two states have been the victim of what the CDC called a record-breaking outbreak of coronavirus.
In a release Wednesday, CDC said the outbreak now threatens only 5,900 people from four states, and 1,753 more are infected since the outbreak started.
Preventing coronavirus outbreaks
That's the "worst outbreak ever," the CDC said. It has already claimed 300 lives so far, and so far this year it claims almost 170 people from 11 states including New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Nevada, New Mexico, Washington, and Minnesota.
The CDC estimates this outbreak could be the most serious coronavirus case recorded since 2003, when it shot down more than half a dozen infections across the United States and Canada. The outbreak affects 2.1 million people worldwide, up from 52,290 in 2013, when it caused 145 deaths and nearly 750,000 infections.

['A Queens-based bank fraudster filed a whopping $6,000 complaint against top HSBC and two others on Friday, claiming the auditors made unlawful fraudulent withdrawals from consumer bank accounts and re-upped the charge against one of the individuals after they paid back fraud charges totaling $11,508.
The claims were forwarded to prosecutors on Friday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s New York office announced on Monday. The swindlers are accused of scamming 13 New York banks, three of which are headquartered in New York City. One alleged victim, a former HSBC employee, recently filed the complaint with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network (FinCEN) under a false pretense of “no liability.”
The fraudsters were indicted on charges of using taxpayer funds and failing to register as a bank fraudster, the indictment states. Since Oct. 1, 2016, the fraudsters allegedly used their transfer funds to defraud residents in Queens of millions of dollars, the FinCEN said.
They were allowed to defraud these New York customers through fraudulently receiving credit and debit card payments in return for travel-related perks or use of personal merchandise, the indictment states.
The problem with these fraudulent transactions, the indictment states, was that “defendants could use the hidden deposit account at the banks’ branches to further their nefarious business activities.”
In the 24 weeks prior to the fraud, the records and other documents provided by the bank fraudsters continued to exist, according to the indictment.
“(The defendants) threatened the victim with severe emotional distress and enhanced fear, (if) they (over) the years dismissed their fraud claims,” the indictment states.
Ultimately, the suspects took their victim down a list of 31 such identities, the indictment states. They then obtained fraudulent transactions from the victims and gradually re-upped the charge against one individual.
“Further actions were taken by the defendants to garnish the victim’s wages, and to attach collateral collateral for loans secured by the suspects’ newly acquired HSBC accounts,” the indictment states.
The banks did not immediately respond to CNN’s request for comment.
The fraudsters named in the latest complaint, admitted to filing a false pretense complaint from March 17 to April 5, while in March they appealed a denial of their final pretense claim.
“The defendant bank fraud scheme was … devised through the belief that the only other victims of fraud are banks and the accused fraudsters were HSBC employees,” the indictment states.
In December 2017, HSBC and Nassau Provincial Police jointly investigated the fraud. The case was part of the investigation dubbed NCOOC 2012.
While the three have been convicted in the latest fraud complaint, this no longer is as bad as it first thought.
']

Title: Recovery efforts underway after body found in river
Generation:
["(CNN) — Crews on the Savannah River are excavating the remains of a “very serious” body found Tuesday morning, according to the Savannah River Commission and local officials.
Earlier Monday, authorities reported that the body of the woman, who had been reported missing by her estranged husband, was in a muddy creek on the Savannah River.
Witnesses told CNN that a motorist saw the woman hiking through the river on a boat with a saw lying across the side of her vehicle, before she stepped out into the river.
State officials did not immediately return a CNN request for comment on the cause of death, and investigators have yet to determine the cause of death, according to the commission’s website.
“An environmental rescue team and a resident are gathering the remains of the woman for further investigation and an official cause of death has not yet been determined,” the website states.
Deputy Chief State Highway Patrol spokesman Andrew Akins said multiple agencies are involved in the investigation.
Suspect removed from body in river, police say
On Thursday, Savannah Fire and EMS Department Capt. Jim Richter said the suspect had removed himself from a dead body at the scene.
“I'm aware of (a) witness tell us he saw some scuba divers retrieve the body. It's not right now,” Richter said at a news conference.
Richter said there has been no further reports of water-related injuries, and authorities are still searching the area for anything out of the ordinary.
"]

Title: Saint Joseph Medical Center launches NICU reading program
Generation:
['By Suzanne Dehe, CNN
Medical Center Executive Director
SANTA FE, N.M. (CNN) — The head of Saint Joseph Medical Center in Santa Fe welcomed the morning in a room full of relief workers and advocacy groups to announce the launch of a reading program.
“We are sending out a call to people, many of them older and in their late 30s or early 40s, who really need reading help,” Dr. Jonathan Fitzenhagen said in a news conference in town Tuesday.
Many are helping themselves to help those with mental health problems, he said.
Corticians from across the country have poured into the hospital, beginning a pilot program for testing the number of successful tests for the baby carrier they carry, doctors and nurses said.
“Hopefully, by testing our baby carriers, we’ll be able to get more babies who have trouble breathing into the NICU,” Dr. Maria Driscoll, a cardiac surgeon at Saint Joseph, said at the news conference.
To help the hospital track that health statistic, Saint Joseph partnered with nonprofit nonprofit Children’s Development Partners to provide the reading service for families with developmental disabilities.
Dr. Fitzenhagen said the goal is to compile a database of children’s health data that can be used to manage baby carriers’ health — and might catch people suffering from behavioral disorders who don’t have access to support services.
“Our goal is to track autism and breast cancer and breast cancer by using a social care contract that we have between us and kids who may be having trouble in our care,” he said.
The program will soon see another benefit — greater numbers of mothers and fathers using the service to help their babies take on a higher workload — he said.
Although the reading program is a small one, the founder — Dr. Rebecca Burks — said it represents a step in giving parents their full attention to their families and prepares them for the future.
“Parents need the full picture of what their children are going through and the children who might still be wandering the streets in the big city,” Dr. Burks said.
Saint Joseph Medical Center is within walking distance of 13 hospitals and countless classrooms.
Studies have shown that the best way to raise more babies with a regular mother is to ensure the babies suffer from normal development of our babies, the San Juan-based hospital said.
“I think that health care needs to be as integrated as it can be so it is critical that we see them getting the best care possible,” Reis wrote in a 2015 article on the organization’s web site.
']

Miko is one of three pets given a life-changing prognosis by a major flu bug, dubbed swine flu.
“She’s kept herself busy since she was sick so we haven’t had to worry about her at all,” said owner Amy Brui.
After she was sick for 19 days she came back in April 2009 and was diagnosed with swine flu.
Little came out of the blue this year after having that bird’s-eye vision of the flu.
“It was going all up and she went from here to there,” said Brui.
Her panda counterpart, Tialata, also had a big day for her.
“I’ve always wanted to get her so we planned to have her in the same hospital that I was born in,” said Brui.
Miko is making a new life on her own.
Born only 31 months after she was diagnosed, she is equipped to withstand the strain.
“On the daily basis we can see how much her mind is affected by the symptoms of it,” said Brui.
The treatment for her included breathing machines and tools, as well as medication, have been given by veterinarians.

Brody owns the Logan Alert Pets with his wife, Katie, and his daughter, Alexie, who shares an apartment with Maggie, a poodle kitty.

Title: Judge overturns Utah death row inmate Von Lester Taylor's double murder conviction
Generation:
["× Judge overturns Utah death row inmate Von Lester Taylor’s double murder conviction
LOS ANGELES (CNN) — A federal judge has overturned a 23-year-old man’s conviction for two killings in San Francisco in which a single bullet failed to hit the man’s lifeless body and dragged him into an open parking lot, a former TV producer said Monday.
In his ruling, U.S. District Judge Murray Snow denied a $200,000 bail bond for Mark Rix, also known as Pete and Jake Morgan, who were convicted of first-degree murder in August 2012.
But Snow upheld the bonds' value, stating that Rix's earlier conviction for first-degree murder was ineffective because the gun believed to have been used to murder Taylor failed to store enough heat to stop the killing.
“The court notes that Rix failed to restrain the gun in the case, thus lessening the likelihood of a battery weapon being used in the murder,” Snow wrote in his order.
Prosecutors say Rix killed Taylor and his 3-year-old grandson Matt King in August 2014 in a Matt Warner Road area near San Francisco. A woman who witnessed the crime was among those who said they feared for their lives when Rix was hired to kill them, prosecutors say.
But the court found Rix should have been held criminally responsible for himself and the others.
“The court finds that the officials of the [San Francisco Department of Corrections] policy forbade Rix from using the [Ryan] Carroll gun at the time of the murders,” the judges wrote.
The court said Rix could not be held criminally responsible for Smith’s death in the murders that occurred just days before Christmas 2016, citing another factor. “The misconduct of Smith and his aide continued when Smith proposed getting sheriff’s deputies and police to shoot him during his interview,” Snow wrote.
According to a statement made to the San Francisco Chronicle and obtained by CNN affiliate KTXL, a spokeswoman for the San Francisco Bay Area Sheriff’s Department says the office cannot comment because the judicial process is confidential.
“Given that homicide investigations can be notoriously lengthy, these tend to lack common legal principles,” Snow said.
In 2016, Utah deputy sheriffs called for Riverside County, where Rix was convicted, to reinstate bond.
Rix had his bail set at $50,000. Some details of what Rix might have gotten out of the courtroom were not known at that time.
"]

Title: Video shows mountain lion attacking deputy in Larimer County
Generation:
['× Video shows mountain lion attacking deputy in Larimer County
LARRETT COUNTY, Colo. — A mountain lion attack on a Douglas County deputy involved with the Larimer County Sheriff’s Office on Thursday afternoon is not believed to be a response to recent incidents or of any kind of animal cruelty, according to the Douglas County Sheriff’s Office.
Multiple law enforcement agencies responded to the incident of a male mountain lion attacking a sheriff’s deputy at 12:22 p.m. in the 300 block of 300 South.
The sheriff’s office said the suspected mountain lion did not flee from deputies and it had attack and death ends.
One deputy was able to put the situation behind him and return fire with an Taser, but the mountain lion attacked him with its paw, giving it more time to attack.
As of 7:24 p.m., the sheriff’s office said the mountain lion has killed two people and injured nine in the 14 days since the incident.
A 19-year-old woman and another man were taken to Douglas County hospitals to be treated for injuries they sustained during the attack.
All were believed to be in their 30s. All of the victims suffered major injuries. All were injured in the attack.
The sheriff’s office doesn’t know where the mountain lion originated, and all injuries are considered minor.
The mountain lion is 8-foot-wide, reddish-orange with a speckled greenish-orange coloring. It lives in a neighborhood in Larimer County.
If the person who attacked the deputy had any animals, they would likely have died from their injuries, according to deputies.
Anyone with information about the incident is asked to call the Douglas County Sheriff’s Office at 720-798-6811 or the agency’s website at danielc.larson.com
']

Title: Private event industry hit hard in midst of ban on large gatherings in Oregon
Generation:
['Forget the aroma of hummus and Cuban sandwiches.
People who head out to Oregon in June to watch the Republican National Convention might want to consider the boisterous feeling of anticipation that accompanied last summer’s initial Republican National Convention in Miami, home of the Land of the Rising Sun.
The volcanic, three-week-long convention began on Monday and will hold Saturday and Sunday, when nearly 120,000 people, who will be in the Washington, D.C., suburb of Eugene, will swarm to Eugene for a week of dayslong party-oriented activities including a town hall meeting in the high school auditorium, panel discussions in Eugene’s science library and then a performance by the Michener Boys Choir.
For Oregon residents, the event starts with a Friday morning football game between Eugene and Portland in Eugene, a little after 11 a.m. local time on the first Saturday of May. The games kick off on Saturday, with a blue and red warning for road rage. A repeat of last summer’s contest between Eugene and Phoenix will be held on Saturday.
Records show only 27 cities have ordinances banning all rallies, meetings and “alt-demonstrations” involving a large number of people, said event organizer Tim Williams.
When reservations are taken, the date for the event (which costs $1,160 per person), the person selected on the first ballot of the election to fill the designated chairperson, begins Tuesday at noon.
“The purpose of this event is to bring people together for one of the highest stakes on earth,” said J.W. Lawrence, VP and general manager of Oregon’s Agusa Festival, which is holding the event in Eugene. “We hope we will attract every imaginable crowd, depending on how we define our crowd size.”
The first venue for the outdoor event is within a 60-mile radius of New York City. Other top-tier cities such as San Francisco and Miami, too, also have similar ones, Williams said.
“Since Oregon only holds 25 percent of the country’s land, the Biggert-Waters could be a center for all kinds of gatherings and live music, with professional tailgating and live entertainment, too,” said Amy Robinson, Agusa Festival’s coordinator.
The ticket prices range from $84 to $125. Roseburg has a ticket price of $175. Ashland is only $25 cheaper than Eugene, Robinson said.
For this information, contact the Oregon Organizing and Management Council at (202) 794-3663 or visit annuvitions.org
']
