Title: Business is booming for local woman making masks
Generation:
['Kathy Ramsey said her face is not like the rest of the face.
She grew up a roller-coaster, high school dropout and now matriarch of a service business. But Ramsey is a mother of two young daughters in the San Francisco suburb of Daly City, California.
She asked about plastic surgery, how she finds time to look her best, how much exercise her kids are getting at school, and her business plans for the years ahead.
When it came to doing their business, Ramsey, who was a stylist and makeup artist before giving back to her circle of roots for nearly 20 years, knows people look at the masks and jump at the chance to help them not feel obligated.
“They say, ‘You do it better than me,’ ” Ramsey said. “For me to do something to bring attention to something that I’ve felt up until now is so important.”
Ramsey, 53, in the foothills of the San Francisco Bay, believes success lies in combining her core values of “going about your business the right way” with her values of helping people succeed.
She’s a certified cake cook and pastry chef who took her children to Savannah College of Art and Design in New York City. She’s a former dance teacher and chairman of the Electrical Engineering Engineering Faculty Association. She’s an avid writer, and owner of Los Angeles-based Makito Cosmetics.
Ramsey says her power with clients stems from her personal history, and she sees a deep connection to the women’s movement that makes her feel connected to them and to those around her.
Like everyone in the San Francisco region, the minority of women who participate in business equity lawsuits now are represented by the 10 Asian-American women who said they suffered huge economic losses after suing after falling for just the wrong suit.
Ramsey says her company in which she runs the Kaki Tumpeks plus Beauty City project also brings attention to healthcare issues related to women’s attitudes toward women.
“We believe women in this country should be judged more fairly based on their looks and grooming needs,” Ramsey said. “We believe that being educated on beauty, wellness and wellness is life-changer.”
The story of the woman who lost her voice to cancer in 2012, for which she became famous, can’t be told without listening, and when the story goes to print, she wants to know what she did before launching her business.
Ramsey felt health was a priority in her last year at school. Her kids stayed away from her for periods while she underwent surgery to treat stage IV breast cancer in 2013. Her 2014 procedure was the subject of an impassioned debate between her and her husband about whether he would be best person to make her money.
Ramsey found herself having to confront the idea she wasn’t likely to be able to afford another procedure if she went forward, and the reality she faced when she landed a job in the Great City Jobs website as a fashion designer at Harper’s Bazaar.
“It’s hard for me to believe something I know about now that they’ve seen and heard,” she said. “This is my life.”
Ramsey was able to work with the charity Smashbox to raise funds for the Skin Institute, a nonprofit that helps women overcome the effects of severe body dysmorphia and plastic surgery while working toward becoming successful women.
While she does not think there is any way she can break the glass ceiling at Smashbox to pay it forward, the idea of a business in which people have collective voices made it onto the scene, such as when yoga promoter, Metrot in Calabasas, decided to run her own business, has made her believe the post office is bigger than them.
']

Herbivriazole was once known for its stimulant and psychoactive effects. On November 18, 2016, it was given to Michael Johnson, a student at Brown-Roberts Elementary School, with a prescription for an “intoxicating high.”
Johnson found his nose and mouth “unresponsive,” and snorted the drug, according to the federal court document.
The school declined to discuss the issue with media, citing a pending lawsuit. A Brown-Roberts School District representative said the drug was passed on to students as a protective measure.

Title: Red Cross calls on healthy donors as coronavirus concerns cancel blood drives
Generation:
['RED CROSS
More than 100,000 blood drives are planned in the coming months as it examines pledges to head off “human coronavirus” in children, raising $3.2 million from more than 350,000 donors.
The grants will apply to blood drives for the eight pilot types of coronavirus, which occur every 30 years and infect millions of children in the developing world.
Global leaders from major pharmaceutical companies, science agencies and more than a dozen international donor agencies convened on Saturday at the Burundi Cultural Centre in the capital, Bujumbura, to improve the practice of public health campaigns.
The first blood drive will be held at 9 a.m. on April 19, to benefit the Global Warming Solutions Project, which aims to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions by 60 percent by 2050.
Conference participants will include UNICEF Deputy Commissioner Sanfilippo Arnende, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, CIA Director John Negroponte, UN Secretary General, General Assembly member school Tuvalu, UN Population Fund Director Hilda Rodolfo and senior media specialists Rob Liefsberg and Angelian D. Mirjandad.
Safer and smarter
Scientists are looking at how people can spend less time drinking, coughing and hunger.
Scientific wisdom on how to cut down on or reuse energy-saving cloths and other flimsy traditional materials has continued to evolve, but the question now is can we stop offering cheap, effective alternatives.
That’s where the United Nations Nuclear Regulatory Commission is trying to come up with a new way of limiting the use of aircraft fuel that is fuelled in huge numbers by coal, tar sands and other industrial sources.
There’s a decision coming up at the UN nuclear commission, the world’s largest arms sales organization, on how to check whether biofuels can be used to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The vehicle options would go beyond only cleaner fuels, to include solar or wind turbines powered by biofuels, water purification, biofuels for cleaning the land and near-shore planting of trees.
Rope is industry’s cancer watchdog
The biofuels industry is increasing its concerns that change in biofuels used can cause hormone-like reproductive problems for a variety of diseases, including cancer, multiple sclerosis and kidney disease.
The industry’s chief executive officer Jose Alvarro said there are 10 major companies working with the biofuels industry on studies about developing biofuels for use in packaging and in advertising.
To date, only 24 biofuels from the UK have been approved to fuel vehicles, and more than half are in the pipeline, according to the Biofuels Industry Council.
Al Alvarro also said that biofuels would add to the global pressure on governments to slash fuel use from the Earth’s abundant biofuels.
Chemical chemists develop new treatments that use compost to produce biofuels, but will require relatively high price tags and high regulatory fees, he added.
A new opportunity
The cost of using biofuels may be considered a huge money shot if biofuels, particularly cell deposits, do not change in the short term, he said.
But BNDA, the World Bank Group and the United Nations, which supported the U.N. review, have said they have not seen enough to protect billions of people who currently use fossil fuels.
The current outlook is for biofuels to be extracted commercially as quickly as possible, Alvarro said.
']

Title: West Covina Parents Arrested After 9-Month-Old Girl Found To Have Cocaine, Meth In Her System

When a 9-month-old girl, the daughter of a young man and her father were pulled over for a new-door-door stop on Interstate 10 in West Covina, police arrested them on suspicion of selling cocaine.
Authorities on Tuesday, April 4, obtained a search warrant to search the apartment in which the 13-year-old was held, records show.
Lorsen Castro, 21, and his girlfriend Nana Derecki, 21, are out on $100,000 bail. Derecki, a doctoral student at East Central University in Houston, Texas, told CNN affiliate KTVK she didn’t plan to leave the apartment to go with her boyfriend.
Castro was arrested at around 1:45 p.m. Tuesday, hours after authorities began reporting on cocaine use in the home, KTVK reported.
At least one of the four adults inside the apartment in West Covina failed to report the child, the warrant shows.
“With the lack of access to their own apartments, we didn’t know how you could stay home with the medication if you could do so. You just thought you were going to be left alone,” police said.
One 911 caller reported that the child was around 1,000 pounds. Neighbors told police the home is 5 miles away.
Castro allegedly made several calls between the apartment and his girlfriend, allegedly talking about drugs in the apartment, an officer said.
Castro allegedly offered to give the girl narcotics, and he was arrested.
On Tuesday, authorities tried to get information from the apartment through a series of Facebook and Twitter postings, KTVK reported. In one message, Castro allegedly told the residents that police were going to swoop in on him because he was the house guest.
The sheriff’s office received the initial call for information from the apartment that at 2 p.m. Tuesday, search warrants show.
Earlier Tuesday, KTVK reported that Police responded to a call in response to a report of an aggressive man with tattoos and alcohol.
On that call, police were told the caller had been sitting in the vehicle with his girlfriend when someone came out with what appeared to be drug residue, KTVK reported. Police were awaiting background checks on the vehicle.
The operator of the car told officers that Castro told him there was “an uptick” in people with criminal records because he shared methamphetamine with other juveniles in the car, KTVK reported.
In another message posted on Facebook, Castro allegedly said to someone “I went and did some work for a family friend to help them get money off of the rent and get clean.” He said his girlfriend, who is 16 years old, was also among the callers.
The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals recently upheld an arrest warrant for Castro, saying he, allegedly with his girlfriend, played with methamphetamine and cocaine at homes in Green Valley, Livermore and East Orange.
“The physician essentially concluded that cocaine use was not inconsequential in the courts, given the overwhelming evidence that cocaine use is treated at high levels in the medical community,” Judge Kathleen Shanahan wrote for the court, KTVK reported.
Two others, police said, are being interviewed.
The woman in the car, a man and a woman on parole, was not in the vehicle.
Last July, KTVK reported that police were sent to the home where Derecki’s mother lives after the girl was reported to be having seizures.
Derecki lived in the apartment.
Police who searched the home on Tuesday found a hardy, red-colored 3-liter bottle of Ecstasy, a 91-caliber handgun and three other drugs, both listed for sale on the Snyp.com website.
According to court records, the 10-month-old girl was taken to the emergency room and was treated for seizures and impingement.
']

John Faulkner, a first-year wrestling coach at Wisconsin, expressed his disappointment to the players at Mid-Mountain in Butler County and to the group he coaches and practices at Northwestern State, a program he says focuses on academics and athleticism, not tragedy.
Faulkner said he expects the standard of excellence from every college to be matched, but he reminded fans that he believes NCAA rules will make the tournament difficult to imagine.
Football fans are also going to need to prepare for a number of dangers on campus, including flu-like symptoms and vomiting, Faulkner said. And the wait for football is part of a 100-day process.
“Let’s face it, the tournament started long ago, and we want to get right back into it,” he said. “This is something that is going to be impossible.”
McKinley, a freshman track star, said she still expects the tournament to be a success.
“I have almost equal expectations,” she said. “I love it so much.”
A statement from Big Ten Conference president Garry Willard congratulated people and added that the conference stands “in strong solidarity with the football program and the NCAA Committee.”
Another Big Ten Conference Conference commissioner, Ohio State University president Grant Strong, called for a committee be convened to investigate the NCAA tournament.
“The number of major sports programs that are engaged in rigorous and resource-oriented postseason play does not outweigh its importance to the entire school community,” Strong said. “If the NCAA is unable to find its way to the heart of college sports communities, as it has in virtually every other facet of life in the country, then it will not host such programs.”
The NCAA had been scheduled to begin taking applications for its 2014 national sportswriters’ championship in January, but it will not take applications until May, allowing some large school sports in which a person from a major school or professional sports organization play to quickly adopt or adopt new rules.
For now, teams from all of Wisconsin have attended games and practices at Eugene this spring, and players seem to be working to learn from the experience.
“I haven’t had a problem getting hit. No, I don’t anticipate it getting worse,” Faulkner said. “They are ready to use their muscles. You just need to know you have a really hard day to get ready.”
University of Wisconsin athletic director Kim McSorley said she is aware of the competition from the Ivy League and even the RPI, although she has not seen it changing.
The country’s Big Ten conference was set to return to the NCAA Tournament as it did in 2009, but last year’s tournament was canceled because of continuing disease concerns. Tournament teams in the Big Ten lost out because of controversy with tournament rules, including increasing restrictions on the ball movements.
Other teams include Texas and USC, while Northwestern State played the same tournament last year.
Florida State, the No. 2 seed, and Vanderbilt played their games at noon and said earlier today that they would again be sending as many players as possible.
Wisconsin’s FSU players, who are ranked No. 2 in the USA Today Coaches Poll, will be cheering at home on Wednesday, from Galax as the March Madness draws near.
McSorley said the NCAA has not reached a decision on schools that are firming their programs or are placing other teams in a position to participate at a higher level.
She noted that the NCAA is “dumping two much higher-ranked teams right now.”
McSorley, who as she prepares for the tournament in practice for a month, is optimistic that the Big Ten will be a once-in-a-generation winner and “maybe a champion in 2024.”
“I am not one of those people that thought we could beat them in the Big Ten,” she said. “I know we are going to be going back in five years if things work out like that.”

Title: NCAA's Decision to Cancel the Big Dance Is the Right Call, Even If a Sad One

But as of today, Americans have more to lose.
I could spend the rest of our waking hours planning for the 60 seconds of time in which I see how far this Final Four really has to go before I go home.
In fact, I will be traveling to watch the Final Four tonight with my husband Mike, who has been on my side the entire tournament.
After seeing the Real Tar Heels win the Final Four four years ago, I will also watch another Final Four. After Oklahoma won last year's crown, I watched as the Crimson Tide reached the Final Four for the first time since 1993, and the Tar Heels still have the dubious honor of a Sweet 16 appearance.
Oh, and did I mention that a CBS sports poll from last Wednesday indicated that Tennessee and No. 1 UCLA did not win the national title?
But until Feb. 29, I still had to plan for the $5.50 Super Bowl ticket to be sold on StubHub.com.
So what will the higher ticket prices turn out to be? I imagine ticket broker Roth said one price, but of course, I don't know. And I want to point out that there is no way I can predict that again (when it comes to the Big Dance, at least).
The Big Dance is currently coming down because of it's escalating price tag. Most American households do not include ESPN's streaming service, ESPN Plus, on their household bill, because it costs per bill to access ESPN. The price of the service, which includes the broadcast of the national final four on ESPN2 (next season, ESPN is expected to put something similar in place), is being hiked recently, partly because of ESPN.com.
ESPN isn't exactly the hottest platform for baseball games. Its Price tag of $20,000 is not above a similarly expensive market rental with Amazon's Prime (for families in Washington or Los Angeles, so the price of an Xbox console is $400). Other times, it seems, ESPN Plus is at least a half price.
It makes me wonder if Amazon can really keep this price tag of ESPN Plus.
All in all, I do believe that although it's possible that ESPN will increase its price, there isn't a single person to support this price hike. If anything, I suspect that it will be the former, especially when it comes to sports programming and publishing. CNN won't allow it, and it certainly won't promote the sports themselves. It will be distributed live in different ways.
Neither is ESPN Studios and its video-on-demand product ESPNU.
Most networks are tracking the revenue impact of ESPN+ and ESPN2 among their members. Even though ESPN+ hasn't been advertised as such, I would find myself holding an extra $1 if I were a member.
It's been, and still is, a steady source of income for many Americans. If it were less, it would be a sad event. But the act of creating a baseline of daily revenue, as opposed to an inclusive one, doesn't make things easy.
Just as it makes me think we've seen those four years this close to the end of time, if we have less than 12 years to protect our traditional golden age of sports, we probably have less than 12 years to protect our beloved UConn-Kentucky. (Again, I'll say, although some people point out that it is close, I have no idea how many.)
']

Peng recalls that the ship was about to load its cargo along with its leader, was sailing up the Indian Ocean, and managed to negotiate the "perfect passage" through the German harbors of Koln, Palau and Messerschmitt. It was that rare occurrence that made the first port call a very special one.
Peng had been staying in China with his uncle and a friend, who was late and had to hold a cookout in the shipyard's dining room -- sort of like a high school cooking school -- and there was "no one in the family where I learned my Chinese cooking skills," Peng told Power Money.
Later that month, he and other cabin servants disembarked from the ship and went to dance with them.
"At lunchtime, we were all sitting at a table on the boat in the harbour," Peng recalled. "We were sat in the middle of a motor boat, with a man in a wooden chair, and we all played the Western music for three or four minutes. As everyone got ready to leave, a party of about 50 party-goers began acting like it was an all-male party."
Suddenly, some people started shooting rounds at the living room where gambling was taking place.
"Everyone's very upset," Peng said. "So I put the TV up, and about ten seconds later, I heard someone banging on the wall and flames shooting through the room."
The fire was later extinguished by some guests, but there was blood and smoke. "I wasn't used to smoking, just on vacation," he said.
Soon, Peng and other Chinese cabin servants caught the brunt of the fire. "When I arrived home at 7 a.m. (local time), the fire was well contained," he recalled.
"We were asleep at the time, and I said, 'Why are you smoking?'" Peng recalls. "It was kind of ironic to me because I was smoking so much tobacco at the time."
The fire had also brought new challenges to port life.

Title: Apple says it's fine to wipe your iPhone with a Clorox wipe

Since word of his private detection, Apple has now acted, for the first time, to crack down on the errant minor alterations on iPhones that don't go into place, Todd Adams told CNET this week.
"We do not tolerate inappropriate hardware configuration and this has always happened," Apple VP of external affairs Jon Louderback said in a statement to CNET. "We've made clear that hardware configuration does not feature this type of modification and we still have policies in place to ensure products comply with all Apple laws and we expect consumers to behave responsibly."
"In addition, due to the overwhelming amount of support we've received from customers, we've thoroughly reviewed all of our customer information. And we've taken steps to ensure the final product is updated in line with modern technology."
He said it was the first time that Apple had blocked the handling of minor alterations, which does not include the case of getting rid of a bug with the wipe because it does not go into place.
"The regulatory environment already is an environment for big changes," Adams said, adding that that the company does look to see that changes in hardware configurations and there aren't "whole every device in the world experiencing a change."

Title: Why oil prices are crashing and what it means
Generation:
['Please enable Javascript to watch this video
NEW YORK -- It's time to pull out the Kleenex and look at our hyper-critical global economy.
Far from just another day of extraordinary new economic indicators, global stock market and housing prices were dropping again Monday night and Tuesday morning.
Consider last week's comments by Donald Trump that might be seen as part of the "team of John Heilemann and Lucy Jordan" as the Fed brings out a fighter jet against a financial crisis:
Expect more volatility Tuesday, says Paul Dales, Senior U.S. economist at Capital Economics. "Growth is likely to be even slower than we thought earlier this year, cutting into the progress of the global recovery," he says. "This weaker GDP is likely to impact confidence further, pointing to a more pessimistic outlook for the global economy."
Growth is not the only figure that needs to be taken seriously.
Money Morning Global Energy Strategist Dr. Kent Moors says the U.S. economy isn't doing as well as we thought it would. "Even as the economy is adding jobs, though, it's slowly slowing in other regions," Moors says. "What's most likely to drive these numbers is the impact of the oil price slump which has continued to fuel a severe sell-off in oil markets."
Moors notes that China is barely growing, as oil-product sales have fallen dramatically since 2016 as a result of a huge flooding in the region. China's economy contracted at its weakest pace in more than three years last quarter.
The biggest concern for Fed policymakers these days is the impact of rising crude prices in the U.S. and Europe.
This isn't just a question of importation.
Last month the European Central Bank unveiled a policy target for weaker crude prices.
And now in markets around the world, Europe's oil market is in its darkest frame in years as the Europeans try to engineer monetary reform.
Europe is forecast to deliver $50 billion more in funding from central banks than it did last quarter.
The European Central Bank says the European economy will grow about 1.9% in 2019 and 1.6% in 2020.
While everyone is hoping that the Eurozone will "break even," the 11 countries predicted to grow just 0.7% this year have weaker growth than expected.
']

Title: China boasts massive car and aviation markets. Both collapsed in February
Generation:
['By Reuters
A beautiful Chinese city with the life-like skyline is covered in a wind-swept landscape in a rural area off the coast of Chongqing, China's second-largest city, according to figures released on Tuesday by the Chinese National Development and Reform Commission.
The Mainland Development Council (NDC) said car sales, foreign exchange reserves and road network were all at their highest levels since 2008.
It spent $23.48 billion in the first three months of this year.
"China's car sales volume grew 76% year on year in March - the most in a calendar month since 2008," the NDC said in its semi-annual report.
Based on DSC data, sales jumped more than 30% in the first three months of this year to between 4.8 million and 5.9 million vehicles.
Rising demand for hybrid vehicles and a surging pace of exports allowed China to post its biggest car sales growth since 2007, its annual state inspection agency official Hu Jintao said.
Corporates such as Chinese carmakers "will have a very good earnings-share ratio," said Hao Weihen, a member of the National People's Congress, which holds the second-highest number of seats on the ruling Communist Party's Politburo.
Demand is picking up, said Zhu Feng, a research economist at Beijing Private Bank.
Demand for passenger cars also posted the fastest growth in two years, hitting 5.7 million units, up 65% from a year earlier, the NDC said.
"Hong Kong and Singapore now represent large swaths of China's car sales," said Zhu.
Automakers are expected to boost production in April, with carmakers due to announce a hefty order of over 400,000 cars by the end of the month.
Automakers have also been boosting production, including offering discounts for China first-time buyers to put consumers back on the road.
Analysts at Credit Suisse estimate that a 21% rise in China's auto sales this year could be the only one of the five main trends for the coming year.
The worst economic downturn in more than a decade was much worse than predictions of stronger exports and growth.
Industrial output reached its highest level in more than a decade in March, up 2.3% on the year, better than a Reuters poll forecast of 1.5%.
GM, Toyota and Renault posted the strongest earnings growth since 2003, according to Dealogic.
China's car market is growing rapidly. Vehicles currently account for 31% of global vehicle sales, but those, including hybrid vehicles, are up a whopping 58%.
The government, which released its target for vehicle sales to hit 1.5 million units in 2025, insists demand is worth it and protects car makers from overcapacity.
Total vehicle sales in China reached 48.3 million units in January-March, according to China's National Bureau of Statistics, up 20% on the year.
Experts say this year could be a better year than 2012.
"The Chinese auto industry is poised to win back its growth for the coming year," NDC director Li Yifei said in a statement.
"Its long-term growth rate will come to be more than 4-5% (this year) and in the next 10 years," he said.
($1 = 6.2773 Chinese yuan)
']

Title: 'Beauty is freedom': The North Korean millennials wearing makeup to rebel against the state
Generation:
['The protest that launched this week’s Rebel Women’s March in Washington, D.C., is coming from North Korea and its charismatic young leaders. But its existence is also coming from the struggles faced by society’s burgeoning women, according to women’s rights advocacy organization Carolina Moore.
The 2015 revolution is about advancing women’s rights, but with critics of the women’s movement embracing her movement as a concern, Moore believes she’s closer to eradicating North Korea’s policies than to stopping them.
“I’m willing to be a dictator and have made the abolition of the human trafficking, which led to the criminalization of child labor,” Moore told CNN’s Dana Bash. “I have 10 years of experience working with these types of organizations. This is what we must do.”
She said the United States doesn’t fully understand North Korea’s problems, including the growing economy, the shocking death toll and oppression. But Moore is the first person to see that its leadership is willing to face those issues.
“When these social issues come up, sometimes there are dictatorships, there’s been that talk of militarization of the Korean Peninsula, they’re just not that clear,” she said. “That makes it challenging to us.”
North Korea’s government is also intent on keeping its leaders away from friends and relatives of Kim Jong Un, her father, the powerful leader. According to Moore, the new leader has taken a real interest in Kim Jong Un, who is believed to have had “significant and extensive” involvement in promoting women’s rights within North Korea.
Moore believes North Korea’s leaders have noticed that the young and established women’s movement may not be immune from facing life threats in the future.
“It’s always important for leaders to stick to their own spirit,” she said. “That’s a difficult thing for any leader.”
']

Title: The tourism legacy of the Olympic Games
Generation:
['LAHORE: The Olympic games are incredible. They also represent one of Pakistan’s most crucial cultural moments, leaving a deep imprint on the nation.
In 1964, the first Winter Olympics opened in Beijing – where athletes and officials spent an exhilarating hour on the black-and-blue red pitch – and held for 17 months, with the 1932 Olympics ending in Brazil.
When World War II broke out in Japan and Poland in 1945, the United States was thrust into a war that was not due to be fought, but rather focused on the cultural and educational landscape of its own South American colony.
During this period, the two countries relied heavily on the Lunar New Year (UNINTH) holiday, and the Lunar New Year celebrations, often managed to confine themselves to San Francisco as it happened in Shanghai and Paris.
The three-day long UNINTH festival, especially during the winter months, brought the country together.
All of this with the help of China, where the Lunar New Year clock is calculated after the event is run and forgotten.
According to an official, UNINTH did not reach every household in Pakistan in 1964 because that would have banned the holiday. The actual results, in an opinion piece in the Pakistani newspaper Wazir, are questionable.
Wazir’s opinion piece stated that the Chinese regime did not have the constitutional right to approve holidays and celebrations that were planned and executed by the UN in 1964, for fear of upsetting the sensibilities of its neighbours.
Pakistan’s constitution, according to Wazir, stipulates, “Public holidays cannot be granted without reason, and some restrictions are unnecessary…”
Much of the UNINTH is purely coincidental, according to Wazir. The UN was founded in 1934 when Nawaz Sharif joined Pakistan on a visit to the US. In 1979 he held a cabinet meeting. “The Council of Ministers published a draft charter eight years later to launch a long-planned truce between Pakistan and the US,” he said.
Pakistan’s prime minister Ali Zeidan hosted an in-kind fundraiser in Washington on 18 November 1979 to “issue recognition of independence”. Zeidan was awarded the “World Heart, Citizenship and Development Award” in 2010.
After independence, the People’s Republic of China signed an association agreement with Pakistan; an official of the Chinese embassy in Pakistan hailed Zeidan as one of the leaders of this movement, thanks to a posting with Pakistan Peoples Party PPP and later the Congress Party.
The China’s embassy in Pakistan said the commitment, “we consider Pakistan’s historic presence and historic contributions to the promotion of democracy and culture in the Asia-Pacific region”.

Today, Daniel starts early for school, before he starts high school. He takes lessons to study materials and read to make sure he has the knowledge he needs to be successful in school.

Title: How this outbreak is adding to the risk of miscalculation between global enemies
Generation:
['By Alexander Ramsey
April 5, 2015
The 23rd General Authority of the United Nations has begun launching a global plan to combat miscalculation. The plan was designed to open up possibilities within the intergovernmental organizations and within their internal mechanisms, such as bilateral, multilateral agreements that undermine peacekeeping efforts in or outside the region. The plan will develop special measures to counteract internal miscalculations in the Security Council. Experts believe that the plan could slow down the rising threat of internal miscalculation.
A widely respected U.N. expert, David Addington, has said that central stability and continuity of an American presidency could be tested at any time. Addington is set to appear on the UNT directorate panel as a member of the UN legal committee (the UN Criminal Code). Members of the Presidential Advisory Council on Foreign Relations, the U.S. State Department’s strategic counsel, and others discuss the role of the Security Council in any crisis in any context.
This brings us to the alarming dynamics within this crisis. To protect an organ against internal miscalculation, we must defeat external miscalculations. Although external miscalculations occur frequently, it is mainly in developed countries that tend to avoid taking the extra step of looking at the public balance in understanding internal miscalculations and an ad hoc policy toward this trend. The panel itself has a very rigid role, however, as the governments we are supposed to represent are judged on their value. They regard outsiders with special protection, often in the form of role models, to avoid the internal incidents that could cast the region and its oversight mechanisms as a complete failure.
The internal miscalculation within the Security Council is neither the end of instability in the Middle East nor the beginning of a new crisis. Resurgence of destabilization in the world’s major industrial economies is possible. China is likely to be the major influence in causing the problems of the region, and Iran, likely to continue its influence in the world economy, is likely to be the main influence in achieving this, either by facilitating new alliances or funding them.
We must limit the use of external miscalculations, have more bilateral and multilateral discussions and building more institutional units outside the Security Council to investigate internal miscalculations, to prevent and limit external miscalculations from exacerbating.
Finally, global organizations should engage in direct dialogue with their respective leaderships, providing them with the tools they need to address external miscalculations, and to equip them with sufficient legal structures to protect from internal miscalculations by responding appropriately to the perceived role they may be responsible for. They must resolve the internal miscalculations if some kind of systemic response is required. Diplomats whose involvement in internal structures has been an issue in the past, however, should take firm action.
David Addington, who is regarded as a master of hybrid diplomacy, is well established in both international and domestic diplomacy. He was the U.S. ambassador to the Council from 2006-2014. (see for an in depth look at the president’s position on the Syria crisis, Syria and Mideast.) He has lectured on international law at more than a dozen foreign and domestic universities.
Addington has been deeply involved in a broad range of relationships within global organizations, including the Development and Humanitarian Policy Council, the Intergovernmental Council on International Human Rights, and the Future of Missionational Missions. His advice on UNT matters include strengthening and upgrading existing mechanisms to address internal security. Addington is a well-regarded and accomplished person and a strong advocate for human rights.
My colleagues on these issues had better hope that New Zealand is not a global leader in this area, when it comes to international efforts to constrain external miscalculations by solving internal miscalculations. Such efforts could curtail the warming of conflict zones, enhance U.S. posture in their midst, and help to create a safe climate for peacekeeping forces in other region.
T. Simon Bolivar is the Assistant Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Aid at the United Nations. Former President Barack Obama once served under one of his presidential first-term appointees: Jerry Kostelnik, now at the World Food Program. Although not an occasional foreign correspondent, Bolivar is also fluent in Latin American and African languages.
']

Title: Photos: The coronavirus is leaving empty spaces everywhere
Generation:
['(CNN) — A coronavirus, from a rare sexually transmitted infection called rompscales that are no more contagious than STDs, now appears to be among the most severe.
Scientists hope the source of the disease can be traced to an underground brothel, a U.S. government scientist told CNN affiliate WSOC.
On Monday, it was confirmed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that rompscales, which can carry amoebic hypoxia, have infected 24 in 22 states, the CDC reported Monday. More than 30 others have died.
That could mean the virus may have missed its usual path, or it could have started infecting people the the virus has not yet previously touched, according to a study published last month in the journal Emerging Infectious Diseases.
“The combination of infection with amoebic hypoxia — the loss of cellular activity that drains bodily fluids — and the virus’s passive presence is suggestive of a possible carrier,” Dr. Luis Adrian, a virologist and virologist at Emory University, said in a statement.
The highly contagious illness occurs when the body’s immune system clatters down into a maelstrom of viruses and bacteria capable of infecting and killing a person.
The most common causes of the virus are transmission of blood-borne thrombocytopenia, the body’s enzyme that stops the clumps from forming normally.
“This is what started this disease, and we suspect that it started infecting people in different ways,” Dr. Keith Skinner, the CDC’s lead scientist on rompscales, told CNN’s Eric Kyllo.
An infected person is completely “completely unresponsive, but can be given medication that increases the body’s overall immunity,” Skinner said.
The official cause of the deadly rompscales is unknown.
Much of the chlamydia virus that started in 2010 was thought to be behind rompscales’ discovery, but it’s now been linked to cancer, bone marrow disease and other infections, according to the CDC.
Individuals who have a cousin in the U.S. or Canada may also be at high risk for the virus, Skinner said.
The American Red Cross sent a well-child and pregnant woman from Florida to Atlanta to check on her baby.
Although rompscales are not officially named, American Red Cross spokesman Scott Marshall told CNN affiliate WBZZ-TV that the infection is “explosive”.
“We think we are seeing the species change so dramatically that maybe we are also seeing the trigger of the timing of this virus,” Marshall said.
The CDC said it has been working with other agencies to determine how it might relate to rompscales.
A preliminary research team led by Albuquerque, New Mexico-based investigators working with U.S. Customs and Border Protection is looking at “cocaine-type pharmaceuticals to treat serious infections, and whether other drugs can be used for more widely understood and management of the type of severe infections we have,” the CDC said.
The strain of rompscales also infects humans.
The virus is usually discovered in travel-acquired viruses and bacteria, where only tiny trace amounts of the virus have been observed in people. Unlike most colds, which can infect the nervous system and even cause the bite of a baby, rompscales can potentially infect other organ systems including heart, lung and kidney systems.
']

Title: How religious communities are modifying traditions to prevent coronavirus spread
Generation:
['WASHINGTON (CNN) — Religious communities in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan are using religious rituals to eradicate coronavirus-carrying sexually transmitted infections and encourage copycat infections and reuse of contaminated organs, according to a study published Wednesday in the journal Nature Medicine.
The idea that people living in a congregation of Hindu, Muslim and Buddhist monasteries should develop entire families’ bodies and reputation, scientists say, dates back to the 20th century.
“Religious communities in Japan are exploring ways to become more inclusive by aligning domestic traditions with current religious practices and approaches and altering existing ritual and restorative practices,” says co-author Nancy Zhou, an associate professor at Monash University and one of the study’s senior authors.
Older congregations don’t seem to have joined forces, the authors write, “regardless of whether individual bodies make the recipients feel good.”
Related:
Organ donations matching up with international aid
Liberty of ‘Made in America’ art exhibit complete with environmental awards
Ellen Schlossmann, deputy director of the Jandektz Family Research Council, recognizes the work of leading academics in their analysis of religious traditions in Japan and South Korea, which she says are often notoriously quiet and methodical.
But Zhou points out that religious leaders do play a role in transparency and non-judgment. In Japan, the kind of social justice activism Zhou ran for the mainstream politician in the 1980s is still culturally important to many different groups.
Related: Westerners find it difficult to relate to Japanese
“As Jews and Japanese Catholics, we have to integrate norms, practices and values,” Zhou says.
In the United States, the assumption that people from different faiths live harmoniously throughout their communal and cultural traditions appears to be tied to the ideal of a welcoming society.
But in the cases of maverick and transformative leaders from various religions, members and believers are sometimes forgotten because of their little-known history or cultural fit, says Rachel McConchie, emerita professor of religious ethics at Tufts University.
“It’s important to people to understand how their communities operate and what they want to achieve,” she says.
In South Korea, there are efforts to transform communities’ practices, processes and practices, including continuing studies of polytechnic education, as well as churches and other religious institutions for further education and training.
“They are changing the people they affect,” she says.
The opposite is true in Taiwan, where many churches are adopting modern traditions, including the Tenuta word traditional; which to many Buddhist followers have already become, into “Koo Ma Son,” which translated into either Buddhist or Hindu prayer, according to Greer Seederman, Asian adviser at the American Atheists.
']

Title: Children displaced in the Boko Haram conflict are on a path to success thanks to a school prioritizing peace
Generation:
['The creation of a separate Northern Nigerian school district called the Central Aribo Diaries made education possible to ensure the sustainable release of cholera patients. It has also brought peace to that ethnically divided area which has been experiencing a conflict since the January 2014 insurgency at the behest of international criminal organizations.
The Central Aribo Diaries is the world’s only public school and is located in the ancient copper mine of the ancestral Mesiba region of northern Nigeria where peace has reignited recently.
In its latest annual report, Boko Haram is ranked as one of the world’s most dangerous groups, having killed more than 15,000 people since 2014, according to Amnesty International, 1,000 of which were children.
Researchers have mapped over a billion casualties in Nigeria and found that more than 2.2 million people have been displaced since Boko Haram seized Nigeria in 2014.
A few places in the north of Nigeria have emerged as safe haven locations for the Al-Qaeda-linked group known as Boko Haram, prompting the government to retrench security forces and embrace whatever strategies it can to give Boko Haram a chance to regroup and regroup and regroup and retake their weapons caches.
Some of those fighters, who are also known as “mujahidin,” began calling the town of Ijebu-Ikpe the Ijebu/Ogun State. The region has lost half its population since 2014, over 67,000 people since.

Title: Italy is a test of how a Western economy bear an almost-total shutdown
Generation:
['Concerns about the Italian economy have been running through most Italians ever. Asked about Italy’s famous “sick letter scandal,” one of Italy’s richest men (some 40 million euros), Mario Monti gave his audience: “Why? When you hear ‘loopholes?’ Why? Why?”
Although Italy has a terrible record of having a free-market economy, one byproduct of Europe’s failure to tolerate the protectionist phase is that it is now increasingly able to accept the unfair increase in the value of the euro by borrowing at high interest rates to fund its huge budget deficits.
The limited growth, and the sharp fall in competitiveness, driven partly by the eurozone crisis, is likely to have left Italy saddled with a budget shortfall equivalent to half of the nation’s GDP in just four years, 20 years after all the elites who attended election talks at the time blamed growth for their country’s economic woes.
In that period, it has borrowed from the European Central Bank to finance its rapid budget cuts, which have also slowed growth.
To ease the fiscal burden, Italy’s Central Bank is increasing interest rates by another 5.8 percent on June 2, almost 3 percentage points higher than what it set aside to buy its bonds in the early years of the euro-era, and more than it will raise every month in its general tax and export sales.
If these interest rates are to match those imposed for corporate and municipal bondholders, the economic burden would also spiral out of control.
']

The Internet is blowing up.
Users and writers are writing about social media on Twitter and elsewhere.
Amid reports of harassment that human rights activists had called out at Twitter last week, the anger was palpable.

Unsurprisingly, social networks are harping on the facts that — in fact — we aren’t working for all women and girls.
“In 2017, there were over 2.1 million women and girls who fell victim to sexual assault,” Joshua Dinkins, director of the Campaign for an Open Internet, a New York-based anti-bullying advocacy group, told CNN on Monday. “That is the number of women and girls that were targeted over the years, both by networks and others around the world.
“Every time our friends go online to criticise or harass someone, they send another message. It’s sometimes just a loop, and it wasn’t until this recent social media incident, unfortunately, that we saw that very thing happen.”
On Sunday, Dinkins added that social networks should do more to facilitate victims of abuse.
“Social networks should do more to help survivors of sexual violence,” he said. “In fact, these efforts by the industry need to happen even sooner than it seems to be.”

Title: Fraudsters get hefty prison terms for impersonating French minister
Generation:
['PARIS — Hand-wringing abroad is part of a growing trend in which political prosecutions are bringing dubious or family-friendly charges against powerful or self-serving defendants across Europe.
Prosecutors in France have sentenced, acquitted or even brought criminal charges against 15 alleged bank fraudsters over the past year. At least one case involves someone trying to blame those who steal from his or her relatives. And five people are now facing the death penalty for allegedly helping the money-laundering scheme disguised as a French public servant.
Many of the cases involve that country’s most notorious banker Manuel Valls, who oversaw PIGS Insurance as his Ministry of Social Services, a company he led from 2006 until his death in January 2014.
And unlike France’s Roman Catholic Church, the widely viewed Valls family remains far from conventional politics. It is a blessedly secular France. Members of the Valls family, currently in power, tend to be the most Catholic in the country. One of the brothers who survived the family ouster is the head of the Citroen bank, Leo Bibeau. Two siblings are ex-priestes — his wife told him not to declare his wife’s assets, according to court documents — and two nephews.
It’s nothing new. Many people with trusted social contacts also often connected with French jobs on the world’s highest level of state dependency, paying for travel and often sending food.
Yet there’s no reason to think the gangs will protect citizens of a country full of members of the underworld who have fled Haiti over the spring and early summer for Germany and Germany’s northeastern territories.
Those organized crime syndicates, mostly based in Europe, are using Europe’s best-known identity as the currency for serving their increasing interest in generating the identities of criminal organizations.
One industry lobby group blames greedy individuals who send money to political commissars, though the British government said Wednesday it was handling the case of 84 people.
While France has an estimated 5,000 mln euros in account for the criminals seeking to collect their identities, very few find a way to collect them, and it is the perceived instability and integration of families that prosecutors believe poses a danger. Some of the members steal financial information from victims’ bank accounts, and turn credit cards into forged documents, taking hundreds of millions of euros of government receipts from unsuspecting banks, holding business deals for the elite and influencing public discourse in the media.
“Who is the shadowy figure telling the stories of the operatives the police and judges are scouring for?” asks Frank Piquet, of the Liberal Party, who regularly relies on contacts from the media and has helped the security forces identify small groups of charged suspects.
That’s what senior lawyer Amos Mavalomo believes has helped create an increasingly menacing picture of the ultra-conservative Valls family.
Shortly after losing his leadership as finance minister in 2014, Valls ran a family-friendly bank called Valleur. His wife, Isabelle, was appointed on a couple of occasions to the Public Protection Commission (PGC), a job given to politicians and politicians in other positions of power.
The prosecution alleges that at least some of Valls’ associates, prosecutors say, used intermediaries to arrange anonymous accounts in France and those of owners of more than 100 international conglomerates.
“The twisted, twisted truth has been made public,” Poulais said last week.
Mavalomo says most of the plots involved a kind of agent of influence, a person who paid money for something by other means or paid money with government property. He said such people are so exercised with the prestige of having a common clientele that they can now profit by taking advantage of publicity, which can have devastating consequences.
He says that, at least, isn’t the case. As in other cases, Valls’ clients can be kept under surveillance as long as they don’t leak their identities or do anything untoward.
But some details on the Valls family’s murky business ventures have been deeply muddled, without any official documentation or proof. In one instance, a company that handles transactions to insurance companies helped in the arrest of a German communications expert charged with helping Qatari businessmen obtain top ratings on Emirates Airlines.
Mavalomo says such leaks are not illegal, but “they have many cracks in the concrete.”
']

Title: Mars rover expected to launch this year delayed until 2022, partially due to coronavirus
Generation:
['Updated at 4:45 p.m. Eastern: This version of the story was updated to reflect the radar reveal from the Mars rovers' Nov. 6 crash landings:
After performing some tests along the Meridiani Planum section of Mars' plains, a plan science research rover that smashed into boulders was finally able to successfully land on the Red Planet's surface, a technical spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Mars Exploration Program said on Monday.
"Two spacecraft have landed, and they'll continue to land and rot," Dave Rodney, interim engineer on Mars Exploration Program operations, said in a statement to CNN. "But the Mars' design quality won't be up and running to capacity until 2018-19 and we expect new tires will likely need to be laid for the next two years."
"While we are glad to get past the crash," he added, "this is the first of many re-connections and complications with Mars Exploration Program."
A 33-foot-tall high, highly sensitive crater dome about the size of Belgium by the way, the moon's ring of dust created by the spacecraft's breakup and descent has been named the Meridiani Planum by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). The craft blasted into the vast expanse of space last September, but the fragments from that crash, at which time the Messenger spacecraft blasted into the inner part of the planet's surface, held no clues about why it hit the rocks on land.
The 31 fragments remained lodged on the surface, while the others scattered on to the shores of Mars.
They remain unopened, but some of the world's most gifted scientists were able to pass them on to cameras captured on separate devices on the spacecraft's return stage from the first landing.
"I've actually been looking at everything in sight and back and there were multiple data points about the texture of the Martian atmosphere — the oxygen levels — after they were broken off," University of Maryland immunologist Peter Hoffman, who studies instruments on planetary surfaces, told NBC News.
"We probably are in the perfect position to not only determine the melting effect, but that the surface is actually far more amazing than if you just put together a ring over a wall of Martian sediment. ..."
Now that scientists have proven that the lost spacecraft has undergone some kind of descent, they may one day be able to put a small amount of exposure on the rocks while they assess its future, saving the rover's life in the process.
The soft-tissue samples from the November crash are being archived at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory near Pasadena, California.
The team announced the latest news of the initial tests on Mars in November. On Nov. 6, NASA spokesperson Ed Crossland said they recovered enough aluminum phosphate to run the solid core of the spacecraft on a rotating test program in which scientists drill solid surfaces under pavement, breaking the surface open to soak up the metal.
The United States is collaborating with scientists from Japan, Canada, Germany, Italy, Spain, Australia, Denmark, France, Norway, China, Switzerland, Canada, Mexico, the Netherlands, Ireland, the United Kingdom, Britain, Russia, Japan, the United States and the European Space Agency to develop better mapping software on the Mars surface, which they hope will help them better understand the Martian climate.
"NASA and the Mars Exploration Program is committed to finding a large enough region on the Earth that scientists can easily scale back and re-connect information to the surface," Kenny Cheng, administrator of NASA's Science Mission Directorate in Washington, D.C., told CNN's Jonathan Lemire. "Because of that, we plan to schedule a mid-year briefing to try to flesh out these features in that review."
']

Title: Ireland closes schools and colleges to halt coronavirus spread
Generation:
['Ireland closed its schools and colleges to students evacuated for a coronavirus outbreak that has been causing hundreds of deaths in Europe, according to a Health Department spokesperson.
The HSD said the closed schools closed after large numbers of schools, colleges and health centers around Ireland have opened to manage the spread of the virus, which is considered uncommon.
“We are surprised that the latest cases have gone unreported,” HSD spokesperson Maria Burstein told CNN. “The prognosis for the impact of the coronavirus has been dimmed.”
HSD said 7 of the 9 confirmed deaths in Ireland had been “suspected of infecting others across the country.”
The confirmation toll is likely higher than previously reported, with another 35 deaths in one case in which they died after the presence of coronavirus in the affected areas.
Burstein said 29 students — 16 from Dublin, 10 from Gahan, all from Bristol — were found to have acquired the virus from the school’s toilets.
“After being approached by local nurses, seven of the eight reached a fever pitch and refused medical attention,” she said.
Flooding
KCCD has moved 11 children and seven boys into temporary housing near Galway, as was feared earlier this week. The body will be sent to the CDC for further identification, according to the department.
“The warnings continued to pour in after the temperature spiked to 37°C,” KCCD in a statement said. “The Waco Incident is being investigated as a threat to health, and the likelihood of further spread at this stage remains high.”
The issue has left authorities more worried than the adults in schools and colleges.
“All schools will provide separate care for students,” HSD said. “They will not be moved or sent to a school due to the risk.”
Education Minister Eamon Gilmore has also called for a Scottish government briefing on the warning system.
“We’re already seeing an increase in calls for a wider alert system,” Gilmore told lawmakers in Parliament. “It is a turn-off at school gates.”
Last year Ireland was also affected by a failed double bomb bomb attack on parliament in Dublin, leaving two dead and dozens injured.
']

Title: What you need to know about coronavirus on Thursday, March 12
Generation:
['Please enable Javascript to watch this video
The coronavirus currently infecting and killing thousands of people worldwide is the same as the human immunodeficiency virus that was found just last year, a Canadian professor is warning -- and the new disease could be worse.
Dr. Deborah Goyette, M.D., of the University of Ottawa, will discuss coronavirus in a discussion at the International Conference on Infectious Diseases on Thursday, April 12 at the Intermountain Graduate School of Public Health, 56 W. Irving St., Calgary, Alberta, Canada.
She will be presenting the cautionary tale of how coronavirus can wreak havoc on even tiny creatures.
"Our dominant cause of coronavirus infection was transmission of the abnormal precursor Bacterium norovirus that is doing havoc on the virus," she said. "By the time we saw this infection spreading so far, we had acquired the world's first person first case. Our second victim is now returning to the host, only to be exposed to the virus at the same time as the main cause. An infectious virus that destroys cells, transmits and spreads viruses, spreads very quickly. This is because the virus is spread by a single, broad-organism cell, not a single strand of cells."
In that case, the coronavirus has traveled over the border and isolated enough cells that adults survive for just a few days, then wander off, attacking the rest of the world and killing millions worldwide.
"The wind blows the virus at the will of the immune system," she said. "The disruption that the virus has caused as it does not infect you or your immune system is very severe. The virus then spreads rapidly to other parts of the body. The body and its immune system loses many immune cells and antibodies -- or good defenses -- that protect its body. This leads to the virus being able to destroy the body and diminish its ability to fight off infection."
Her findings are published in New England Journal of Medicine.
Here's what the experts are focusing on:
Tracking the virus once it's at a root to start with
Protecting against the disease early
Protecting the body from infection early and keep any form of infection as a matter of course
If a person has it at any stage in their life and has a clear reason for it
Avoidant, resistant, and resistramiral infections: Here's what the experts are focused on, on the type of infection:
A main probable cause of the virus
The virus is spread by local transmission of virus or other aerosol particles from infected people or pets
These aerosol particles, which are usually aerosolized, include aerosols from one end to the other with resistance, and vapor from another end that may include viruses like Bacillus anthracis or Merkel's virus.
Barring these and other potential results, coronavirus infection won't spread very far. However, it could take a few days or more. The virus can be transmitted as short-term as a few milliliters of it.
If the virus were spread by close relatives, like the human flu and Avian flu (and those associated with both strains), it would be at this stage of the development.
It is impossible to predict when people will see disease and have an undetected or extreme reaction. Confirmation of symptoms such as fever and cough could appear between five to seven days after an unusual symptom was diagnosed.
"HIV has, again, been very damaging to human population in the past," Dr. Goyette said. "HIV has now entered a new phase."
Doctors are making some incredible progress in removing the virus from human bodies, and in preventing transmission.
"Our goal is to prevent transmission and prevent it with other types of vaccines," she said. "But we're getting good results -- we just need to keep people informed."
Funding for virus safety remains a little fuzzy, though. Right now, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is funding a research effort to develop vaccine formulations based on a whole-genome RNA (MLN) test to improve overall cellular and molecular mapping of viruses.
The FDA has been completely focused on this field. According to NIH, one of the things it is trying to do is ramp up funding for field-to-field testing.
And this work is being funded by $90 million that is available for new research. With one million dollars, it's no wonder scientists are moving toward increasing funding for novel genetic diagnostics.
']

Denny, a farmer, has received a mortgage for $3000,000. A month later, he has used his $900,000 savings to pay off the $20,000 mortgage. Denny has been the face of rural Iowa.
Now five days after everyone talked of free-market capitalism , you can watch a video-recorded commercial in the Iowa City Civic Center because the Iowa Heritage Commission has suspended the town of Iowa City from selling off some land.
It all begins in a backyard shed -- in yet another attempt to steal the great land of Iowa, preserve the remarkable outdoor spaces of the city and have it yours. Denny from the small farm out in Northern Iowa can see the future with a remarkable gift:
"
The decision came after the political backlash against it. His employer, United Paper Co., said they were not sold off those lands because it would kill farmers in that region and even if they had sold them land all at once. Iowa Council President Franklin Weingarten wrote in a letter on behalf of the city council that he wanted to do this once more.
What is next?
Iowa Heritage won't make the decision until July 3 -- just 30 days before the election.
The Iowa Civic Center in Des Moines
Iowa's legislature passed a resolution saying, "It is in all of our control to make any or all property available to the government for the sale of privately held or commercially owned acres (at auction). That property must be preserved."
The city council said, "If any property is available at auction or should be auctioned (previously) against the reasonableness and purpose of [it] being auctioned, then this resolution is a direct order to the government that it shall not permit any portion of the public lands to be used for public benefit."
If you really are worried about the look of the homes, you must be focused on this search:
"I get a lot of things, but as far as I'm concerned, this land and that's the most valuable one, with the few acres," Denny told CNN. "We want to keep it out of city hands."
Also, his family's quarry, the countryside. Denny wants his farm to stay connected to the city and his plant was saved so he could work on his property.
Denny wanted his farm to feel home:
"There's always a day when we're just going to come and check our house, like we get out of town or ride a bike," he said. "It's no different from a day where we're just going to be there or get a coffee and drive all over the place."
A king-size bed and chairs
The entire farm remains attached to Denny's roof, but the décor is really Denny's. There are beautiful beds and a huge flatbed truck is for his livestock. A large pot of grass sits on a couch and serves as a lookout for deer and coyotes. There's also a tray of suncream on a porch. And other plant life is evident:
"The ground layer is really well done," said Carl Cannon, the area's agriculture commissioner. Denny is afraid the guardrails that free-float he built in front of his house might rip their fences.
"It's a walk from my house to the farm," he said. "There's an old house with pieces of wood everywhere."

Title: Why no one is reading your coronavirus emails
Generation:
['You want to have a Secret Service buzzer in your room for everyone to listen in and help you if you haven’t made those emails public yet.
But no one is either part of an elaborate, complicated, high-tech scheme to alert the public that someone has been sending those risks.
“It’s a new phenomena,” Aaron Shutfeld, editor in chief of Popular Science at InformationWeek, tells CNN. “This really springs from the idea that many of our everyday interactions are having very different financial implications.”
Why do we talk about potential risks, such as how much money is left over after a deal is reached with a corporation that might have made a single error?
“We don’t have time to revisit this,” Shutfeld says. “It doesn’t take you long to realize that we are really trying to hide things from our friends and family.”
In fact, the systems to alert people of high-risk or dangerous situations that become public have been developed by software programmers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Google.
The new systems allow anyone to use a Secret Service app, calls to the IRS, messages to Congress or other public accounts such as those personal financial records of people in the news, and a “watch” app to help them understand and handle what’s happening in the news.
Of course, the security argument to push out new alerts is complicated.
“I think that’s still a relatively complicated task,” Shutfeld says. “It’s actually a very different exercise from one in the past, where you had to become more user-friendly and be able to go back and take notes.”
Privacy advocates who have long sought an information storage system that would be more open to inquiry, like a Wikipedia check-in or browsing history, have found the programs aren’t likely to be successful for fear of being used to leak information even from government records.
Cory Gulling, senior policy analyst at the nonprofit Consumer Watchdog, is already pushing for more privacy protections.
“There is an old saying: the last one is always upon us,” he says. “It’s important that people remain hopeful about privacy and those that they trust are well informed and objective.”
Privacy advocates argued for a system that would help determine when a person is potentially exposed and what can be done about them.
“I would hope that everyone should have a really robust and effective warning system that will be embedded into their personal email,” Susan Paulo, program manager of the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s public affairs department, tells CNN.
It’s not just that the new, lower-level alerts could be less intrusive.
“These alerts, basically requiring the user to have an identification number that the recipient is agreeing to, I think, could address some of the problems that we currently have with government programs,” Gulling says.
']

Title: In speech, Biden shows how a normal president responds in crisis
