['(CNN) — When he was young, Biden did not tell people what to do.
But when he was a young president, he tried to shake people’s worries.
Biden spoke on Wednesday at the big annual Ben Bernanke Forum, co-hosted by Chase Manhattan Bank and the Federal Reserve Board of Governors and its member board, Ben Bernanke.
Biden and Bernanke in 2012 were launching the Fed’s $4 trillion ultra-loose financial policy program.
And they, along with their pro-fiscal-year Plan B plan, were the focus of a televised speech they shared.
In the pre-speech session, the 28-year-old Biden spoke of his parents’ fears that a criminal defendant would probably get away with murder if he had gotten into a bank account.
Biden took credit for better managing the Department of Justice’s perception that the political process was simply too destabilizing. He cited a 2008 court decision to correct Justice Department misgivings about raising the price of a small burst copper mine through price shocks.
Although taxes are included in the GDP benefit, the price of copper, often used for mining by the government, was much higher during the Great Recession than it was during the Cold War.
Even in the 1980s, President Ronald Reagan was sympathetic to attempts to lower prices.
Biden said he decided to run for the presidential race with his mother’s eye on the polling numbers, not the polls.
Biden said in a speech earlier this year that he used the health care law to advocate that insurers and employers adjust premiums to the changes they are required to make.
The Florida senator spoke on Wednesday to a program of eight or nine community community groups, so that they could better compete with new doctors in the battleground state.
Biden, who spoke Tuesday at the Glendale Community College, said he was determined to hold up the end-game of the health-care debate at the United States Supreme Court, and won out on the issue.
“I consider my opponents to be cowards,” Biden said on Wednesday. “They did not believe in the growth of the American economy and they have no interest in fixing it.”
Biden’s campaign manager said he was proud of Biden and that he “truly believes that the fight is not over.”
']

Title: Doctor: How to reduce your vulnerability to coronavirus -- when sleeping
Generation:
['
Dear Doctor,
Last month, I had the eye contact that I have never had before. I was so rested, you always know which areas I want to focus on for improved sleep. After a few days, you tell me I don’t sleep in that way; that you wake at 3 in the morning and then get up, then I wake up at 8 in the morning. You say you want to sleep in that way, but in reality, I’ve never slept in that way with any of you.
Many years ago, I fell asleep in bed and there was no perceptible feeling going on. It was time to open the book on how to sleep in winter. Some scientific study found that women who sleep in “dark” airways lack benefits from an antioxidant, anti-microbial immunity, and anxiety, but their sleep cycles get disrupted and rebound. Those women reported a morning of negativity and habitual snoring. Some studies have indicated the opposite.
I think she loves you just fine, but I have started to make trouble because the anticipation builds up in the belly, away from your friends and family. On nights when I’m awake and asleep, it gets more intense and overburdens me, and now, sometimes, I get very angry and defensive. I learn to hug you and tell you we have become a little too good at messing with our senses. I now sleep in that airway sitting on the side of your butt, a few inches shorter than before. Sometimes, it’s my body that stops working, so I go to bed expecting to enjoy another evening.
My problem at this stage in my life is that I’m not an ideal, non-surgical person, and probably never will be. Now, I have already started working with my husband and children in advanced engineering in the form of my second career, not for the same reason as you, but for a long time. A normal person would be fine with sleeping in airways, but when your husband and kids wake up during the night, they have to go to bed?
My wife is a fine actress, but did you guys really take care of your eyes, when your eyes are closed every morning, and when your cheeks are spotless, deep? Do you want to sneak a whiff of your possible sins in your eyes every day, for the rest of your life? Well, not to do that is a pretty big bad bet, especially if you’re looking for a more relaxed, family-oriented sleep.
I have suggested dieting to help with your weight loss, and though you’re fine, you have not gotten over your body issues and it’s not that easy. Cutting out caffeine — as diet pills do — can help, as are other choices, and as they are relatively affordable. But you’ve talked all the time of knowing, “I want to lose weight,” and “all your tools and weight loss” can do the trick, right? I know it sounds dumb, but I do find that your neck, not your shoulders, are your biggest weaknesses, so it’s really pretty hard for me to pull that off, too.
I also suggested reducing your natural fats like olive oil and niacin, and making a meal made with organic ingredients, such as chicken liver, mushrooms, and grilled vegetables, which are low in saturated fat. I also ask my wife to make a small bowl of cereal every once in a while. I don’t think she will do this!
Please, better sleep and find ways to sleep better.
I know from the studies we do, that many doctors can tell you about fall-related sleep disorders, but I feel your question is rhetorical. I know there are many ways to help — and there are good ones too.
Thanks for your prayers,
Dr. Kentashita
']

Title: It's time to let the experts do their jobs, Mr. President
Generation:
['By the way, President Donald Trump did something simple when he called cable news a liar — gave the will of a caucus of cable news executives, its independent watchdog, their political bosses, Republicans and Democrats alike, a rooster sandwich and a sandwich of the same type.
That’s an insane, rude, obscene and inappropriate act.
The watchdog is really the utility of the political staff at NBC News. And they have an ethical code of conduct that they are always at odds with to which they have once again come under fire. This is outrageous.
I am confident that next year, with the recent disintegration of the presidency, CNN will feel normal and normal. It will be clear to all of us who might otherwise be questioning what these American patriots in NBC News are trying to get out of their fiefdom.
What a load of garbage.
Jeez, what a waste of our time.
And Donald Trump has repeatedly shown himself the ability and his ability to ignore standards and respectfully treat the experts in the newsroom — this administration — as if they had the devil on their backs, becoming the dean of journalists and history books, it would be fools not to act.
But each time the speaker of the House or the federal investigators in the Senate or the acting attorney general of the Department of Justice or any of the Trump presidential lackeys make the line about what will happen “if Marco Rubio ends up not running, we’ll all go nuts,” this is the moment to do it, and we are here to support it — actually endorsing it for now.
We just can’t see another Republican House member — even the person most people of faith are sadder about — going all the way to Washington.
We want our Senate and D.C. Democrats to be represented by a congressman with an ethics issue on their plate, a voice in Washington — think the Republican Majority of the House, Democratic Majority of the Senate — and yet — there’s an excuse for Mr. Trump to call a Republican and say he’s going to end up not running.
No, this is totally off-base, but the most frequent excuse for condemnation at the White House is to quote a respected historian.
And so we — let’s not kid ourselves, sorry. It’s almost stupid because we’re in a country that thrives on ignorance.
It’s rather interesting to me when a debate show such as “Newsweek” shows only for minutes — even more so that the following would be interesting:
In 2006, a host asked President George W. Bush what he thought of Congress and members of his own party in an interview in Chicago. It was Washingtonian style.
If it weren’t for he, it wouldn’t be worth much in the stands or on the air. But in 2012 the same debate show, which brought so much drama to an otherwise sunny day, brought a subject whose shortcomings were not excused as an opportunity to flounce the nation with “bombshell” information as we all know it — one deliberately always dodges the need to ask specifically why someone has a hole in their chest and one deliberately slights a joke — the morning after the show that he supposedly grumbled about McCain, even though it had nothing to do with Ukraine.
And then there was the recent TV show, not to call it a show, and no executive ever said something inappropriate about Sen. Susan Collins. This was fascinating, going all the way back to Christopher Dodd, who so assiduously avoided calling an entire episode of “Crossfire” “hyperbole.”
They did it with more speechwriter unquenchable fieryness than even Senator Collins could fathom, and even on TV they could give us z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z z']

Title: President Trump, heed these five lessons from my career in disaster response
Generation:
['During his disastrous first 100 days in office, President Donald Trump has repeatedly called the “rainbow effect” from the hurricane Katrina.
His explanation for the damage seems suspect, but at least he offers serious solutions to the mess of people and infrastructure both physically and psychologically damaged by the hurricane.
New Orleans residents and tourists who lost their homes when a tornado tore through the city in the middle of September remain recovering from their destruction and potential recovery challenges.
What was lost, they are not.
What has been lost, they are not.
We now have emergency preparations in place in Atlanta. An attack on a major, fortified levee system by the North Carolina Aids Board, known for its success, is happening very well.
But the Bush administration, anxious about its approval, ended its disaster response efforts eight months ago. In exchange, the administration suspended the first stages of FEMA’s requests for emergency relief from 10 months.
That decision was what triggered the Katrina disaster.
One year later, New Orleans is still looking ahead and waiting for more destruction. My president, President Trump, heed these five lessons.
Prepare for disasters. Get out of the way of powerful monsters, e.g., the Islamic State. Restore emergency preparedness with comprehensive deployment of disaster response and other capabilities that can bring us back from the brink. Be wise in the latest stock market, with an eye on stock markets for safety and not cash-in-hand fun.
By design, whatever the urgency of a crisis, prepare for what may happen at any moment. The greatest threat we face is now a threat from terrorism. Don’t just wait until your time is up; before you start to panic, keep checking the computer and the mail. Don’t wait for the tornado to hit. There is too much different data in this maze for us to catch up.
Be patient. The storm threat isn’t going to come in four or five minutes. Let us appreciate the work of those who saved people and raised us through the adversity of the “rainbow effect.” Remember that the long-term solution to our physical and emotional damage is to make more workable and scalable assets.
Recovery efforts in the aftermath of the storm show that any effective response is workable in the short term. In the event of a disaster, confront an enormous array of challenges, as you are.
The recovery efforts from Superstorm Sandy have been a tremendous success story, showing that rebuilding these areas of our minds and homes has not always been easy.
If you are self-driven, your truck and package truck are going to be hit harder than your car. On the roads in advance, make sure there is new water and batteries available. Plan a safe and inexpensive way to drive through the cleanup. The higher your weight, the less fuel you burn through the road. Remember: your life is not exempt from the dirty oil or salt. Use local, safe and basic emergency preparedness.
If you live in New York City, make sure there are adequate outside fuel and is sufficient in the event of a serious earthquake. The transportation infrastructure in New York could be improved by creating a storm waiting area in a park, for example. If the city is short of buses and trains, use the subway system. And when the streets are plastered with damaged vehicles, take any routes you see are public.
Turn off the lights and get out of your cars. Do not get in a “Got Milk?” situation. It’s going to be messy and take time. But remember: it’s business as usual.
']

Title: A prison pandemic? Steps to avoid the worst
Generation:
['When I first came back home in late March, I read several books about the death of a society that tried to become the world’s last with the shrillness of a captive human population. It seemed accurate to me. At first, I chafed at reading about the make-believe horror that lay in the streets of a state that hands over so much responsibility for the dead to the authorities.
Why did the government find itself taking on the needs of people who had all made mistakes or failed, hurting them in various ways, with the lack of moral reasoning, from moving the heads of the state (where they looked like prisoners) to imprisoning the beheaded captives?
Obviously, we didn’t get what we wanted. But let me make one salient point. We failed our country by being so preoccupied with the problem that we didn’t care enough to fail (and the citizens of our U.S. might well think so) to solve it.
One of the reasons behind the failure to make some sort of radical change in this country was because, well, human instinct did not make up for so many of our failures. We failed to have our disagreements, not to spark our own internal conflicts, not to dwell on the small things (the things of life), not to debate the details (the things of economics, and the things of society).
No longer, we put people in cages because of what they did. But we placed a lot of people out of work, and we made decisions on lives, not their lives.
The people we imprison are emotionally draining, but they are usually saved – they have nothing to worry about. They’re taken, freed and sent home. The fearlessness of they are fine, albeit tiny, save them from being dispatched to the World Health Organization and the law enforcement agencies.
And so we avert some pretty awful problems: We say we just can’t handle all of them. Somehow, the government got in over our heads – in fact, we gave up on all of them, even the most minor ones, because we didn’t have the power to protect them.
But we do have the power. And the resources.
The existence of large national parks and a powerful pension system contribute nicely to the idea of national leadership, because we value those lost people who died in these jungles, at the hands of tiny creatures like snakes.
But we’re also making the world less safe, by keeping terrorism (and increasingly, urbanization) on our soil.
We can’t let people get access to communications if they have no choice but to hide information from law enforcement.
And once again, our government is asking us to pay a price for our failure to condemn terrorism.
Just imagine what it would be like to know, under a prevailing economic market, that all of the government’s work, even if it’s entirely by my own mistake, will be in vain in some way for our national interests.
I don’t think we should be asking our citizens to die for the country that always seems ripe for a multi-national fundraising drive for the murder of the father of their children. And I don’t think we should be trying to become richer by letting the world rot forever for so many reasons.
Who knows if there are other things that are more important than having to beat the market?
']

Title: Nordic Prime Ministers: We are committed to protecting women's rights
Generation:
['The headquarters of what UN Women dubbed a "Green Revolution" was taken down on Monday afternoon.
The organizations representing more than 400 women and women in the wider Nordic region released a statement that said that the "Green Revolution" created more than 1.3 million new jobs in the Nordic countries during the second quarter of 2018, employing over 200,000 people.
It also showed that when the governments decide to defend female empowerment, it's because women's contribution to human rights is "incredibly high."
"A number of policies implemented by countries during the Green Revolution demonstrated that women’s rights were fully respected by the rest of the human community. This means that women’s progress to reach their full potential now, without penalising them economically, is still more important than ever," said Samantha Illuuskas, the Global Executive Director of Navigating Equality (NV).
NV was launched in October 2015 as an anti-racist, pro-women organization that focuses on women's rights and domestic violence.
The organization launched the Oslo Agreement, which committed to "protecting women's rights without regard to social or economic status", in September 2016, to strengthen it's role in protecting women's rights.
It helped drive peace and security in the Nordics and was instrumental in the movement for the end of gender and sexual violence that began on 6 November 1983.
“Women matter,” said Davita Valdars, the Director of the Millennium Development Goals Council. “Women are the future of the world."
']

Title: Netanyahu scrabbles his way to one of his biggest victories
Generation:
['Bethlehem, PA (CNN) — He has seized control of the Netanyahu-dominated Israeli Cabinet, but the Israeli Prime Minister doesn’t wield immense clout as Prime Minister.
Like most of the 78 ministers in the Cabinet, Benjamin Netanyahu has relied mostly on his top advisers and helpers to push his agenda in recent years.
The problem was a series of heart-rending court defeats, which pit Israel’s Jewish communities against their Arab counterparts in Jerusalem and Gaza, since the U.S. Army’s controversial Invictus Games.
Netanyahu’s refusal to let the army’s now-defunct Ramapo unit take the field, has drawn national ire and prompted protests by an estimated 200,000 Palestinians who have come to the forefront of demonstrations elsewhere.
He has even driven opposition parties to boycotts, especially of Arab diplomatic relationships, and even assigned his first-choice defense minister to push the unilateral action.
But his attempts to squash Arab protesters have been fairly successful, and he’s following up on key demands.
Israel granted “mandatory” visas to Palestinian journalists and artists as part of new immigration procedures, and he’s able to block military aid to the Arab states.
He also broadened Israeli law to force participation by the Arab leadership in an annual national referendum, just in case Netanyahu had little choice.
His decision to launch a boycott on Arab Israeli schools — in the hope that the Arab boycott would help Israel thrive politically and hand Palestinian development chances — is a win-win.
Even before his election, Netanyahu said Palestinian school students “should feel free to observe the traditions of an individual representative of the people of Palestine.”
In the Gaza Strip and north of the northern West Bank, he said, Palestinians who have lived in Israel for generations “should not dare to engage in acts that threaten and undermine the region’s unity.”
This time, the far-right far-left government overrode Israeli restrictions on the possibility of Palestinian peaceful demonstrations.
He said she was right to develop a policy that would give Palestinians “an extension and an opportunity to teach their children their way of life.”
In Lebanon, he promoted “the same message, but with a different rhythm,” with the tactic of lumping Lebanon with Palestinian villages.
This time, he asked Hezbollah, the Lebanon-based terrorist group whose arsenal Netanyahu sees as the primary threat to Israel, to boycott Lebanon’s federal elections.
While he’s all but caved to Arab demands for free elections, Palestinians seem resolute.
Though they won’t back down from any demands, the Arab camp is not ready to abandon them or change anything.
And they’re not at all surprised that Netanyahu will keep pushing an initiative.
“He believes it is necessary to bring his country into a state that is a unified and flexible, not a dictatorship,” said Nomaan Merchant, spokesman for the Palestinian factions Fatah and Hamas.
“All major institutions of the Palestinian state are recognized by Israel, not by Hezbollah,” she added.
With the most recent four-year Israeli-Palestinian peace plan by Israeli and Palestinian negotiators in place, the Palestinian flag would appear on the Beirut metro platform Tuesday evening, with the heart of the rest of Lebanon immediately behind it.
For its part, the Lebanese government stands ready to fight such a “nuclear-arms race” and “reunite Jerusalem with Beirut,” according to its Foreign Ministry spokesman.
“They will not only fight the physical battle to claim the first Palestinian State on the other side of the Jordan River, but they will fight to liberate Palestine from Israel,” Sinem Nadiayeh, the head of the political arm of Lebanon’s Communist Party, said at a press conference.
Follow CNN on Twitter: @nadamnach, CNN 360, CNN Travel channel, CNN Traffic channel, CNN Arabic, Facebook and Google+.
(c) 2019, CNN
']

Title: 90% of people are biased against women. That's the challenge we face
Generation:
["B.I.G. I quit working for my husband because he hated working women. All he wanted to do was work and get a good job. Without coming to terms with it, he didn't realize we both worked for peanuts. He said he would work where he could make it pay. No one was ever paid less than he did. No one was ever employed less than he did. No one was fired less than he did. Neither of us had a big career other than doing wrestling and movies. No one can tell if we wanted the same fate for us. No one can say we couldn't do the same. Neither of us could. We had two kids. One of them was diagnosed with a cancer. We started counseling each other. When that baby needed some insurance, one of us said she was better than my husband. In Colorado Springs, Colorado we broke up. The baby left the home with his grandparents. Before we made another public statement about him, he moved to Florida, which, because of the 50% Latino vote, would affect every family, including our own. He kept us afloat until she got the insurance. Then he left the baby with the grandparents.
So you should have been appalled by the investigation (which is especially painful, from a male perspective, given our demographic composition). For example, one would assume that we have 100% white momma-and-baby girls. They have had things happen before. Other women never had everything happen before. Everyone has different options. It should also be considered before you register to vote for us. We need to be cautious about taking on advertising campaigns not based on gender, so there are a lot of votes that could affect us.
But those are the main starting points. First is voting rights. Or citizenship.
First. The simple truth is that people are not good at voting. There are still millions of people who live in segregation. To lead the way, you have to have proof of citizenship, and identification, ID, or passports and possible citizenship. It is more problematic if you're Latino. If I make my landlord tell me that I am white and I'm in the closet I'm probably going to look horrible. What is the point of voting if everyone is black, brown, white, or Hispanic?
Second. Voting rights. Early voting. Voters could be deported. Voting rights should not be broken up by the few thousand people who somehow hold down jobs and homes.
The issues that have been shown to be out of control include race-based discrimination, pressure from ruling class power elites, corporate power culture, and poverty and addiction. In fact, 85% of Latinos who are illegally married into the U.S. have no legal right to vote, according to the Demos study. Those statistics should convince you of the need for change. No, we did not see this study, and we believe that we are dealing with a broken system, not a mania for change.
Now we hear from highly vulnerable minorities. If we're not careful, the majority of families who have been impacted by such violence will likely be the ones with the most needs. We can't stop them. We can't make these new families vulnerable, but we can make some changes that make them better. When you’re inside a household, you feel a sense of connectedness. You want to feel connected with people and you want to move in with them. When you get the opportunities, you move up in life. But you're changing relationships all over the place. A party is a lifestyle. You can’t kill yourself before you get married. You’re aging and this situation isn’t the prettiest place to be. You shouldn’t be. The people at fault aren’t voters. They’re wives, mothers, and wives of brothers and sisters. Racism is a disease, a truth. If you’re married, you should have a child as an adult. No one is exempt from racism. But we don’t want to raise children alone. We all contribute to the community. It’s time for change in our government.
"]

Title: Opinion: The real thing holding Africa's female entrepreneurs back
Generation:
['To any female entrepreneur seeking a career change, there are several key essential building blocks to success: You have to have a diverse background, you have your skills, you have the money to invest and you have the energy to do it all. That would be a prerequisite for anyone of any age to be here.
One of the barriers for women entrepreneurs is the level of discrimination and harassment that impact all gender stereotypes. Quite often these stereotypes go into "them," or "us" as that is often an official stereotype. Many women simply don't know what they are actually talking about. And this imposter is expected to cling back onto the "them" stereotypes. If nothing else, it takes some courage to pull back and try to get the conversation moving in a place where entrepreneurs don't get what they are trying to achieve.
But how has this impacted entrepreneurship in Africa?
According to a 2017 World Bank survey of women around the world (that was conducted by the state-run Global Expert Report Center at the International Centre for Women and Girls) women were the three times as likely as men to take ownership of businesses. In fact, four-fifths of African girls were of the view that "worldwide, women are less successful." Even the lack of economic opportunities and empowering equity rules around gender equality has changed this stance.
A 2015 study by the international partnership for Women and Girls at the University of Rochester also shows that more women are taking ownership of businesses in Nigeria than at any other time in the world over the past 20 years. Still, women make up a small fraction of all Fortune 500 companies, leaving a lot of room for success in any country, but there is clear evidence that Africa can lead by example in this regard.
The same is true in neighbouring Kenya, where women are more than twice as likely as men to own businesses and grow them by at least 50% by 2020. Girls and women more often than men are now doing business at a moment's notice, yet leaders tend to focus more on supporting girls in private sector enterprises.
So just as gender differences have a huge impact on leadership among business leaders, so have their contribution to the success of children and youth. Incredibly, despite the wide range of challenges, Africa has the highest concentration of female entrepreneurs. For example, only nine percent of African women say they are more likely to become "connected and successful" than those who are less connected, at 41% and 57%, respectively.
By contrast, more than 60% of African women say their "self-dealing" will be a significant factor in wealth creation for them over time. These women are encouraged to talk about this on their social media profiles; women have two senior roles, both on Twitter - an aide (in part) and a consultant; and they work in strategic sectors, including pharmaceutical, mobile and technology. Just as importantly, women are more inclined to use social media to publicly support or promote their children, or to ask questions about what goes on in their relationships with their partners or the surrounding community.
There are opportunities for female entrepreneurs in America, and they are mostly the ones who are fastest growing ones, almost all of them in those national wealth chains.
These women need every chance they can get to shape the future of small business and our continent and achieve a more inclusive society, but if we spend too much time focusing on economic disparities and discrimination and rarely grasp the commonalities that results from it, we risk stifling women's entrepreneurial dreams. To get even more women into management, we need to invest more in research and coaching to ensure that we get more girls to work in senior management positions, as well as pay better compensation.
These are all important areas to look for, but money talks. You have to be willing to roll your sleeves up and bite your nails. If you are going to take on the entrepreneurial challenges that everyone else is looking for, there are better ways to do it. But there is no reason we can't do it.
']

Title: Why the Louvre is closed
Generation:
["This week's opening of the Louvre world headquarters came after backlash from seven people including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, including the former head of France's own National Assembly.
The architect-confrontational tendency has not gone away, though. The battle between fans and critics
The Louvre isn't where crowds are going to go to the next great night of art that is inspired by history's greatest stars. A thick tapestry of 800-metre long passages has gladdened the cavernous cavernous city of Paris, and was used for its Musee des Arts et modernes (MoA).
What was the symbol of giant towers in the desert is now firmly planted over three gigantic runways, and the tallest structure in the world now sits half way in a complex way. Built decades ago, the ambitions of the Louvre project had never really left Paris.
In the era of the Lutfur Rahman museum, an exhibition for 30 years , and all the funds saved for building another museum, the €7 billion ($8.6 billion) project was meant to return to Lyon.
It made the most of best-seller lists that valued a few aspects of the Louvre, including:
· Four major guests from France, France, and its close partner in Europe, the Netherlands: where Macau is at its most successful to date, with more than $9 billion in foreign currency reserves, plus all of the gold the North Koreans enjoyed.
· One of the most well-known buildings in the museum: the Luteck Castle in Luxor. Located in the South Seine region, visitors can build houses in this castle, the tallest of its kind in the world, that houses fewer than 150 people.
· MoA, whose building has won numerous awards including the Cannes Film Festival and its other annual competition, the Paris International Festival of Arts.
· The Green and Freed. It has become known as The Green Statue, or Green Life of Paris (GBL) , and the first Green Line from Paris to Africa. The city is located in the Green Line (LGT) of Saigon, and then stands on an East Coast highway from Amsterdam to Chicago. The name itself can be confused with the Green Line by today's uses of the moniker and the plane's plane number.
The green world will continue to expand in the near future, beginning with the Louvre's archival collection of text books by Claude Monet and Juan Carlos Fresnadillo, which also celebrate Gaultier's life. The Louvre's first exhibit with the professor, La Geneveurs Van de Louvre Prie, was held in 1995 and will open in 1987.
The #Louvreopening vigil was organized by the P. F. P. Louvre Foundation (www.1ole.duptadamionet.org), a private, not-for-profit organization of public works organizations committed to running public facilities around the world.
The Louvre was only opened on Sunday. The rest of the works and the surroundings of the world are not yet ready.
The BBC Wales has a team of journalists handling this story.
"]

Title: NATO Secretary General: Why we're in Afghanistan and what a peace deal could do
Generation:
['British secretary of state for defence Mike Hammer unveiled the EU military mission to Afghanistan on Monday in Warsaw as it intensifies deployment there in preparation for an extended mission.
Hammer said the four-day mission would send troops into the country "to provide for the transition of security to an Afghan National Army and government, as well as training and health services" to train and equip local forces.
He warned that billions of dollars of cuts and fees imposed by the EU may effectively be waived and should not be seen as a "parity" between Britain and the United States.
"We won't give up on the goal of winning a deal between America and the EU, with America supporting and fighting alongside and having a role in Afghanistan," Hammer said.
"To reiterate, there is no agreement, no compromise, no loser on the ground. And there is no agreement, no bargain, not even a political or legal solution."
Bending the knife under the arms of the United States and the EU, the EU is pressing for Britain to take part in the long-term commitment of an operation in Afghanistan to transition to a government by 2025.
Hammer acknowledged that it is "really tough" for the US to become involved in the operation in Afghanistan and that Britain would have to "lose a lot of steam" if it wanted to take part.
British Prime Minister Theresa May called for a Brexit-style transition in Afghanistan to begin so that Britain could "be a part of the politics and the exercises of Europe and to help build a region that is a safe, secure and healthy place for the whole of humanity."
Hammer's speech at a Warsaw news conference came amid strong NATO support for the United States in Afghanistan.
"As NATO puts it, it is strategic if you will in world politics, its global clout is one reason for me to ask myself whether or not I can still be part of this ability, especially after 13 years in Afghanistan," Hammer said.
"But we have to make sure that as we prepare for a mission in Afghanistan, the United States and the British government do business with the Afghans, secure the stability of Afghanistan, welcome the people, come back home and help rebuild Iraq in the Iraqi way, that they stay focused on their common security tasks.
"To that end, we will look at the issue of American involvement in Afghanistan because we are convinced that this is the best way to ensure the security of Afghanistan and the stability of its people."
British Prime Minister Theresa May called for a Brexit-style transition in Afghanistan to begin so that Britain could "be a part of the politics and the exercises of Europe and to help build a region that is a safe, secure and healthy place for the whole of humanity."
Hammer expressed his deepest regret for Britain's way of handling the situation in Afghanistan, citing during Prime Minister Theresa May's visit that billions of pounds of cuts and fees were imposed on the local population as a result of the conflict.
Hammer said Britain would not be the only player in a deal for an operation in Afghanistan, but that it would "see the Taliban as a most important partner, that Afghan-led peace building in Afghanistan needs to happen, that our strategy for the withdrawal of foreign troops is bearing fruit."
Hammer said Britain did not want the troops for NATO's role in Afghanistan "under any circumstance."
He said British responsibility for the mission would rest with the government in Kabul.
"For the purpose of the mission, it cannot be just a single pound, it can be taken together with the government, the British government, the council of ministers and with the European Union," Hammer said.
He described the achievement of the mission as "absolutely remarkable" for NATO.
Hammer said the next phase of withdrawal would be followed by a phased redeployment.
He said it would be "very, very difficult," with 30,000 extra troops to be deployed in a phased deployment.

Title: Biden victories leave Sanders speechless
Generation:
['Sen. Bernie Sanders, D-Vt., delivered a general-election speech this week, and the Democratic nominee and his brother thanked him for his 2008 speech.
Speaking at the University of Vermont’s Convocation Center on Wednesday evening, Sen. Sanders, D-Vt., expressed his gratitude to Biden for accepting him as his “new friend,” and said, “I just want to say this was a great moment.”
Sanders, who has lived in Burlington since 1999, is a fierce critic of Hillary Clinton’s approach to combat global warming. He has amassed thousands of supporters since his 2008 campaign, and has been consistently a key player in Congress during the presidential campaigns of both parties.
At a campaign stop on Tuesday in Stowe, Vermont, Sen. Sanders told the crowd he “had a great start, but what I’ve learned is this is different.”
Sanders has tried to expand his voice and challenge the Democratic Party’s liberal groups that have sought to use him to win over more centrist members of the party base.
In his speech, the Vermont senator reminded the audience of his age, noting he is about 40 years old.
He expressed the fact that Democrats could not win a majority in Congress for a third term. He criticized Trump’s policies for stifling social progress and his focus on issues including health care and education. He called the four Democratic presidents under President Clinton for decades who set minority-party standards, and called for their successors to emulate them.
Sens. Chris Coons, D-Del., and Joe Manchin, D-W.Va., each — a trial lawyer for a district in the Northern Midwestern state — were honored with awards.
Sanders’ speech was laced with references to history, including several measures dating to John F. Kennedy’s presidency, including whether the United States was prepared to confront a Soviet threat or whether the fall of the Soviet Union was merely a smoke screen for U.S. independence.
In light of his Democratic Democratic presence in Congress, Sanders’s speeches — something the Vermont senator has done sparingly — may be smaller in tone than Biden’s.
']

Title: In coronavirus crisis, Tom Hanks is more of a role model than Donald Trump

['By Lauren Akunyili
WASHINGTON — Bill Clinton rode on a stool that resembled a phantasmagoric mist — his lips, his nose, his ears, his wide smile. Hanks walked away enviously nervous. Each face contained the drama of a dutiful offspring.
This experience took a day and a half off from exposure to the world and environment to Franklin D. Roosevelt. Unlike Trump, D. Roosevelt’s fellow New York Democrat, Richard Nixon, spoke aloud during a brief speech at his expense. But the impassioned speech remained an event. His message represented something to listen to.
That night, Hanks said a memorial plenary session of the World Press Foundation — a summit of editors and press freedom advocates — “was like a blockbuster” meeting. It was on, no, not Trump’s prom, but the president’s presidency and controversies around it.
During a 10-minute discussion of the reverberations, which Sanders supports in the Senate, the president refused to hold hands and sign a joint resolution to campaign for the death penalty.
As Obama died on June 8, 1970, Eli Manning ran toward him while watching the Oval Office. The former New York Giants running back couldn’t tell whether he was drowning or catching a falling shower. Manning avoided drowning by cowering, immobilized on the couch, a toothpick in his hand in a booth at a nearby meeting with Obama.
For months afterward, Trump laid before the reporter, sitting, like a colossus from outer space, watching the pram like son of the commander in chief. He took offense at Manning’s diary entry and told the reporters to avoid reading it.
In just the past decade, the outgoing president has conducted political functions for three diverse presidents, with both Democratic and Republican.
For its 20-minute session, the World Press Foundation, formerly known as the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, had to work with major news organizations — including the New York Times, Time and Washington Post — as well as at least four movie companies to pay to air the president’s remarks.
To its credit, the group, which first established in 2000, has held informal sessions in Washington and New York between 2006 and 2010 and has held three executive meetings since 2010.
However, Clinton — who at one point shied away from Trump’s words — got the gravitas that D. Roosevelt needed.
If there’s a major move, it is Clinton, who hired Bill Clinton to perform the gravity care that George H.W. Bush experienced on January 7, 1992: the inauguration of the nation’s first black president.
The argument comes down to constitutional issues, particularly on human rights and the media, said David Nunan, a distinguished professor of information policy at the University of Texas at Austin.

Title: Trump's speech won't erase his bumbling response on coronavirus

Tragedy-defying: Johnson relays Trump's extraordinary tactical skills

Trump went on to swear, about "unusual foreign policy decisions" like the US invasion of Syria and hold Iran accountable, for example.
And for his unpredictability, he allegedly said, about opinions on foreign policy within American society that Americans didn't share.
"You do not think the world is very calm," he said, "but if we want to know that, we need to know what's going on with people coming to the United States, buying groceries, hoping they're going to vote."
But the occupant of the Oval Office is no stranger to syntax traps. He's one of the most effective interpreters of unscripted stump speeches.
John G. Reilly/Reuters The self-assured President Trump seems to relish reminding voters of his sometimes-simplistic, sometimes-ignoring, nearly indecipherable style
His first real speech came in 2016, when he spoke with a mostly non-English accent. But the speech was nearly dead-on, said Yale professor Paul von Clausewitz.
"Well, the fact that his preparedness was flat and his speech execution was off," he told Axios.

Many observers felt this critical rollout would have been a major gift to Trump's base, but the post-debate controversy was not.

And it didn't help that President Obama, later saying that "that meant we were talking about the things he talked about that people liked," was hurt by the media coverage.
Why today?
Because such a contentious, back and forth is one thing. But words, as the other hand, simply don't get out of control. As Trump put it: "You cannot deal with the powers that be, because you have been president for years."
Moreover, Trump did emphasize America's "special relationship with Britain," an essential part of the US-British alliance, and the ongoing settlement of the South China Sea dispute.
But Clinton's experience in public engagement made that a weaker responsibility. So she filled it with heated verbal exchanges.

Title: Why Bernie Sanders struck out with black voters

['WASHINGTON (CNN) — South Carolina, South Dakota, Iowa, Nevada, Vermont, New Hampshire, North Carolina, West Virginia, Massachusetts, Kansas, Oklahoma, Kansas and West Virginia produced a bright future for America. Sanders piously argued his new health care bill would help African-Americans, but in its increasing efficiency, did not recognize the possible peril or intricacies of the Republican health care policy and could create an explosion of voter frustration. Just a month into 2016, Sanders held a victory party to mark “Breakfast with the New York Times.”

Yet by ignoring Sanders’ single clear choice as the solution to a health care system that couldn’t work, Democrats saw their sole potential in a black candidate for Congress. Sanders, not Trump, would be the leading reason for most people to pull the lever for a progressive health care overhaul.
His rise was the result of 9 million small communities, most of which have experienced stagnant employment or profound layoffs since the recession, yet he emerged from his policies, in black neighborhoods, with clear compassion for people with disabilities and low-income families, creating a window to crisis-riddled social systems. He has done so without compromising his conservative principles, with themes of openness and accountability from a position of privilege as well as freedom and civil rights.
Proud as the head of the most influential political dynasty in the world, Sanders’s bright future amounted to little more than a “single digit increase in our college students debt” as governor Clark Debicki was going for re-election. Moreover, Sanders had been seen as willing to pay fines for failing to respond to racial disparities in policies, experiments and resources so long as wealthy people could get affordable housing.
Three national studies in 2017 identified key structural factors pushing racial disparities in America from historically low levels to a state-by-state breakdown, revealing a concept close to original sources.
Donald Trump’s presidency and recent congressional gridlock over health care sparked the wave of tension in the South and South Carolina. Divided and divided communities and ideologies were edging toward outright economic populism. Sanders emerged as the clear party leader’s response.
Disgruntled black voters in black states continued their rebellious streak with Vermont; the Sandersian surge since the primaries left Democrats in squaring off against the reliably socially conservative challengers in states with high voting-age populations. South Carolina gained the Democratic presidential nomination for Sanders and senators close to him.
Democratic elites soon flooded into the Trump-purchased Midwest, joining him in canceling expensive tax cuts and establishing a government-shifting machine.
Post-election, the Democratic party began to divide the country. Even after winning over Latinos and other minorities, the Democratic Party was viewed by a majority of black voters as unenlightened, hostile to minorities and pro-life, progressive and progressive. Clinton surged ahead of Sanders with Hispanic voters — a demographic that shaped her as an African-American.
A year after Trump came to power, black voters licked the wounds of, and followed Sanders’ lead.
Like Democrats in 2016, Sanders will suffer the blow of losing his legacy. That failure will diminish his hopes of becoming president and trigger a little more widespread resentment. But as first-term Democrats gird themselves for their future, they will confront the dust, meted out more racially and culturally.

Title: Trump's coronavirus speech was a disaster

['By Sarah Leah Whitson, CNN Legal Affairs Staff Writer
President Donald Trump declared the upcoming Ebola epidemic pandemic "an epidemic I do not know about" when he delivered a national security address on Thursday.
He was introducing "America First," a Washington-based National Security Council speech about "our values" and explained where the U.S. stands with the World Health Organization (WHO).
"I think the hallmark of an effective response to this epidemic is the intent, the duration, the expectations, the remedies, and the partnership that we have in place that allows us to respond," he said.
"We can come together to be even stronger with our friends and allies as we grapple with this horrific and deadly threat," he added.
Trump started his speech by announcing that United States had pumped more than $16 million into drug eradication and primary prevention as an emergency measure in response to the outbreak.
The chemicals provided to the U.S. help fight the hemorrhagic fever, which makes it easier to transmit the virus to sick people.
Trump later held a gaggle of reporters together who were waiting for the president to discuss the threats facing the United States at the time.
']

A close congressional race between Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders is focusing on how to push their governing visions in the American public.
Monday night, Sanders, the senator from Vermont, announced that he is co-chairing the Democratic National Committee. Supporters of his effort to represent the biggest Democratic constituency in Washington know the same. And while Sanders isn't really a former presidential candidate, he is responsible for running most party policies.
To accomplish that, he's reintroduced a bill, filed by Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.), that would require the IRS to report any taxpayer information on all domestic tax returns -- be it from the government's website, such as the IRS Form 1099 or return filers' name or Social Security number.
The bill would apply to all personal income and use of funds from state and local sources.
Obama-era limits
Sanders, a self-described socialist, knows a lot about the campaign's impact on the nation's economy. The Democratic frontrunner's support has rocketed in his home state, where, aside from a handful of favored candidates, the primary this past February was a draw.
But so far this campaign has been overshadowed by the Affordable Care Act. Sanders has also brought one of his most prominent opponents, Vermont Sen. Jeff Merkley, to Washington to woo the country's congressional delegation.
At the top of the list of potential 2016 candidates is a supposed war hero, famed oceanographer Richard Nixon, but the Congressional Budget Office has said he did not make the cut.

'Democrat army' ready to back either candidate

Title: What we're missing about age and the presidency
Generation:
['The world has come a long way, a comeback from the rusting pantheon of insignificance that seemed to fail more often than any other world apart from the Great Depression. It's a story about the return of Americans who think, less than six months ago, that even Americans who thought they could both be mighty simpletons had a serious drug problem. Or at least that's how it started.
It's about the damage done to that "everything else" routine by the Republicans' tax-cut plan, which, without mentioning the more salient buzz surrounding the gobs of drama in this case, drew the broadest yawns of the century and a quarter-million words and an 800-pound beach ball of media scrutiny. And if you've got a question that readers can't bear to answer without at least one extra wrinkle, it is a question that presages a presidential election.
What if the nation is now as global a place as the United States, or the latest to join the Amazon forest of humankind, or the American college-age population of spangly-hipped teenage playboys in environs that Mark Twain rewrote from fake or offbeat love stories?
It's all quite profound. Maybe in general, we're feeling the proverbial cry from sadness. Maybe it's what they call a woe is me feeling? Who are these groupings, I don't know. Perhaps they're shouting about the powers-that-be in an emergency somehow tamped down, and ours, with its increasing ideological acumen, have a legitimate authority to carry it out. Maybe the parliamentarianry in Washington is just as indulgent.
Just what they're, you might say, are those things that we'll find out by getting busy, running or having any such thing happen, but it's a subject nobody wants to talk about or get carried away with. It's possible that middle- and high-schoolers from that working-class-low-income generation -- self-described Roman Catholics, Protestants, ahistorians, swank bloggers -- will answer that question together.
But they'll miss every single one. We'll still think that presidential candidates and other matters will never attend an afternoon Bible study together and remark on the standards of the flow of justice of our very system, or of the long, and never-to-be-repeated, truth of the Bible. And if that does happen, they'll be asking, ``What would Jesus do?''
You might pause and wonder what Joseph Smith accomplished during the last 17 months of his life. He created a brand of civilization that was, in fact, run by the apolitical people of all faith and all races. It's not like there's another Methodist in history, a revolutionary teacher, a family patriarch, a half-naked coal miner, a Democratic head of state.
So, according to the New Testament, that sacred law -- the Law of We We, as Paul used to say in 9) Timothy, and the Law of Mind, and the Law of Peace -- exists because a kind of bureaucracy exists that is somehow more heavily regulated by the press and executive agencies than by a church or a religious group. It is, if you'll forgive a fraction of the shouting and spitting from members of both parties, actually pretty ancient, and it all traces back to the arrival of our civil right to religious speech. And the law is what the latter set in motion when it came up for the legislative and presidential nominations in 2004.
When you hear John Milton speak with a brooding tone, it might seem as if he was sipping a bottle of wine or coals en route to a senatorial appointment. But Milton was right when he said that all political activity that takes place under this law would be meaningless without this law. But here's something else that he didn't say: There are currently many, many other things that don't require a strong political act.
And this is, apparently, what we've got.
And we're not really talking about the stuff you say the next time you like to claim to know, "That's me." For there are many things on which people take the media and the faith in stride. We're talking about these things that we don't really know about. There are many things to which we assume we are not part, and the lies we try to make about them that we just didn't know about.
That's what's happening to us, Mr. Trump. All we need to know is that we're tired of being told what to believe.
']

Title: Coronavirus shows up Trump's compassion deficit
Generation:
['By Lauren Trott and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva
WASHINGTON, April 5 (CNN) - Former President Ronald Reagan to Trump in 2017:We need to learn to be compassionate to people.
(Crosstalk)
Former President Ronald Reagan, who now works to raise awareness of malnourished people, lobbied President Trump's presidency for medical research funding when Reagan died two years ago.
Reagan urged the U.S. government to do whatever it could to prevent the spread of the virus that caused his passing.
The scientific debate over how to curb vaccine complications is growing more contentious.
Health officials say they can reduce the number of vaccine-preventable cases, reduce total deaths, increase access to treatment and cure for the disease.
But the substance of Reagan's critique was shared last year by medical journal the Lancet about vaccines. It was published under the title Ofpacing Healing America: A Global Summit on Vaccine Research.
That was the conclusion of new research done by the Nobel Prize-winning team that led that study.
Reagan concluded:
"A woman who creates her entire life that she gives birth to is like a blade of wood. She is, by definition, a blade cutter. These minutes of physiologic existance and a sentence or two of discipline they receive for practice and not build upon what they have encountered so far.
These minutes of enlightenment? The experience of a bariatrician who no longer had much to be ashamed of his success so he could shed the burden of failure, let a patient with obesity cope with the inadequacies of those who need his professional attention to the complexity of their life.
"Yes, we can develop vaccines that can reduce the risk of vaccination, but we also can include every human life."
That report documented how most vaccines are ineffective. And that reasoning was followed up by more than 500 recommendations by President Trump and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention as they worked to prevent vaccine complications.
Alongside his legacy of delivering on his commitments, the president told Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price that the U.S. needs a plan for stopping the spread of vaccine complications among young people and their families.
"I want children to reach maturity first, not age four," he said.
Reagan also pointed out:
"A disease like polio, an encephalitis vaccine (FIV) is not the cure we need right now, as the vaccine precludes the effective protection of MMR."
Ultimately, all Americans are to blame for this deadly health threat. And, it is often the administration of the state and federal governments that supports the vaccine response.
No one is to blame but individual communities, where different approaches are needed. Some will demand assistance. Others will say bad things should not come from Washington.
"This is not how government works. It will be a lot easier to build the infrastructure around it than it is today," said Representative Frank Wolf, a Pennsylvania Republican, in an interview last year with a group of former reporters at the USO in Minnesota.
"It all depends on what the state chooses to do with how these recommendations are framed."
But nothing has happened yet.
"It is too early to say whether we are making progress or a disaster," Wolf said.
"I have a responsibility to be here. I will be here with them for five minutes if I feel they need help."
Copyright 2019 by CNN NewSource. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
']

Title: Four women were serious candidates for president. What happened?
Generation:
['OMAHA, Neb. — They were Hillary Clinton and John Kasich, the two prospective Democrats running to succeed President Donald Trump.
Yet as a group, they were also poised to defeat an idea that was becoming — and still is — a high priority among those at the table to determine who will be the nominee.
The 2024 GOP presidential nomination, championed by Republican Rudy Giuliani, has one party and the entire nation. The other party — Barack Obama and President George W. Bush — are on the other side.
The notion of a second, third, fourth — taking a less consequential individual out of the election process — has become a little more complicated at times this year, with first-time candidate Carly Fiorina, conservative talk radio host Glenn Beck and rookie New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie all running the board.
So what was this Republican group? Who did they choose? What was their base? The vast plurality of Americans — roughly 60 percent — who had tuned in to see if they could unite, according to a 2016 Wall Street Journal-ABC poll conducted shortly after Trump’s upset win over the Democrat, Hillary Clinton.
Fiorina says she cannot see the day they’ll hand that responsibility to one another. That’s because the base cares about establishment politics — “it feeds into Republican bigotry and political cynicism,” she said, before adding that she’s not convinced Trump is sincere.
The people who had been thought to be leading the party are also Democrats, she said, and that’s why the party had its “spot on.” They are to be elected into an elite executive board, she said. And that’s why she, Christie and Obama didn’t end up being huge candidates; because they will never be given a run at their first thought, she said.
They may well not have reached that point until years later, when the national discourse begins to get a little more assertive. And they’ll have to grow up once the nominations are announced, assuming, of course, that the current president, Hillary Clinton, and Republican Paul Ryan are not contenders for the office at the time.
So what exactly has emerged?
There’s nothing surprising about GOP candidates, current and former campaign observers say. And it’s debatable whether the real-life successes of Trump and Clinton represented what’s needed for leadership — and what their next steps might be as candidates turn to the type of outsiders they once considered the weak link in their power relations.
Hobbs, for instance, noted that if he is one of the most popular left-wing politicians on Earth, he will probably be no closer to winning confirmation than the candidate who is there today.
Five other finalists — Bloomberg’s Carly Fiorina, former eBay CEO Meg Whitman, former Vermont Gov. Howard Dean of Dean University, Clemson University President Robert Woodruff, Florida governor Jeb Bush and Rep. Jim Greer of Indiana — have similar profiles. They are expected to gain help in winning interviews with a variety of media outlets this week, before president-elect Trump takes office.
In 2004, after the election, Gerald Ford reportedly said that he believed six different candidates were viable for the Republican nomination, regardless of how they received the nomination.
There has been a torrent of hope for third-party candidates in the wake of the president’s shock victory, according to some analysts. For the first time, Trump had signaled a willingness to use organized labor to help him with the conservative agenda. In December, the president publicly offered his top team of staffers to raise taxes to pay for infrastructure projects, among other policy proposals.
On Thursday, John Kasich told The New York Times that in the short term, he was worried that the primary race might not make sense to motivate more voters with a non-political focus, and more likely to only focus on what Trump has said. Yet every speaker at an event to encourage working class voters said that the Republican ticket would make a difference if the field remained focused on serious issues.

Title: I'm chronically ill, and this is what Congress can do to protect me
Generation:
['This version of Yvonne Fletcher’s full story is a great cover story by The Huffington Post, part 7 story, part 2 story, part 3 story, part 4 story and this is maybe my opinion. Here is a fact:
Congress must create a new set of standards and guidelines for assessing research findings and disease response, including the use of new information about the disease rather than analyzing existing sources. This set of standards will let researchers track new information, check medical literature, and set important other standards. In the modern era, the ease with which information is recorded by researchers has created new opportunities to investigate and identify new treatments and treatments for a wide range of diseases.
Likely Sen. Dianne Feinstein, D-Calif., says that this proposal is more “truthful” than the current multi-partisan bipartisan effort, because because “and this is precisely where the Congress should be heading.” But in truth, we must keep considering these claims before considering the results.
So, what do we do with the secret declarations made by senators representing states across the country to Congress? This is what two anonymous senators wrote about this week in a letters to their colleagues and other prominent people in the health industry:
– Until Congress brings these limitations to their own throats, industry-sponsored revisions to existing protections will likely be ignored.
– Although this is nothing new to either of the two groups (Paul & Zoll are working on one legislation), that concern is long-standing. Many politicians have gone so far as to outright deny the existence of this so-called biological consensus. Not only does our penchant for “truthful” statements decry the existence of “false” concerns, they implicitly admit to their fearmongering about “research”. Nothing is more upsetting to the American medical community than when a doctor’s medical career is called into question. To the extent that it is true, major health providers who are trying to make health care accessible and affordable will seek to pass off this concern as factual rather than a political issue.
– But that doesn’t make it so. And just because these common-sense changes don’t directly address scientific consensus, they raise a dangerous issue of legality. Moreover, Congress would be left with a choice to reconsider the science or reject outright a wide range of ways it uses scientific evidence to investigate the cause of diseases, something none of us in this case is suggesting.
To be clear, we are not suggesting that you can ignore the scientific evidence. We urge the health insurance companies to give their employees legal protection from taxpayer-funded insurance fraud —– through mandatory medical savings plans, a careful inspection of claims and rules for reporting health care fraud. So Congress would have two choices: ignore these sort of claims, endorse and maintain the myth that scientific evidence is built on pseudoscience or throw out the scientific consensus completely.
– But instead of voting with their paymasters, or passively congratulating future senators for doing what is right for the American medical community, business interests and the United States of America should make a case for the obvious: Government support for health research, rather than opposing unnecessary research.
– To spare the readers of this story the senseless “reparations” that this senators helped arrange. Because we didn’t know what they were talking about, we were mortified that the senators didn’t try to write our article. But we’ll be writing about it in the coming days.
']

Title: It would be a disaster for us to have to choose between Sanders and Trump
Generation:
['The remarkable video, which appears from a public-private organization called Project Revolver, recently hit a YouTube video within. It has been featured here at CNN, and here at Nextgov.
"McConnell and Trump are working to clean up the leaks. So: If the Democrats go insane over this, just imagine what's happening in the White House. If the president is distracted by impeachment threats against him and then somehow his toxic backdoor investigations continue, maybe he'll seek some type of solution. So: Or he might use executive orders to start the investigation and remove himself from office. Or he might throw everything he has at the movie industry, get thrown into a nasty firing squad and kick some $1.5 million away."
So: This is crazy. Imagine the anarchy happening to our government, which is starting to wake up and start to clean up?
Well, the plan for a bill called the "end to privilege" would take away the ability of certain types of individuals to have access to government funds, including inheritance and estate tax deductions. And that is without even addressing the fact that people don't actually receive any sort of compensation. Most potential beneficiaries will be primarily those whose interests are paramount, not those whose wishes are at risk. The individualizing of the privilege would only entice institutional money managers with their expertise and compassion to behave fiscally like "the canary in the coal mine." It would further take away critical checks, balances and trust — a fundamental American achievement, no matter who controls it.
The plan would take away the ability of other individuals to have their day in court or judge in private to declare who is more likely to make decisions about their affairs, and would leave the very people who are inherently less selfish who would be able to refuse to commit "chosen" roles in government. The idea of "trust" and "trusts" would also be made to conflict when you as a potential long-term participant say, "Don't treat me any differently today than I was earlier." There would be severe flaws to the system in which we currently operate, but a gigantic bundle of nooks and crannies in our government would be steadily open to the prancing monkeys in their orgasms, pulling the strings behind the curtain.
Well, Paul Ryan would be put to the test. CNN, et al. includes this clip as part of its guide to Republicans who must vote against McConnell and McConnell. It's worth sharing here.
Let's face it, the most people going to Congress are not the ones who are going to blink, ready to have their day in court. Paul Ryan would be outraged that his party would be taking on a special exemption for corporate greed, as a condition of his post-Senate confirmation, which his party wants (so he gets every politician he nominates). Inflated profits like this will hold public officials accountable, as does his preference for TIGER drug companies to "channel" with federal drug agencies like the DEA (which is what General Electric will do.) Ryan's bill will not go far enough to help keep millions of people from becoming abusers. Ryan is set to this week present a set of alternatives to the proposal that he might make to the public on his way out the door. They include controlling the other people's money in the name of trust, mandating the right to vote and requiring corporations to disclose more public information, and just about making the corporate and estate tax write off once and for all. In fact, they could at least postpone the lifting of the estate tax for a few years, and eliminate the corporate tax altogether — if needed. Then, imagine the windfall to be generated from these proposals, while at the same time allowing corporations to retain the possibility of receiving tax deductions for their investments. Only, after all, one wonders what the "benefit" they pay to the most powerful person in the government, and especially their children, would pay for the most pain, while allowing the people receiving their tax dollars to look after them all. Let's get rid of him.
I really hope we don't get caught up in this argument, because the end of entitlements as we know it will destroy the foundations of our civil society, and it's clear that as long as we remain distrustful of the Washington, D.C. establishment, they will continue. Paul Ryan and his constituents would rightly be outraged. But perhaps they'd just be able to sit there and enjoy a chuckle, please. Paul Ryan is available to micromanage Congress as we like, unless he so egregiously blocks the legislative branch.
']

Title: The Super Tuesday no one predicted a week ago
Generation:
['With only two days remaining before the GOP primaries, President Donald Trump and Democratic challengers and independent voters were salivating at the prospect of raising money to help their campaign.
But it was just the start of the day, as Trump accused Sanders’s Democratic opponent of trying to “turn our country into a socialist country” and called in his own candidate, Wisconsin’s Paul Ryan, to take a shot at him.
The latest set of developments wasn’t pleasant for the White House, which was in town to help Sanders launch his own ticket.
At various stages of his effort, Obama himself rallied supporters to a rally in Pennsylvania, where Obama told the crowd his divided country was “trying to turn our country into socialism.”
CNN’s Maureen Dowd reported in an article published Monday that Obama had claimed that Sanders “can hold a major key to determining what a new country of America can look like.”
By that, Dowd meant Sanders.
If the allegation proves to be true, it would be by far the most consequential piece of evidence of the primary season that went wrong this week, CNN’s Trump claim or any other.
As the long weekend nears, these developments are becoming increasingly important for undecided voters, given the critical implications for the winner in a far-off presidential primary.
The popular Democratic Party primary gives the presumptive Republican nominee a chance to offer a bold pivot against the Republican frontrunner.
During the 2012 campaign, Romney lost to President Obama by 16 percentage points. What could we glean from this situation?
This was not a Trump candidacy, but a Republican contest that had become about as close as the Republican race can get, in terms of demographics.
In 2012, in the House and Senate primaries, the Republican contenders appeared to be a coalition of Republicans and Democrats, a diverse coalition.
They were not the kind of coalition of Republicans and Democrats that would carry the party to a major victory in the midterm elections.
At the time, Obama and his team wanted to block a Bernie Sanders-led ticket from being established. And they weren’t about to let Trump become their nominee.
But Sanders on Tuesday said the election is also being “the result of a brand war.”
“He said he was going to win in Michigan,” Sanders said of Trump. “He said he was going to win in Wisconsin,” Sanders said of Trump. “What he said at the time is it’s not about whether or not a Democrat wins the election,” Sanders said.
In all likelihood, Trump and his opponents are entirely aligned, at least a little, with the nominee. Trump is going to win the Republican nomination, the New York Times said.
And Sanders isn’t the only one in the race. And the core of that race isn’t among Republicans.
Liberal Democrats will likely be resistant to Sanders, said Robert Killeen, a law professor at Rice University and former executive director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform.
“He’s an enormously popular guy, not so much politically aligned with what the Democratic Party stands for,” Killeen said. “But Sanders is too obviously big for that party.”
Clinton has never had a campaign like this, to the extent that she has been able to distract voters from her own unpopularity within the party.
By suggesting Sanders will beat Trump in a state with a sizable Democratic electorate, Clinton himself is saying that somehow she and Trump won’t work together.
Sanders could appear that way, if his campaign is a show of fiscal restraint while bending to popular pressure from Republicans. Trump has spent years trying to shift control of the Democratic Party away from the Republicans. And his own handlers have toned down their style, pulling left and center in a move that has energized centrist Democratic voters and the Democratic Party.
Those who favor smaller government or greater freedom are predisposed to support Clinton, according to the most recent surveys. Sanders has repeatedly said that he and Trump could form a coalition of alliances to accomplish certain goals.
Still, the election could yield a unique opportunity to sway the electorate in a more compromising direction.
']

Title: Black voters know the only thing that matters
Generation:
['A study by the nonpartisan Pew Research Center says 34.2% of black voters are black, compared to 31.5% of white voters. That’s a remarkable disparity for a state that holds just 23 electoral votes and is averaging around 40 electoral votes over the past century. So where does that lead us?
“It doesn’t surprise me. I wouldn’t call it surprising, but it certainly gives you a very strong sense of feeling and calling,” says Brokaw, who played basketball with Cheney in the 80s. “You look at Pennsylvania and Florida for instance and think about voter turnout and everything else… What could possibly go wrong?”
That may seem like a pipe dream, but Professor Kowalberg doesn’t see anything like it coming from middle-of-the-road voters in the GOP. “Well, the Iowa voting averages out,” he says. “Maybe a few others… but somewhere around the 26% of white voters say they don’t vote. These were pretty common.”
Whoa, that’s a lot of people out there. Those numbers (a handful) don’t seem all that surprising – why is this a big deal when one group is responsible for the majority of demographic change in a state like Iowa, with an average of nearly 65% of its voters reporting no current Democrat or Republican in the last few years?
Pew puts it this way: 43.8% of Republican voters in Iowa went to the polls in 2016, putting them in great position for an eventual statewide contest. Then there’s Gary Burtless, the presumptive Republican nominee in Iowa who beat Democrat Chuck Grassley, 58-39, for the Senate in 2014 and added another 1.2 million votes to the caucus. The rest of the country’s electorate does the same.
The “other,” folks just from Iowa, that’s the other five states that haven’t managed to maintain the double-digit gains Obama achieved in 2008. He won on the red and blue lines in 2008 by 36 points, but within these five states his margin fell below 20 points – a loss that created significant resentment for Republicans.
That’s actually the case in South Carolina, where Joni Ernst’s formidable 8-point lead over Rand Paul fell away due to new data from a new poll from the conservative conservative Southern Institute. And the race for governor of Massachusetts is in serious jeopardy: although not super-safe, the presumptive Republican nominee is far from the worst: polls give him a 2.5% lead, and he trails Obama by 8 points.
Still, there’s something to be said for the diversity of opinions in Iowa, even if we simply interpret that poll results to indicate a loosening of the racial nature of the population.
“If you want to be clear and satisfying on how you’re affecting the electorate, you have to embrace very diverse demographics,” says Brokaw. “And I think that’s one of the things that has been more of a challenge than any other piece of the puzzle.”
But he makes good points in his comparison of battleground states. Iowa, Nevada, New Hampshire, South Carolina, Wisconsin, Oregon, and Massachusetts all have historical gains of at least 20 electoral votes – a pretty large sum of support for a candidate on any given map. The success of the Democrats in states like Colorado and North Carolina, say, comes down to a much more predictable ability to control demographics, such as demographics in the Midwest, South, and Appalachia.
Whether that means that Iowa does have the second-fastest growing racial electorate in a major population group, or that some of the country’s rural areas – left mostly by professionals – somehow lag behind, Brokaw is certain that Iowa will win its first major presidential race.
“If you have to deal with a white population in a very rural state like Iowa, then that won’t be an issue,” he says. “In fact, they’re pretty young, and all of a sudden they’re in control. I think that’s a pretty interesting phenomenon, because it appears it’s still changing.”
']

Title: Warren Buffett has the right answer to crony capitalism: women (opinion)
