One has to imagine some sort of logic in the audience’s reaction to the idea of funding female scientists who are actively on behalf of the government because they want a little piece of why capitalism works.
“Put something in the price of a company, and it is highly profitable,” the article quoted Buffett. But more often than not, a company must sell in order to receive a profit.
In other words, if women CEOs had to work more to their benefit, there would be less competition. That is the premise behind some of the biggest paid media industries today. But as Buffett pointed out, just because your CEO pays less than your “golden cows” does not mean that her employees are.
“And she really would be more effective with fewer new hires if the company was simultaneously reopening” an intellectual minefield which the American economy and business talk about.
No, those press pundits are just understating the absurd scale of the problem.
On the surface, women now make up 90% of the nation’s entrepreneurs, and they provide an incredible amount of profits, the typical CEO pays a whopping 15,000 people 1.5 times the average salary of women. The pay gap is predicted to widen more than a trillion dollars by 2040 if women don’t find opportunities to partner or invest with their friends.
The simple way out of this inequality seems to be to move from an industry as creative and exciting as Facebook to an ever-changing class of businesses: education, careers, work, family, and anything else that’s at hand.

Whatever your reasons for wanting business to move forward, make sure your company has women in mind for its future expansion. Already they’re tackling issues like military academies and the over-reliance on minorities in major fields like manufacturing, transportation, and construction.
Also, introduce the technology sector to the kind of people who would dare to put money where their mouth is, leading to the arrival of robots, pipelines, broadband networks, and other labor-saving ideas that can fill a decade’s worth of jobs.
The whole purpose of the Dodd-Frank financial reform system is to make sure people aren’t trapped in the corridors of power.
This article was written by my partner at Jeffs & Sidell, who is an investor in the world of marketplaces and invests in the best value companies.

Title: The way we talk about coronavirus matters
Generation:
['By Lisa Respers France
You know it’s the “after” moment when you’re up with your ex and wonder if she was “talking” because some vague thought somehow has put you in an emotional state? And then you discover, like the former social media user here, she took the time to fight back, publicly hammering her old boss off of Facebook. People don’t understand what kind of chaos there can be online or what it’s like to move forward because of the “fanati.”
Mixed in there is the tendency to smack people off the ledge of social networks by excoriating them for perceived ill will, and the quick — and tempting — turn away the object of their scorn at all costs.
On the surface, the one thing we’ve learned, in surveys carried out by CNN, is that as long as we can’t escape the healthy sense of social media balance — that when we want our updates, tweets, and most importantly Instagram postings to be easily shared safely, as opposed to constantly updating them with what we decide were misleading information, we may as well crack open a bottle and cuddle up to each other.
But that doesn’t mean we’re all reliant on our personal and personal interests to stay in the best light.
It’s easy to be happy online. We have a lot of photos of our kids, vacation photos, and, for several weeks, we have a lot of feeling of so much fun back-to-back and so many ways we can mingle with one another.
Even while we’re distracted and gossipy, an ill-defined “social media friendly” reality can have other messages that cause you to be an even more fickle customer.
Everyone would much rather have “real” social media likes and connections and have the occasional pool of Facebook friends.
So many people are searching for their first real contact, but we can always turn to filters to get past these red flags or dispel gossip.
Yes, we know when we’re missing that feeling of “outside the mainstream” — we have our website, we love to be photographed, we’re happy to be given a free event and we work insanely hard to tell our kids how we feel.
But, does that really mean “social media friendly” is everything that we need to have or should be?
Many people feel they need to gain access to these functions. They wish they could do that, but honestly, it depends on how far they try. We get so used to social media interactions that we do a constant spin on where to go and what to do in general, but what if they’re lonely? What if they’re lonely? How should they stay from being captured by other people?
Social media strategy never goes entirely wrong. In an ideal world, we would want to continuously be safe, but if we were to inadvertently create social media friendships with strangers, we’d be fighting away from each other.
Everyone has a different perspective when it comes to giving up their selfie, sharing their dog, or engaging in social media chat. It’s tricky to let go of that aggression, but I’d give it one hell of a try.
']

Title: If my campus closes down, my job could go with it

I usually check my homework at 11 in the morning. Now, it’s 10 on the morning of April 5. I usually check it out. Sometimes I wake up at 2 a.m. to watch television or hear whatever music they’re going to come up with a night before until 1 a.m. (as if from left field) so that I have two chances to copy and practice something. This is not always my best day. Sometimes I’ll check out of the office in the morning before sunrise, and that usually leaves me just staring at my computer screen with a blackening spot where my fingers begin to wilt.
Whenever this happens, I grab my phone and hang up. I scroll around until midnight and catch up to what my mom says: “The post-graduation nap is about one hour before we have to do this forever!”
It’s strange when I get out of the house and I can’t see an emergency cellphone in my hand. But I catch up with my friends at 10 a.m. I don’t need to at night, and I don’t need to ever check my email for all the stuff on the phone. So I take the day off. Then when I woke up I could barely figure out what I was doing for five minutes with this mess of articles about getting it right in my head. I worry that someone will screw up my account, or that things will get automated and we will all be people exposed to a lot of nasty behavior.
Now that all the electronic circuit boards have gone into effect in all schools, I take up something fun for the kids, like sculpting, spinning and dog-and-chip puppets. I’m going to see an installation tomorrow called “The Fountains of Fountains.”
I know how much I love watching these things, it’s the biggest thrill I get getting to watch them. How long can I let them do this? How long can they take to learn? Are they going to use some kind of language when you ask them to use the words “stuff”? Are they going to make slimeballs to destroy the steel box that will come out of this thing?
This book in which I talk with my friends about the travelogues has helped me learn some basic footnotes, what they might be turning up their noses at before it actually happens. This shows that the constant lag between lectures and homework has taught me some basic skills in the sub-dialectical realm that I am still learning today. It also seems that while it might have been some new fun once I have completed my 10 on the morning of April 5, learning to correct spelling mistakes and explain media bills can be a little more tedious. This is certainly not my first semester to try this theory of civics. I just did it once.

Title: The popularity of 'Love Is Blind' reveals what we're missing in our lives
Generation:
['Dear friend: Dear friend, I just want to help the gay community. I have to tell you that I live in Chicago and … too many friends all over America think that we are condemned to be captives to far-flung ideas that on one level meet social conventions.
Well, apparently so. According to the latest edition of American Psycho magazine, which just made up a cover story for HBO's upcoming sex horror series that is set to premiere later this year, 'Love Is Blind' is their annual phenomenon.
We want to thank God for telling us this. We also want to thank you, the magazine, for revealing what makes the gay community so captivating and endearing to the world. Because, this is why, in the aftermath of the sexual harassment scandal that roiled Hollywood this spring, the only thing left for the LGBTQ community to do was rise up and hit the reset button with its members.
The magazine details exactly how they got this treatment and what they did to improve the situation. Apparently, Charlie Huston, legendary writer and producer, began the fight by talking about the subject in no uncertain terms in the first paragraph of the magazine article. Among the revelations included Huston's use of "fake," "fake-or-offend," "le" and "silent" pronouns, thereby allowing homosexuality to be referred to and improving the situation. In his inimitable wisdom, writer Huston, unafraid to use any form of non-conformist language, suggested that gay men should be openly confronted with the truths of their sexual orientation, including conceiving of a child with someone else.
During the article, Huston explained why he chose to use the word "faggot" with pride. He explains: "If I've had my day in courts, I know that speech matters a lot for people in their own state of mind. And obviously you can speak of being homosexual, but that doesn't matter because they are destroying you, because they are destroying your future."
Huston also argued in response to the responses of various community members, including his own political views, that there were men in the gay community who were looking out for their own homes and were erecting homes to be filled with gay men.
Quite an effort and largely directed at the entertainment industry, the AIDS crisis was particularly significant in the context of gay rights. In his piece about the struggles against the AIDS virus, Huston suggested that it was all because Hollywood, instead of their 'bunny vibes' promoting issues, was engaged in a glorification of a largely marginalized community on the gay/lesbian/bi/LGBT space.
The presence of such a dishonest white, free-wheeling media climate in light of Hollywood's insistence to protect its own homo sapiens by challenging the 'bunny vibes' is quite damning. For Huston, gay and transgender people - who the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation is protesting as being "hostile" to the "bunny vibes" - are well aware of the problems and this is why they reacted so ferociously. And therein lies the problem with the gay community. Because, the gay community is not surrounded by a white, free-wheeling media environment.
Huston's article, while detailing the challenges faced by its members, is meant to illustrate the fact that sexual exploitation is not only a problem affecting heterosexuals, it is even affecting gay people.
The story also makes clear that the bottom line is that the gay community has been marginalised, neglected and demonised by Hollywood which in turn has driven the gay community to take its own destinies. Because such divisive language of lust and violation have done nothing to uplift the trans community or women; instead they have been used as scapegoats which unfortunately attempt to manipulate the LGBT community into believing that things are not easy for them.
While it is entirely acceptable that gay people can be critically held and embattled by the BGLA-operated media which is patronising, this kind of pseudo-pleasure only creates a fantasy space for hostile outsiders who want to protect the "s***s" from themselves, or any other group of individuals who has little to lose by resorting to such extreme language.
This is a world where homophobia is defined by its perpetuation. And it's precisely this really sad kind of group that is able to justify and subvert its form of intolerance to what it perceives as opportunity.
Thank God for the success that you have had with 'Love Is Blind'.
']

Title: Working from home is a lifesaver -- and a big danger

['By Richard Burpo, editor, Barstool

Most employees, on the other hand, would all like to be able to work from home. They are 28% more productive and 29% more likely to score in the social category, compared to only when they’re working directly from home. Only when they’re simply sitting up straight.
Despite a good deal of research and extensive analysis that points out the risks, your working from home is still frighteningly high: According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, one in five American adults can also be stuck in an office setting because of work-life balance issues. More research is needed, but a fix could make it easier for workers to find a job and instead stay at home.
Where is my work?
I’m in the unenviable position of working from home, and it’s a shame: It’s hard to stay away from coworkers and families, as all workers do, and when going home is a breeze.
Unfortunately, it can be a real threat, and if you have to do it at home, you might be one of the few people who do get to re-establish independence.
It’s a good idea to do your homework, do your own routine, measure up in your work-life life and make it easier to share with your children and friends.

The virus A is an antigen that has been used in a variety of products, like droppings for homeless dogs, lawnmowers and skiing equipment.
Clostridium difficile can thrive for about three years, and how long does that stretch? By our estimates, over three years.
In their book “Guiding Cybersecurity : Two Ways to assess and Protect against Clostridium difficile,” research team leader Anil Patel, an infectious disease specialist at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, offers three key ways to fight the virus:
Diagnostic is a tool, but it is only a limited tool. It is important to monitor the virus’s activity to make sure it’s tracking the vaccine efficacy for vaccine candidates. In the next step, Patel and his colleagues applied the same search to identifying new genetic codes for protein groups in how the virus types can evolve. “If we can isolate the protein groups and improve on them, then we can continue to test new strains. We can use this to find gene mutation-lovers. Our interpretation of this may also enable us to recreate genetic changes in other groups of viruses in an environment that offers better immunity,” says Patel.
Early detection helps
The team developed the SIMON1 laboratory device, which aggregates two layers of a virus group measuring a visitor’s blood, the germ line, and the threshold for testing the symptoms. The two layers are then scanned by an infrared camera, keeping in view the virus’s presence and then counting the Ebola virus as it moves between the two layers. It has developed a way to determine precisely the virus within each case, thanks to its camorbatic properties.
Alarmingly, one of the team’s findings was that one of the seven strains whose virus-fighting test had emerged 20 days earlier in the virus lineage, was five times more potent than Clostridium difficile. And it’s likely much more effective.
To prevent illness, the researchers also wanted to collect the viruses using ECG scanning and lung CT scans. This allows them to conduct a pilot study to determine whether each other in the sample will suffer severe allergic reaction if they are exposed to Clostridium difficile.
The way to beat the virus
It’s also important to understand why the flu virus is so effective against Clostridium difficile. Adverse reactions such as the viral diarrhoea and vomiting, often caused by the germ, can kill an even more innocent viral strain of Clostridium difficile, “because Clostridium in itself is linked to drug toxicity,” says Patel.
“The influenza pandemic of 1918 ultimately caused thousands of deaths from disease caused by Clostridium difficile (clostridium difficile) in what would have been estimated to be a serious public health emergency,” Patel adds. “Now it’s showing that we should be looking at doing even more urgently and thoroughly.”

['SAN JOSE, Calif. - Jerry Sandusky was finally forced to speak out recently after 13 years of being "slaughtered" by child sex abuse.

But another line is coming out now:
"If you don't want to get involved, make a deal. There are all kinds of ways you can do that to get a deal."
That means it's not just money -- the Boys & Girls Clubs are to play a primary role as well. They're also to provide the group, students and staff with educational opportunities, potrinding exhibitions and conference nights.
They also want to do more with those still there, like graduating senior Katherine Smith with a "deep perspective."
"She knows what she's put in and it's good to see her smile and how she'll make her parents proud," said Scott Sallanz, communications director of the Boys & Girls Clubs of San Jose.
Cheryl Frost is still up and running at the Boys & Girls Clubs of San Jose. The 24-year-old teacher spent the past three years getting a foothold in her role. Now she runs Sunday School for No Strings Attached. She said her school is a brand with "so many little things that really kick off a young person's journey."
"You just have to have hope," Frost said. "Think about kids who have lost an opportunity and kids that have never had a chance to experience something. This is proof."
The Boys & Girls Clubs' new life as a nonprofit organization in 2012 got off to a tough start as 70% of its youth are under 15 and the percentage of ages 50 to 64 declined, according to a study by Stanford Law School.
But according to Scott Sallanz, the Boys & Girls Clubs of San Jose have found success and momentum with many younger members, including 13-year-old Mitchel Bailey, who works part-time as a counselor.
"The children that are new to the program have seen first hand all the best friends they've had on the playground," Sallanz said. "And not to stereotype, but they know that they've put the pieces together and something good is going to happen."
Justin Ross said he's watching his daughter on Saturday with a special message.
"She needs this," Ross said. "I promise her my job is to go in there and find a solution. We've got a lot of work to do on this one."
Ross said the Boys & Girls Clubs of San Jose have updated their Web site to reflect the changes.
"It's a better place," Ross said. "The little things like this are going to change. And if you want to have a career, just be with kids like yourself."
']

MEMPHIS, Tenn. — The community of Memorial of the Annapolis Valley on Sunday morning, February 21, 2019, came together to pay tribute to one of the most courageous and successful women in the world.
Amie Harwick, of Columbia, Tennessee, was slain by three men, whom she worked with and befriended over the course of more than 30 years in her career.
“This is the most tragic and the most heartbreaking,” Mayor Sharon Chapman said in a news release. “Her memory has far exceeded that of any other event we would rather forget. She was such a talented woman, whose death affects so many of us, from colleagues to students, from community members to donors.”
The community responded to the news by asking those who knew the Harwick family to “give back to the little children in our community.”
Stories like this one will be constantly present.
It all starts with “you tell me I loved you and I’ll tell you I loved you,” Harwick’s sister Aileen Hutchings said in an interview with CNN affiliate WKRN.
“I will never forget when she walked into my office in town and her chin got up and she’s got my hand down and she brought my teeth out of their teeth. ‘Mr. Harwick,’ she said.”
“It’s true. We’re just standing there feeling upset. She was good-looking and she knew everybody well, and she knew what to say and didn’t need to say anything.”
Hutchings said Harwick’s family, together with others, have been lending their voice to public service.
“Just yesterday we went to the funeral, and someone at the funeral said they have people from the community coming, and they’re doing a lot of service from the community,” she said. “We’re talking about the people on the street that would be the same regardless of who is doing what.”
While Harwick’s death is a tragic and tragic incident, it still resonates, especially to the community of Columbia.
“I would hope and pray that the angels (are) not sending anybody who happened to be in this area — and especially in the Circuit Court house — into a murder,” Hutchings said. “That’s something she’s dedicated to every day and so many other ladies and family members who love her are hurting right now.”
The Virginia City Police Department, who investigated Harwick’s death as a homicide, said in a press release: “We have received media reports from around the globe and news organizations that depict a double murder involving multiple individuals in central Virginia, occurring in either downtown Columbia or within south Petersburg, North Petersburg, Robert Wood Johnson, Frederick Miller and Virginia City.”
That in addition to deliberate vandalism, “circumstances clearly suggest that this individual could have murdered those involved in the murder,” the release said.
The assailants were identified as Robert and Christina Brown and arrested on August 1st, 2017. They are listed as a suspect in the assault on Thursday, February 23rd, 2018.
Harwick was legally blind in one eye after a laser followed her for several days.

Title: I was raped and broken. So I picked up my camera

['When I was growing up in Alexandria, Virginia, no matter what my mother told me that I was too thin to be abused anymore, I never felt that way, and my friend, who was also pregnant at the time, never reported it to police. While I was only a child of 8 years old, my mom constantly spoke of my innocence, reminding me of the five of us in trouble. My mom had mentioned that the land where we lived was under sanctions against her for having poor eyesight and, so, my mother convinced my dad to do the same. In the midst of the abstinence campaign, my best friend teased me when I was younger, teasing and teasing her throughout her entire life. When I was ten years old, she wanted to push me out of my home state for fighting with her boyfriend. She was always joking around and told me to keep my mouth shut. I followed her advice when I was five years old.
My mother often told me what was really going on with me: “Pick a fight in class, bitch.” In return, I’d promise I would just make my boyfriend happy, but that didn’t last long. I once called her (mostly with a pretty smile) a “crazy bitch.” Whenever I showed up on stage, I pretended I wasn’t in trouble and said that I was treated like that too. I didn’t tell her about that, just the show that I was performing and she was thrilled with me. And when that one made the news, my mom knew what it was like to be in a room full of girls. I’d been there many times and planned on waiting until they started filming so that I could escape, but by then my mom was terrified, mostly because she knew I was probably being abused. That seemed impossible to stop.
When my mother came home, even though she knew that I was a difficult and vulnerable person, I was probably too emotionally unstable to say anything about it. By that time, she would finally direct me toward something constructive: contacting the police. I decided I’d try my best to avoid the police altogether. I honestly was surprised that they still treated me like a child at all, when I was a child and somewhat vulnerable as a child. It turns out that if I ever told anyone I was going to do anything wrong, they’d be so much more likely to lash out than help me. I went on to have a good relationship with them and each time, they’d treat me like a person. My mother never told me that I was reaching for the “toys” in the toys she was making with my hands. She always addressed me as “normal” and tried to scare me away from them. Even though I had a strong sexual desire, she tried to help me. I always shared her feelings (like I wanted to be a girl) so I wouldn’t be seen as insecure as her. I never got the attention she wanted me to get. It hurt so bad that I never gave her another compliment to call her a “y” (that’s like “kookaa hoon”), but I did express my discomfort to her over time. I learned to say things like, “If you hate me, then you hate me,” and “I’m not my own worst enemy.”
The fear that I went to such a mental hospital to deal with that I shouldn’t be allowed to represent myself to a relative, like the man who abused me when I was little and wanted me to be nothing like him (and he was already a beautiful son). I wanted to be called “Aye” or “justa peja” or my mom simply as that. I had to climb into that room in awe of that experience.
Ironically, all those years later, my mother is now cancer free, and I’m so glad she survived.
']

['When I served as the legislative director for the Iowa Republican Party, I started noticing, up to then, quite a few people on the right, some of them coming to me, to say things like “We want to be looked at more respectfully.” People, they were marching, and they would start with things like, “President Trump and House Republicans are being too divisive with one another,” or “It’s time to open the floodgates and give the moderates in Congress more options.” As when I explained to Senator Young something like “We do think (he) ought to look at ways to get conservatives to the table for conservative compromises.”
But I also noticed that a little bit, knowing folks I didn’t know. And I also noticed some “Instincters” I knew. A few of them who told me, for example, about the failed Romney-Ryan arrangement during the Republican primaries, and other candidates. When I asked for opinions, then-GOP primary voters said, “She’s gross.” I mean, was it mean? Was she mean? Didn’t he kiss her kiss a lot before the primary? He’s just not good at what we do.
The truth is, a lot of these people, a lot of them, coming from high-pressure lists of who they know, high-powered people like me, come from pretty high places. They know how to run their own companies. They know how to get their own bank accounts. They know how to run a business. They know how to run their company as a husband and father. And they’re just excited about being looked at more respectfully.
I think that that’s what’s most important here. Not having anybody standing up against Trump, when he is praising or vilifying a Republican running for president who openly peddles his theories that minorities make up this country’s poor, with his calls for closing the borders to illegal immigrants and not hurting families, and more. That’s what’s more important here than a team trying to do this kind of foolishness, on a very short notice. They’re ready to use their leverage, and they’re not going to hesitate.
These folks are ready. They’re part of a bipartisan group here. They’re serious. And they’re so good at it they’re willing to overlook the flaws of their own party.
The issues they want to deal with, even though they might get one or two votes (to be more likely than Republicans) to do it, are vastly different. They want to fix the problems. They’re not going to trade ideas for the most unpopular ideas. They want their ideas to change in a genuine way, to bring the American people into line, rather than fragmenting the party and wrecking every congressional re-election in the country for a single week.
So, in the years ahead, I think they’ll start talking about things like, “We want to be looked at more respectfully.” I think they’ll start thinking, “It’s time to open the floodgates and give the moderates more options.”
']

That is a bill that would only benefit the very rich! What is wrong with these policies? These are not a demeaning message to someone that doesn’t want us to pay for his policies!
It’s now their job to replace him as president with John Kasich, and that could cost us up to $500 billion a year!
To keep things running smoothly, Trump and Kasich have had a major skirmish that brought them closer together as they represent Ohio. Kasich holds the seat of office on Ohio’s 4th Congressional District and Kasich represents Florida’s 2nd Congressional District.
Trump has never really been a partisan in Ohio. He runs on the right, cares about working people, and enjoys winning so badly with the support of the many minorities, Native Americans, women, LGBTQ people, veterans, immigrants, immigrants to the U.S. from other countries, and people of color! He wears his heart on his sleeve and so has always been a winner.
The best thing he ever did was the tax cuts and make the American dream even easier to find. Donald Trump loved that. He is an unbelievably capable candidate to lead us down a path of economic growth and prosperity!
Make no mistake, the damage has already been done to our national debt and our kids’ future will be devastating. The president is also the Democrat with the most popular celebrity in America – if all goes according to plan!
The lesson learned by Washington is this: Having a national consensus to prevent a crisis now could cause another crisis in the future. I love this country because it has a national consensus. But even if our country’s leadership demands a radical spending spree, I believe it is perfectly reasonable to ask the federal debt to be cut dramatically.
Americans are resilient and we need to be prepared for emergencies and other challenges. But it’s up to Congress to put out the fires and sit down and do what is right and what is necessary for us to function and protect our families and our communities.
We’re really tearing down our dreams for future generations that are Donald Trump.
Please follow CNN on Twitter and see CNN’s “There is no Trump!” video
']

Title: SE Cupp: A third party could get us out of this mess
Generation:
['By Troy Smith, CNN
(CNN) — A third party could do enough to protect you, but then it could prove toxic for you.
That’s why companies are banking on a new gig-by-gig approach to risk, a simplified jargonish place to work on a variety of fronts: the so-called G4S approach.
“Beyond risk” consists of a three-year-long effort to identify the most appropriate risk-related behaviors to manage. In other words, G4S companies plan on getting your company out of these risk-gathering activities.
“Instead of the single taggable tagline,” says Lance Baker, a researcher at Cornell University’s JPL (formerly Nanticoke Research Institute) and the director of G4S Research International. “Instead of getting a handle on what you’re willing to risk, the tagline is, ‘How can we prevent the environment from preventing climate change?’”
G4S is part of 18 companies that will roll out a G4S service from May through July — and even more in the coming months.
The programs are designed to support companies that treat climate change as a simple luxury; a recognized disaster; and that people don’t need anymore.
The result is: better outcomes, fewer such experiences and less climate change-related problems, according to Baker.
But those are just some of the tasks that G4S experts are focusing on.
Baker says one of the ways G4S helps companies push their boundaries is by giving G4S teams a way to trade over email privileges from the bulk of companies.
“Organizations and employees have access to more appropriate email policies and controls,” he explains. “Competing email providers also allow organizations to specify which technologies the server enables them to use for email updates and policies.”
Companies can then assign those users multiple emails — such as appointments, donations, reviews and status updates — so there isn’t a standard hierarchy for lead, lead or lead management. That means managers can view whether to assign a lead solely for a call, not because it’s merely useful.
“One or two senior managers on one team may have a team on that team,” Baker says. “This turns it into a successful business case for the entire team.”
McDonald’s, a restaurant chain that deploys the G4S software, says that contractors such as FedEx and UPS are more inclined to enter into monthly contracts than moving over to new servers.
And FedEx — a key customer for G4S and its three partners — says it’s given more notice of its plans to shift back to a cloud-based environment. It promises speedier shipping times and a path to inventory replacements by analyzing emails.
“With the data on our servers (as opposed to our centralized data centers), those same users can move to a cloud-based environment,” FedEx says.
“I think the work is difficult to quantify,” says Dan Harrison, a senior vice president for business development at Fast Company in its annual “10 Companies Dominating the World.” “But it’s good news to realize you’re literally sitting at this crossroads with a very difficult action plan.”
He says companies have to plan around those words. That means, he says, selecting the right website, having automated resources on your website and otherwise managing emails using small Web-based machines.
“You can work with the people you want in your organization, and then combine what you know to provide solutions to that,” says Harrison. “A lot of companies would love to have something like that. It is an absolute passion for the company, which is all about the experience.”
']

Title: Confronting the cult of partisan media
Generation:
['Posted Wednesday, April 5, 2017 9:46 pm
When I attend university in the American south, many of my peers continue to push for an end to the partisan media: the media the elite select and maintain. This, though, is especially true of all college and university professors. And the universities I attend have their own partisan institutions, which are as well.
Consider the biggest universities in the nation: Notre Dame, Cornell, Rutgers, Columbia, Yale, Cal, South Florida, and Washington. College presidents are active in Congress, and former members of Congress and former members of Congress are engaging with Fox News, ABC News, CNN, MSNBC, CBS News, Fox Business, CNN and other news outlets. I have been invited to attend broadcast dinners hosted by these networks, events I have yet to attend.
I never met college presidents. When I did, however, I was introduced to media chief Bob Woodward who asked me why there was so much coverage on campus and radio. He then asked me to write a thesis on the shift in media coverage from its former, and admirable, authorial character.
There was a huge surge in independent online reporting in the '80s, and I thought that was positive news. However, the media coverage have increased, as was the magnitude of the increase in partisan outlets: CBS a daily met several times, Fox News Sunday and CNN tied for second, and is more than twice the size of the pro-reform HuffPo
Over the last several years, my generation has become completely separate from the political left. Neither PBS nor CNN exist. Neither Fox News nor CNN have time to interact with students or students at Cornell. It has been strange. Journalism, perhaps, isn't the center of the new politics -- its center is college.
Everything I do at Cornell compares to my predecessors. More importantly, it compares not only to my predecessors, but to my parents' generation. My parents graduated from college in 1964. But my parents' generation are now gone.
The media strategy by these institutions that is succeeding right now, how they adapt to the changing media landscape, and how they respond to it, reveals a very disturbing truth.
One of the most misleading aspects of college journalism is that they are aloof in fact -- they don't try to be conservative, they don't respond to criticism, they feel they cannot control their audience.
When students ask what degree they received, they are often assuming that they were doing a thing right. When students ask what college classes they attended -- not simply what colleges they attended -- they are often relying on the words of the individual on the college website.
These kinds of deceptive tactics continue to exist. For example, some media outlets have reported that the Colorado Springs college had admitted as many as six dishonest students to a school, sometimes double or triple the number of students admitted as told.
Time after time, colleges have encouraged students to find the truth. The national debate on college admissions has continued apace, after news outlets have focused exclusively on the selective admissions process.
At the University of Michigan, there was an overnight student suspension after a freshman student exposed he had a "too-boyish-looking" obsession with the BDSM movement. The university had a headmaster then.
Then there was the Amherst College of Art and Design, where administrators fired the dean of students after a sophomore student was accused of taking part in an art contest in the jewelry department. That same group of students remain enrolled at Amherst, yet again, because of (the host's) partisan coverage.
The underlying truth is that these universities are not doing anything right. This is less about education, more about media manipulation.
This is particularly true of colleges who are dominant in their own universities. These schools have been associated with prominent networks like MSNBC, ABC News, Fox News, CNN, NPR, Time and NPR, not to mention the academic reputation of those networks and professors (many of whom were unionized at their colleges).
Part of the problem has to do with the role that professors play in society. Under President Donald Trump, colleges have been criticized as caring — much too caring — about taxpayer dollars. Republicans, after all, have done a fantastic job at reducing class sizes in recent years.
They have been very active in increasing the amount of money that the government spends on universities. Also, they are expanding their budgets year after year in ways that favor student neediest students.
There is a lot to learn about these universities. But those who engage in both their politics and the factual analyses that aim to advance their interests will have a very difficult time hearing from them.
']

Title: 26 voices on why the free press matters
Generation:
['By Charles M. Smith
Senior White House correspondent, CNN
We’re nowhere near full support for the democratic reform narrative in the United States. We have a population under 40, where as the CEO of the Small Business Administration, Jessica Mendoza was in charge of getting grants to many businesses.
Our government was introduced to the media by Congress, which stripped two major media voices of their power. Yours, the late editorial page editor turned columnist, John King. Rulings from the editorial board weren’t distributed to members of Congress. And there were no hearings.
That made us all mistrust government. After all, these were people we needed more than an inkling we could be informed by old news clips or scientific data.
Do you really think we are paying attention to the truth? We must.
We see in the paydays of our Facebook friends what we can buy and how we can find out about it. And we buy things by filing them to the press. And sometimes by friends. And sometimes by lovers of the free press.
Think about it. As King observed in his vivid lucid writings of the challenges of standing up for liberty, he no longer felt let down, and he admitted publicly that he was a “man of honesty.”
Today, if we blame the media for the Trump administration’s dismal economic success, it is largely inaccurate. We are still in the dark about the failure of the administration. And we’re left with the images that we wanted to portray to make people forget our voices have been silent for so long. And that seems to be the underlying theme for this political discourse.
For the last two decades, freedom of the press has been a campaign issue in our country, and we’ve been working together for years to put it out to pasture. There is talk about replacing the Federal Communications Commission with a smaller one, and it’s fair to suggest that this could happen in a Democrat-controlled Senate. Or one with no big White House.
But perhaps most troubling is the rhetoric we have heard. I’ll set the record straight: The current administration’s obsession with free speech isn’t just about the collection of evidence that proves Republican policies didn’t work—it’s also about taking the fight to lower our voices.
Even when we have an elected leader who has her heart set on the presidency, we don’t have the political will, or the legal capacity, to wield that power. A powerful executive insists that we stop pursuing laws that harm jobs. Even the incoming administration has a tradition of bending to President Trump’s will, most recently when the president-elect nominated Timothy O’Brien, then the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, to chair the agency for public safety.
We need leaders who are interested in civil discourse, who want to share the common ground rather than engage in global warfare. Those among us who are on the center of the conversation will have the chance to exercise those civic values. Those of us in opposition of the president-elect will have the chance to use that perspective in the fight to promote Trump and his agenda. That’s why freedom of the press makes our democracy great.
']

Title: Democracy's immune system is in trouble. Here's what we can do
Generation:
["Tweet. Like Twitter!
Yes, Twitter, it's the social network where many people will comment on news, suggest new products and often about politics themselves.
But it's also like Facebook, where people will merely digest the news and post video reviews for each other.
But Twitter is where The Washington Post takes its own political satire seriously as it competes with Google's Daily Beast and Time to attract readers.
Everything has always been and will always be different from the rest of us.
I've spent the last year wondering if Twitter is up to the challenge of taking on our once-rock-solid, inaccessible legacy.
Twitter announced that it was holding a contest that kicked off Tuesday. What it saw was a way to incentivize contributions and increase the amount that people can donate.
The company then announced that it would award $10,000 worth of prizes to people who tweet, share, blog or comment about what they saw or heard. Those two were top entries.
To answer that question:
Those who click on a link to the contest's winner will be rewarded with a brand new Twitter handle: Sheryl Sandberg's Twitter Handle, the @SylSandberg.
A $5,000 reward will be given in a lifetime. You can still enter.
Counting the winners is limited to people who can tweet their responses on Monday.
If you didn't already have your @SylSandberg handle, don't panic. This is the second year in a row that the group won a contest with the hashtag #CleanAnalysis.
By the way, Twitter announced that it will be returning to its roots of #ThinkNow for more information.
And just in case you're wondering what Twitter did to spark the study of reproductive rights, you just read that Sarah Palin's kids were involved in it. The trouble is, they're never actually citizens and aren't even eligible to vote. That means that birth control isn't that easy to access.
But you still have a lot of possibilities.
While you may agree that voting is a pain, how do you imagine changing our culture through the use of social media?
Researchers at the UCLA Shute Institute said their research on the creation of a government website suggested a way to improve the lives of Americans whose social and political movements had made it difficult for them to obtain birth control.
It's just a start, though.
Here are a few ways social media can make us more connected.
In a statement, CEO Jack Dorsey said:
Today, we celebrate 40 years of leading men who changed the way we do business, innovate and connect. We see the power of big ideas to impact society through active involvement and video campaigns. Think Now, at 60 million unique users per day, celebrates of some of those 30 years of badass female leaders.
That was a pretty massive undertaking.
But I'm on to something.
Do we really need any more women in government? Well, quite possibly. But I don't think Republicans are going to get paid if they want to. And I hope no one gets pooh-poohed at home when they pick up their phones and watch people in prison complain about not having access to contraceptives.
I hope no one is asked about it. I hope we make it possible for women to voice their concerns —whether they get it from friends or corporate or individual or political leaders — directly.
But I'm afraid, they're scared to do so.
"]

Title: You can't build the truth on a scaffold of lies
Generation:
["We had to write a letter because somebody needed a crowbar to take the paper. You had to write a secret. Just raise your hand on your phone and ask if you could jump in. Wait until I could ask. Hello, that very future was the future.
The streets across the nation - they are full of sticky mud, dust, and muds. We hope that you hold it by the hands. The world was never meant to be a place with smooth buildings, but with smooth footprints, smooth surfaces.
This is how we know that perfect characters are anywhere.
There is no circle. There is no dead, lifeless body. There is no sewn to steel. The human personage that is made in these exact places is just the symbol for perfect characters that exist, simply uncorks, and invites us to create them.
And that's what we do. Without dreaming of all the illusions or blurred reality, we would miss the glaring truth: perfect characters exist. When you see these, you understand the beautiful, hardworking souls that they are. If you just see the quiet, rustic simplicity in the sheepish way – or worse, the simple uplifting, ochre life of those down to earth, young, juicy rhinos and grizzled bears – it's a sign of sure things.
We post the world as beautiful, as progressive, as crisp as roses. We post the powerful grey clouds. Even then, we might be giddy that some of this is real, and on the bottom of the mountain we're flying.
The beauty of the world is written on the inside of our heads, on the dirt of the earth, on that wall that the giant horses sit in, on the yoga mats, on the hills of autumn. We are seeing mountains as imperfect shapes, though often rather fluffy and natural.
I wrote the letter before we knew the world that existed. It's the most magical and startling thing we've ever seen. It's the most beautiful and magical thing we have ever experienced.
It took months of translation, carefully dictating to the codt of human nature. I wrote my letter by phone to (note: only) executive editor of Detroit, the unknown. I didn't always like the phone, never liked the hard news, and never like all that jazz. I wrote the letter three days after the first of my family's trees exploded. I wrote it on the day of their birthday. I wrote it on the day the first men got up.
I gave myself a holiday too, because life, my heart and my soul, are always me.
I wrote it to celebrate beauty in the world. It was art. It was poetry. It was fair, even in the world we can still belong to, and I loved it.
And that's the difference between honest and fiction, truth and fiction. It's the difference between sluts and rebel.
"]

Title: Why the black press is more relevant than ever
Generation:
['“The FBI and Congress should be laughing.”
That’s the refrain from U.S. Rep. Devin Nunes (R-Calif.) at a news conference where he sought to correct his oft-maligned report about the FBI’s 2014 raid on Planned Parenthood.
The incident prompted Trump to dismiss Nunes altogether, for reasons ranging from opportunism to a revealing defect. He suggested the probe was going, yes, tough enough for his investigation of the FBI.
His next tweet referring to any probe with “strong subject matter” is a reminder of his insatiable zeal for the political right.
Nunes’s findings of an ongoing investigation into leaks to journalists has stoked a national debate over the legitimacy of congressional investigations.
The fast-growing, heated press has been a vital, if temporarily embattled, conduit for many investigations over the past two decades.
It serves as a critical thumb in a headlong rush by the Trump administration to end the partisan gridlock at the federal and state levels.
But to those who favor the status quo, Nunes’s personal attacks are just a trip down memory lane. He has focused on the FBI’s investigation into possible links between Trump campaign aides and Russians during the 2016 election, and blamed Republicans for their failure to investigate possible collusion between members of the Trump campaign and Moscow.
None of this involved collusion and didn’t happen, of course. The story died along the campaign trail.
Democrats were prepared for it, but they didn’t know how to react. That job should never have been left to a partisan outlet, particularly one that so frequently supports the GOP.
Nunes thinks the FBI acted illegally and somehow lied to Congress, and he has issues with the lawmakers trying to flip over the issue.
When asked about the reports of an FBI agent planting two leaks at the Arizona State Department of Public Safety (PSA), he accused them of being “deliberately a political attack in the spirit of the Committee on Investigating Hillary Clinton’s Email Scandal.”
“I’m not getting involved in it,” Nunes said, adding, “It has nothing to do with me or our investigations.”
Nunes would be successful.
But even if the FBI mishandled the story, it’s unlikely they’ll provide proof that the agency has in fact done anything wrong, like of the manner in which it found out about the leak of memos issued by Tom Bossert, the former head of the FBI’s Los Angeles division.
“We have more information than information we could have been given,” Nunes said.
The questions are the consequence of what happened during that embarrassing confrontation in the House in December. Rep. Greg Walden (R-Ore.) has tried to put on the record why Trump made that decision, and he has two eyes waiting for the conclusions.
But the Congressional Ethics Committee is willing to add to the furor. The panel’s advisory panel on congressional ethics will investigate the FBI’s Internal Revenue Service (IRS) leaks to the media, and whether any such emails are relevant to the 2018 congressional elections.
Investigators already are gearing up for the outcome of the probe, as they are in California.
President Trump has made it clear he is fed up of Nunes and his findings, and the constant chatter about the “Russian witch hunt” has bolstered Democrats’ desire to hold the probe on the account of “top political staffers.”
But Nunes may be right to do so. Trump’s former legal adviser, Michael Cohen, was indicted on a criminal conspiracy charge in December. Trump could face some complicated charges if he responds to the entire investigation without self-serving complaints by Republicans and special counsel Robert Mueller.
Nunes’s goal is clear: Americans should be laughing at all sorts of conduct while a scandal engulfs them in a partisan realm.
']

Title: Branding news outlets as foreign agents won't make them any more transparent
Generation:
["Any foreign journalist who scoops a story that gives them a severe audience on social media or sports will soon face a double-whammy.
The Washington Post's reporters, Cameron Bailey and Ezra Klein, expose some foreign agents as struggling to navigate media policy over a reported breakup with their longtime partner. Their stories that trace many of these non-western stories back to Washington, represented at least part of their journalistic modus operandi. A focus on domestic communications — there's a broad spectrum of the global press in both the Beltway and in the workplace — makes them as infrequently relevant to journalists as their journalists.
But it's not just domestic access that's undermined. The coverage of Russia's alleged interference in the 2016 election, and U.S. obstruction of the Russia investigation, has given foreign journalists greater access to Fox News and MSNBC. That's why it's imperative we in Washington and elsewhere start working in a new, more transparent way — to defend American journalists against foreign agents or foreign meddling. It's not too late.
The stakes are higher today, and the news media in the United States must use their power to define the boundaries and the frontiers of a global industry that is already vibrant.
"]

Title: Student journalists deserve a free press too
Generation:
['By Andrew Hill
My friend and colleague, Mary Atkin, just graduated from a female journalism degree in 2012, and this year she and a small group of students from the University of Pittsburgh published two books about journalism — one about the 2001 anthrax sting in Washington and the other about the concept of free speech.
My colleague, Nick Alden, is one of us, but mostly we’re students and students of other institutions. We were interested to see what the writers from both platforms thought about free speech, and largely what they thought about it.
I gave this title to a great book (Entitled Free Speech for Journalists by Mary Atkin, in reference to the Nature Line column about 'spreadability and the evolution of consent' in politics). He wrote about how the “contentistic” movement, he said, “for many of us has become little more than a yawning yawn” and to what extent do we think and speak as we believe?
Mary Atkin and her colleagues—Mary Langford, Kevin Drew, and Jesse Mathews—found the kind of diverse perspective we need as journalists. As one of our esteemed contributors, I agreed with her. When I showed her a journalist posing a thorny question, she used a pen to elaborate in detail.
So why did she put out this book? Why did we think that brave young journalists should be respected in their area of expertise? Mary Atkin said that free speech has always been important, but journalists should have the freedom to express themselves equally. Atkin told me that “it would not matter whether [the journalists] said what they said, or if they said what they thought, whether they stood by what they said.”
In my mind, free speech was not just just the form of written criticism, or as a tool that publishers would employ to dress up their books to give them brand recognition, but also those books for the success of the other professions. For example, writers who wrote for various TV shows gave unexpected and unexpected success by announcing that their subjects were writers. Women writers encouraged us to think outside the box in popular culture, and writers who had an opinion that could be misinterpreted by anyone. Even if we’re in college, we’re free to express ourselves outside of our free time.
Journalists from various networks and/or media organizations must take the same risk to argue against free speech at all. For them, the vast majority of time spent covering the earth can give us skills and voice that cover a variety of subject areas, which allows them to show us what they mean when talking about what we do. And speaking to a journalist does not necessarily mean asking you to practice your spoken word. Journalists like Mary Atkin, who speaks directly and comprehensively, can even offer words of support and encouragement, for example, to writers who want to connect, even support, people not to be influenced by a message.
Journalists sometimes have to show us what’s really important to them and how important it is to them, but that’s how the small group of them came up with the idea for "Free Speech for Journalists." I’ll tell you why: because, as we all know, we are precious hanmen.
I am so proud of this idea. It’s so important to us that we must treat each other with respect and respect without it interfering with our freedom to assert ourselves. Thank you, Mary Atkin, for upping your homework.
']

Title: Media martyrs: Among those who died while working as journalists in the past 15 years
Generation:
['Posted Tuesday, April 5, 2019 11:00 am
One year into holding leadership positions in the government broadcasting industry, the path to independence has been very rough. When President Trump announced in the spring of 2017 that he was creating a special commission to study the scope of the national broadcasting industry, it was ostensibly to prioritize new industry measures like better use of and investment in broadcasting. But one year later, this new group of bipartisan industry leaders seem to have stumbled, and, as of last week, may not even be emerging.
Many of these well-connected corporate moguls have been conducting interviews among their peers and their organizations in the past two years, attracting welcome attention for their collaborative approaches, free-wheeling investigations, and their outspokenness in making the case for both the importance of local media and the limitations of federal law.
According to the Financial Times, Vice President Mike Pence worked with the former Prince Charlie speechwriter in 1995, and in 1997 he persuaded members of Congress to act on economic aid for Syrian refugees. (Three of them sought the same punishment from Congress.) During the 2000 campaign, Vice President Joe Biden also held discussions with the party and the White House on the issue, and in 2007 Biden threatened to boycott the GOP Party convention if the system’s elected officials failed to support the convention resolution condemning the Islamic State.
“They’re no longer dominant groups in the party anymore — they’re already gone,” says David Jernigan, a U.S. professor and former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations. There has been a rapid consolidation of the powerful within this new breed of media leaders.
“A number of important congressional Republicans and senators, and not a few powerful voices, are becoming increasingly vocal in supporting the separation of powers,” Jernigan says. “It’s a fairly dramatic shift. This separation of powers is one of the major contributors to large-scale illegal immigration.”
Much of the recent upheaval over a proposal to restrict immigration comes from discussion of the specific barriers this effort would seek to relieve, such as the restrictions on the civil immigration system, for the recruitment of candidates for U.S. Special Forces. But the idea is catching on. And it’s being embraced by Congress, some of which already has laws in place, such as those concerning outreach to the elderly and infirm.
It’s almost certainly not the single single biggest issue the Republicans and their new majority have debated, though the four Senate senators behind the so-called immigration bill have promised — with the hope of being able to iron out major parts — that the divisions within their party will be addressed as soon as possible. “I think they’re willing to get together,” says Jernigan. “There seems to be a willingness on both sides.”
Meanwhile, those efforts are small potatoes compared to what has been happening throughout the North American broadcast business at a federal level. Comcast Corp., the parent company of CNN, with its sale of Charter Communications to CNN earlier this year, showed that, even if it falls short of breaking even, it has still managed to turn a profit. Turner Broadcasting Group, Inc., a division of Time Warner, reported a 19.4% increase in earnings for its second quarter. The median price paid for cable television in the US is $18.78 per month.
All that’s left of that business, however, is to look for ways to be the most competitive in the industry. “First and foremost, competition is great” says Jan Lande, president of the nation’s largest and most respected multicultural and multicultural group called Media First. “New technologies, in terms of content development, impact access to new audiences, and also new production platforms, will do more to improve access to and guide video news in African-American communities.”
This year, companies including Yahoo, Facebook, and Netflix have discussed potentially harvesting the popularity of streaming as news in the Philippines, creating even more interesting ways to reach poor people in the first place, as the ratings of the Netflix drama, “House of Cards,” shows. The prospects, however, are decidedly bleak.
']

Title: Why press freedom is your freedom
Generation:
['Saudi Arabia is one of the world’s most repressive regimes and according to CNN is a total tyrannical regime. CNN Arabia seems to produce the perfect case for a New Era.
Several news outlets have a record of using violent language to condemn Saudi Arabia. But why did King Abdullah, the supreme head of the Islamic State (ISIS), bravely use violence against religious minorities or journalists to deal with vicious protests? Is it a matter of prestige or prestige?
Like all propaganda outlets, CNN does not treat its report as the state’s home page. The government was not given the opportunity to hide from the news, nor was its distorting or controlling coverage just simply evident. To get around the law, CNN utilizes the “safe space” CNN is developing over in Saudi Arabia—a "one stop shop" for the coverage of events around the world, and a convenient place for anyone with a digital presence.
As you can see from the chart above, even when reporters weren’t using live footage, CNN has often dealt with sporadic, far from violent protests in the West. That’s because press freedom is an internationalist non-state means of promoting information. CNN has done a U.S. plus handful of investigative journalism and has allowed foreign reporters working out of Riyadh to work on cover stories reporting on any violation of international law.
If you look closely at the Times of London and other newspapers from which we are embedded, they have been deeply critical of the Saudi rulers for many months. And just recently, they demanded that the Saudi government remove us from certain sections of its weekly newspaper.
CNN’s reporting on these big-city protests can seem so mainstream, but the demand for our exit seems like a statement to anyone looking into U.S. national security.
To turn against the Communist East Asian regimes in that region, you could turn the American media against dictators in your own country. This was one plan—which was based on my argument that democracy has been trapped in ever-so-slightly “wrong” countries, where there is no one, and no one is held accountable. Democracy has helped create the Black Death and other unrestpots that we’ve been held responsible for all through the decades.
And while every American understands that democracy has been trapped in ever-so-slightly “wrong” countries, if we allow conflict and repression to destroy an institution like a democracy, we are bound to do whatever it takes to keep it safe. There is no “democracy” to criticize.
That is why CNN has built a government by consent of the American people. As we learn, they do not make their own decisions. As their platform highlights the really notable newsstand, CNN has controlled their own newsroom for years, and access is rare for the publication.
So why do we expect outrage? The U.S. government has found all sorts of unacceptable errors or outright violations of human rights. It has undermined the various institutions that make those institutions work. That is why there is such a vibrant role for BBC journalists that employ freelance Iraqis, and even better, BBC reporters in Saudi Arabia.
It’s clear that CNN’s cover story on Saudi Arabia is largely engineered by Saudi Arabia’s media. There is no identifiable “democracy” in the headline, yet there is an almost prima facie consensus among the mainstream media and in Saudi society that any misadventure that occurs there is being completely committed by the Saudi government.
In many ways CNN is playing a major role as a propaganda arm for the Saudi regime. Alongside any failure to sufficiently defend fundamental human rights in Saudi Arabia, CNN journalists love a mission and are willing to pursue the underdog. Title: What it's like to be me
Generation:
['Mark Olson works from home when he needs to talk to his wife Melissa every time she walks through the door.
She spends months preparing and preparing for him, all the while doing chores. For the past three months, her two young kids have been her main focus.
"Two of my three granddaughters have gotten older and, who knows how many more kids will come out like that?" said Olson, who grew up in Woodstock, NJ. "I love what I do. I love our kids, though, and we make sure their day passes without me having any care."
Olson is a father of two and a grandfather. His wife, Melissa, had been diagnosed with cancer and underwent surgery, called a beta-lateral sarcoma, two years ago. But she says she's in good spirits, too.
"I'm a good blouse, I'm a great mom. I think my whole life has been about managing and maintaining," she said. "If anything, it's hurt a little bit that my kids haven't been as smart as they should have been."
After successful surgeries, Olson and Melissa have been able to speak with their kids while they were cancer-free and continuing to research and prepare for surgery. Still, she doesn't feel as though she's making a difference.
"It's not the same for me and it's not like I'm completely sure. They're still getting me through it," Olson said. "I feel good."
"They're both emotionally strong and I feel like that's more important. They take the time to actually get to know me and speak to me. Sometimes, when I talk to them, it's not the same as a conversation. To keep moving forward with the rest of the family."
Olson hopes the visits will ultimately be enough to keep her healthy. But, just like Jessica Dickerman, a bit of advice may come in handy.
"You would think you have good control over what you do," Olson said. "The kids will be able to be healthy. They have no concept of it. And to help, they could just take it one day at a time. I would love that for them."
']

Title: Democrats' only choice is to impeach Trump
Generation:
['1 of 2 2 of 2
By Rachel Abramson, CNN
WASHINGTON (CNN) -- On Wednesday, the Congressional Oversight Panel and the nation's top political strategist delivered their vote on constitutional amendments to allow Congress to impeach President Donald Trump.
"The Constitution, the House, and the Senate should protect American democracy from becoming an unholy collection of evil people who stir up patriotic passion," the panel's chairman and ranking member, Rep. Jason Chaffetz of Utah, said in a statement.
Citing a "radical fundamentalism that has dramatically transformed our political establishment," he added, "this amendment would enshrine Senate control over the president's power to fire law enforcement, make attorney general appointments, remove political appointees from his Cabinet and change campaign finance laws to favor corporate donors rather than Americans."
Some Democrats have lashed out at the commission for voting to remove Trump from office while Vice President Mike Pence and others got extensions for the debate.
"Today is an unprecedented day in which our political leaders are using national power in a way that fundamentally corrupts the American people," said House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi, the panel's chairman.
At this point, it's unclear how the panel will vote on the amendment, and who will decide. But the panel and most other political and legal experts, including campaign finance experts, say that it represents a "strike" on the "risk-reward" of being taken out of the president's hands and without a parallel attempt to move it to the floor.
Rep. John Lewis of Georgia, who is black, called it a blow to racial justice and constitutional interpretation that "we've no longer had a president who can say that the Constitution is a joke."
The panel recommends that Trump's removal be part of a fourth-term. That would mean Trump would retain his office until 2024, a year later than the current president and Democratic challenger Hillary Clinton.
It's unclear how Republican Attorney General Jeff Sessions, currently the most senior legal official in the Trump administration, would be involved. The panel is considering whether it would approve his request to continue his legal service pending his review of the commission's findings.
During the hearing, multiple Republican members of the panel cried foul over the commission's decision, including Rep. Elijah Cummings of Maryland, a member of the "No on 4" leadership team.
"Maybe the self-righteous national order of our day, which is 'vote 'em up or 'vote 'em down,' is coming to an end," said Cummings.
In addition to causing a split among the panel's members, the protests at two White House events on Wednesday made it clear that there would be no room for broad discussion.
House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., joined Trump for one of the first White House events of the day, where Trump called on the commission to "let the criminal justice system go away."
It's unclear what went into the concerns held on Wednesday.
In reality, they were the only way for the majority of the panel to keep hearing President Trump's views on immigration, taxes, jobs and economic initiatives.
The panel members were sympathetic to each side on a number of issues, but said their main request was to keep them waiting until they were resolved on the measure to vote on it, so that they could "gather together and say, 'Wow, here we go. What do we do?'"
']

Title: What happens when a patient says, 'Doc, help me die'
Generation:
['She’s a preschool student in South Korea. She never spoke words of gratitude. She was cancer-stricken. And yet, she was carrying a God-given and unexpected gift to millions through her special day.

He had been diagnosed with cancer that year and would have killed him. We thought the idea of burying him would be tinged with shame, but the same day our friend and motherly angel struck their life. She informed us the night before that her no-malignant brain tumor had spread.
It was Aug. 9, 2010.
“Just the light of life!”
His powers were fading and he was nowhere to be found.
“Our little boy is too young,” the nurse assured us. “Could you please explain to him how this could have occurred in the first place?”
We offered. “Father, don’t let them assume he is dead,” she said. “He will never be able to read, write or make decisions. Let us think about his life before his eyes. Let them pass on this wisdom and significance to other children.”
We are grateful, but we can’t help but be thankful.
On the occasion of Mother Nature’s great birthday, I’ve ventured out into the unknown, we’ve gone back to the basics, and I haven’t had that much time to process the gift of generosity.
“Darling,” I’ve confessed, “Don’t let them assume you are dead.” Not a word of it. A full explanation is necessary to win over the sanity who withholds judgment from such a simple request.
To give someone food that had been stored in a tiny refrigerator when I gave birth to my twin girls — twins! Both! Both! 2!
Although the offer of food and chores are a gift for others, the challenge is, it needs that same consideration for ourselves.
“I’ve done the right thing. I’ve given him a good one. He’s so smart. I haven’t had to say goodbye to him yet.”

Title: Together we make a family
Generation:
['When I was a child in the 1920s, my father found a home in Miami. He was a writer and a favorite teacher of mine, one of those famous teachers who was “spring-loaded” — some of the proudest teachers. I will never forget his teaching, though. As I sat in the dining room watching in on his phone, I hoped it would come to an end soon.
Then all of a sudden it happened.
I sat there, looking at the paper, wondering what could have occurred, and I was at the brink of tears. Would I have been able to make it there? Do I owe so much gratitude to those dear friends, the children, and the children of families who had survived? I barely finished the essay, I probably thought that my mother would have said that to her desk. If I hadn’t lived in the house in Mexico then I’d probably feel like I should have been the problem. I must have warned them of that – by going to school then starting my own business.
Luckily, there was a mother in The Upside Down, who helped me navigate many of the feelings that so many of us dread. I knew she planned on caring for me financially, while we were still living separately. After she retired in the mid 1950s, we moved into a $2,000-a-month apartment. She did a few things: organizing the schedules, giving me a little advance notice of the work, and arranging when time allowed to leave for some reason. After my mother died in 1986, I left all of that.
Now, 20 years later, we are sharing the bed in our Los Angeles home, a Japanese model apartment with a full-time law school principal. More than 30 people have signed on to our television show, Los Angeles, and we are talking about the entire city. We’re building our country’s first building society. We’re asking the country’s leading tax-subsidized organizations to set up various fund bodies with a combined total of $21 billion in deposits and will be spending our money by creating a nonprofit credit union, one of the largest groups of entrepreneurs in the country.
We’re also asking banks to offer an incentive to individuals who donate money by making their contributions tax deductible as long as they don’t hold their money in a bank account for more than 90 days. The aim is to make life easier for those who want to buy homes without any need for a bank account. We want each of our founding partners, employers, and job candidates, to be treated the same as those of everyone else that owns a home. This new research has proven to be both welcome and controversial.
In a film, I watched the death of a beloved family member, alongside an in-depth conversation with an organization called the Aryan Empire that promotes the abolition of the Japanese military. The authors of the recent film won a Pulitzer Prize for their book, “The Walls: Conversations with Former FBI Agents.” They spent three years documenting their family. Nothing short of the push for civil rights and housing reform, these three and the final 11 are finalists in this year’s American Documentary Festival competition for documentaries for A Documentary Filmmaker Award and these two work together to attract international television audiences, in particular for A Documentary Filmmaker.
I walked away with some anxiety about the future. The horizon has changed. As I wondered about my future, I wondered if the Chicago Tribune had touched so many lives with its website, genealogy blog, and the like. We talked about Monday, Easter Sunday, the flood of spring chickens and the clean-up of the 10,000 homes that fell down when the mail started arriving. We had lunch together a couple of times each month. We talked about how a small group of parents was figuring out what to do with their kids in this country. We sat down and laid out the simple outline of how to get our kids back to school, quit drinking, and go out on the weekends.
On my Saturday, I wondered if The Upside Down would succeed, and when I ended up winning a Pulitzer for reporting for a new segment, I realized that it could. Would it be impossible for anyone to admit that they were driving on the freeway in a Toyota Prius? Would it be possible to post a crowd observation on Facebook? Had this made a difference?
']

Trump pledged in his inaugural address that the wall would be built while he was inaugurated. Even after months of delays, it has finally been given the green light by congressional leaders -- leaders from both parties -- to begin construction, at what's called a "phased start" period.
"We can put a wall on our southern border with other nations for our jobs, our farms, our precious homeland," Trump said in the audience, a surprise to many Republicans.

The order, Obama's, was an acceptable solution to many problems. It was also one that was highly recommended by some early economists — including Robert Shiller, Martin Feldstein, and Albert L. Katz — and it was widely approved by many White House professionals as a successful measure.
There have, however, been some bumps along the way, particularly with some crucial pieces of legislation affected by last year's disastrous midterm elections.

I'll know if that statement is true but the fact is, President Trump is now making a lot of fans out of trying to figure out what caused this Executive Order.
The directive from the Homeland Security Department encourages political and racial profiling and makes clear that the Department of Homeland Security is essentially acting in concert with the FBI.
Trump has not said what triggered the Order, but as Democrats have repeatedly accused him of, he has never provided clear answers.

That indicates that one man cannot then discredit the whole process in the very theater of a just-in-time, “just-in-time” approach.
If the new executive order is based on above-board explanations and methods, rather than urgent actions, it would seem that the governing bodies and the US National Security Agency are dangerously lacking — or are merely overlooked for ideological reasons.
Such an action is not what the Trump administration should be pursuing. It would be dangerous and disruptive — for the economy, for the culture of the American way of life, for society itself.

No one can deny the importance of acting to protest and to represent and make a difference.
This is a very different political moment, and it's necessary to make sure we can do that again.
Turning a new light on this event or two will be both a challenge and a blessing to all in this country.

Title: Trump obeys Seinfeld's law

Thus began a weird and amusing storybook about how the words that little Donald had become in the direction of the presidency come through when he hit the keyboard. On screen, John asked Trump if he had ever, in any way, violated the law when he read the order issued by Judge Roy Moore, the Alabama congressman accused of having an affair with a 13-year-old girl.

John Trump: “Nothing.”

Both Donald Trump and John Trump accepted the apology and pleaded with their father to apologize.
“It is really messed up,” John Trump said. “It has to stop. You do something against the law.”
“I have been served with a very profound apology,” Donald Trump said. “You do something against the law.”

Title: I was married with 2 kids when I realized I'm gay
