['The question from a man my age was: "Where am I now?" As the wedding dress came up and feathers began to fly, I couldn't help but wonder what was on me. I turned to his dad, told him I loved him, and finally shut the door. It was an uncomfortable moment, and then I realised I'd lost my humanity.
Homosexuality has been one of the most shocking aspects of the Catholic Church since the creation of a definition of what constituted marriage on March 6, 1968. Some 6,000 of the largest Catholic bishops have declared it illegal, and President George W. Bush has been harshly criticized for his willingness to divide the church into increasingly secular branches.
I was not gay at the time, and I could certainly have explored that issue in a different way, without getting as close to an authentic confession as I could possibly have. Even though I had always believed the full word, I put in a neutral stance at the time, to see in the current changing field it's not something I'd find anywhere near my authentic self.
This isn't a change of heart, and I'm sure many Catholics will listen to the argument that homosexual conversion is inherently intolerable. I've never said that, but I do see it as immoral and I'm glad to see that it's becoming more and more common. But we've come a long way, and the outrage that brought me here today is something that will only be felt in a different way.
Even by Catholicism's most conservative members, homosexual conversion is on an increase. Only a few Protestant denominations, including the United States Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), have approved gay marriage. LGBT Americans continue to outnumber their counterparts in other denominations, and church officials acknowledge that sin often attracts more librarians. Although U.S.A. no longer considers same-sex marriage legal in its territories, there have been many church member protests that have led to restrictions on the practice, such as having lesbian worship and online guilds.
With two children in the home we've built, the future is bright, and the embarrassment that came just now is a smile I'll never forget. I don't know if it's been the right call for my parents to continue being gay as Catholics, or a legitimate and justifiable reason. Some situations in which bishops are shown to be evil are understandable and one thing Catholicism has done is to get out of the way while learning to live within our own means.
So, as I've made my decision in good faith, I feel as though we're now putting aside the irreconcilable differences between others to learn to live life in the spirit of the people we love. The church is still best because it isn't only for Catholics who want to redefine their faith. It can make assumptions about others that need to be clarified.
This year, I will spend my part of my final year participating in fall semester church, shedding light on the "Gay Liberation Movement, the Nation's Leading Church Evangelist," to speak at a high school reunion and advocate on behalf of LGBT individuals in predominantly Catholic and conservative churches. Because, as I said, we've made the same mistake. We live in a time in which, as the gay movement gains wider acceptance, claims to be straight or gay marriage progress are judged differently.
But I want you to know I've changed my mind about our relationship. I'm no longer going to say the word am I gay. It's not a new thing. It's a time in the history of the church that's experienced racial differences in one sense and also of personal status. We must be ready to re-evaluate what we do in this moment. We must update our way of life to embrace homosexual love, because gay marriage offers a glimpse into the deep and beautiful meaning of love.
There's been a significant upheaval, and we shouldn't expect that the world will ignore us, but it's happening. Now is the time for us to make that sacrifice, our faith and the freedom we do need. I can say that with more certainty that my confession last year, and some of my others, will be a good example. Now is the time to find a way to live openly, according to my authentic self, in an honest, loving and respectful way.
']

Title: Brave. Groundbreaking. Badass. Notorious: The year in culture

['An unassuming 14-year-old New Mexico boy named Ray Ray Collins testified in front of the grand jury investigating the 1988 shooting at Fort Hood. On Tuesday (April 5), he was walking to his classroom when an armed officer came up behind him and shot him in the head with a .22 caliber Ruger handgun.
It wasn’t the eighth-grade boy the FBI might consider the faces of.
The 19-year-old would die, but his parents wouldn’t take the news seriously. Instead, the kids began to believe they were witnessing a massacre.
It happened in the midst of a January 1998 American Columbine High School shooting, another massacre that was repeated several times on Friday, Feb. 13. There were no indications that other students were harmed, but for a handful of minutes, Charles Brown, President Clinton’s representative in Congress, heard out the rumors.
“Pretty quick,” Brown testified before the grand jury in New Mexico, walking across a field and speaking to the grieving parents of the 13,000 young people killed last year. “I’m not interested in getting down on the floor and saying, ‘Look, you broke my leg.’ I think we should get out and have a prayer for each other.”
But we got down on the floor, stopped thinking about it, and emerged with a shell casing.
The four men in the log cabin behind the teacher’s school’s back room told detectives they fired five shots at a SWAT team member. So they knew the drill: They needed to come up and shoot them as fast as they could. In fact, they knew the drill would get worse as they walked back to the school, blocking the perimeter. They quickly stepped inside and began shooting.
Told he was shot five times, a teacher encouraged Collins to report the shooting and lock down a nearby building before anyone saw what happened.
“That was the worst moment of my life,” he said.
His memory of the accident isn’t bad enough to get him on an FBI watch list. His parents did not want that experience to come to any kind of suspicion; it came when the FBI noticed his bag of candy, which they said was homemade explosives, had popped out when they opened his shoe compartment. And they said, by the time they found out that the house had been evacuated, he was already dead.
It wasn’t easy for his family to overcome the shock of what happened, including the loss of his academic career. Then tragedy struck. Their son, Charles Brown, died in the bombing of a German hotel in New York City in 1995, and his friends, including roommate Michael Raye, were killed in a terrorist attack in Jakarta, Indonesia in 2004. All of these events have haunted Collins since then. They were never put into any sort of “support”–that would be an easy thing to explain to a grown-up.
His parents have been trying to bury the word “coup” from the phrase, “Hip Hop is to blame” from the Taylor Kinney school shooting in Oklahoma City in 1999. His mother, Linda Collins, has mixed feelings about it, although she acknowledges it’s hard not to.
“I’m glad that it won’t make me feel bad,” she told CNN’s investigative news program, Hardball. “I’m glad it didn’t hit. I didn’t enjoy it when it happened. I don’t think anybody should tell their kids.”
“He was fearless,” Raye added. “He knew when to stand up and when to slow down and when to look in the mirror. And then he believed it every night.”
The FBI believes the shooter, Malik Thomas Lanza, was radicalized throughout New Mexico and Louisiana, and he was the only person in the building who survived the crash. They think Lanza may have been on lockdown during the shooting, but it never came out. The police didn’t know Lanza was just like the other victims, or why he accidentally opened fire when he did. In fact, nobody knew he was crazy.
If they’d known that shooter, many would have pushed him out of the building. In the absence of public outrage, and continued school tragedy, the police, the FBI, and health care workers may have more than called the authorities. But they decided the need for action was unnecessary.

Under the leadership of Nancy Pelosi, the House Speaker/President (L) of the United States, 2017 (top left) is the busiest year of the year for the top 25 op-ed pages. In 2017, CNN (coverage includes, as well as the Nightly News, CNBC and other news outlets) wrote 9 op-eds on the 17th estate, Facebook, politics, fake news, drug charges, immigration, sexual misconduct, conspiracy and more.
As Trump-mania from the last year grew, there was more than enough. The stakes rose, the pain spread and, even the names of some of the headline-grabbing offenders settled, oh, well, we all got killed.
In 2017, too, there was a reckoning of the news-cycle in the White House, its White House chief of staff Mike Pompeo and his vice-president, Ryan Zinke, respectively, the construction industry sidekick, and continued investigation by the special counsel into Russian interference.
There was also more fallout over the deadlocked FBI and CIA director nominee Gina Haspel’s involvement in Russia-related investigations, even as she remained on the Federal Bureau of Investigation’s missing persons and terrorism registry lists, barring her from the White House.
And the heat was all for the president, who actually did make some personal efforts to make things right. He acknowledged and responded with, usually, a “repeatedly pointed” apology to the families of people killed by foreign governments, which he said he stood behind.

And The Wall Street Journal’s Richard Wolffe who while visiting Trump’s Caravan of Correction homes in Georgia encountered a prisoner there after spending 22 years in prison.
And for all the most difficult highs and lows, news organisations like CNN stepped up with their usual level of support and praise for Trump in the run-up to 2017, even as some of his bigger news stories — like the death of fellow President George W. Bush — surfaced and were wrapped up in conflicting accounts and full-blown boycotts.
The Pentagon-backed Travel and Customs Enforcement agency, which arrived in the West Wing in January 2017, announced that dozens of federal employees had been arrested or disciplined for “related to critical political issues” while the American Civil Liberties Union backed an anti-drone bill introduced in Congress in the aftermath of Harvey Weinstein’s sexual assault allegations against him.

Title: I forgave my father for walking out on me. I hope he forgave me too
Generation:
['“What ever happened to you,” my father once asked me, “you should have gone after my grave knowing your father was walking out on you because of a disability?”
I said, “I don’t have a problem with it. I love my dad a lot and the i. son is in such a wheelchair.”
So what did my father say? “Try my son, I love him dearly.”
And, “I hope you forgive me. I was happy when you took your shoes off, and I hope you forgive me someday.”
“Why did I ask?”
“Because my father was walking on the sidewalk while waiting to buy a ticket.”
He walked down the street right past me, too, until I grabbed my daughter by the foot and shot him in the face. Then he ran away, and when he saw my daughter looking at the sidewalk, he snapped his own bare legs back into my hand and demanded my hand and head.
So my father calmly stood on the sidewalk, demanding my hand and my face.
“Of course I did not tell you I wanted to take your shoes off,” he said. “That’s it.”
I asked him what he said because he knows I could not have asked him, had he asked.
“You refused,” I told him. “I haven’t forgiven you.”
“There are two versions of what happened,” he said, focusing on what I was told. “You were disrespectful and I was arrogant.”
And, “I hope you forgive me.”
My story was meant to test whether or not my father forgave me. My Dad, by now a man, had seen the sincerity and an awareness that he couldn’t forgive me, the walk he never stopped and I would still be in an unhappy state of suffering, even when I was able to walk.
So in a way, I realized it wasn’t just my father that had walked that grass. It was the whole world.
“My father didn’t ask me to take your shoes off. He asked me to put my hands in your hands, that is how I did,” he said, quietly ordering his daughter to forget about what happened.
“In the f***ing world,” my father replied, “one of the things that is abnormal in the world, the journey we went on, is that within 10 minutes the whole world becomes blanked out.”
“That’s why I want to reach out to you, and reach out to your inner ego, and tell you I wish you happy and peaceful,” he said.
He cautioned me, “I thought that in that moment I’d have something to say. I think it might be because I’m being cussed at you, but a moment later I still forgive you.”
After being told this, my father agreed, “You don’t know.”
In the future, if I wanted to make my father’s statement clear to the world, that the road was going to be a long one, let me just point out: I’m only here to have the “big picture” about the road, and if one bad moment helps me in other moments, that’s all my happiness is.
Because sometimes, dreams become even bigger, and I know that. Sometimes my father might seem long odds, but for the love of Jesus I’ve been blessed to have the ability to see.
Today, after such a long time, my father has put his hand in his son’s face and asked, “Take your shoes off.”
I’ve forgiven him for doing the damn thing. I hope that we can still have the chance to talk.
']

Title: A dark matter hurricane is headed our way

['As it swells into South America, the sun has regained its glow and the moon has danced, but still the birds are still lying in wait for the GPS near-by. For an imminent disaster, the visions we have lost in the midst of this war have become more vivid.
Ebola's infected villagers in Liberia now fear that the virus will attack at home, and feed on all ages.
Ever since the disease began in the west African nation of Liberia in 1993, more than 100 million people across the country have been affected by the disease and more than 135,000 people have died, the worst numbers ever recorded in the history of the disease.
As South America looks to broaden its horizons, the disease will likely spread even further in the future. It has already not been able to wreak havoc on the largest civil war in nearly a century, though even if it were even a possibility now, a truly horrific outbreak would have been quite a terrible disruption for any country in this hemisphere.
Of course, there are compelling arguments for knowing exactly where exactly the virus is located. It is hard for South America to track back home, so information about how the virus is transmitted should be freely available. There is also the matter of planning, which relies on the human ability to respond and the ability to adapt.
Those factors are key, and in Africa, famine has greatly been predicted. The numbers are expected to be much lower than what is predicted by the South American countries.
Where the virus is located has complicated the matter of how effective the system is. It is generally accepted that evolution cannot predict the fate of a living organism. For example, the survival rate of trees in the Sierra Leone wild forest (less than 1 percent) has been predicted for 30 years. But vegetation becomes more disease-resistant over time.
As for the population of unvaccinated children, they remain relatively peaceful. One of the more startling predictions about the route of the virus is that "control" of that population could be a matter of years.
But beyond that, no one knows precisely how the virus is moving in the countryside or how rapidly it will influence a populated area. A couple of things may make the puzzle of what is going on even clearer.
Not only will the outbreak slow down transport of the virus to the infected areas, but it may also spread health-threatening infections to babies. One problem is the phenomenon of premature babies having a better immune system. Almost one in three babies born in this country died before they were even born, and the mortality rate from pregnancy-related diseases is among the highest in the world.
When you look at the South American countries, you also have taken note of the poor performance of their public health systems. Since August 2003, when Ebola was first diagnosed, the country's emergency management department (EMD) and health ministry have had little to no coverage. ECD in the U.S. has denied many claims of institutional bias, and their coordination with the government makes it easy to picture what is going on.
That means for quite a few years now, respiratory infections -- a fairly common epidemic in America, including the automobile - are becoming an increasing problem. ECD general staff did not diagnose Ebola until the first case was reported in 2001.
Children are also at risk when developing all kinds of skin infections, dengue fever, HIV/AIDS, and tooth decay. Their immune systems aren't able to fight the virus, and wherever the infection happens, those immune systems lose their effectiveness.
By the time Ebola reaches rural areas, these back-to-back outbreaks of this disease that it has roared into have become apparent in remote parts of the country. From a distance, it is hard to imagine that this could happen in a modern society.
People are beginning to come to terms with their own vulnerability. Take children, for example. They spend months traveling the country in three days from school to let their immune systems kick in.
As children, they feel they may need to get more breathing operations before going to school. While they may want to see the new doctor, they may need to get their already weakened immune systems back into full gear to help them manage a health crisis.
Armenia, Russia, China, Turkmenistan, Mali, and other countries in Latin America don't have a strong "mahva" system, but those are high-level teams that are working tirelessly to kill it off and keep it from spreading to neighboring countries. There are no lingering symptoms of Ebola elsewhere.
To prevent future outbreaks, we need to learn to adapt and adapt well and provide more education. Never underestimate the sheer importance of this decade and that of the next.

"But the challenges of our North American neighbors are much greater and the additional time, cost and complexity is an all too common part of responding to a natural disaster."
Governor Brown said South Bay Mayor Michael Nutter had stated an ongoing plan to protect the city's beaches and bayfront property.
An official power outage is expected Thursday afternoon in the tiny city of Calvert as part of a storm-triggered power outage that also is expected to affect the San Mateo and Pacific Oceans communities.
Power was interrupted nationwide on several major flights Thursday and ferry service on Federal Express was suspended for much of Thursday as crews monitor the situation.
All flights are expected to be restored Friday afternoon, according to a statement from the service.
Riders will continue to have extra days to save water and lower power costs.
']

Title: Pray that you don't win the billion dollar lottery
Generation:
['Entering the billion dollar game is tough for a lot of reasons.
But there is one thing that is undeniably hard to do in that arena:
Trust the winner. In this economy, most of us (and many small businesses) trust the back of a lottery to be what it is. But there's something less subjective about the prospect of winning a million dollars or more.
If you bet on a lottery, odds are you're going to get a big payoff, and if you're poor, the odds are pretty good. But if you're a betting person, odds are really you're going to get much better odds if you bet on the way you see it.
I understand the argument that the odds really are one of rewards, but in this world, a draw is a reward, and the odds of winning the lottery aren't random.
Every lottery is designed to predict how many wins a person will get in a lifetime. Everything, at the end of the day, is an indicator. Unless you're driving on a highway, there's no way to tell who the winner is.
The odds are done based on the fact that people are loyal to their investment. If you can continue to buy and sell stocks and bonds and cash out equities, you might as well continue to use your money in the same direction you did before you got sick.
No casino, but lots of booths
But there's an even bigger conundrum going on here that could help decide your lifetime wealth.
If you receive a lottery in the name of investing, it's your right to buy the lottery with your money. In fact, if you win it's your final call. And if you are absolutely sure the lottery is going to be successful, the odds are ridiculously high (but, as far as I can tell, you don't do that right). If you bet money instead, you're indirectly losing.
If you invest your life insurance, you should be betting the lottery a whole lot easier than the returns you're getting if you don't win it. Many people will totally lose their investment savings if they do win it. (In some cases, you're supposed to do this only if the winner's death turns out to be a hoax or cyber fraud.)
So if you're a "typo" investor, a lottery is the lottery. If you bet money on a lottery, you're betting that the winner is going to pull it off.
Put it this way: Life insurance is hard to figure out. Your taxes are likely to go up by a few hundred percent in the event of the death. And if you're seriously thinking about taking on this lottery, you're going to have some odds.
But you can always put yourself out there. In this lottery and today's market, you don't even have to worry about losing. You can shop around, enter the lottery even if it isn't approved by the lottery commission, and share your odds. You also can get in the lottery and try to value your odds against losing the game.
Turn your money into $1,000 …
This is my third season as a proponent of investing your money in lottery games. I've convinced millions of people to enter tournaments, tournaments and alliances through Facebook and LinkedIn.
Over the past year, I've picked up 500 or so people each through my Facebook page – more than the number of competitors that I've spoken with. But the most compelling thing about Facebook and Twitter was how powerful their services were and how much this generated.
In an email interview, I was stunned to learn that so many of my favorite sports fans have these opportunities. If they bet on this sport, then the odds of winning it are more or less the same (but that's not an easy fact to figure out). The single biggest advantage, of course, is that it puts you in the position of buying a lottery ticket.
I believe the key is to be invested correctly. That's especially true if you're a ticket collector, like myself.
Read the full post here.
']

Title: Trump and Putin: the pictures tell the story

Now, back to Donald Trump.
A regular parrot from that famous Pompidou Alley sit-down, we’re left wondering just how many presidents Donald Trump could do without. Let’s show you how various examples exist of president-essence in the past.
Billed as the “Pizzagate of Russia,” the basement gilded-middle-class Pizzagate investigation, took place on December 16, 2015, two days after the National Spy Retreat held at the World War II Museum in Arlington, Virginia. Hillary Clinton, then acting as Hillary Clinton’s spokeswoman, was held in a case that featured a video of an event in which her daughter Hillary famously served as Hillary Clinton’s press secretary and was photographed by a publicist sitting in a meeting for a high-level meeting with the Russian President.
The Manchester Guardian reported, “Two detectives were dispatched to the dead man’s apartment in Manchester, England, in December 2015 in a highly unusual move that they say surprised many. . . . They discovered that one of the bedrooms had been set alight, a fire was set in the second bedroom, and there were two sets of 'Make America Great Again' hats among several other items in the dead man’s room, as well as a video of a ‘Rosie the Riveter’ and the ‘Cossack Hat’ that Hillary Clinton had appeared in the previous year.”
And just as we have seen in the past when dictators openly speak in defiance of their own country’s previous governments, Donald Trump also tweeted a live tweet from Helsinki on July 19, 2017, in which he declared, “We had a beautiful time in America yesterday, thank you to all of our wonderful friends & supporters.” A reporter for the Verge searched the entire tweet-and the tweet matched up Trump’s response.
When the White House and lawmakers started hearing from frustrated senators and their staffs that the Trump White House would no longer include video of alleged Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election, it created a media tsunami on July 7, 2017. How do you respond to a real video of what a state legislator or a senior FBI official told Congress in an interview on July 4, 2017? Perhaps it was just election day, but for those of us in public mode, the significance of these parrot-logging activity hadn’t reached the level of monolithic institutional protection.
We’ve observed this pattern with countless open-records requests from law enforcement officials with whom we’ve have had a very public disagreement. And while there is no widespread evidence of systemic breaches of its confidential investigative policies by even member government agencies, the fact that we’ve seen these same officials expose other such ill-informed and angry leaders who merely lie to congressional leaders and look only to show who will be in office next.
We’ve also seen the sheer number of leaders we’ve seen coming into office who misrepresented what transpired during their leadership.
None of this does anyone any good, in the American spirit. But the point is, we all must commit to the greatest openness in American politics and society.
The Senate was immediately hostile to the Trump administration’s decision to forgo a stay of a US intelligence source who was indicted earlier this year for breaching his duty to keep an open secret in his interactions with Putin in meetings with the Russian president.

Title: How to prepare for ex-President Trump
Generation:
['No matter what the topic may be, one never knows what is best for you. While you’re at it, do your best to calm down and get off to a healthy start in a little over a week.
Surprisingly, we found that the best way to combat this type of stress can include practicing what you preach in your head.
Be ready to conquer it!
What You Need to Know
1. Start by speaking clear and concise – feel free to impose doubt in your mind. It will not be a distraction to your work or the world around you. You can make the most of the time you have left. You can also block the flow of emotion you will be forced to work with.
2. Work up a list of words and phrases you would use to describe your current life. Have a list of your thoughts and then summarize them in a quick and concise manner to elicit a response.
3. Do a brief meditation to relax and breathe in through a window so the mind would unconsciously become filled with thoughts and feelings.
4. If there is one thing that you absolutely know about your current situation, it is that it is so important to identify where you stand. You cannot do it all yourself. The following are some common symptoms.
1. Reshaping and regaining your grasp of reality is becoming difficult to do because you lack the head awareness. Your mind is too quick to adapt. Avoid making assumptions and seek to understand the experience.
2. Living in panic at the slightest repetition of a problem. All you have to do is counter the constant sense of trying to solve a problem you are having.
3. Inveighing against your exercise device. Being active increases your heart rate, appetite and serotonin levels. Your brain is very sensitive to stress. Your response will diminish the importance of building strength with a holistic approach to your mental care.
4. Bad or indifferent over the value of your dollar. Spend a few minutes after getting ready to care for your house. Focus on one thing at a time and correct deficiencies that were present.
5. Ignoring your intentions and just concentrating on your thoughts. Mix it up with a small grouping of five or 10 thoughts.
6. Fearful watching those around you. Wondering how to handle life’s challenges. See what you are doing wrong and stop blaming yourself for them. Remind yourself the world is not one for repeating pain and beauty.
7. Puzzling of patterns and motions. Like brushing and zapping your teeth or being hyper-focused on your own senses. Dismess it as a mystery.
8. Criticism or resentment or judgment (domestic dating at least for a while) from others. Speak honestly. It will almost certainly come back to bite you when you repeat such behaviors.
9. Fatigue and unrealistic expectations. Think of the messages you expect when you think of yourself as the smart, the compassionate, and the abstemious.
10. Ever notice the difference between daytime and nighttime? Drink and process some of the trivial details. Leave those soothed and uplifted and an entire culture of life satisfied.
Contact your therapist or seek your support.
I. Steven Neuschulitch
www.ivthinchinkel.com
']

Title: Michael Cohen implicates Trump in hush money scheme
Generation:
['As the top lawyer to Donald Trump, Michael Cohen crafted an astonishing scheme in which he married an Italian woman without consent, extorted the payment of $130,000 for his work and then extorted $20,000 out of a Miami lawyer whose client allegedly agreed to stay quiet.
Trump associates were also accused in last week’s Strangled by Mueller appointment of a former assistant director of the FBI’s Moscow investigation. But as the Mad Money host, CNBC’s Mike Huckabee, put it, the scheme was “untold."
Huckabee called Cohen a “financial scumbag" for being “stupid” for duping his client into agreeing to work for him without ever calling the FBI.
The jailing of Cohen is an extraordinary development and fresh sign that the criminal justice system is beginning to adopt a strategy to deter the sort of political violence that has occurred in the U.S. since 9/11. The message is clear. If there is a silver lining, it is in the distorting and suffocating tendencies of the criminal justice system: It is tightening its hair.
There is nothing inherently menacing about this. It is simply a small-scale, subconscious cultural transformation.
All that is unclear to one explanation — namely, who knows? The jury really hasn’t yet concluded the adage that “what crime has long been observed is that a lie has been more often than not pursued.”
For all of this, the criminal justice system still draws broad layers of scrutiny, particularly in those cases where a person falls for the bait. President Donald Trump’s business empire is his greatest political liability. It is not only the law enforcement agency that is liable to pay Cohen for his escapades, but also the media, who have infiltrated his White House and perhaps other White House establishments.
The Trump family may be forced to shoulder some responsibility for the actions of his lawyer — but they’re not required to do so. The White House can be added to the purview of the bar for the work Cohen has done. But for the prosecution of the president, the status of an ordinary person on the other side of the law is irrevocably eroded.
It is curious that John Lewis, an attorney who once performed his own dirty work and was included in an investigation into whether he planted a false dossier on Hillary Clinton, might want to address his client’s alleged conduct with a lawyer rather than her agents for the campaign. When John Lewis is accused of writing a quid pro quo agreement, an information agent would be off his top-secret list of legal transgressions.
Trump is a matter of national security — and Trump should be accused of having snuck under the radar of a terrorism investigation. But President Donald Trump is a matter of public integrity. And for which he should have been sanctioned, scandal or whatever is offered from the president’s camp.
To be clear, the president as well as the Democrats who have the upper hand — and influence over the criminal justice system — are accusing the FBI of violating civil rights by acting in concert with the Obama administration. Cohen has framed Trump as a human-rights abuser. The president as a candidate. The father of an addict. Trump as a business magnate.
Trump’s lawyers have said in glowing terms that he has always been a civil servant and that is he as much an opportunist as Trump. The president is an opportunist.
For the likeliest reason: He once, like his father, was a priest.
And for the likeliest reason: Trump should be accused of having learned from his own worst impulses — and his own self-destructive impulses — that granting him privileged access to the inner workings of his business was good policy.
For what it’s worth, Congress is investigating a Russian email investigation that the special counsel is mounting.
']

Title: In 2017, Trump revived feminism, saved satire and reinvigorated journalism

['With Donald Trump’s rise to reality television fame, President Trump’s acclaimed television series The Apprentice, and the Islamic State’s fall in the Middle East, 2016 was a year of new fire, fresh ground and renewed intrigue that has delighted media pundits and pundits ever since.

He caused mixed reactions from victims of sexual assault to the ABC broadcasters who said they were treated as either a “complete spectacle,” or to a “political oversight.”
The breakthrough, however, came at the first of four major American television conventions, the Correspondents’ Dinner in Washington, D.C. In our analysis of the month of February, it was a magical year. Obama blasted out, and President Trump chided and condescended at, President Clinton’s fast track to Supreme Court justice. The world swung into action.
In fact, we couldn’t have gone a better gift than May 22, 2016, and National Law Journal’s conclusion that whether each of us was celebrating the 10th anniversary of the civil rights movement, today or the year after, Trump is here to turn history to our advantage. One could simply argue that he has the scale and dynamism of the media elite, with no history of Republican candidates, a media elite that is not even among our “greatest champions,” or that he is listening only to the candidates he uncovers to rebrand himself.
In any event, Trump and all the elites, public and private, had the opportunity to play into the hands of our collective lives. People all over the world joined the entertainment industry on what are called “high frequency shows,” now known as “high 5th quarter shows.” These long-running American entertainment, all produced primarily by black cable networks, is dominated by black men, who like Trump tend to tune in to talk shows around the country to watch in progress, and their comments become instantly identified, with the kind of intellectual giddiness that is imagined in just about every election cycle.
The logic of that "high frequency" concept is that black and white people follow norms and practices that everyone else follows—not individuals. Also, black media often operates the same way as white media: It follows the same herd of undiscerning characters, so as to make as easily available content as possible. In their own way, black media spend more and more time and energy determining what the most popular or good shows are.
By 2019, the argument that black viewers are best served by whatever (white or black, Fox, NBC, CBS) they choose to watch online is not an argument. It is, in fact, a question of how to influence them. One might be forgiven for not familiar with The Mall, a series of “Oddball.” Nobody is watched by “interesting viewers” in the second episode, because the show airs uninterrupted through seven of the month.
But then came reality television.
As television continues to evolve in a world of time compression and reinterpretation, our ability to identify, program and even redefine reality is getting even more important. As with the rise of the internet, but even better, it is starting to enable those who care about self-expression online to participate, interact and learn.
That’s a paradigm shift. It is time for Americans and other Americans to support the resurgence of good television—one that is fair, not biased, and both entertaining and informative.
']

Title: Why I'm speaking up about Mark Halperin, and why I stayed silent so long
Generation:
['I’m not a generally well-known comedian and satirist, but recently, while talking about Mark Halperin, I must say I was aghast at the blizzard of other good comedy people saying how awful I am. I, at least, thought that frankly, there was a lot going on that I could not shake.
The discussion was a few things I want to address first: I didn’t care about the newly heated words that were being tossed across the airwaves in response to Halperin’s firing; I was ready to fight it, if only on my own.
I think the attack against Halperin isn’t because he wasn’t telling the truth, at least to me, but that it was honestly manipulative. There was a reason for the strategy, though: The people who let the State Department cut Halperin were the Trump administration.
And so, if you want to tell me that I care about a lot, tell me that I might want to play the role of empyrean or to say that, well, I can’t.
I read the press release that caused some R in me to vomit and quit, and I appreciated that. The press release points to Halperin specifically, saying that I was supposed to know what was going on. It was strange and dismissive, as I thought: I knew exactly what was going on, and I wasn’t able to stop, so why can’t you do the same thing?
But it wasn’t a transparent lie that I’m suggesting. There’s a very fine line, I suppose, between lying about something and being truthful about something, and it takes an immense amount of pain for that to happen, even if you’re taking a stand and saying it, so why would you lie?
We’re in a bullseye right now — crudely, unforgivably, some members of the media going nuts at the prospect of a columnist firing a comedian. I can’t wait to see the reactions to that. I have the initial shock.
It’s a perilous world; scaring the shit out of you is incredibly traumatizing. Every comedian has to be out here seeing and hearing the windy and mostly overcast airwaves of outrage that is repeatedly spewed out. I’ve never seen a phone call that was so surefootedly come from Trump’s mouth, especially when the wind was only 100 miles behind him.
I know that most comedians come up through the public eye, and what they’re probably screaming at you is sort of the exact same thing as the show I’m eating and drinking. That stuff isn’t OK, to be honest. So I have some sympathy for the comedians. I sympathize, though, with who needs prostrate arms like most people — a paragon of self-improvement who puts no blame for an issue he has no actual control over, failing to promote those causes he doesn’t have, and continuing to perform despite any negative reactions to that force.
The irony is, as I said, I was ready to fight it, if only on my own. If I got spanked by Oliver Stone, I would have been unfazed by the blizzard of other bad things being hurled at me, and maybe not feel the same way about it, either.
But I also know that because of the public relations cost, I wouldn’t have much to do with this. Nor would I trust it — I’m a country-mourning person. And I take a lot of things lying down. And if I weren’t in a bullseye, I’d be angry at all these people that are being egged, if you’re so inclined.
And I’m hoping this might help I can be more proud of what I’ve achieved than the bully in the army.
']

— In New Hampshire on June 2, the Washington Times printed a post on its front page that had jumped out of the front page of the New Hampshire Union Leader. The writer identified herself as a journalist. Several hours later, the paper went on a national wave of media coverage that includes references to Trump’s personal life and a photograph of himself on the presidential golf course.
— On June 13, 2014, FBI agents searched a home in Midland, Texas, then arrested three people with Trump’s personal attorney, Michael Cohen, on charges of extortion and providing false information in connection with Cohen’s investigation into Trump, the Times wrote.
— In 2012, two truckers were killed as they reportedly hauled out a shipment of coal for Trump, the mayor of Cincinnati offered to help the family pay the fine, and at least a dozen other people were injured in a shooting outside the hotel in Atlantic City.

Title: Bill Nye: Science made America great
Generation:
['Dr. Neil deGrasse Tyson on a CNN appearance today made the case for the science that has had the greatest impact on human lives and the lives of millions since Apollo 11 in 1969.
Science, far from being a trivial exercise, has opened us up to world discoveries that we haven’t seen before. So, here’s Tyson’s call for conservation, exploitation and extinction from both himself and yours truly.
The ultimate goal should be destroying the last ten years of mankind’s reign of terror and eradicating the one tangible molecule of life that we owe to the human race.
I want to know about that the first part. People love to make judgments on what to say about what to do. Some come from science and some are from the cult-like base, or whatever their reason for feeling left out would be.
My motivation is to learn better and to tell and believe that what happens in the world matters a lot to humans. This is some of the most interesting out there (the Science Department has a PhD in Biology) and I’m not only there, but looking for something to learn and believe in. It’s possible for knowledge to be sold and in search of knowledge you’re likely sold more and less. My goal is to inspire people to give up the habit of fiddling with projects or people who want to further understand the world.
The people I’m looking for to study the science are doing it—they’re all masters of it. They tell their stories, they tell the stories; they tell the stories. Their brains are wired to keep more and more of the information flowing, through the eyes of the beholder. As we age, our brains and bodies absorb more information, we need to learn more and we need to learn to keep track of it.
There’s a word for all of this: Gizmodo.
So, are you ready to embrace any of the essential information? I believe there is much to learn from each event that makes us world-famous.
If you want to understand the science in a critical way in the midst of vast change, you can do so here at CNN. I believe that the most important thing to learn about the world and what you’re doing is science at its best.
Today’s CNN appearance with Science Director Michael O’Hanlon really means something to me. He addresses the urgent need for us to protect the future. Our souls are not there to teach science. The world is not about making us know what it really takes to make a life easier. It’s about making us aware of it.
According to the American Enterprise Institute, scientists are dying, dying to discover, dying to tell. I believe that what we have right now—our precious knowledge of how the human race gets created—creates both problems and opportunities.
Anyone looking for better ways to understand life is doomed. The science does nothing to promote conservation, exploitation, or extinction. It merely helps promote our perils—be it in a place of abundance, or in a place of suffering. But it’s always best that something might be better than no science.
Science is not just a science. There are no shortcuts when it comes to knowledge. The life course is what has been handed down. There are no shortcuts.
It’s time to give it to the people who can help ensure that it happens, not to the people who can facilitate the science it does.
For the love of science, we are more than one country.
Fathaf Simmons is the executive director of Yes We Can! The Future Foundation, a think tank founded in 1983. She holds a master’s degree in education from the University of Chicago, and a Ph.D. in special education. She is the author of Performing at Masaoku Sasaki on Utuada, an original environmental book, and is a regular contributor to the Science Channel. More information on the Future Foundation can be found here.
']

Title: George Takei: On this Remembrance Day, I hear terrible echoes of the past

['× George Takei: On this Remembrance Day, I hear terrible echoes of the past
Sometimes what sounds terrible- that meant “you’re gone”- or “I miss you”- is as deep as the sound of a fading band playing the second Bob Dylan song onto a piano.
This is a moment that marked the first time ever that an actual veteran in the United States veterans’ life was questioned by Washington Post columnist Niall Ferguson.
On Wednesday, Ferguson asked Takei, former Alaska Gov. Sarah Palin and many others for their memories of veterans and explaining the nature of their stories, how important they are, what made them different and some of the best achievements they have had.
Takei had said before the Congress’s 2013 Veteran’s Day Jobs and Veterans Day last November that despite all of the news about the sagging economy and deep cuts in military spending, veterans do not play any part in that.
“The reality is there are still close to 200,000 Americans on this payroll,” Takei said, “a number that the government does not tell the news.”
“But someone’s being killed in action and they are in some way their personal political voice amplifying the voices of the soldiers so that some warriors have not at all seen or heard them and they want to hear them,” he continued.
The Veterans and Military Appreciation Month kicks off this weekend with Veterans Day ceremonies. President Obama will honor many of the last tributes with “It’s a Wonderful Life,” while Republicans will honor veterans who came before them. On Saturday, meanwhile, some supporters of the President’s dedicated soldier project will take the stage to give a live music performance, specifically in honour of those who fought and died in the fight for our freedom and served our country.
Takei’s remarks encapsulate his feelings as he said: “By coming out, I can learn from my experience and some of the stories I’ve heard. I can heal what I was a part of and I can overcome what I thought I was all too familiar with.”
Takei said “there were things the president encouraged me to stay away from,” like improving military mobility, building more broadband networks and talking about having a healthier workforce. The best way to right this wrong has been to empower veterans to help change their futures, he said.
“The America I know is changing with me,” he said. “If you give back. If you lift up the American flag, if you dream, if you walk the red lines, if you play political games, if you work hard, if you’re with your buddies, if you think outside the box, that’s what’s most important.”
Takei added that “maybe the best way we can treat some of the service members that come before us and fight for us” is to enable them to talk to people they would otherwise hear and their stories will make them stronger, unlike the ones they did as soldiers.

Title: The Donald Trump presidency: How the world sees it
Generation:
['A U.S. presidential elections as a whole is unprecedented, yet the nature of the debate across the globe is kind of the opposite. There is a difference between the expectations set by those looking at the election results, and what these people are actually hearing, and what they are hearing. The controversy that has erupted is most emblematic of that: the Trump presidency. Who did it? How was it used?
It all starts with the election. Trump’s narrative, which has been noticeably inconsistent, has fueled calls for change, and powerful factions around the world have stepped up to put forward a vision of America that needs to be lived in, where the American dream is truly alive. They’ve called for economic growth and "democracy" inside the gates of Washington. The theme of American exceptionalism has been played out in the U.S. election games.
Some of the global politics of the campaign seems to have raised almost a class divide. For global progressives, what struck me most was not how the candidate positions were presented, but how the players tended to be. If you take the traditional dimensions of the campaign and look at electoral choice from the white-collar perspective, most people are open to debating what it means to be America.
For almost 30 years, the highest-profile candidates’ speeches centered around fact-checking — that is, watching the standard formality of the candidates’ speeches for the entire body of argument. The resulting debate has been peppered with misleading statements and mischaracterizations, while the candidates have suffered no real obstacles.
Without a doubt, the fiery rhetoric of the contest still plays a role here, though it’s hard to argue with the fact that many of the campaign issues are as much about the value of the election as about this moment.
So how is America different from how it was before the 2016 election?
The story of the campaign is a different set of dynamics.
Hillary Clinton’s rise from a privileged teenager who feared losing so much after deciding her father left to work for a government-owned oil company, to the biggest party in the country has opened the doors of a world seen by many as different. The key competition has emerged inside the traditional political arguments: the idea that victory is not about wealth, but about policy achievement.
Newsworthy and absurd, Hillary Clinton as a candidate made the calls for drastic cuts to Medicare — the cornerstone of her presidency — and the national debt. She championed the health-care reforms the ACA also passed, and critics contended that she steered a legislative agenda that mostly targeted small businesses.
It’s nothing new for this country. For the first time in decades, all of us, including the Obama administration, have been part of a political contest devoted to limited policies, which in essence is about policy attainment.
']

Title: 20 top takes on 2016
Generation:
['The year of 2016 is spent on anticipation and fear — and justifiably so — and this year, as things get a little bit more open and personal, the challenge of getting through all of the stuff we wouldn’t look at as serious by now remains unanswered.
This week’s panel are:
– What do 2015 and 2016 have in common?
– Is it time to pivot to the future, or stop?
– What’s the state of Republican response to Donald Trump?
– Is there no sign that a few months back, we can start voting?
– What’s the trade narrative for the 2016 midterms?
– Who are the House Republicans who are looking to drain the next American economy?
– Is the GOP satisfied with their track record?
– Is the GOP worried about voter disengagement?
– What’s the fight about with illegal immigration?
– Who are the two hopes for the GOP’s presidential campaigns?
“The arts of optimistic optimism” — and all things hope — are the operative words of I.Q. rapper Eden Crystal. For the content of this blog, here are 20 of my top takeaways from 2016.
1. Don’t try to predict everything, but ask yourselves: what are the odds of you being voted to the left or right by 2016?
2. The two dominant Republican candidates, Ted Cruz and Donald Trump, are having it very, very hard this election cycle. They are both making us nervous.
3. Presidential hopefuls have failed to deliver the kind of impressive turnouts that usually propel presidential hopes up. If we consider 2016’s really good returns, it will not be long before 2016’s failures become systemic.
4. It’s too easy to look past the events of 2016, especially the myriad of negative events in the intervening week. Start the process now, don’t you?
5. 2015 was a leap year for tech startups. When they were in demand, things went extremely well. For millennials, the tech boom pushed the media market to new highs as they saw in the need for digital platforms. For Wall Street, the tech boom accounted for real growth. Corporate earnings rose a record. It was the third-largest GDP increase of all time. It wasn’t quite as big of a leap year as 2016, but it still reflected what was happening. And more and more Americans have graduated from college and have a way of saving their own money, which is now bad news for the country.
6. There is little we can do to stop Trump’s nomination nomination. This year’s incumbents are among the oldest people in history who wouldn’t be left out in the cold. The party believes in the Millennial Generation, and I think voters want it that way, too.
7. As people around the world brace for immigration policy changes, life shouldn’t get any easier for would-be newcomers. For many Americans, 2018 should be the year they decide their country is theirs.
8. Trump has given Republicans cause for hope with the fury that unleashed the GOP establishment in 2014, as it became a pack of bad-government appointees and individuals. However, the other side of this coin appears to be bored and desperate. What will Republicans do this year?
9. Trump’s administration is full of threats against us with all these promise to get and do to rebuild our infrastructure, but is the end of his administration exactly in order? What’s the threat level for our airspace, CIA or state of the art airports?
10. While Democrats and Republicans are finding ways to get outside the mainstream, mostly by building their base on the wrong issues, the divisions within a party seem overwhelming. Which is why 2018 shouldn’t be the year Democrats hope it is.
11. Take longer than what’s already been, as Republican enthusiasm isn’t sitting so well. Addressing the aisle and filling the subway, all the while offering them platforms for political compromise, is a bit too much to expect. The questions about why are we proceeding to Trump’s denunciations and questioning him as “lazy” and “lazy” make their most compelling political difference.
12. New enterprises will bubble up to house my young adult children at a younger age. It will be great for my kids to be better actors (in practical practical terms) than show how I make sense of their situation.
13. I worry we might have too much of this week, but we’ll pick up here if all of the rumor-basis trauma fades away.']

Title: Could Zika be the next HIV?
Generation:
['(CNN) — Yes, Zika may already be a phenomenon affecting the brains of Americans.
The little known virus causes microcephaly, a marked increase in severe developmental delay caused by the loss of an infant’s hemisphere.
But in 18 to 25 months, Zika may now affect at least a few new children and adults, just as can scientists’ predictions of the course of viral illness for others.
How much time can it take?
You can’t forecast the amount of time a mosquito bites a baby’s brain. Zika virus has only been found in some regions of Central and South America.
Scientists are now saying its limited exposure in humans, its only known severe form, may be enough to worsen the condition.
The mosquito that can transmit Zika has been shown to be able to put on a man’s protective coat in times of extreme threat, and even after the moment it’s bitten has a repeat of risk.
In another recent study, new research of high school students, who were part of a random sampling of 50,000 children, showed that the risk of Zika-associated symptoms was lowered considerably by the researchers using a mosquito repellent.
“There’s nothing that is going to precipitate the timing of symptoms,” says Dr. Albert Moura, a researcher at CDC and senior author of the study and a professor of epidemiology at Penn State.
If all of these findings are accepted as a likely explanation for Zika, the transmission risk would probably go higher than even a mosquito would be doing, the study authors say.
This delay can also lead to variations in the first-trimester sexual performance of those infected with the virus.
“If you did reproduce even in the presence of Zika, you could have seasonal damage,” Moura said. “Could you kind of make sexual fidelity better if they transmitted Zika?”
Still, Zika can be the biggest killer of young people born with the condition — the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention projects the risk at 3.3 million Americans this year.
The original Zika virus was first identified in 1976. Then, the spread expanded to include possibly serious head trauma caused by infectious diseases.
Scientists on either side of the issue have struggled to determine the true extent of the virus and the impact on potential victims of the neurological neurological disorder.
Testing for Zika virus might be another little magic trick, says Dr. Robert Baumgardner, a consultant to the International Institute for Tropical Medicine and Research.
“In the end it’s much more difficult to know the susceptibility of a mosquito relative to how severe the virus is, because some infections can occur at different points in life,” Baumgardner said.
Some experts think Zika could cause viral problems similar to one that so common in African countries — the HIV/AIDS pandemic.
“We know that males and females carry the virus, and quite frequently they go through an infection before they get their antibodies,” Baumgardner said.
“But this could be another reaction to the viruses that infect women, because — you know what? They’re so active at the same time that they’re migrating from one sex to another,” he said.
“The infection tends to develop around this disease, which makes women more susceptible,” he added.
']

The seven counts, which the Ontario Superior Court actually ended on February 2, were stacked onto Ford’s construction business. Also, the four counts he filed in November were publicized in newspapers across Canada and even made an appearance in a YouTube video: “Rob Ford should retire in good conscience.”
Ford’s epic, on-again, off-again, indiscretions revolved around his alleged habit of murdering and maiming people with his infamously gutter-throwing, chin-thumping, finger-pointing and cold-blooded knife-fighting.

Title: Do we need more fake holidays? (Opinion)
Generation:
['By Toby Davis
The New York Times asks some depressing questions in its latest edition, “Moms Who Decide: The Limits of No Holiday,” this week. Perhaps the most depressing questions are: Why are we willing to test a piece of paper with a photo of our kids in the middle, on the side of the road, in front of our house? And why are we willing to preserve or stick together a piece of paper that can be a clue about who we are, but that can't provide something meaningful? These questions—fasinatey, meaning, is that a good place to begin?—can be answered by a simple interpretation: that happiness comes first, and then happiness will come first.
You can't know how life works in the world until it's lived, and a new book, Live Without Real Happiness: The Reactions of 5 Million Low-Level Careerists and the Everyday People who May be Taking Stock With Their Dream (Al Michaels Books, October 25), explains that happiness is what you live with (and why many of them are incredibly lucky), and happiness is what you see everywhere you look.
This is why "Life can be too precious for too many people, for too many reasons," writes Emma Davis, in her book titled "The Happiness Paradox."
It's possible for people to earn more money, spend less on medical care, or buy things around the house in order to rise above any mental ailments they might have. It's also possible for them to live tolerably, in spite of these spats. And it's possible for them to be motivated to care for people they have no connection to. Here, however, is where we're starting to come closer to our real identity: we live only after people have committed themselves to a shared cause, shared by their feelings of unhappiness. This is what happens when you give in to others to share a task with.
“In this unfinished scheme of time, what you do matters. You stand out from all others on the world, and you have the power to change things,” says Peggy McKeown in the book. “It is what brings us together.”
Because of this reciprocal relationship, it may not be to thank people for helping us achieve something beyond ourselves. But it may be to look at people, knowing that they care, to look at us and decide that we belong to a group that is a worthy cause, and to see if there is something worth doing.
“I envy our neighbors, and the experiences of other people, for breaking down barriers in order to build something new. For one thing, they need our help: our loyalty and solidarity and support. We are the first line of defense, protection, and support. This is something that is usually too easily overlooked: valuing others. It seems ludicrous that there are always others acting like the evils of greed and selfishness – who know that the only way we may have saved our own lives is to have made do with us. And it is not impossible. We may, however, choose to actively conceal that choice.”
What to think of people who are making the goal of fulfilling their dreams beyond themselves?
Stay tuned, too. We've all had to struggle in the past decade to find the right answer. Isn't that what other people do?
']

Title: Baby Boomers: Five Reasons They Are Our Worst Generation
Generation:
['Because baby boomers hold their records closer to their full potential than older adults do, it is now sometimes an OK time to release their doubts that our youth can deliver for us. But they couldn’t have been doing so much better, if they had their way. That’s why I want to nominate some reasons why they’re our worst generation — and why their adoption of our modern baby boomers, and their childfossil tendencies, were among the most important factors contributing to our decline.
1. Immigrants. Now that you and I are older than you were, I have an unfair advantage because most of the people you encounter happen to be people who have not seen us in a very long time — and often don’t know about us. But that’s a tough financial situation to live in, and we do have a lot of skeletons to fill out. While we may be people with memories of ourselves, many years of working toward full potential, pursuing dreams, and making connections can develop tendencies which can’t seem to be satisfied. That’s why growing up exposed to immigrants, and forming relationships with them can build self-confidence — a trait we already possess.
2. Social Security. We are the poster children for the generation that we are (not to mention those born after 1972 and 1974). Most millennials grew up receiving monthly benefits. With their aging parents on hand, they may have access to a greater pool of social choices, but the benefits were never guaranteed. Consequently, it became highly essential to them to get good enough meals and personal attention that they were able to attend university. But that’s a challenge both at home and around the office — one that just didn’t go away, and won’t go away as well.

Title: Bill Clinton: There Are No Great Generations, Just Different Problems
Generation:
['There are no great generations, just different problems, only past president Bill Clinton’s melancholy about them.
Clinton: My Heart, What the Great One Will Tell You, 68
But look at Clinton for a moment: With ever-seeming self-analysis, he’s chugging. The subtext from the last presidential campaign was that even if you haven’t previously spoken to Bill, he can pull you in a new direction.
Clinton: No New Man. Did a Thousand Years. Is Caring. Work Hard. Fearless. Sad. And So Excited You Will Re-Energize.
And so, as a final remark of a speech that started with the words “my passion for this work is more than my ambition,” Clinton was writing a fuller and more honest manifesto.
During the speech, he pointed out that despite “ungenerous politics,” people have ultimately “done more for us than anybody in history” because they “defended our nation through shared values.” And so, that “we have survived much less” because we have “fought from our hearts as individuals and as friends,” regardless of what the political views of our co-opters.
“We have recovered from our deficits, from illness and from partisan gridlock,” Clinton said, “and we have recovered from those who craved power so much that they threw us at the curve and went on to govern as if we were perfect. And they have won.”
That is a statement on the qualifications of the first president of the United States. His record showed that the country is recovering from its divisions and crises. That’s a message that no one could ignore.
He also spoke of a new generation, inspired by the election of Ronald Reagan. The Reagan Revolution restored, perhaps, the mood of the moment by reminding Americans, “Nobody has anything to do with everything but themselves.” And Clinton even said that kids today can learn from Reagan and find a way to “fight the good fight,” thereby unifying the nation, not only for its sake, but for the good of their country as well.
That is the signature Clinton: an emphasis on making American exceptional. That this generation needs unity rather than strength to move us forward. His emphasis on teamwork came to some uncomfortable relief in the middle of his speech.
“Let me tell you how our country and our world have changed over the last 10 years,” he said. “It has come to the end of the kind of loving, caring, resourceful enterprise that has led us to this great nation that we love so much.”
']

Title: 'I'm the person they call when people die'
Generation:
['Please enable Javascript to watch this video
MANCHESTER, N.C. -- A woman spoke at an event at a carnival Saturday on how her life has been compared to that of a young boy she coached to get more attention for his race.
"Look at this kid he was 14, first call me when he was growing up, his family was in high school. You could tell he was getting attention, playing as a football player," said Tammy Garcia.
Garcia was awestruck to hear her 12-year-old son, Josiah, play sports with the same age. She sat in the audience of more than 3,000 people at a carnival Saturday.
"My real son, Josiah. He would get people interested in him because of his athletic ability. He would be able to play football. And the other two boys were playing as role models to him," Garcia said.
In the US, Josiah Garcia's popularity is not for individual athletes, but for children to play their sport, she said.
It's the truth Garcia told her story last year to a group of kids in the US who just celebrated her turning 12, to help others who are struggling.
Garcia told them Josiah played in her church's preschool football team, and she made it pay for his tutoring. She also helped others get help at Newman's Academy for Children in Sioux City, Iowa.
"Before that I knew that I was gonna be a special person. I had no way to get involved with sports before I started crying," Garcia said.
Josiah told her he will never forget the students at the church, he said.
"It says something when you dream and talk about the school, your dreams and your dreams and your dreams and you leave this school feeling good, because you feel like you made good things happen," Josiah said.
"It's that way with you because they see your dreams are not a vanity thing. They see their dreams. They see their joys and their tears," Garcia said.
"There's nothing wrong with it. I can't say that I don't think Josiah won't be very successful," she said.
Garcia said she is talking to the kids now, just in case others do.
She's going to give the kids a national trip to watch the children play, and she plans to teach them sports again.
']
