Title: Is it ethical to colonize Mars? (Opinion)
Generation:
['And you thought the new wave of space travel was experimental. We don’t yet know whether the Earth is already colonizing Mars, but, perhaps, it does. Perhaps, we must now ponder what countries including China, India, and Pakistan are doing to colonize the planet.
These are just a few of the troubling developments occurring this week. From blustery nature to environmental questions to crippling emission controls, it is both great and disturbing news that two areas of the planet are planning to colonize their own host bodies. According to a Washington Post report, SOBANES—already known as “U.S. Road Greenhouse”—is now effectively trialing its own land volcanoes.
We simply can’t allow everything that is set for mining to end in this way. The hilltops are toxic, man-made, and interrelated with the rest of the planet. Acid has a toxic chemical meaning it reduces water productivity, energy usage, and socio-emotional effects on those of us living on the planet. According to climate projections, acid spills will increase dramatically in the coming decades. (EPA is currently working to curtail carbon dioxide emissions, although the latter effort is being slowed because of continued public disapproval for the project.)
India and Pakistan are following in their footsteps by colonizing Mars. Positron emission projections show that by 2022, similar popular concepts in exploring the Earth will be repeated over seven times in the next decade. (In fact, World Vision’s Planetary Accountability Index shows humans, elephants, and other endangered mammals (actually those in Africa, Asia, and North America) with more chances of being impacted by climate change than any other group in the world.) The demands, if anything, for increased access to space on an ongoing basis might reverse the ecological and economic benefits of colonizing.
The power of these developments is being felt worldwide. Some refer to them as “fossil fuels.” But they’re largely a monetary ploy. Until 2006, many globally geared fossil fuels flowed out of China and India into the South Pacific. The result was an entirely unregulated fuel-allocation of resources. A remarkable sums of money have been funneled into the developing world via plantations.
Brompton Hotels Inc. started in 1983, offering eco-oriented accommodation in West Africa and Indian Ocean islands. Their pioneers say the hotel’s founder, Thomas Foster, Sr., designed his own nest in the Indian Ocean to enhance the tribe’s governance.
Since their arrival, Foster, born in Jamaica, has been the archetypal yesteryear, a “triumph of wilderness,” “land for profit,” and “family home.” Foster has developed a vocabulary that translates to “east of the world,” “coast for profit,” and “new frontier.” He’s directed commercial efforts to countries that come to him with a new appetite for experimental approaches to designing home offices.
The gradual dismantling of the grain-control systems of mass-production in the 1970s and ’80s (cost-cutting and terminalism) and industrialization in the mid-1990s (job-creating, and usually legal, materials) made the option of colonizing more and more difficult, and expensive. Foster’s saw his irretrievable mining technologies seen as just as stunningly feasible in the coming decades. They can hold up to the difficulty of operating these lightweight resorts, which keep the temperature of the atmosphere well below 40 degrees.
Foster’s eco-civility model would be refreshing, and why not? It holds that people create new “connection” to nature. “We will be able to physically sustain the environment by loving our environment. We will be able to share it with other people. Then, there will be a bottom-up model, with each of us contributing to a new host,” he says. (The best line in the book is “on our own.”) And he’s showing his new species for the world.
']

Title: How 'Back to the Future' blew it
Generation:
['DEARBORN, Mich. (CNN) — An aging pop-culture phenomenon such as the "Back to the Future" generation wasn't very happy about the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles get their own series.
It wouldn't be the first time, according to the best-selling toy line, a group from Lehigh University has tried to make sense of what it means to be a student.
In an interview, the group asked the Walt Disney Studios to help break down a Hollywood movie's history and provide a new chapter for participants, such as a New York city clerk.
After a yearlong study, the nonprofit group finally launched the "Metric Ecosystem Plan," which was intended to lay the groundwork for further research. The plan is to help gather information to see how millennials and older adults are progressing through the digital age.
"We're hoping to collect as much info as possible, particularly from millennials who have undergone the transition from the device to the digital world," Robert Shaheen, co-founder of the Metric Ecosystem Group, told CNN Money.
The project will feature researchers and psychologists from the University of Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania State University, and the University of Michigan, along with Hollywood executives. Shaheen said no productions have ever been on the stage of the Studio Theater or PPL.
"It's the first time we've done it," Shaheen said. "We'll look at how all the young people are doing it."
In addition to the report, the Metric Ecosystem Group has published suggestions for the future.
The Walt Disney Studios tells that programming for future generations will help increase the company's ability to reach millennials. One way: sending children to the park, Shaheen said.
"Over the next 10 years, probably you won't see any production about using the park system to collect data," he said. "It's a little bit of a time bomb in terms of everything going on."
The Metric Ecosystem Group was formed by a panel of scientists, developers and "youngsters" who thought kids would be interested in seeing how other people in the group were doing, Shaheen said.
"It's probably like you bring up a Jenga or something like that to fit in with the millennials," he said.
He said that the group wants to improve connectivity and tech for young people. "We want to make sure everyone has a place to go after their breaks," he said.
']

Title: I was the unpopular kid. Now I'm a parent. Here's what I learned.
Generation:
["It is hard to tell parents apart from the wide world around us. They are everywhere. They show us how to consume smart words, how to understand meaning, how to process concepts with life. They tell us what we need to do to make a better future.
I have the good fortune of being far more self-sufficient and flirting with routine, much less feeling the compulsion to navigate the possibility of most of life's serious questions in the open like wonder, crisis, optimism and patience.
I was more anxious and detached today, feeling the sorrow of those bereaved by their loved ones. I was more adventurous and aware than most, because I had been one before all this. I have less curiosity now, more curiosity in my own life, more joy in my own life. I am on a different planet now than when I started school; I am so much happier.
My liberal values -- Freedom and Spreading Communication -- are clear now, as is my deeper caring with those seeking peace and relief. It seems to me that my economic values do not apply today, because I'm finding it harder and harder to do this than most. It is more difficult to focus. My thinking, on this presentistic, ephemeral moment, now suggests with increased clarity the fast-paced mode of education that justifies further engagement and control. Not after my college days, but after my marriage collapse.
I am spending a lot more time getting more out of life, less time travelling and more time thinking about activities, less time arguing and putting the things in order. All of which, combined with sadness, makes me miss my wife, more than most of her other attempts at making our futures happen. She wants us to look at things in a different way, but what she actually hasn't yet looked at since college is her thoughts.
On a recent afternoon, I was at the Potomac Arts League, all of us wandering around the modest home we shared with our family. Like a gymnast, we have had very little time to focus on the positive, the empty, the unfruitful.
To me, when I would be in the garden at night, I would think a little differently of that kind of life. I might be depressed, tired and worried, more than I know how to accomplish.
To the children of our world, I speak of hope. The opposite is true. I believe that the language we speak in these days of optimism and freshness can easily translate into selfishness. A victory more seriously than anything else can easily be taken away from my hopes.
It is no longer at all apparent that a triumph over humanity can be won. But this moment, and the fact that I had the power to make it happen, were not broken days ago. It was still there today -- ready to form, in my desire to hold the conversation in two ways: for positive assessment of one another, and for seeking the consolation of peace in my search for meaning in others' and our shared lives.
* T. Chewy, the author of three books and a course on the life of a vegan, talks about her special relationship with salmon. She taught in New York City from 2003 to 2007 before moving to Oslo in 2010.
"]

Title: Biden on 'Colbert' -- shockingly frank and noble
Generation:
['Everyone knew that Vice President Joe Biden would not become the first American elected president from Delaware. He looks a lot like Donald Trump. But he's a grownup, thoughtful and talented writer. He's a hunter. He picks up wounded animals. And on a television show on Wednesday, he shared this profound wisdom with NBC's host, Stephen Colbert.
In the years leading up to his election, Biden also shared this talking point with the world: the importance of getting the country's troops home from Iraq by August. He didn't like it, and was supportive, well aware of all of the problems that the country was facing. But when Biden decided to leave office, he had a different worldview, an honest answer about life in this place, an honest outlook about America.
He tells me how in college he wrote a profile of former Vice President Dick Cheney, and it was leaked, and on his Facebook page that day, people were pointing to him as the only guy who wanted the troops out of Iraq and Afghanistan and starting wars for Obama's youth.
"It was arrogant,” Biden said. “We might be morally on the course to war, but we are doing it with the best energy we have in the world and we were not willing to wait."
Biden didn't need to go somewhere and stay there. He chose to go back home.
When I asked him what he wrote in the cover of "Colbert," Biden answered that he wrote back to the Clinton Foundation he and his mother were having a soft spot for, and it wasn't just one bad day.
"The Clinton Foundation," he said. “I was lucky enough to be among a group of Democratic officials working with a woman who was willing to do just that."
When my friend Julia shouted out that her husband had voted for Hillary Clinton twice, Biden said she could have no recollection of the night, so he didn't come out and say something out of the blue.
“Every Democratic insider or special interest group knows that Debbie Wasserman Schultz, the former chief of staff, hasn't been a true friend to Mr. Obama or to our country in terms of service and credibility as well," Biden said.
The problem is, with Biden, it is clear that we now have a party whose primary event is the presidency. And he told me that even at the time, "you know, we could have re-elected George Bush, or there would have been just a country war with Syria, and then we'd turn all that around."
The president of the United States, he wrote, "lied to the world about the possibility of a nuclear bomb and this was it,” Biden said.
“While we may not have fought the longest war in our history, it is clearly been the center of a lot of our attention as we engage in major policy transitions," Biden said.
“You know, you end up needing close control of your mind and you go into a completely different world for the first time in our history," he said. "And on top of that, if you really think about what happened, the fact that people went out into the streets not knowing who was leader, who was leader-in-waiting, the press covering up their mistakes, the public view of the American government, that somehow it's not us that is going to make sure that people are informed."
In a world where the president of the United States is the leader of the free world, the first to step out of the shadows and speak up for the people, how can Biden be any different from Obama? His presidency should be a remarkable memory.
As the country and the world go down the road that will determine the fate of this nation, Biden reminds us, we're going to have to win wars, we're going to have the international coalition, we're going to have the major cities armed, and we're going to have the rule of law.
Biden has been living with these truths for over 40 years.
I'm listening to the vice president get he answers out with your head. It's not boring.
Now come on. Tell me: how can we win wars, and Obama and Bush won wars?
By Larry Kramer
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today.
Video of Vice President Joe Biden's speech to the VICE BET Awards was being shared on Twitter and Instagram. Click here to see the videos.
']

David Schmidt appears on CNN's 'The Conversation' on April 5.
The flu is a lethal scourge, especially in people.
You probably haven't heard the phrase, "searched, swabbed, checking you in" since 9/11, but I don't think that to be too bad. Such tests are numerous and mandatory. They're mandatory if you want to test yourself for infection.
I keep telling people I have a policy of looking for lab tests they can do and not only the test for quacks, but also other complications, such as barbiturates and bran. Before the test even ends, one must confirm yes. The key here is the two of you have to reach some sort of genuine pairing. Unless you're constantly tested they won't. The shocking thing about this sickness is we cannot convince people to eat better because there are too many nutters and hens. They don't come to try that old chap or become peanut butter. We do have custom testers that can help people. We do an obvious flagellation test for lab sperm. They say to themselves "it does work" and tell them to try it; and not just pretend.
It's important to use real tests even if it's imperfect. The upsides of putting a novel test together are most damning. They'll confine humans to simple plot twists, spoilers and time travel. And they don't meet anyone who does, but they've done the research they need.
If I had a question as to which he or she was a prophet - if at any point in their life that has happened to a woman, I don't want to be like that or why I keep being so quick to discuss it on Twitter, don't get me wrong - I would feel as though my question had already been answered.
People tell me they want to have more risk. It's wrong. The correlation between risk and survival rate is ridiculous. If I wanted to be perfect, I'd have told myself to go out of the way, to avoid dealing with crazy people. Why in the world are we making so many deals with who could really have possibly knocked us down, why do we think it's all down to pure luck?
My answer to that, please, is that a couple of things will get you there.
Gently resist the urge to assume what other people will think, and avoid the temptation to just be like them. Think for yourself. Read the entire Laura Ingraham classic I Love You: the Life of the unborn and study the fetus. Put yourself right, all the way through a six-month abortion. You could ask the judge if you had a miscarriage or if you thought the fetus was killed and if so, you could begin to see whether you were morally obliged to do so.
If you have an abortion or a miscarriage, shame on you. The psychological realities are so great, and the losses are so real that it's almost inconceivable to "play it safe." A clear, unequivocal threat of eternal damnation, a reality that is indefensible and utterly repugnant.
I would not advise you not to do this. Whatever your experiences may be, do the right thing. A proper marriage, two men, a viable economy, not just wealth. That's where we keep our children. Like, the dad or mom, lose their jobs, get paid very little. Unless, of course, you've had a bad relationship.
I'm sorry. God bless you, you put your bodies on Earth and pay for it. Good luck.
']

Title: How outrage over Cecil killing misses the point
Generation:
['Re: “Cecil problem: We can’t allow a smaller government,” by Jonathan Franzen, March 30.
My dear Jonathan, please, do not overreact! You have spoken and in actuality you understand the international debate over Cecil.
He was a human being and a sick man that made a huge impact on the social and political issue that many have asked about. In fact it is our job to ask if he was treated well and if he treated me fairly.
There are other issues that are also worth examining.
Secondly, it’s a matter of self-explanatory question. Is that good? Are we too focused on the elephant in the room?
Thirdly, it comes to my question about genetics.
Though genetics is my strongest objection to the debate.
I don’t have a scientific degree but I am a writer who writes stories about the experiences of every human race and it’s my view that I should be included in discussions that have me going to the Parkes Center for Human Genetics & Human Reproduction, Uppsala University in Sweden and leading and ill-informed individuals who love the trees.
It doesn’t work that way.
I also know that this debate over C. Cecil and other Cecilian attacks misses the point. I won’t comment on this topic unless it comes up in my lifetime, but it definitely does not capture the attention that most people have been asking.
Many countries, including the United States, have a diverse and sensitive population.
Cecil and I are allies. So who thinks the world might have been better off without the Cecilian? We don’t want it to happen.
Some people are clear about what they think and what they feel about Cecil. Some people are tactless and afraid of it.
']

Title: Top CNN op-eds of 2015 (so far)
Generation:
['Hot off the controversy of Donald Trump’s immigration speech in D.C., CNN rounds up some of the top CNN op-eds of the last 12 months, out of Friday’s 100-plus published Tuesday morning.
The sharpest disagreement appears to be this paragraph in February when Trump described “caravan immigrants” from Mexico as Americans.
“You don’t build cars at all, that’s the problem,” Trump said. “People like you, who hate the Mexican people so much, that they actually don’t love their neighbors, that dislike their farmers.”
This comment is almost certainly Trump’s most popular and vilest comment of the year, serving as a recipe for his downfall and leading to a range of other high-profile immigration controversies.
Here’s a head-scratcher that jumps out at us:
“It appears to be the most controversial comment of the year.”
“I still believe in (immigration), not just your religion.”
“I am personally against immigration for 100 years. But if the government took away my choice of supplier to help me pay for my college education, is there more to my religion than that?”
“I’m deeply offended by ‘ethnic cleansing.’ That’s just not legitimate.”
“My great-grandfather, first Mexican American president, took millions of slaves. He’s called genocide.”
“If there’s one country there are any who are, it’s another country.”
“The commonwealth is many people of ethnicity.”
There’s no much of a back-and-forth about this point, but they appear to be coming at it in different ways.
Last month, for example, Trump said, “When they come, you know you’re going to be destroyed. And there’s no merit whatsoever in it.”
The single sentence this paragraph addresses so critically is this, which ought to be avoided at all costs:
“Many of you are privately religious, but everyone should get along, regardless of their race, but many of you are in love with your neighbors because you have brothers who care about your neighbors. The great pride of your country and your neighbors, regardless of religion, is tremendously important.”
The comment above falls short of completely cutting out all of the support for immigration from the faith community that follows with their support.

Title: Syria crisis: How world should respond (Opinion)
Generation:
["Syrian President Bashar al-Assad may not look as spectacular as hundreds of thousands of Syrian refugees in the most ravaged parts of the country. He is well beyond the reach of weapons supplies or humanitarian humanitarian assistance. Even among these, his regime is clearly confronting hundreds of thousands of enemies – indeed, many new and often great enemies.
Assad's regime increasingly relies on chemical weapons attacks to suppress its resistance to its very existence. Syria's refusal to disarm has brought new threats, namely from Iran, as well as from Russia, which has been exporting its nuclear arsenal to Iran. If Syria does not simply arm and assist Iran, including through greater military cooperation, the same regime will have enough weapons to stockpile 24.5 mm mortar rounds, all in a matter of minutes, while millions of civilians are forced to make the grim choice between continued use of weaponry, starvation, and the potential to inflict collateral damage by sarin gas.
Most recently, Russia approved an agreement between Syria and the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons to deliver more chemical weapons to the United Nations that war-ravaged government still denies. The agreement is huge: over 500,000 chemical weapons weapons have been seized in Syria for over a decade. That is enough to put civilians on the brink of war for at least a year.
There is not an excuse for blocking the implementation of the deal. The Assad regime still claims that Russia will not allow its poison gas supply to restart, but NATO countries such as France, Turkey, the United Kingdom, and Germany have already asserted that they will not allow the delivery of this gas to make any claim on that side of the equation.
Any confidence in the determination of Syria to fight its chemical weapons must be restored immediately. This would enable the arming of Syrian rebel forces to gain ground and make life tougher for the Syrian regime and its fascist militias.
NATO has recently joined the campaign to arm the forces of a Syrian government that lies in direct opposition to the US-led coalition on the ground. Most recently, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg has voiced doubts about arming the Assad regime, which led to the most recent escalation of violence in Syria. President Obama and Secretary Tillerson are not backing down.
Syria's detention and addition of at least 14,000 prisoners as part of this campaign are problematic. In addition, Syrian forces have arbitrarily detained and tortured dozens of potential recruits. At the end of the special session last year, 84 detainees were reportedly beaten, the Guardian reported.
Though the Syrian government denies many allegations, the UN criminal investigation suggests there were many more. At least 52,000 Syrians have been detained in recent months for alleged rebellion against the Assad regime, many of them members of the ISIL (Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant) militant group.
Although the opposition refuses to accept it is possible to negotiate the consequences of any agreement. The chemical weapons attack on Assad's forces amount to beyond-human-level sabotage; failure to cease production of chemical weapons would be a U.S. stalling (and ultimately, a humanitarian disaster), and Western allies would be badly affected by such a move.
In time, Assad may have a willing ally in this agreement, such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar, which have resisted weapons transfers for a long time. If this country disputes their legitimacy, support for Assad becomes a priority. Even if those countries did not support what is happening in Syria, they would reject the agreement because it would be highly discriminatory toward the country.
With Russia, Iran, and Turkey opposed to the agreement, those US, Russian, and European allies will have to go after Syria's own people because it already remains one of the most oppressive dictatorships in the world. The wider world would suffer if the United States were to impose its laws on those countries, threatening their worth as proxies against them. A democratic and civil society in the Middle East requires people who share their values, for example, to do so without fear of terror or Assad or their sponsors pulling their levers to advance a regime regime that has been the result of unfair military competition for nearly 60 years.
Without support from the United States, Russia, and the Western Alliance, Assad's regime would be effectively punished for its attacks on civilians, ending in mass killing, and ending the country's legitimacy.
"]

Title: Why can't America have high-speed trains?
Generation:
['Most people use public transportation for pleasure. But can they afford high-speed trains? They pay almost no tax. The cost of the mass-transit system might be increased, if we had a plan for low-income riders that would be cheaper for folks who don’t have the best track and can travel anywhere in America. That’s why Amtrak and the Transbay Transit System continue to look skeptically into such a concept.
From my perspective, the Amtrak model seems like a start. If we envision a way for low-income, job-seeking folks to buy elevated rail tickets and take Amtrak trains, the train could meet their needs.
Most people are already on the roads. Train travel isn’t nearly as disruptive or convenient as it would be for the very frail, just-less-mobile, upper-class or middle-class. But on the average, rides won’t be pleasant. You get involved in and around disruptive, unmotivated snobs.
New, cheaper, urban-ready public transportation just isn’t on the radar screen of American voters. Congressman Jack Kingston (R-Ga.) has long been a champion of a rail-ticket idea, proposing a proposed $60 billion rail ticket system (see his excellent article on Rails-to-Trails and Transit (see page 5 of this section). Kingston and his colleagues have yet to finalize a funding proposal for the proposed scheme.
We have never had trains — train tickets, say — as transportation or for any other good reason than because people can get to and from work. The price of day-to-day commuters is probably high. But we have not had trains and I don’t know what the cost of long-distance traveling might be. Many people find rail-ticketing silly and costly, but they know that’s not how it should be. For years the cost of travel has been high — it is $170 for 20 minutes or more — but that’s just not the skyrocketing price of real life.
Of course, there’s a huge economic, societal, civic and cultural impact of Amtrak and the Transbay Transit System. Even in the best of times people are really poor, and government regulation has been appalling. U.S. investments in infrastructure are plagued by insufficient security, lack of proper mapping, poor transit data and poor transportation data.
So, why, if we’re so keen on Rail2.0 and the future of this country, would we sign the Paris Accord to save American jobs? With the alternative, that is. The only viable route to make this a reality is train tickets for people like me. There are 100+ transit options on the big national plan — including high-speed, all-rail and rural trains — and if we don’t include only a low-income, job-seeking race-crawl-only option, that cannot fly. We can. Now we can.
Now this is just a good idea. I think it makes the progressive, the working-class, the public-to-tea-sister-in-heart part of the system much more progressive. Of course, when we find ways to reverse public education — and it’s the top cause of 21st-century poverty — we might consider ordering lanes of all modes of transport and adding to the gridlocks of roads.
Most people would be left to wonder if that’s how much we should spend money on mass transit if we put our collective voice at the forefront of the debate. But, if a train ticket-ticket idea works, it might make a lot of sense.
']

Title: The marriage apocalypse may be coming (Opinion)
Generation:
['So what is the state of society and the marriage system that is supposed to be more effective as a more confident society? I believe the answer would be good marriage.
Your marriage system has always needed the same tools as it did at the time you were a young widow. As a stillborn child, you could put your mind to a variety of travails and keep doing what you wanted to do. It was a pleasure to use one's free will to attempt to save yourself, and not for financial gain, but to create bonds based on value and happiness that could continue to allow you to marry in a meaningful and loving way.
I don't believe that you can go back to your old ways, but I hope you've learned a valuable lesson in how not to tell a man how you can't marry. And don't give up on the good things in your life that you already have. For example, if he had been divorced, or he lost his job, what type of relationships would you choose to take with you in this day and age? Would you give yourself the little moments of happiness that you have already lost, or would you instead take the step of taking a better look? Of course you would.
If you are writing this, it may not be your fault if it happened to you; I think all those who had the misfortune to hurt others don't know how to get their relationship back. If you did, it was your fault. I know of no model for redefining the marriage system to allow other people to define the freedom they have to live happily together without massive amounts of responsibility for their relationships, and because one's own romance and emotion are just as valuable as one's own potential, you owe it to others to take care of them.
It is important to distinguish between the people in these marriages and the ones in the union. You need to look at the gender of each individual as the reason for their independence, because a relationship is not created for every pair but it must always be allowed to function for that individual to have.
Marriage is also about growth and change in relationships, for one human being is a last resort. You can't ask for an invitation to grow more deeply. You can't bring in so many people to save you. And while I don't think you could simply dismantle marriage, you do have to find ways to make it better for your marriage.
But if your marriage is good, how could you let yourself feel unhappy, frustrated, or broke with your spouses? Perhaps you chose the more "normal" one, the more difficulty you could find in marriage and the additional stress it puts on you, or may not be able to maintain enough tension for you to stay together. How can you provide that stability?
But don't let your marriages teach you a lesson. Try to find each of those moments where, for some reason, you have to find a way to strike out, only to regret it later. Once the bad loves are settled down, the good ones can live happily together for a number of reasons: divorcees get to continue to go to therapy; less children are raised, and you work at attaining them.
Sometimes you even are willing to cut out your family's ties. Is your marriage system the result of a breakdown of communication that is now becoming a rarity? It is tough to endure when our marriages are broken up. Not only have you not been able to get along as a couple, but at the same time you have reorganized yourselves to get closer and closer to your goals.
All relationships are good. Two man/woman marriages are good. But marriage and family relationships are good too.
Your marriage won't last forever. There will always be ways to manipulate relationships to give you more control, but the best strategy is to recognize that it may not be what you want to see for your marriage or family. And perhaps even sooner.
']

Title: Without God, life is still meaningful (Opinion)
Generation:
['Our humanitarian founders included three defining themes within this brave history of humanitarian intervention: the nature of what we do, the desire to teach others, and the final destination.
After a particularly eventful decade, our best years were defined by the sublime project of moral imagination: the birth of the human being. In the not-so-distant past the reader was dealt with by the dynamic aspirations and emotions of a child or woman who had fought for their lives for liberty. Now we are witness to the wholeness of our vulnerability and the swagger of our courage.
I have often been worried about the limits of our commitment to our humanitarian endeavours. It is reassuring to be in the midst of a mission of service to humanity. More than ever a glimpse of our genuine hope for change from these remarkable stories captures our heart. Even when we were on this journey, what was most important in our lives was our humanity and that of children. We can remember the saddening grief of this girl, however, to whom there will be little hope.
Many of the accounts of child soldiers presented changes in our relationship to children. The story of Fatima has been challenging to bring to light, as when her father was killed in their country of birth. The mother was not comfortable with the weight of her son but was full of feelings of helplessness that her own mother still found unbearable. The war in Iraq showed a desperate side of her daughter.
But there was no quick fix for the pain caused by the loss of a child. We saw the suffering in more direct ways. After the disastrous war in Iran, there was a renewed and painful focus on the loss of her loved ones in Iraq. The clear battle line is still yet to be drawn between Iran and Iraq.
As we eye the future, the caring that is the hallmark of humanitarianism is the hope for the future. This optimism is a release from our pain and our anxiety.
The journey to fruition of humanitarianism serves to raise the faithful children. But we must recognize that this journey is also a journey to the survival of humanity. And no matter how difficult the task, there is a home in which all involved can move from crisis to triumph.
This is something that one senses when we examine and reflect on the historical and theological truths to come. We recognize that calling for the impossible can help us rebuild from the catastrophe. We see in our eyes, our hearts, our aspirations, our hopes.
“We cannot deny that there is something that we know we cannot change or that the ability to prevent it is under threat,” Jesus says. We promise the conquerors that we will not give up, no matter what.
By E.A. Canton, Graduate, Ithaca, NY
']

Title: Nudity doesn't shock us anymore
Generation:
['The audience in Paris was treated to our same disjointed response to everything the governments around the world have been shunning for the past decade: nudity.
That number was 75% for two moments, and most of us almost exclusively laughed, mostly because of a skewed view of the planet.
Last week, the French government described a far-right manifesto on attacking Islam as an "extremely offensive misrepresentation" that attacked the "of Muslims" and treated Muslims as villains.
Allegations that cartoons mocking Islam exist were immediately dismissed by the new French president, Jean-Marc Ayrault, and dozens of leading comedians. Some don't support such cartoons, others did, and have denied any responsibility for them.
They wanted to promote a second Jesus "to differentiate between evil and good."
After all, we're not trying to radicalize we Muslims to paint him as an evil, anti-Christ.
Nudity isn't more important than a repressed, scarred version of what goes on in the mind.
Most people were probably surprised to learn that in a recent survey the French were remarkably opposed to pornography for adults, nearly as much as Turks and Italians. The reason for this surprise: male and female nudity was common among French women - the latter a respectable 51% in 2011 compared to 36% at the time of the survey, according to the Cartel magazine.
"Nudity is a sign of respect and understanding," said Emma Ferrie, a feminist author who first got an interview with a writer 20 years ago called Dan Hooper, who didn't have any more coming to mind.
After an interview with the interviewer, Ferrie asked how many children have told them about their childhood nudity, which she explained has grown to include "designancy, pornography, influence, painting, film installations and more in other ways."
But a 2009 French poll found that French adults are much more likely to believe the disrespect of the religion was significant than that of many other countries.
In an interview with the New York Times, historian Jacques Upis disagreed. "Nudity is not really a bad thing," he said. "It's a very public thing. It's not an 'overture,' when there's still visual relevance. The problem with it is, it's a really unimportant image in terms of the cultural identity, which is very important. In fact, people are furious that there's nudity. But it isn't any different than much of any other contemporary image."
That doesn't mean that women and men would be offended.
"No other religion is more considered a taboo than women's sexuality," Ferrie said. "Nudity is, by definition, something that involves a group of people wanting to be liked. The idea that you have to be sexually attractive, and that you have to be strong, which is only in my reading of the Internet and in terms of my social media, and yet, you do have a lot of that underneath. The situation with pornography is much more oppressive than about a society where that kind of surface is overregulated."
Recent French presidential elections bring a new wave of controversy surrounding the country. Prime Minister Manuel Valls has been accused of avoiding routine election duties and of mishandling polls, an apparent touchstone for voters' frustrations and a criticism that Valls was being too close to his people, who elected him when an activist dubbed Valls a sex killer.
In his annual State of the Union address, President Emmanuel Macron has made a number of controversial moves, striking a hardline tone with President Trump, releasing a list of vague proposals and announcing he has personally called on Trump to intervene.
France's opposition parties have called for Valls to be removed.
Amateur election observers and a leading league in online voting saw the use of "nudity" as a weapon in the battle for a parliamentary vote in the lower house. But those opposed to Valls' plans may find the frequency of nude pictures in French elections to be concerning.
Those who don't want to be surprised that so many countries regard nude pictures as a taboo.
"Even so, it's in our blood to tolerate nude pictures," said Bastille Day celebrant Jean Hebranna. "Nudity is not an automatic phenomenon. It's just something that can happen everywhere."
']

Title: Why more women choose not to marry
Generation:
['As transgender women have continued to have a louder voice on their issues – after an outbreak of the first stage of transitioning from male to female, nearly two decades have passed since a New York Times article asked readers what a life without regard for gender identity would be like.
After fighting on a grandiose dream to “lose weight without getting hurt,” Kristen Morgan, a transgender woman who accepted the de facto term “male,” wanted to announce her positive conversion to a trans woman. But then Morgan fell for a reality TV reality TV show called “The Color Purple,” which described the impossibly physical transformation Morgan would undergo to accommodate one’s gender identity. It was a temporary phenomenon, and her conversion story from male to female didn’t end well.
As a mother of girls, Morgan has made some unfortunate mistakes. Like admitting her gender identity. Like having given up her customary male position at the altar because she was suicidal and when the Bible was very angry with her he said, “Your natural body will follow the mistake, but that will be your downfall.” For that, she was beaten, starved, and put on a bone-headed diet. And then her editors at the Times implored her to meet their publisher in Washington D.C. to meet his publisher, Brooke Spector. It was an accident, the Times reported.
Here’s what Morgan said in her defense, according to The Telegraph, “The deceit!” this side of that. We need to stop losing our support for our girls, our friends, our sexual freedom. We need to stop gaining status, earning status, and avoiding a peer pressure that may make us angry at one another for thinking they can have a knee-jerk reaction. And we need to stop being told we must conform with what the Bible says about self-consciousness. We can never deny that we must take extreme forms of parenting.
Despite the masthead and prominence of those infamous advertisers, the transgender community remains the most aspirational and offensive media plaything in the United States. Like Hitler’s inspiration and the Holocaust – they all came from nowhere. About 46% of the population identify with their past gender. The total number of people labeled “transgender” comes to just over 50 million. That’s about the same as what women make every day on a daily basis in the United States.
It’s time for the Times to let readers know that transgender experiences are not only plausible but sustainable. We can defeat transphobia with a message that is culturally informed. Men and women need to go fight for equality without being depicted or spoken about. We need to fight for the same issues women face today without being at odds with them.
']

Title: Do You Use CBD Oils for Your Child?
Generation:
['You know, our struggle with such overuse of disposable medical products.
People are well aware of the fact that CBD-containing products—a category in which the oil does not contain any cannabinoids—are regularly sold as prescription medications. However, they’re not the same as they are considered to be.
Of course they are, for the same reason as the rest of us: Also, it’s cheaper than counterfeiting, and manufacturers can actually market more to consumer with the greater flavor. In other words, for the brand, the fragrance of CBD is rated 7-10 for its technically “intelligible” effect, according to the Aphution Center, the world’s biggest bath and body lotion exporter.
That’s not all—users can use some of the product to inject themselves with the drug, of course, without also cutting down on the amount of distress caused by it.
There are many smart people out there who love CBD and don’t need it. They rarely miss a cold in medical school, a comatose, half-naked male homeless mother who can’t even eat her nightstand alone and only goes to bed later, or perhaps, when they know he just hasn’t gotten off the booze, a naked and drug-addicted sick b*tch, or their loved ones who don’t want to put him in the hospital.
Of course, “open secret” about how CBD feels and tastes is not something you should search for, so maybe you’re afraid to ask.
Of course, it is impossible to tell what you need if you don’t consult a professional.
So when can you get CBD-based products or make a homeopathic bath made to use the drug? Here are a few suggestions.
Bafflingly, the best advice is to just use a bath for it. Because that’s what CBD does in terms of alleviating pain or suffering, you never want a woman dying of lung cancer, ever.
CBD lowers the pain threshold, which is perhaps why a woman suffocating with pain for such a long time seems to have a profound mental sense of humor.
Only a clinical team of pharmacist would recommend this. How could they not?
Most women with allergies have difficulty plying their high levels of CBD with sunlight or water.
For some women, CBD is only a supplement. It is a D compound (also called KER), which is used as an antidepressant, as well as weight loss supplement, for that same reason.
The only legal thing is that it is cheaper than public consumption, but there are a few medicinal and agricultural products that offer most, if not all, benefits of the brand.
So, we’re thinking only well-known CBD brands might offer you a chance to show you what is possible and how it could potentially help you and those around you.

Title: Why Does My Kid Prefer My Partner?
Generation:
['The question that is being asked in the American consumer debate is: why do my friends prefer my girlfriend? Usually they are blunt. They argue about it so much, they would presumably change it all over again if they could. Being a couple might not seem like much of a deal to them.
But these friends are skeptical. They are not passive consumers; they are creatures of habit. They don’t obsess about trends, rules, budgets, relationships, or marriages. They are normal adults who never made any move to the next one. They can be clueless, just like Adam, Nina, and countless others who constantly struggle to comprehend how a pair works.
The four of us were sitting at the computer dining at friends’ house when this didn’t seem like the situation we would need to be in. I brought a friend in to support me. I asked her if she would like to change the date, someone who lives somewhere outside the US, made some suggestions to Z’s, and asked if she could promise we would, again, be friends with our future partners.
I was not going to tell anybody not to be friends. However, I was comfortable with the idea that we would be friends and we would commit to each other.
She was taken aback. “Well, how would I know?!” I said.
“Your girlfriend might be better at being a partner. You might be more intelligent,” she said.
There was only one more eyebrow. Now I was beginning to cringe. I thought a lot about myself and most of my friends.
“Who doesn’t want to be friends with their girlfriend?”
A few of us received more responses. Some of them gave us a glimpse of what our preppy friends might be like, like fancy dresses and aviators to feed our kids and a leash around our dog, and all of them took those suggestions as though it was an American classic. There was a whole many more of us who may know a single woman from listening to a punk rock tune than from going to a high school band dressed in drag.
There are a lot of people out there today who have been just tuning out their girlfriends for like 10 years. Most probably think of them as raging sadists and will do anything to not be my boyfriend. But at least one woman who goes through such a difficult time is not there to knock off your girlfriends. She would be much more willing to settle for being the one being the one giving an honest honest assessment of her partner.
I can only imagine how traumatic it would be for many women to be their girlfriends when they are confronted with something they have no choice but to say: no, no, no, no. They are no better human beings than these girls. “What do you want to know? Title: We Want to Hear Your Tiny Victories
Generation:
['
Are We Real Enough?
There’s the question: Are we real enough? I have to beg you to just say yes. This is such a good question. I have more than 30,000 emails floating around the web begging my question. As their criteria for answering are legal, physical, moral, and reality-based, this question becomes much more complex than what they look like. The difficulty is, they are tough questions to answer. The real challenge is not how everyone is answering them, but the difficulty of making them known.
Hopefully this problem will soon be addressed. For those of you who know me, I am a wacky morning warrior who uses email to get out to social media to talk with my friends and venture into the real world.
However, there is a way I could have done something that had less communication stress. That is, I could have demanded that they either give me a bigger voice, or give me information which would better serve my teleconferencing abilities or me and the other human beings around me. I am constantly being reminded of the burden of both! If I’m not being served, who are I supposed to feel important?
The argument is simple. If I have a short and deep awareness of what is happening and am constantly receiving requests for information, and have that information revealed, I am simply getting in on the action!
My question is, What is the urge to tell those not to please me? Is it because I want them to please me? And, where is the logic in this? Why do I have to feel this burden, and that isn’t my response?
We already have the reputation as “wacky morning warriors” who constantly succeed in breaking news in order to run papers. Remember those stories of the men trying to fight against drug dealers? Even those stories that I heard about were altered in an effort to promote this story.
Showing no apology would not go a long way to help anyone break into an organization which is effectively “wacky”.
When I am facing end, I can feel the increasing sensitivity to my abilities to be outspoken, without having to correct this issue, or I can go forward with my activism. The issue of authenticity, and then there are these things I have to come up with …
There is always an element of truth or truthiness to be found in the response of a “Wacky morning warrior” to an “annoying morning warrior”.
Having an opinion is integral to the freedom of thought, where people are free to express themselves. The C++ and SC requirements that come with Web analytics and operations are the foundation for a level of analysis which is much more efficient than doing real science. If you want to solve a problem, publish a page, publish a report, publish a piece, publish a blog, you need facts and words to get out.
It doesn’t matter if you want to use protocol or jargon to compromise. It is the truth that matters. We need to redefine our moral order because we need the truth. Without it, your email needs to be “wacky”, just enough to not be considered an effective platform for human communication.
I highly recommend reading a book by an expert like Ed Hickey. He has authored more than one column for Sports Illustrated and is an inspiration for all of those reading these articles.
I hope someone else will follow his example, but I do hope that the subject of people trying to solve a real problem will come up … that is what I have become more of. I would like to hear your opinions and question: What are we Real Enough? What do we want to know?
']

Title: Congress Nears Stimulus Deal With White House as Wall Street Suffers Rout
Generation:
['House Republicans defied President Donald Trump's push for more green jobs and deep spending cuts to create 700,000 new jobs and empower government-owned electric utilities, a four-month stopgap bill passed by Congress Thursday afternoon.
While presidents have ended their hostage takings by canceling important payments over time, the responsibility for sending other lawmakers to negotiate deals with the White House rests on Congress. That is, until later this week, when Congress reconvenes.
That impasse makes it difficult for Senate Democratic leaders and White House officials to negotiate an overhaul of the nation's capital's financial system. Leaders have said they will reserve much of their consideration to the long-term fiscal cliff of tax hikes and spending cuts — if not permanent increases in tax rates — that would plunge the economy back into a recession.
Click here to check out CNN's economic coverage
House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., said he was confident that congressional leaders could make a joint workable deal to deal with the fiscal cliff. He joined liberal Democrats in passing an $85 billion bill for health care that ends the federal government's monthly subsidy to insurers. McCarthy was joined in passing the money with the bipartisan help of a smaller package of trade-balancing measures that included protections for workers at large auto-dealer operations.
"I look forward to a very long and fruitful week," he said.
'A merry mess'
The House had elected Trump to represent his Florida home on Tuesday, but so far, he has not worked closely with lawmakers he ostensibly thought he might. Prior to Tuesday, he had been allowed to say no to dozens of bills through the first half of his presidency.
Asked for a side-by-side comparison, Republican Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., said he had not heard from Trump in weeks. "I knew it would be a matter of time," he said, referring to his decision not to seek reelection in 2019. "I am still waiting."
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., said he was optimistic the Democratic leadership would push for quick progress on a fiscal cliff compromise.
"We're going to work that out," McConnell said. "Whatever’s needed to reach an agreement, I have spoken to the leader of the Democratic leadership."
McConnell, who is a leading Trump critic, is adamantly opposed to increased spending unless tax rates are permanently set at a higher rate. Over the last few weeks, he has been frustrated by a lack of progress in key votes by House Democrats. The GOP tax bill includes tax cuts for many middle-class Americans, long an important part of what many Democrats say was the economic revival under the Trump administration.
McConnell told reporters Thursday he could make up with whatever the Democratic leadership does and is not looking to negotiate the fiscal cliff tax bill in advance. "I will keep working with the leadership to get everything done and keep a framework in place," he said.
That framework includes protections for drivers, farm workers and small business owners, and enforcement of regulatory requirements against corporate fraud, the president announced.
Reid done for now
The Senate will take up the spending package later this week and votes on its first time Thursday, the S2081. Democratic Whip Dick Durbin of Illinois said he was confident this would be enough to get a deal to Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer of New York.
But Reid "will definitely not run for reelection, so he will have to keep fighting. I'm in it for the long term," he said.
Democratic Sen. Ben Cardin of Maryland said Democrats had finally coalesced around a bill now in the hands of Schumer and Democratic Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., who introduced it separately in a joint-session session Tuesday. "They have answered that call," Cardin said.
Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., conceded that the House would have to work out a deal.
"Let's be honest, it's not acceptable to the president," he said.
Even in the absence of a budget agreement, the Homeland Security Agency will provide funding for the start of next fiscal year that President Obama signed into law in January.
The House has scheduled a vote on legislation designed to contain the deficit and avert what Democrats expect to be a potential tax increase by raising income taxes on wealthy Americans. The bill would increase tax rates on those earning more than $400,000 annually.
']

Title: The President as Bystander: Trump Struggles to Unify a Nation on Edge
Generation:
["(CNN) — On April 9th, Trump predicted “I’m going to win elections” for his party.
On Monday night, Trump told his national audience that he was willing to work together for something if it helped inspire unity in the nation.
“If I can help inspire unity — and I don’t know if you know what I know because I don’t know who to vote for,” he said. “I have a lot of confidence in the people of this country, they actually live in a country that can be united.”
The matter-of-fact president was referring to his Electoral College victory, and his approval rating, which has plummeted in recent weeks amid accusations that he was selling out the 2016 election.
One thing Trump doesn’t seem to have looked like is a unified force beyond the Obama administration and its predecessor, as evidenced by the power outage that occurred at an internal White House business on Monday morning.
There were no immediate details about what caused the hack on the White House.
The intelligence community has yet to formally charge the president. Several who participated in the company’s hacking attempted to unearth or attribute any vulnerability in the Trump server on which its operators are sitting, and have linked the attack to a Middle East group.
Trump, by phone on Monday, said that he had been briefed on the attack, “because I was a little nervous” and “the president was warned, of course. But I don’t think any of the Americans are culpable.”
“It was a right, it was good that they didn’t do anything bad to attack us, that they didn’t warn us, but I guess they thought it was a good thing that there wasn’t an attack. And I’m sure that they have a piece of information that’s in this puzzle and they’re investigating it,” he said.
“They’re not a group of people hacking and they’re not a group of people trying to benefit no one,” he added. “So you’re dealing with a group of people who are a little nervous, maybe a little hesitant about what they’re doing to me but are looking at this as something that I can do from a law enforcement or an intelligence standpoint, very help me and help those other guys, is working my way through this.”
What is unfolding politically, unfortunately, is an expected disaster for Trump and his party.
Last month, days after his divisive inauguration as president, Trump was noticeably absent from the Republican National Convention, and the prime-time presidential debate lasted barely a minute.
On Monday, on the streets of the U.S. capital, blue colors were projected on blue screens as Trump refused to attend the event.
“I’ve got to have a meeting with Speaker Paul Ryan so I can see why he’s standing up against President Obama,” Trump said, while explaining that he did not want to change his demands for reforms to the national debt.
Trump is grappling with the prospect of losing a string of presidential election in 2020. The CBO reported that roughly 10 million people voted for the Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in the 2016 election.
On Tuesday, Donald Trump Jr. addressed the upheaval on Twitter, urging people to get behind Democrats, saying he planned to “take the push for stronger trade regulations, which is gonna be very, very hard.”
On Tuesday night, more than 85,000 people took to social media to express their discontent over an impending Trump administration transition.
“I'm fighting back, I think, against the Trump administration. And I think it's gonna hurt us a lot to see Donald Trump get elected. And just go to the gym and get a good job and win,” said John Humphrey, a white Republican activist.
"]

Title: Louisiana Postpones April Primary as 4 More States Prepare to Vote on Tuesday
Generation:
['The 2016 presidential race has won’t get too close to Thanksgiving as President Donald Trump and Democratic candidates have joined forces to push the Democratic Party’s vote-by-mail initiative.
While most states are making preparations to vote on Tuesday, some of the most important ones are still deciding when to participate.
× :\xa0About a mile from the North Carolina hotel where the final results will be known, US Airways is switching its Sunday flights to New York from Charlotte International Airport. In an email to supporters, the airline said it will provide four new, shorter flights between Charlotte and New York.
Advertisement
In a statement, New York Mayor Bill de Blasio said after the first-term president needed a “new beginning” to handle the worst financial crisis in 40 years.
“While the United States is currently in the midst of a recession, many New Yorkers are coming together to celebrate the many jobs we’ve created and the millions of Americans we’ve supported during the hard times,” he said.
After more than 17,000 people moved to evacuate their homes across the country after Hurricane Maria struck this year, The New York Times noted that an estimated 100,000 people were helping with the effort.
Those numbers are “only the tip of the iceberg,” the paper said. “Nor has any politician ever told us where the oil is at or what the amount of money New Yorkers need is.”
The Times cited an analysis of the nation’s tolls during hurricane-related arrivals that found that during the early part of 2017 the difference between what New Yorkers were spending on Thanksgiving dinner and what was spent on their Christmas gifts — an estimated 76 percent — was a fraction of the 2.5 million people who did the annual celebration last year.
In addition, the Times reported that in some areas — including Orange County, N.J., Puerto Rico and Louisiana — up to 6.5 million people — more than half — received the holiday gift because of the economic crisis.
The study confirmed that power is still down in places like eastern Louisiana where the blizzard and flooding caused widespread damage to infrastructure.
The next primary election is on Nov. 6.
']

Title: Afraid of Coronavirus? That Might Say Something About Your Politics
Generation:
['It has been a long winter, but the overnight Arctic blast is only a relatively small part of the looming nuclear threat. Every year, the number of people infected with a nagging virus rolls through the country, and thus, their health status. Though we’re not a worldwide pandemic, things do get complicated.
In 2015, the first case of avian influenza was reported in Nigeria. Since then, illness has spiked across much of the continent, with 108 confirmed and 65 deaths, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Some of the more problematic conditions have included viral and bacterial infections and, though historically, viruses like avian influenza and H1N1 were blamed for many deaths and illnesses, since avian influenza is common in this region.
Though there are generally no vaccines in Nigeria, the NCDC in Nigeria says that one vaccine that could avert the worst and most serious consequences of a rogue infectious virus is Leif Oji LFC-2, which works in conjunction with the animal flu vaccine Relenza.
Out of over 1,600 people with the virus, 153 were dead in Nigeria last year.
']

Title: American Astronomyâs Future Goes on Trial in Washington
Generation:
['(CNN) - "Everyone is invested," says Fareed Zakaria. He was put through everything he could possibly want, from food, to religion, to politics.
He has done that for a number of years, including two years running a chapter in the Academy of Sciences journal, Harvard Searching for Queries.
Zakaria is in the third and final cycle of "All About Astronomy," which will debut Thursday and take place on the Governor's Mall on Friday, the last full day before the Memorial Day weekend.
His goal, Zakaria says, is to know how to ask it all questions - and talk about it with everyone, including President Trump.
All About is a cross between Science Fair and Comic Con, with members seeking quality, accurate answers on topics ranging from jobs to cancer.
The show runs from Tuesday to Friday, so the show's audience, for the first time, gets to see what Zakaria and colleagues are up to.
Zakaria says his journey began during a civil service seminar at Oxford University in 2011. He was preparing a book to be released that year, and there he met engineers from NASA and others, and the two teamed up to form a group called the Physics America, an organization that hosts panel discussions and films, he says.

Zakaria and his fellow physicists from the Harvard team engaged a group of professional people, bringing the suits from NASA, Tech.com, and NASA Earth Observatory along. They created a workbook with science facts, but also compelling visualizations - including one where a robot artificially carries astronauts to the bottom of the ocean - that someone might visit to find out more about what's going on.
Zakaria says he was asked a time and time again to explain physics in terms of his perspective on things like colonities, booms and bombs - things that seem more abstract than anything else.
Like any other scientist, Zakaria's objectives are broad - what he hopes to uncover in terms of his own theoretical exploration.
"What we aim to do is discover what happened during the last two years of the past 20 years or so when you just randomly go around and ask everyone, 'What happened?'" Zakaria says. "That's what all the scientists want. I'm interested in what lies ahead of us."
Zakaria says there are three goals for "All About Astronomy," and they'll use what he calls a material curiosity - bits that touch and appreciate life and its complicated interactions - to dig deeper.
His aim, he says, is to better understand the cosmos - and everything that happened before it, so that "we can better understand what it was like before the rise of the sun."

Title: Pentagon Asks to Reconsider Awarding Huge Cloud Contract to Amazon
Generation:
['The Pentagon on Thursday encouraged the U.S. government to reassess its awarding of a big new defence contract to Amazon Web Services on the basis of the agreement's "end-to-end impact."
The order, which specifies that the contract can be assessed both vertically and horizontally, applies to total cost incurred in delivering and maintaining Amazon's cloud services.
Also in the order, the Defense Department said it is transferring the contract to Lockheed Martin Corp.
The contract was awarded to AWS by the Army and was valued at about $1.9 billion. A total of $1.9 billion was being allocated to follow-on contracts, mostly for developing infrastructure-as-a-service (ESV) units to be launched in 2020 and in 2025.
While AWS isn't seen as an inherently bad choice for the Pentagon to award the contract to Amazon, it could set up bad precedent if its importance is put off until 2023. In 2018, for example, the Pentagon awarded another $733 million in contracts to Lockheed, according to a Pentagon release.
The order requires the Defense Department to certify that the contracts have "complete access" to the product or services it chose, the Army and Lockheed said.
The number of instances of subcontracting is limited by the size of the contracts; as of mid-December, the Defense Department submitted just 27 instances of such activity. The White House put the number at 457.
In a statement on Thursday, the Pentagon said its "regulatory bodies and institutions" are working to improve disclosure and practices that allow transparency.
"The Department's watchdog bodies make major efforts to ensure the highest standards of delivery," the statement said. "These efforts range from using our standard information accounting system to ensuring our agencies have the data and information they need to implement security and technology risks protections."
While the Pentagon has requested internal reviews, it only received a partial order in September that ordered some kinds of share construction, with the federal government confirming with that order that request had been granted.
Pentagon orders
Those with an open start-up award under the process must follow specific contracting requirements, including not less than two months after the program is awarded, to be eligible for a variety of awards.
One drawback is that the process is designed to award just one or even two deals at a time. It should produce clear analysis on the technology issues affecting the previous deal, but it is not yet clear if that happened.
Facing a lawsuit from U.S. District Judge William Alsup in Georgia, the Defense Department sought to put the decision under seal and said the case would be sent to the 9th Circuit Appeals Court. The Defense Department has asked for a trial date, so it is unclear how fast the appeals court can rule.

Title: Opinion | The Pandemic vs. The President
Generation:
['Editor's note:
Since President Trump has taken office, his administration has promoted a new national government policy with over 300 policies and plans. The State of the Union Address, 2017 was called "The Unexpected Job Creation Act of 2017," which is now President-elect Trump's biggest priority, promising that as much as 30,000 jobs will be created every year. Last month, the director of the Center for American Progress was on record as saying, "As we remain focused on job creation and keeping jobs up, we have an enormous amount of unfinished business -- the debt limit and the tax cuts. With each passing minute, more work remains to be done to create thousands of new jobs."
I am frequently turned on by the pre-meditated paralysis in Congress, the hostility in the White House and I'm appalled by the policies and programs being fought for. We all expect leaders will, and we will. But to be distracted by this ruse of ideas is not an objective reflection of the direction of the country, nor is it a first step towards solutions, nor a cause to begin to heal a nation.
The situation facing Congress today is a different and much more complex, yet equally dangerous situation. The shutdown has forced Congress to put two pieces of paper that none of us could have imagined these past days -- and that leaves us with a vote on the debt limit and the DREAM Act to prevent federal deficits from spiraling out of control.
The district of California has the third highest rate of youth unemployment in the country -- with 22,500 children living in foster care, the highest rate in the U.S. -- and just 25% of the working adults there are employed or looking for a job. A report released last month from the Center for American Progress said the DREAM Act may allow 800,000 undocumented undocumented students to complete their education while deferring student loans for up to 30 years. But while 40% of those DACA recipients will have their student loans repaid, it would also save them $900 million dollars per year. This bill would also create $3 billion in private school scholarships -- and there are more that could be made available than meets the bill's standards for funding essential services.
The U.S. Capitol has been haunted by immigration actions over the past two days. This is not the first time that the U.S. Capitol has become a battleground, when it was immersed in a partisan fight between the president and House Speaker Paul Ryan, fighting over American policies on both sides of the aisle, and limited and worrying spending on the president's two most important domestic priorities: Social Security and immigration.
And the biggest dangers for the Trump presidency come from President Barack Obama's actions during the height of the financial crisis.
Republicans controlled the House and Senate since 2007. The presidents and their Cabinet, Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and his staff, faced off over nearly every issue facing their respective parties at the critical issue: immigration. Lawmakers passed a bill in 2016, for example, that followed a law on illegal entry by illegal immigrants and allowed those entering the country without authorization to stay for two years. All too often the Obama administration made it clear that, while it allowed more than 1.6 million to enter the country illegally, it prohibited them from doing so for 30 years or longer, effectively leaving them with nowhere to stay. The federal government was also complicit in allowing the many millions of illegals to enter the country illegally, breaking the law even after numerous legal challenges to the entry of these individuals. By reversing this law, the Obama administration ensured that, through legal loopholes and the internment of thousands of people, nearly 700,000 people have simply disappeared from our homeland -- ending in the exodus from our nation.
My children are too young to know what that means, and fear that this will soon be the end of the White House. But as President Trump has shown us -- it is not all bad news for a country -- it is not all bad news for a nation. And when there is less cooperation across the aisle, it becomes even more difficult to understand the divisions on national issues.
Finally, people must also be reminded that fighting on the battlefield is one of the most difficult facets of creating a society. This never-ending battle for the country is not over. And the situation is changing daily at the very touch of Capitol Hill. The Fight for the Nation can only get started if Congress does its job, prioritizing bipartisanship above fights. Congress needs to pull together and show Republicans and Democrats that we are on the right track. At the national level, Congress should not be defeated on the political battlefield, not the president.
']

Title: Two Women Fell Sick From the Coronavirus. One Survived.

The other woman received a text message from Silverman saying she had developed abdominal pain, fever and a severe sinus infection.
In a statement, Silverman told CNN that her family and friends were worried for her.
“I have been invited back to our dining room to eat whatever I wanted to consume, and not trying to hit the toilet, and in the family food,” Silverman said. “I have had no food, no shelter, no water, no worry and have a great time. I purchased my Clorox Tray from my friend Harvey’s. I rented a booster seat and the attendant said to the “you gotta drop the bag, kid.” So I did. And as I filled up with the big bag and the other carton – the meanderer cradled a large speck of blood from my chin and shoulders – I remembered Ben Stiller’s Leggett Brute’s finger. And it wasn’t just that I remembered that; it was that I remembered saying “here I am, just putting my finger on Ben.”
About a half hour later, I remembered that my clorox Tray had splashed up with such pain in my hand that I had to stay at the locker and the attendant spit out my swab. Stunned. Even though I was in the same part of the room, there was no way to direct the woman who told the doorman to pull my key and drive me home. Oh how smug – it was only me.
My hand was getting sad. That’s when I thought, is this why they give out drug store freebies? Because they want to lure me in. And that’s the bizarre thing about these pharmacies and barbershops – that someone has assumed that the only way they can get an incentive on consumers is with a bit of bad publicity.
The Drug Price Chopper blog ran a feature on what makes and what makes not only some drugstores, but also bars and hamburger places and restaurants. Don't ask. This and many other random questions are slated for framing and captioning on the pages of these pages… unless you’re rich.

Title: The President as Bystander: Trump Struggles to Unify a Nation on Edge
Generation:
['A strained relationship between President Donald Trump and Congress led to a fragile U.S. reaction to his aggressive on-the-ground posture in Europe on Saturday, the first moment in Trump’s presidency which he has been able to maneuver around through the new security architecture installed by Defense Secretary Jim Mattis.
Despite the Republican challenger’s vaunted new style of persuasion, policy and intelligence communication style under Trump, Congress was confronted with constant reminders that they didn’t need such a man.
On Friday, when Trump told an audience at the White House after the Pentagon meeting that “defense is the right thing to do,” the Congress responded with a resounding “no,” a sign of its lack of a coherent message.
House Speaker Paul Ryan immediately took to Twitter to respond.
“In the face of headwinds in Congress, Republicans have decided to vote ‘no’ on policymaking as best they can,” he wrote.
David Bauder, Paul Ryan’s press secretary, quickly followed with a rebuttal.
“Republicans are divided by tradition on issues and by instinct,” Bauder wrote. “There is also undeniable evidence that the wisdom of the president’s chief of staff, John Kelly, has been greatly diminished.”
Congressman Artur Davis slammed “Frankly, I don’t trust Mike Kelly — and I don’t think he’s smart enough to tell any coherent message,” he said in a closed-door message to the press.
Rep. Jason Chaffetz, R-Utah, continued, “Here we are in this inflexible, powerless bipartisan environment.”
A leaderless Congress with no clear message, a group of moderate Republicans, a handful of early-October gov’s, a half-dozen senators and a few White House officials, obliged.
Vice President Mike Pence took on the public’s petty messages, rolling out tired rumors and conspiracies about his opponent Trump’s supposed connections to Russia, and slashing forth the narrative that Trump has built a wall along the Mexican border, instead of building a wall between the United States and Mexico to secure his border.
A festering absence of policy and communication that the Trump team wanted to pursue — however brief — until his administration was aligning more closely with the Pentagon and Congress.
Trump had been forced into an indignity to House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., when she asked a Thursday intelligence briefing about the Syrian chemical weapons attack on Friday.
He promptly shot a video with a similar tactic, which more worked.
Trump was using foreign policy principles to argue he had no moral right to interfere with Congress over his own military actions.
He has argued that the intelligence community’s assessments are far from reliable and thus, contrary to some experts, are in fact skewed by the Obama administration.
Trump also has invoked the Watergate scandal during his campaign — documents that suggest an undetermined extent of his support for the president — and has sought to cast the missteps as pretexts that serve his campaign best.
He also has bypassed the usual White House channels of communication and diplomacy, much like he did in the White House’s attempt to have Mike Pence to describe his possible presidential bid.
']
