Title: Stephen Sondheim, the Man Who Felt Too Much
Generation:
['He was livid about a cold contract with the publisher that would “come to dead” and left him “too broken” to work any more, he began to question the Sondheim test, worked out with the editor to accept payments on each book, stayed home less, and continued to act for the publisher.
Now, as he is sending emails daily attesting that it was all in the name of more books – yes, and no more books – he concludes: “I’m not sorry but I am a sinner who felt he had no right. I can feel ashamed about it now.”
But who is to blame?
This is the territory of the critics. And it matters because it is a way of saying that the writing on a script (the Schlosser of the books in this case) is meant to help the reader understand what the characters want – without an intermediary who lends itself to this copious amount of material.
As the critics have noted, it is not a novel to note, and it probably doesn’t matter how much the authors hire the people who write the narration. They usually have a script, so it is not immediately clear how much it cost the writer to get it right. The writers then have to give them written notes that give evidence that the story even works. And it will be tougher for the Sondheimians to say where they got this quantity of material.
So when the writer: “Man of La Mancha”
That part is beautiful; and it helped the Sondheims come to terms with that realization. The couple of books they have read since 1968 – “A Shopkeeper’s Daughter” and “I Started Over,” for example – was one of them.
“Man of La Mancha” is a period piece, and when his wife, Annie, gets “a report” at his home, she notices that the collection isn’t just about him. She is a living legend, a “poisonous dictator,” who she nevertheless believed to herself to be smart, funny, and capable of undermining the government – a devious and abhorrent feminizer with a murderer’s head, donning the high-heeled shoes of albino Monty Python and taking her heritage seriously.
Not only is Annie the film’s lovable, laconic protagonist – Annie has only agreed to marry her dad, who turns out to be a slaughter-machine – she is also her husband’s mistress, a heroine who gets more personal in his descent into madness than she realizes.
Annie kind and funny
How else can Annie illuminate the private life of William, her maid of honor who confides in her about her strange past? In the book, and in an art direction display where Annie might just surface in a moment, Annie lets the reader click through to some of William’s grievances.
The story uses Annie as a victim, letting the reader know what more she can ask of William about his familial love for his butler. Some of these actions are actions that only LeRoy would have pursued: being a child and friends, forging a relationship, dating and dying, sleeping with a friend – something many people are struggling with – and kissing into someone she loves.
The twists and turns of characters quickly convey the slithery, looking maternal disposition of the story. And it’s not just children who carry the blame for this. John Waters’ earlier musical works, including “The Lion King,” and “West Side Story,” have not been able to evoke the drab façade of human-ness of “Man of La Mancha.” The more the story stays true to the theme of innocence and meaning in fact, the more involved William is in his action.
But Richard Rabin, former editor of The New Yorker and author of “Twin Shadow: The Genius of Romantic Theatre,” calls it another betrayal of the kind that the Schlosser implicitly acknowledged, or drew the most ire from the critics.
And it is one of the reasons why the critics do not want to take them seriously.
']

Title: Stephen Sondheim, the Man Who Felt Too Much
Generation:
['LOS ANGELES — A two-way camera via the wireless internet. A microwave. A microwave oven built into a telephone. A microwave.
All wrapped in a white box in the hands of the author of the best-selling, cult classic, "Goodbye Mr. Lonely Girl."
To someone whose work will likely never have reached the big screen, the quality at its best is just harder to come by.
That's because Sondheim finds rhythm through the brilliant precision of his technique. Two movies count — "Roma" for more than just bad movies. In one case, the victory of famous woman Behati Prinsloo over her original boyfriend was achieved with lines from "La La Land." In the other, "La La Land" turned the Oscars into a domestic comedy. In both cases, a juicy line poked a hot mic out of a newspaper. And in "Roma," the unfiltered excellence of a pleasant ending is unmistakable.
"All the worst things come true when it's as funny and a little dramatic as possible," said Sondheim. "Roma" sold more than 12 million copies in Spain and Mexico, and it never came to the Oscars. But for the moment, "La La Land" and "Roma" are these awards salons.
"This summer I'm going to be thinking of friends and family because this will be what I miss the most. It will be something very special," said Sondheim, who is simultaneously thrilled with the news of "La La Land."
Though many writers and directors don't want to do any work that can -- as a writer and writer's boy -- be 'so dramatic and great that it will be hard to find people to watch it,' Sondheim said. "I love all the years I've been working on them. In other words, 'La La Land,' its story is timeless and one of those beautiful stories."
"La La Land" stars Emma Stone as Elle Fanning, best known for "The Favourite." It follows Elizabeth Perkins (Stone), a talented and kind college student who winds up in love with Ryan (Ryan Gosling), a brilliant U.S. filmmaker from Hawaii who works at his museum collection.
Its exhilarating beginning never gets old. Taking cues from the Broadway stage musical "Hamilton," it also echoes the music of legendary cinematographer Emmanuel Lubezki, who recorded music in three stints with the giant Lumière di Suter and later with the BBC and the Bond franchise.
"I remember hearing 'V.I.P.' at the American Academy of Dramatic Arts at the beginning of the 70s and in that time composers seemed to pay more attention to scenery than voice as a character," said Steinberger, who had led Sondheim's Orange Wave production in London for the Tony Award-winning year. "The bar was ajar. La La Land was livelier and every one of those changes we make now."
And the film: Sondheim, who last year finished composing the score for the film "Crazy Rich Asians," tends to leave his mind somewhat fuzzy. He is 90 years old and has a long life expectancy, and he doesn't need subtitles.
"Literally the relationship between society and the actors who we call actors is the most sacred institution in Hollywood," said a frustrated Richard Roney, who had been working with Sondheim in London to create "Roma."
Sondheim's longtime collaborator, Leo Tolstoy, is the Ukrainian master of tragedy.
"Roma is as committed to tragedy as you could imagine. People want to hate Roma," Tolstoy said. "And remember, he discovered nothing but tragedy."
It's a character whose movie needs crying at every stop of its run and is a scathing indictment of the way Hollywood concentrates on women over men.
"It's the 12-year-old girl who is the new king, which makes a mockery of humanity," Tolstoy said. "And he's had fun with it, too. In their political world, this is how people live. It's the way they break it."
']

As an African woman who’s happily coming back from an earlier Africa (in the United States) it seems like freedom is only possible when you’re there to help others. And to a woman in a country that is in such a dire need of social assistance, it isn’t really possible to survive without that kind of freedom.
Here are three steps women from around the world can take to help their fellow women in the struggle to end oppression:
Know where you stand
We say that you have at least two options. You can’t simply steal a cash or a laptop, but you can make a small contribution. You can donate the money you have to house a fellow woman whose circumstances are so precarious. You can donate the kindness you need to help more women outside of your own country who are struggling with the same situations you are.
It’s also a reasonable cost to finance the project. Some people can afford to buy you a deposit and go out and give a little while longer with the cash.
It’s also necessary. Women out there are missing the more fundamental elements to survive this struggle: schools, hospitals, water, food, health, love. We also need to find out where your work and family is being used by someone in the real world. It’s the most powerful tool women have in the fight against oppression, and then there’s the strength to shoulder the pain and suffering while you can.
Women who want to support the fight against oppression can identify and ask, “What’s the most important thing I can do for the rest of my life?”
Yale University is getting money from the ExxonMobil Foundation in recognition of men who have gone through the same fight against oppression: btw, beer for those living in need. What a man is in a better position to ask for help than Susan Lockhart of Yale University.

Title: Opinion | How to Fix the Coronavirus Testing Mess in 7 Days
Generation:
['If you ever thought about getting all the due diligence you need before developing a test kit for a person at large, then you’re going to be amazed when I arrive in a guest house—after two days of treatment and no problems—with nothing out of the ordinary. I’m a rookie program manager on a most famous government contract for a company called Research and Development Canada, and this past week my third visit to the clinic.
I was most likely wrong to think that R&D Canada might have an obligation to I, nor should they, to offer prospective test subjects. But the hype has circulated. R&D Canada definitely has the upper hand in the testing work out there in the US, especially with a $62.3 million first round of test tubes that were designed to test specific mutations in P6 proteins. Once it was decided, R&D Canada could test roughly 15,000 P6 proteins for testing purposes in the country. Not to be outdone by Research and Development Canada, I found a plane ticket to Arizona to take the test kits home and one of those tickets was an only-in-last-series after-hours appointment at the Arizona State Hospital.
So did not I say “surprise”? Well, yes.
I had difficulty with fly-fishing and possibly was left bleeding profusely in the back of my head after a 5 kilometre run when my flight attendants came to the door, ordered me to fly quickly and then covered me with a bucket of water and ordered my flight attendant to go. I was dropped off, and made to wait for two minutes for service. Luckily, my flight attendant arrived at the medical examination center shortly after that, so we had good reason to expect a quick examination.
I pulled the huge bucket off my throat, ate a few bites and felt no ill. After that, I actually had a bit of tenderness (like I would have had under the category of “human”).
I thought it was supposed to be my day, but then came the next morning when the blood-sugar levels were level with just 12 or 13 ng/mL.
I marveled that even on the table prior to treatment or to my test of 15 pesticides with two measures were down to a trivial five ng/mL.
I opened the box and watched as the grapefruit fly slowed down again. At the last minute, I realized that, with a slightly lower than normal level of snoring, I got the chance to dig a little deeper into my bag.
My flight attendant, this time a diehard R&D Canada fan, insisted that I return to the clinic, so I put my receipts on the chair. She relayed the details of my main issues. For some reason, she didn’t have any answers to my questions. This is how it works: She used a personal pronouns that reflect her thinking or to dramatize why she found me too toxic to trust. And she was right. When I went in, I gave her a clean “Yellow Xer” from the yellow worm test tube, and she eventually contacted me about joining her.
My needs are good enough to be discharged on an appointment and the results don’t disappoint.
Did I make the right choice? In any event, no. Most importantly, whatever I was sent to, it worked in a positive way. No longer were I on fumes and suffering from sinusitis. No longer were the cases my tests revealed rampant.
I made it three days to have my test tube removed, and that is a miracle even if it wasn’t possible to do.
So yeah, right off the bat, if you keep ticking over from one point of view and you act like I didn’t care to care about you, chances are you can expect to take a couple more days to move on.
Once you find out you have a good test kit, use it as your key to get through these 3-plus months of on-the-go treatment. The week after you sit down to assess your own asthma and how it might affect you in coming years, you will be better prepared to start your own treatment with a minor diversion.
Get it done—one week at a time.

Title: Opinion | How to Fix the Coronavirus Testing Mess in 7 Days
Generation:
['It's hard to believe that Thursday morning, April 4, 1984, may have set such a different standard for the technology that makes and supports testing for viruses. While this was undoubtedly good news to the mother of virus testers, health professionals over the years have never fully understood the severity of the disease and how to address it.
Shall we turn a new leaf and use the new definitions?
To paraphrase the market-leading testing labs of the early 1980s, what many people learn is that the test system is not just for individual and shared samples. It's for the whole family, on all levels. And not just diagnostics. It's a test to eliminate viruses, just in case one or more, too. You don't need to know that the virus itself is the cause of everything that's wrong with you.
And the facility's data is intended for dissemination by qualified medical personnel, especially doctors, nurses, and social workers.
This made perfect sense to several federal and state agencies that are handling the virus test itself.
That wasn't the end.
Biologists, help workers, and law enforcement first gathered information, then began collecting checks to determine the order of importance of each sample. By requiring use of "crossover" samples, scientists investigated the origin of the infection and created a model to forecast the sequence of the virus's attacks.
Even monitoring and processing samples is slow and often inefficient.
It was not until about 19 months after the disease spread that scientists managed to establish the date and conditions that propelled the virus into circulation.
"There was no known cause," says Dr. David Higgs, a geneticist at Duke University. "We knew the vector of the disease was being directed through the livestock."
"We knew there was no shortage of viruses," says medical director Dr. Richard J. Neuwirth. "And we knew there were no epidemics. And we knew there were no outbreaks."
He noted, "Harms to all of us are that we choose to use our expertise to solve our problems. And in some cases, we choose to do it for ourselves."
In 2015, about 200,000 former patients in New York City were vaccinated against meningitis while the virus was in the air. That's equivalent to every day's training for a nurse or doctor's assistant, according to the CDC.
And no brand-new $37 million facility was built on the old way.
The Institute of Medicine set a standard for testing, the New York Times reported last November. Before that, businesses and school districts had to pay "state, federal and local law enforcement agencies" to test their own vaccines.
That has now vanished.
As a result, scientists can no longer address the inadequacies of diagnostic testing.
Instead, attempts are now made to cover up deficiencies of laboratory work, like the date on a serum test used in several years, and the environment where a virus is discovered. For cancer, tests are not needed to treat it. In many cases, patients on tests may be immunocompromised.
"We've made some really excellent progress," says Dr. Neuwirth. "We are now one step away from dealing with all the data that the community has over there -- input from all of us and then getting able to drill down into the science in the laboratory to see what the data would show. It would be very useful in terms of getting this data out as quickly as possible."
The kind of testing laboratories that dot our modern society run on a very lean, by-the-book process. More importantly, they often meet all sorts of ethical, technological, and data-driven needs and milestones.
']

"Years ago it seemed that the change that most people were noticing was of between one in six and one in four patients infected with Mosquito or Eficus - which was obviously very low," said Kathryn Corin told CNN's Don Lemon. "That is now closer to one in 10."
The new threshold for disease was set up for 69 countries in the American children's health kit that had been sold in Southern Europe until last year.
The information was released by the World Health Organization in Brussels.
"Health workers and healthcare workers want to make sure we are allowing people to continue to make decisions as they see fit about the use of antibiotics and for their children," Konrad Prell, an assistant professor at the University of Pennsylvania who chairs the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's Doing It Well Program, told CNN.
Corin said those changes are connected to the 7,000 children who fell ill nationwide last year in the southeastern US. "It's true that roughly 1 million people have it and another 1 million, hundreds of thousands in isolated cases, have end-stage liver cancer, and other human-borne illnesses," he said.
The United States has had over 1 million kids who had a test result tied to Mosquito or Eficus, an influenza virus that has infected 175 million people worldwide.
The disease is spread by contact with feces and contact with raw food, washing in the ground or walking over contaminated surfaces.
Breastfeeding in the shower also increases this number of youngsters who have the virus. But it will take a serious bacterial infection to cause symptoms.
Most outbreaks are caused by a strain of the bacteria E. coli. Mosquito or Eficus has been linked to 129 deaths from that strain in less than 100 countries.
In the Western world there is little known about how Mosquito or Eficus react to food. Both strains of the virus are linked to an outbreak of diarrhoea in Spain where 36 children died, according to the children's center.
Asked why Mosquito-Eficus has gained popularity over other strains of the virus, whose effects are unknown, Dr. Kieran Russell, who directs the U.S. Centers for Disease Control's Microbiology and Immunology Center in Atlanta, told CNN: "If the incidence of infection with the Lactobacillus makes its way through the food supply it can occur in a very small group of individuals with microcephaly, the strain from which is the virus."
The CDC in 2010 reported that the "viruses for which the virus was the primary agent had increased to nearly three-fourths of the overall number of outbreaks of bacterial species, causing or supporting numerous illness problems," including sickle cell, wasting and heart disease.
The World Health Organization said that Mosquito and Eficus pose a risk to persons who eat human waste, fish and to pets when they eat raw foods, animal waste and soil.

Title: Opinion | The Government Has Failed on Coronavirus, but There Is Still Time
Generation:
["By Ramzi Bardsley
President Trump is perhaps the most striking example of government in a trillion-dollar age. His administration, he said, was “boring,” “crying,” “miserable,” “phony,” “sick,” “crying,” “crying,” “shooting ducks,” and “gobbling flocks,” but so far, he has not produced a single death related to the deadly virus, let alone reversed course, like President Obama in the worst possible circumstances, when he almost didn’t save a few lives as a president of first the government, then the government is almost willfully naïve and inept, yet has never even found time to address a single disaster on earth.
This president has the same habit of his unfortunate choice of words and policies as President Obama and President Bush, in spite of having experienced everything in all of its trimmings. He can’t just abandon the substance of his policies and be seen to fail so often. It is another delusion to live in the age of instantaneous change, the result of changing circumstances, people taking an opportunity, and ultimately losing that opportunity. It’s the path from stone to sink, the reality behind the zombie-like condition on Earth, the one that is often lacking. Sometimes this is the most frustrating reaction of all when a large number of unfortunate people miss the opportunity.
Lone Survivor
This is a harrowing tale, caught with deep seated sadness and immense terror upon arrival in Aden, Yemen on April 7, 2016. Ambulances arrived at the scene quickly to save more than 30 young women and children from drowning. The children and children’s father went to attempt to save their mother when the shipwrecks started sinking. The father survived, taking the time to enjoy some lost time for his family and the kids.
As a father, and as a husband, and as a U.S. citizen and as a soldier, a key element of the family remained intact, primarily with his wife, until his death. The American people and particularly the Yemeni people began to see that his actions were wrong and that his service was not appropriate for us or his country.
His memorials to the innocent babies that were lost to this disease were filled with pictures of his daughters, who were killed as a result of being too scared to seek medical attention, and of their entire and tragic lives lost. Unfortunately, in this case, the most painful and tragic of the disasters that we experienced, is yet to come.
Nepalese Elder Saves Lives
In 2009, el Ghani, a Nepalese citizen, died after being pulled by his Nepalese neighbor near the southern Iraqi border. Pregnant pregnant El Ghani watched her husband's baby being born and save him by throwing him across the border to save him. He endured 47 hours of labor, 16 hours of hospitalization, and 1,000 hours of nursing aid by the Nepalese government and Abu Dhabi Care Fund. El Ghani, initially immolated himself but managed to survive into the night before a local soldier came to rescue him and gave him an opportunity to come home. This experience made his death a landmark in the history of Nepal, but has so far been very hard on the family since his death.
At the end of the night, unrolled cat, son, 3-year-old girl, nanny, and grandchildren watched the family's home take its last breath; el Ghani and his family waited in the Air Force tent until he was able to wiggle free and live. Once el Ghani was freed, he was able to make it back home in time to assist his wife and all those, with the help of his family, who served from the time they were very little. However, before he could become comfortably into his pajamas, el Ghani died.
The truth is, our country is, as he spoke in prison, a human tragedy, and our government has failed on this important issue. It’s time for our government to acknowledge the profound loss of our democracy and leadership to ensure that we can fully recover from this tragedy.
"]

Title: Opinion | Broadway Is Closed. Write Poems Instead.

["I recently wrote a letter to one of my frequent readers. It was sitting on the table for a long time. The print of the letters concerned more about a portfolio than the same good stuff we're about to write. So I decided to write them all together.

I usually offer clues to find what is coming. So there are some clues I want to stick in next week. Here's something to ponder:
There are things out there that I see as postmodern problems. Or perhaps, as I would say, self-pitying problems. At least you're not stuck with me.
Basically, I see my argument as evidence that the themes we can do something about are too compelling to ignore. Why don't we keep them. They aren't more-defunct. Or less-defunct.
But even if they don't become routine, they haven't gotten stale. And I hope you're interested in reading them. I wish you luck in coming forward, because those days are gone.
"]

Title: âAgnes of the Desertâ Joins Modernismâs Pantheon
Generation:
['Art has become a big deal this past week as the Roman-era mosaic stood atop the Atlas mountain near Bella Vista, northeast of Los Angeles.
But the potted landscape is a quintessential cache of Italian artists, such as Francesco Cali of Renzo Piano, Carole Solomon of Thom Browne and Markus Kuehne of Piemonte - as well as other groups, such as the Lumina Society of Latin America.
Cali has been an international work of art for more than a decade, making yet more comebacks and showings of his features during the coming weeks at the New Museum in New York, when calls roll in for European curators on his exhibition, \x80\x93 À\x98Agnes of the Desert, to conclude this fall.
\x93I asked for it because my wife is a physician and I wanted to be part of it,\x80\x9d Cali, 58, said by phone Wednesday afternoon.
Mature and hand-painted art such as the Palazzo d\x92America in Del Rey, Calif., uses classic photography and incorporates techniques such as color palettes and rubbers. It has its roots in Italian art. His work has been exhibited in the Salvador Dali museum in Venice and in two Los Angeles venues, one in Rambla del Rey and another in Vancouver.
The Palazzo d\x92America is meant as a link between London art, Cali said, with the and the contemporary art in its many iterations from the city, to Mumbai, the Arctic north, the sea, to Japan.
Cali embraces modernist means as his work is both mundane and positively dramatic, according to N. Shen, a fellow curator of Modern art at the Seattle Art Museum.
\x93When there is an issue,\x80\x9d Shen said, \x93you can translate it into something else. Italianism is very personal.\x80\x9d
His work \x93is not abstract,\x80\x9d he said. \x93It is formal, dark, engaging,\x80\x9d he said.
Shen is honored that Cali\x92s works are about art, even if their places and meanings are not the only. \x93There are divisions,\x80\x9d he said. \x93There are declarations and statements. There are stories.\x80\x9d
Solomon of the New Museum (2010) received her doctorate in fine arts from Louisiana State University and studied botany there before getting to the Los Angeles Art Museum.
\x93My main contribution to her study was how to find ideas,\x80\x9d she said. \x93She had a great approach that was completely abstract. So I wanted to use her ideas to construct new ways.\x80\x94
Cali himself is an abstractionist.
\x93He used ultraprapure or cascading formulas, but he didn\x80\x99t agree with the complex ideas,\x80\x94 he said. \x93I wanted to try something different. I thought that after a while, he would change it.
\x80\x9cIt\x80\x99s not an abstract painting,\x80\x94 he said. \x93A static painting is sound, but it has a lot of subtleties, in that you don\x80\x99t know when or where. So I think it was a departure from everyday painting.
\x80\x9cThere is that tendency,\x80\x94 Cali said, \x80\x9cof thinking visually, and in other ways, as you say, it is almost like the way we draw.\x80\x94
His companion, wife Sara, suggested that Cali use what she termed “What-To& Miss\x80\x94 because it is an \x80\x98Everything-to-Lots-to-Feel-This-In’ quip, but it is something I would really like to do. I think it is a little poignant to be reminded of what is under total control.â\x80\x9d
Roma, Luis Sánchez Solís, who died in 2006, was a personal favorite of Cali, and his work is also displayed in the Los Angeles show.
\x80\x9cI still love this really wonderful woman and art, so I\x80\x99m wondering what kind of woman I’ll see in this show, with her going on so many shows,\x80\x94 he said.
The show closes on May 6.
']

Title: Wall Street Rises After Historic Plunge: Live Market Updates
Generation:
['NEW YORK (CNNMoney) — After popping more than 400 points in the last two trading sessions — ahead of a massive market selloff — stock markets around the world jumped higher Friday, with the FTSE100 and the DAX both about 600 points higher.
That was more than a 4% gain at one point.
Indeed, the front-month S&P 500 was up 2.7% so far this week — its second-biggest gain in a week — and are up by about 1% on the week.
“The market can’t stop moving higher right now,” said Mihir Sharma, chief market strategist at ING Group. “If you just scratch the surface of the major geopolitical concern, I think the market could become much more serious and even more expensive than a year ago.”
Back in 2008, stock markets plunged along with the wider economy and the financial industry. But since then, the underlying fundamentals have fundamentally improved: Credit markets have recovered a bit and the Fed has taken a slow but steady look at monetary policy — well after abruptly reducing its recent bond purchases.
Credit markets have gotten a bumpy ride, but the losers are usually small ones — even if they’re small.
“These markets are so volatile,” said Alison Lucas, head of fixed income and currencies at OppenheimerFunds. “The last few days haven’t been quite the same — the market got into a tizzy, again, but this isn’t the entire year.”
“There’s just really been some selling,” she added. “There was a lot of selling made up mostly of risk-averse investors, which I find to be quite sobering.”
What’s just the latest in a series of big moves in key issues
So far this week, Dow components were up 1.2% and the S&P 500 was up 0.7%. In other words, the markets finished strong and created some pretty dramatic headlines.
People weren’t just taking profits — they were piling into stocks.
By midmorning Friday, Boeing’s stock had risen to new highs.
North Korea-related shares were especially a sellers’ choice, with major foreign miners down sharply as China’s foreign reserves dropped.
Google shares have jumped more than 9%.
Foolish writers were bracing for the surprise return of China’s central bank Wednesday, after Vice President Lu Chao presided over a rare engagement of Chinese officials in Beijing, and which sparked a flurry of communication from investors in the United States.
The three appointments completed a set of vaguely charged warnings that Hu Jintao must demonstrate a willingness to push the yuan back toward the world’s third-largest economy.
Xi is scheduled to return from his meeting in Mexico later this week, while the United States and Japan will hold talks in L.A. April 7-8.
And an increasing number of European governments have been urging European Central Bank President Mario Draghi to act faster and more aggressively.
Inflation rose a little bit this week. The German government reported that consumer prices fell 4.8% in March, and the British government reported that inflation had increased slightly in March — compared to the previous month, though not as fast as previously thought.
Uncertainty is well away, with Germany’s Angela Merkel talking warmly of her country’s economic woes and on television talks with French President Emmanuel Macron on the condition that the euro zone break up.
On the other hand, Italy held a national conference to discuss its future when it goes on bond purchases — a monthly upgrade by the main vote-counting body. The country’s borrowing costs have risen since Draghi spoke up that week.
And, of course, all this continued for another day.
And, for another time, Japan also adjusted its policy course. The Japanese market hasn’t exactly been aggressive this year. That kind of market volatility could help the country in the coming weeks, if at all.
“If this situation does come down and we see these sort of moves to disrupt markets over the next few days, that doesn’t mean the long-term picture is pretty bad,” said Nishantha Dunya, chief investment officer at First Trust Private Bank Japan.
']

“The uncertainty persists, and investors are seeing more peripheral risk,” said John Tilghman, the head of investment banking at Westlake Securities.

“We’ve had a bad week, a lot of arrests, lots of outrageous acts that were carried out by authorities,” he said. “How could this be held up, and not prosecute? The government needs to conduct the job.”

U.S. immigration authorities have detentions up to 10 deportations at any one time a week, the border crossing that houses approximately 160,000 people is closed to foreign immigration.

Concerns over a virus that has caused many other cases in North Korea rose in recent weeks after North Korea blamed Trump for using a missile to launch a nuclear attack into the South in early March.

Title: Opinion | The Pandemic vs. The President
Generation:
['By World AIDS Day
In 2015, we celebrated the world’s first-ever, global goal to eradicate the deadly virus, and we are seeking to spread the cure.
Our personal journeys toward that goal, however, are often shrouded in controversy, controversy, controversy. Like everybody else, we try to avoid it. It reminds us that with all of the challenges we face we never let things get in the way of progress, and we just have to keep getting better.
In 2015 we began to see the emerging efforts by many countries to battle the deadly disease. The number of universal public health interventions are projected to reach 3 billion in 2018. By that point, more than 51 million people have undergone treatment, and nearly 1 million have been cured, a remarkable achievement.
We also began to see some progress. Those who had been treated for malaria had virtually no symptoms. What had transformed was the discovery of a community-based antimalarial medication called Replico, which had been stockpiled during the previous epidemics of malaria. With the combination of the four antimalarial medications and the zinc replacement medication, the medication made an immediate and significant difference. It cut off the immune system’s responses to malaria and eliminated the need for treatment. But the double whammy is the introduction of even more prescription-drug misuse; many people evade the use of drugs due to stigma, stigma and fear.
So we began to wonder if it would be possible to get rid of malaria and get rid of this disease in time. The answer lies in research by friends of mine and others in the field of malaria.
I set out to study malaria with the number one goal in mind. I wanted to find the answer to the answer to the “why”: for the benefit of the public. That is why I plan to detail the results of my recent research at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Public Health (AAPPH) in San Francisco this coming September.
My research explores how preventative interventions, like malaria medications, like replico, are linked to the prevention of malaria. The idea is that it’s the reduction of symptoms, the delivery of a disease prevention medication to the patient, that makes a difference. It helps the patient decide if their problem with malaria is a health problem, and is then considered critical and prevented. After that, the patients can focus on the other life-threatening conditions that call for a different type of treatment.
Since the start of this year, more than 3,200 malaria cases have been diagnosed in the U.S. alone and almost 4,000 deaths are attributable to the disease. Because the burden of malaria is so low, we are providing treatment to as many patients as possible as much as possible. We are also setting up blood donors to prevent malaria and identify people who are carriers of the disease.
We will analyze some results from my research on this topic and make our recommendations to the international medical community.
I want to make a point of saying that malaria treatment is not the problem. This is because until the disease is cut off, it is a single disease disease. The simple benefit of malaria treatment is that it prevents infection from getting to the person the disease strikes.
There is a “one shot” approach that can reduce the burden of the disease. We prescribe malaria medications that are effective against malaria but also must be given to everyone who lives in a region that has the best shot of living on the same bed as a malaria diagnosis. And we also prescribe a new kind of antimalarial pill.
I want to assure everyone that this data will be shared with clinicians and private health-care companies to demonstrate that it is possible to minimize the burden of malaria. And my research will be tailored to cases in which all sides of a public-health challenge are equally different and that makes getting rid of the disease easier.
And let me tell you that I have taught myself this before: If you want to see progress, not only are you trying to make progress but you want your friends and your colleagues to know too. Every person has the right to go to a doctor and ask him to prescribe a new drug. People have to be tried together; they have to accept and think outside the box.
That has only been a “One Shot” approach. I am not going to be the one to make what is going to be a “One Shot” an “A.”
']

This rhetoric was but enough to break the dearth of candidates this cycle, only a few of whom were senior senators, senators or members of Congress. Last year’s primaries were smaller, more ideologically motivated ones that flipped leaders in the battleground states they were home to or, since then, to former President Barack Obama and for Bill Clinton.
The issue is that the country has in some way contributed to its current dysfunction. Serious discussions in Washington fail to recognize the stakes. We’re essentially governed by a small group of ideologues. They insist on what they’re not responsible for, but we just don’t get it.
The practice of electing members by party and engaging with the president to advance their agenda tells us too little about how we should deal with a matter of responsibility.
Doing nothing causes government leaders to think twice. President Trump has muzzled his chief of staff, Jared Kushner, who takes personal responsibility for the president’s actions, and repeatedly publicly committed the nation’s worst national security policy failure to the wrong people.
Doing nothing is government’s method of pursuing a domestic agenda and working to fix that system. The borders of the country are porous and our enemies treat us as enemies with reckless abandon. Our ability to control the powerful and avoid crisis and disaster is at stake, and with that comes political accountability.
The biggest financial crisis of our time has nothing to do with the system, nothing to do with collective brinksmanship, nothing to do with political gamesmanship between lobbyists and politicians. It’s all about the resulting spiraling public debt and the massive waste and fraud we produce in government.
Keep in mind, however, that the problem is not personnel. It’s wealth. As an economist and former professor, I know how to demonstrate in recent years how good it is to put all our people in a place that can make money. Too many folks don’t know how much they’re earning. We’re not seeing the impact of the trickle-down wealth effect.
That’s what tax reform was all about, and tax reform has instead been the result of a triage and a triage exercise. Social Security and Medicare are largely overfunded, and nobody understands how each can account for all that means.
We need to address those problems to raise revenue and produce more services. So now and then we have a president who doesn’t care about the policies he’s implementing, and then a leader who doesn’t understand what the problem really is.
If we elect more Republicans and progressives, we’ll see how the system works for decades to come. A blessedly-hearted Congress and the citizens who faithfully vote for the constitution’s supreme court should share some responsibility.
']

Then of course there is the need for everyone to go home, including everyone in the family, to get tested. It’s very worrying. If that happens, then perhaps this is something you can’t stay away from, especially with the way it’s spread.

Naloxone can save a child’s life by getting them as close to a roll of smoke as possible, which might, in my opinion, be more effective. I have proof. According to the CDC, there have been 1,322 deaths from the very serious coronavirus in its lifetime (2001-2015).
The toll is even higher, from 100 babies to 120 adults, and you can’t trust vaccine manufacturers when it comes to the nasty side of it. The percentages of people who get the virus, and perhaps some people who get it in themselves, might not seem quite as high. But it could be a higher number, or it could be that it is just extremely rare. There are statistics which make you think of another causality or another being a vaccine potential.
One thing I’ve seen over the years is there are fewer veteran people that have been vaccinated, which probably explains the lower death rates. There may be high rates of antibodies to various viruses.
But an increasing number of people actually have copies of the virus that replicate and spread. Therefore, it’s much more likely that the virus is going to be spread via the use of smuggled or pirated water, or bacterial paste, or sex. At the risk of upsetting these experts, it is understandable that this is just an example of how viral diseases work. There is definitely a vaccine against such viruses, and the fact that there are many more of them means that they can be accurately identified.
With the money spent to fight Ebola, it is now worth it for anyone to think about screening in their community for the "superbug" virus as well as the other viruses that have been prevalent across the US and Europe.
I’m so impressed by the fact that the CDC has let millions of people know about who really gets the infection and who is not so susceptible. Not to scare them, but to educate them.

The space-damaged platform, along with a spooky scene of A Star Is Born, have become one of the unofficial sites of a major Queen Elizabeth II trip to London.
“Everything the monarch did from her inaugural in February 1977 to her life as a British monarch, from her rise to power to her legacy has gone on display in Buckingham Palace, among many, many media outlets,” Franklin said.
The Queen’s exploits have become far more significant than each other. In 2010 she commanded headlines that people largely saw as election promises — that the Queen would not challenge British rule. She was John Major’s shadow chancellor.

She kept her distance from Churchill, but two years later she called him to present a memorial rock — a reluctant but suitable ship.

“No one asks for special treatment, or any criticism from government employees, but in that case, the public has no opinion of a government entity to simply trust,” she said.
So whether you agree with, disagree, or share what it is that has been bad in your life, here are some of the things that you should be looking at today.
1. Text you you don’t want on Facebook
Anyone (anyone with a smartphone) can get on Facebook, all the time, and get help looking for problems, or problems when they don’t really like you. If your bad judgment is known to anyone, what happens is that one mistake is another but an even more dangerous one, when it comes to regulating your behavior on social media.
2. Speaking in other people’s language
For some, learning a different language could be a new lesson in living your whole life without someone believing in it. However, this often brings with it difficult communication skills, and some users are learning English while abroad as well.
3. Embracing the “engagement required” mindset
Opinions on particular topics can be either irrational or deliberately chosen in order to divide the conversation. However, when you think about it, of course, people might not realize just how active social media allows us to be.
4. Spreading lies and disinformation
Failed or participating in deception may appear politically and with one breath, on paper, and that translates into information that requires misinformation or disinformation to be produced in an effective manner. However, fake news is also misleading and harmful. For example, in many countries, disinformation is considered either by the media’s professional standards or by the public, or, if one is inclined to classify it as public, it is termed dishonest propaganda, which is a mixture of false and misleading propaganda.
5. How to get in front of public opinion
When all the arguments and opinions of our politicians make it to the main presentation, we give it weight, right? Wrong.

This is the kind of conversation that could ultimately lead to positive developments for the public to take risks in what they want to do on social media and develop their opinions.
The Executive Director of ACLU’s Institute on Cybersecurity said the following:
“Over the last twenty years, our society has been forced to turn to the digital digital reality for ways to effectively handle complex information for certain countries, when they would rather resort to reporting and distortion than engaging with the facts. With nearly every social change, at least part of the public backlash against such disinformation has been driven by the release of false, troubling and highly damaging information. We can expect many more false and misleading propaganda campaigns that expand to undermine trust in information and the value of information, when there is no time or place for those who disseminate it.”
6. Understanding how to deflect falsehoods from one another
Good news, bad news, and worse lies can pile up online, and undermine trust in the communication infrastructure to communicate with each other and with the world at large.
What if you were to one day want to take a step in the other direction? Would it be interesting to help in this area? How would you do it?

Cybersecurity and Privacy of Governments have always been different. However, if the US privacy beleaguered by this dynamic is it, then its case needs to be taken more seriously to grasp how our government, like, for that matter, could harm the public.

Title: Special reports
Generation:
['The driving environment is beyond safety, so should taxpayers prepare for a hefty increase in the vehicle excise tax (DHT) levied on vehicles bought in 2018.
The biggest increase in charges will be experienced in the March quarter of the current fiscal year (FY2018), which ended March 31, 2018.
The current excise tax on vehicles purchased in 2018 was 5.8 per cent, which was 3.2 per cent higher than the September 2017 increase.
In comparison, last fiscal year’s excise tax on 2018 vehicles was 3.6 per cent, 4.6 per cent higher than the September 2017 increase.
Looking at the contribution of “gear”, the new petrol tax added three points to the tax rate. The amount it would be introduced to, the amount it would be levied and the percentage increase are present.
The tax rate for diesel vehicles in the state of Kerala has more than doubled to 5.1 per cent. To boost revenue stream and therefore the whole economy, the 2.5 per cent new diesel motor vehicle excise tax received in 2018 has been increased to 9.8 per cent.
The diesel motor vehicle excise tax was double to 6.7 per cent last year, and the income tax on petrol vehicles increased to 2.5 per cent from 4.3 per cent a year ago. This helps in generating more revenues for the state government.
Turning to the income tax, income tax has been increased to 20 per cent from 18 per cent and the income tax on sugarcane and cane processing in Wanchadri district has been increased from 5 per cent to 20 per cent and sugar production has also increased from 5.4 per cent to 6.7 per cent. The current rate of income tax has been increased from 10 per cent to 14 per cent.
The income tax has also been increased to eight per cent from four per cent and the income tax on supermarkets in the state increased from 11 per cent to 18 per cent from 16 per cent.
Meanwhile, at a meeting held in Ketutla, President of National Association of Manufacturers, Rajul Singha was very much satisfied that there was a passing and vigorous development in the industry for their good interest. This situation has been further enhanced by the manufacturing push by UPA government.
He appreciated the support of the people in the state government on agrarian production issues.
The senior Congress leader also reiterated the higher excise tax on drinking water and infrastructure. He said the time has come for the state government to take a step back to correct and reverse the situation created by the high cess on water infrastructure in the state.
In line with the values of trust and respect people put in their way, the Deputy Governor in Meghalaya, Marathjan Samaj Party Dr. Ananda Gundu, after a “careful” election of Congress government, has taken an aggressive step in coming out in opposition against the incumbent government.
He is challenging the party chief to make amendments on budget of the house concerning the funds the state government spends on health and education. He added that the state government should pay about Rs.2,015 crore in withholding tax for the last five years.
']

Title: Long Reads
Generation:
['Long Reads
Monday, April 7, 2018
If it’s a recipe that’s not in itself a cookbook, perhaps a recent visit with the cook on wheels gives you an idea of how much you can actually learn about cooking and cooking basics. What’s yet to be determined is whether it’s “cookbooks,” or just a compilation of your favorite quick and easy dinners. Sorry, there are some recipes that you can’t find on Google to make your kitchen better. But so far, many of them are small in scale.
i. Amaze me with baking candies, mummies and sticky rice. Okay, so it was just candy to be made, right? It was sure to happen! Or it could be because I’m addicted to it. You all know how it is. The best-selling bottled magnum cognac ($25) is released today, with no mention of the ingredients. This one just beat the authenticity award at the Oscars.
Tweet cookies with salad, make with beef, mashed potatoes, grapes and vegetables. They don’t much use juice or sugar, but they are still a great time. This one is a cute idea, so cookable if you’re not a big fan of the science fiction genre.
Bread and eggs cracker with pasta. For breakfast, you’ll need lots of butter and olive oil; plenty of flour; and plenty of extra virgin olive oil. And the “wood” kind of idea: 1 (O) pound dry bread to break up the sugary flour. All of the key ingredients can be made into a tough, sharp thick bread for breakfast. Besides baking, you can get homemade muffins in the box.
Master the art of french toast with broccoli, carrots, onions and parsley. They don’t have such things as the right amount of salt. Sheer butter? Which is a shame, given how wonderful this one is.
Sweets with black beans, rice and noodles. The impressive work-in-progress recipe involves 16 hot items, enough for two.
Serves 6
4 cups chicken broth
6 cups broccoli, 1 cup sliced mushrooms, 2 cups chopped raw
1/2 cup shredded fresh parsley, chopped
1/2 cup extra virgin olive oil
4 eggs
1 cup vegan flour
1 teaspoon kosher salt
5 tablespoons heavy cream
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper
1 teaspoon freshly ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground cinnamon
2 tablespoons freshly ground black pepper
2 tablespoons butter
pinch of sugar
3/4 cup white wine
8-ounce can red-wine-flavored nonstick pitta bread (about 1 cup)
1/4 cup shredded zucchini, stems removed, and cut into halves
1. On a lightly floured surface, brush the chicken broth with the remaining ingredients. Stir in the broccoli, mushrooms, parsley, cumin, cinnamon, and/or cumin into the broth. Set aside.
2. Muddle all the onion and zucchini seeds with the bread. Drizzle in the remaining ingredients. Top with prepared flour and sprinkle with sugar, stirring until all the bread is browned and all the zucchini is tender. Cover and refrigerate at least an hour.
3. Skim 1/4 cup white wine vinegar from the jar for finishing. Sprinkle over the other vinegar, and spoon the remaining vinegar into the chilled serving bowl. Pour the vinegar over the bread and sprinkle over the remaining wine. Discard the vinegar and smooth, cover and refrigerate for at least an hour.
4. Cream the butter and lemon juice together in a large bowl. Mix in the egg wash. Turn the sauce over and add all the balsamic vinegar, salt, and pepper. Pour about 1/2 cup of the white wine over the flour mixture. Season the bread with the remaining vinegar. Taste and add more.
5. Add 1/4 cup of the bacon to the sauce, topping with the egg wash. Strain and drizzle in the orange juice. Season with 2 tablespoons more of the sugar and blend to coat. Serve with the batter.
Note:
Prepare slow cooker for serving. Preheat on low and reduce heat to low until it’s about 375 degrees F. Place on an island. Cover and transfer the balsamic vinegar to a nonstick or steel pan. Put the skillet on medium heat. Season the rolls and prepare for serving. When the rotisserie oven should be halfway complete, remove and set aside.
']

Title: Have Your Say
Generation:
['The outbursts over the last weekend have only heightened the illusory sense of freedom we have as a people—and the self-importance we have toward the rest of us.
Our sense of ourselves as being real somehow deteriorates as a human being, and yet, we crave anything. We shower on mountains, shower on alligators, shower on bears, shower on alligators. We put on makeup that makes us look totally ordinary. We pose with our hands in ungodly positions, take our shower. We hardly ever have time to think about life or our everyday practices, or say how we, at the end of the day, are most likely feeling our feelings. These thoughts contain enormous generality to our conscious existence, and they've been presented in ways almost as absurdly as we see any human being do. I've written some diatribes (research for some time and I'm still humming) on this subject, but never a fear of what one might say. Feelings of being right, and being wrong or wrong do occasionally influence other, more fundamental terms, and still, they hurt and hurt people. No surprise that most people I know behave in similar ways. We, the people we love in our own skin, have these thoughts, opinions, and we are often convinced that whatever we say must be right.
Where, in this? In our own selves, the more ideas we blur to ourselves about life, the more everyday we feel judged, hurt, and hurt ourselves. And the less we celebrate and celebrate the freedom we have into existence, the more we get resentful that not just is there pleasure in a sense. Try to say, "This is just making you unhappy, and is that the ordinary thing?"
It's easy to point and show a box of labels. It's hard to say, "Why is everything in its own fashion?"
One person--this person's opinion--can explain the things that don't differ drastically from others. Others can consider that, too.
If so, surely we can end up doing the same work.
Some people insist, "I don't care. Don't fret." Others need to make this clear. We grow up and move in different, and different, ways. We're raised in different, disparate, varied, repetitive ways.
Some people change. Others aren't changed at all.
Why am I alive? We understand we're different. Let's change some of these differences by restructuring them for more equal things.
This also may be the most important way to sum up the journey, which I'm very pleased I've had the chance to explore. If you're, in any way, not being different, why are we different? We're all different, but we're a racial group, a sexual group, and life -- the underlying components of all of our differences. For instance, I'm different for a different reason. There are times when I feel like I'm being drastically different from my colleagues. For instance, I think a black person has very very high IQ, but statistically black people outperform white people in IQ. So, the difference is clearly a good thing for me. But how do I keep myself moving forward in the way I'm moving forward?
If you're not changing at all, just hear me out, and not just in your front yard or the movies you were watching last week.
Do you recognize your real self?
']

The aerodynamic terrain of Australia’s icy country is strangely quiet. Like Italy, it’s just a frozen lagoon of six and a half miles on the western bank of the Bruce and Lord Mount Baker rivers.
And you can’t see anyone without carrying a stick. The Bureau of Meteorology on Monday evening warned of “hazardous sky pollution” due to a long winter cloud cover and weekend thunderstorms.
But the not-so-grim tone of the BSMA’s news release accompanying the advisories is actually upbeat and balanced. This is part of its explanation of how Australia needs to reevaluate its environmental health.
The BSMA said that its recommendation, which made it to the official final plan stage of a review earlier this year, also covers the rubbish-strewn landscapes of Central Australia, as well as everything from oil and mining activities to electricity and oil in the Western Australia-South Australia region.
Bureau chief Paul Hogan has already said Australia should “revisit our environmental records as part of a formal review process.”
That inquiry began in the late 1980s and saw complex decisions about substances being shipped to Australia, including bio-based fertilizers. Bats have been banned in Australia because of concerns about malnutrition.

I don’t think any of those groups were the first to do well in November, I think there was always going to be a chunk of that following the Trump Election of November, but there were very active (organized) groups doing very well, even when the president wasn’t at the rallies, like: the Iranian Americans in Miami, Brazilian marchers in Chicago, Middle Eastern Patriots in Omaha, Michigan Patriots in Denver, Susan Wexler in Dayton, Iowa Patriots in New York City, Minnesota Patriots in Oregon, Wisconsin Patriots in St. Paul, and Milwaukee Patriots in Kansas City.

I would say that it’s mostly as individuals who did well on Election Day as they could have ever hoped for.
I agree and fully support the efforts of elected representatives of the people and the organization that make our world work and make democracy works. They are to be commended.
I have a few other “better things” that people keep mentioning to me this election year: a chance to vote for a change that they can feel good about.

Title: Elizabeth Warren: Where did it go wrong for her?
Generation:
['WASHINGTON (CNN) — Elizabeth Warren has a bitter history with Republicans. But as a Harvard graduate with an activist background, her party has developed its own program that forces reform. In January, a conservative advocacy group in Colorado accused the GOP of playing politics by prosecuting senators for having dual citizenship and three children of Taiwanese parents who were not born in the United States. Now, in an interview, Warren is calling the accusations baseless.
Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat, told the Wall Street Journal that in her autobiography, released on Tuesday, "when I hear that there is a big campaign to vilify me in Washington, I don't know if I put it in perspective."
Warren said the Republicans targeted her birth family. She said the demagoguery was because of her "immigrant heritage, and immigration laws."
"I had been a Roman Catholic and I have a very simple message to the Republicans: It's not so simple. And I believe that,'" Warren told the Journal.
Trump's immigration, she said, was "the only path" to citizenship.
Democrats, including Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, said the story was false.
"Senator Warren is wrong," Gillibrand told CNN in an interview. "She has never said that anyone in her family was born in the United States."
Warren had been a darling of liberal media establishment since entering public life and after winning election in 2008 to the U.S. Senate. A minority in the Democratic Senate, she represents parts of the conservative business and advocacy community and has made immigration her top priority of the month.
She has been seeking to reform immigration law, which was enacted by a Democratic president in 2012 under a Republican-led Congress. In 2017, the House of Representatives passed a new immigration bill that stripped protections for people in the U.S. illegally.
The situation she described in the new book, titled "As You Think," is exacerbated by the fact that polls show Trump popularity levels among Americans are starting to decline, suggesting Trump is perceived as his weakest economic asset as president.
"Senator Warren makes a list of things she would do that she would not do that they find amusing," said a Democratic aide who believes that Democrats have enough leverage in talks with the Senate to pass the new measure.
Warren told the Journal that Republicans need a "tough stance."
"'We've got to get a tough stance in what we call the country's immigration law," she said. "Our laws fall short of that ... I would prefer that we get a tough stance on all of these things."
Warren said the party of the president will raise "facts and prejudices" as a way to win votes.
']

Title: Things to do indoors with your children
Generation:
['Kids: Kids get electric, too, in a new recommendation from Los Angeles-based parenting bloggers to give you and your kids together just as much time as with adults.
They have little houses, or cubicles, or built-in televisions on which to entertain or watch their favorite shows. They also keep the door shut and watch their favorite sports and other adult films, which can even be turned off on their pets.
It’s a reminder that no matter what life has thrown at them, kids keep getting smarter and smarter, but only as they get older.
Sometimes, the best-case scenario is the best-case scenario: You live your life until age 70, pay down your mortgage, and come out of retirement in a brand-new fancy, healthy lifestyle.
Then, with the help of adults who listen, you finish your mortgage. The good news is, you’ll leave a legacy that is far more individual than mere nostalgia.
In some cases, they’ll have to live, shop and attend town-hall meetings to overcome feelings of isolation.
One of my favorite foods these days is chocolate. At first, I didn’t think my husband and I had a chance to visit the country’s chocolate makers because of our mischievous kids. Eventually, though, I did, realizing that by happy, delicious chocolate, a choc-a-can is much better than plain chocolate.
Then I got this email from one of my grandchildren, who says he’s a chocolate lover, even though he always insisted that we visit the country’s antiques dealers. We go to the antiques fairs to purchase antiques, and sometimes, he wants to see the bricks that we made in college. There’s no room to grab and be a part of that junk, since we don’t live in them.
In the end, I have to say this: Maybe it’s because I sit around in bed longer nights to keep up with my grandchildren. Maybe this is because I watch so much TV so often, and this is what has me feeling grateful and thankful this year.
In some cases, it’s because I have guilt, or as some parents have told me, a worry about losing me. One of the more common fears about taking their children to the airport after a trip is that they’ll forget to bring toilet paper.
Sometimes, though, guilt and worries add motivation to the adventure of turning your life upside down. At the end of a break, I go to the park where I think about all the kids that have been taken away, and pick them up. It’s like closing your eyes and letting a whole new world fill your world.
In those moments, as my grandchildren open their computers to learn to read and discover new things, they’ll learn how to relax, or how to shop and live, or how to have safe meals.
They’ll feel secure when they start school. They’ll feel that in their lifetime, they’ll put out the pieces of the puzzle and figure out how to stay like that. In the end, if their parents can live out their dreams or stay like that, they’ll find someplace new.
So the good news: No matter how much time you spend away from your kids, there’s no feeling like a “car that can’t run.” And if your kids don’t want you and their house moving so often, they’ll find a new job as they grow up, but the car that just crashed right in front of them isn’t going to bring their new home with it.
That’s because we’ve got two generations of kids. Our only difference is that our grandchildren will be living in the same place for three generations.
We will spend time together, eating, spending time with our kids, and building a living, breathing family life.
']

Title: Bristol sisters aim to raise awareness of 'honour hate'
Generation:
['By Justin Sullivan, CNN Political Correspondent
WASHINGTON, April 5 (CNN) - From Donald Trump on down, visiting science in the southern states states means thinking about the name of your favorite song and not thinking about your own grievances.
But in Washington, where President Trump has called several shows of the National Prayer Breakfast famous for their rousing prayer, the real-life sisters in Bristol, Missouri, want to raise awareness of the hate and its effects on Muslims, Hindus and other ethnic minorities in the US.
Their show, "Black Men Are Gentle," is one of the most public actions of theirs to come on the issue.
"We don't necessarily feel like we are on the side of the Obama era," said wife Gina, a 13-year veteran of the women's council.
Gina claims the first time she came to speak about the issue, her brother was killed in a car accident, that wasn't unique to the US, and it wasn't a protest against the religion of black people. It was simply the first time for her to say that she hoped the Republican Party would treat all minorities equally.
Daughters Gina and Sarah, in their early 20s, gave birth to their first son in 2008 and Gina is currently in her mid-30s.
"Our aim in the show was to raise awareness that this is something that affects every single American," said Sarah, a lifelong Baptist missionary.
She continues that she can't envision the chaos and instability that would be felt with the arrival of President Trump in the US, when things could have been so good and Trump had such a positive effect on the country, in other words.
Both women are intentional about how they want to frame this moment.
"This is a country where we're supposed to worship the God that we're supposed to love so deeply," Gina told CNN.
She added that what drew her to the show was the message about all of us feeling so vulnerable in this world and how family shows that we could be OK and continue being a people first and know everyone's security is our home.
Sarah believes what has happened in the Middle East and elsewhere is just a symptom of the way Americans have lost perspective, she said.
"It is the same attitude where a lot of people now don't realize that everyone needs to just be open to humanity and know everybody's existence," she said.
"This show is putting a spotlight on that and realizing that is a part of humanity right now," Sarah added.
"Black Men Are Gentle" will take place at The O'Hare International Airport in Chicago on March 29 and 30 and is sold out.
']

Title: Smart motorways plan aims to boost safety
Generation:
['From a sleek sleek exterior to the posh interior, the Smart Park for Connected Cars project has gone through significant improvements for the city, representing some of the most horrific crashes on the roads around the country.
At Ground Zero, a massive traffic tragedy, a parking ramp and the ground floor of a converted military school called Vakon Opal built to make it a safe place for all but the bravest of those taking their yearly vacation at the gym, repairs have been made, a local court was relocated and the parking ramp is now comparable to an office tower.
But while dozens of these improvements were made before the tragedy, these improvements occurred at a time when technology might not be so helpful for long term safety. The Smart Park and parking ramp are what saved lives, especially for those with long commutes. Unfortunately, a recent study (pdf) by Navigant’s Insurance Survey (apropos of Navigant’s award-winning series evaluating claims for auto insurance and how drivers experience those expenses) found that too many owners reported delays of at least 2 minutes or more in their car crashes.
The reason is simple: cars are so advanced, it is impractical to continually upgrade them. It’s important to consider the underlying reasoning behind this effect when considering a deductible of $1000 or more and achieve continued safety. That remains extremely difficult to achieve with any technology, but it should be particularly important when operating a vehicle in extreme traffic conditions. Only high-quality, technology- and communication-oriented technologies are able to make even the most proficient cars and vehicles crash without rumbling into each other. So with this analysis, Navigant noted that their findings on technology and safety are the opposite of what most other insurance data suggest. In a nutshell, injuries to drivers and victims of a major crash increase by 85%, and deaths are also reduced by 77%.
Many other studies suggest that cars are driving more independently than in peak times, by a majority of 2%, although that doesn’t mean one driver gets hit with head or neck injuries.
Still, safety improvements for drivers on all parameters are the same thing. Landings, use of the correct navigation system, etc., are all great improvements in passenger safety, but they are often not implemented until at least before a crash occurs.
One approach that seems to work better for most is the Smart Park. Like other approaches to collision mitigation, this technology aimed to increase pedestrian safety, so commuters stay in the loop when approaching traffic on the road. The city explains that it has also turned to overwork to boost pedestrian safety and their ability to hold passengers for as long as possible.
Not all pedestrian safety measures are found in the Smart Park, at least not on every speed limit or active oncoming moving sidewalks. It is a myth that pedestrian safety is solely caused by cars and traveling quite carefully (it is possible that roadworks causing damage to the flow of traffic can also create avoidance of obstacles), but its true magnitude is less and less because hundreds of thousands of pedestrians die and thousands more are injured each year.
In addition to reduced losses for drivers on tight traffic (and making more of them safely disabled), it can also add to costs for apartment dwellers. The Smart Park does not implement optimal pedestrian traffic design for that specific type of traffic. Instead, it can minimize the need for non-lethal assistance such as use of a pedestrian control device like a strong, level of foot and the ability to manually go into a path of traffic. And, of course, pedestrian safety is made more difficult by the increasing presence of cars, making pedestrians less inclined to get out of the way.
When evaluating self-driving cars, another helpful strategy is to watch how fast the car runs to slow down traffic (just not directly, it is much faster), as shown by a recent survey done by the Colorado DMV. All 90 percent of respondents reported that they have engaged in a 75 mph zone early in their driving, which might indicate that they are actively accelerating their driving habits to accelerate traffic. In other words, while they may not be at an optimal velocity, that is a good measure of how fast they are moving, and that in turn can help reduce their chances of injuries and death.
Most importantly, it allows people to have the options they want when it comes to their car when they choose to drive to work.

Title: Chelsea Manning case: Judge orders release from prison
Generation:
['By Tom Barlow
(CNN) — An Army sergeant who gained access to former President Barack Obama’s email account while serving as a whistle-blower for WikiLeaks has been ordered released from federal prison.
Prison officials had sought release in court documents and said Monday the Department of Justice had completed “substantial assistance in obtaining” the papers, according to a letter obtained by CNN. The unnamed inmate was ordered to serve his time before being transferred to federal prison for questioning.
The judge approved the release order during a separate court hearing Monday, in which the defendant, 21-year-old Bradley Manning, is said to have denied trying to leak classified data.
Manning, one of the masterminds of the “Dark Knight” hacking scandal, is accused of leaking classified information.
At a lengthy hearing Wednesday, a federal judge ordered Manning released without pretrial hearings to move forward with his case in U.S. District Court in San Francisco.
Manning’s defense team is asking for a continuance and argues he isn’t entitled to a new trial because of another criminal conviction — an open-ended statute of limitations.
Pamela Engel, Manning’s lawyer, told CNN she planned to ask the court whether the judge would have granted the pending motion.
“We appreciate your patience,” Engel said. “But I would note that, like everyone else, we have yet to receive any briefing from this court.”
Attorneys for the government and Manning’s U.S. attorney filed a joint brief questioning the timing of the June 2016 detainer, which has languished since its release. In the brief, the attorney has asked the court to decide what time period Justice Department lawyers will seek to obtain the documents and the continued implementation of a court-ordered detainer.
The court meets once each day.
At the time of the detainer, President Donald Trump signed an executive order extending the terms of the detainer. The order lifted the stop-gap provision and set the process a few weeks ago.
Manning was captured by FBI agents from his home in Manning’s hometown of Fort Hood, Texas, in December 2013. One of Obama’s top diplomats in Iraq, Manning is based in Florida.
CNN has reached out to Manning’s attorneys for comment.
The defense contends Manning attempted to obtain classified information from the Defense Department, which was less than 16 months after Obama took office. The judge previously ruled Manning had access to confidential information and withheld it.
Manning was sentenced in December to 20 years in prison for leaking information to the website, WikiLeaks, about soldiers’ rapes, sexual assaults, hostage takers and preparations for the 2010 U.S. invasion of Iraq. The court-ordered detainer is a “hard-right” document the judge decided was secret.
Manning’s attorneys contend the litigation was closed by the sentencing and that he is entitled to a new trial.
Manning was working at Fort Hood at the time of the hack.
']

Title: Guinea-Bissau: Political chaos could boost cocaine trade
Generation:
['By Sam Leyne
A West African cocaine-smuggling route could be linked to increased drug trafficking in Guinea-Bissau by Islamic groups and political turbulence in the north of the country, analysts said.
A spy from the Ministry of Political Affairs (MDE) told the World Drug Report that President Faustino Timbuktu, who departed Guinea-Bissau earlier this week, was traveling with dangerous VIPs including Chief Osama Zamudio, the spy head of the NCMOC, as part of a delegation of EU ministers, the paper said, citing Jean Tegua Achie, the head of the NCMOC.
Although poverty and violence are not new problems for the Franco-Guinea-Bissau government, in the 40 years since President Francisco Bagro Diallo fled with his wife La Marate, separatist forces have attempted to fragment the region.
Nyajine Cahal, a French NGO and rebel leader, told the World Drug Report that criminality in Guinea-Bissau is among the problems affecting the drug industry in the east of the country, saying: “Coles [Belières, a major international cocaine market], which could leave such Colombian narcotics gangs open to the possibility of smuggling the drugs to the West African continent."
According to Mr. Cahal, the primary driver of illicit drug trafficking is the route via the Côte d’Ivoire–Afrique nationale. "The organisation of safe passage exists through the movement of arms, drugs and ammo into the majority of illicit trafficking areas in the country," he told the World Drug Report.
This report warns that the key risk is the emergence of terrorist groups that the country’s security forces are unable to tackle. A 2002 arms embargo still remains to be implemented in the country.
In 2018, the estimated cost of fighting the militants in Guinea-Bissau’s northern region stood at $2.6 billion. This figure includes the $800 million costs of the ongoing offensive by the armed forces and security agencies in the south and the budget of the international bloc that provides funding to the conflict.
Mr. Cahal said: “The two major problems in the country today, in terms of the state of lawlessness and security forces, may just be the new drug enforcer.”
He added that the polluting activities of military forces have made the task of fighting all the criminals more difficult. He also pointed out that the stability of the country is only guaranteed once there is permanent peace and stability is restored, and that the application of a criminal law is high.
Mr. Cahal was also critical of the Inter-Continental Hotel, which has been guilty of the same high level of violence that has dogged Guinea-Bissau for years, especially when it reopened amid renewed insecurity after the United Nations called for a cease-fire two years ago.
But Mr. Cahal said: “As long as the establishment of a militia and the role of police are still considered the state of law, criminal structures inside the political systems must be destroyed or used as a model of resilience.”
The West African regional bloc called for a ceasefire, the release of prisoners of war and for the commission of elections that would pave the way for constitutional reform. It said efforts should be made to find a peaceful solution to the crisis in Guinea-Bissau, in areas that are already plagued by civil war and logistical bottlenecks.
']

The deadly flu is spreading in Southeast Asia and the Middle East, following an outbreak that began in Thailand earlier this year. More than 60,000 people have been sickened by the virus in those countries.
Global health officials have warned of a risk of new transmission for a third consecutive year.
About 39,000 students are being temporarily put on notice for early initiation of school, to cut short lessons and to wash and disinfect personal property, The Lancet reported.
About 1.5 million Australians attend public primary schools every year, but almost half the students now must be vaccinated, according to International Alert, an international network of medical and scientific experts.
About 60,000 British schoolchildren are exposed to swine flu, which has killed at least 96 people and infected hundreds more, according to the British Health Protection Agency.
H1N1 virus can cause infections between three and five times larger than previously estimated.
