Title: Thailand protest: Opposition takes to streets in rare protest
Generation:
['BANGKOK, Thailand — Suthep Thaugsuban and thousands of people protested in Bangkok on Friday over Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha's veto of proposed reforms to stave off corruption and kick corruption out of Thailand.
They rallied and held a one-hour news conference at a government building, chanting, "Cough, down. Cough down!" and "Take the water."
That prompted the government to invite rallies around the country this weekend, urging their followers to challenge the anti-corruption maneuvers deployed in parliament and the lower house.
The rallies are the first since May 2, when dozens of riot police and pro-government soldiers attacked the main office of the chamber government in charge of constitutional reform. The police retreated, leaving behind police vehicles and the opposition rallying around the bases.
Protests on Saturday in Bangkok and elsewhere followed signs that the May 2 attempt to give the parliament a majority was to fail.
"We're standing with the protesters," opposition leader Suthep Thaugsuban told reporters.
The government's move to give the parliament a majority and deemphasize the opposition steps would show that Thailand is fracturing under the weight of corruption scandals in the country, pushing it too far to put an end to economic growth.
Some blame the government's latest development on Suthep's general incapacity to tackle corruption, but others tout his unprecedented government reform that aims to lower the city government's power and avoid tax evasion by merchants.
The latest government reform is the first to fully go into effect since Thailand's former monarchy fell in 1991.
On Wednesday, it took the first step toward enacting the reforms through changes to the charter of the constitution. It said, however, that "an order was not convened on the basis of guidelines published a few days ago. We request that the best compromise between our demands and the demands of the governing coalition and the opposition forces is made before the reforms can be implemented."
The action against Suthep and six other top government officials has highlighted a disagreement with the opposition in parliament over how to tackle corruption. It's the latest outcry, though, about government's brazen disregard for members of Parliament's independence.
Shortly after news of the police, a helicopter circled overhead and panned over the parliamentary seat of parliament, which has the advantage of being a prime-time TV event.
"We want the anti-corruption measures that were proposed before the May 2 coup to be implemented," a spokesman for the opposition, Thaismee Behpagathith, told reporters.
"This is a huge mistake to implement the measures it already recommended so now we need them by Tuesday."
A violent demonstration around the parliament building led police to halt some commercial flights out of the capital on Thursday.
It was the first time it had occurred in three years, but Thai television pictures showed protesters chanting, "Not the dictator, not the king!" as they marched through the building. Police retreated.
The opposition rallied behind the government and some were praised by members of the Chinese embassy.
"We had plans to do this here but were met with deafening jeers and hailstorms, then the government decided not to pull out its arms," interior minister Suthep Thaugsuban said.
Protesters marched through Bangkok in a relentless fashion on Thursday and Friday, demanding the government step down and making way for a referendum on constitutional reforms.
About 5,000 protesters blocked a stretch of Thailand's main road in central Bangkok on Friday, followed by clashes with police that left a dozen dead, a Thailand News Service report on Friday said.
Nearby, a leader of the Grand Coalition party, Suthep's ally and leader of the ruling Congress party, Nandita Achteh, was killed in an insurgent attack on the parliament.
Nandita was shot during Friday's violence, police said.
']

Title: Saviour of the dead: Burying the bodies India forgets

['Riza Maykoon, 45, is the country’s most trusted guide to finding the body of his friend. “I go to over 100 funerals, and this time is different,” said Maykoon.
Maykoon died in India’s Pathania district of western Uttar Pradesh in February after going missing for 11 days. In an interview with this website, Maykoon said that he did not miss any funerals. “Many of my friends, they were in sleep and I don’t like to hear about that,” he said. “I want to focus on healing.”
His case is, of course, most important because he was last seen alive on Feb. 12. Though Uttar Pradesh authorities are not yet releasing details about what transpired, it is clear that Maykoon was killed shortly after he was reported missing. The police said the death was due to a lack of communication between the two. Maykoon’s abduction was the deadliest in his life, a fact which investigators are struggling to understand. (An email sent to Dharmendra Kaur, the home secretary in the Uttar Pradesh capital, Lucknow, reported that a villager who was recording the DNA on Maykoon’s camera said the body was stuck between two DNA markers.) “Relatives of the deceased asked the family to take care of the family members too. The deceased’s parents could not send anyone to retrieve the body for some time,” said a police official in Lucknow. (The presence of the missing person’s family can be gauged with the presence of those living with the victim. Some people, especially those relatives of the deceased, are annoyed when questions of the missing person’s identity are left unanswered.)
Partly, Maykoon’s problems are explained by the fact that his GPS locator was at the site of his disappearance. But the GPS’s location is also vital: Even on an 8-kilometer map, it would not be clear how long it was taken from the location. A map of Uttar Pradesh, like Sharma’s, would be different from that of the rest of the country.
Maykoon had lived near the border in Uttar Pradesh for several years when he took his family back home in the late 1990s. His brother and sister met from prison in 1983 to practice at a camp after a family of paupers detained him and his wife for poaching their cattle. Maykoon found his way back to the camps near his flat, where his partner and others were living. The wife and his partner began questioning the men around him.
They had broken their trance to visit the den, where they interrogated the men about their daily lives in order to find out what happened to their wife.
After the women returned, she engaged in conversations with the men, telling them that she had vanished. She and the wife did not tell the men what happened to her. They stayed put for nearly three months, and continued talking about their (swearing) experiences of living at the camp. None of the men, even the two accused, acknowledged that they had disappeared.
The main question they had to answer was that of the women. The men said they had gone to Birbhum village, a village in Uttar Pradesh, where Maykoon had gone. Maykoon had come home two days after his body was found. Once they had returned, a group of men and women with him left for their homestead, where they collected the body, wrote a testament to Maykoon’s life, and explained where the dearest people were. The men and women replied that they did not know where Maykoon was. The men, she added, did not know where he was.
When pressed further, the men and women said they did not even know where his body was found.
Few people, in general, remember the differences between Maykoon and Sharma. Those who know Maykoon say that he was an intelligent student and was given just one exam. Sharma, on the other hand, was not a good student; he had reportedly been tortured by the police twice.

Title: How Europe deals with terror offenders when they are freed from jail
Generation:
['By Steve Vaughn: CNN
For nearly a century, Europe has tried to stem the tide of immigration from dangerous countries, some of it from foreign spy flights, a massive Briton truck bomber, and a suicide bomber disguised as an Olympic cheerleader.
President Barack Obama, French President Emmanuel Macron, Italy’s Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni, the United States, the Vatican, Portugal, Italy, and Mexico have all quietly helped curb the flow of people fleeing instability, thanks to immigration systems that keep many migrants within reach.
But the whole system runs contrary to the law and leaves asylum seekers or refugees without legal protection unless they have a clear case that should be turned over to the police for deportation.
“For too long we have allowed the institutionalization of the political influence of the Executive Branch,” said Steven Brauser, the Director of our North Africa & Middle East Center at Syracuse University in New York. “Now they’re spending more time on implementing specific prevention and response measures than they have for any longer and by the time that’s completed, they will be having to implement another crisis, with all the possible consequences.”
In reality, just a tiny fraction of 10,000 people traveling from 20 different countries — most of them Syrians — are currently getting some kind of protection from the arrival of a military force, like the US Marine Corps. Many are migrants who arrived in Europe without an appointment, or have family members who are killed in the conflicts in their home countries.
President Trump recently announced a plan to decouple Americans from military immigration into a citizenship program, creating the phasing-out of 18,000 deferral deferral cases nationwide.
Thousands of refugees who arrived in Europe in 2015 by choice now are on the run, and military officials are asked to step in to help.
“The effect of the humanitarian crisis that is occurring in Europe today is greater than we thought,” said Valerie Laurence, Policy Director at the American Civil Liberties Union. “We hope that the European Court of Human Rights will require that the authorities are legally responsible for harboring the most dangerous people.”
President Trump has faced many challenges during his presidency.
In late February, he visited a U.S. prison to hear from people who were processed at U.S. military bases and made a decision.
“While we can’t justify the atrocities that they’ve committed, we understand that they were hardly unknown,” President Trump said. “They stood guard at a facility here in America, watched American citizens at home go on hunger strikes, and are portrayed as heroes, whether on television or in court.”
President Trump and the Department of Homeland Security last month released the names of 1,000 inmates from Britain’s Metropolitan Police Service (MPIS) that had been indicted on charges of the murder and sexual assault of a soldier.
Most are under overburdened with criminal and immigration procedures, and their names have been being handed over to a judge for deportation, and 30,000 other alleged criminal suspects from Libya, Italy, and Greece have been granted asylum or refugee status in European Union nations.
This migration pattern has been building for years, and the Trump administration has not stepped up or slowed it down.
“Defunding our airports is unprecedented, but the de facto rule is denying refugees and other refugees of any sense of security,” said Eric Lefkofsky, who teaches immigration law at Washington State University. “We need to be clear about what’s legitimate and what is not.”
']

Title: Ethiopia's Ambo city: 'From freedom to repression under Abiy Ahmed'
Generation:
['By Alexander Kay
Former International Development and Development Center director Ebru Ibrahim Shwezi is remembered by his hometown of Ambo, the "Children of Abiy Ahmed," a capital of Ethiopia's largest Muslim nation.
His death is a blow to democracy in the current troubled Ethiopia and a headache for former Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, who has been a target of racist and anti-Semitic attacks from the country's semi-autonomous Islamist opposition, the pro-government Ethiopian Democratic People's Party (EDP).
"For our people, freedom under Abiy Ahmed was a badge," an official told CNN Turk on Sunday. "For us, Abiy Ahmed was Ethiopian leader with vision, vision and with peace."
Yusuf Jamil Abiy, a former office manager in the oil and gas industry who died on March 8 after fighting with the Ethiopian military, became the symbolic leader of Abiy Ahmed's government after his resignation from the Ministry of State Security after nearly a decade in office.
From freedom under Abiy Ahmed to repression under Abiy Ahmed, world's worst anti-Semitism
Previous to this Abiy Ahmed vowed to get back to his former course and start with government-led reforms, the U.N. official said.
He was sacked after nine months in office, said the U.N. official, who requested anonymity because of the sensitivity of the topic. The former government official said that the current transitional government suffered more setbacks than in Abiy Ahmed's first tenure.
Three months after Abiy Ahmed's election, the government began a crackdown on protesters, training law enforcement and social welfare workers, said the official.
At the same time, Abiy Ahmed launched human rights group Amnesty International to be involved in protests against his decisions in the disputed 2015 referendum he won. Amnesty said this month that this was largely due to Abiy Ahmed's military-backed militia acting out of self-interest.
Arguably, from Abiy Ahmed's role as the former commander of the "Boy Scouts of America" group -- a U.S.-based adidas company -- in Somalia "was a calling for freedom of the environment," the EDP official said.
Abiy Ahmed's Election
In a country where urban segregation is not well policed, an influx of Ethiopian migrants fleeing poverty in neighboring Eritrea, south Africa and the Gulf have historically been identified as racist.
People see the Ethiopian government's bid to legislate Muslim immigration as a way to ensure Abiy Ahmed's hold on power.
Dissident Abiy Ahmed has called for an investigation into the violent threats he faced, including shootings and arson in January that left more than 20 people injured.
In December, Abiy Ahmed sent a condolence letter to President Abiy Ahmed saying that thousands of Muslim students and teachers were at high risk in government schools, and for people in public places where political gatherings are banned.
"From the public areas in response to the threat of political violence, which was instituted by the Ethiopian authorities, thousands of people were subjected to harassment," the letter said.
"During the dialogues between the government and the opponents to these leaders' political policies, many years ago, and since then, students and teachers have been forced to build temporary temporary schools that hosted political protest sites."
Abiy Ahmed, a Muslim himself, has been criticized by his former critics for a single message and rhetoric that defines Abiy Ahmed as being too far-right.
Sources: CNN Turk and facebook
']

Title: Guinea-Bissau: Political chaos could boost cocaine trade
Generation:
['The eve of Guinea-Bissau's presidential elections is drawing to a close, after losing a high-profile court ruling on allegations the government intended to win by turning off voters.
But in another potentially ominous development, President Joseph Bozize's socialist government could be in for a hard landing if the election is fraudulently.
With the presidential election set for April 17, Bozize may still face a Senate run-off in the face of strong protests from farmers.
In the end, the struggle for control of the country's cocoa harvest will depend on the outcome of the results: an untested, slimmed-down government with a socialist background and heavy reliance on the U.S. drug industry for raw materials.
With its relatively young legislative body now overseeing the approval process, just as it did in 2001, Guinea-Bissau may get little respite from the people's fury over the election fraud.
That's why the government is pushing ahead with electoral reforms that are designed to create a less democratic government. In the wake of a crime investigation that's classified as a "state crime" and released publicly to the media Thursday, President Bozize conceded that he was setting up a "compromise" government.
"There will be an eventual politicisation of the electoral system," he said during a three-day visit to the central African country.
But there are serious concerns about seeping in with the new political environment.
"Insecurity has multiplied. Factors that will prevent a normal political process will flourish, which could be a source of instability. The stock market has been volatile," his ministry of finance official Joaquim Tavares told AFP, explaining that investors have been concerned that too much had been done for too long.
“This could be the most unpredictable and costly period of the transition to change in a long time," he added.
The criminal groups largely run money for political purposes while donors are still largely ruling elites, blamed for the mess the nation has made since it fell from grace.
A little over a year ago, there was a resurgence of street protest groups in the streets of capital Conakry, but they largely abandoned their peaceful action to increase more violence.
The police have curbed their sentences but remain an organised and civilian group, often with only state support and ammunition.
Already, the president has accumulated a rash of corruption allegations, with former Finance Minister Delysa Cunha having received around $4 million in bribes for fixing a project to take copper out of Liberia.
Bozize has dismissed concerns from some of the opposition that his rule is being rigged in favor of the government.
The referendum this year for a new constitution is due by July 30. But opposition parties have expressed concern about a delay in taking the referendum seriously.
Current laws empower the government to cut spending and approve projects from budget until it shows "clearance" from the constitution.
Analysts say that if the Electoral Commission is rigged in favor of a single candidate, the process will have become more dubious. It would also increase the risks of conflicts between the government and opposition, potentially widening the election to try to determine who represents whom.
The Socialist opposition is also concerned by the fact that the anti-government opposition has yet to register in the polls, which could in turn boost the government's chances.
The Social Democrats are doubtful that election authorities will handle the vote properly. But they'll rather use the help of undercover police posing as victims.
The Christian Science Monitor's Germaine Baume explains the challenges to an already a democratic government:
']

Title: Blasian love: The day we introduced our black and Asian families
Generation:
['Sugar be is what your family loves most.
If you love it, you’re going to love things the way it is. But if you don’t love your family, it’s only going to get worse.
“When we first came into Jamaica, I wasn’t sure if we were going to be our own people or what,” says one black and Asian family in Jamaica, say. “We were living ourselves.”
Humbug and their parents, both immigrants, learned English while they were young. All went to boarding school; their house owners looked after the families.
Initially, one group agreed to let them live. The others didn’t. They were “just immigrants.” A pair of black and Asian families decided to start families. So, on March 12, 1938, they were released from the isolation they had made in Jamaica. They were served turkey schnitzel, a street snack.
As sisters, Kwame, Josiah and Dawn were able to get a married pair of parents, Frederick and Barbara Phillips, together they finally got married. My cousin Adam Lee, from Jamaica, and his brother Errol were equally happy.
I have never seen children like this. They are like the cosy saloons of a small American East Indies town. It’s hard to imagine anything but the unwashed, ruddy smiles that they share every night.
When they met Dawn, a 4-year-old girl who she danced with the entire time she was pregnant, they became fast friends. In fact, she worked as a paralegal in the bookstore. She even went on a marriage attempt with a role model she knew and worked hard to impress.
The whole family soon grew acquainted, with Dawn even dating a new dog and a son, Benjamin.
Two months later, like the couple as a whole, her dress matched Dawn’s. Just days after birth, her first child, Noah, was born, and the birth marks the birth of the couple’s child. And Dawn’s little brother, Spencer, who will now live with his mother and stepmother, Devon.
But even more so, though the connection made sense to the family as members, their youngest son, Kisha, remained almost 14 months old. Years later he decided to settle down with his maternal grandmother.
Maybe their relationship helped them chart a new path and filled their huge void. As unlikely families are in Jamaica today, they left a small legacy for all to deal with.
“Through our parents and their work, our lives, we gave them some confidence that they could be successful,” says Dawn. “But we didn’t want them to make it in a white world. We also wanted them to feel what it felt like to be well-rounded. I want them to understand they are always being looked at as individuals and not as royalty, and we need to remember that.”
“On your day off, your mom would come home and tell you everything she ever wanted to know about your day,” concludes another black and Asian family who loved their parents.
“At our wedding, our wedding story didn’t end with our couple accepting and sharing marriage vows. This was our first chance at establishing a lifelong bond and a source of solid foundation for future generations. We did not feel truly entitled to everything they had achieved. None of our family came to Jamaica at the same time. One of our brothers gained admittance to citizenship for his father after 40 years; my aunt gained special privileges for a very interesting reason, being an artist, and then she would leave home. But we started to look forward to owning an American owned business for a second chance. We knew something important was important, and one of the things that we accomplished together, is to build a new society.”
For more from Sugar Be, visit
']

['By Annette Jones
Got a call home? If it’s a pesky slip, beware of recurring calls to a call center, says an expert in identity theft protection.
Peter Huard told CNN he’s lost roughly $200 to $300 in expensive customer service calls last week. He says the problem lies in the complex notion that a call center costs only what the calls cost.
“The most nefarious kind of call centers try to order a call as many times as they can to get better quality of service, and often times add on money,” Huard said.
But experts say many call centers pay only what they think customers want, meaning that the action is only really worth what the profit margin is.
“They’re better off deciding to do things properly, and be transparent with the customer about the type of calls and how the service is really going to work,” Huard said.
But it doesn’t get a pass from the commercial service providers, he added.
He may be paying the same premium for calls that aren’t ordered, but the cost of entry can be a huge percentage.
When the wrong call comes up, a call center will ask you to fill out an affidavit confirming the call is yours, in case your bank never called, he said.
“The phone can ask if you’re a customer of a bank so it can tell you how big the loan is, but if you don’t take it, it is not even that important for a call center to ask,” he added.

["By Tribune News Service, Washington
April 5 (CNN) — How would a man from the U.S. Tea Party family convert to Christianity and beyond the longstanding rumors of “Christmas in America?”
Some days after those rumors are over, you know that some kind of conservative activist inside the tea party is in the thick of it.
In March, John Holdren, a close friend and advisor to American evangelicals and a long-time conservative commentator, convinced many to vote for Republicans.
He was suddenly irascible. He was led to a bookstore in Chicago and with several people inside – as many in his own family – he became the leader of the “rose cult.”
That street preacher?
“He will be on your street,” said Holdren. “How can you go in here and disbelieve if something that some American politician sees as yet another White Guy who ascends to one of the holiest lands in God’s creation? How can you go out here, in church, and walk around all day, because you’re conservative?”
To his family and to the rest of the Tea Party faithful, Holdren was a blasphemer.
They thought he was crazy and they wished they had seen him again, but he did not.
“So, to come in here and convert this former Christian preacher is about the apple of their eye,” said his friend Curt Smith, who interviewed Holdren for the book American Christians, a nearly-licensed Christian publication, last week.
“He looked like an egomaniac,” said Smith. “You should see him as something else. It looks like he’s travelling around the country and being calloused by the truth, and there’s nothing in his face you can find in that.”
“That’s what it looks like,” Holdren told Smith. “You get him ambushed and you have to tell him things that must be true.”
The book encourages the interpretation of the tea party as a conservative movement. It outlines a vicious, divinely inspired Catholic theology in which God thinks of America as a carnal realm whose wrath worshiped the Christian nation.
Holdren said his source is David French, a white Christian who rose to fame in 1998 as a flash figure in the Christian church, now an outspoken atheist and rabbi.
He denied knowledge of Holdren’s anti-christian views but said Holdren did not have a military training.
According to Smith, Holdren in the book began to think badly about the Tea Party when he felt a “trusting” father found evidence of opposition to Christianity in his country.
“Even though he was Christian,” Smith said, “he still thought about that as serious involvement, and always believed about the political process of the country.”
There is no doubt that “American Christianity” is something Holdren believes. As former adviser to a Republican congressman in Texas, he served in the Cabinet of the Georgia Republican Ronald Reagan and later as a member of Congress from Louisiana.
He said he is not the first person to believe that Holdren is from America.
“Like The Volker Family in the ’70s and early ’80s, I have always believed there are tyrants in American history,” Holdren told Smith. “But you go in and find a small people who are doing this or that because they’re willing to take a massive political cost.
“I’ve always known there were atheists in America, so I was surprised, no?” Smith said. “‘What?’ ‘That’s right! They’re anti-God!’ ‘Well, some people are OK with it because they’re atheist.’ ‘Well, maybe it’s something you’re dealing with as an American and that’s fair!’ ‘The Bible is the Bible.’ ‘God is with us here!'”
(CNN) — The “Pagan revival” in America, more than anything else, brings up the question of who should have the power to make America a more democratic place for all.
Holdren gets it. It’s easy to see where he’s coming from.
"]

Title: How much of your body is your own?

Lifestyle (from the vegetable icon, to the cat enthusiast, to expert) and trends/commentaries vary greatly from person to person. So, for a more detailed description of these subjects and themes, go to our Living Curiosities section.
Riding the trail of viral copycat blogs, or the sleepwalking or obsession with strangers, brand in money and junk, today is fraught with something of existential complexity. There is the obvious jaw-dropping introspection about relationships, relationship problems, siblings, parenting (even leaving them in a compromising position), and even health/growth and security scares (“is there a helicopter dad?”). Not to mention the diversity of danger and consequences. And then there is the dizzying number of opinions and prognostications about who knows better, and why, other people. So, what good advice can you give?
If all that were a plodding buck away into 2011, it would have only been a blink to have been frank. The phrase 'we must laugh about this' has landed on its head. It’s a noun, verb and icon. Not since the 18th century have even a noun for comedy, pushing the boundaries, or humor, for that matter, seemed the distinctive part of the medium, characterized not by worry or brevity but by a sad, gentler-faced puzzlement.
But to us, humor is about more than laughter. It is powerful, dangerous, sexy, cool, cool and so much more than society gives it credit for. Looking back at the past decade's laughter will take a trip back to when the food was salty and the babes were late, but well-chosen. And while some of us are sick of the antimalism once seen and treasured, others come of age and appreciate the elegant characterisms of our laughter.
Let’s be frank: I am not saying you must laugh because you are never disappointed, but because some really cool new media experiments like YouTube are genuinely scary and salacious in an attempt to cultivate a sense of humor. Now, in what could be the greatest volume of overpraise ever — back in 1964 and the start of Stephen King’s Dr. Phillips — sarcasm isn’t anything new. Life can be funny no matter what the subject. And speaking of sarcasm, how many comedians can say no when they are the whole giggling room where people watch, shake their heads, laugh and smile?
Now, the fact that I just sent this letter to someone at work is no shock. I was 40ish and thought I was fifty-something, having just bought my first product for a woman who has been on maternity leave since the twenty-first birthday (given the age, it’s almost always a case of comparing health and grooming before the pregnancy), when the delivery came, and it was on with hours of pleasure.
Over the years, I have grown to appreciate the hilariousness of it all, and the humor as good and glamorous as laugh at somebody else’s health scare. Why do men and women laugh when you’re married? Do they laugh when you get a lovely girlfriend? Do they laugh when you take care of them properly? They laugh when they make you feel old, and laugh when you cry when you’re trying not to cry, and they laugh when you’re anxious about all the different efforts you’ve made to make them feel old.
I want to offer this provocative advice to those who have looked to it for advice, or advice they wish to do to themselves, but are choosing to avoid it. Here are four reasons I think, in no particular order, that you must give your all to your life and to work at it.
"]

The platform also gives you the ability to create your own news feed or personalise the selections you’ve made on your News and weather reports, Twitter streams and Facebook Groups.
More details are likely to come, but if you’re interested, we have a brief breakdown of the presenters who will be relaunching the platform next year:

Title: Learn how the BBC is working to strengthen trust and transparency in online news
Generation:
['This story was adapted from an NPR piece that was provided to CNN by the BBC.
[This article has been changed to highlight the BBC working with the Open Society Foundation to build a better trust and transparency in online news.]
SEATTLE, Wash. (CN) — The press outlet described the BBC as “100 percent open for business” Friday, but an organization critical of the way the BBC distributes its material did not bother to note that a reporter reported it was one.
The BBC executive led an executive committee meeting aimed at improving the availability of text and video content on its website, according to a story by Jeffrey Elligh, the executive director of the BBC Trust, published in the journal All Things Digital. The BBC executive committee took up the issue of access to information online on a wide scale.
“Our job is to educate the public on the latest news and the potential dangers of the current unregulated and insecure environments,” the executive committee report read. “To do this we are aware of the growing threat to our establishment.”
Through its public relations agency, communications, the BBC seeks to place users into at least equal peer pressure, Elligh said.
“We are constantly studying the danger of Internet connectivity and the online environment that it represents,” he said. “As far as what is engaging a reader online, the key factor is that what is engaging a reader online is engaging their online lives.”
The BBC’s decision to rely on Twitter seemed to be based on, Elligh said, an analysis of a recent study by Trust magazine that found that, on average, an average citizen who used the microblogging service received 23 tweets a day and a retweet every 30 minutes. The BBC found that 125 fewer tweets per day than the audience CNN was based on.
“It is crucial for media organizations and independent sources of information to develop how they disseminate their content to a public that is more inclusive and welcoming to all,” the BBC statement said.
The company, however, did not mention the company in its comments.
